Date: Wed, 28 Sep 94 11:05:08 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Turbo 'S'

| From: Ring  <ring@uhunix.uhcc.Hawaii.Edu>
|
| Could somebody please enlighten me on all those things that distinguish the
| '88 944 Turbo _S_ from the other 944s?  Besides the price premium, of course.

Poking around in _my_ archives, I found the following.  I hope Steve has no
objection to my reproducing it.

| From: Steve Timmins  <timmins@warthog.cns.udel.edu>
| To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
| Subject: RE: 944 turbo S questions : Additions
| Date: Wednesday, June 15, 1994 7:57AM
|
| > > 1.  What differences exist between the standard 944 Turbo and the Turbo S
| > > version?
| > "S" has different features depending on year.  In 1989, the 944 Turbo S
| > (951S) was renamed to 944 Turbo, and the "old" model was dropped.  The
| > "S" has a larger turbocharger, 247 vs. 217 SAE bhp, strengthed 1st
| > gear, xmission cooler (was option on 87+ turbo), great stereo, ABS,
| > tighter chassis (bushings, etc.).  There's probably a couple other
| > little things I've forgotten, but basically, it's faster and better
| > than the base turbo.
| >
| A few other peices or details:
| 88 951S, 1989 951 had:
| 	928S4 front brakes with 1.25" thich rotors (welcome!)
| 	Strenghtened A-Arms
| 	Koni Gas Sport shocks with height adj front coilovers and
| 		narrower springs for added clearance
| 	25.5 mm rear torsioin bar (vs 24mm, ,28% stiffer)
| 	26.8mm front swat (as oppoed to 24mm)
| 	Transmission:  ALl had strengthened LSD with heavy duty R&P
| 	Forged 7.5 + 9" x 16" wheels with 225 + 245 tires
| 		(OTHERS STOCK 205+225 ON 7+8" cast aluminum or fuchs)
| 	Airbag
|
| Also note - cotrary to popular superstition, all 1988 TS models were
| not the rose-quartz with plaid.  Somewhere about july porsche realized
| Americans only wore plaid golfing and offered a wider range of colors.

More info (thanks to Stephen):
| From: Stephen I Jagernauth  <netmail!sjagernauth@attmail.com>
| To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
| Subject: FAQ - 944 Stats summary for new buyers
| Date: Tuesday, February 15, 1994 4:10PM
|
| I've been compiling data on the 944 series and maybe it belongs in 
the FAQ.
| Credit to "The Illustrated Buyer's Guide" - Dean Batchelor for the numbers.
|
| 			Porsche 944 Summary
| 			-------------------
| Models	Engine   HP	Comments
| -------------	------- -----	-------------------------------------------
| '82-'85 944  	  2.5l	143HP	Introduced in US as 1983 model
| '851/2-'88 944  2.5l	156HP	More desirable, various upgrades
| '89 944 	  2.7l	162HP	last year for basic 944 coupe
| '87-'88 924S    2.5l	156HP	944 drivetrain/suspension in 924 body
| 				lighter & faster than 944, dated body style
| '861/2-'89 944S  2.7l	188HP	16 valve head
| '86-'88 944Turbo 2.5l	217HP	'87+ more desirable due to std dual air bags.
| '88-'89 944TurboS 2.5l 247HP   Ltd prod of approx 470 in '88 and 700 in '89
|  			   	More desirable, higher cost, collectible?
| '891/2-'92 944S2 3.0l	208HP	larger 16-valve motor, torquey at lower rpm
| '89-?  944S2 Cab 3.0l 208HP	nice-looking convertible
| '93+    968 	   3.0l	236HP 	6speed, revised headlights a la 928,
| 				variable valve timing

Lorenzo had another question:

| Besides the above pure 'unobtaniumobile', what's considered the best
| bargain in a 944, as far as year and version go?  With $12,000 being my
| general budget.

I've seen a few very clean '87 and '88 944S models in the $10k-11k price
range.  This would be my choice when I go shopping to update from my '84.
(Unless I can stretch the budget to go for an S2.)

The non-S turbo gives you a few more HP, but at increased
purchase, insurance, and maintanence costs.  You also have to live with
the turbo lag.

    Eric

Date:          Thu, 29 Sep 1994 13:38:02 
From: "Trevor Wagenfuehr" <trevor@internet.wst.com>
Subject:       914 Exhaust Valves

While checking prices on replacement exhaust valves for my 2.0 liter 
914 I have discovered that I can choose between the OEM style Sodium 
cooled valves or Stainless steel valves.

Do either of these valves have any advantages over the other?
(other than price!).

It seems that dealer oriented sources sell the Sodium cooled and the 
generic parts houses sell the Stainless.

Which style should I use?... why?

Trevor Wagenfuehr
( trevor@wst.com )

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 08:02:47 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Swap Meet, Sunday Oct 2

There will be a swap meet at Forrestal Village Shopping Center, about 5
miles north of downtown Princeton (NJ) on Route 1 on Sunday October 2nd.

The swap meet will be held, rain or shine.  In the case of rain, it will be
moved to the covered parking garage.

It's a good sized meet, not as large as Ski Roundtop, about the same size as
the Zone 1 Swap Meet in May.  
- --

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 12:55:16 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject:  Re: Porsche Struts

Stan,

Don't be hasty when you generalize:
You wrote:> All Porsche struts are the three-piece type where you have the
strut body,the screw-on cap, and the insert.
In fact, on some 944 and 944 Turbos, the front strut is a one-piece (read
$$$) unit which cannot be renewed.

But I wouldn't expect you to know everything about everything!  :-)

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 14:01:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: RE: 914 bucking

>914 bucking
>    Anyone BT,DT on this?
>    I developed a problem in my powertrain (74 2.0L) at the end of
>this Saturday's autocross.  At full throttle in first gear the car
>would buck and jerk.  It felt as if I was driving over some very
>sharp bumps in the road--my engine lid popped open.  I was able to
>repeat the behavior at part-throttle (mostly floored) in first, and
>at around 3300 RPM full throttle in second.  Other gears have not
>exhibited this behavior.

Dave,

        Was this while the cluth was fully engaged? Or while you were in
the process of engaging it? Also was it an actuall "bucking" or more of a
violent "shudder". The reason why I ask is that I have a violent shudder
sometimes while engaging the clutch at higher power in lower gears. From
what I've read I believe that this could be bad engine/tranny mounts. Are
there any unpleasant noises with it?



 -Josh

Joshua Hadler
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 06:59:50 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: 356 headliner



Jordan Holt wrote: "I am replacing the headliner in my 1960 356 B Coupe. The
original (??) color is a light grey.  CBE interiors in Eatonton, Georgia has
an "OEM White" that doesn't match, but no grey."

Jordan, are you certain the headliner is original? If so, very unusual. I
can't remember ever seeing anything but white. Refer to Brett Johnson's
book, The 356 Porsche, on page 122: "White perforated vinyl headliners,
according to the factory books, arrived with the 356A model change."
Although I know, that in those days, the factory would "build-to-suit," I
didn't know that included the headliners. 

My advice: take the white headliner - even if you can get light grey, no one
will believe it is original unless, of course, you have documentation (for
example, my sales receipt lists an extra charge of $47.60 for "white" white
paint not included in the color list).

Larry Wilson

Subject: Balance Shaft Adjustments.



Pfiles..

 I have decided to keep the 924S and jazz it up a bit, join the PCA,SCCA and 
maybe get into this racing thing a bit...but  there are a few must do 
firsts..

First, I need to get rid of these horrid vibrations..the last guy I took the

were out of time..
The motor mount I can handle, but should I replace it with stock fluidfilled 
mounts or use solid mounts..???
As for the balance shafts..how hard of a procedure is this..I suspect that I 
will also want to replace the timing belt will I'm in there but how do I get 
the shafts back in time??? Do I need to drop the radiator..???

<<JPW>>
1987 924S Guards Red.

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 11:13:12 EST
From: "Gregory Nyce" <gnyce@nas.edu>
Subject: 914: popped outa' gear, no power


  hey all,

  New (3 weeks now) 914 ('75, 2.0L) owner has a brief but electrifying
  scare last night... car pops out of gear (2nd), just cruising along on a
  busy street.  When put back into 2nd, nothing... ditto for 1st, 3rd,
  reverse, anything!.  First
  thought..."O-my-God-I-dropped-the-transmission!!!?R#@)"  Have pretty much
  nixed that.  Seems to still be shifting, just no power to drivetrain.  Am
  thinking it may be the cv, driver side wheel.  Possible?  Anyone with
  experience in this?  Common?  Not a major problem?  The timing sucks, I'm
  going out of town on Sunday, and have no time to try anything on my own
  (gotta learn sometime), so car is currently at the shop (one recommended
  by another P-philer).  IF this is it, what can I expect $$?

  Thanks all... and am glad to finally be able to join as a owner/driver,
  and not just a covetous and lusful pedestrian.  -Greg

  GNYCE@NAS.EDU
  "... ok, but now what?"

Date: Thu, Sep 29, 1994 10:23 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Whats the sccop on heater controls [911]

In message <9409282123.AA17977@crab.cig.mot.com> Richard Hocking writes:
> I look in the manual for my '87 911 and it talks about the heater 
> controls being a dial marked 0 to 9.  The dial on my car is marked
> 0 to 3 and the 3 has the little defrost symbol next to it.
> 
> Does anyone know what the scoop is with this ?
> 
> Should it be 0 to 9 and the previous owner changed out the heater
> controls ?
> 
> Also, while I'm asking questions is 0-3 = cold-hot.  Is 3 a special 
> setting since it has the little symbol.  Anyone with a knowledge
> of the 0-3 controls.  If you could send a description I would be 
> grateful.

Hi Rick,

I have the same situation with my '86 cab and the owners manual.  When 
I asked the dealer what the story was, I was advised that the manual
refers to the (Optional) automatic heat control system, and I "don't 
have that option".  I thought it sounded fishy, but there it is...


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 10:51:26 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Bursch Mufflers

When I bought my '74 914 2.0 it had what I thought was a Bursch muffler. 
It was quite loud, but sounded great, and the resonances, if there were
any, weren't noticeable.  

Recently I rebuilt the top end and while doing so discovered that this
muffler was not a Bursch, and it had a hole in it.  So I replaced it with a
Bursch from GPR. While it's by no means quiet (esp. at idle), it feels like
a great match for my motor (stock except perhaps for the cam - unknown
history).  I love the way it sounds (it's quite raspy). At highway cruise
with the top on and windows up the car is actually pretty quiet.  If you
like to hear your motor, and you enjoy moving up and down the rev range (my
motor is quite happy to pull beyond the redline, but there isn't much power
up there) you may like the Bursch, but _it's not quiet_.

The "high quality black paint" on the header/collector part of the Bursch
burned off completely within 50 miles.  The muffler is still black,
however. Also, with 195/50's the rear clearance is a bit low.  It fits
perfectly.

I wish the 914 had its exhaust on the _passenger side_ so the driver could
hear it but at reduced volume.

Hope this helps,

Andrew


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 13:35:48 EDT
From: "Bill Kan" <bkan@banmail.ibk.ml.com>
Subject: need help resolving 951 characteristics

I'm just joining the P-file world and would like to confirm some things that I 
have noticed about my '88 951.

Is the stock clutch on a 951 high in comparison to other Porsches?

My 951 seems to be very very sensitive to road conditions.  The quality of 
road is transmitted to me via the degree of vibration in the steering wheel.  
The wheel is quiet if the road is smooth but will become noisy at the slight 
indication of the road being not flat.  I bring this up because my 951 seems 
much more sensitive than a friends 88 911 with 17" SP8000s.  Two shops I spoke 
with essentially told me that was part of my introduction to a Porsche-land 
and 944s.  

Thanks.

Bill

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 10:32:49 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: The Porsche Blues


	Sorry to re-open a debate which raged a while ago, but I'm trying
to ascertain exactly what colour *my* 911 is. When I bought it, the
salesman described it as "Baltic Blue", but the paint sticker says "378 9
7 Taubenblau Metallic", as does the touch-up paint which I received with
it.

	However, I'm told that the literal translation of taubenblau is
"Dove Blue", a colour I've never come across before.

	Can any Porschephiles shed further enlightenment?

	Also, do Porsche have more Blues than any other colour? So far I've
come across:

		Baltic Blue
		Venetian Blue
		Slate Blue
		Diamond Blue
		Marine Blue
		Lagoon Blue
		Prussian Blue
		Midnight Blue
		Iris Blue
		Riviera Blue

Philip Katz                                        Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 
1989 Carrera Sport Coupe (Taubenblau Metallic)
No cats

P.S.  Those people writing Porsche poems should look out for a copy of _If
Wishes Were Porsches - Nursery Rhymes for Modern Times_ by Tom Derbyshire
and Stefan Underhill. Published by Cassell in 1986 with ISBN
0-304-32187-7. (Though when I was looking up the ISBN number, I noticed
that it was originally published in the US as _If Wishes Were Saabs_!!)

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 12:42:45 +0100 (MET)
From: Ludo.VanHelleputte@hep.iihe.ac.be (Ludo Van Helleputte)
Subject: ** To TED or not to TED **

> Date: Mon, 26 Sep 94 18:07:17 PDT
> From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
> Subject: Ted
>
> Either some porschephile is framing Ted or Ted's getting back some
> of his own medicine, but I thought you'd be interested in hearing his
> side of the story.
>
> Dan Bezzant
> '68 912
>
>>Subject: Re: Your problems with Ted Matsumura on rahul.net
>>In-Reply-To: Message from bezzant (Dan Bezzant)
>>   of Thu, 22 Sep 94 10:48:53 -0800

>>forged messages in his name.  I don't really know what
>>is going on, but Ted reported that he was being

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 10:53:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: Whats the sccop on heater controls [911]

Richard Hocking wrote:
> I look in the manual for my '87 911 and it talks about the heater 
> controls being a dial marked 0 to 9.  The dial on my car is marked
> 0 to 3 and the 3 has the little defrost symbol next to it.

The dial marked 0 to 9 would be for an automatic heater control - you
set that dial and it automatically moves the heater lever up and down.
The one that has 0 to 3 is a heater fan speed control, and you move
the heater lever(s) up and down manually.  I've owned cars with both,
and I don't really have a preference (except that my current one, which
does not have the automatic heater control, has two heater levers, one
for the driver and one for the passenger, which I do like better).

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@handmadesw.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 07:14:21 -0700
From: jgregory@porsche.trevose.sgi.com
Subject: Re: Brakes

On Sep 28,  4:58pm, Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School wrote:
> Subject: Brakes
>
> I've run a couple autocross events and am hoping to do at least one
> driver's ed event before winter hits.  My question is, how do you
> determine when to change your brake pads?  Do I need to pull the wheels
> and check or can I rely on the sensor?  These are "regular" pads on the
> car now (shop installed for street use).  As always, your wise counsel is
> apprecated!
>
> Jerry Mac
> 84 911 Targa (Cognac Brown)
> 88 blond Daddy's girl
> 92 blond Porschephile and car freak
> 88 Canine beast of unknown origins
>-- End of excerpt from Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School

*LOOK* at the pads! It's really easy to pull them out. I would not recommend
trying to do a driver's school with anything less than 50% pad. Most schools
won't pass a car (Tech inspection) with <50% pad. All the work is in getting
the wheels on & off. Porsche has just about the easiest setup for changing
pads.

 -jim gregory
 87 944T

Date: Wed, 28 Sep 1994 18:51:14 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: Re: wasserpumper oil vs.water


Hi, Lou

You have a very valid complaint.  The O-rings should
last longer than that.  Keep us posted. 

My case turned out to be worse than we had thought when
I took it in last Fri.  Seems that the "cooler" (or what-
ever you call that finned box that the oil goes through to
get cooled) itself had a hole in it. Corrosion caused it:
about the size of a No.2 pencil lead. And with 90-100 lbs. 
pressure behind it, it wasted oil into the water faster than
my ex- wasted my checking account.  

The bottom line was (and its a good thing I love this car) the
new cooler was $310, and the total came to $750!  With all the
flushings they did of the oil and water cavities, the interior
of my engine is *got* to be in concours condition.

Herb

p.s. - will extra Prozac help my depressed bank account?

Subject: Re: 85.5 944 Sunroof Woes (fwd)

Chris,

My car, which is a 85/2 944, only have one relay. I have not had a chance to
check ( Living in Chicago, the day-light hours are getting shorter
and shorter by the day ), but this weekend, I will take a look at Hayes as
well as check out the Part Number off my relay.

For your info, my sunroof functions perfectly except for the fact that
I can not remove it. Once I took the car to the dealer, where the mechanic
(for testing purposes) swapped the relay out of another 944 and the roof
came right off. So I found the problem but have not replaced it since the
quoted price was about $200 for the relay. If you are going to buy one 
check out the EuroSelect Catalog.

Husain.

------------------------------

Date: 29 Sep 1994 19:18:56 GMT
From: Kim_Knapp@onenet-bbs.org (Kim Knapp)
Subject: Thru Europe in 993

Bruce (and others who asked about the trip to pick up our new 993 in Europe),

	Got back last night (after a 17 hr trip back, including 2 hour drive from
Denver to our home in Beaver Creek). Had a great trip driving through
Burgundy. Started off driving from Stuttgart on the Autobahn to the
Baden-Baden exit where we got off and had lunch at B-B. Don't get too
excited, the Autobahn was too crowded to get any high speed driving in (and
the car was too new, having only 23 miles when we started). It took a little
while getting used to having to read the KM/Hr markings on our speedometer
because they were small since it was a US-spec car! But I did NOT go 120 MPH
in any 120 KPH zones :-). After lunch in B-B we drove down through the
Schwarzewald (black forest). Whenever we stopped we attracted a small crowd
of German tourists who couldn't resist the 993 (it looks great in red). The
driving on the forest roads was great, as the rear suspension of the 993
really allows spirited driving without the notorious trailing throttle
oversteer. My C2 was good, but I never felt comfortable pushing it to the
limits like I could the 993. We headed west out of the Black Forest to
Strasburg and drove into town to do a little sightseeing. Again, the car got
many thumbs up and whistles from Europeans as we drove by. The 911 seems to
be more rare in France then in the US. Driving in a big city in Europe can be
very intimidating, but I had some experience from before so I tried not to
get too sweaty-palmed while trying to get around and trying to remember what
the strange signs meant :-). After Strasburg it was a few hours of driving to
Chateau D'Isenbourg, south of Colmar. Quite a bit of driving for the first
day. D'Isenbourg was nice and we had a nice dinner there.
	The second day we headed down to Mulhous to see the Schlumpf museum and
their wonderful display of cars (including an old Lotus 7 that looks like my
Caterham). From there we headed on back roads over the hills that are on the
west side of the Rhein and into the northern Burgundy farmlands. This was
probably the most enjoyable traveling, once I got onto the lesser traveled
"D" roads. With the detailed Michelin guides, we were able to explore many
small roads and villages on our way to our next chateau, Chateau de Vault de
Lugny, near Avallon. This was our second favorite place to stay on the trip.
Absolutely beautiful old chateau with a 13th century fortress tower,
wonderful rooms and good food, not to mention the great country setting with
geese, ducks, hens, roosters, and peacocks roaming on the grounds. We spent
two nights there, exploring the local country-side and the old medieval
village of Vezelay. On our last day we had lunch at L'Esperance and headed
towards Beaune, again on the back roads.
	In Beaune, we stayed at Hostellerie de Levernois, just east of town. Do not
stay there. There are other chateaux in the area which are better. The
Hostellerie looks like it was built in the fifties for tourists and the room
we were in had serious mold problems from a water leak. The food there was
good, but it seemed to us (and to our German friends who came down from
Wiesbaden to join part of our trip in their white 993) that all the tourists
were put in one room and all the local French customers were put in a
seperate room. Sort of tacky. We were in Beaune for two nights and had a
wonderful meal at the Relais & Chateau in Lamelois, about 20 KM south of
Beaune, on the other night. Also, we enjoyed exploring Beaune and Dijon.
	Next we headed towards Lyon with our German friends in our two 993's. This
time we took the French autobahn (130 KPH speed limit) and trucked along at
about 160 KPH (my friend is a little crazy when it comes to driving). These
were the nicest autobahns we were to find on our trip, since the German
autobahns seem to be taken over by truck traffic these days, especially in
southwest Germany. We drove through Lyon and had lunch at a nice restaurant
(and chateau) outside of town about 30 km, on the Rhone, called Beau
Rivierge. From there we went back north to Chateau Bagnols which is about 40
km northwest of Lyon. This chateau was the highlight of the trip. It is a
restored castle from the 12 century and was the most luxurious and beautiful
place we have ever stayed. It was so nicely restored that there were tourists
stopping by wanting to see the castle all day every day. We stayed there two
nights and ate at Paul Bocuse's famous restaurant one of those nights. Since
we thought we may be drinking a lot of wine at Bocuse, we had a driver take
us there. Unfortunately, he got lost and finally we insisted that he hire a
cab to lead us to the restaurant (we passed the same bridge on the Rhone 4
times!). Although we arrived at Paul Bocuse 40 minutes late and were very
tense from the ride, the waiter calmed us down and was very nice to us. Of
course, we had a great meal. The dinner at Bagnols was also very nice.
	Our German friends headed back home and we went to Chamonix. It rained most
of the time there so we didn't get to hike, which was very dissappointing. It
was clear enough to enjoy the views, though. Again, we had a great meal where
we stayed (Auberge du Bois Prin).
	From Chamonix we drove back to Stuttgart to return the car. Once again, the
German autobahns were crowded, continually under construction and, all in
all, not conducive to high speed driving, although I did get a chance to
blast up to 150 MPH once. Since I had driven my friends 930 at 160 MPH before
It was not a big deal, but it would have been nice to see what the top
indicated speed would be with the 993.
	When we returned to Stuttgart, we had over 1500 miles on the car and I was
pretty exhausted from all the driving. The next time (some day) we will go
through Switzerland and try to drive less distances each day. The most
enjoyable driving was on the French back roads (the smaller the better) and
the French autobahns followed by the drive through the Black Forest. The
French national roads were less enjoyable, due to traffic, and the German
autobahns were, generally, a pain. BTW, we rented a car and drove to our
friends' home in Wiesbaden and the autobahns near Wiesbaden were much better,
but the rental car was slow :-(.
	Well, hope I didn't bore you too much.
					Kim
- -------
Sent from the OneNet Boulder BBS  (303) 444-7569  
Graphical interface available for Macintosh & MS Windows users.

OneNet member Network Regional Hub.  
Providing access to Information, Tools & Community

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 09:05 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 test pipe

>This brings up an interesting question.  I've never see test pipes
>advertised for 951s as performance enhancements.  Have I just 
>missed something, or do these not help turbo charged cars performance?

They do help a little bit, but not much.  The reason you don't see them
advertised is that the boys and girls in Washington can read too, and
they take a real dim view of modifying emissions control equipment.  You
see such 911 stuff advertised (eg, SSI heat exchangers) because it is
ostensibly sold only to pre-cat cars.  A lot of people do put the stuff
on later cars.  This will become increasingly problematic in the next
fews years as inspectors keep getting (pressured to be) tougher on
illegal mods.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 1994 22:05:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: WAHRHAFT@sonoma.edu
Subject: 914 "pulses"

I hope someone can help me with a problem that has
avoided every attempt at solution.
    I have a 1976 914 2 liter with about 18,000 on a carefully
rebuilt motor. I have had the same problem withboth the old
motor and with this rebuilt one.
     The problem is a slight bucking or pulsating or hesitation
in the engine. It is not a regular rhythm but is repetative.
It NEVER happens when the accellerator is more than half depressed.
It only happens when I have a light foot on the gas.
It tends to happen when accellerating gently in 3 and/or 4th
gears.  It is more pronounced when the motor is cold and in
the first couple of miles of the morning the motor may also
kind of burp a couple of times.  It also happens at constant
speeds when I have a light foot on the gas.  On level ground
at about 50-55 mph in 5th gear, for instance, or when pulling
a hill in 4th.  
     We have checked the temp. and pressure sensors, the relays, 
the fuel pressure setting, installed a new throttle switch, 
tried putting another computer on it. Also the alternator and 
distributor are new.
    I'd appreciate any hints aabout what this might be.

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 06:29:17 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: wasserpumper oil vs.water

Lou,
Please be advised that if water gets into the oil it is prudent to replace
the rod bearings. Apparently they are very vulnerable to poor lubrication and
using water for a lubricant certainly qualifies.
When ever Porsche fixes the water - oil mixing chamber (oil cooler) they
replace the rod bearings. Often they don't even tell you they do this, as
happened to me. I only found out the bearings were replaced when I talked to
the mechanic. There was no information on the repair invoice.
Cute Huh?
Regards
Jerry


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 1994 01:11:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Exhaust Valves

> While checking prices on replacement exhaust valves for my 2.0 liter 
> 914 I have discovered that I can choose between the OEM style Sodium 
> cooled valves or Stainless steel valves.
> 
> Do either of these valves have any advantages over the other?
> (other than price!).

Use the sodium filled exhaust valves *ONLY* if the original application
was sodium filled. The 2.0 914 is such a case. There are others -- 356SC
and I think Super 90, some 911s, etc.

The sodium filled valves have a very different heat transfer property
than the solid valves do. This is very important for correct operation
of the engine and not burning the valves in very short order.

Let's put it like this: you have to do *EXTRA* stuff to make a sodium
filled valve. Non filled valves have been around for a loooong time and
as you observed, are cheaper. Now, given that, would the factory have
*REALLY* gone to the extra effort and expense if it weren't justified?

Only use stainless valves for racing engines where they are on a scheduled
disassembly basis of no more than 20 hours operation. They start burning
after that.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 1994 00:33:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Euro911 heater / RS America

> HEATER Question:
> In my 1981 Euro 911SC Targa, my heater control lever, located between the 
> front seats, just to the right of the parking brake lever, does not work
> anymore.  It used to go up or down automagically, in response to turning
> the heat control dial, from 0 to 9 or DEF.  This dial is also located
> between the seats, on top of the housing of said heater levers.  When I
> turn the dial, the lever stays in the down position, and pulling it
> upwards manually does not help, it just goes back down.  What is wrong
> with this european heater system (I think the US system is different)?

The little ball and socket gizmo inside the control unit has come loose.
This is *VERY* common as there's a cheezy plastic socket that wears
out. The replacement part is like $1.25 at the dealer, but you have
to do a moderate amount of surgery to the car to install it. I wrote this
up at some point in the past, and frankly don't have time to go dig
it out of the archives for a while yet. The proceedure is in the factory
service manual, and is *NOT* very involved, other than you *MUST*
remove the passenger side front seat to do the work.

> I do not have a manual on the car interior controls.  How do the dash
> levers control the temperature, in conjunction with the center console?

Get a owners manual, about $20 most places. Very instructive. The dash
levers handle air distribution and fresh air venting, the floor control
handles heat.

> What does the lever on the top left do (the one next to the fan speed
> control lever) ?  The levers on the dash are sort of stiff to move.  Is
> this normal?  

The stiffness is normal if something is wrong, which is actually pretty
normal... It's worth it to spend some time lubing the cables from time
to time...

> Lastly, you should know that the heater blower fan has been
> removed from the engine compartment for more HP.  It used to be bolted 
> into the rear, left hand corner of the engine compartment.  Though this
> has not been there since I've had the car, the heat still worked somewhat.
> Now that the center lever does not raise, I get no heat at all.  Oh yeah-

That's like saying you unbolted the rear view mirror to make more HP.
Put the fan BACK ON THE CAR. It's there for more than just the heater,
it's part of the engine cooling system. Do it now.  If it wasn't needed,
it wouldn't be there.

> Does that little stubby rubber thermostat up by the rear view mirror really
> work as a climate control?  

Yes.

Stan
> RS America Question:
> I was over at Dicks Auto Body in Somerville, MA yesterday picking
> up my 911 after an alignment, and noticed one of the guys was washing
> a Silver colored 911 outside.  As I drove away, I noticed on the rear 
> trunk/engine lid, under the whale tail, had an "RS America" script on it
> instead of Carrera2/4.
> 
> What is different about an RS America from a Carrera 2 or 4.  It looked
> brand new, or was at least an 90 (?) or newer, since it had the one
> piece, molded bumpers, vs. the older 911's with the bellows.  Was this
> a special edition 911?  It was a normal 911 body, not the turbo widebody.
> Just wondering.  What engine is in this car?  What makes it different?
> 
> One last curiosity:  Does anyone know how much my car, a 1981 European
> model 911SC Targa with the beefed up sport suspension costed brand new,
> back in 81?  A round dollar amount would be fine ($50K?), I am very curious.
> I frequently wonder how much this was new, and what a comparably priced 
> car is nowadays.  (ie:Is it the equivalent of buy a $70K 993 today?)
> 
> -Barry Chapin
> 1981 Euro 911 SC Targa (now a widebody)
> 1985 $100 Junker Chevette (November-March)
> Patent Law Student	Suffolk University, Boston, MA
> Engineer		Draper Laboratory, Cambridge, MA

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 00:19 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: The Porsche Blues

Philip,

Both your English and German names are correct.  The colour was first
used, if memory serves, in '89.  I first saw it on a 928S4 in an
advertisement, and later on a friend's 944S2.  It's one of my favourites.
I've always taken the literal translation to be Pigeon Blue, though.

Other recent blues include Copenhagen Blue and Ocean Blue (metallic).
The latter is called Nautik in German and is my car's colour: dark
blue with rose highlights.

Kevin




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 22:37 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Balance Shaft Adjustments.

You want to replace the motor mount(s) with the latest factory parts.
I don't know anyone who runs any other kind of mount in a street car.

The balance shaft retime is just a matter of aligning them properly
with respect to TDC.  Why they're off position is a good question.  If
you just bought the car, and you don't know when the balance and timing
belts were last replaced, you really ought to have them replaced like
yesterday.  The parts are cheap on an eight-valve car.  Also check
all the other components in the belt train.

Kevin Gross*

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 8:14:00 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: '73 911T for sale

At a shop that was making a boat trailer for me the woman has a
'73 911T Targa.  While we talked about Porsches she mentioned that
she would be interested in selling it.  The car appears to be in fair
to good conditon-a good clean-up might make all the difference in
the world.  It's kind of a burgandy with black interior.  Fuchs,
body looked good at a glance.  Motor was rebuilt several years ago
but only has like 5K on it.  Some special pistons/cylinders 
(Aireal???), E cams, heads and mechanical injectors modified
for better flow.  Revs easily past 7K.  I may have much of this
detail wrong, so call her and ask for details.  I was thinking
of buying it and switching motors with my car!

Anyway, price is $5K which seems fair to me.  She has no internet
access and I don't have any involvement in this so call her
directly.  I could get a little more info or take a better look
at the car if it would help anyone out.  

Car is located in San Jose CA.  Tell her the guy with the
MasterCraft told you about it.

Car is at Sport Boats in San Jose daily at (408) 292-6503.


Mark

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 09:41:14 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 914 Engine swaps??

Bryan, no I haven't done a 914 engine swap, but I have put a 911 engine in a
Vanagon.  I have to think that the oil tank issue with the 911 engine has to
be a lot cheaper/easier to solve than the radiator issue with any humid engine.
You weren't pricing a new original 914-6 oil tank were you?  When two different
vendors in the back of every Porsche mag want to sell you reasonably priced
aftermarket parts?  

Yes, the 911 engine will be more expensive than the Mazda, but I'll bet a com-
petent 914-6 conversion will be worth more at sale than a competent 914-"what
is THAT?" conversion.

Either way, you picked a great car to start with.  If I didn't live in rust
hell, I'd probably have a 914.  Let us know what you decide.

B.

William R. Kennedy
77 911S Targa  ice green metallic
81 VW Vanagon  elfenbein  71 911T powered
Japanese cars that HAVE to be running every Monday morning unlike the above


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 09:02 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: wasserpumper oil vs.water

Jerry,

In fact Porsche decided that the bearings need to be inspected, not
necessarily replaced.  They did not always call for this inspection.
I had my heat exchanger resealed before they inspected bottom ends, and
never had a problem with the bearings.  The tech bulletin is book D,
group 1, number 8707, dated 6 May 87.

We did my bottom end over last winter.  Despite getting water
in there years ago, despite six not-so-gentle years of track
events and year-round driving, and despite the Cult of the Number
Two Conn Rod Bearing circle of fear, they were all absolutely
perfect.  (We replaced them anyways.)

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 1994 13:49:49 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Lower noise-ratio->356list

Hiall,

First I'm glad we have tta.com back pumping bytes again.

Second I would like to have your viewpoints in the following matter; 

Are there any guys/gals out there that would have enjoyed a separate list 
for the vintage porsche's??
(Vintage is not a clear defined word, but anything pre '66 might be 
suitable. ;-)

The porschephiles list is the *best* porsche list for general purposes, but 
if you're mostly into the old 4cyl 4bangers the 'noise-ratio' gets abowe 95% .

There are some *terrific* 356 experts out there, just a couple of keystrokes 
away. 

I'd expect such a list to be very little (< 50 people?), all with main 
interests in the vinatge cars. 

I'd be very happy if you sent me your viewpoints directly to tvo@hrp.no and 
did not bother the list with this issue. 

Goal;  small group with *untraditionally low noise-ratio*. 

I'm talking *new* site here, and it is *not* another 'split-the-list' 
proposal...

Cheers,
Trond.

Date:          Fri, 30 Sep 1994 08:48:42 
From: "Trevor Wagenfuehr" <trevor@internet.wst.com>
Subject:       Re: 914 "pulses"

>      The problem is a slight bucking or pulsating or hesitation
> in the engine. It is not a regular rhythm but is repetative.
> It NEVER happens when the accellerator is more than half depressed.
> It only happens when I have a light foot on the gas.

I suggest checking the output volumn of the fuel pump.
I just recently solved a similiar problem on my '74 2.0 that drove
me nuts for about 3 months. It turned out that even though my fuel
pump was pumping enough volume to keep the pressure up at idle,
it wasn't enough to keep the pressure up under load at a constant 
throttle position.  My guess is that the enrichment curcuit of the 
throttle switch helps to mask the problem by opening the injectors 
for a slightly longer period of time when the throttle is opened 
wider - then when the manifold pressure equalizes again, the injector 
durations are shortened and then aren't injecting enough fuel again.
This causes the moter to run LEAN and is a very bad thing if not 
corrected quickly. ( My reward for not checking the fuel pump sooner 
is a burned valve )

hope this helps!

Trevor Wagenfuehr
(trevor@wst.com)
'74 914 2.0

Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 22:37 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Motronic - idle problem

Tom,

>1. Temp sensor seems to work fine - if it wasn't , wouldn't I see an
>improper temp reading in the dash gauge ? Right ?

Wrong.  Separate circuit, separate sender.  The engine temp sender
really goes wrong very rarely, though.

>2. Idle stablizer seems to work fine. I tested the unit it'self and it
>open/closes, and when discounted in a runing car, idle drops significantly.

The fact that it makes a difference unplugged is a pretty good sign
that it's doing something.  I assume you cleaned it out with carb
cleaner or whatever.

>I tried via the Bosch book to test Dwell difference, I only get a reading
>of 10 degress instead of 30. Dwell meter was connected neg to ground, Pos.
>to the negative terminal of the ignition coil ( This is right ?)

Dunno, outside my knowledge.

>3. all hoses, rubbers show no signs of leaks
>
>4. One hose from the aux. air valve shows a little crack - but nothing
>major.

Define major!  I'd recommend trying the pressurization procedure
described in the workshop manual.  You cut the end off an old fuel
filter, install a tire valve where the fitting used to be, clamp
it on the induction hose instead of the air flow meter, and pump it
up to about 0.5 bar.  I did this to my car a few weeks ago, and it
really works well.  You can hear any leaks, esp. if you have an
electronic stethoscope, or just put a length of hose to your ear.

Check esp. the lower injector o-rings and the intake manifold gasket.
You can do this with the engine running by dribbling water on them.
If they leak, they will visibly and audibly inhale the water.  If
not, it just pools by the gasket/ring.

>6. Haynes says idle adjustment can be performed via control screw on the
>throlle housing - yet on my 86 - this is a small brass rod with a plastic
>cap and nut. Is this really an adjustment ?

Sorry, dunno, by 16-valver doesn't have an idle adjustment.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 11:30:10 EDT
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: 914: popped outa' gear, no power

Most likely sheared CV joint bolts.  You should be able to see a driveshaft
hanging down underneath the car.  Solution: have the bolts torqued to spec next
time (ask me how I know).  If you're lucky the transmission flange and the CV
joint survived - you'll just need 4 new bolts.  Make sure the 2 roll pins are
also present in the CV joint.

Could also be a sheared pin in the shift linkage inside the transmission.  You
can tell if this is the case from the feel of the stick - it's like
there's no H-pattern there.  You can get to this pin via a small access plate
on the bottom rear of the transmission (held on by 4 10mm nuts).

Could also be a dropped grub screw at the shift coupler just outside the
firewall.  If you're lucky you still have the rubber boot that goes over the
coupler and the screw is in there.  I used loctite on that one.  Same lack
of H-pattern, but the stick can be moved outside the normal range of motion.

Those are the three modes of failure I've experienced...

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe
  former '71 914 Canary Yellow

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 09:01:28 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; replacing steering rack, Blown 944 head

>Subject: Need a 951 Steering Rack

>Does anyone have a spare (willing to sell cheap) steering rack
>for a 86 951, one that doesn't leak!   Mines got the drips
>REAL bad.  Anyone changed one in their garage?  Any pointers?
>What's a good price on a rebuilt one.  My dealership wants
>$1100 for a rebuilt one.
>JJ

  1.  I replaced one in a 928, it went much better than I'd feared (most
  everything was easy to get to). I got mine on sale, rebuilt thru
  Zim's for about $350.
    The one trick for installation is that Porsche (well, most cars)
  use these giant (like 36mm) "thin" nuts on the tie rod ends, a normal 
  wrench is too wide. To get to it, I bought a cheap 36mm open end wrench,
  and took a grinder to it to narrow it enough to fit between the 
  obstructions.
    Of course you'll need to have your front end re-aligned afterwards,
  but you can get close enough to get it to a shop. Make sure to replace
  the dust boots (if they don't come with the rack) or you'll waste your
  inner tie rods, I guarantee.

   2. On another subject (all you water coolers) does the 16-valve
      928 use the same valves as an '87 944 ?? I've got a pair of
      good spare heads for a 928 (market for them is Zilch) and a 
      friend who lost the timing belt on their 944. Does anybody know
      if;
         - They are the same valves ?
         - They are the same length and stem diameter ?
         - If the 928 valve is bigger, has anybody heard of cutting
           bigger valve pockets and installing 928 valves in the 944 head ?
         - Or what/where is the right price on 944 valves ?

       Thanks !  Lee A.


------------------------------

Howdy Porschephiles,

I've gotten a disturbing number of messages to the list announcing the
departure of sundry folks, citing the noise level.  Gosh, I don't know
quite how to put this so as to avoid hurting any tender feelings, but now
that you've acquired a Porsche, and a goodly number of you are all
Varminted-up as well, would you consider getting a grip?

The worst is over (well ok, once you've endured this); what could be worse?
(yeah, Yeah.  Me too, I cheered up & things got worse...)

But it occurs that perhaps it wasn't the reasons stated that percipitated
these departures.  Perhaps a distaste for the general level of "Piling-on"
has made folks too uncomfortable.  We Americans like to think that we have
a higher than average sense of fair-play.  I think we do.  And "Piling-on"
isn't "fair-play."

I agree with the gentleman from Belgium who noted that Ted is responsible
for the security of his account.  Also, Ted deserved to get his butt kicked
for his "Dr. Porsche" mailing, and Stan properly kicked his butt for that.
If he's also guilty of the mail-bombing he's accused of, and denies; he's
in for a lot worse than that.  But the Constitution I swore an oath to
defend, many years ago, says that folks accused of a crime should be
presumed innocent until their guilt is established, and that still remains
to be established.  I'm not defending Ted, I'm keeping an open mind.

So the question is, "What time is it, Uncle Bart?"  I'm glad you asked
Kiddo.  It's *time* to LIGHTEN-UP a bit.  Have a great week-end, everyone.
Love and Kisses (er, ummm, better make that last bit "Porsches")!

Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 07:43:34 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Balance Shaft Adjustments

Jim,

1) Motor mounts should be replaced with the fluid filled factory mounts, but
of the Turbo type.  Generally available new from the usual aftermarket
places for about $135-150 each.  My recommendation is to do both sides at
the same time, although usually, the side nearest the exhaust manifold is
the culpritl.  You can do it yourself, with appropriate jackstands, and a
couple of good floor jacks.

The symptom that indicates bad motor mounts is a vibration in the steering
wheel at idle, which disappears at rpm's above 1600 or so.

2) Balance shaft timing is another story.  The symptom for balance shaft
timing being incorrect is a buzzing vibration (not unlike a vibrator) in the
shift knob.  It does not go away with higher rpm.

If the relationship between the balance shaft pulleys and the balance shafts
has not been disturbed (has the water pump been replaced? have the balance
shaft seals been replaced?) by some mechanic/hack, then timing the balance
shafts is not too difficult.   Of course, you will need appropriate timing
diagrams (Jim Pasha's article in Excellence (June 94 I think) had an
excellent diagram of timing for the balance shafts) and you will also need
the infamous cam belt tension gauge P9201 - (spend the money...If you're
going racing, you're going to have to get used to it!).

Of course, fix one problem at a time.  My suggestion is to check the balance
shaft timing first by removing the upper belt cover, rotating (by hand) the
motor to TDC on Cylinder #1, verifying TDC by noting the timing mark on the
camshaft pulley through the inspection hole, then checking the balance shaft
timing on the pulleys (the lower balance shaft timing can be inspected with
the lower belt cover in place, through the inspection hole).

Good luck

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944


p.s. I do have used 944 Turbo Motor Mounts for sale - old style, $25 each.

- --
- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net
MHVNet - The Mid-Hudson Valley's Internet Connection
Public Unix Access System with SLIP/CSLIP/PPP, Shell, UUCP and BBS
Data: (914) 473-0191, Fax: (914) 229-0197, Voice: (914) 229-9853

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 1994 09:43:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Cherie Woodward <cherie@corp.cirrus.com>
Subject: One man's 356 story (short)



	My SO (Ben) and I were driving to SF for a peek at the X'Jing
	exhibit at DeYoung. We'd stopped at Fra.Serra rest area for a
	walk in their garden and a drink. When we were pulling out, a
	'63 356 - charcoal grey - pulled in.

	We've both always loved the look and I made Ben park next to
	it to get a better look and maybe pick the owners brain. He
	was a grizzled dude, very amicable.

	He told us that he was looking for a new car, in '63, and
	fell in love with this model. The salesman ensured him that
	this car would last him the rest of his life. He insisted
	that because he never had high maintenance cost, and the dream-
	boat had never given him problems, he retired at 56. He also
	stated that he did an upper/lower rebuild himself, without a
	manual and that the motor has over 300K, still original.

	He asked us a few questions about the '70 911 we were driving.
	He knows that car will be his only ride 'til he can't drive no
	mo.

	I felt the day was charmed....

	Salutations!

	cherie

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 08:29:51 PDT
From: john@pelican.hac.com (John Drab)
Subject: Re: 914 Exhaust Valves

> 
> While checking prices on replacement exhaust valves for my 2.0 liter 
> 914 I have discovered that I can choose between the OEM style Sodium 
> cooled valves or Stainless steel valves.
> 
> Do either of these valves have any advantages over the other?
> (other than price!).
> 
> It seems that dealer oriented sources sell the Sodium cooled and the 
> generic parts houses sell the Stainless.
> 
> Which style should I use?... why?
> 
> Trevor Wagenfuehr
> ( trevor@wst.com )
> 

	The sodium in the sodium-filled exhaust valves is there to help
thermal conduction from the valve face to the valve stem so that the heat
can be dissipated into the head via the valve guide. Stainless steel, on the
other hand, is a *very* poor thermal conductor which cause the valve face
to run at higher temperature.

	Advantages of the sodium-filled valve include:
Ability to utilize higher compression with a given gas
Ability to use lower octane gas at a given compression
Ability to operate with more spark advance (at a given compression/gas)
Longer operating life.

	Disadvantages of the sodium-filled valve:
High cost
Higher mass

	Advantages of SS valve:
Hot face resists build-up
Much cheaper
Lower mass (can be set up to rev higher without float )

	Disadvantages of SS valve:
low thermal conductivity

	If you are trying to make more power by twisting the motor at higher rpm,
SS may help (Titanium would help much more ) but at the expense of lifetime.
For a street motor the sodium-filled valve is what I prefer for long life and high
performance.

								-jd


PS I finally got my tie rods replaced and have a new set of ferodo AF pads !

Date: 30 Sep 1994 11:17:59 -0800
From: "Bill White" <Bill.White.LDIV@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: Clutch job for 1987 911

> My question is: What do you recommend that we replace during the
> clutch job? Does everything need to be replaced (i.e. clutch disk, pressure
> plate, throw out bearing...) or can we just change the clutch disk and save
> ourselves some unnecessary expenses. One mechanic told us that we only need
> to change the clutch disk and another wants to change everything and then
add
> some new "kit" to the clutch package. I guess the "kit" is some kind of
> update to the transmission, can anyone enlighten me on this kit? 

When I had the clutch replaced on my 87, my mechanic performed an update that
changed the bearings the the throwout bearing fork rotates in and maybe the
fork but I'm not sure. This is appearantly a Porsche recommended update -
before they did the work, he explained the problem and showed me a tech note
describing the update. I also saw the old bearings while they were still in
the bell housing (is that a proper term for a p-car?) and they were trashed.
The pedal effort was much lower and smoother after the fix.

> Lastly, does
> $1500 sound reasonable for all parts and labor? 

If my memory is correct, I paid $1600 for the complete job including the
update. I think the update added 250-300 to the job.

Bill

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 1994 13:25:16 -0500 (EST)
From: James K Benson <jbenson@ecn.purdue.edu>
Subject: 944 Turbo information


In response to several questions posted on 944 Turbos:

*(The difference between the Turbo S and a standard Turbo)*
   The Turbo S incorporated many of the performance upgrades
of the race cars, built for the Turbo Cup Series, into a production
car.  1000 Turbo S's were made in 1988, 700 came to the US.  Most were
silver rose metallic with burgandy interior.  In 1989 all 944 Turbos
had the Turbo S upgrades.  They are as follows:

Engine:
	The engine has larger exhaust valves than the standard Turbo.
	The K26 turbocharger has improved exhaust and compressor blades
	allowing faster spin up.  The KLR computer runs a little higher
	boost pressure (1.82 bar absolute) than the standard Turbo (1.75
	bar abs.).  This rates the Turbo S at 247 bhp and 258 ft*lbs of
	tourque @ 4000 rpm.  The stock Turbo is 217 bhp and 243 ft*lbs
	@ 3500rpm.  

Transmission:
	The limited slip differential with external transmission oil
	cooler is standard on the S.  It's an option on the other
	Turbos.  Also, first and second gears are given an additional
	heat treatment to withstand the additional torque developed by
	the engine.

Suspension:
	Koni adustable shocks on all four corners.  The front struts
	are double adjustble, for stiffness and ride height.  The front
	springs are stiffer, about 165 lbs/in over 130 lbs/in for the
	stock suspension.  The front sway bars are 26.5 mm and rear are
	18 mm.  Off hand I can't remember the dimensions for the standard
	car but they are somewhat less.  The rear torsion bars on the 
	Turbo S are also larger diameter.  In addition, all the rubber
       	suspension bushings on the Turbo S are made of a stiffer compound.

Brakes:
	Front brakes on the Turbo S are the same as the 928 S4.  They
        are substantially larger than a standard Turbo.

Other:
	Airbabags, ABS, improved stereo system are all standard.
	7 and 9 x 16 forged wheels.

*(Price ranges and what you can get for $12000)*
   As far as prices go, the ranges for average to good condition Turbos:

'86                $10-$12 K
'87                $13-$15 K
'88                $14-$16 K
'88 & 89 Turbo S   $17-$20 K

I know I'll get all sorts of disagreement on these price ranges, but these
are ballpark of what owners are asking for their cars.  Usually dealerships
will be on the high end.  For the $12000 range (specific question) I 
recommend an '86 Turbo.  It's an awful lot of car for that price.  There
are quite a few around and if you're patient you should be able to find a
pretty clean example without having to drive through 2 states to see it.
Maintenance costs are higher on a Turbo than a plain 944.  More high stressed
parts to fail and more parts in general.  Also, for this reason, certain
repair jobs require longer labor for the Turbos than a plain 944.

*(Oil use and consumption)*
   As far as oil use, I recommend Mobile 1 15w 50.  Especially if you run the
car hard or track it, the high heat and high rpms really degrade the oil.
One quart for 1500 miles seems like low consumption to me.  I track my
car and it will use a quart to a quart and a half for a weekend event (300 
miles).  Otherwise, for highway, maybe a quart per 800 miles or so.  Do
not let the oil level get low.  The rod bearings (esp #2) are suceptable
to oil starvation.  Watch the level and keep it on or even slightly above
full, if you run the car hard and don't let go even half a quart down for
street/highway (easy) use.

*(Wheels, offsets, etc.)*
   An 88 Turbo S or '89 will have the 7 and 9 x 16 in. forged
seven spoke "Club Sport" wheels.  The 944 S2 and early C2/C4 seven spoke
wheels are the cast version, sometimes called "Design 90" wheels.  Forging
is a better manufacturing process than casting.  Forged wheels are
stronger than cast.  They are less likely to crack.  Any wheel off a 944 
from 1987 on will fit any other 944 in that year range.  The wheel offsets
were changed in 1987 to accommondate the ABS option, whether the car had the
option or not.  The C2/C4, RS Amer, 968, C2 Turbos, etc.., all have the
ABS offset hubs (Fuchs will not fit on a C2).  Therefore, the new 17 in.
5 spoke wheels will fit on any '87 or newer 944.  For a 944 Turbo, I'd
recommend the 7.5 and 9 x 17 set that the 968 w/ M030 came with. 

*(Catalytic Test Pipe)*
Removing the catalytic converter will improve the performance of a 944 Turbo.
It will run a little cooler and sound a little louder.  European versions
have what is called a primary muffler in place of the catalytic converter,
which acts as an addtional muffler on US cars.  I removed the cat. in my
car for the two reasons above.  I had always heard that the cats were well
enough designed, that they did not reduce performance.  Wrong.  The car
breathes a lot better and has more pull on the top end.  The real top end,
like above 120 mph in 4th gear.  If you don't run the car at high speed
tracks (Road America, Brainerd Int'l Raceway, etc) you may
not notice much improvement.  Everything is a trade off.


Jim Benson
'89 944 Turbo

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 15:17:03 cst
From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: 944 windshields

     To All,
     
     I just wanted to post a notice to everyone that has a 944x.
     I just went through a bad experience that actually turned out pretty 
     good at the end. I own a '86 944 and was changing the front hood 
     shocks when out of the blue the bottom of the shock just tapped the 
     bottom of the window and shattered about a one inch section of the 
     lower windshield. Needless to say this grew within a week to cover the 
     hole shield. For those of you that have ever cracked a 944 windshield, 
     you know that this is one of the most expensive w/s on the market at a 
     install price of avg. $1100. 
     On line here I was directed to one of the most friendly based 944 
     parts companies that you could ever deal with. 
     Porsche All 944 (1 800 255-7944) Even though they didn't have a W/S
     they where very helpful in directing me to someone that did.
     Glass Wholesalers (or Distributors) 800 421-1414 had factory OEM W/S 
     for $440. Once I received it, the company that was to install it 
     couldn't get it in. (To keep this as short as possible I will skip the 
     details. This glass does not go in like normal glass.)
     Don was eager enough to tell me that if they needed someone to walk 
     them through the process, via phone, he would. I was nervous having 
     someone put it in that had obviously had no experience with P-Cars.
     But they had more experience installing car glass than anyone in the 
     state. 
     In making a return call to Glass Distributors, Don tried to forewarn 
     me to be real careful with this W/S. He said,"we ship most of this 
     glass to people that are trying to change hoodshocks or readjust their 
     hoods". He commented that he was going to write a article to warn 
     people of this in an upcoming issue of Pana. At this point I had to 
     tell him of my idiotic adventure and that I wished that I had talked 
     to him sooner.
     After thinking about it, I decided to give an FYI to all here just in 
     case. Hopefully this will give you a heads up when playing under the 
     hood or around the windshield wipers. This is a very sensitive area.
     And, I would personally give a THUMBS UP! to both of the companies 
     listed above.
     
     Ed Montgomery
     '86 944 (White)

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 17:10:00 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
Subject: Double shocks on 911 Hood:


Steve Watson wrote:

>I heard from another 911 owner that the double shocks that can be installed
>on a 911 hood in place of the stock single shocks, tend to raise the upper
>corners up and out of alignment with the body.  Ive noticed this on
>my 911 and thought that the hood was misaligned.

I installed double shocks on both the front hood and the engine lid about 
two years ago.  I got tired of having the shocks wear out and dropping the 
hood/rear lid on my head!!  On the front hood, the corner where the double 
shock is installed is also raised up.  I guess the double shock exerts too 
much upward pressure for the weight of the hood to hold it down.  I don't 
think it causes any permanent damage but ** I'd really be interested to know 
if it has caused permanent damage to anyone else car**.  I'm planning to 
keep the double shock for the same reasons I installed it unless someone 
knows of the possibility of damage.  I did not have this problem with the 
rear lid.  I've also got the full whale tail, same as Mike Dayton, so the 
extra weight is offsetting the extra upward pressure from the double shock 
and keeping the body fit.  I suspect that this extra tail weight over the 
regular, no tail,  rear lid is what wears out the shocks so quickly 
(replaced every 2-3 years)

Regards.

------------------------------

Date: 30 Sep 1994 11:30:12 -0800
From: "Bill White" <Bill.White.LDIV@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re:  Clutch job for 1987 911

> My question is: What do you recommend that we replace during the
> clutch job? Does everything need to be replaced (i.e. clutch disk, pressure
> plate, throw out bearing...) or can we just change the clutch disk and save
> ourselves some unnecessary expenses. One mechanic told us that we only need
> to change the clutch disk and another wants to change everything and then
add
> some new "kit" to the clutch package. I guess the "kit" is some kind of
> update to the transmission, can anyone enlighten me on this kit? 

When I had the clutch replaced on my 87, my mechanic performed an update that
changed the bearings the the throwout bearing fork rotates in and the fork.
This is appearantly a Porsche recommended update - before they did the work,
he explained the problem with the original needle bearings and showed me a
tech note describing the update. I also saw the old bearings while they were
still in the bell housing (is that a proper term for a p-car?) and they were
trashed. The pedal effort was much lower and smoother after the fix. I also
had the rubber center clutch plate (the cause for my clutch problems)
replaced with a spring centered clutch plate and it appears to work fine.

> Lastly, does
> $1500 sound reasonable for all parts and labor? 

If my memory is correct, I paid $1600 for the complete job including the
update. I think the update added 250-300 to the job.

Bill

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 17:56:00 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
Subject: 911SC overheating


Lowell (netgod) wrote:
>My 1983 Targa is overheating at full throttle settings.
There's been a lot of discussions about 911 temperatures.  Interestingly, 
the owner's manual only says that when the temp gets to the red bar (in cars 
without numbered gauges) is the temperature excessive.  The bottom of the 
red bar translates to 302F degrees.  (The guages have degrees C printed on 
the far left side of the bars, back behind the face of the guage).  IMHO, 
Porsche either felt that less than 300 degrees was not too hot, they knew 
the cars would run very hot and did not want to scare owners or they wanted 
to sell lots of overheating-derived repairs (I think it's really choice 2). 


General concensus from the experts seems to be that 300 degrees is much too 
hot for long engine life.  A typical solution is to replace the front oil 
loop with either a factory or aftermarket oil radiator.  I've used both 
Terbotrol and B&B with the B&B appearing to work slightly better for my car, 
YMMV.  Depending on the how hot the climate where you live is, auxilliary 
cooler fans may be helpful. .  My temp (in Phoenix) still runs 230-240 when 
it's hot out, in traffic, with the air on so next year I'm going to add a 
fan.  You should price shop around salvage centers to find a system out of 
an 84 or an 87+ model (if you want the aux fan) to compare with the 
aftermarket products.  Be sure to really clean out a salvage system. 
 Mobile1 (or any synthetic) will help reduce the temperature, which you've 
already done.

Regards.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 17:43:00 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
Subject: Euro911 heater


Barry Chapin wrote:
>In my 1981 Euro 911SC Targa, my heater control lever, located between the
>front seats, just to the right of the parking brake lever, does not work
>anymore.  <snip>  What is wrong with this european heater system (I think 
the US >system is different)?
This is a different system from the US models.  In my 83SC there is only the 
auto heat control dial, no levers.  Not having a manual for that car myself, 
I would venture a guess that the cable connected to the dial mechanism had 
failed.

>I do not have a manual on the car interior controls.
This should be in the regular owners manual.  You should be able to order 
one through a Porsche dealer.

>How do the dash levers control the temperature, in conjunction with the 
center >console?  What does the lever on the top left do (the one next to 
the fan speed
>control lever) ?
This lever controls fan speed for ventilation air.  As it moves from left to 
right it first opens fresh air vents and then turns on the fan.  It does not 
help increase warm air flow on car with the auto temp control (the "lever" 
controls do this).

>The levers on the dash are sort of stiff to move.  Is this normal?
They should not be real stiff.  You should feel just a slight resistance.

>Oh yeah-Does that little stubby rubber thermostat up by the rear view 
mirror really
>work as a climate control?
Yes it works well, as long as the connector wire hasn't come loose.  You can 
undo the screws that hold it up and check to see if the wire still makes a 
good connection.  If it has come loose, then the thermostat doesn't work.

Regards.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 15:46:03 cdt
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: Rebuilding 914 ign switch.


  Brian, and my Porschephile friends;
  Yes, the switch can be cleaned and reused.
  Procedure:
  Use an X/acto knife blade to gently pry the 2 tabs on the side
of the switch body apart to separate the contacts from the cover.
  Be careful not to flex the nylon too far or the tabs will break.
  Use a solvent to clean the center and outer contacts on both
halves of the switch.  You may have to use a pencil eraser to scrub
the oxides off the contact zone, an ink eraser works best.
  Re-lube with silicone grease and reassemble.
  End procedure.

  The switch body is keyed so you cannot mess it up.  The center contact
is silver plated and is the starter contact.  While you have it apart
inspect carefully for heat warpage that might cause mis-alignment of
the internals and aggravate the fail mode.

  I've posted this before about the cause of this failure:
  There is no spike supressor diode across the starter's engagement
solenoid.  The ~300V spike is enough to fritz the contacts over time.
  Adding a 1n4004 or 4005 in proper polarity will permanent fix.

  Not sure, but all 9xx cars may share in this..

  -kyle

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Oct 1994 02:02:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Replacing 911 oil return tubes

> Should I replace them with stock or the aluminum after market adjustable
> ones?

Aftermarket expandibles can be installed with the engine in the car; using
the stock parts requires sigificant disassembly and should not be
done unless you're doing at least a valve job. By the same token, I
always replace the expandible jobbies with the real parts if I have to
take the top end apart, just on principle...

> Is it a straight forward job, or is it something that requires some mechanic magic?

Can be done in your driveway with a floor jack and hand tools.

> I am leaking about three drips a week on a daily driver.

Then my best advice is forget it -- take it as proof positive that
you're driving a Porsche. 

Stan

Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 23:57:37 PDT
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: ALL: re: 356 list



	I like the idea of a 356 only list, but I do understand the
concern of losing this content from p-files. Two alternatives I propose:

	1- separate 356 list and Cc: porschephiles; or

	2- use the first 3 spaces of the subject line to indicate which
cars are being referred to (ie, 356,911,944,etc, or ALL,AIR,H2O)
	
	This second alternative (which I think someone might have
suggested before) would allow people with limited time (or expensive
access time for those of us who don't get this access with work) to
quickly scan their mail for the info that interests them. 

	I think it would be great to keep everyone in good communication
with each other, and using a 3-character code in the subject line might
actually encourage some of the busier people to stay with the list because
it would be more user friendly.

	All this system would take to implement is for people to start
using these codes in their subject lines, like I have above. Of course,
you can still write a regular subject after the code. Show your support by
using these codes, or post your suggestions/comments. 

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914
'71 Alfa GTJunior
