Date: Sat, 01 Oct 94 03:31:36 EDT
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Zenith Carb Adjustment

Dear Tom:

       Before you try to adjust the Zeniths, make CERTAIN that the timing is
right (30-35 deg high speed advance, 3-7 deg advance idle), the valves are
adjusted correctly, and the plugs and wires are in good shape!

     Then, and only then can you adjust the carbs! The mixture screws (one
per hole) are like your garden hose valve- screw them in and they cut off the
gas; screw them out and they  increase the gas. I screw the screw in with my
right hand (starting on #1 cylinder, the rt front), with my left hand on the
middle of the fan shroud to feel how the engine responds. As you near all the
way in, the cylinder should die and the engine run rough. Back the screw out
and the cylinder should kick in. Go too far and it'll run rough again (too
rich). Iterate until you find a position such that a 1/8 turn either way
makes it run worse. Then go to the next idle mixture screw.
   Once you get all 4  mixture screws adjusted, put on your Synchrometer (NOT
a "Unisyn" The Synchrometer is like an air mass meter on a fuel injection
system and does NOT disturb the engine like the old obsolete Unisyn does
However if you have a Unisyn, you can peel off the rubber bottom and use it
with your  new Synchrometer). Compare the air draw side to side, and adjust
the idle STOP screw until both carbs draw an even amount AND the idle is from
900-1100 RPM. (I prefer 1000-1100 RPM, the oil pressure is higher and the
generator is usually charging).  Then repeat the idle mixture procedure. Then
check the side-to-side air draw with the Synchrometer. Repeat until happy.
   If you find a mixture screw that has no affect on the engine when you
screw the screw alllll the way in, you probably have a clogged idle jet. The
idle jet is located inside the square cover on the side of the Zenith, held
by a 10mm across the flat bolt. NOTE WELL: if you should remove that bolt,
the entire contents of the float bowl (gasoline),  WILL gush out allover your
plug wires and hot "J" pipes. Place rags or some such underneath before you
remove the cover!  You have been forewarned.

AND:
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Oct 1994 03:26:10 -0500
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update -- IMPORTANT TO READ IT THIS TIME!

October 1994

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

Well, it's been another interesting month... Ted Matsumura FINALLY has 
been kicked off this list. In the event that he does anything to annoy you
or to attempt to make your system unusable, please let me know at
once.  There have been reports of retaliatory activity.

With the Great Unpleasantness surrounding this, we've had a good deal of
attrition. We've also gotten back some folks that went anti-Ted a long
time ago, and have a ton of new members. Membership is up to about 850
at this point. The Who's Who will not be mailed out for a while though
to give me a chance to clean it up, removing the "old dead members".

The digest is new and improved -- new software will auto-send
the digest before it hits the 50k byte limit that many of the on-line
services have trouble with. So, that means you'll typically be getting
three digests a day, not one.

And, some trivia: the current membership of 850 is spread over 417 different
domains. Since I'm using smart mailer software, it only sends one copy to
each domain. If the average digest is 150k, that means that there are over
*FIVE HUNDRED MILLION* bits per day of Porschephiles traffic on the 
Internet. If I were using stupid mail software, it would be well over a
gigabit a day of Porschephiles. So, when the list seems to have a slow
turn over time, remember this.

Finally, a moment of silence for my 911. It's gone to live with a new
owner, as of about three weeks ago. It was a great car, certainly the
best of the street 911s I've had to date. While I'll miss it, I'm
re-focusing on my racing and 356 activities for a while. Once my new
venture pans out, I'll have to see about a made-to-measure 993...

Stan


COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at n_weissenberger@harvard.edu.   You can ask her for info or 
get her to send you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds published the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 or (908) 287-8070..

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
'64 356 SC  		(OK, so I fell in love again...)

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Oct 1994 02:21:53 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: RE-Lower noise-ratio->356list

> Trond writes, "The porschephiles list is the *best* porsche list for general
> purposes, but if you're mostly into the old 4cyl 4bangers the 'noise-ratio'
> gets abowe 95%."

> When I bought my new '61 Normal Coupe, I bought a Porsche. When I bought my
> used '55 Speedster, I bought a Porsche. And, when I bought my used '86 951,
> as a garage companion to the other two, I bought a Porsche. I'm interested
> in every thing Porsche does - all Porsche cars. What in the world do your
> mean, "noise-ratio?" 

OK, I'm a certifiable Porsche nut. I've had at least one each of the air 
cooled street cars, none each of the water cooled cars, have lusted after the
Mooney with the Porsche engine, seriously considered getting my dad a
Porsche Junior tractor, etc. This list is consequently for all things
Porsche.

I understand Trond's concerns though -- if I want to get a 356 specific
answer, I have to wade through a PILE of non-356 stuff. In fact, the
356 content is just about zero. So from *THAT* perspective, the signal
(356 content) to noise (everything else) ratio is pretty bad.

Here's the kicker: you find tidbits of info that are useful in all the
other "non-356" stuff. Like welding tips from Kyle talking about 914s,
or brake plumbing tips from Nathan Ulrich talking about race-grade 944s,
or interior tips from people talking about concour prep for Carrera RSs.
When we start splitting the list up, we lose that.

My personal solution to this is to maintain my own private list of people
that share certain interests -- on paper. That way I know who to shoot
a private mail message to for a clear and concise response in real time
about specialized topics. I've created my own personal network of contacts
and people I turn to when I need info.  People I would not have met except
via this list. People I would not have respected enough to value their
opinions except for what I've heard of their advice and opinions on this
list.

So, if there *ARE* little specialized sub-lists out there, that's
OK. My own interests are broad enough that it's not a requirement
for me, and my ego needs are met via enough other things that I don't feel
like I have to somehow "own" all the Porsche content in the world.  And I 
somehow figure that if there's a specialized list out there that 
I *should* be interested in, they'll find me...

> A Porsche is a Porsche is a Porsche is a . . . . (except maybe those owned
> by a DOS user).

Or as a buddy of mine used to say (typically after working too close to
either the propolene oxide or the beer fridge): "A Porsche is a great car
unless it's a character in Shakespeare".... 8{P (lame, I know, but I'm
just reporting it....)

Stan

Date: Sat, 1 Oct 1994 07:44:46 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: This could ONLY happen in California...



I'm so pissed off I can't see straight!!
In this morning's San Jose Mercury News,
there is a story about a new law passed
in California that can allow the State
to seize and SELL your car if you are
convicted of driving without a license
twice in 5 years. This law takes effect
on January 1, 1995.

Now, the article states that this law
is intended to remove vehicles from
the possession of people caught
driving with suspended or revoked
licenses. BUT, the article continues,
the law also applies if you are
stopped by the police and cannot
produce a license because you
may have left it at home. Pretty
serious punishment for a minor
traffic violation.....
 

So this law also affects people
who may be law abiding, licensed
drivers, who for whatever reason
forget to carry a license with them.
I'm no political activist, but such
an erosion of civil liberty such as
this may turn me into one.  The
Governor who signed this is up for
election in November..... His name
is Pete Wilson. Vote for ANYBODY
else, please!!

Jim Bauman
'86 Carrera Cab

Resident of the People's Republik of Kalifornia

Date: 01 Oct 94 13:23:05 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Bart Chambers' tire wear

Hi, Bart.
 
If you are wearing the rears out twice as fast as the fronts, I think you
should look at the example of a Really Expert Slalom Driver who used to be
on this list. Ya see, ya gotta mix tire brands on your car to fine-tune its
handling AND WEAR. A harder compound at the rear will equalize wear. After
all, the factory doesn't have time to do this on each production car. Also,
because you probably drive alone, there will be slightly more weight on the
left rear. You should consider having not only harder tires at the rear, but
carefully select a slightly harder brand on the left rear compared to right
rear. (Sears Roadhandlers are good, hard tires.) Also hard tires bounce off
curbs much better, preserving the clearcoat on your wheels so you won't have
to put an entire row of hose reels around your house.
 
NO, NO, THIS WAS AN ATTEMPT AT HUMOR!!! PUT AWAY THE CUTTING TORCH! (We have
to cherish the memory of the dear departed Ted M somehow, don't we? Don't
we??? NOT...)
 
Pete

Date: 01 Oct 94 13:23:02 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Setting 356 Zenith carbs

Hi, Tom.
 
I have mostly Solexes, so I had to read the manual. Translating from
German:
 
1. Warm engine, remove air cleaners.
 
2. Pop throttle linkage off carburetors.
 
3. Turn in both idle speed adjustment screws (idle stop screws) together
until idle is about 1000 rpm.
 
4. Tighten both idle mixture screw all the way (not too tight, could
damage seat) then open 1.5 turns. From this point, working on each
carburetor individually, turn left or right until
engine runs smoothest. UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES LEAVE IDLE MIXTURE SCREWS IN
CLOSED POSITION. Repeat this fine-tuning on other carb.
 
5. Loosen idle stop screws until idle speed is 650-750 rpm.
 
6. Use special device P 75 [this is the old Unisyn; you'd be much better off
buying the more modern STE Synchrometer with the appropriate rubber adapter;
see ads in Porsche magazines, lots of places have it].
 
[following is for old Unisyn] Turn idle mixture screws to place ball about
halfway up in tube.
 
7. Without turning screw on Unisyn, place on other carb and
turn idle stop screw to place ball at same level as other carb.
 
8. Turn idle mixture screws on both carbs so that ball shows minimal
oscillations.
 
9. Press throttle linkage rods back onto carbs. ACHTUNG! Adjust length of
rods if necessary so that they fit right onto ball ends without being
forced.
 
10. Set idle speed with hand throttle to 1200-1300 rpm. Check for same
throttle opening with Unisyn again, as under #7 and #8. If the levels are
not the same for both carbs, adjust linkage length.
 
11. Check idle speed again.
 
12. Check accelerator pump volume, 0.2- 0.3 cc for two strokes.
 
13. Check stop bolt for throttle pedal. When throttle pedal is floored,
throttle arms on carbs should be about 1 mm short of hitting end of travel.
 
14. Put air cleaners back on.
 
Remark: If smooth idle is not achievable, the throttle body must be checked
according to section 8 KR. The carbs must be removed for this procedure.
 
 
If you adapt sections 7 & 8 for the Synchrometer, that's it.
 
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 01 Oct 94 13:22:44 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: James Dean & Beck Spyder

John Berry asked if anybody had retraced James Dean's route.
 
A couple of years ago, I was testing a Beck Spyder for a car magazine. It
was even tricked out with the number 130 and "Little Bastard" written across
the engine lid. The photographer and I decided to go up to the accident
scene and shoot it there. So we have photos of the car parked by the
monument, reflected in the monument, and in front of the Cholame "post
office" (read: shack). On the way, we passed famous Brown Material Road and
did a self-timed photo of ourselves examining our shoe soles <g>.
 
Then we shot the car in Paso Robles and headed back to LA the next day. We
had nothing to do on a Sunday afternoon, the photographer asked what we
should do now, the sun was too high for photography, so I suggested we rent
"Rebel without a Cause." Watched that. Got idea. We went up to Griffith
Observatory to shoot the Spyder after sundown, lit by our truck headlights.
While shooting in front of the place where the last scenes in "Rebel" were
filmed, a middle-aged guy came by and asked if this was a car like James
Dean had. "Well, yes and no, it's a fiberglass replica but faithful to the
original idea." He said he used to hang out with James Dean. Yeah, sure, we
thought, everybody in Hollywood probably says that. He then said he used to
ride around in his white Speedster before he sold it to buy the 550. Now it
gets interesting; most wannabes don't know about the Speedster. Maybe this
guy is for real. I said we were shooting here because the movie ended here.
"Oh, yeah, I was in that movie." Really? Who did you play? "I was second in
command of the gang, and got shot by Sal Mineo in the old Getty Mansion."
Oh, heck, we just watched you a couple of hours ago on video. He said that
he was hired as 'gang rumble advisor' to the film, out of Hollywood High,
and was sort of talked into acting by James Dean. He's been at it ever
since. Name is Frank Mazzola. He said he never got a ride in the 550, as
Dean was busy prepping it for racing and the accident happened before he
could just cruise around in it. So I suggested he drive the replica down to
the LA Zoo and back up. He got his James Dean 550 ride, just a few decades
late.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 01 Oct 1994 14:21:44 PDT
From: Robert Ayers <ayers@mv.us.adobe.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche Hood Shocks

The hood-support thread seems to have reappeared, with 
remarks about doubling the shocks etc:

For those with 912s and older 911s:

    Early 911 hoods are longer and weigh more than current 
    onnes, because the treatment of the hood where it reaches
    the front of the car has changed.  Early hoods wrap down
    to become part of the front of the car; recent hoods stop
    at the top of the bumper.
    So recent shocks aren't designed to hold up older hoods,
    and they die early.

This tidbit is from a recent Automotion catalog.  They added
that they sell old-spec shocks for old-style hoods.

Bob

Date: Sat, 01 Oct 94 18:47:00 PDT
From: Martin Cox <mcox@mswisard.kla.com>
Subject: Re: 85.5 944 Sunroof Woes (fwd)


Hussain said.......
>..... but don't remember (as someone else posted to this list ) that there 
>is a second relay in the rear.......

Chris and Hussain.

The roof did change slightly in February 1986 (if I remember right from the 
shop manual) but the relay circuit is the same as the 85.5. There is the main 
relay controlling the roof which is an elctronic type in the fusebox (not so 
easy to test). There are two more relays on the motor plate in the rear that 
are indicated as one relay in the wiring diagram. These would be easy to test 
out of the car. There is an additonal microswitch on the post 86 that 
indicates when the roof is closed (this could be the switch at the front of 
the roof). I think that the pre 85.5's are similar. 

Sorry I don't have the manual to hand to verify all the details so this is 
from memory - feel free to correct me if i'm wrong guys.

Regarding the microswitches, I thought that my roof was operating "correctly" 
until I realised that being able to unlock the roof at speed was not 
Porsche's expectation for the design! (unlike a convertable Ford Mustang that 
I once drove. Being able to open a convertible top whilst moving could have 
interesting results). Definitely worth checking all 4. 


Martin Cox - '87 944

Dear Subscribers,

I know that you've all suffered through a lot in the last couple of
weeks, but the worst seems to be over. So, now it's time to sit back
relax and get on to *normal* Porschephiles business.

Following this message, Ted is no longer a valid subject for conversation
on this list. If you should have any questions or concerns about what
he's doing now or might have done in the past, please address those to me 
via private mail. I really mean "not a valid subject" -- no Ted bashing, 
no nothing. These are my last official words on Ted.

There is an on-going investigation as to where the mail bombs came
from, who was trying to break in to tta.com, and who else had any
related activities. This is being coordinated by the CERT, so we're
in pretty good hands. If you were one of the people that originally
contacted  me about being mail bombed with the 12 mb files or anything
else that you believe to have originated at rahul.net, please
get in touch with me again. I want to make sure I haven't left anything
out.

I would appreciate it if you could assist me in one final manner on 
this subject: should you encounter any messages that appear to be from
Ted which happen to mention me, with good or bad intent, please forward
them to me with the headers intact if possible. They may be required
in other matters.

This message is being copied to Ted and the operator of rahul.net to
ensure that they are fully aware of these actions.

Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

and the rear sheet metal to get a puller in

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 02 Oct 94 06:50:12 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: 951 rattle solution

Are you bothered by rattles coming from the rear of your 951?  I know I was.
I searched and searched and couldn't find the source until it occurred to me
that when I was applying the brakes the rattle went away. 
Turns out the problem is with the brake pads in the rear calipers. The
backing plates for the pads are a sloppy fit in the caliper. This seems to be
especially prevalent in aftermarket pads although I have since learned that
it can be a problem with factory pads as well.
The result is that the backing plates shake up and down over rough roads
resulting in the backing plates hitting the rotor "hats". This produces the
rattling noise.
The solution is to make sure that the pads are held more firmly in the
caliper. You can accomplish this by altering the retaining spring or shimming
the pads until any slop is eliminated. I used some thin aluminum shims and it
works just fine.
The other solution is to turn up the radio.
Hope this helps.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue



------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 2 Oct 1994 10:27:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 Blower Removal

Unfortunately I've had to remove my blower several times. It's held on by 
the big nut and a key. The shaft is slightly tapered (or so it seems) and 
once you hunker down that nut it gets real tight. We have fabricated a 
puller using a piece of 3/4" steel with two holes drilled in it just 
larger than the blower diameter. Then we took two 3/8" long bolts, put a 
95 degree bend at the end, cleaned up the bend with a file, and hooked 
the bolts behind the blower hub. If you tighten up the bolts with the 
blower nut on the shaft flush with the end, you can pop the blower off 
by  backing out the nut. Even though we used a generous amount of  
anti-sieze the last time, it took considerable force to break it loose. 
It's true there isn't a great deal of room to work behind the engine but 
if you're careful with the dimensions of the "puller" it works quite 
well. It seems to me we're having to use too much force, but I don't see 
any other way to do it. Perhaps there are some smarter folk out there!  

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 2 Oct 1994 11:24:22 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: Re: Some questions (long answer)


Richard - 

I've waited to give an answer to your question of "Are Porsches
worthwhile to own," to see if some of the more knowledgable
and erudite amongst us would respond. Hopefully they will but
meantime, I'll throw my couple of phennings your way.

I hadn't paid much attention to the marque for a long time (kids,
vans, soccer games, dance practices left no time or money to indulge)
but life being what it is, things allowed for the purchase of one
a couple of years ago.  I must say I have never appreciated any
thing mechanical as much as I have this car. It is, simply, a joy.
The car is a better car than I will ever be a driver. Thus the 
challange: to become a better driver.  If you were lucky enough to 
read Kim's travelog on driving a new 993 in Europe, you could tell that 
this is truly one of the ultimate pleasures of this life.  For me, I'm 
at the other end of the wide spectrum of drivers: it's my daily haul to 
and from anywhere (she got the van and gives me the single digit salute 
in the winter and I smile and wave in the summer). I wish I didn't have to use
it that way and someday I won't have to. Meanwhile, it gets me there
reliably every time I ask it to. 

It being a mechanial baby, it's going to wear and occasionally break. To
fix means to spend money - this isn't a Ford or Toyota Corolla that you can
run down to the nearest auto parts store and necessarily pick up what 
you need.  This is a car where parts tend to be expensive because of the
rather limited number manufactured (economy of scale in reverse) and the
number of competent fixers are fewer than those for Buicks.  What you have 
noticed on this list is a cross section of a wide variety of models
over an even wider variety of years. You have people talking about driving
and maintaining 356s from the '60s along with others doing the same with their
models from the '70s, '80s and up to the present day.  These people see
their value in what they have and are willing to do what it takes to
keep it so.

If some of us seem a little shrill at times about certain maintnance features,
it's because we are trying to convey that some things (though they actually
be few in number) *must* be done in order keep the car from becoming an
expensive, and sad, pile of junk. As an example, my 944 is actually very easy
to tune up: plugs, "points" and air filter. Change the oil at regular
intervals (depends on your driving) keep it clean and spiffy (you will
want to do this) and do the driver's manual check items and off you go.
But the cam/timing belt is an absolute must to be replaced on schedule.
The price of ignoring it or ignorance is a new engine. That ain't cheap.

Has the last three years of ownership been worth it? Yes. 
Knowing then what I now would I do it again? Yes.
Why? Well, I've fallen in love the beast and I look so damn good in it! (can't
deny the ego value, either).

It is worth it to you? Only you can decide that and then only by actually buying,
driving and enjoying it will you know for sure.

Stan repeated a few weeks ago what someone had said some months back, "Porsches
will get you through times of no sex better than sex will get you through times
of no Porsches."  This is truer than you may believe!

I hope you go for it and let us know what happens.

Good luck,

Herb Myers
'83 944
Dark Red Metallic

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:06:45 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Euro parts sources, avoid Freisinger

 
Hi, Allen.
 
Regarding parts sources in Europe, I don't know too many, but I do know
enough to avoid Freisinger. It's a long story and he's the subject of
several inside jokes at Porsche, but it's probably best to leave it at that.
I have friends who used to work at Porsche and who live about 5 miles from his
shop in Karlsruhe. They come over here during business trips to buy parts
every few years, and I often ship stuff to them.
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:07:03 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: valve guide install

 
Hi, Tom.
 
The guides may feel fine, or even measure fine, now when they're out of the
heads. But when they are pressed in, the shrink fit means that the guide
will be squeezed down, and the bore in the head will be stretched out a
little. That's why you ream them AFTER they're in the head.
 
Pete
 
 
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:06:48 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 headliner replacement

 
Hi, Jordan.
 
How bad is your original headliner? If it isn't torn, it can be re-dyed to
look fresh.
 
The same process can be used to dye a replacement headliner any color or
shade you like. There are guys who go around to used car dealers and fix
tears in vinyl and re-dye vinyl and leather. I had the original headliner of
one of my 356s redyed to cover the leaching rubber and glue stains for about
$100, because of the problem you're having now -- the repro headliners look
different.
 
The vinyl dyes are made by several companies including SEM. Auto paint
specialists may carry them.
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:06:51 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Kim's Euro trip

 
Hi, Kim.
 
Thanks for the travelogue. You hit some of my personal favorite spots. Did
you stay at the Chateau d'Isenbourg? Neat place, great restaurant. My idea
of a fun weekend was heading off to friends in Strasbourg on Friday after
work, and exploring roads in the Vosges hills west and south of town. Thanks
also for telling everybody that the autobahn isn't all it's cracked up to
be, so to speak. Deep down, nobody believes you can't blast along on it all
day long.
 
If you had given enough warning, I would have given you a list of other
stuff to do around Baden-Baden and Stuttgart and such. There's a great
open-air restaurant outside B-B, just past the SWF radio antenna, called
Klosterschenke, with views of vineyards and the Rhine valley. And the
theme swimming pool in B-B, the Carcalla-Therme, is kinda neat. And when in
B-B, gotta go to the casino, just to say you did it.
 
I hope you took the time to at least see the Porsche museum. The Mercedes
museum is much bigger and well worth the commuter rail ride to the other
side of town.
 
I used to do top speed runs to test cars on the section from Karlsruhe north
toward the Walldorf junction, at night.
 
Pete

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:06:40 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Tiptronic

 
Hi, Chris.
 
>If you have to have an automatic, the Tiptronic is probably the best
>automatic there is.
 
Exactly. I don't want an automatic either but the Tiptronic gives you the
most control over shifts of any automatic on the market.
 
>like the F1 guys use...
 
The 1995 Tiptronic adds steering-wheel rocker switches for going up and down
through the gears.
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 02 Oct 94 13:06:42 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: brake caliper bolts

 
Hi, Andrew.
 
>What's so special about the bolts holding calipers together?
 
The strength grade. 11.9 is a high-strength bolt. You can get these from
well-stocked local nut and bolt suppliers. These should not be re-used. The
torque may be low, but you have high force on the pistons trying to split
the calipers apart. Also they're loaded in bending. Considering that it's
your butt, replacing these is probably the cheapest part of a caliper
overhaul. The old ones will probably still work OK. But only probably.
 
Pete
(Sitting around, waiting for UPS brake parts, but with new bolts in hand)

Date: Sun, 2 Oct 94 16:26:00 EDT
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: Hi-Watt Headlights

>Before this thread dies, I'd like to hear if any 911 (specifically 911SC)
>owners have experience with running higher headlight wattage than the
>stock 55W/60W.  With or without adding relays etc. to carry the xtra

I've been running 100W/55W (that's right, 100W low beams, 55W high beams)
with my H1 setup for a couple years now with no problems.  The wire gauge
appears identical for the high and low beam circuits, so I figure the low
beam circuit could take the extra power just as easily as the high beam.

BTW the H1's are very good at keeping the light below the level of the
oncoming drivers' eyes.  Never been flashed.

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe
  '89 Feline unit
  '88 Feline unit (new acquisition)

Subject: 356 desire


Many years ago my wife and I sold our '62 356B to help finance my MBA.  Even 
tho we love, and will not part with, our '83 911SC,  we have decided it's 
time to expand our fleet of automobiles to include another 356.  This is not 
going to be a track car, an "investment-grade" car or a restoration project, 
just one to fix up, drive and enjoy.  Reading about Trond's heroic efforts 
has made me realize that I don't have the time, patience or mechanical 
skills for a "project".  What I'm looking for at this time is knowledge. 
 I'm joining the 356 Registry and our local AZ 356 club.  There's a couple 
of books listed in FAQ that I'm going to check into:

     Duane Spencer:  Porsche 356 Performance Handbook
     Dr. Brett Johnson: The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity

Are there any other sources of information or experiences that I should 
check into?  After I figure out exactly what to look for, I'll then start 
the looking process.

Regards.

Date: Sun,  2 Oct 94 21:20:55 PDT
From: George Durden <durden@bga.com>
Subject: 914 Calipers -- Thanks

I just wanted to thank everyone who responded with advice
on the piston removal procedure for the 914 rear brake calipers.
The point of confusion in my case was that the 4mm socket
headed plug bolt had ejected itself from the driver's side
caliper (somewhere on the highway) and the hex adjuster
contained behind said plug ejected also. Now that I realize
what happened I am in a quandry. I picked up a caliper 
rebuild kit from Automotion ($39 for each caliper). Most 
expensive rubber washers I''ve bought in a while. I picked up
a pair of stainless steel hex headed plug bolts also, but I'm still
short an adjuster mechanism for the caliper. Is the adjuster
mainly for the Emergency brake or is it imperative to the operation
of the normal brake also. If it's E-brake only, I'll rebuild the caliper
without it and go with it. Else, I'm hunting for an adjuster mechanism
(yeah those are easy to find...)

Advice?
George

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 00:20:45 -0500
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Ted Update

Dear Subscribers,

I know that you've all suffered through a lot in the last couple of
weeks, but the worst seems to be over. So, now it's time to sit back
relax and get on to *normal* Porschephiles business.

Following this message, Ted is no longer a valid subject for conversation
on this list. If you should have any questions or concerns about what
he's doing now or might have done in the past, please address those to me 
via private mail. I really mean "not a valid subject" -- no Ted bashing, 
no nothing. These are my last official words on Ted.

There is an on-going investigation as to where the mail bombs came
from, who was trying to break in to tta.com, and who else had any
related activities. This is being coordinated by the CERT, so we're
in pretty good hands. If you were one of the people that originally
contacted  me about being mail bombed with the 12 mb files or anything
else that you believe to have originated at rahul.net, please
get in touch with me again. I want to make sure I haven't left anything
out.

I would appreciate it if you could assist me in one final manner on 
this subject: should you encounter any messages that appear to be from
Ted which happen to mention me, with good or bad intent, please forward
them to me with the headers intact if possible. They may be required
in other matters.

This message is being copied to Ted and the operator of rahul.net to
ensure that they are fully aware of these actions.

Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 07:30:48 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)

Date: Mon, Oct 3, 1994 7:56 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: performance upgrade

In message <Pine.3.89.9410021459.A26812-0100000@brahms.udel.edu> Carl Brian 
Klinetob writes:

> After fixing up the body, i'm now looking to add 
> some to the performance.  What do you recommend?  Some say the chips are 
> the way to go.  Others say I should stick to suspension.  I realize that 
> i'm not presently capable of driving the car to it's full potential but i 
> do intend to get involved with professional instruction and some track 
> time as money allows.  

Hi Brian,

YMMV, but the best *FIrst* investment you can make in performance, is in
making yourself a better driver.  Afterall, this investment, properly 
utilized, is transferable to every other car you will ever drive.

In addition, money spent in *go-faster* mods, only increases your chances
for disaster if *You* are not competent to handle what you already have.

Of course, I'm just an ol' country boy, so what do I know...?

Anyway, Welcome to the group, and congratulations on getting a P-toy!
Best of luck to you!

Date: Mon, 03 Oct 94 07:40:46 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Performance Upgrades

Hi Carl,

For your 83 944, I would budget my money in the following priority:

1) Join the Porsche Club of America.  The $36 per year gives you access to
Porsche experts, relatively cheap parts, a great magazine and driver
education.

2) Go to driver education.  In the northeast (Delaware is near the
Northeast, isn't it?) there is a multitude of great places to drive. Most of
them are used by PCA regions for driver education and club racing. 
Typically, the cost is $60 to $100 per day, depending on the region, and the
cost of renting the track.  

3) Brakes.  Upgrade your brakes to Cool Carbon or Cool Kevlar.  They squeal,
but they are phenomonal.

4) Suspension. Upgrade to at least 86 Turbo Swaybars and Koni Adjustable
Shocks.  Your car may not have a rear swaybar, in which case you have to buy
the mounting hardware also.  If you are seriously tracking the car with
serious rubber, upgrade the steel front A-arms to the 85/2 or 86 Aluminum
Control Arms.

5) Chips are available for your car. Several suppliers are available, some
of whom are porschephiles.

Of course, this list does not include consumables, like tires, 108 octane
gas, nitrogen for your tires. roll cages, helmets and 5-point harnesses.

Lastly, the cheap thing to do is do items 1 and 2 above, without changing
your car one iota.  (Read: Learn to drive what you have.)

Good luck

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

testing?  Or anything as dangerous as gasoline that would leave the injectors
cleaner than they were at the start of the test?

to sprayed around, I'd rather do it out in the middle of a garage bay than in
a dark, cramped, 12v wired engine compartment.

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 10:59:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Best wheels for 914 Track

> I am in the process of setting up a 914 for the track. The car has the
> steel flairs on front and back. Im told by some to run 8 inch wheels all
> the way round but others say to run 7 front and 8 rear. Their reason is
> that 8 inch all round will cause the steering to be overly heavy and might
> induce mor oversteer. Thanks for any comments. 

Ghost Racing has a 914-6 GT that uses 15x8s all the way around. Drives like
a dream on the track, steering is a little heavy on the street but only
relative to the feather-light "normal" 914 steering. It's more like a late
911 with lots of castor.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 94 09:27:39 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: (44 Belts and mounts and Mass Unsubscribes.


Hi gang,

I've seen a few people bow out because of the actions of one idiot.
Relax, things will get back to normal quickly. This is just a lesson in
what happens when a sociopath decides to get attention for himself.

I've seen a few more postings on 944/924S/968 belts and motor mounts.

1) If the engine is vibrating, get it fixed pronto.
2) If someone tells you the balance shafts are out of time, get that
fixed even faster. 
3) If there are no records with your new purchase indicating the last 
time the belts were changed, change them.

The cost to change belts should be no more than $250. If a shop want to 
charge you more, find out why. The belts are no more than $75 and the 
time to change is about two hours (turbos are more) ALL belts, cam and 
balance shafts must be timed together. If the mechanic doesn't know how 
to do it in that time, find another one. 

Always recheck tension with the gauge. Remember to have it re-checked 
2,000 miles after initial installation.

FYI, the Pirelli belt seems to be the best, it seems to stretch the 
least and remain in time.

Motor mounts. The latest motor mounts will run $350 to $400 depending 
on who you buy them from. They will have green paint on them and are 
NOT hydraulic. Figure 5 to 6 hours installation. You can do them 
yourself if you are patient. HINT: remove the front cross-member from
the car when you change them.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 14:32:44 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: fuel injector testing

Regarding FI (injector) testing: National makes a purpose-built chip (the
LM1949 Injector Drive Controller) which is intended as a driver for fuel
injectors (1 chip per injector, or per group of injectors firing together,
I suppose). It requires very few external components (a Darlington and a
few R's and C's, plus a clock), and does all the neat tricks (different
peak and hold currents, compensation for battery voltage drop, etc.) It's
in a DIP-8 package.

If you plan on making an injector test fixture (out of the car), this may
be the simplest and best way to go.  Call your local distributor for
samples.

Andrew

do with coolant disapearing and not knowing where it was going.

Well, this weekend I found a nice small puddle under my car.  The coolant seems
to be comming from between the timing belt cover and the engine.  I assume this
means the seals on the water pump are going (gone?).  The leak is still quite small
and I only found the puddle once, no new puddle since Saturday.

Question:  How long can I run the car with this sort of a leak?  The car has over 
94000 miles on it and I have no idea when or if the pump has ever been changed.  
I had been planning on changing the water pump when I change the timming/ballance belts 
in about 6000 miles.  Can I wait this long for the water pump replacement?

Are there any signs to watch for that show a imminent failure?  

Thanks for any advice.

Steve '87 944S

Subject: 951 Wheel Bearings

This weekend I decided to find my power steering leak and while
I was in the process of it I checked my suspension.  It appears
that I have a bad front right wheel bearing.  This doesn't seem
too bad to fix, but in the European Select catalog there is no
bearing listed for my '87 951.  According to it, I have to 
replace the entire control arm.  Is this true or did I miss something?
This will seriously irritate me if I have to spend $650 just to
replace a bearing!

As it turned out, my problem with the steering rack was that a
hose that ran from one side to the other of the rack was 
disconnected on the passenger side.  I hooked this back up
and I haven't lost any power steering fluid yet.  When I 
turn sharply I still hear some grinding - I'm hoping this
is just air bubbles in the pump.  How do you bleed a power
steering system?

One additional question:  How much would a decent set of track
wheels cost for my car.  I don't want anything pretty.  They
just have to be the correct size and straight.

Thanks,

Ross Stites

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 94 13:33:27 PDT
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 911: fuel tank refinish

Finished refinishing (sounds funny) my fuel tank this weekend.  Really came
out quite nice.  Thanks to all who gave advice on chemicals, paints and
undercoatings.

I stripped the tank to bare metal, ground off all traces of rust and
applied the Scotch anti-rust metal prep, a coat of zinc based primer
and Scotch black undercoating.  This was all done after re-sealing the
insides with the product from Hirsch (sp).

Looks great and after test fitting the tank, and looking under the
car, the rest definitely will be redone.

Am I the only one, or do the rest of you encounter this.  You begin one
thing and find that to do right, three more need to happen and because
of those three, nine more and so on.  Or am I just being too neurotic. B^)

Tom '70 911T

Date: 3 Oct 1994 15:43:24 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 AFC (L-jet) questio

RE> 914 AFC (L-jet) question
>I want to know if there is any way for me to recalibrate 
>this beast.

    The "right way" (at least, according to the factory manual)
to do this is to hook up a CO-meter to the exhaust.  Tweak the
knob until you get about 2% CO *before* the cat.  (75's have the
catalytic converter, right?)  This is done as an adjustment on 
the *whole* system, and can be used to compensate for vaccuum
leaks, etc.
  
>As an aside to this, what does the adjustment screw on the AFC box 
>actually do.  Again, it looks as though someone decided it need 
>adjustment and has done so.  I would guess that it is a mixture 
>adjustment, and if so which way leans it out?

    The screw adjusts the amount of air that bypasses the flap.  It
will adjust your mixture.  In (right to tighten) should mean that
the flap measures more of the air coming through the intake, and
should richen the mixture.  Out (left to loosen) should mean that
the flap measures less of the air coming in (more of it is un-
measured) and so should lean out the mixture.
    Rich is an unusual mode for the 1.8s, usually they get some sort
of vaccuum leak somewhere and run lean (like mine).
    Also check the cold start valve and the switch that controls it.
The switch may be stuck "on", or the valve may leak even when closed.

- --DD

I do on the curved windsheild of my 356.

     the process to dismantle the turbo?

     to the turbo.  I have removed it, and the compressor housing.  I noticed

     oil, it leaks around the compressor blade.

     behind the blade, but am now stuck.  The plate that seems to hold it all 
     together won't come out.  It there some trick to getting it out?

the required specs.

he can undo this temporary fix. I don't know what he did but I do remember
him raising the car and dismounting the front left tire on both occasion.
Total Cost $60.

located on that side, but I was looking for speculation as to what
the guy did to reduce the CO numbers. Since this is an annual thing
I want to keep the car under EPA compliance. Assuming that he disconnected
the O2 sensor would that effect performance.

Date: Mon, 03 Oct 94 11:05:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: My 1st autocross

Hello 'philes,

I ran my 1st autox yesterday and had an absolute blast!!!  My 914/6 is still 
on jackstands so I took my wife's 1991 Toyota Tercel with the "sport" 
package.  This consisted of 4 doors, automatic tranny, and 155/80 SR 13 
tires.  :-)

I managed to place 2nd in my class even though I was up against higher 
powered cars.  I lost to an experienced driver in a Paseo.  I don't feel bad 
 - I feel great!!!  I was freaked as hell at the start, and I surprised both 
the announcer and myself by not getting a DNF nor hitting any cones on my 3 
runs.  My times were 87.898, 81.816, and 79.637.

I had a blast and learned *A LOT* about how the car handles under high-speed 
cornering.  This was the first time I've really pushed the car since I don't 
believe in learning about that on the street!  I can definitely see how these 
events would help in making you a better driver.

Thanks for your encouragement, Stan.  To those who haven't done this: try it 
 - especially the 911 owners!!!  Learn what your car does when it's pushed to 
the limits.  It's fun and *SAFE*.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

1975 914/6 (in intensive care, awaiting transfusion)
1991 Toyota Tercel (autox demon)

Date: 3 Oct 1994 10:32:11 U
From: "QM Admin" <QM_Admin@babylon.saic.com>
Subject: ALL- re- 356 list

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               ALL: re: 356 list



	I like the idea of a 356 only list, but I do understand the
concern of losing this content from p-files. Two alternatives I propose:

	1- separate 356 list and Cc: porschephiles; or

	2- use the first 3 spaces of the subject line to indicate which
cars are being referred to (ie, 356,911,944,etc, or ALL,AIR,H2O)
	
	This second alternative (which I think someone might have
suggested before) would allow people with limited time (or expensive
access time for those of us who don't get this access with work) to
quickly scan their mail for the info that interests them. 

	I think it would be great to keep everyone in good communication
with each other, and using a 3-character code in the subject line might
actually encourage some of the busier people to stay with the list because
it would be more user friendly.

	All this system would take to implement is for people to start
using these codes in their subject lines, like I have above. Of course,
you can still write a regular subject after the code. Show your support by
using these codes, or post your suggestions/comments. 

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914
'71 Alfa GTJunior

Date: 3 Oct 1994 10:33:22 U
From: "QM Admin" <QM_Admin@babylon.saic.com>
Subject: Re: Rebuilding 914 ign switc

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE>Rebuilding 914 ign switch.


  Brian, and my Porschephile friends;
  Yes, the switch can be cleaned and reused.
  Procedure:
  Use an X/acto knife blade to gently pry the 2 tabs on the side
of the switch body apart to separate the contacts from the cover.
  Be careful not to flex the nylon too far or the tabs will break.
  Use a solvent to clean the center and outer contacts on both
halves of the switch.  You may have to use a pencil eraser to scrub
the oxides off the contact zone, an ink eraser works best.
  Re-lube with silicone grease and reassemble.
  End procedure.

  The switch body is keyed so you cannot mess it up.  The center contact
is silver plated and is the starter contact.  While you have it apart
inspect carefully for heat warpage that might cause mis-alignment of
the internals and aggravate the fail mode.

  I've posted this before about the cause of this failure:
  There is no spike supressor diode across the starter's engagement
solenoid.  The ~300V spike is enough to fritz the contacts over time.
  Adding a 1n4004 or 4005 in proper polarity will permanent fix.

  Not sure, but all 9xx cars may share in this..

  -kyle

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 94 9:04:26 EDT
From: Brian Abernathy <cba@atl.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #885 Mon Oct 3 02:00:03 CDT 1994

I wanted to thank everyone on the Porschephiles list.  I got a wonderful
response to my question about rebuilding the ignition switch of my 914 -
especially from Kyle.  (I had also posted the same question in the VW
newsgroup, but all I got from them was rude comments!)

I followed Kyle's instructions, and found that everything he had 
described was exactly like mine.  So, it appears that even the 914
shares the same mechanism as some of it's more expensive cousins.

I did have one small hitch - taking the switch out of the sleeve that
houses the ignition lock.  After I got everything into a better light,
I discovered a small screw.  Normally, I wouldn't have a screwdriver
that small, but I recently bought a small "eyeglasses repair kit" at
the drugstore, and it included a small screwdriver, which was exactly 
the size I needed.

Once the switch was out, it came apart exactly as Kyle had described.
The contacts were pitted, and once I got them burnished, the switch
worked correctly.  Tonight, it goes back in to the steering column.

On a non-related thread:  There was a discussion about "varmits".
I had to place a tent of plastic over my 914, then roll a bug-bomb
underneath.  Seems I had a nest of red wasps in the bumper.  The
next morning, there were about a dozen dead wasps under the plastic.  
They tried to fly out when the bomb went off, but they were trapped
under the plastic.  NOW maybe I can adjust the clutch cable!

Thanks for the help, everybody!
- --

------------------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 11:32:32 U
From: "CPQM Admin" <CPQM_Admin@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: 911SC overheating

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               911SC overheating


Lowell (netgod) wrote:
>My 1983 Targa is overheating at full throttle settings.
There's been a lot of discussions about 911 temperatures.  Interestingly, 
the owner's manual only says that when the temp gets to the red bar (in cars 
without numbered gauges) is the temperature excessive.  The bottom of the 
red bar translates to 302F degrees.  (The guages have degrees C printed on 
the far left side of the bars, back behind the face of the guage).  IMHO, 
Porsche either felt that less than 300 degrees was not too hot, they knew 
the cars would run very hot and did not want to scare owners or they wanted 
to sell lots of overheating-derived repairs (I think it's really choice 2). 


General concensus from the experts seems to be that 300 degrees is much too 
hot for long engine life.  A typical solution is to replace the front oil 
loop with either a factory or aftermarket oil radiator.  I've used both 
Terbotrol and B&B with the B&B appearing to work slightly better for my car, 
YMMV.  Depending on the how hot the climate where you live is, auxilliary 
cooler fans may be helpful. .  My temp (in Phoenix) still runs 230-240 when 
it's hot out, in traffic, with the air on so next year I'm going to add a 
fan.  You should price shop around salvage centers to find a system out of 
an 84 or an 87+ model (if you want the aux fan) to compare with the 
aftermarket products.  Be sure to really clean out a salvage system. 
 Mobile1 (or any synthetic) will help reduce the temperature, which you've 
already done.

Regards.

Received: from geglan.geg.mot.com by csn1.geg.mot.com (AIX 3.2/UCB 5.64/4.03)
          id AA16146; Fri, 30 Sep 1994 17:45:58 -0700
Received: by gegpo1.geg.mot.com with Microsoft Mail
	id <2E8CB3A7@gegpo1.geg.mot.com>; Fri, 30 Sep 94 17:56:07 MST
From: Frith Robert <p26051@gegpo6.geg.mot.com>
To: porschephiles <porschephiles@tta.com>
Subject: 911SC overheating
Date: Fri, 30 Sep 94 17:56:00 MST
Message-Id: <2E8CB3A7@gegpo1.geg.mot.com>

------------------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 10:38:03 U
From: "QM Admin" <QM_Admin@babylon.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  Clutch job for 1987 911

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE> Clutch job for 1987 911

> My question is: What do you recommend that we replace during the
> clutch job? Does everything need to be replaced (i.e. clutch disk, pressure
> plate, throw out bearing...) or can we just change the clutch disk and save
> ourselves some unnecessary expenses. One mechanic told us that we only need
> to change the clutch disk and another wants to change everything and then
add
> some new "kit" to the clutch package. I guess the "kit" is some kind of
> update to the transmission, can anyone enlighten me on this kit? 

When I had the clutch replaced on my 87, my mechanic performed an update that
changed the bearings the the throwout bearing fork rotates in and the fork.
This is appearantly a Porsche recommended update - before they did the work,
he explained the problem with the original needle bearings and showed me a
tech note describing the update. I also saw the old bearings while they were
still in the bell housing (is that a proper term for a p-car?) and they were
trashed. The pedal effort was much lower and smoother after the fix. I also
had the rubber center clutch plate (the cause for my clutch problems)
replaced with a spring centered clutch plate and it appears to work fine.

> Lastly, does
> $1500 sound reasonable for all parts and labor? 

If my memory is correct, I paid $1600 for the complete job including the
update. I think the update added 250-300 to the job.

Bill

------------------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 10:37:28 U
From: "QM Admin" <QM_Admin@babylon.saic.com>
Subject: 911SC overheating

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               911SC overheating


Lowell (netgod) wrote:
>My 1983 Targa is overheating at full throttle settings.
There's been a lot of discussions about 911 temperatures.  Interestingly, 
the owner's manual only says that when the temp gets to the red bar (in cars 
without numbered gauges) is the temperature excessive.  The bottom of the 
red bar translates to 302F degrees.  (The guages have degrees C printed on 
the far left side of the bars, back behind the face of the guage).  IMHO, 
Porsche either felt that less than 300 degrees was not too hot, they knew 
the cars would run very hot and did not want to scare owners or they wanted 
to sell lots of overheating-derived repairs (I think it's really choice 2). 


General concensus from the experts seems to be that 300 degrees is much too 
hot for long engine life.  A typical solution is to replace the front oil 
loop with either a factory or aftermarket oil radiator.  I've used both 
Terbotrol and B&B with the B&B appearing to work slightly better for my car, 
YMMV.  Depending on the how hot the climate where you live is, auxilliary 
cooler fans may be helpful. .  My temp (in Phoenix) still runs 230-240 when 
it's hot out, in traffic, with the air on so next year I'm going to add a 
fan.  You should price shop around salvage centers to find a system out of 
an 84 or an 87+ model (if you want the aux fan) to compare with the 
aftermarket products.  Be sure to really clean out a salvage system. 
 Mobile1 (or any synthetic) will help reduce the temperature, which you've 
already done.

Regards.

- ------------------ RFC822 Header Follows ------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 11:20:51 U
From: "CPQM Admin" <CPQM_Admin@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Euro911 heater

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               Euro911 heater


Barry Chapin wrote:
>In my 1981 Euro 911SC Targa, my heater control lever, located between the
>front seats, just to the right of the parking brake lever, does not work
>anymore.  <snip>  What is wrong with this european heater system (I think 
the US >system is different)?
This is a different system from the US models.  In my 83SC there is only the 
auto heat control dial, no levers.  Not having a manual for that car myself, 
I would venture a guess that the cable connected to the dial mechanism had 
failed.

>I do not have a manual on the car interior controls.
This should be in the regular owners manual.  You should be able to order 
one through a Porsche dealer.

>How do the dash levers control the temperature, in conjunction with the 
center >console?  What does the lever on the top left do (the one next to 
the fan speed
>control lever) ?
This lever controls fan speed for ventilation air.  As it moves from left to 
right it first opens fresh air vents and then turns on the fan.  It does not 
help increase warm air flow on car with the auto temp control (the "lever" 
controls do this).

>The levers on the dash are sort of stiff to move.  Is this normal?
They should not be real stiff.  You should feel just a slight resistance.

>Oh yeah-Does that little stubby rubber thermostat up by the rear view 
mirror really
>work as a climate control?
Yes it works well, as long as the connector wire hasn't come loose.  You can 
undo the screws that hold it up and check to see if the wire still makes a 
good connection.  If it has come loose, then the thermostat doesn't work.

Regards.

- ------------------ RFC822 Header Follows ------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 11:31:38 U
From: "CPQM Admin" <CPQM_Admin@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: 944 windshields

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               944 windshields

     To All,
     
     I just wanted to post a notice to everyone that has a 944x.
     I just went through a bad experience that actually turned out pretty 
     good at the end. I own a '86 944 and was changing the front hood 
     shocks when out of the blue the bottom of the shock just tapped the 
     bottom of the window and shattered about a one inch section of the 
     lower windshield. Needless to say this grew within a week to cover the 
     hole shield. For those of you that have ever cracked a 944 windshield, 
     you know that this is one of the most expensive w/s on the market at a 
     install price of avg. $1100. 
     On line here I was directed to one of the most friendly based 944 
     parts companies that you could ever deal with. 
     Porsche All 944 (1 800 255-7944) Even though they didn't have a W/S
     they where very helpful in directing me to someone that did.
     Glass Wholesalers (or Distributors) 800 421-1414 had factory OEM W/S 
     for $440. Once I received it, the company that was to install it 
     couldn't get it in. (To keep this as short as possible I will skip the 
     details. This glass does not go in like normal glass.)
     Don was eager enough to tell me that if they needed someone to walk 
     them through the process, via phone, he would. I was nervous having 
     someone put it in that had obviously had no experience with P-Cars.
     But they had more experience installing car glass than anyone in the 
     state. 
     In making a return call to Glass Distributors, Don tried to forewarn 
     me to be real careful with this W/S. He said,"we ship most of this 
     glass to people that are trying to change hoodshocks or readjust their 
     hoods". He commented that he was going to write a article to warn 
     people of this in an upcoming issue of Pana. At this point I had to 
     tell him of my idiotic adventure and that I wished that I had talked 
     to him sooner.
     After thinking about it, I decided to give an FYI to all here just in 
     case. Hopefully this will give you a heads up when playing under the 
     hood or around the windshield wipers. This is a very sensitive area.
     And, I would personally give a THUMBS UP! to both of the companies 
     listed above.
     
     Ed Montgomery
     '86 944 (White)


- ------------------ RFC822 Header Follows ------------------

Date: Sun, 2 Oct 94 23:27:49 PDT
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More Re: Lower noise-ratio->356list 


> Trond writes, "The porschephiles list is the *best* porsche list for general 
> purposes, but if you're mostly into the old 4cyl 4bangers the 'noise-ratio' 
> gets abowe 95%." 
 
> When I bought my new '61 Normal Coupe, I bought a Porsche. When I bought my 
> used '55 Speedster, I bought a Porsche. And, when I bought my used '86 951, 
> as a garage companion to the other two, I bought a Porsche. I'm interested 
> in every thing Porsche does - all Porsche cars. What in the world do your 
> mean, "noise-ratio?"  
 
Stan writes . . . 
 
OK, I'm a certifiable Porsche nut. I've had at least one each of the air  
cooled street cars, none each of the water cooled cars, have lusted after the 
Mooney with the Porsche engine, seriously considered getting my dad a 
Porsche Junior tractor, etc. This list is consequently for all things 
Porsche. 
 
I understand Trond's concerns though -- if I want to get a 356 specific 
answer, I have to wade through a PILE of non-356 stuff. In fact, the 
356 content is just about zero. So from *THAT* perspective, the signal 
(356 content) to noise (everything else) ratio is pretty bad. 
 
Here's the kicker: you find tidbits of info that are useful in all the 
other "non-356" stuff. Like welding tips from Kyle talking about 914s, 
or brake plumbing tips from Nathan Ulrich talking about race-grade 944s, 
or interior tips from people talking about concour prep for Carrera RSs. 
When we start splitting the list up, we lose that. 
 
My personal solution to this is to maintain my own private list of people 
that share certain interests -- on paper. That way I know who to shoot 
a private mail message to for a clear and concise response in real time 
about specialized topics. I've created my own personal network of contacts 
and people I turn to when I need info.  People I would not have met except 
via this list. People I would not have respected enough to value their 
opinions except for what I've heard of their advice and opinions on this 
list. 
 
So, if there *ARE* little specialized sub-lists out there, that's 
OK. My own interests are broad enough that it's not a requirement 
for me, and my ego needs are met via enough other things that I don't feel 
like I have to somehow "own" all the Porsche content in the world.  And I  
somehow figure that if there's a specialized list out there that  
I *should* be interested in, they'll find me... 
 
> A Porsche is a Porsche is a Porsche is a . . . . (except maybe those owned 
> by a DOS user). 
 
Or as a buddy of mine used to say (typically after working too close to 
either the propolene oxide or the beer fridge): "A Porsche is a great car 
unless it's a character in Shakespeare".... 8{P (lame, I know, but I'm 
just reporting it....) 
 
Stan 
 
- ------------------------------ 
 
I couldn't agree with Stan more! 
 
Furthermore, it's nice to be able to contribute from time to time general 
knowledge that has been gleaned from the 356 related work that I do. 
 
I do think it would be helpful to informally adopt as a standard (where 
appropriate) beginning each subject line with the model number (i.e. 356: 
<subject>), but since the list isn't broken (any more) . . . let's not fix it! 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B S90 Cabriolet 




------------------------------

Date: 3 Oct 1994 10:31:12 U
From: "QM Admin" <QM_Admin@babylon.saic.com>
Subject: Re: RE-Lower noise-ratio->35

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE>RE-Lower noise-ratio->356list

> Trond writes, "The porschephiles list is the *best* porsche list for
general
> purposes, but if you're mostly into the old 4cyl 4bangers the 'noise-ratio'
> gets abowe 95%."

> When I bought my new '61 Normal Coupe, I bought a Porsche. When I bought my
> used '55 Speedster, I bought a Porsche. And, when I bought my used '86 951,
> as a garage companion to the other two, I bought a Porsche. I'm interested
> in every thing Porsche does - all Porsche cars. What in the world do your
> mean, "noise-ratio?" 

OK, I'm a certifiable Porsche nut. I've had at least one each of the air 
cooled street cars, none each of the water cooled cars, have lusted after the
Mooney with the Porsche engine, seriously considered getting my dad a
Porsche Junior tractor, etc. This list is consequently for all things
Porsche.

I understand Trond's concerns though -- if I want to get a 356 specific
answer, I have to wade through a PILE of non-356 stuff. In fact, the
356 content is just about zero. So from *THAT* perspective, the signal
(356 content) to noise (everything else) ratio is pretty bad.

Here's the kicker: you find tidbits of info that are useful in all the
other "non-356" stuff. Like welding tips from Kyle talking about 914s,
or brake plumbing tips from Nathan Ulrich talking about race-grade 944s,
or interior tips from people talking about concour prep for Carrera RSs.
When we start splitting the list up, we lose that.

My personal solution to this is to maintain my own private list of people
that share certain interests -- on paper. That way I know who to shoot
a private mail message to for a clear and concise response in real time
about specialized topics. I've created my own personal network of contacts
and people I turn to when I need info.  People I would not have met except
via this list. People I would not have respected enough to value their
opinions except for what I've heard of their advice and opinions on this
list.

So, if there *ARE* little specialized sub-lists out there, that's
OK. My own interests are broad enough that it's not a requirement
for me, and my ego needs are met via enough other things that I don't feel
like I have to somehow "own" all the Porsche content in the world.  And I 
somehow figure that if there's a specialized list out there that 
I *should* be interested in, they'll find me...

> A Porsche is a Porsche is a Porsche is a . . . . (except maybe those owned
> by a DOS user).

Or as a buddy of mine used to say (typically after working too close to
either the propolene oxide or the beer fridge): "A Porsche is a great car
unless it's a character in Shakespeare".... 8{P (lame, I know, but I'm
just reporting it....)

Stan

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 00:13:56 EDT
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1984 911, Buying Questions

I have a 1980 911SC with over 200K miles which is driven daily and is still a
reliable and fun car. Although it's getting harder to find an SC with low
miles, they are still out there and are generally cheaper than 3.2 Carreras.
In our newsletter, SC's with similar mileage to an early 3.2 are usually $3 -
5k cheaper. They are both great cars though!

Good Luck! Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com
66 911, 67 911S, 80 911SC

Subject: Carrera 4

I don't know how to ask this without seeming stupid so I'll just take my
lumps. I am considering purchasing a new 993, or alternatively a new C-4.
What is the great advantage of a 4 wheel drive system in a sports car like a
Porsche? I know it will transmit power to all wheel simultaneously, making
for better traction, but does this really alter performance for the
recreational driving these cars are mostly used for? Is it worth the $6000
difference in cost? What other aspects of handling are affected? I appreciate
any and all opinions, even flames.

Thanks.

Gary

Date: Mon, 03 Oct 94 15:00:51 cdt
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: RE: 914 popped out of gear..no power



  Greg, and 914 folk..

  914 popped out of gear and no nothing go-go anymore!

  !! This sounds like what happened to me -1500 miles from home!
  It sounds like you stripped the center hub out of your clutch
disk.  Were you by chance accelerating and changing gears when 
this happened?  I bet you have a clutch with rubber pucks as torsional
shock springs in the clutch disk.  These can fail just like you
describe.  Have you been able to 'catch' it and make it grip long
enough to limp it to a shop?  How aged is your clutch and how was
it performing when hard accelerating (passing)?

  Sorry Greg, but I would say plan on getting at the very least
a new clutch disk.  umm, specify a steel spring center disk...

 -kyle

to come up, but I usually just pull the front edge back towards
the rear of the car slowly with a lot of force.

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 09:03:16 EDT
From: ClinTNS@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944S coolant leak

On Oct 3 Steve Elkins writes;
>Greetings,

>Several weeks ago I asked several questions about my 944S.  One of >these
had
>to
>
>Well, this weekend I found a nice small puddle under my car.  The >coolant
>seems
>to be comming from between the timing belt cover and the engine.  I >assume
>this
>means the seals on the water pump are going (gone?).  The leak is >still
quite
>small
>and I only found the puddle once, no new puddle since Saturday.

>Question:  How long can I run the car with this sort of a leak?  The >car
has
 Steve,
Take care of this problem immediately.  I've heard of guys driving
their cars with these types of leaks and never experiencing problems,
however, I had my water pump seize up on me and came within a
a fraction of MM of shearing my timing belt.  Luckily my mechanic
had the foresight to tell me to have the car flatbedded in rather than
driving it.  Water pumps are cheap compared to the damage you
can do if one seizes up on you.
Clint '86 951 
    



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 03 Oct 94 15:34:24 cdt
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: Welding and Don's 914 hinge rework.



  Don, and 'philers.

  Sorry, but cant help with your FI problem.  (ask me anything about
GM TBI and TPI systems tho')

  On your hinge rework..
  For these, a light weight MIG will do a wonderful job.  The stick
welder might just blow holes in the panel (which is the backside of
the wheelhouse) unless you are *very* good at stick welding panels.

  Replacing these is one of the easier tasks on a 914, and a great
starting point if you move on to other things in need of repair.
  The most difficult part is removing the remains of the old hinge
mounts in preparation for installing the new.  It is a cramped place
to work unless you got the powerplant out, even then...
  Remove the engine deck lid, its only two 10mm bolts.
  Another glitch in this task is those pesky springs, use the MIG
or buzz box to *make* the right tool for that job. practice, practice.

  But, in practicality you may be better off just prepping the car
and taking the mount(S)? and all to a welding shop for the one time
installation.  Be sure to mark where the old hinge mounts were so things
line up again as they should, umm use a pin drift to dent the panel
right thru the bolt hole and use that as the index for the new parts.
  I used 'rosette' welds to reattach the mount plates, and I hog
out a drain hole at the bottom of the 'cup' and coat with 'cold zinc'
after welding to prevent rust reoccurance.

  Oh, cant get the old bolts out?  Shame, these need lubrication to
keep 'em from seizing in the bearing surface.  That is what starts 
this process of breaking the mounts away from the spot welds.
  There is a fix tho' it entails drilling a hole into the bolt face
and inserting a zerk fitting, and cutting a groove and drilling a 
channel in the bearing surface to allow a shot of grease to fill in.
  Anyone know if these are available from aftermarket?  sources?

  Shoot me a note if you need more detail.

  -kyle     did we learn something from the "Ted tantrums"?
            perhaps that provocation results in retaliation.

------------------------------

Bob, I found this in my archives, so for your possible edification, here 'tis:

- ------------ Forwarded Message begins here ------------
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacd1.cacd.rockwell.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 1994 10:30:24 -0500 (CDT)
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Re:  State Farm Insurance

>My experience with State Farm has been good also, with some
>qualifications.  They clearly have no interest in insuring anyone with the
>slightest statistical chance of having an accident and they mercilessly
>"cherry pick".  I am presently in good with them but I currently have them
>insuring my house and four cars including a Ferrari and a 911.  Rates are
>very reasonable.  But, reality isn't very far away.  If you have any kind
>of an accident, even if clearly not your fault, you get rated and pay more
>for 5 years anyway.  They're not interested in details; if they pay our
>for any reason, you pay it back.  However, they do pay off fairly and
>quickly when it's their turn.  All things considered, they get good marks
>from me. However, If I were 25 years old, single, one speding ticket and
>driving a Corvette, They would hesitate about 5/8 of a second before
>showing that person the door.

This isn't exactly true.  I haven't had any problems with State Farm.
I've just turned 25 and my wife and I have our Porsche and BMW on
State Farm - no we don't own a house so we don't have home owners 
insurance through them.  I pretty much fit your description except
that I'm married and State Farm has some of the better rates I've
found.

Ross

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 09:39 EST

I think the company you mean is Glass Suppliers, Inc. in Sterling, VA, who
advertise in PANO.  Mention you're a PCA member and they'll give you a good
price.  I got a new SEKURIT windshield installed from them along with the rear
hatch re-glued for about $650.  Less than half what the dealer wanted :)
