Date: 4 Oct 1994 07:27:15 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Insurance

 10/4/94       7:14 AM        Subject:    Insurance
My 2 cents about insurance:  After about 10 years with CSAA (AAA for
California) I ended up switching to Nationwide and saving $500 per year. 
This surprised me because I price shopped on a regular basis and didn't think
that there could be that much savings available.  The savings were primarily
from the Porsche (951).  The total bill is $1600/year for three cars and two
drivers (clean records).  
'86 951  (my daily driver  8k miles per year)
'89 Nissan Maxima (wife's daily driver 18k miles per year)
'92 Ford Explorer 4WD (weekend pleasure rate)
The Porsche is the cheapest out of the three.
Nans



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 1994 14:14:50 -0400
From: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@tac3.vv.hac.com>
Subject: Re: 914 popped out of gear


I had the same problem on my 914.  After lots of good advice
from porschephiles I finally got smart and checked the
CV joints on the car.  It turned out that the right
inner CV joint had sheared.  

To find the problem I eventually jacked up the rear of
the car and manually turned the the rear wheels while looking
at the CV joints - and then ran the car in gear (with
help) and watched the CV joints.  Then it became obvious,
the inner CV joint would turn, but the half shaft
wouldn't.  Took me a while to find it though.

Good luck, Alex

into the lines replacing the vapor but this has not solved the problem.

love it, just doesn't always start when I want it to.

Subject: tires and N2

George-

On Oct.3 you answered a posting from Carl, and at the end of your answer  
you mentioned consumables, including nitrogen for tires.  This got my 
attention, because about a year ago a person who races some sort of 
stock-cars told me that he uses nitrogen in his tires, I think he said 
it reduces the pressure increase due to heating of the tires.  At the 
time I wondered if this really made any difference, since air, if I 
remember correctly, is abour 70 to 75% nitrogen.  I did not want to quiz 
him to hard and possibly offend him, since he loans me a set of electronic
wheel scales from time to time.  I would like to stay friendly with him.

Can  you explain what the advantage of inflating tires with nitrogen is, 
and is it really useful in driver training situations, with about 30 minute
run sessions.  I have used a pyrometer on my tires and they seem to run 
about 135 degrees.  I would appreciate any wisdom you can shed on this.

Thanks in advance

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 14:09 EST
From: "N. Jay Ellis" <0005008816@mcimail.com>
Subject: 951 wheel offset

In their otherwise very complete description of the differences between the 
944 Turbo and Turbo "S", someone recently stated that all 951s from 87 and on
can use the same wheels. I'm not sure if that's accurate, as the offsets were
changed in 87 and again in 88 for the 951 "S".  Here's the offsets (in mm) 
from the factory 951 manual (other p-philers please correct if this conflicts
with what you know):

Year            Front   Rear
- ----            -----   ----
<=86            23.3mm  23.3mm
87              52.3    52.3
88 non "S"      52.3    52.3   
88 951S         65      60   (928S4 brakes in front, 9" wheels in rear)
89 (all)        65      60   (Manual doesn't distinguish between the 88
                              951S and the 89, so I assume they're the same)

Some C2 models have the 52.3mm offset, so 87 and 88 951 (non-S) owners are in
luck for finding a second set of track wheels.   

Jay Ellis                                             
'87 951 Guards Red
500-8816@MCIMail.com
ellisn@iia.org





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 13:48:20 EDT
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944S coolant leak

>Well, this weekend I found a nice small puddle under my car.  The coolant
seems
>to be comming from between the timing belt cover and the engine.  I assume
this
>means the seals on the water pump are going (gone?).  The leak is still
quite small
>and I only found the puddle once, no new puddle since Saturday.

>Question:  How long can I run the car with this sort of a leak?  The car has
over 
>94000 miles on it and I have no idea when or if the pump has ever been
changed.  
>I had been planning on changing the water pump when I change the
timming/ballance >belts in about 6000 miles.  Can I wait this long for the
water pump replacement?

Steve,

FWIW, my water pump seized with NO warning except a very small trace of dried
coolant on the front of the engine case as you describe. There was no visible
leak. I foolishly decided to "let it get worse". Additionally, by waiting
until the pump seized, the core was gouged up by the impeller when the
bearing failed, making the core worth zero instead of $50.00. And then there
was the $150 worth of towing...

My advice is: replace the pump now.

Best of luck...

  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 13:02:17 PST
From: Len Schultz <Len_Schultz@ccm2.jf.intel.com>
Subject: 911 dolly ideas: Thank you


Text item: Text_1

     
     Thank you all for your dolly ideas.
     
     What I ended up doing was placing a hydraulic jack under the transmission 
     mount point under a "thin" 2x4 which ran the length of the support bracket.
     
     I placed another hydraulic jack under the engine block by the drain plug.  
     I ran a 2x4 along the length of the block until it ran into sensitive 
     areas.  I had another "thin" 2x4 running perpendicular.  The center crossed 
     the 2x4, and the ends touched the exhaust pipes.  I cut this "thin" 2x4 in 
     the center slightly to weaken it so most of the weight was on the 2x4.
     
     Dropping the engine was no problem for one person, and the hydraulic jacks 
     performed well as dollies.  It was easy to pull the engine out from under 
     the car.  I am now dismantling the damaged areas on this contraption.  It 
     is rather stable, as I was really yanking on some stuck bolts with no 
     problem.
     
     Hopefully installation will be just as easy....
     
     --Len Schultz
       '79 930
       '84 944

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 17:27:05 EDT

You can upgrade to those forged wheels with no concern about the rest of the
car. They are a direct bolt on.
As for the deck lid- it is not supposed to raise by itself. You are supposed
to lift it. If it popped up by inself it would excessively strain the hinges.

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 10:14:37 PDT
From: lemq@ccmail.apldbio.com
Subject: Re[2]: Clutch job for 1987 911



>When I had the clutch replaced on my 87, my mechanic performed an update that
>changed the bearings the the throwout bearing fork rotates in and the fork.
>This is appearantly a Porsche recommended update - before they did the work,
>he explained the problem with the original needle bearings and showed me a
>tech note describing the update. I also saw the old bearings while they were
>still in the bell housing (is that a proper term for a p-car?) and they were
>trashed. The pedal effort was much lower and smoother after the fix. I also
>had the rubber center clutch plate (the cause for my clutch problems)
>replaced with a spring centered clutch plate and it appears to work fine.

Does anyone know if there is a similar update for 84-86 Carrera? Will it make 
the clutch effort lighter? I have been procrastinating for the last year and a 
half on my 84 carrera clutch. But, it is now starting to grind downshifting to 
second gear while double clutching. It has always had a rough clutch take up 
action due to the rubber center plate. And the clutch effort is extremely high. 
If I can only reduce the clutch effort on this car, I would keep it for life. 
Else, does anyone want to buy an 84 Carrera Cabriolet with low miles?

Minh

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 94 15:11:57 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Carrera 4

> I don't know how to ask this without seeming stupid so I'll just take my
> lumps. I am considering purchasing a new 993, or alternatively a new C-4.
> What is the great advantage of a 4 wheel drive system in a sports car like a
> Porsche?                                                                  

No stupid questions, only stupid opinions...

Here in the northeast US, 4 wheel drive will allow you to flog your beloved
Porsche all year long, in snow up to about 6" deep.  Higher than that and
you risk highcentering.

Is it worth $6K more than the 2 wheel drive version?  Well, the previous
arrangement in the Carrera 4 made some pretty lousy drivers pretty good at
some track events.  We had one guy who refused to even come close to the
edges of Lime Rock Park, and he still managed to turn in some pretty good
times in a C4.

Perhaps a more pertinent question is whether or not the viscous setup will
be as responsive and durable as a full differential setup.  Methinks  that
a cheaper power transmission setup is the real reason that
the price delta (from C2 to C4) is less for the 993 C2 to 993 C4.

Anyhow, you pays your money and you takes your chance.

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944

George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 1994 14:48:35 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: Just Say No To Wimpy Exhausts

Fellow Porschephiles,

What's up with everybody wanting *quieter* exhausts? Haven't any of you
fallen in love with the raw, thunderous straight-piped exhaust belching
from the rear of a kick-ass race car? It's heaven to hear an engine
breathing free!!! I want my cars to sound like that. An exhaust note which
says "this car's got balls!" and wakes the neighbors at 3AM!!!

I'm currently running the Quiet Bursch exhaust on my '74 and the sound is
wonderful but it AIN'T LOUD ENOUGH!!! So I've ordered the glasspack Bursch
and I'll put that on this weekend. I'm even going to put the Bursch racing
megaphones on there after I put a set of Bursch headers on it early next
year and see how loud that is. Probably get me a ticket for noise-ordinance
violation!!! ;-> Has anybody run the megaphones? How do they sound?

My Turbo still has the stock exhaust and it's pitifully quiet. I'm definitely
going to straight-pipe the wastegate and put a B&B exhaust system on it
next year. A friend has a 400+ HP 930 that rumbles and spits at low RPMs
and sounds like it doesn't even want to run. Then on boost it'll blow you
away!! I *LOVE* that!!!

Anybody else sing the praises of a tumultuous exhaust sound?

Dustin Boyette
ldg@mercury.interpath.net
1974 911 Carrera, Signal Green
1978 930, Grand Prix White
1981 Lancia Beta Coupe 2000, Silver

Date: Tue, Oct 4, 1994 1:11 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4

Hi Gary,

If you (or anyone else) is interested in the Factory press release, that
addresses your specific questions, send me your fax number and I'll fax it
to you.

> I don't know how to ask this without seeming stupid so I'll just take my
> lumps. I am considering purchasing a new 993, or alternatively a new C-4.
> What is the great advantage of a 4 wheel drive system in a sports car like a
> Porsche? I know it will transmit power to all wheel simultaneously, making
> for better traction, but does this really alter performance for the
> recreational driving these cars are mostly used for?

I am told that there is a decided difference in handling characteristics 
between the 964/C-4 and the 993/C-4, in that it was practically impossible
to induce oversteer (hang the tail out) in the earlier version, while the
993 version allows this.  Pete Albrecht might have a word or two to add on
this, since he was among the select group that got to test the (rare) V-6
version for AutoWeek.

> Is it worth the $6000

This is the classic YMMV.  What's $6000 among friends?  How do you like 
driving your *normal* 911 when things get wet and slippery?  (No Pete, I'm
not in MY Porsche under *those* conditions either...)  For that matter,
do you *ever* plan to expose your expensive toy to such conditions?

> What other aspects of handling are affected? 

Well, it is 150 lbs heavier than the normal 993.  I suspect that the
extra grip will offset the extra avoirdupois, with the net result being
merely a *different* feel.  You might like it, or you might not, Quien Sabe?

Check it out, my friend; then these mysteries will be revealed to you...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 04 Oct 1994 12:59:19 -0600
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: 914 Q about engine swaps (was 914's  with transplanted V8's)

Kyle writes about the availability of
  >  914's with american powerplants:
(at least one anyway).

I've seen one of these, and, in its favor, it goes like a bat out the Fire.
I never drove it so I can't comment on its handling, but I don't expect it
handled well--too much rear weight bias.  Were I going to try swapping a V8
into the 914 (I'm not, BTW) I'd think about an lighter alloy engine.  Hmm...
I wonder if a 928 power plant would fit.  That'd keep things in the family.

The major problem, however, with any engine swap that brings appreciable
power gains is that the rest of the car must be beefed up to handle that
extra power. Bigger brakes, more rubber on the road, beefier chassis,
stronger transaxle, new electrical systems (something has to drive the
transplanted injection system), etc.  These are the things that tend to push
these kinds projects into the hyperexpensive realms.  Additionally, one has
to keep the end product in mind.  Will if provide the charms of original 914
only with more power or will it be an uncontrollable beast?  ('Course my
wife claims my stock 914 is an uncontrollable beast).

Now, a question from the dreamer in me that wants shoehorn a late-model 911
power plant into the middle of my 914.  What really are the mechanical
issues to create a tractable automobile?  Anybody BTDT and survived to crow
about it?  I'd just like to how deep into the pipe I've been dreaming.  

Stph


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 08:10:57 CST
From: "Mike Selner Jr" <mike@MR.Net>
Subject: Re: 944S coolant leak

On Mon, 3 Oct 94 12:37:37 -0700, 
Steve Elkins  <spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov> wrote:

>
>Greetings,
>
>Several weeks ago I asked several questions about my 944S.  One of these had to
>do with coolant disapearing and not knowing where it was going.
>
>Well, this weekend I found a nice small puddle under my car.  The coolant seems
>to be comming from between the timing belt cover and the engine.  I assume this
>means the seals on the water pump are going (gone?).  The leak is still quite small
>and I only found the puddle once, no new puddle since Saturday.

To use the Ed McMahon phrase: "You are CORRECT, Sir!".

>
>Question:  How long can I run the car with this sort of a leak?  The car has over 
>94000 miles on it and I have no idea when or if the pump has ever been changed.  
>I had been planning on changing the water pump when I change the timming/ballance belts 
>in about 6000 miles.  Can I wait this long for the water pump replacement?
>
>Are there any signs to watch for that show a imminent failure?  
>

I have seen them dribble for 6mos. (My '87 944S did that) and I have
also seen them puke all at once.  I think there is potential for 
belt and/or roller damage if excessive coolant gets in the area by the 
belts.  I think I'd change it before any trips or demanding driving.

It's an expensive proposition, but it is wise to check all the radiator 
hoses and the timing/balance belt rollers at this time.  Also you should 
check the balance shaft oil seals (right behind the balance shaft 
sprockets) and the front crankshaft seal.
(sigh) and also it might be time to do the power steering hose(s).
The one that goes in front of the water pump has been updated to
a version which goes behind the fat radiator hose.  This will
clean up that area from oily crud and ease access to the water pump.

Check out Jim Pasha's article in Excellence Magazine about belts and
water pumps.  I think it was August 94.

>Thanks for any advice.
>
>Steve '87 944S
>

Mike Selner, Jr                             mike@mjs.com  
Manager, Systems Development                612-454-9201  voice
MJS Systems, Inc                            612-454-7699  facs

------------------------------

Date: 4 Oct 1994 09:01:09 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Zone 7 AutoX (long)

Zone 7 AutoX (long)
    I had a good weekend.  I wish I'd been there both days, but
I was kinda busy Saturday...
    The course was surprisingly fast.  I was warned that Laguna
Paddock autocrosses were almost always a big triangle--this one
was, but it was well-disguised.  Two tight hairpins, two nice
straights, and a lot of twisties for one of the corners.  I was
able to hold 3rd gear through about 1/4 - 1/3 of the course,
which is unusual for me.
    Several people (including some *fast* people!) complimented
me on my time--46.1 or so.  My former Nemesis, Bert Del Villano,
who has since moved up to "Improved" class with A008RS tires,
only beat me by about a second.  The tires are supposedly good
for about 2-3 seconds on this length of course, so I'm very very
happy with that!
    My "bucking" problem turned out to be a $6 vaccuum hose (to
the vaccuum advance on the distributor) instead of the $50+ tranny
mounts that I replaced.  Oops--but they needed to be done anyway.
    My new tires are working out wonderfully.  I got the same type
of tire--A509--but in 195/50-15, instead of the /60s I was using.
What a difference!  I don't know if the other tires are just too
old or what, but the car seemed to hold a lot better, and I was
getting a *lot* more feedback from the car.  For the first time
ever, I was able to detect the back end losing grip before it was
completely gone, and correct it without losing *major* amounts of
time.  I am *VERY* happy with the new tires!  Low profile, stiff
sidewall is definitely the way to go--the heck with the harsher
street ride--"Toys are to be played with!"
    The next event is on the 15th, up at the Sonoma County Airport.
Come out and play!  Test the limits of yourself and your car, im-
prove your driving and car-awareness, raise your heart rate, give
yourself a big shot of adrenaline, and GO FAST!  Safely.

- --DD
vroooOOOOOoooommmm....

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 08:42:02 PDT
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Remedy for Windshield Wiper "Shudder"


- --Boundary-4201524-0-0

Thomas: 
 
Yes, I've been living with the problem for so long, I sort of take it for 
granted.  That's why I thought I'd give the list a try . . . just in case 
someone had a miracle solution. 
 
In any event, I think I'll publish the feedback I receive once the results are 
tabulated. 
 
As for Rain-X, I think it's great - at least the stuff for the outside of the 
windshield.  I use it on the windsheild of my 356 and in all but the heaviest 
downpour I can get by without the wipers.!  I once drove the ~50 miles from 
Sacramento to Palo Alto in a pretty steady light rain without using the 
wipers, although I wouldn't recommend trying that at night. 
 
One caveat about Rain-X: It seems to be sensitive to window cleaners that are 
heavy on ammonia which causes the windsheld to develop a thin haze when it 
dries.  However, the haze is easily removed with a soft, dry cloth to no 
apparent ill effect as far as the Rain-X functionality is concerned. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@oracle.us.com) 
1962 356B Super 90 Cabriolet

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 08:48 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Bearings

Ross,

Sounds like you are describing the control arm ball joint, and not
the wheel bearings.  On the 85.5 and later cars, they are not
separately replaceable.  I have been told that the ball joints are
peened into the aluminum arm, a one-time operation it would seem.

There is an outfit in Texas, if memory serves, advertising an
alternative repair or replacement.  Their ads run in Panorama.  I
don't know what it is they do.  If you (or anyone) does decide to
give them a try, be cautious.  Having a control arm ball joint fail
could be a pretty dangerous thing.

Buying a good used arm is tempting.  Make sure you trust the fellow
you buy it from.  944's get recycled because they get totalled,
generally.  When they get totalled, it's 'cause they hit something
real good.  And when they hit something, it's usually with the
front end of the car -- can you say understeer?!  The *only*
recycler I trust for a part like this, personally, is 944 Ecology,
owned and operated by Porschephiles' very own George B.

The way you check a ball joint (either control arm or tie rod) is
by lifting the lower half (the cup) and looking for play between
the cup and the ball (upper part).  The easiest way to do this is
with a large pair of pipe wrench pliers ("channel locks"), placing
one jaw under the bottom and the other, typically, over the pinch
clamp which captures the ball rod coming out the top of the joint.

Puhn suggests in his book that manufacturers will give you a wear
limit spec., but I have yet to see one from Porsche.  If you see
more than a millimeter, swallow hard.  Remember that there is sort
of a "servo" action to play: as things start to get loose, they
then can pound harder and accelerate wear.

Y'all should check your ball joints as periodic maintenance items.
In addition to checking for play, look for slashed or leaking rubber
boots.  Pretty common, and you can replace them with boots available
from VW/Audi.  But only if you catch them early enough.  The ball
joints get overlooked by a lot of PCA track event tech inspectors,
probably because they have to get under the car!

WRT the power steering rack, the bleed procedure is to turn the
steering wheel from lock to lock a number of times, topping off the
reservoir as needed.  If you are stil symptomatic after trying this,
it may be that something is wrong with the pump or rack.  Make sure
the pump belt is tensioned properly.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Tue,  4 Oct 94 11:14:49 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: 944 S2 vs Turbo S

I am curious how many of the Turbo S upgrades appear on the S2.
I know the S2 has the big brakes and I believe it has the same
suspension upgrades.  Did the S2 come standard with
LSD, the trany cooler, and hardened gears?  The note below
says that the S2 did not have the forged wheels.

I am evaluating what my next car should be.  I want a step up from
my '84 944.  The car will be used for everything: daily driver, auto-x,
and driver's ed at the track.  Seems like the S2 would have an
advantage in auto-x and in stop and go traffic because of the
lack of turbo lag.  The turbo, of course, would be faster at the
track.  Anyone driven both and care to comment?  You turbo
owners, do you notice the turbo lag when autocrossing or in
traffic?

Thanks,

    Eric
- ----------
| From: James K Benson  <jbenson@ecn.purdue.edu>
| Subject: 944 Turbo information
| Date: Friday, September 30, 1994 1:25PM

<some stuff deleted>

| Transmission:
| 	The limited slip differential with external transmission oil
| 	cooler is standard on the S.  It's an option on the other
| 	Turbos.  Also, first and second gears are given an additional
| 	heat treatment to withstand the additional torque developed by
| 	the engine.
|
| Suspension:
| 	Koni adustable shocks on all four corners.  The front struts
| 	are double adjustble, for stiffness and ride height.  The front
| 	springs are stiffer, about 165 lbs/in over 130 lbs/in for the
| 	stock suspension.  The front sway bars are 26.5 mm and rear are
| 	18 mm.  Off hand I can't remember the dimensions for the standard
| 	car but they are somewhat less.  The rear torsion bars on the
| 	Turbo S are also larger diameter.  In addition, all the rubber
|        	suspension bushings on the Turbo S are made of a stiffer compound.
|
| Brakes:
| 	Front brakes on the Turbo S are the same as the 928 S4.  They
|         are substantially larger than a standard Turbo.
|
| *(Wheels, offsets, etc.)*
|    An 88 Turbo S or '89 will have the 7 and 9 x 16 in. forged
| seven spoke "Club Sport" wheels.  The 944 S2 and early C2/C4 seven spoke
| wheels are the cast version, sometimes called "Design 90" wheels.  Forging
| is a better manufacturing process than casting.  Forged wheels are
| stronger than cast.  They are less likely to crack.  Any wheel off a 944
| from 1987 on will fit any other 944 in that year range.  The wheel offsets
| were changed in 1987 to accommondate the ABS option, whether the car had the
| option or not.  The C2/C4, RS Amer, 968, C2 Turbos, etc.., all have the
| ABS offset hubs (Fuchs will not fit on a C2).  Therefore, the new 17 in.
| 5 spoke wheels will fit on any '87 or newer 944.  For a 944 Turbo, I'd
| recommend the 7.5 and 9 x 17 set that the 968 w/ M030 came with.

------------------------------

On Mon, 3 Oct 94 09:27:39 PDT James Pasha said:

>The cost to change belts should be no more than $250. If a shop want to
>charge you more, find out why. The belts are no more than $75 and the
>time to change is about two hours (turbos are more) ALL belts, cam and
>balance shafts must be timed together. If the mechanic doesn't know how
>to do it in that time, find another one.

I had a shop tell me it was 7-8 hours labor to change JUST the timing
belt.  Needless to say, I ran VERY far away holding onto my wallet.

>Always recheck tension with the gauge. Remember to have it re-checked
>2,000 miles after initial installation.
>

Jim, I have an '87 944S with the self tensioner. Does it hurt to
set the tension more often than what is recommended?  I've already
done the 2000 mile retention.  Would it hurt to set it every 5000
miles?  I mean, it's so easy to do.

>least and remain in time.

My belt is a Pirelli. Had the latest part number. I got both belts
and all the rollers from Zims for < $200.  Is this belt the $180
belt Kevin was referring to? I hope so.

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 1994 09:46:08 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for October

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                  (last revised October 4, 1994)                     +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It will be posted 
regularly, once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are 
undoubtedly additions changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited 
in improving the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of 
the FAQ.

The only change this month is the inclusion of an item on oil additives 
(Slick-50, etc.).

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative 
issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting
all of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with
slow mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want
to convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          President, NetSmiths, Ltd.
          2025 Lincoln Highway
          Edison, NJ 08817

     He lives in Houston TX and works in Edison NJ (Don't bitch about 
*YOUR* commute): 
          Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
                   voice:  (713) 661-2084 
                   FAX:    (713) 661-0633
          Edison:  e-mail: stan@netsmiths.com 
                   voice:  (908) 287-8070 
                   FAX:    (908) 287-3883

     His cars currently include:  
          '81 Euro 911SC Targa (daily driver when he's where it is)
          '74 914 2.0 (SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)
          '64 356 SC (OK, so he fell in love again).

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

    Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available via FTP at tta.com in /pub/porschephiles/
Archives in five subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94) each of which has 
the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: This FAQ; also specific FAQs about specific Porsche models
are being added (so far there's only one, for the 914--feel free to
contribute one on YOUR favorite Porsche).
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state of residence, their car's year and model, and their net
address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the information,
and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out on a monthly
basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't send your Alfa
Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send submissions or changes 
to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1-703-922-9300

Does take non-US membership.  You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to
join.  Hours are 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.  Have 
your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number(s) handy, if you own a car, 
or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your 
check.  National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is 
reachable via e-mail at n_weissenberger@harvard.edu.  You can ask her 
for info or get her to send you an application as well.

          Porsche Club of Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1-313-558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the
classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1-619-325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1-215-652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     Porsche Cars North America, for a fee of $20, will research the 
original bill of sale for your car and give you a Certificate of 
Authenticity stating the facts and figures for the car as it was 
delivered to the dealer.  If you're interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What models of streetable Porsches have been made over the years?

     356  - The original Porsche sports car, built from 1948 until 
            1965; various engine and drivetrain components and various 
            styling variations existed.
     550  - Really more of a racer in the fifties, but driven on the
            street as well; this is the car James Dean died in.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the coming
            993.  Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Through its long life, many many variations, from the
            original 2.0 litre car to the new 3.8 litre RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1967 through
            1970.
     912E - The 911 with a four-cylinder engine from the 914, 1976.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between 
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6 
            was a variant with a two litre 911 engine inserted in place 
            of the four-cylinder engine.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine, updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain.
            Has the best aerodynamic shape of any Porsche.
     928  - The high end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5 litres 
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5 litre displacement, except for a 2.7 litre
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3.0 litre 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative.  2.85 litre, four valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive.
     964  - Another name for the 911 Carrera 4 and Carrera 2 as introduced
            in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992.  Most noteworthy feature
            is variable valve timing.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 4/94.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT - Been there, done that
     FAQ  - Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
     FWIW - For what it's worth
     IMHO - In my humble opinion
     IMO  - In my opinion
     PCA  - Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     POC  - Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     PCGB - Porsche Club of Great Britain
     PCNA - Porsche Cars of North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PANO - Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
     PAG  - Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     WWW  - World Wide Web
     YMMV - Your mileage may vary
     :-)  - Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to "read"
            it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years

=======================================================================

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

     Free catalog.

=======================================================================

What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?

There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for you
depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the technical
articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of their
Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's executive
office.

What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  
If you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note:
Information about water-cooled cars is lacking; those with favorites
should submit them to one of the names at the end of this FAQ.)

     Bruce Anderson
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Duane Spencer
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     Dr. Brett Johnson
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Charles O. Probst
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Fred Puhn
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Harry Pellow 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
 

There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While the
Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications.
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Bruce was invited to join and did so back in '91. The load then
was too much for him.  All of what, 2k a day or so.  Now, at 15x to 20x
that load, he probably doesn't want back on.  He's not stupid -- he 
knows where we are.

     No specifics are available regarding other renowned Porsche people.
If they want to be known, they will announce their presence.  (Besides,
your definition of "renowned" may differ from mine.)

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute can do
so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are always
welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Date: 04 Oct 94 19:26:42 EDT

Subject: New 911 powerplant

Hi, George.
 
I had nothing to do with the V6 thing. But interesting that it reappeared
(g). It's like the OJ thing. One TV station generates BS, and the others all
gobble it up with a fork and spoon because it must be true, after all it
was reported by da Media.
 
I run the numbers, provide the results to their staff, along with my
transcribed comments which they weave into the story if they like. I don't
write the story or provide the tech specs.
 
The price on the coupe is lots lower than they quoted, $59,900. The cab is
$68,200
 
Pete

a relief to Darren and others.  The price of 944S/S2/968 timing belts

list back in the spring, but is about half that or less now.

Jim tells me that Automotion has the latest, .02, Pirelli part, which
they apparently sell for about $35.

Of course, I have one of the $183 belts in my car!

Kevin

Import Dismantlers. My Stoddard catalog doesn't show it either.
 
It may be possible to replace just the tapered roller bearings. Is the
finger itself worn or damaged? A good bearing supply shop may be able to
help.

Is this job for the pros only. 
Experts, please advise,

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 1994 20:56:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

Bruce -

Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget 
about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us 
both know.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-GGR
SCCA-SFR

------------------------------

Date: 04 Oct 94 19:26:34 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 alignment questions

Hi, Trevor.
 
At the track, you'll see racers using a Dunlop gauge to set camber. They're
not terribly expensive but the home shop still won't get enough use out of
one to justify it.
 
You can set your own toe-in fairly accurately if you have a flat garage
floor. With the wheels pointed straight ahead, CAREFULLY push a tack into
the tire tread at the back of the tire (at the level of the axle). Drop a
plumb bob over the pin, and carefully mark the location of its pointer on
the garage floor. I use some tape, put a dot on it. Now roll the car forward
1/2 tire rotation, so the pin is now at the front of the tire, again at axle
height, and do the same. With a steel tape measure, carefully measure the
distance between the front and rear marks. Subtract, and that's your toe-in
expressed as a distance. If you need it expressed in degrees, just do some
trigonometry using the tire diameter (not the distance you've rolled it).
Angle = arctan (distance difference/tire diameter).
 
There are other settings, of course, and as far as I know you need fancier
equipment to do them.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 04 Oct 94 22:20:03 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: Remedy for Windshield Wiper "Shudder"

Michael Hodos writes:

"Has anyone figured out how to reliably stop the windshield wiper shudder that
seems to develop a few days into the rainy season? "

I use Bosch wipers, and had the same problem last winter.  Near the end of the
season I asked my foreign parts guy what he thought was going on.  He said that
the wipers leave a little trace of themselves on the windshield, and then stick
on that deposit as they're traversing it.  He said alcohol would remove it.

Well, I looked, and sure enough there was barely visible set of vertical streaks
of faint grey in the area where the skipping ocurred, which came off with
rubbing alcohol.  As I recall, no streaks after that.

I never heard of a preventive measure, though.

On a similar subject, Al Schlegel of the local (San Diego) PCA recommends
cleaning the wiper blades with a small amount of lacquer thinner, and then
treating with a small amount of Armorall, as a way of making the blades last
longer.  I tried this on both the 928 and our Taurus, and it did bring both sets
of streaky blades back to life.  Perhaps this will also cut down on the on-glass
deposits.

Alan Watkins ('86 928)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 02:03:14 +0100 (MET)
From: joker@diku.dk
Subject: Re: Euro parts sources, avoid Freisinger

> Hi, Allen.
>  
> Regarding parts sources in Europe, I don't know too many, but I do know
> enough to avoid Freisinger. It's a long story and he's the subject of
> several inside jokes at Porsche, but it's probably best to leave it at that.
> I have friends who used to work at Porsche and who live about 5 miles from his
> shop in Karlsruhe. They come over here during business trips to buy parts
> every few years, and I often ship stuff to them.
>  
> Pete
>  

I'll second that. About two years ago I was in germany when my cluth gave
it's last breath rather suddenly costing a defective 2nd gear also. 

But since I was nearby and the shop I usually use (in Denmark) knows
Freisinger I went to him. He could fix it all in one day, he said, 
and he did. Only thing is, that I got a bill of DM4500 (=$3k) for  
a new cluth and fixing the gearbox. He had not only fixed the 2nd gear
but almost renovated the entire gearbox completely!!!

That would have been fine, except that the gearbox was only 2 months
old, COMING FROM FREISINGER HIMSELF!!!

The bill was shipped to Denmark (my usual shop) who told him this and
he reduced the price to around $2k, which was still a bit high. 

Bottom line: DON'T USE FREISINGER...

Christian

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 94 16:14:35 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: Critters under 914's

>> 
>> On a non-related thread:  There was a discussion about "varmits".
>> I had to place a tent of plastic over my 914, then roll a bug-bomb
>> underneath.  Seems I had a nest of red wasps in the bumper.  The
>> next morning, there were about a dozen dead wasps under the plastic.  
>> They tried to fly out when the bomb went off, but they were trapped
>> under the plastic.  NOW maybe I can adjust the clutch cable!
>> 

Sounds familar.  A few years back, a friend and I were going to change
my tie rods on my 914 - an upgrade to the turbo units.  After dropping
the inspection plate/cover under the front suspension, we found
ourselves face to face with a _large_ black widow spider - inches
away. 

I did the plastic tent (plus a car cover) and a couple of bug bombs to
get rid of any others that my have been under the car (the first one
was adopted as the garage mascott).  

After the encounter, with my 914 being black, the nickname "the Black
Widow" was adopted for my car - which now sports a spiderweb and a red
hour-glass.

Still, driving home that night after finding the first spider was an
interesting experience.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914 "Black Widow"


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 2 Oct 94 14:34:08 -0700
From: Patty Winter <winter@apple.com>
Subject: Mini Porsche Parade in Yosemite :-)


Evidently I'm not the only one who considers the Yosemite area to
be Porsche driving heaven. I was heading from the valley to Glacier
Point yesterday afternoon when somewhere near El Capitan, I spotted
what looked like a black 993 in the other lane a ways ahead of me.

As I got a little closer, I saw what appeared to be another 993 ahead
of the that one. And another, and another, and....Well, to make a
long story short, there were six New 911(tm)s in a row, all sporting
manufacturer's license plates from Nevada. Presumably some PCNA folks
trying out the new toys for the weekend.

A couple of them waved as I went by. The others didn't; either they
were too intent on their driving (only 35 mph and not exactly a
challenging road), or they didn't deign to acknowledge a 944. :-)   
I briefly considered pulling in ahead of the front one--there being 
few opportunities for a 944 driver to have six 911s trailing behind her
- --but I was trying to get to Sentinel Dome by a certain time and also
had to be ready to make a left turn soon, so I just kept going.

For the record, there was one silver, one black, one bright yellow,
two of a plum color (similar to a beautiful Ferrari 308 I saw once),
and I think the sixth one may also have been black. No Guards' Reds,
which seems odd for a group of six Porsches. :-) 

A few hours later, I went past a 356 that was going up the Chinquapin
Road, and I also saw a couple of other 911s. Dunno where the other
944 folks were; there must have been some secret 944 convention
somewhere else I didn't know about. :-)

I had a great time driving in on Highway 120, going to and from 
Sentinel Dome via the Chinquapin and Glacier Point Roads, and leaving
the park on Highway 140 (the Merced River Canyon). I can't actually
prove that God made the Sierra Nevada for the benefit of sports-car
drivers, but I think I could make a good case that Caltrans made the
roads for us. :-)


Patty
'86 951 Garnet Red "Pfeffer"
'92 Feline Brown Tabby "Sara Feathertail"


------------------------------

Date: 4 Oct 94 18:02:35 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: re: 914 aux air regulator

I've known my AAR was bad for a long time, since I had to live with a
really low (almost stalling) idle during warmup and high idle afterwards,
but never really was into fixing it until the recent thread.

So I thought I'd share my opinions about my fix.  I tried soaking and
banging the AAR to free the valve (and 12 volts), but I'm an impatient
type and didn't want to wait the possible two weeks as some other
porschephile wrote, so I took more drastic measures.  I pried the bottom
part away from the valve/hoses part, since the metal, although thick
gauge, was just 'wrapped' around the flat area of the valve.  This showed
the simple internals.  The bottom is not in any way linked to the top,
inside the metal can is a plastic housing and a sort of filament.  As
most of you know, this heats up when the 12 volts is applied to the wire
and the case is the ground.

The bimetal 'spring' is placed as close to the filament as possible, but
is only connected to the other half, ie the valve.  The spring can be
pulled off the valve shaft after a small adjustment screw is removed.
Then you can just turn the shaft by hand while using your preferred lube
on the shaft and the valve.  Reassemble with the adjustment in the same
position.

This all assumes you can live with re-sealing the unit with high temp
silicone or something, and have some pry marks on it.

Depending on where the valve decided to freeze at, applying 12 volts might
be the opposite of what you would want to do to free it.  Looking at
the valve through the hose fitting, it is important to know that it rotates
(counter clockwise while heating, when looking down on it as mounted in
the engine compartment), and that there is about a 6mm long slot in it.
If you can't see the slot at all, it is frozen in warmed-up mode.  If you
can see a lot of the slot, it is frozen in cold mode, and 12V might help
loosen it while soaking.

Mark Skala
mvmas@mvusa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: 05 Oct 94 00:33:38 EDT
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: 951 Wheel Shimmy Revisited Again!

I am running out of solutions concerning a front end shimmy problem that I
have had for quite some time now. I will give you a brief history on the car
and explain what work has been performed. The car is an 86' 944 Turbo.
I purchased the car 10/93, with 85K almost a year ago.(near perfect Condition)
It came equipped with 928 Type/ "Phone Dial" wheels. The option sticker 
revealed a forged wheel option 7" & 8" Fuch's. I then found out that the 
"Phone Dial" wheels were the wrong offset (they were 87' wheels for the 
changed front end geometry). Someone pulled a fast one!! The shimmy did not 
seem to show up until I changed the front brake pads. I did not replace the 
wheels in the exact position on the hub. Live and learn. I had  both wheels 
balanced, the shimmy changed slightly. I then had a P-Mechanic take a look at 
the front end. He said that the upper strut bearings were bad and needed to be
replaced. I did this @ 90 K and also replaced the front shocks with Koni Sport
shocks.(yellow) No change! A very reputable P-Mechanic test drove the car and 
said that my Pirelli p-700's steel belts had probably shifted. He said that 
this was common with the Pirelli's. I replaced all 4 tires (was time any way) 
with BF Goodrich Comp T/A ZR-4's. I also sold my 87' Phone Dials and replaced 
them with the proper Fuch's (brand new from Robert Wood).  At this time a four
wheel alignment was performed. He also checked my work (strut replacement). 
After spending hudreds of dollars the front end felt great. I was a happy 
camper. No pull. Steering wheel now perfectly centered. No shimmy! Well, not 
very often or very servere anyway. Since then I have put 5000 more miles on 
the car. It gradually got worse as time went by. The shimmy in the steering 
wheel is now a constant problem. It doesn't favor a certain speed, it happens 
for several miles then stops completely for a brief time. At speeds (50+) the 
steering wheel actually shakes my arm. I tried having the wheels balanced on 
the car. The drivers side front did not balance correctly, The mechanic said: 
"that my tire was probably bad!" Doesn't anyone know what they are doing??  
Help!!! Now the shimmy is even worse! At times I can feel vibration in my legs
and feet!

As far as I know , the rotors are original. New pads @ 86 K

I checked the wheels & tires for truness. They look perfect.

On warm days when the brakes are heated up, I get a rubbing sound when I
apply the brakes. The vibrating/rubbing sound will disappear when I
apply hard pressure to the pedal. Rotors Warped? 

I have tried the technique where you apply the brakes when the problem occurs,
while keeping a constant speed. No change with the shimmy. No shimmy during 
braking.

I also have some movement in the front wheels at the top of the strut, when I 
move the wheel top to bottom. I have been told that this is normal? Side to 
side is nice and solid.
Possible wheel bearings? Had those checked 7K ago, they were adjusted, and
said to be fine by the "mechanic" who said I needed upper strut bearings!

I am at a loss. Maybe suspension components? Everything looks OK?

PLEASE HELP!!! This problem is driving me crazyyyyyyyyyyyyy!!!!!!!

If there are any sugestions anyone can give I would greatly appreciate your 
help.

Mike Kehr  86' 951  Guards Red

Date: Wed, 05 Oct 94 07:57:25 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in tires

I suspect your chain is being yanked a bit. Serious racers use nitrogen in
their tires as it does not expand as much as air when heated. therefore tire
pressures stay more stable over a wider variety of heat ranges. The REALLY
serious racers and professionals do this. At the early stages of track play
it is not needed.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Wed, 05 Oct 94 11:40:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 p-brake question


There are two adjustments.  One is a jam nut on the linkage at the hand 
brake
lever.  The other is a "star" adjuster inside each of the rear rotor hats. 
 It may be that
all one of these cars need is a little adjustment.  Or the shoes may be 
smoked,
and they are depressingly expensive last time I checked (which was a bunch
of years ago).  It is quick and easy to pop the rear rotors off and probably 
worth
doing as part of a pre-purchase inspection.

Kevin

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 14:08:37 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Nitrogen

The deal is that the nitrogen is dry, no water. That means that the
pressure change with temperature (PV=nRT, for an ideal gas) isn't affected
by the ambient humidity.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (944 turbo)(NEW Clutch!)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Wed, 05 Oct 94 11:35:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 911 Valve Cover Studs


Dustin,

>Also, what is the best stuff to put on them when I put the new ones back in
>the cam housing so they won't easily come out again? Locktite?

Time out -- think about what it is you're proposing to do.  You have a stud
and nut which may be junk, right?  So as you turn the nut, the stud backs 
out,
making replacement easy.  Now, let's say you had put a litte red Loctite on
it last time -- what would happen?  Uh, you'd rip the nut off and have a 
junk
stud staring you in the face, locked to the cam housing.

Studs back out, head gaskets blow out, and rocker arms break, and we're
all the better for it.

Kevin

Date: Wed, Oct 5, 1994 8:31 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: 1987 911 Carerra Sound System

Hi Jose,

> I finally purchased a black 1987 911 Carerra!   Anyway, I need to upgrade the
> blaubangt sound system in order to continue enjoying my CD's <g>. Any
> recommendations as to CD Receiver model and speakers for the 911 acoustics? I
> don't want to change the orginal interier or speaker layout if I can help it.

Congratulations!  There's really no need to replace your blaupunkt system if
you want to keep the car original.  You can easily add a CD changer under the
hood with a remote in the cockpit.  I have an inexpensive Panasonic 6-disk
changer with a wired remote.  It plays thru the Blaupunkt radio, tuned to 
87.9 (not sure of the exact freq, check the manual that comes with the 
changer).  Works great.

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: 	Wed, 5 Oct 1994 11:43:55 -0400
From: Roy Kao <e0ewqbwu@credit.erin.utoronto.ca>
Subject: Review of new Carrera 4 (993)

I've just read the articles in the two UK magazines concerning the new 
Carrera 4, Performance Car and CAR.  It seems that Porsche AG has made 
many improvements to the AWD system on the new C4 compared to the last 
generation C4.  It seems that the distribution of power is now better 
handled and that the extra weight of the AWD system no longer affect the 
accerleration numbers compared to the C2.  If I was in the market for the 
new 993 (and I wish to God I was..), I'd probably shell out the extra 
money for the AWD system.  This way, I'd get to go to track days in dry 
or wet conditions and have lots of fun in either.  As for now, I'd have 
to be content as a university student and look for a '90 or so C2 or C4 
and hope I find a real peach.

		
		* Roy Kao - e0ewqbwu@tuzo.erin.utoronto.ca *
		*    '93 VW Corrado VR6, '88 BMW 635CSi	   *
		*     "Why fly when you can DRIVE?...."    *

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 94 12:46:23 PDT

I've seen a few of these - specifically where people pulled a small

track car.  8-)

Date: Tue, 4 Oct 1994 18:14:57 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: Re: 944S coolant leak


Steve - 

I second what Jerry said about not waiting any longer
to get your leak fixed (No comments, Barton!). My water 
pump did what you described and I got it fixed. Then, not 
24 hours later the radiator sprang a leak (read geyser!). 
My mechanic said you never know what's wrong until you start 
fixing things. So I guess one moral is to pressure test the 
system after the pump is replaced. It *may* show up 
other faults before you get out on the hiway - and maybe
it won't. YMMV.

Good Luck!

Herb Myers
'83 944
Dk Met Red

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Oct 1994 13:52:41 +0200

Subject: More Help on 356 Part

 Windows hang up on me in the middle of this sending, here we go again....

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 19:54:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Carillo rods for 951

> Has anyone had any experience using Carillo rods in a 944 turbo? 

Sorry, I don't do water. But I *DO* have tons of experience in using
Carrillos in VWs, 914s, 911s, 930s, and misc. big-block Ford stock car
motors.

In a word (ok, two words): finest kind. They are absolute necessities
for high-rev racing motors, and they last and last and last and last...
On your average air cooled motor, take a counterweighted crank, PolyDyne
the bearings, and use Carrillos, and the bottom end is just about 
bulletproof. Of course, it also helps to have lightened tool steel 
wristpins and lightweight forged pistons too.

Not sure about "worth it" for a street car, though. Kevin? Nathan?

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 09:56:54 -0500
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Why gauges sometimes register high readings

This may explain why gauges (temp, fuel etc)  sometimes show higher or
lower than expected. 

As cars get older the electrical connections weaken (corrosion, dust, 
dirt etc increase the electrical resistance at the connectors), and as a
result the gauges show a little higher than they did when the car was 
newer. It has happened on my 87 Jetta and it had happened on my  1978 924.
Both cars indicated slightly hotter coolant than when newer, both cars 
were checked at Autobahn Inc, at different years.  Both times the coolant
temps were within  limits although the gauges were showing higher than
whan the cars were newer. In the case of the 924, the gauge was
approaching red,  but the coolant temp was still acceptable. 

The 924 fuel gauge indicated empty when the tank was 1/3 full...

Anyone with additional comments/experience on these?...

(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis   email ourios@zeus.wustl.edu 
87 911 Carrera targa - summer yellow, black full leather interior

Date: 5 Oct 1994 12:12:19 -0800
From: "Bill White" <Bill.White.LDIV@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

Bruce stated:

>Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
>lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
>tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget 
>about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us 
>both know.

Nitrogen will expand with increasing temperature! The presumption is that it
will not expand as fast as air. A quick glance at the Virial coefficients for
"standard" air and N2 indicates that this is probably an effect of order 1%.
However, this would vary greatly with the moisture content in the air. 

Bill White

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 94 12:40:20 PDT
From: john@pelican.hac.com (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: Nitrogen in tires

> Bruce -
> 
> Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
> lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
> tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget 
> about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us 
> both know.
> 
> Mike Lommatzsch
> 
> PCA-GGR
> SCCA-SFR
> 
	

	Me thinks this is an old (racer's) wives tale... In the pressure/temperature
range in question both N2 and Air (which is 78% N2) behave as nearly ideal gasses.
That means that :

(Pressure) * (Volume) = (number of moles of gas) * (gas constant R) * (absolute temperature)

Now, if you were really desperate to save a little weight you could fill your tires with
Helium or Hydrogen. Of course, both of these would leak out pretty fast and the H2 is also
pretty flammable.


									-jd

Date: 05 Oct 94 10:27:42 EDT
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Interesting 911 conversion fyi

Saw this on Compuserve, thought someone might be interested. Left out 
Bruce's COMPUSERVE address because he doesn't want it publicized. Bruce 
wrote the 911 Performance Handbook.

".... I am doing a 911 project car that is based on a 1972 911 myself. I am 
doing a lot of mechanical updates and will document the project several 
places. 

I picked the 1972 because of the unusual oil tank location. My car will be 
made to look like a 1973 911 RS lightweight, but wit (sic) all sorts of 
modern updates, including a G 50 transmission and a 3.6 engine updated to 
3.8 specifications...............................  

I got a nice sound one and a half owner California car. No rust at all, 
just run down and in need of work. I picked the 1972 911T because it had 
the funny oil tank location, which was a one year deal with the tank in 
front of the right rear wheel instead of in the normal 911 position behind 
the right rear wheel. I actually just bought the car as a body donor for my 
Project 911. This is a project for the Porsche Club of America. I will 
write a series of articles on the conversion of my Project car in the 
Porsche Clubs Panorama magazine. 

Bruce Anderson"

Wonder if Bruce means RSR 3.8 specs. Should be devastating. Compuserve is a 
real interesting place by the way. Recently had a post responded to by 
Vasek Polak(pretty famous racer/dealer?) who said that John Buffam(pretty 
famous rally driver) would be able to help with a question and providing a 
phone number. Of course Ferry Porsche hasn't responded to me yet, just to 
Stan. Oh well:)

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 94 16:53:07 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  951 Wheel Shimmy Revisited Again!

Mike,

I'll admit right up front that I don't know for sure, but you can
check these things yourself.

First, wheel bearings.  Any chance that these are out of adjustment?
Did you take the hubs off when you changed the pads?

Second, what condition are the ball joints in?  (See earlier post on
ball joints and the alloy a-arms.)

And then, a strange one, what kind of shape are the a-arm bushings in?
These are the bushings on the inboard part of the a-arms where they 
piviot on the body.  I've never actually seen this on a 944, but with
some VW's that have similar setups to the early 944's, I've seen a
similar problem.

Hope some of that helps.
(If I'm wrong, I'm sure one of these guys can correct me.)

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com

tire. This apparently reduces the pressure differential between hot tires
and cold tires; perhaps more importantly, it eliminates the difference in
that differential on humid days vs. dry days. Not sure how much of a
difference, though... Any comments about the possible use of Helium here
and its effect on unsprung weight :-)???

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 17:53:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 display model


> I have visited every auto-related shop in 5 cities without finding a decent
> model of a 944.  None of the catalogs I get show one, either.  Anyone know of
> a source for a nice metal or plastic display model, perhaps 8-9 inches long?

I like to build model kits of cars I own so that they look exactly like 
my actual car. For my 944, I was able to locate a 1/24 scale kit from 
Revell (made in W.Germany). The number on the box is 7289 which might be 
the catalog number. The title on the box is 'Porsche 944S'. It is dated 
1988. Fortunately, the actual kit had 'Phone-dial' wheels just like mine, 
unlike those pictured on the cover. Also, it included a 951-style rear 
apron which the previous owner of my regular 944 had installed. By 
slightly modifying the Euro-bumpers of the model, it was identical to the 
real thing. Hint: use lacquer automotive touchup spray-paint, followed by 
several coats of lacquer clear-coat for the body.

Hope this helps.
Chris
'86 944 Crystal Green Metallic
