------------------------------

Date: Wed,  5 Oct 94 18:38:45 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 Wheel Shimmy Revisited Again!

[...]
> I am at a loss. Maybe suspension components? Everything looks OK?
>
> PLEASE HELP!!! This problem is driving me crazyyyyyyyyyyyyy!!!!!!!

Mike, it sounds you've done a lot of analysis and spent time & money here.

You did not specifically mention replacing wheel bearings, or checking 
the A-arm ball joints.  These are wear items and could cause wheel shimmy.

You mentioned that braking stops the shimmy.  This is a good clue.  
This indicates a shaking rotor and stable caliper.  The rotor is 
affected by the wheel bearing's condition and adjustment; the caliper 
is not.  Also, both the rotor and caliper are affected by the ball 
joint and shock tower bushing (i.e., the mounting points for the whole 
strut assembly).

I would investigate the wheel bearings at this point.  They're 
reasonably cheap ($40-$60 per side, if I recall) and easy to replace.  
Give it a try.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 15:02:59 -0400
From: ay973@freenet.carleton.ca (Bruce Hatt)
Subject: Re: 911 fuel injection trouble

one way to test your fuel accumulator would be to
 undo the cold start valve fuel line at the valve.
there should be a short spray if it is holding
 pressure (note: engine is off). then put the line
in a beaker and have someone turn the engine over
 for a second. if there's instant fuel spray it's
not likely the pump but to make sure a pressure
 test should read 72 psi acc. to my clymer manual.
the problem with your engine turning over too long
 then running poorly sounds like fuel starvation
to me.if the fuel pump is working right then it 
 could be too much fuel.to check the cold start
valve for leaking,take it out with the fuel line
 still connected and unplug the electrical connection
and put the valve in a cup or something to gather
 any fuel that leaks.if you can bypass the pump
to make it work good otherwise have someone turn
 the engine over .if the valve leaks it's bad.
it's possible to check the injectors in a similar
 manner except that the fuel pump must be turned
on without turning over the engine.they shouldn't
 leak unless they are bad.it's unlikely that a
non functioning warm-up reg. would cause these
 symptoms.
 to clean the injection system and combustion
chamber(inc. valves),the best thing around in my 
 opinion, is lubro moly's jetron and ventil sauber.

- --
 
Hatt.
- ----

Date: Wed,  5 Oct 94 15:12:36 CDT
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: Is it an '89 951 or a 88 951 S?

Hello Everybody!

I've been looking and calling around to different parts houses locally and 
nationwide to price various things I know I'll be needing soon.  One of 
the biggest stumbling blocks to getting an accurate part number and price 
is convincing the person on the phone that there were TWO 951 models in 
1988; 951 and 951S.  Most company's computers seem to jump from the '88 
951 to the '89 951 with no mention of the '88 951 S.  My question is this: 
Can I just tell these people that I have an '89 951 (or '89 944 Turbo) and 
be reasonably assured I'll get the right part?

I've been following the threads describing the uniqueness of the '88 951S 
and '89 951.  I think it's the best 944 investment.  Given the limited 
production runs, it may even be collectable some day in the distant 
future; but, speccing parts for it is turning out to be a pain.

What do you all think?  Is it safe to tell 'em '89 951?

Bert

outraged, and suicidal. I survived: I strolled over to my Kalahari Kool, 
started the engine, slipped Rod Stewart into the player, and streaked down 
North Main and onto I-23 as quickly as traffic allowed. Soon the joys of 
acceleration, and shifting, and weaving, and racing overwhelmed the memory 
of that tragedy in the end zone.   

.. and as for...
 
>Hi, Mike.
>Defunct wheels make nifty hose reels.
>Pete
and
>>expensive, and sad, pile of junk. As an example, my 944 is actually very easy
>>to tune up: plugs, "points" and air filter...
>Where do you get 944 "points" and where do you put them once you got 'em?
>Eric

"unsubscribe"!  Way to go Pete and Eric..

(,Stan)?

and finally, as for:

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 13:11:19 -0500
From: sundt@cc.bellcore.com (Mark Sundt)
Subject: Re: 944 S2 vs Turbo S

>and driver's ed at the track.  Seems like the S2 would have an
>advantage in auto-x and in stop and go traffic because of the
>lack of turbo lag.  The turbo, of course, would be faster at the
>track.  Anyone driven both and care to comment?  You turbo
>owners, do you notice the turbo lag when autocrossing or in
>traffic?

Eric,

Actually, the turbo lag is not really noticeable. It feels more like the
car just doesn't have alot of power at the low end (compared to the top
end). As for autocrossing, the tall gearing is likely to cause more
difficulties than the turbo. In particular, a good launch in first gear
requires ~3K+ RPM before engaging the clutch (slowly). With a LSD this will
keep the car from bogging down and produce just the right amount of
wheelspin. You can just imagine how good this is for the life of one of
these (normally short-lived) clutches :-). My experience is with a stock
'86 951 (w/limited slip, w/o chip) but a stock Turbo S should be similar.
If you put a chip in a 951 then the "launch" becomes much easier (better
"tip-in" throttle response, I'm told). As for the S2, I don't have any
direct experience, but would guess that the advantage in autocrossing, if
there is one, would be small.

Hope this helps.

Mark
'86 951 Guards Red
sundt@cc.bellcore.com



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 16:50:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: wolpert@eece.maine.edu (Seth Wolpert)
Subject: The "bargain" 912

Greetings all.

I went to look at the much-discussed 912 I posted about last week,
and thought I'd post my findings rather than reply to all of the
individuals who responded to the post.
 
>From a distance, the car looked pretty good, with the black paint
faded in some spots, but no rust holes.  The closer I got, though,
the worse it looked.  The body felt like it had lots of filler
under the paint.  It had loose door handles and bumper fittings,
cracked lenses, and missing trim pieces.  The interior was also a
write-off with all of the vinyl sagging, torn, or faded.  Guages
were all there, but the glove box was very hard to get open.  It
smelled mildewy.  The undercarriage had some serious rust, and the
forward attaching point for the right side lower A arm had totally
disintegrated.  The engine had a thick layer of dust on in, and 
the car was in such a state of disassembly that I could not even
contemplate cranking it over.  The carbs, fuel tank, battery, and
rear shocks and springs were all off the car.  The roof and rear
window were in good shape, but the chassis showed flex with the
roof off.

In short, I think I'm gonna pass on this one.  It'll cost far more
to fix up than it'll be worth when it's done.

Thanks to all who related their experiences with early 911/912
models.  You made my evaluation of the car much more comfortable.
 
Seth Wolpert

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  5 Oct 94 11:41:04 PDT
From: Mike Conte <mikecon@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4

The 89-94 C4's use a true center differential with wheelspeed sensors 
and electronic clutches to distribute power to the wheels. It is true 
all-wheel drive. Normally I think the split is 67% to the rear and 33% 
to the front. If a wheel begins to slip, its power is reduced and sent 
to the other three wheels. This system --- a remarkably sophisticated 
one -- make it possible to drive the C4 in all kinds of poor 
conditions, and very hard to spin. However it is noticably heavier than 
the C2, and tends to understeer quite a bit when driven hard. So the 
real driving enthusiasts tended to favor the C2 of the same era. It was 
also $10k more money for the C4, and for lots of people, hard to 
justify when the only external difference was a "4" on the decklid.

The new 993 C4 has a much simpler system for power distribution. 
Normally, all the power is sent to the rear wheels. A viscous coupling 
to the front wheels send power to the fronts only when the rear wheels 
begin to slip (slippage and shear forces make the viscous gel become a 
solid). Porsche also uses ABD (Advanced Braking Differential?) which 
uses the ABS sensors detect wheel slippage and applies the brakes to 
the wheel that is slipping, at speeds less than about 40 miles an hour. 
The advantages of the new viscous system are that it is lighter and 
gives the driving feel of a two-wheel drive car until the limits of 
rear traction have been exceeded. So the enthusiasts should like it 
better. It is also cheaper and simpler, which is itself not a bad thing 
either -- in computers we might call it more elegant! While it is not 
as sophisticated a drive system as the old C4s AWD, between it and the 
ABD, the new C4 should be drivable in all kinds of rotten weather. In 
many ways the new C4 is the best of both worlds - more fun to drive in 
the dry, without giving up much in the rain or snow to the old C4. And 
it's cheaper.

FWIW, most "4x4's" on the market don't use systems as nearly as 
sophisticated as even the 993's.

(I am writing this from memory - someone please chime in if I have 
gotten some technical bits wrong.)

Mike

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Calling all Floridians...

I recently looked at a used 93 RS America originally from Florida and
wondered if anyone might know the history on this car. It was white w/o a
sunroof, had a PCA decal on the window, a Miami dealers license plate
holder, and non standard 16" OEM starfish wheels. All this added up made me
think that someone in southern Florida, who was a PCA member, could have
been running the car in some local driving events (using the standard 17"
wheels and using the 16" wheels for the street). The dealer here in Houston
seems to always have a bunch of Florida cars, supposedly from a high end
auction house down there somewhere.

Anyway, I thought this car might ring a bell with someone who could give a
yea or nay on the condition and or treatment of the car. Other than the
wheels it looks pretty good and has < 10,000 miles. This seems like pretty
low mileage if it is street miles but 10,000 miles at Moroso would be a lot
of wear and tear. I was told I could pick it up for somewhere in the $38 -
40 K range, which is still a lot of money to me but after driving one this
weekend at a local track event at TWS my mouth is watering.

Anyone want to buy a nice 74 Carrera or a 89 951 ??

Thanks
Joe Wilkinson
74 Carrera

Date: Wed,  5 Oct 94 14:02:57 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; vapor lock on 930



>From: "David L. Asher" <asherd@csn.org>
>Subject: 930 turbo vapor lock

>Only recently became a Porsche owner and E-mail user but hope someone can
>help with Porsche problem.  I have had a difficult time starting the
>automobile after driving it, turning it off and allowing the engine heat
>to build up after short periods of time, approx. 20+ minutes or so.  I've
>been told the reason is fuel vaporization from engine heat prior to ignition.
>One mechanic redid the ignition sequence so that the electronic fuel
>pumps can be activated prior to ignition, thus allowing liquid gasoline
>into the lines replacing the vapor but this has not solved the problem.
>Any suggestions?  The car is a 1977 Turbo Carrera and when it runs, I
>love it, just doesn't always start when I want it to.

   First, make sure your fuel pump is really good. If its whining or making
  much noise when hot, its probably bad.
   Vapor lock on the CIS system is prevented by the "accumulator," it is
  basically a piston on a spring. When you turn off the pump, the spring puts
  pressure on the fuel lines to prevent vapor lock. Generally when they go bad
  they leak, unless yours is leaking its probably ok.
    From the supply side, the only reason you keep pressure is because of
  a check valve in the fuel pump. Without it working right, pressure bleeds
  straight off as fuel is pushed back to the tank. A common symptom of a
  bad check valve is that the car will start only after cranking for a couple
  minutes (this problem on a friend's car made me a believer in Interstate
  batteries !). The fuel pump on your car I believe is up under the steering
  rack, this is a cheap and easy part to replace.
    I know it seems funny that you can activate your fuel pump and not rid
  the vapor lock, I can't explain why that happens but it does.
     Don't custom wire your ignition ! Though I've been the first to do
  things like this, it really is the worst thing to do in that you'll probably
  end up with a worse connection, plus soon you can end up with a pile of
  spaghetti and be left wondering where wires really go....

       Hope this works for you--Lee


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 20:03:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 brakes/bearings

>      I noticed Zim's has rear 356 rotors for $49.95.  I thought
> that looked pretty good vs. Stoddards, etc at about $120.  While
> I'm at it I'd like to rebuild the calipers, and replace the rear
> wheel bearings.  I looked at the book last night.  Other than
> having to deal with a myriad of parking brake pieces, a half
> dozen seals, and pressing the bearing, The torque figure for the
> axle nut caught my eye.
> 
>      Is 400 Ft/lbs really required?  I've done Dana 44 axles (1/2
> ton pickup/jeep size) and always managed with a combination of a
> 1/2" impact and pursuader on a breaker bar, and jsut put it back
> "as tight as you can get it".  I think the spec on these was
> around 250 Ft/lbs.  Are the rear wheel bearings do-able at home?

Funny you should ask this.... I'm in the middle of that right now
myself, waiting on the second box of stuff from Zims to arrive.
While I'm replacing everything else (front bearings and seals, all
four rotors, pads, rebuilding calipers, replacing master
cylinder, rubber brake lines and emergency brake shoes) I'm only
replacing the seals on the rear bearings. 

Why? In part because they're not kidding about needing 400 foot lbs
of torque. Even the lowly VW Beetle used 375 foot pounds to hold
it's rear drums on. You need  a special tool that you bolt across
two of the lugs bolts that then braces the hub against rotation 
by pressure on the floor. And about a 4 foot long breaker bar. There's
even a special VW part number for it and you can still get it fromA
Baum (the folks that actually make almost all of the VW / Porsche
special tools).

So, until the bearings start complaining, I'm going to take  a pass
on that exercise. Then I'll probably let Elmer do it, since he's
got the tools and the experience. And I figure you need to do that
what, every 30 years?

Oh -- on price: obligatory plug for United German Imports in
Pittstown NJ. They have a full package for $495 that has in theory
everything you need to do the job in a one-stop shopping manner.
It's a little less expensive to buy from Zims, but you have to 
remember what all you need... 

Finally, when you get ready to do brakes on your 356, make *SURE*
you have wheel bearing seals on hand. Odds are, you're gonna need
them. That's why I'm driving the Beetle this week instead of the
356...

Stan

Stan

available on Porsche's '86 or newer w/less than 120,000 miles!

Len,

According to the workshop manual, this is done on a 944 by prying it
up with a thin putty knife.

The manual also warns you to be careful not to damage the paint. 
Whenever they say something obvious like that, it typically means that
there's a real good chance you're going to screw it up!

Kevin

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 10:22:47 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

>Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
>lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
>tires heat up. 

Sigh.... We used to store the IMSA slicks in airtight bags filled with
nitrogen, and filled the tires with nitrogen, because it is widely 
believed that in an all-nitrogen, low-to-no oxygen environment, the
tires *LAST LONGER* i.e. they don't get harder over time.

Now, we never tested this theory any longer than we had to, mind you,
so I can't say how true it is...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 09:50:25 MDT
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Nitrogen in tires

Mike Lommatzsch said:
>Nitrogen will not expand as your tires heat up.

Jerry944T said:
>Serious racers use nitrogen in their tires as it does not expand
as much as air when heated.

According to the basic laws of chemistry and physics, *ALL* gases
expand equally (and linearly within wide limits) with temperature
changes. (Scientists in the group will recall the formula PV=NRT).
I looked up nitrogen and found no mention of any unusual behavior
re. temperature & pressure.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 08:40 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Carillo rods for 951

Per Stan's note, yes, the Carillos are well respected, reliable, and
all the other good stuff.  They are also available with non-standard
dimensions, for example with a smaller little-end bore for our race
car's smaller wrist pins.

I don't know about 944 Turbo applications.  Not sure whether the
Andial stroker kit includes different con rods, but I can ask.  The
shop has done a couple of those.

BTW, I will not even utter the name of that *other* company selling
"trick" conn rods for 911's, the ones advertised in Pano.  Suffice it
to say that were I to voice an opinion, it would make Pete's reflections
on T*d sound like an Academy Award acceptance speech.

Kevin

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 14:52:23 PDT
From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM" <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>
Subject: new 944 owner


Hi netters, 
 
          I had bugged you all some time back regarding the purchase of a 
924 first and then a 944. Well, tell you what, I DID IT!  
 
          I bought a '84.5 944 last friday (sept 30). The car is in very  
good shape and has done 87k miles. I had come to this country about three 
months back and has made an old dream of owning a Porsche come true. I  
used to drive an old Ambassador in India with a 2 litre 41 BHP diesel 
engine (transplanted) and you cannot imagine the difference.  
 
          I am already in love with my 944 and am still getting used to  
it. I have some doubts which I will ask in a later post. 
 
Cheers, 
Sreelal Ramachandran 
84.5 944 (burgundy metallic)

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 16:09:05 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 hood badge removal

> Dear Porsche Friends:
> I can't seem to be able to get to the badge's back on the 944. I even removed
> the front bumper (had a headlight washer leak...) but could not get to it.
> 
> Are they just pressed on? Held in place by glue or what?!!

Hi, Lou...

Yep, you guessed it...held in place by (the magic of) friction.

The pins in back of the crest fit into a couple of black plastic grommets. I
use a gasket scraper to get a bit under the badge and then gently pry it up
(without damaging the paint!)

Good luck

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 08:18:47 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Handbrake

Yep, Kevin Gross is right (again!).

The handbrake brake shoes list for $50.25 each (p/n 928.352.097.10) and you
do need four of them to do the job.  Of course, I know a source for used
shoes (:-)) at great prices...

OTOH, the symptom was that the handle would not stay in the up position. 
Most likely, the ratchet release is rusted in place or the spring is broken
or something is screwed up on the handle which might be diagnosed by
inspection of the parts inside the cabin.  Easier to look at and diagnose
with the driver seat out.  Besides, it's a chance to find all those quarters
and dimes that have fallen out of the previous owners' pockets.

(Where do you think that I get all of my spending cash???)

George Beuselinck

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 10:36:00 PDT

>I looked at this myself when I bought the 911.  Porsche makes a hitch for the
>car (according to the dealers I queried in London), and I could have had it
>installed for about 1,500 pounds sterling.  [snip]

Only 1,500 pounds, eh?  That's about $3000 CDN or $2235 US.  This is what I 
paid for my pickup truck which has a towing capacity of about 7000 pounds 
PLUS I get an 8-foot bed which I could fill with tires, tools, and a small 
swimming pool.

There's got to be about half a million competant shops out there which could 
weld you a custom hitch which would bolt in place for easy 
installation/removal for the light loads you require.  I'm betting they could 
do this for about 1/10 the cost of the installed Porsche part.

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 10:47:54 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 944 p-brake question


Matthew,

	Sounds most likely to be a broken handbrake cable.

	The handbrake on my 944 (85/2) was never very good. Even though I
adjusted it a number of times, it kept needing more and more
"clicks" to hold the car on a slope. Eventually it snapped - the
week before I sold the car :-(

	Replacement is not especially trivial.

	I also suspect that many people don't adjust the cable at the
handbrake end properly - the service manual says that you have to
remove the driver's seat to do it, though some small spanners and
*lots* of patoence will also work. It *is* much easier with the seat
out (my seat was out for recovering, so I though I'd clean or adjust
anything which I couldn't normally get at). There is also a star
adjuster inside each rear wheel.

	Good luck with your search.

Regards,
Philip

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 14:09:04 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

Gee - I just tried to answer the quote about using nitrogen in the tires
instead of air.  Didn't know we would have to re-take chemistry to
understand it.  Yes, people use nitrogen in their tires "trying' to
eliniminate or reduce the expansion of the tires as they get hot.  Yes,
air consists of 78+-% nitrogen, and yes the water content is a source of
further problems.  But everything helps when you are trying to achieve a
goal or in this cause a quicker time.  Even if the help is so small that
it becomes physcological.  And no let's not get into physcological games 
we all play with our cars or competitors.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-GGR
SCCA-SFR

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 14:31:29 PDT
From: steve@pyramid.com (Stephen Chan)
Subject: Re: Carbon deposits and water?

> 
> I read on another thread (BMW) that someone was injecting "water" into the 
> combustion chamber (intake manifold) as a methos of "removing" carbon deposits.
> I assume that the physics behind it are that water vapor formed increases the 
> effective compression and then ....
> 
> Has any one tried injecting water into the intake system and "cleaned" p-car
> valves. I knoe that there are engines that use water-injection system to 
> increase performance (e.g. dragsters?)
> 

I once read an interesting article from Smokey Yunick years ago
who strongly discouraged anyone from using water injection on their
engine.  Apparently, the water "steam" cleans the chambers, thus
nullifying the job motor oil is supposed to do.

Steve

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 10:27:11 PST
From: Patrick Buddenbaum <Patrick_Buddenbaum@ccm.fm.intel.com>
Subject: 911 jerky acceleration problem when cold


Text item: 911 jerky acceleration problem when cold


  Greetings fellow p-philes -

  I have an '84 911 that gets a bit moody when cold.  She starts up
  immediately, though runs a bit rough at low RPMs (around 700) for a few
  seconds until something (?) kicks in and boosts the RPMs by 100 or 2.  So
  far, no problems - except that I haven't moved yet.  As soon as I start
  driving, I get jerky acceleration in 1st and sometimes 2nd gear, usually
  in the low-RPM band.  Given the outside temperature, this problem goes
  away anywhere from 30 seconds to 5 minutes of driving.  Colder the
  weather, the longer the problem is around.  Runs like a champ when
  warmed-up.

  And the net wisdom of the p-philes says ???

  Thanks in advance,
  Pat Buddenbaum
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com

  '84 911 Carrera coupe (black)
  '92 Golden Retriever (spoiled)

Hunter,

Next time you are in a big bookstore (Barnes & Noble type), or a hobbyshop,
pick up one of the model car magazines. You will find mail order places that
have "new old stock" of discontinued models. I suspect that there may be no
current production of 944 kits since the real cars haven't been in production
for a couple of years.

I have a 1:24 scale euro '86 944 Turbo model built from a Hasegawa kit, which
a dealer was able to order for me, but this was a few years ago (like 1991 or
92).

And, sadly, I also suspect that there aren't too many teenagers falling
asleep dreaming of owning one of our delightfully solid, balanced
automobiles. Their loss...and not much incentive for the kit manufacturers.

Good luck!

    Well, it looks like I've hit my first case of Really Bad
News (tm) on my two-liter.  While I was crawling around under
it last weekend, I checked out where the fuel pump should be
mounted.  It ain't.  It appears that the mounting bracket has
pulled out of the metal it was bolted/welded/riveted/whatever
to.  Because said metal has a fairly advanced case of rot.  I
think that said metal is a part of the right-rear suspension,
which would make this a case of the Dreaded 914 Suspension
Console Rot (also tm).  I do know that the battery tray has
been replaced--I naively assumed that the console was checked
out at that time...

banger?

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 15:58:08 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Value of PCA Membership

> Is this consumer fraud stuff, or just serious puffing??
>
> Rudy Garcia
> '84 944
> rgarcia@msu.edu
>

Rudy, obviously you have not joined the Porsche Club, or you would not be
asking such a question.

As an example, (bear with me please) - my waterpump on my 83 944 sprung a
leak in 1987.  I took it to the dealer, who quoted me a price of $1600 to
replace the waterpump, belts, and labor.  With the help of several unselfish
PCA members in my region, we did the job ourselves in 6 hours, total cost
$200.  Now, I will grant that we used a rebuilt pump instead of a new one
(PCNA at that time was not offering rebuilts), but certainly I saved $1400
in one incident alone.  That itself will pay my PCA dues for as many years
as I will be alive...

I'm sure that as a Michigan State student, $36 can buy you a lot of pizza
and beer (to cry in, after a football loss), but it can be the best $36 you
can spend on your Porsche.

George Beuselinck
PCA Member #88126467 (You could look it up)

George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 08:27:02 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Dimensions of a 944

Hi, Colin,               
                                                                             
I am 6foot1inch (when I don't slouch, yes, mom) and have no problem in my 83 
944.  My helmet does hit the sunroof, but I have gotten used to that...      
                                               
> The other thing I'm a little worried about is- how wide is this car?  I 
> live in San Francisco, so street parking is not really an option.  My 
> garage is narrow, and I want to make sure a 944 would fit.  How about a 
> 924S?  Is it significantly narrower than the 944?

According to the tech book (WKD 423 320 - Porsche 924S/944 Models
Dimensions Tolerances), the width of a 924S is 1685 mm, while the width of a
944 is 1735 mm.

The conversion to inches/feet/yards/furlongs/etc. is left as an exercise for
the student...

George Beuselinck

Date: Thu, Oct 6, 1994 11:40 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Returned mail: Host unknown (fwd)

(this just bounced)
To: john@pelican.hac.com931-3910
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in tires

In message <9410051940.AA04809@pelican.hac.com> John (619 writes:
> > Bruce -
> > 
> > Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
> > lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
> > tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget 
> > about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us 
> > both know.

[snip]
> 	Me thinks this is an old (racer's) wives tale... In the pressure/temperature
> range in question both N2 and Air (which is 78% N2) behave as nearly ideal 
> gasses.
> That means that :
> 
> (Pressure) * (Volume) = (number of moles of gas) * (gas constant R) * 
> (absolute temperature)

True.  Nitrogen is used primarily because it is first dried to remove the 
moisture.  Water in the gas used is what buggers the deal.

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 10:39:15 +0500
From: Barry Chapin 617-258-2809 <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 930 Fuel vapor lock problem -> fuel pump.

RE:
Subject: 930 turbo vapor lock

Only recently became a Porsche owner and E-mail user but hope someone can 
help with Porsche problem.  I have had a difficult time starting the 
automobile after driving it, turning it off and allowing the engine heat 
to build up after short periods of time, approx. 20+ minutes or so.  I've 
been told the reason is fuel vaporization from engine heat prior to ignition.
One mechanic redid the ignition sequence so that the electronic fuel 
pumps can be activated prior to ignition, thus allowing liquid gasoline 
into the lines replacing the vapor but this has not solved the problem.  
Any suggestions?  The car is a 1977 Turbo Carrera and when it runs, I 
love it, just doesn't always start when I want it to.
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

This sound just like the fuel pump check valve.  It is located on the
tip of the fuel pump, stopping the reverse flow of fule into the tank
which is caused by back pressure from a hot engine.  Have the check calve
checked/

 -Barry Chapin
chpain@draper.com

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 12:55:12 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 356 brakes/bearings

> dozen seals, and pressing the bearing, The torque figure for the
> axle nut caught my eye.
>      Is 400 Ft/lbs really required?  I've done Dana 44 axles (1/2
> ton pickup/jeep size) and always managed with a combination of a
> 1/2" impact and pursuader on a breaker bar, and jsut put it back
> "as tight as you can get it".  I think the spec on these was
> around 250 Ft/lbs.

My swing-axle beetle rear axle nut required an estimated 600 ft-lb to
unseat. 500-odd was the best we could do with the breaker bar and
cheater pipe, which wouldn't budge the bugger. Finally got it off with
a Ubangi - an ingenious device made of half-inch plate steel, with a
hex hole in it of the right size to fit the nut (36 mm?) and on the other
end, two flats (for hitting...) and a 1/2 inch drive hole. You put the
breaker bar in the drive hole, the hex hole over the nut, stand on the
cheater pipe, and hit the flat part with a sledge hammer. Still took
three whacks... the Ubangi is availble from Johnny's Speed & Chrome,
see Hot VW's back pages for the ever-present ad.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 13:53:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@starbase.neosoft.com>
Subject: Re: Remedy for Windshield Wiper "Shudder"

> "Has anyone figured out how to reliably stop the windshield wiper shudder that
> seems to develop a few days into the rainy season? "

I always found that the shudder is due to a different effect than deposits off
of the wiper blade on the glass.

The wiper blade is made to pivot as it sweeps the glass.  An ASCII cross 
sction looks like this:

wiper direction --->                       <---

        /                (wiper blade)          \
_________________        glass surface      ________________

When the wiper is parked, it is always on the same side, and the blade changes 
shape through time.  I find that the shudder occurs when the wiper doesn't 
flex in the proper direction, due to fatigue of the rubber, or shape
deformation.  Replacing the blades is the only solution I know of, other than
leaving the wiper arms sticking straight up so you don't deform the blades.

The latter looks pretty silly going down the road <g>.

 -chuck
'83 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 14:44:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: sgluckst@atlantis.com (Sheldon Gluckstein)
Subject: 951 DME relay

Last week the DME relay in my '86 951 was acting up, and I was wondering
if anyone else has experienced the same symtoms, and can offer suggestions
as to cause.  

While driving to work the engine would suddenly cut out for a fraction
of a second and then kick in again.  Whenever this happened I could 
hear a relay drop.  This happened about 5 miles after I started driving
the car when it was cold.  The relay would drop out about once every 
minute whether I was cruising, or stopped for a light.  Well, I limped
it home and later on picked up a new DME relay from the dealer.

The next day I swapped relays, and drove to work.  Again the same 
thing started happening, only worse, now the relay fluttered, and
that makes for one hell of a rough idle !  I limped this home to and
removed the relay and inserted a jumper across the three pinouts which
would correspond to the contacts the closed relay would make.  With a
lot of effort I got it running, only to stall and turn over but 
not start at all.
At this point I had it towed to the dealer.  When I called them the
next day, they said that they popped the new relay in, boosted the battery
and it ran fine.  They drove it, idled it and no bad relay action.

To me this is black magic, as I basically did what they did.  Soo...
the question is what the heck happened.  Any ideas out there ?


Thx,

Sheldon.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 12:24:00 PDT
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: porsche models



Someone was recently asking about models of 944's. Someone else responded
that a 944 kit was available from Revell. I know of one other 944 kit, a
1/24 scale from Hasegawa. If people are interested, some other kits that I
know of:
Fujimi 1/24 356A/B/C speedster, Carrera, Roadster, Cab, Coupe, Karmann
Coupes available, also various 911's . The Fujimi EM series has fantastic
detail, done to scale. In the case of the 356's it includes a crankshaft
c/w rods, and counterweights (only if the engine had counterweights)! I
kid you NOT! Expensive and well worth the money if you have the time and
some modelling skills to devote to it.
Tamiya 1/12 934, 935- Big, superdetailed, working suspension, in short,
unbelievable! Expensive, I paid about US$40 for my 934 in Japan, I suspect
it would be double that at least here.
Tamiya 1/20 935,928 Good kits, reasonably priced.
Revell 1/24 904 - poor kit, the lines are OK, the engine is a joke. I
built mine with a 2.0L Carrera from a Fujimi kit that I wired with
ignition (that task alone took 2-3 hours), a trans from a Fujimi 911, and
wheels from a Fujimi 356C. Needs extensive reworking, but the results can
be good.
Gunze Sangyo (I think) 904,906- you can tell what they are supposed to be,
but overall kit is very poor.

There are others, this is all I could think of at the moment.

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914 (still for sale)
'71 Alfa GTJunior

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 15:00:13 EST
From: reid_zeigler@merck.com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: toxic rodents


As if we didn't have enough to worry about....

I've been working on a 924 Turbo that had been lying fallow
for a year and had become the residence of some furry friends.
There was a well established nest on top of the engine and 
besides nibbling through a few fuel lines and wires, the little
buggers used the spark plug wells for their own Porsche-potties.

I used an air hose to blow mouse excrement all over my garage
before removing the plugs. (a shop-vac would have been a better
choice in retrospect)

In relaying the story to our biosafety guy at work (also auto-
motively certifiable) he said that I should have been wearing 
a dust mask or better yet, a cartridge type full-face mask to 
protect myself against Hantavirus in the mouse droppings. 

My first reaction was that it was silly, BUT ... there are 
increasing cases of this nasty virus, and it *can* be deadly.
So, take care of your nice killer felines, give them free range
of your garage over the winter, and if you do end up with little
critters in your car over the winter - be careful with the clean
up.


#######################################################################

Reid Zeigler                             "I have the simplest tastes.
Sr. Mgr. Visual Communications            I am always satisfied with
Merck Research Laboratories               the best."
zeigler@merck.com                                      - Oscar Wilde

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 08:22:47 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Why gauges sometimes register high readings

>>
>>This may explain why gauges (temp, fuel etc)  sometimes show higher or
>>lower than expected. 
>>
>>As cars get older the electrical connections weaken (corrosion, dust, 
>>dirt etc increase the electrical resistance at the connectors), and as a
>>result the gauges show a little higher than they did when the car was 
>>newer. It has happened on my 87 Jetta and it had happened on my  1978 924.
>>

Seems that this should make gauges read lower, not higher. I assume that
gauges are typically in series with a sensor, and that the sensor is a
variable resistor, that changes with whatever is being sensed. The lower
the resistance, the higher the gauge reading. So additional resistance
in the circuit should make the reading lower.

One possibility for making the reading higher would be excessive voltage
to the instrument. Maybe the regulator doesn't do as good a job as it
did when it was new? I have noticed that turning on my headlights makes
my temperature gauge read a little higher, and assumed that the
regulator was overcompensating for the increased current drain. Maybe
that's a bad assumption (wouldn't be the first time...). Anybody got
a more persuasive explanation?

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: 6 Oct 1994 08:00:15 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-tires and N2

                       Subject:                               Time:7:49 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          re:tires and N2                        Date:10/6/94
Tom writes:


>On Oct.3 you answered a posting from Carl, and at the end of your answer  
>you mentioned consumables, including nitrogen for tires.  This got my 
>attention, because about a year ago a person who races some sort of 
>stock-cars told me that he uses nitrogen in his tires, I think he said 
>it reduces the pressure increase due to heating of the tires.

snip

>Can  you explain what the advantage of inflating tires with nitrogen is, 
>and is it really useful in driver training situations, with about 30 minute
>run sessions.  I have used a pyrometer on my tires and they seem to run 
>about 135 degrees.  I would appreciate any wisdom you can shed on this.

I've heard this claim before and my immediate thought was BS.  However,
I've learned to pay attention to the empirical evidence: if these are the 
measured numbers, saying they're impossible is, well, stupid.

The only reason I can come up with to explain the effect (if it exists - I 
haven't made any measurements...) is the water content of the air.  

Bottled N2 (or any other gas) should be pretty dry.

Compressed air is often quite damp due to condensation in the compressor
and the effect may be more due to the water than the gas.  Be aware that 
I'm speaking off the top of my head here and have not sat down and checked
the tables for wet air vs. temperature.



- --Soren

well as co-serve on our region's AX committee with him).  Jay is a super
nice guy that does quality work and offers a 12 month warrantee.  *AND* you
deal directly with the person who does the work.  I believe his prices are
in-line with the others, I'd just recommend Jay because of the personal care
her gives each and every pump he does (not a high volume business BTW).

Tell him Scott sent you....

Date:     Thu, 6 Oct 94 9:35:28 EDT
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@pica.army.mil>
Subject:  N2 (was Track Upgrades)

Mike writes:
>Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is
>lighter than air).......NOT. 

Agreed; definitely "NOT".  Air is ~80% Nitrogen, so there's not going to
be much difference between them.  Most of the balance of air is Oxygen,
which is very close to N2 in molecular weight, too.  Maybe someone's
thinking of Helium?  That shouldn't make a difference anyway, IMO.


> ...It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your tires heat up.  

With heat, the gas will become more energetic and TRY to expand, but
since the volume is fixed by the tire, the pressure will go up instead.
The Ideal Gas Law suffices for modelling the changes:  PV/T = constant.

To better model real world physics' molecular interactions, you should
use the Van der Waals equation of state, but I don't think you need that
level of precision here.  Forgetting to use Absolute temperatures (Kelvin
or Rankine scales) is the most common error made when applying the Ideal
Gas Law...heating from 20C to 40C is NOT a +100% increase, but only +7%.


>...Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget about having
>to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us both know.

FWIW, I don't think Helium will work either, although I will *speculate*
that it might be _possible_ to have a constant pressure while temperature
increases but only as a short term effect.  My speculation is because He
is a very small molecule, it is a hard gas to keep bottled.  Its possible
that the He could leak out at a rate roughly equal to the increase in
temperature so that your tire pressure could remain constant.  But as
time passes, the pressure will go DOWN as He continues to escape (and it
will go down a LOT when the tire cools).  Helium is notorious for being
able to escape confinement; it even passes through even Steel and Aluminum
pressure vessels. 


 -hugh


PS:  As a practical aside to all of this, has anyone ever weighed an
empty-vs-full tire to see how much (little) weight we're talking about here?

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 07:40:02 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Just Say No To Wimpy Exhausts


OK.  Here goes.

My car had twinn cherry bombs welded to flanges which bolt dirtectly to
race headers.  Idle is reasonable, as is a 3000 RMP cruise, but plant
it and all hell breaks loose!

If you have any doubts, ask anyone who has seen (or heard it) at the
track, namely Steve Stomski (sp).

Interestingly enough, a pair of the local Porsche Gurus gave me a rash
of (word deleted) about tham, saying you couldn't put a $20 exhaust on
a $20K car and expect it to work.  TO prove their point they bolted on
their "hot setup", a pair of 5" supertrapps with 15 diffusers each.
The supertrapps added 0.2 seconds to the 3000-7000 RMPPM runtime on the
local jetting hill!\


They've been real quiet ever since.

I do, howveer have a "street" exhaust, made of 2 california turbo
mufflers, but boy does it take a high end performance hit!



 I'm currently running the Quiet Bursch exhaust on my '74 and the sound is
> wonderful but it AIN'T LOUD ENOUGH!!! So I've ordered the glasspack Bursch
> and I'll put that on this weekend. I'm even going to put the Bursch racing
> megaphones on there after I put a set of Bursch headers on it early next
> year and see how loud that is. Probably get me a ticket for noise-ordinance
> violation!!! ;-> Has anybody run the megaphones? How do they sound?
> 
> My Turbo still has the stock exhaust and it's pitifully quiet. I'm definitely
> going to straight-pipe the wastegate and put a B&B exhaust system on it
> next year. A friend has a 400+ HP 930 that rumbles and spits at low RPMs
> and sounds like it doesn't even want to run. Then on boost it'll blow you
> away!! I *LOVE* that!!!
> 
> Anybody else sing the praises of a tumultuous exhaust sound?
> 
> Dustin Boyette
> ldg@mercury.interpath.net
> 1974 911 Carrera, Signal Green
> 1978 930, Grand Prix White
> 1981 Lancia Beta Coupe 2000, Silver

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 07:57:00 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Zone 1 Tech Tactics, March 18-19

Here's the PCA newsletter press release for the Zone 1 Tech Tactics for 
1995.  Several porschephiles attended last year and had a great time...
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Mark your calendars now for the weekend of March 18-19, 
1995!... because you won't want to miss out on all the fun and 
events we have planned for this "very special" 15th annual Tech 
Tactics weekend.

Tech Tactics is a two-day event, offering:

 -  Several interesting speakers who present programs on 
technical, and just a few not-so-technical, subjects, all 
intended to help you and your Porsche enjoy your relationship.

 -  A vendor display area, just outside the doors of the 
sessions, enticing you to purchase many items useful to you and 
your Porsche.

 -  Door prizes, awarded at various times during the weekend.

 -  Lots of socializing, especially in the hospitality suite on 
Friday and Saturday evenings.
 -  NEW THIS YEAR!
   Our keynote speaker will be a representative from the 
Porsche factory - a first for this event. The factory will also 
present several very interesting and challenging contests to 
pique your interest and bring out your competitiveness - with 
prizes for the winners!

It's a great time to get out from under the winter doldrums, 
visit with your PCA friends - and make new ones - meet the 
speakers, and learn a lot about your favorite marque.

A new registration format will be offered this year, whereby 
you can design your own weekend package.  This has come about 
as many people can only attend for one day, or for part of the 
weekend.  We hope to make this easier for you, and encourage 
increases attendance through this flexibility.

Complete details will be sent to each editor within the next 
few weeks, so watch your newsletters for complete registration 
information.  If you have any questions or need additional 
information, please do not hesitate to contact Bob and Joan 
Moir at (908) 879-6171.

We look forward to hearing from you and meeting you at the 15th 
annual Zone 1 Tech Tactics, March 18-19, 1995 at the Sheraton 
Hotel at Monarch Place in Springfield, Massachusetts.

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 08:40 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Carillo rods for 951

Per Stan's note, yes, the Carillos are well respected, reliable, and
all the other good stuff.  They are also available with non-standard
dimensions, for example with a smaller little-end bore for our race
car's smaller wrist pins.

I don't know about 944 Turbo applications.  Not sure whether the
Andial stroker kit includes different con rods, but I can ask.  The
shop has done a couple of those.

BTW, I will not even utter the name of that *other* company selling
"trick" conn rods for 911's, the ones advertised in Pano.  Suffice it
to say that were I to voice an opinion, it would make Pete's reflections
on T*d sound like an Academy Award acceptance speech.

Kevin

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 16:09:05 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 hood badge removal

> Dear Porsche Friends:
> I can't seem to be able to get to the badge's back on the 944. I even removed
> the front bumper (had a headlight washer leak...) but could not get to it.
> 
> Are they just pressed on? Held in place by glue or what?!!

Hi, Lou...

Yep, you guessed it...held in place by (the magic of) friction.

The pins in back of the crest fit into a couple of black plastic grommets. I
use a gasket scraper to get a bit under the badge and then gently pry it up
(without damaging the paint!)

Good luck
George Beuselinck

(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 08:18:47 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Handbrake

Yep, Kevin Gross is right (again!).

The handbrake brake shoes list for $50.25 each (p/n 928.352.097.10) and you
do need four of them to do the job.  Of course, I know a source for used
shoes (:-)) at great prices...

OTOH, the symptom was that the handle would not stay in the up position. 
Most likely, the ratchet release is rusted in place or the spring is broken
or something is screwed up on the handle which might be diagnosed by
inspection of the parts inside the cabin.  Easier to look at and diagnose
with the driver seat out.  Besides, it's a chance to find all those quarters
and dimes that have fallen out of the previous owners' pockets.

(Where do you think that I get all of my spending cash???)

George Beuselinck
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Only 1,500 pounds, eh?  That's about $3000 CDN or $2235 US.  This is what I

PLUS I get an 8-foot bed which I could fill with tires, tools, and a small 
swimming pool.

There's got to be about half a million competant shops out there which could 
weld you a custom hitch which would bolt in place for easy 
installation/removal for the light loads you require.  I'm betting they could 
do this for about 1/10 the cost of the installed Porsche part.

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 10:47:54 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 944 p-brake question


Matthew,

	Sounds most likely to be a broken handbrake cable.

	The handbrake on my 944 (85/2) was never very good. Even though I
adjusted it a number of times, it kept needing more and more
"clicks" to hold the car on a slope. Eventually it snapped - the
week before I sold the car :-(

	Replacement is not especially trivial.

	I also suspect that many people don't adjust the cable at the
handbrake end properly - the service manual says that you have to
remove the driver's seat to do it, though some small spanners and
*lots* of patoence will also work. It *is* much easier with the seat
out (my seat was out for recovering, so I though I'd clean or adjust
anything which I couldn't normally get at). There is also a star
adjuster inside each rear wheel.

	Good luck with your search.

Regards,
Philip

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 14:09:04 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

Gee - I just tried to answer the quote about using nitrogen in the tires
instead of air.  Didn't know we would have to re-take chemistry to
understand it.  Yes, people use nitrogen in their tires "trying' to
eliniminate or reduce the expansion of the tires as they get hot.  Yes,
air consists of 78+-% nitrogen, and yes the water content is a source of
further problems.  But everything helps when you are trying to achieve a
goal or in this cause a quicker time.  Even if the help is so small that
it becomes physcological.  And no let's not get into physcological games 
we all play with our cars or competitors.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-GGR
SCCA-SFR

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 14:31:29 PDT
From: steve@pyramid.com (Stephen Chan)
Subject: Re: Carbon deposits and water?

> 
> I read on another thread (BMW) that someone was injecting "water" into the 
> combustion chamber (intake manifold) as a methos of "removing" carbon deposits.
> I assume that the physics behind it are that water vapor formed increases the 
> effective compression and then ....
> 
> Has any one tried injecting water into the intake system and "cleaned" p-car
> valves. I knoe that there are engines that use water-injection system to 
> increase performance (e.g. dragsters?)
> 

I once read an interesting article from Smokey Yunick years ago
who strongly discouraged anyone from using water injection on their
engine.  Apparently, the water "steam" cleans the chambers, thus
nullifying the job motor oil is supposed to do.

Steve

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 10:27:11 PST
From: Patrick Buddenbaum <Patrick_Buddenbaum@ccm.fm.intel.com>
Subject: 911 jerky acceleration problem when cold


Text item: 911 jerky acceleration problem when cold


  Greetings fellow p-philes -

  I have an '84 911 that gets a bit moody when cold.  She starts up
  immediately, though runs a bit rough at low RPMs (around 700) for a few
  seconds until something (?) kicks in and boosts the RPMs by 100 or 2.  So
  far, no problems - except that I haven't moved yet.  As soon as I start
  driving, I get jerky acceleration in 1st and sometimes 2nd gear, usually
  in the low-RPM band.  Given the outside temperature, this problem goes
  away anywhere from 30 seconds to 5 minutes of driving.  Colder the
  weather, the longer the problem is around.  Runs like a champ when
  warmed-up.

  And the net wisdom of the p-philes says ???

  Thanks in advance,
  Pat Buddenbaum
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com

  '84 911 Carrera coupe (black)
  '92 Golden Retriever (spoiled)

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 16:24:53 EDT

>a source for a nice metal or plastic display model, perhaps 8-9 inches long?

>Hunter


Hunter,

Next time you are in a big bookstore (Barnes & Noble type), or a hobbyshop,
pick up one of the model car magazines. You will find mail order places that
have "new old stock" of discontinued models. I suspect that there may be no
current production of 944 kits since the real cars haven't been in production
for a couple of years.

I have a 1:24 scale euro '86 944 Turbo model built from a Hasegawa kit, which
a dealer was able to order for me, but this was a few years ago (like 1991 or
92).

And, sadly, I also suspect that there aren't too many teenagers falling
asleep dreaming of owning one of our delightfully solid, balanced
automobiles. Their loss...and not much incentive for the kit manufacturers.

Good luck!

Date: 6 Oct 1994 08:44:59 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 914 Suspension Console Rot

914 Suspension Console Rot
    Well, it looks like I've hit my first case of Really Bad
News (tm) on my two-liter.  While I was crawling around under
it last weekend, I checked out where the fuel pump should be
mounted.  It ain't.  It appears that the mounting bracket has
pulled out of the metal it was bolted/welded/riveted/whatever
to.  Because said metal has a fairly advanced case of rot.  I
think that said metal is a part of the right-rear suspension,
which would make this a case of the Dreaded 914 Suspension
Console Rot (also tm).  I do know that the battery tray has
been replaced--I naively assumed that the console was checked
out at that time...
    First, is this where the fuel pump goes on a stock four-
banger?
    Second, what kind of pain^H^H^H^Hexpense am I looking at?
If I can find a place to put everything, I *may* be able to drop
the engine myself, and I know a former State Welding Champion
that I *may* be able to buy enough beer for to weld it right...
Any gotchas in that?
    Third, anyone wanna donate to the cause?  ;-)
Sympathy will be accepted almost as willingly as cash or checks.

- --DD  (bleah.)

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 15:58:08 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Value of PCA Membership

> Is this consumer fraud stuff, or just serious puffing??
>
> Rudy Garcia
> '84 944
> rgarcia@msu.edu
>

Rudy, obviously you have not joined the Porsche Club, or you would not be
asking such a question.

As an example, (bear with me please) - my waterpump on my 83 944 sprung a
leak in 1987.  I took it to the dealer, who quoted me a price of $1600 to
replace the waterpump, belts, and labor.  With the help of several unselfish
PCA members in my region, we did the job ourselves in 6 hours, total cost
$200.  Now, I will grant that we used a rebuilt pump instead of a new one
(PCNA at that time was not offering rebuilts), but certainly I saved $1400
in one incident alone.  That itself will pay my PCA dues for as many years
as I will be alive...

I'm sure that as a Michigan State student, $36 can buy you a lot of pizza
and beer (to cry in, after a football loss), but it can be the best $36 you
can spend on your Porsche.

George Beuselinck
PCA Member #88126467 (You could look it up)
- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 08:27:02 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Dimensions of a 944

Hi, Colin,               
                                                                             
I am 6foot1inch (when I don't slouch, yes, mom) and have no problem in my 83 
944.  My helmet does hit the sunroof, but I have gotten used to that...      
                                               
> The other thing I'm a little worried about is- how wide is this car?  I 
> live in San Francisco, so street parking is not really an option.  My 
> garage is narrow, and I want to make sure a 944 would fit.  How about a 
> 924S?  Is it significantly narrower than the 944?

According to the tech book (WKD 423 320 - Porsche 924S/944 Models
Dimensions Tolerances), the width of a 924S is 1685 mm, while the width of a
944 is 1735 mm.

The conversion to inches/feet/yards/furlongs/etc. is left as an exercise for
the student...

George Beuselinck

Date: Thu, Oct 6, 1994 11:40 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Returned mail: Host unknown (fwd)

(this just bounced)
To: john@pelican.hac.com931-3910
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in tires

In message <9410051940.AA04809@pelican.hac.com> John (619 writes:
> > Bruce -
> > 
> > Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is 
> > lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your 
> > tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget 
> > about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us 
> > both know.

[snip]
> 	Me thinks this is an old (racer's) wives tale... In the pressure/temperature
> range in question both N2 and Air (which is 78% N2) behave as nearly ideal 
> gasses.
> That means that :
> 
> (Pressure) * (Volume) = (number of moles of gas) * (gas constant R) * 
> (absolute temperature)

True.
End of Porschephiles

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 1994 14:56:06 -0500
From: sarsfld@tiac.net (Steve Sarsfield)
Subject: Re: Wiper Shudder

Michael Hodos recently wrote:

>>Yes, I've been living with [windshield shudder] for so long, I sort of take
>>it for granted.  That's why I thought I'd give the list a try . . . just in
>>case someone had a miracle solution. 

Although I haven't seen it on my Porsche, I have seen windshield wiper
shudder on my wife's 91 Plymouth Laser.  I saw an edition of Owings Motor
Week, the PBS TV show, that suggested the following course of action for
shudder. First, wipe your windshield down with Prep-Sol (while trying not
to get any on the rubber). I tried this, but it didn't really help.  Of
course, it suggested replacing the blades or the whole wiper.  Didn't help
the Laser.  Then it suggested tightening, or replacing the springs on the
underside of the wiper blade.  It makes sense, if the springs are worn, you
won't get enough tension against the windshield, and they'll shudder. 
Success.


On another subject:
My 1983 944 makes what I can describe as nothing else but a short,
flatulent sound after driving about 20-25 minutes.  It makes the sound once
and only once during each trip.  The sound seems to be coming from the
front driver's side - maybe the wheel area.  At first, I thought it was the
*&^$!!* useless power antennae motor kicking in every once and while,
giving its last gasps.  But now I'm not so sure as it seems to happen more
often when cornering.

I'm not too worried about it, but I wondered if other 944'ers out there
have run into this.  (When it happens, my wife and I just look at each
other and excuse ourselves.)

...I'm already imagining the responses I'll get to this one.

Date: Thu,  6 Oct 94 13:20:39 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 930 Turbo HP History

>Subject: 930 Performance questions

>       Does anybody know the horsepower, 0-60, and 1/4 mile of the 930s?
>(All American models).  The 3.0 and the 3.3 liter.  You can leave
>out the 3.6 Turbo - I can't afford it!  :)  I drove an '87 Slantnose
>Turbo about a year ago and it didn't seem to be as quick as a '92 Turbo
>I drove.  When did they change the engine to the 3.3 and are there
>variations in horsepower for the same engine sizes?  Please forgive the
>bundle of questions.  Also, what are the years that Porsche did not ship.
 >      Thanks,
 >      Chris Crowe

  I've never had a 930,(I've tried to buy 2) but I do know;
  1. The 3.0 liter appeared in '76, HP was about 235 (I still have the
     Panorama introducing this model !).
  2. The 3.3 liter came out in '78 with 254hp, but also the significant
     improvments of the Intercooler and the 917 brakes. I could only reason
     that the intercooler goes a long way in making the engine survive.
     Apparently you can find intercoolers for the earlier cars, but you'll
     have to change the rear decklid to the "tray" type to fit.
       Both the 3.0 and 3.3 use an aluminum case, but I'm guessing the
     3.0 didn't include a fender-mounted oil cooler. 
  3. I guess in '85 HP became 282, apparently still under CIS power.
     I don't know when/if DME was adpoted for the 3.3l turbo.
  4. Despite what Porsche Claims, the first production car with a Turbo
     WASN'T the 930, it was the 12-year-earlier Corvair. Agreed, 18-second
     quarter mile then probably left room for some improvement...
  5. The Porsche Turbo was imported every single year to the US, though
     HP is 20-35hp less because of exhaust changes. A lot of 930s in the
     US are Euro converts, though.
  6. How fast are each ? How fast can you drive ??  A Porsche mechanic
     assured me that most 930s have been slid over a curb sometime in their
     life, but if 13 second quarter miles aren't enough you can change
     the exhaust, get a bigger intercooler/bump the boost, replace the cams
     with SC cams, and mill the barrels to up the compression, or replace to
     a bigger turbo.

      Staying with a '78 or newer car probably makes sense, I'm sure a lot
     of people would argue that a 944 turbo is faster, safer and cheaper,
     but it sure lacks the visual impact of the 930.

              - Lee A, no turbos here


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 11:12:45 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: My Windshield Wiper solution

Michael Hodos writes:

>Has anyone figured out how to reliably stop the windshield wiper shudder that
>seems to develop a few days into the rainy season?

I don't know if my solution is the ultimate answer but I will tell you what 
has worked for me!

For one thing I keep my windshield clean--I clean it or at least wipe the dust 
off every time I fill the gas up.

The next and most important thing is that I try to "park" the wipers with the 
blades bending opposite of it's normal "off" position.  In other words, 
under normal conditions whenever you turn the wipers off, the wipers will come 
to rest at the end of it's last swipe with the blades slightly bent up towards 
the top.  But what I do is at the end of the day or when I finally put the car 
away for the night, I will pull the wipers out from the windshield and force 
(very slightly) to make the blades bend downward so that the blades will rest 
with the opposite bend.  My theory is that since the blades are always bending 
one way, it bends against the windshield during the swipe vs. bending with the 
wipe during operation.

Lastly whenever you have to use the wipers, always make sure that the 
windshield is wet.  You don't want to use the wipers against the dirt or dust 
that will scratch your windshield.  The dirt will also ruin the the blades.

Since I tend to keep my windshield relatively clean, I don't use nor need 
Rain-X.  I don't need to use the wipers during a heavy rainstorm on freeway 
driving.  Of course once I use the wipers on the freeway, then I have to use 
the wipers.  Usually if it starts to rain while I'm on the freeway, I don't 
need to use my wipers since the wind current tends to push the raindrops away 
and allow me to see w/o using the wipers.  I do this for both day or night.

Since I "discovered" this solution, my wipers have lasted about 5 or 6 years 
before needing replacement.  I think the opposite bends on the blades also 
protects it from the sun too.

I don't do this all the time since my wife also drive "my" cars.  I only do 
this when I'm driving the car that just came in from the rain or if I remember 
to do it to the car that my wife just brought back home.  Otherwise, I wait 
until I get gas and wipe the windshield clean before bending the blades down. 
 My wife couldn't be bothered with such minor details.

That's "my little secret" brew for the windshield wipers.  It seems to work 
for me and I still do this since I have nothing to lose except for a few 
seconds after bring the car home or I make sure to wipe the windshield clean 
every fill-up and car wash.

Quincy Dong
QLD1@pge.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 20:35:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Alternative to 944 belt tension gauge

 
We all know that it is important to use this $360+ tool to tension a $20
timing belt. However, how feasible would it be to find a cheaper, non-Porsche
specific, equally precise belt tension gauge and calibrate it against the
factory gauge? (In fact, I think the original tool comes with a special
piece of metal for calibration). Of course, you'd have to make sure it
would fit within the confines of the belt assembly. These would probably 
sell like 'hot-cakes'. Just an idea...

Chris
'86 944


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 94 21:27 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Bearings

Ross,

The 0.5" of play at the tire top is not good.  It could be a wheel
bearing, it could also be a strut going bad, or it could be the control
arm ball joint.

You already know how to check the ball joint.  To check the strut, first
take the wheel off.  Put one hand on the strut, the other on the top
of the rotor.  Wiggle the rotor in and out with hand #2.  Hand #1 will
tell you whether the strut is indeed internally loose and moving.

Loose struts are very common, and are often misdiagnosed as a bad
wheel bearing.  A certain amount of looseness is no big deal.  Past
a certain point, the camber change will affect handling.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 1994 13:47:21 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 944 S2 vs Turbo S

Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com> wrote:

>I am evaluating what my next car should be.  I want a step up from
>my '84 944.  The car will be used for everything: daily driver, auto-x,
>and driver's ed at the track.  Seems like the S2 would have an
>advantage in auto-x and in stop and go traffic because of the
>lack of turbo lag.  The turbo, of course, would be faster at the
>track.  Anyone driven both and care to comment?  You turbo
>owners, do you notice the turbo lag when autocrossing or in
>traffic?

Caveat: the following is not an expert opinion but simply my experience and 
opinion.

I have limited experience with the 944S having test-driven an '87 once; none 
with the 944S2.  I remember making the used-car slimeball very nervous with my
spirited acceleration and cornering.  The power in the 16-valve seemed to come
on strongly above approx. 4000rpm very smoothly.  However, below 4500, I found
it lacking.  I expect the S2 is similar in nature.

I am very familiar with the Turbo but I have not driven the Turbo S.  I expect
they drive similarly. In the Turbo, at lower speeds, boost kicks in between 
2500-3000 rpm and is much like an on-off switch but I've gotten used to 
flooring the pedal and waiting a sec or so for the turbo to spool up.  I don't
find my Turbo very competitive in autox compared to naturally aspirated 911s 
or 914s, esp. in tight, short tracks.  The main reason is due to the on-off 
nature of the turbo at the low speeds typical in autox.  I suspect that the 
944S2 will be quicker than the Turbo at autox, all other factors being equal. 
 However, on fast highway drives and on the track, I don't notice the turbo 
lag if the gears are selected properly.  Keeping the revs up by 
heel-and-toeing probably helps.   Another 'future' advantage to the turbos is
the cheap and simple chip upgrades for more power, and someday you **will** 
want more power.

I've seen several claims that the Turbos are "driven harder" and are therefore
subject to abuse and higher maintenance costs.  I question this theory since 
**any** car could have been driven very hard and abused.  

Trivia question: How many Turbo owners on this list have actually had to 
replace the turbo/intercooler or other components specific to the Turbo 
models?  The owners on this list are probably not representative of the 
general population out there since a lot of us track our cars but also 
maintain them better.

When I buy again, it will be a 914 for play and someday a Turbo S or 911.

Whew!  This has gotten more lengthy than I expected...

____________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	               '87 951 Pearl Black 
AT&T Business Communication Services   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ 
sjagernauth@attmail.com    "I speaketh not for my employer"



					    
                                   

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 22:40:11 -0400 (EDT)
From: Carl Brian Klinetob <vp@brahms.udel.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 p-brake question


Matt,
	My 83 just had the same problem.  It just takes a little labor 
time (less than one hour)and a few basic tools.  There are no broken 
parts, the engaging clip just needs to be repositioned.  The problem is a 
little hard to explain but becomes clear when the handle is examined.  
	Basically, if you pull the handle too high the clip that holds
the handle up moves past all the teeth.  No matter how hard you push the 
button, the clip won't disengage far enough to move back over the teeth.
The only option is to force the handle down, which pushes the clip around 
so it won't engage anymore.  Like I said, it doesn't make much sense now, 
but the fix is rather simple.  Don't let it stop you from buying a perfectly 
good car.
	Also, if the handle needs to be pulled that far to stop the 
car from moving, check the brake pads for wear or tighted the p-brake 
cable. 

	Good luck finding a car!


Brian Klinetob
University of Delaware
'83 944 
'68 Firebird 400

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 22:43:18 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 914 Q about engine swaps (was 914's with transplanted V8's)

Kennedy Engineered Products sells a number of adapter kits to mate 
various engines with other transmissions including small block v8's and 
v6's to both 901 and 915 gearboxes. Although you can buy one of the 
Detroit iron monsters for your 914, why not just take a much lighter 911 
that will fit in quite nicely. The oil system is sort of messy, but no 
worse than the water cooling you would need. And, if you put a non-P 
engine in you will (I think) ruin the resale value to most P-car folk.

p.s. Kennedy can be reached at 38830 17th Street East
Palmdale, CA 93550 or by phone at 805-272-1147
They have an interesting catalog and are nice to deal with
