Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 22:26:25 -0500
From: sundt@cc.bellcore.com (Mark Sundt)
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Shimmy Revisited Again!

>I have tried the technique where you apply the brakes when the problem occurs,
>while keeping a constant speed. No change with the shimmy. No shimmy during
>braking.
>
>I also have some movement in the front wheels at the top of the strut, when I
>move the wheel top to bottom. I have been told that this is normal? Side to
>side is nice and solid.
>Possible wheel bearings? Had those checked 7K ago, they were adjusted, and
>said to be fine by the "mechanic" who said I needed upper strut bearings!
>
>I am at a loss. Maybe suspension components? Everything looks OK?

Mike,

The only shimmy that I ever had was on a Volkswagen Rabbit that had a bad
tie rod end. The shimmy got worse the faster you went; at 65+ it was
unbearable. When braking this shimmy also went away. Did someone
specifically check out your tie rods or steering rack for play?

If that doesn't pan out, I would concur with Jim Selders that you should
zero in on the wheel bearing(s)

Hope this helps.

Mark



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 05 Oct 94 23:16:23 EDT
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Do I really want an early 911 S?

dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us asked :

- --------------------------------
Subject: Do I really want a '69 911S?

Though my 914/6 3.0 liter  project has been a blast, I'm now inspired to 
replace my trusty '76 911 with something more interesting. I've often 
thought a '69, '70, or '71 lightweight "S" would really be fun to own. I 
really don't care about the gas mileage, but how much trouble does the 
high compression bring about in terms of fuel? It's almost impossible to 
find 92 octane gas here in the Ozarks.
- -------------------------------------

Dave, 

Here is some info about the eary 911 S models, and some opinions.

The '69 S is about as fast in the 1/4 mile as the 2.4 T. Also the '69S
pistons are no longer available. The 2.2 ('70 & '71) is better, and with more
power. They were also available with some cool lightweight options like the
aluminum rear deck lid and license panel. I don't know what else made them so
light, but I remember a road test that showed about 2100 lbs weight (I don't
really believe it). The 2.2S may be hard to run on 92 octane gas, the 2.0 S
being even worse (CAM2 probably). 

The 2.4S has much lower compression (8.5 to 1) and will run fine on most
premium or PLUS grades of unleaded gas. The '72 and '73 did not offer the
lightweight options, but should weigh no more than 2300 pounds. (Of course
you can make them light if you want!) The 2.4 S engine is more tractable too.
Also rustproofing was better than the early models, with partial galvanizing
of chassis steel. The tranny is stronger too, and better than the weird
"pull" clutch of '71 or so. So you shouldn't overlook the 2.4 S. An E should
be nearly as good, but seems hard to find lately.

Good luck, hope you can find a nice early S !

Mike Piera '72 911 S Targa   AnalogMike@aol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 16:02:01 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: N2 in tires


N2 in tires?  Because it eliminates oxidation of the rubber (and other
organics), greatly extending the life of the carcass.  Aircraft use it
(some do, anyway) because carcass failure is so annoying when it happens
halfway down the runway at liftoff speed with all the fuel tanks 
full...  I think N2 for car tires was even discussed in the popular
press a decade or so ago, at which time tire life increases by a factor
of several were claimed. 

For racers, who might lovingly deposit their tread around the track
in an afternoon, the time vs. oxidation issue might not be such a big
deal.  But then, carcass failure at the end of the main straight IS
equally annoying...

 -Ed


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 22:37:00 -0500
From: sundt@cc.bellcore.com (Mark Sundt)
Subject: Re: 911 fuel injection trouble

>1976 911-S  2.7L  with K-jetronic FI
>My car is very very hard to start - 15-20 seconds of cranking -
>several times.  Finally it catches but seems like it runs on 3
>cylinders for a short while.  Thermoswitch kicks in and it smooths out
>but runs rough until warm.  When warm/hot it runs great, no miss, good
>acceleration, runs real smooth .

Greg,

Sounds like the warm up regulator. These units act like a choke. They
enrich the fuel mixture (by altering the fuel system pressure) over the
first ~2 minutes of operation. Their primary failure mode is to get stuck
in one position and stop making any adjustment. I used a fuel injection
pressure tester to check for this	type of failure; bought one a number of
years ago from	a Saab dealer (there must be much better sources now) and
have found it indespensible.	They can also help you set the fuel system
pressure (via shims)	and help in diagnosing other problems, too.

The cold start valve only operates for a few seconds in very cold weather,
so it is not likely to be the cause. Also, an air leak major enough to
prevent starting the car will also keep it from idling when it is warm; so
this is also not likely.

Hope this helps.

Mark
'86 951 Guards Red
sundt@cc.bellcore.com



------------------------------

Date: 05 Oct 94 23:14:54 EDT
From: Bill Petersen <76670.1350@compuserve.com>
Subject: State Farm Insurance

Ross,

I'm intrigued that you have had great experience with this firm, yet, expect
them to due you in.

While it is true that you will pay if you have a chargeable accident (3 years,
not 5) the percentage you will pay as an accident sircharge is less that many.
Most customers prefer to pay lower rates while they are accident/ticket free,
while those having accidents pay more. 

The unfortunate fact is that statistically drivers with tickets/accidents have
accidents much more frequently than a separate group with no T or A. 

<If you have any kind
>of an accident, even if clearly not your fault, you get rated and pay more
>for 5 years anyway.  They're not interested in details; if they pay our
>for any reason, you pay it back.>

Not true. While it may differ from state, you do have to be at fault to receive
a sircharge (51% in Ca.). Depending upon how long you have been a client, and
accident free, the sircharge may actually be waived (while you continue to
receive an accident free discount!). They are VERY interested in details. Agent
and client feedback is crucial with this firm.

Disclaimer: I'm a State Farm Agent. <smile>

Ross, your carrier likes doing business with you. It is one company among a
diminishing breed where the president knows what is going on at the consumer
level, IMO.

<<All things considered, they get good marks
>from me.>

It's nice to hear and appreciated!  

<<If I were 25 years old, single, one speding ticket and
>driving a Corvette, They would hesitate about 5/8 of a second before
>showing that person the door.>

In Ca. there would be a 10% sircharge for the ticket. (Waived depending upon
how long with the Co.) Well, if it's a Reckless or DUI.....

Regards,

...Bill

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 23:05:35 -0600
From: knestle@interaccess.com (Ken Nestle)
Subject: BTDT 914 V8 (was 914 Q about engine swaps)

>Stephen writes of 914's with american powerplants:
>(at least one anyway).
>
>I've seen one of these, and, in its favor, it goes like a bat out the Fire.
>I never drove it so I can't comment on its handling, but I don't expect it
>handled well

You say you can't comment, then you comment. More better, you shouldn't
comment :-)

>--too much rear weight bias.

A common misconception. With my car, the combination of aluminum heads, and
the fact that the bulk of V8 extends further forward than original four,
results in almost original weight bias. With the extra power, a little
extra weight on the rear tires is not a disadvantage.

>Were I going to try swapping a V8
>into the 914 (I'm not, BTW) I'd think about an lighter alloy engine.  Hmm...
>I wonder if a 928 power plant would fit.  That'd keep things in the family.

And the cost in the stratosphere!

>The major problem, however, with any engine swap that brings appreciable
>power gains is that the rest of the car must be beefed up to handle that
>extra power. Bigger brakes, more rubber on the road, beefier chassis,
>stronger transaxle, new electrical systems (something has to drive the
>transplanted injection system), etc.

Absolutely!

>These are the things that tend to push
>these kinds projects into the hyperexpensive realms.

Agreed.

> Additionally, one has
>to keep the end product in mind.  Will it provide the charms of original 914
>only with more power or will it be an uncontrollable beast?  ('Course my
>wife claims my stock 914 is an uncontrollable beast).

Wether or not it is an _uncontrollable beast_ is strictly a function of
your own capabilities.
Anything less than judicious application of 400 HP can cause things to
happen with surprising suddeness.
But then there are twenty or thirty guys in this country who routinely
drive 5,000 horsepower vehicles to 300+ MPH in less than 5 seconds. To
them, this is a Sunday drive. To anyone else it would fall somewhere
between excitement overload and sheer terror.
Let your own level of competence be your guide.


Ken Nestle
'75 914 (355 CU, 399 HP Chevy power)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 11:47:28 -0500
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Dismantling a (Holset) turbocharger

Hi Len,

I have an automotive-size turbocharger installed in the lab, and use it 
in experiments when I teach my piston engines and turbomachinery classes
at Washington University. It's a Holset (UK) turbo, designed for Cummins
diesel engines (USA), so your 930 turbo may be different. I have never
seen the insides of the 930 turbo, but all the many others I have seen are
similar to the description below. 

When the turbo is stationary it is normal to have A BIT of play in the 
shaft and A BIT of oil leaking from the shaft. Stress, A BIT. The shaft 
rotation provides the stability and the oil sealing. 

In order to take the Holset apart you need to take out the compressor
diffuser and the turbine diffuser (the scrolls), each in two parts (a
total of four sets of bolts around the perimeter).   What's left is the
middle of the body containing the oil supply and return holes, with the
two impellers (compressor and turbine) at either end. Between the backs of
the two impellers are the shields and the labyrinths on the shaft that 
keep the oil inside the middle of the body. The shaft is integral with the 
turbine impeller, which slides out the turbine side after you have removed
from it the compressor impeller and associated seals, labyrinth, packing
etc. In other cases the turbine is also held on the shaft by a mechanism.
Depending on the direction of shaft rotation, there may be reverse threads
on the nut(s) that hold(s) the impeller(s) on the shaft. It is critical
to get the right torque on this (these) nut(s).  

Now for the bad news. The turbine-impeller/shaft/compressor-impeller
assembly is balanced as a unit, and if you take it apart you must mark it
so that you maintain the azimuthal orientation between the  components,
otherwise it will likely rub and self-destruct when you put it back in
operation. By self-destruct I mean the impeller(s) will rub on  the
diffuser or back shield, rub some metal off, overheat, and burn.  In this
process you are also likely to bend the shaft. You will see the balancing
marks as part of the metal that has been shaved off the perimeter of the
impellers, the back of the impellers, and perhaps the two ends of the
shaft. This balancing is critical; the unit has small diameter, but in
normal operation it rotates at high rpm (the Holset goes up to 150,000
rpm). I would not know where to balance these units. In the past I had
sent mine once to Cummins for balancing (but this was a special case, 
donation to the University). I had also seen a larger compressor impeller
(about 30 inches in diameter), from a slow speed marine diesel engine,
balanced in 1981 at Hellenic Shipyards.

I hope I am not the bearer of bad news, and that this helps.

(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis   email ourios@zeus.wustl.edu 
87 911 Carrera targa - summer yellow, black full leather interior

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Oct 1994 14:01:50 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Track Upgrades

>Bruce -
>
>Most people will tell you that it is to save on weight (i.e. nitrogen is
>lighter than air).......NOT.  It is that Nitrogen will not expand as your
>tires heat up.  Thus, after you set your tire pressures you can forget
>about having to adjust them.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure someone will let us
>both know.

Mike,

This is hogwash!!

Air is 78.06% nitrogen gas by volume (75.5% by weight). But this is not
even important when you understand that all gases act according to a set
of laws. These laws are disussed below (reprinted without permission from
Grolier's Encyclopedia):

         In chemistry and physics, the behavior of gases under varying
         conditions of temperature, pressure, and volume may be
         described and predicted by a set of equations, or gas laws.
         These laws were determined by measurements of actual gases and
         are valid for all substances in the gaseous state.

         The first quantitative measurements on gases were published by
         Robert Boyle in 1660. He observed that if an enclosed amount of
         gas is compressed until it is half its original volume while
         the temperature is kept constant, the pressure will be doubled.
         Quantitatively, Boyle's law is PV = constant, where the value
         of the constant depends on the temperature and the amount of
         gas present.

         Jacques Charles later studied the relationship between the
         temperature of the gas and its volume while maintaining
         constant pressure. Charles observed a steady increase in the
         volume as the temperature increased. Specifically he found that
         for every degree Celsius rise in temperature, the gas volume
         increased by 1/273 of its volume at 0 deg C.

         Charles's observations led to the concept of the absolute
         (Kelvin) temperature scale, since the gas, according to the
         equation, would have zero volume at -273 deg C. The absolute
         temperature scale was defined so that absolute zero equals -273
         deg C and each absolute degree is the same size as a Celsius
         degree. (The modern value for absolute zero is -273.15 deg C.)
         This new temperature scale allows Charles's law to be written
         V/T = constant, where V is the volume of the gas, T is the
         temperature on the absolute scale, and the constant depends on
         the pressure and the amount of gas present. An important device
         resulting from Charles's law is the gas thermometer.

         Joseph Guy-Lussac studied the relationship between pressure and
         temperature and in 1802 found an equation similar to Charles's
         law: P/T = constant.

         Boyle's, Charles's, and Gay-Lussac's laws may be combined to
         express a generalized gas law, PV/T = constant, where the value
         of the constant depends on the amount of gas present and T is
         the absolute (or Kelvin) temperature.

         The generalized gas law may be written in another form: PV/T =
         nR, or PV = nRT; in this form it is called the ideal-gas law. R
         is the gas constant, and n is the number of moles of gas. The
         gas constant can be evaluated experimentally as R = 0.082 liter
         atm/kelvin moles. Knowing R, the fourth variable can be
         evaluated if any three are known.

         The laws discussed above are valid for most gases at moderate
         temperatures and pressures. At low temperatures and high
         pressures, gases deviate from the above laws because the
         molecules are moving slowly at low temperatures and they are
         closer together on the average at higher pressures. Both of
         these effects increase the attractive forces between the
         molecules that cause the deviations from the normal gas laws.

         The gas laws are used by chemists to measure amounts of gases.
         The weighing of gases is usually cumbersome and a technique to
         be avoided, but by using the gas laws the chemist can obtain
         the weight of gas simply by measuring the volume of the gas at
         a known temperature and pressure.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 18:56:59 EDT
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re : 911 fuel injection trouble

>1976 911-S  2.7L  with K-jetronic FI
>My car is very very hard to start - 15-20 seconds of cranking - 
>several times.  Finally it catches but seems like it runs on 3
>cylinders for a short while.  Thermoswitch kicks in and it smooths out
>but runs rough until warm.  When warm/hot it runs great, no miss, >good
acceleration, runs real smooth .

Does this happen when the engine is cold or hot?  If it is hot, I would
suggest measuring the pressure decay to see if the system is holding
fuel after you shut the car off.  Since you've replaced the fuel pump, we
can assume the check valve in the pump is OK.  I would guess the fuel
accumulator is leaking.  If the engine is cold when this happens, it
sounds like the cold start injector isn't working, because if it was, the
engine would most likely fire up - not just sit there and crank.  I would
also suggest you check the control pressure, as it sounds as if this may
be a problem (read "warm-up regulator").  If I'm not mistaken, when the
warm-up regulator fails, the control pressure stays on the high side,
causing the mixture to lean out.  This adversely affects starting.

Unfortunately, without doing some pressure tests, I think you'll only be
guessing if you attempt to start replacing components.  

Good Luck!!

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911 - with a new warm-up regulator

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 21:04:05 EDT
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Interesting 911 conversion

Those are some fairly high level names to drop! I have a friend that has
built an early (67) 911 for vintage racing and as part of the project went to
the trouble of grafting a '72 oil filler door and installing a complete '72
oil system like the one in Bruce's project car. A lot of work and of
questionable legality for vintage racing, but it will make for a better
balanced car! There is a historical basis for this type of system since the
911R used virtually the same approach.

      PhilVB

Date: 06 Oct 94 22:57:39 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Carrera 4

Hi, Mike.
 
Well, you asked for comments.
 
The nominal torque split of the 993 C4 is 31/69, unless the center
differential diffs. I don't know what its limits are, but I don't think it
can go as far as 0/100 or 100/0.
 
I think Audi also used an electronically modulated hydraulic clutch system
like the older C4 for their high-end AWD cars, but I'm not sure. Anybody out
there ever pull Audi duty under their cars?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date:     Thu, 6 Oct 1994 17:41 MDT
From: Hunter Heath  <HEATH@ENDO.MED.UTAH.EDU>
Subject:  Exhaust noise, love of

Dustin Boyette's paean to exhaust noise took me back to Lubbock, Texas, circa
1956 (are you tired of this yet?).  My first motor vehicle (age 13, yes,
legal in them days) was a Cushman Eagle, a kind of pseudo-motorcycle with
scooter-sized wheels.  It was a 6 hp one-lunger, but with the core taken out
of the exhaust pipe (one screw, and voila!), it made a truly wonderful sound,
to thrill a teenager's heart. Throttle up, back off suddenly, maybe blip it a
time or two... snarling lions, man.  Then there was my first car, a '51 Ford
flathead V-8; with dual glasspack mufflers, the rumble shook the earth at
least... well, a *block* away.  Vroom, blat-t-t-t!

Back to reality: the norm for exhaust noise has really changed since the
'60s, and things we could get away with then would get you a Big Ticket now.
My own tolerance for exhaust noise has decreased, maybe out of fear of
deafness, but also from my desire to listen to the radio at less than 100 dB.
And then there's simple consideration for others; the numbers of vehicles on
our streets are so much greater than when I was a lad that if very many of us
chose loud exhausts, life would be decidedly less pleasant.

I do admit an occasional hankering to make some *real* noise... wouldn't it
be nice is "lakes pipes" (any of you old farts remember those) were legal?

So, Dustin: enjoy your exhaust note, but *please* don't come by the house
full throttle at 3 a.m.!

Hunter

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 12:14:24 CDT
From: husain@zeus1.issc.com (Afsar Husain (N3564))
Subject: Re: Why gauges sometimes register high readings

Theo,

   On my 944 I had the same problem with my coolant gauge after I had
a new waterpump installed. The gauge will stay around the red zone. The
dealer where I had the job done, checked out the coolant system and
and assured me that the coolant temperature is fine and that the
gauge is just showing incorrect (high) reading. 

   Not willing  to compromise, I posted the problem to this list and
someone on the list suggested to properly bleed the coolant system. I
followed the recommended procedure to bleed the system and since then
I have had no problem ( i.e high reading ) from my coolant gauge.

Don't know much about Jetta or 924 but you ask for comments and
experiences ;-)

Regards,

Husian

> 
> This may explain why gauges (temp, fuel etc)  sometimes show higher or
> lower than expected. 
> 
> As cars get older the electrical connections weaken (corrosion, dust, 
> dirt etc increase the electrical resistance at the connectors), and as a
> result the gauges show a little higher than they did when the car was 
> newer. It has happened on my 87 Jetta and it had happened on my  1978 924.
> Both cars indicated slightly hotter coolant than when newer, both cars 
> were checked at Autobahn Inc, at different years.  Both times the coolant
> temps were within  limits although the gauges were showing higher than
> whan the cars were newer. In the case of the 924, the gauge was
> approaching red,  but the coolant temp was still acceptable. 
> 
> The 924 fuel gauge indicated empty when the tank was 1/3 full...
> 
> Anyone with additional comments/experience on these?...
> 
> (Theo)
> Theodosios Korakianitis   email ourios@zeus.wustl.edu 
> 87 911 Carrera targa - summer yellow, black full leather interior
> 


- --

> N2 in tires?  Because it eliminates oxidation of the rubber (and other
> organics), greatly extending the life of the carcass.  Aircraft use it
> (some do, anyway) because carcass failure is so annoying when it happens
> halfway down the runway at liftoff speed with all the fuel tanks

cars.  I was told this at Harrod's years ago.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 94 07:16:30 EDT
From: jplawrence@goodyear.com (John Lawrence)
Subject: Re: tires and N2


>   Not Wisdom just a note that most airplane tires are filled with Nitrogen,
>so there must be a advantage in there usage, I assume for heat and cold a
>airplane tire must endure..
>
>  Damon
>
The reason airplane tires are inflated with nitrogen is because nitrogen
does not support combustion, which is important in the event of a fire or
explosion.

John P. Lawrence
Director, Elastomers & Reinforcement Research
The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.



------------------------------

Date: Fri,  7 Oct 94 10:27:29 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Oil Pressure (was: Re: Why gauges sometimes register high readings)

| From: Tim Flint  <tflint@netcom.com>
|
| My 944 reads the oil pressure high when it is cold. I've been wondering
| if this is a bad electrical connection or a problem with the sending unit?

This is normal.  Cold oil is much thicker (viscous) than warm oil and
generates more resistance to its being pumped through the oil
passages.  On cold start my 944 also registers oil pressure near
the top of the gauge.  When warm, the gauge reads about one
third of the way up at idle and then goes back up near the top
as RPMs increase.

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 94 08:56 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Why gauges sometimes register high readings

Tim,

>My 944 reads the oil pressure high when it is cold. I've been wondering 
>if this is a bad electrical connection or a problem with the sending unit?

Normal.  Expect to see about 5 bar off idle, 4 bar idle, when the car
is cold.  Can drop to under 2 bar at idle when hot.  Only worry if it
ever drops to or below 1 bar.

Symptom of a failed sender is that the meter pegs as soon as the electrics
are turned on but while the engine isn't running.

If you ever have to replace it (or have it replaced), take the old one
and open it up.  Tap around the crimp with a chisel.  Really a neat little
mechaism inside, calibrated and all.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 21:18 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: recall/update for 944

Ken,

Actually, this is for everyone on the list who is not an original
owner.  You ought to visit your friendly neighborhood dealer and
fill out a card they have.  This card lets PCNA know that you own
the car.  They'll notify you of any recalls and service actions.

The dealer can also look up the warranty, recall, and service
action history of any US Porsche, through PCNA.  They cannot, of
course, necessarily find its non-warranty service records.  However,
they as often as not can point you to the selling dealer, who is
likely to have the records, often computerized and therefore
easily available.

We went through this process when we picked up a used Benz for
Mrs. Gross last Feb.  Most educational.

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 15:51:58 -0700 (PDT)
From: aa@mda.ca (Adrian Alleyne)
Subject: RE: Why gauges sometimes register high readings

>>In the case of the 924, the gauge was
>>approaching red,  but the coolant temp was still acceptable.
>>The 924 fuel gauge indicated empty when the tank was 1/3 full...
>>Anyone with additional comments/experience on these?...

I had a similar experience after the first time I worked on my 951.  If more
than one gauge is acting strange at the same time I would suspect that
there is a common problem.  In my case I had removed the negative terminal
to the battery which caused the other end (ground to the car body) to loosen.
This resulted in a weak grounding point.

Easy solution is to remove the other end of the battery negative cable, clean
connector and connection area on the body, then replace and tighten to the 
correct torque.  This solved the faulty gauge readings.

Adrian
'86 951 Black (New Clutch - I will post the story with comments on the
                            procedure in the porschephiles archive)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 07:26:48 -0600
From: swig@drmail.dr.att.com (SwigertDB)
Subject: 944 Vibration Problem

I have a problem that I hope some of you may be able
to help with.  I have a 85.5 944 that has a vibration
noticed by the gear shifter shaking around whenever
the RPM reaches about 3700 -3900.  This happens with
the car sitting still, clutch in and out, in any gear
(except I haven't tried in 5th yet).  It goes away with
higher and lower rpms.  It shows both directions through
the band.

The engine mounts are now both new, the timing belts have
now been checked multiple times, all exhaust mounts have
been looked at, and this week the transmission mount has
been examined.  If you have any additional ideas or thoughts,
I would appreciate them.

Thanks in advance,
Duane Swigert
(303) 538-1391
swig@dr.att.com
85.5 944
72 914

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 10:11:45 +0500
From: Barry Chapin 617-258-2809 <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in Tires humor

>Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 09:50:25 MDT
>From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
>Subject: Nitrogen in tires
>
>Mike Lommatzsch said:
>>Nitrogen will not expand as your tires heat up.
>
>Jerry944T said:
>>Serious racers use nitrogen in their tires as it does not expand
>as much as air when heated.
>

Well I use Helium in my tires, to make my car lighter and therefore
go faster.  It is amazing, when I go over the crest of a hill, I can
get great hang times, and then turn on the rocket fuel thrusters to
let me pass in the overhead lane.  I am thinking aobut using a system
such as the Humm-Vee (Hummer) uses to inflate/deflate tires while driving.
This way, I could replace the Helium with Freon without even stopping, 
and thus cool the car more.  Or I could use nitrous-oxide and always drive
around happy  with a smile :-) :-) :-)

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 Euro-911 RUF Widebody Targa, w/lightweight helium wheels.

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 17:35:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Keith M Roberts <kroberts@crl.com>
Subject: Re: 930 Performance questions



On Thu, 6 Oct 1994, Steve Bochinski wrote:

> I also have a question... How many of the years were
> 4 speed vs. 5 speed?  Do you really have to crank up
> the rpms to get to top speed?  (I've been wondering
> about this because I have a 5 speed in my 73 911 and
> can't really imagine going back to 4 speeds!)
> 
> thanks,
> Steve

I'm not sure when Porsche started to use 5-speeds in the 930, but my
'84 has a 4-speed and I can assure you that you won't run out of gears.
My car is good for 55 m.p.h in first, 85-90 in second,and ~130 in third.
The owners manual says top speed is 160, though i've never seen it.

I would like to have a 5 (or 6) speed in my car though. The gearing is so
high that starting from a dead stop can't be done quickly.

Keith Roberts

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 1994 11:57:17 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: JOIN PCA, DAMN IT!!!

This note is *NOT TO FLAME ANYONE* (especially you, Rudy), but I cannot
believe that anybody with a Porsche automobile and living "State Side"
would not be a member of the PCA.   Just receiving PANORAMA once a month is
more than worth the price of admission.

Plus, you will be assigned a Region (based on your geographical location)
wherein you will meet, greet, or otherwise get to know dozens, hundreds,
maybe even thousands, of other P-car owning, racing, touring, autocrossing,
rallying folks.  Sorta like a face-to-face Internet group.

While some Regions are more active than others, all of them host socials
and driving events through out the year, and all produce some kind of a
newsletter with even more helpful and entertaining information.

Just do it!

Okay, if you live "Out West" there is always POC, the Porsche Owners Club,
but you won't get PANO and their parties are held in L.A. They do have a
damn fine Driver's Ed and Racing program though.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 94 08:24:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw3.az05.bull.com>
Subject: Re: Why gauges sometimes register high readings


I would suggest it indicates that your oil is still viscous and has not 
thinned out  due to heating.

944s tend to run with the oil pressure up in the the 4-5 range on the gauge, 
mine only drops to 3 when the engine is both idling and warm.

If you are still concerned check you have a clean filter and clean, new  oil 
of the correct viscosity for the climate you operate the vehicle in and then 
check again.
 ----------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 09:41:44 +0600

    > ....I noticed Zim's has rear 356 rotors for $49.95.  I thought
>that looked pretty good vs. Stoddards, etc at about $120.  While

I have been unhappy with Stoddard's rotor pricing, so I can believe
their high prices, as the same high costs were applied
to my '66 912!  One other thing to watch for:  The small grommet
which holds the emergency brake cable in place is mighty expensive!
You may want (as I did) to clean up the trailing/bannana arms while
you're there.  That little grommet COSTS $28.00 EACH! FROM STODDARD.
And they are the only ones to carry it.  I hunted high-and-low for a
replacemt from the local hw store, but, ended up getting them from
Stoddard and grumbling about the bill.

(However, that was nothing compared to a bushing for the rear of the
front suspension A-Arm, which was $185.00 each, and only available
from Stoddards!  Ouch!)

Ron De Lange

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 8:34:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: Clark Wallace <SAVE@cpva.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 944 hood badge removal

> Dear Porsche Friends:
> I can't seem to be able to get to the badge's back on the 944. I even removed
> the front bumper (had a headlight washer leak...) but could not get to it.
> 
> Are they just pressed on? Held in place by glue or what?!!

Lou...

After reading the responses provided by Kevin and George I'm going to have to
qualify the below as a possibly non-944-universal solution - just to protect
my hiney!  But, on the 944s2 you have to pull the front cowling to access the
air filter and once you've got the cowling in hand, the plastic caps holding
the badge in place are there for the taking (or removing as the case might be).

The cowling (on my s2) is held in place by a row of screws along the hood line,
and a couple of bolts and screws which can be accessed by raising the head
lights and removing the weatherstripping sandwiched between the frame and
the front valence. I realize your front valance is different from mine, but
I would think the cowlings are universal. However, its very possible the s2
cowlings were modified to permit easy removal for the filter change.  Anyway,
with the fasteners removed, you slide the cowling forward and its off!

Once you've located all the fasteners it's really a quick operation, about 30
minutes roundtrip. I would definitely investigate whether or not this procedure
is compatible with your vintage of 944.  Prying the badge off doesn't sound
too appetizing . . 

Good Luck, Clark

------------------------------

Date: 07 Oct 94 11:57:54 EDT

Subject: P-limo & where to buy '72-73 S

P-Limo) One year, Rocky A. who owns the Benihana restaurant chain ran the 
One Lap of America race in a 911 limo, which I believe was based on a '72 
911T Targa. OLOA is primarily a street TSD rally but does include track 
racing and auto-x for points. My favorite entrant came from two guys who 
each had a Dodge Omni Goes Like Hell. They had crashed them before the 
race, 1 front, 1 rear, and ended up combining the front and rear clips to 
build one racer. Porsche entered a couple of 993's (non-limos) in the last 
one.

Where 2 buy 911S) Pano has mostly higher priced cars. And the cars are all 
over the country. Excellence magazine has cars in the classifieds. I would 
check the more reputable independant Porsche service shops in the area. 
Often customer cars are for sale, the cars can be seen close by and you can 
check out the service records without having to see the car first and deal 
with its owner. They will usually tell you if the car is tracked regularly, 
and why the owner is selling, 2 things an owner might lie about. It also 
helps you pick the shop that you want to do the pre-inspection of your 
prospective purchase. Regular customers always let their mechanics know 
when a car is for sale. All P-cars are maintenance-intensive, and 25 year 
old ones more so. My August issue of the Porsche Market Letter had 2 cars, 
both '73 911S for $15-17K, neither in CA. Sept. Pano had 6 cars $9K-27K, 2 
of which were in CA. Email me if you want the ads.

You also might want the check out any PCA events in your area. Probably not 
too many cars for sale, but it's still a shot.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 94 10:16:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: 928, what's it good for?


> Recommended as a tow vehicle for the 911!
> .....
> Phil Coffino
> 86' 928S

I can't imagine ANY Porsche being used as a tow vehicle, even for another 
Porsche, a pure waste of machinery.  However, Porsche does (or use to) sell 
a tow bar you can mount on the 928, for an outrageous fee of course.  Wonder 
how many they sold?  Or maybe I read this wrong,  perhaps you meant to say 
that the 911 should be towed?

In the NY/Philly area the 911 and 924/944 models are a fairly  common sight, 
they must be like Chevy's in California.  I've seen less than 10 928's the 
past year on the open road, double that if you include the two Porsche 
events I attended.  I bought a 928 mostly because you see so few.

The 928 is a great long distance highway cruiser, which is what I primarily 
do.  If I were going to go dashing around cones or race tracks on a regular 
basis, then I would opt for a 911 or 944.  I don't want to tick off the 
owners of other Porsche models, different Porsches for different needs.  I 
would however draw the line at a Porsche station wagon for fulfilling my 
future family hauling needs.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S
SmythB@DBISNA.COM

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 94 11:18:38 EDT
From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.an.hp.com>
Subject: alternate gases in tires.

FWIW Helium has been used in attempts to lower weight in bicycles.  The
US team at the Olympics and various others at track events and record
attempts are reported to have used Helium to save weight.  I've never
seen it done but it was reported in several publications.  Always seemed
really silly to me but bicycle racers do become obsessed with weight. 
In Barcelona the winning pursuit bike was built by Lotus, during
development they noticed that the painter had used primer because the
frame was overweight by something like 4 grams.  In the finale version
they didn't paint the frame at all to save about 12 grams.  Maybe
Porsche will build a track bike next ;-)

Ground breaking for the garage should begin this weekend,  I gave myself
room for a lift when funds become available.

PVM

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 94 16:39:54 PDT
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: 356 Zenith carb plug 


Ted Smith Writes . . .  
 
Okay pfilers, here's one for you.  I need a part for my Zenith carb on my 64C  
cpe.  It's a metal plug that fits into a recessed hole in the side that I  
guess was then peened with a punch to keep it in.  It fell out, a common  
experience I guess.  When I find one I'll epoxy it for a little extra  
security.  Does anyone know of a carb rebuilder in the SF Bay area who may  
have one?  Tried the Maestro and Dieters in Palo Alto with no luck.  Thanks in  
advance.    
 
Ted Smith  
ehsmith@us.oracle.com  
78 911SC  
68 912 Targa Softback  
64 356 cpe  
 
- ------------------------------ 
 
Ted: 
 
The plugs are brass and as far as I know they are not peened in place, just 
tightened firmly.   
 
(As an aside, on our way back from the Yosemite Fall Festival the Best In 
Class Street B - Steve Moore's one owner notchback coupe - lost the same plug 
and he had a few exciting moments hurredly soaking up gasoline with paper 
towels to prevent it from finding its way to a hot part of the engine!) 
 
I checked all my catalogues and I can't find a part number for the plug, but 
Stoddard does offer a Zenith carburator restoration service.  I suggest that 
you give them a call and see if you can convince them to sell you the plug. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super 90 Cabriolet

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 21:36 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Wheel Bearings

Husain,

   I am hoping that I will only have to disconnect the Brakes and Rotor
   assembly, tie-rod end and the bottom two bolts of the Struts assembly. 
   Is this a very simple view and am I missing something?

Yes, that's about right.

   I picked up a used spindle from "Porschephiles' very own George B."
   Any opinions on used parts of this nature?

Well, you know that I think George is a pretty square dealer.  In my
own case, since we have a Magnaflux kit, I'd check 'em with it.

   How difficult is it to disconnect the tie rod end from the spindle
   assembly without the special tie-rod puller tool?

No, you really do not.  It's a waste of money most often.  I bought
one like six years ago, used it once, and gave it to the shop last
year after five years of dust gathering.  It would be a help I suppose
in the odd case of the knuckle really being corroded/etc. onto the
ball stub.  But I wouldn't throw $80 at what is likely a non-problem.

   Do I need a spring compressor for the struts or not?

Not for this job, only if you're replacing the struts at the same time.
Don't event bother disassembling the top of the strut, that is, from
the fender.

   If I mark the location of each disconnected part, would I still
   need an alignment after the assembly?

Ah, well, as a practical matter, I'd say so.

   I only have access to Haynes Manual, is that enough for this 
   job?

Kind of inaccurate, but you can figure most stuff out.  I'd at least
pick up a tech spec booklette for your car so's you know the torque
values.  WKD.423.320.

Stuff to think about doing (in for a dime, in for a dollar):

 - Check rotor thickness and replace if too thin,
 - Replace the two bolts, nuts, etc., which attach the spindle
   to the strut (one eccentric, one normal).  They tend to fasten
   less well after several on/off cycles.
 - Replace the wheel bearings.  If not replace, at least clean
   and repack.
 - Use anti-seize.

Why are you replacing both spindles?  Or should I not ask?

Kevin

Date: Fri, Oct 7, 1994 10:51 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Grow Up

> > > I want my cars to sound like that. An exhaust note which
> > > says "this car's got balls!" and wakes the neighbors at 3AM!!!
[snip]
> > Say, dude, you're an a__h___...  ooops, this is the NEW Porschephiles...
> > er, um, you are a rude and inconsiderate person, and all other Porsche
> > drivers have to live with the stigma that people like you create.  I
> > like the sound too... but save it for the track!  250 million other
> > people have to share the rest of the country with you.
[snip]
> Very well said. I think we have a responsibility to one another. What's
> so cool about waking up your neighbors at 3AM? Immature (sp?) behaviour.
> I don't care to be woken up at 3AM becuase of my neighbor's car, so I
> certainly won't do that to someone else.  I refuse to put loud mufflers on 
> my car even though I can get extra power or better mileage.

I don't want to be guilty of "piling-on" here, but this message needs to be
heard.  Since the anti-social behaviour of any member of an identifiable
group tends to be associated with all members of that group; in a word,
"Don't!"  Waking your neighbors who need their sleep in the course of
earning a living, is beyond juvenile or stupid.  It is *SERIOUSLY* anti-
social.  Mellow is cool, LOUD is *anti-social*.

If you were in his environment, would you provoke an adult male predator;
say, for the sake of argument, a sleeping adult male grizzly?  Haven't you
learned that the adult male human is *the* most dangerous predator alive?
What you propose is stupid and juvenile. In the real world, you will be apt
to discover, to your sorrow, it to be non-habitforming as well.

I suggest that you put a higher premium on your own health.  Immature and
assinine behaviour is often overlooked by adults.  However, when it goes
beyond that, and becomes *SERIOUSLY* anti-social, it frequently, if not
usually, invokes retaliation of some kind, appropriate to the offense.  If
you do that to me, and I can get near enough, you will need serious medical
attention immediately.

Please observe the conspicuous lack of smileys in this message.


Bart Chambers

Date: Fri,  7 Oct 94 17:01:00 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; refinishing Fuchs 

>From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
>Subject: Painting Fuchs
>My question: What would be the recommended method
>for coloring the black Fuchs to match the white car ?

    I don't know if you can have these powder painted, if you can
  thats your best finish (maybe not your best color match, but will last
  forever).

    Second best is to paint;
   1. Strip off any old paint (are the originals anodized ?). Strip off any
       wheel weights, valve stems, etc. Pop out your hubcaps and paint them
       separately.
   2. Prime them with an etching type or epoxy primer. I'd suggest
       Dupont Vari-Prime or PPG DP-90. These both have excellent adhesion
       and will stick to aluminum.
   3. Sand the primer. Forged wheels will take fewer iterations of this,
       depending on just how smooth you want your wheels.
   4. For the paint itself, try and match the same color code as your car with
       either Dupont Imron or PPG Deltron. These are both very durable
       urethanes, you will need one quart to do all 4 wheels. Gloss flattener
       isn't available for Imron, in case you want to take the sheen off the
       paint.
   5. If you were painting them for an aluminum look, I'd suggest using a
       silver metallic out of a spray can then topcoating with Deltron clear
       (like a DAU-82). Imron clear is only available in gallons, which is 
       probably more than you'll want to use. Don't use clear out of a spray
       can, they ALL yellow.

    When painting, the best advice I can give you is to not rush things;
   if you have a touchup gun, use it instead of a full size gun, or keep
   the volume of paint down/pressure at the gun down. With a very small
   surface  its easy to put on too much paint and get runs. Put on just
   enough, and let it get tacky before you put on the next coat.
    Lastly, make sure you take the wheels to someone who won't hack them
   completely up when remounting the tires (my last mistake).

         Good luck ! Lee A.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 09:55:17 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.WUstl.EDU>
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in tires

PV=nRT.  That is a formula I had not seen for a long time.  I agree with 
the basic idea of Howard Rubin.  But, I also disagree(am I messed up or 
what :-) ).
If I remember well, n is the number of moles.  Thus, within the air we 
have lots and lots of gases and as a result lots and lots of ions.  The 
result is that we probably get a much higher n, for a given volume of air 
than we would if we had just one gas, because of all the ions floating 
around. Further more, N2 is not going to break down to N + N.  To explain 
my thoughts, the only reason we use salt on winter roads is the fact that 
NaCl will break down in water to Na+ and Cl-.  There is a formula again 
that tells you how much the freezing temperature of a liquid will depress 
when you mix something in it.  One of the variables in this formula is 
again n.   Well, by having NaCl, just plain table salt, break down, you 
double the amount of n compared to what you would have if you mixed in 
the water something that does not break down.
Now you may ask, why nitrogen.  I will hazard a guess here.  It is rather 
inert.  Hydrogen or oxygen would be simply out of the question, too 
volatile.  I also think nitrogen is rather cheap when compared to 
helium, argon or crypron (or any one of the inert gases group VIII).
I apologize to the folks who find this way to dry and technical.

================================================================================
Menelaos Nicholaos Karamichalis, M.S.  |   510 South Kingshighway Boulevard
mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu		       |   Electronic Radiology Laboratory(ERL)
Work # (314)-362-6965		       |   Mallinckrodt Institute Of Radiology
Home # (314)-361-0865		       |   St. Louis, Missouri 63110, USA
	   Vote Picard/Riker for '96       "We make it so!"
================================================================================

> 
> Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 09:50:25 MDT
> From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
> Subject: Nitrogen in tires
> 
> Mike Lommatzsch said:
> >Nitrogen will not expand as your tires heat up.
> 
> Jerry944T said:
> >Serious racers use nitrogen in their tires as it does not expand
> as much as air when heated.
> 
> According to the basic laws of chemistry and physics, *ALL* gases
> expand equally (and linearly within wide limits) with temperature
> changes. (Scientists in the group will recall the formula PV=NRT).
> I looked up nitrogen and found no mention of any unusual behavior
> re. temperature & pressure.

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 1994 10:37:13 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: 914 Suspension Console Rot

>>> Graphics Group <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov> 10/06/94 11:44am >>>
>914 Suspension Console Rot
>    Well, it looks like I've hit my first case of Really Bad News (tm) on my two-liter.
>While I was crawling around under it last weekend, I checked out where the fuel pump should be
>mounted.  It ain't.
>    First, is this where the fuel pump goes on a stock four- banger?

Dave -
Sorry to hear about your suspension console :-(  I can sympathize with you as I discovered
some rot on mine as I was replacing my battery tray earlier this summer.  I ended up just
temporarily pop-riveting the new tray in place and closing the deck lid, figuring that this
winter I will drop the engine and have the console repaired along with the rusty rear trunk floor.
I haven't looked into repair costs yet.  Until winter, I'm doing a Sgt. Schultz imitation -- I see Nothing!
I know Nothing!

Are you saying that the fuel pump is hanging by its lines - or that it just isn't there?  If it's not there,
it is probably located up under the fuel tank, either by the factory ('75-'76) or as a modification ('70-'74).

A related question to the group:
My '75 914 has plastic(?) fuel lines going from the pump to the engine compartment.  Do these
become brittle with age and need replacement?  I know about replacing the rubber lines.

Good luck with your repairs,
Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 1994 13:37:40 -0500 (EST)
From: Mike 223-6534 <DAILEY_MJ%AMSCLS@corning.com>
Subject: Nokia snow tires

Hello all:

>From the BMW list last season...

Nokia makes 3 tires worth considering:

Hakkapolitta NR09 -- a older tire, excellent in snow but noisy
Hakkapolitta NR10 (or just Hakkapolitta 10)
                  -- newer design, excellent in snow, slightly quieter
                     not available in certain sizes (but the NR09 generally
                     is available in these sizes, which are usually narrower
                     tires for older european cars.)
Nokia NRW -- "all season"; not as agressive as the NR09 or 10,
                     and reportedly more pleasant on dry pavement.  far
                     better than most tires labeled "all season" from what
                     i hear.

by mail order:

Greer Enterprises in WI 414-747-0996

Pat Greer seems like a very nice guy and his prices are quite good.  i
paid $77/tire including shipping for a pair of 185/65R14s and $73/tire
including shipping for a set of 185/65R15s back in December.


Sorta Porsche related...  Re: 993 C4 viscous coupled AWD.

My BMW 325iX viscous AWD works very nicely.

Mike

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 94 10:53:09 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: Dimensions of a 944

As for fitting a tall driver inside a 944, an early model, without
the power seats, affords more room than the later models with the
power seats.

As help for those of us who have to lean the seat back to fit a helmet
inside, there was an extended hub wheel that makes it easier to reach
once the seat is leaned back.  It's just hard to find a burgundy one
to match my car - I know of one, but my friend said she won't give it
up!

Pat 
pat@ixi.saic.com
'86 944 (Rally car)

Date: Thu, 06 Oct 94 21:04:05 EDT
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Interesting 911 conversion

Those are some fairly high level names to drop! I have a friend that has
built an early (67) 911 for vintage racing and as part of the project went to
the trouble of grafting a '72 oil filler door and installing a complete '72
oil system like the one in Bruce's project car. A lot of work and of
questionable legality for vintage racing, but it will make for a better
balanced car! There is a historical basis for this type of system since the
911R used virtually the same approach.

      PhilVB

Date: 06 Oct 94 22:57:39 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Carrera 4

Hi, Mike.
 
Well, you asked for comments.
 
The nominal torque split of the 993 C4 is 31/69, unless the center
differential diffs. I don't know what its limits are, but I don't think it
can go as far as 0/100 or 100/0.
 
I think Audi also used an electronically modulated hydraulic clutch system
like the older C4 for their high-end AWD cars, but I'm not sure. Anybody out
there ever pull Audi duty under their cars?
 
Pete

Date:     Thu, 6 Oct 1994 17:41 MDT
From: Hunter Heath  <HEATH@ENDO.MED.UTAH.EDU>
Subject:  Exhaust noise, love of

Dustin Boyette's paean to exhaust noise took me back to Lubbock, Texas, circa
1956 (are you tired of this yet?).  My first motor vehicle (age 13, yes,
legal in them days) was a Cushman Eagle, a kind of pseudo-motorcycle with
scooter-sized wheels.  It was a 6 hp one-lunger, but with the core taken out
of the exhaust pipe (one screw, and voila!), it made a truly wonderful sound,
to thrill a teenager's heart. Throttle up, back off suddenly, maybe blip it a
time or two... snarling lions, man.  Then there was my first car, a '51 Ford
flathead V-8; with dual glasspack mufflers, the rumble shook the earth at
least... well, a *block* away.  Vroom, blat-t-t-t!

Back to reality: the norm for exhaust noise has really changed since the
'60s, and things we could get away with then would get you a Big Ticket now.
My own tolerance for exhaust noise has decreased, maybe out of fear of
deafness, but also from my desire to listen to the radio at less than 100 dB.
And then there's simple consideration for others; the numbers of vehicles on
our streets are so much greater than when I was a lad that if very many of us
chose loud exhausts, life would be decidedly less pleasant.

I do admit an occasional hankering to make some *real* noise... wouldn't it
be nice is "lakes pipes" (any of you old farts remember those) were legal?

So, Dustin: enjoy your exhaust note, but *please* don't come by the house
full throttle at 3 a.m.!

Hunter

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Oct 94 12:14:24 CDT

and assured me that the coolant temperature is fine and that the
gauge is just showing incorrect (high) reading.

someone on the list suggested to properly bleed the coolant system. I
followed the recommended procedure to bleed the system

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 12:01:28 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Tires and Nitrogen

Folks,

I decided that it would be good to check with the "sci.chem" netwnews group
on the internet about this subject. below you will find some the responses I
have received so far. The consensus is that nitrogen is not a win at all
when compared to air even if the air has some water content. I think we can
now put this old wife's tale to bed now.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com



Alex Krooglik (krooglik@minerva.cis.yale.edu), a Graduate Student from the
Department of Geology and Geophysics at Yale University wrote:

Well, you're lucky enough to own a Porsche, you may as well learn how to
drive the damn thing properly.

Anyway, to your question. Filling the tires with nitrogen will not make any
difference and I'll tell you why. When you are rounding the corners very
sharply, what you are doing is transferring frictional energy to the air.
Additionally, the air is also being compressed. This is the most important
issue. You see, the temperature change of a gas due to compression is a
function of the heat capacity of the gas (which in scientific terms is Cp,
or heat capacity at constant pressure). The process of compression is, in
thermodynamics, called "adiabatic", that is, no heat transfer takes place.
i.e. All heating takes place by performing "work" on the air in your tyres,
namely, your friction.

So, the crux of the matter is, the heat capacities of air and nitrogen are
nearly the same (as you see, air is 79% nitrogen), hence adding nitrogen
would have little effect in the temperature and volume change occurring in
your tyres.

Unfortunately, you are not going to have many alternatives either. The molar
heat capacities of most gases at pressures around atmospheric (35 psi is
only 3 x atmospheric pressure) are all _very_ similar. Unless someone
points out a really exotic gas, you aren't left with many alternatives.

The water vapour has little effect on the compressibility of the gas really.

So, of the other gases you might consider, such as nitrogen, carbon dioxide,
pure oxygen, methane, butane, etc, you will find none are really suitable for
what you need.

If you've any other questions, let me know.

John Douglas Porter (porterj@uclink.berkeley.edu) from U.C. Berkeley wrote:

Because the temperatures you are dealing with are so far above the boiling
points of the constituents of air (except water vapor, which is a very
minor component) and the pressures are so low, the ideal gas law is
actually quite good at describing the relationship between pressure,
volume and temperature of the air in your tires.

The deviations are in the small percent range.  There are improved gas
laws with a few more parameters but they don't really improve the
description.  If you are interested, the data are in the Handbook of
Chemistry and Physics.  There are several semi-empirical equations that
look like PV=nRT with extra parameters for P and V and a slightly modified
R (temperature-dependent, that looks like slightly higher than linear T
dependence overall).

Anyway, since the ideal gas law is so good, one consequence is that the
identity of the gas molecules is completely irrelevant.  So there will be
no discernable difference between air and pure nitrogen, or pure oxygen
(not advised...unless you want to make one hell of a spectacular exit) or
just about any other easily-available gas.  Even heat capacities aren't
really all that different, unless a monatomic rare gas is used.  The
temperature rise of the tire will be dominated by the heat capacity of the
rest of the tire anyway, because the mass of the gas is insignificant.

What will be different for the different gases, though, will be their
non-thermodynamic parameters, especially their heat conductance.  I don't
see how that will help.

Bill C Hutton (wchutt@alex.monsanto.com) from Monsanto Company, Corporate
Research wrote:

Your question really has to do with rubber chemistry. Heat plus oxygen
plus water causes chemical reactions in rubber. Dry nitrogen provides
an inert environment and these reactions (oxidation) of the rubber can
not occur inside the tire. Oxidation will change the properties of the
rubber and could efect the performance of the tire... particularly the
sidewalls where the rubber is the thinest.

Wet air could have different expansion properties than dry nitrogen as
the tire heats up. But I doubt this is a major factor.

Date: Fri, 7 Oct 1994 22:41:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: ero@netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: re:930 Turbo HP

A correction to Turbos being imported to the U.S. Porsche stopped in '79 
and started again with the '86 model. The '78/'79 and '86 all had the 3.3 
motor. The '79 was rated at 261 h.p. and the '86 at 282 h.p. Though the 
Turbos were brought in thru the grey market my mechanic suggested 
avoiding them, though I don't remember why. When I was having my '78 
rebuilt I was looking into some of the go fast goodies. The folks at 
Windward Performance said the '86s used the same fuel system as the '76s 
and the '78/'79s used a larger fuel system, I didn't need to add a 
micro-fueler. I also looked in to SC Turbo grind cams, Windward said I 
wouldn't loose any power at the bottom end. When I contacted Web Cam, 
they said I would loose power at the bottom end. Bruce Anderson suggested 
using the 964 cams, Windward said the 964 cams didn't work very well and 
to stick with the SC cams, so who knows. Hot rodding these motors is very 
expensive, Intercooler $1500 - $2000, Free flow exhaust $1200, micro 
fueler $1200 +, add to that, installation, your talking(spending) 
$4000-$5000. I didn't do any of the above because I ended up spending 
over $5000 having the top end and a few other things done. For daily 
driving, the  261 h.p. is plenty. It's extremely difficult to stay under 
70 m.p.h. because it takes so little power to get there and it feels 
like I'm only doing 50. The used Turbo prices are coming down, at least 
in the bay area. I've seen acouple of low milage, exceptionally clean 
ones for under$30,000. 
Harold
'78 930
'68 crewcab

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Oct 94 01:01:40 -0500
From: lawrence@cs.wisc.edu (larry smith)
Subject: 944 S2 vs Turbo S


- -->I am evaluating what my next car should be.  I want a step up from
- -->my '84 944.  The car will be used for everything: daily driver, auto-x,
- -->and driver's ed at the track.  Seems like the S2 would have an
- -->advantage in auto-x and in stop and go traffic because of the
- -->lack of turbo lag.  The turbo, of course, would be faster at the
- -->track.  Anyone driven both and care to comment?  You turbo
- -->owners, do you notice the turbo lag when autocrossing or in
- -->traffic?

> I have limited experience with the 944S having test-driven an '87 once; none 
> with the 944S2.  I remember making the used-car slimeball very nervous with my
> spirited acceleration and cornering.  The power in the 16-valve seemed to come
> on strongly above approx. 4000rpm very smoothly.  However, below 4500, I found
> it lacking.  I expect the S2 is similar in nature.

- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

 I have owned a 944, driven an 944S, 944S2 and 944 Turbo, (but not a Turbo S)
I agree about the 944S, below 4000rpm the engine is about the same as a 944,
maybe even a little weaker, but kicks in stronger above 4000rpm, however the
944S2 pulls very strongly and very smoothly from around 1500rpm all the way
up to redline.  I think an S2 would be a much better choice for auto-x, the
response is much better, also i have heard that Kelly Moss racing was able to
post better times here at Road America in the S2 than in the 86-88 Turbo cars.
  I found both the Turbo and S2 cars to be much easier for around town driving
than either the 944 or 944S, maybe just because of the higher gearing.  Also
S2's are much harder to find, and more expensive than 86-88 Turbos.  You should
drive *BOTH* types of cars before making a choice.

_______________________________________________________________________________
Larry Smith
85.5 944  (Guard's Red, what else)
_______________________________________________________________________________

Date: 08 Oct 94 11:12:37 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: carbon deposits and water

Hi, Steve.
 
If water steam cleans off the oil film, what would gasoline vapor do?
 
Water injection and to a lesser extent water-methanol injection is an old
trick to keep engines from detonating. Everybody -- Allies, Germany, Japan
- -- used it to produce temporary extreme power under emergency conditions
(combat power) for fighters and bombers. One German system used nitrous
oxide to make a bomber capable of outrunning British fighters, until the
bottle ran dry.
 
A significant percentage of the water vapor will dissociate during the
combustion process to form hydrogen and oxygen. Somewhere down the exhaust
pipe any leftover H and O2 may recombine, or tie up with carbon to form HC
and CO2 and CO. All of the water does not carry through the whole combustion
process as steam.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Sat,  8 Oct 94 00:07:12 PDT
From: George Durden <durden@bga.com>
Subject: Re: 911 fuel injection trouble 

I'm still in the throes of fixing my warm/hot start problem
that is amazingly similar in symptoms. I've replaced the
fuel pump check valve and purchased a CIS injection test
guage and eliminiated the warm start regulator and the
accumulator as suspects. At this point it looks like I have
a leaking injector (pretty common according to local P-mechanics)
and just need to take the time (hopefully this weekend) to test
each injector for bleed-down. The cold start valve is really not
a suspect. If all of the injectors pass test, then it gets expensive
as it's probably a problem in the fuel distributor (~$450 + Labor)
I'm hoping it's  injector(s).

George

Being on the prowl for a 911 Sportmatic, I recently purchased a book 
entitled "The Used 911 Story" written by Peter Zimmerman. I would highly 
recomend this book to anyone wanting to purchased a used 911. He goes 
through every year, starting from 1965, to 1993 and describes whats good, 
bad, etc.. about each year and what problems to look out for. He also has a 
very comprehensive checklist of what things to check out for signs of 
trouble on all 911's.

I ordered it from a mail order book store which advertises in Excellence
magazine, the name escapes me right now. You might want to order a copy.

Thanks,
Kory

Date: Sat, 8 Oct 1994 15:52:58 -0400
From: jfoster@rohmhaas.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: Re: 944 S2 vs Turbo S


>
>I have limited experience with the 944S having test-driven an '87 once; none 
>with the 944S2.  I remember making the used-car slimeball very nervous with my
>spirited acceleration and cornering.  The power in the 16-valve seemed to come
>on strongly above approx. 4000rpm very smoothly.  However, below 4500, I found
>it lacking.  I expect the S2 is similar in nature.
>
I can't agree.  We sold our 87 944S and replaced it with a 91 944S2.  I'd
agree with your assesment of the 944S, there just wasn't much there below
4K.  Different story on the S2 however.  The car has loads of torque and
will pull strongly from 2,200 on up to redline.  This was really noticable
up at Watkins Glen when we'd come up the boot and pull away from almost
anything because of the large amount of torque available.  The faster cars
would then catch us on the straight...  The S2's about as fast as the older
turbo, but has more torque down low.

Date: Sat, 08 Oct 94 13:15:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw3.az05.bull.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Vibration Problem


I hate to make this suggestion but your clutch plate center may be coming 
apart. The center of the disc is a big rubber donut and they are known to 
disintegrate with age (and heat).

As the rubber hub falls apart it will :

a) get out of balance,

and/or

 b) lose  its rigidity in a vertical plane. Either or both of these 
conditions could be causing your vibration.

The cost of replacing the the clutch is not trivial

Hope this is not the problem

Will Hartje
 ----------


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Oct 94 12:43:09 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Why gauges sometimes read high

As expected, whether a high resistance contact causes a gauge to indicate 
higher or lower depends on the gauge + sender wiring arrangement.

For illustration, assume the gauge in the two examples below
indicates higher with more current thru the gauge.  

My examples are from 20+ year old cars.  Extrapolate to newer cars at 
your own risk.

Sender = transducer = FREQUENTLY a variable resistance device.

1. Sender used as shunting resistor 

               +12 ----|
                       >
                       <  <-- series resistor
                       >
                       |----------------|            
                       |                <            
                       |                >  <--- sender
                       |                <
                     gauge              >
                       |                |
                       V                V


  In this case, the gauge will indicate HIGHER if there is a high
  resistance contact to the sender, since the sender shunts less current
  from the gauge.

  If the wire leading to the sender shorts to chassis, the gauge indicates
  lower.

  From my experience, a similar arrangement is used in the 1972 911T oil level
  gauge + sender, since mine indicated a quart or two higher when the sender
  had an ohmic contact to the sender's output tab.  

  I verified this today on my 69T by pulling the wire off the oil level sender.
  The oil level indicator pegged high.

2. Sender in series with the gauge

               +12 ----|
                       |      
                     gauge   
                       |    
                       >    
                       <    <-- sender
                       >   
                       |
                       V


  In this case, the gauge will indicate LOWER if there is a high resistance
  contact to the sender, since the higher the sender resistance, the lower
  the current that will flow in the gauge.

  A sender wire shorted to chassis will indicate higher.

  The fuel level sender in my 69T is this type, again verified by
  pulling off the sender connector in the trunk.

  The fuel indicator dropped to the bottom.

In EITHER arrangement, a HIGHER supply voltage, caused by a failed
voltage regulator, would cause either gauge/sender arrangement to 
indicate HIGHER.

The factory wiring diagrams don't help in determining which type of
gauge/sender arrangement applies since they don't give enough detail.  

For resistance type senders referenced to ground, an open (high resistance)
or a short to ground (low resistance) will indicate which type is used.


John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com


------------------------------

more power on the low-end than does the S.  The general "feel" of the cars
is also quite different.  Although both are wonderful cars, the S2 is one
of my favorites.

From: coffino@cgl.ucsf.edu (Phil Coffino)
To: porscephiles@tta.com
Subject: Crumpled 944 85/2:Totaled?

My soon-to-be-ex has been liberally abusing her 944, with multiple dings
and dents on virtually all accesible sheet metal.  Mechanics and interior,
however, remain good.  Last week she hit an imovable inanimate object
with the left front and broke the windshield with a dense animate object
about the size of a human head.  Estimate to fix the current damage is
about $5000, of which around $1800 is reasonably priced and sourced
parts, the rest labor.  The windshield would take another $600, parts
and labor.  This expenditure of $5600 would produce a badly dinged
car, thew residue of previous damage.

Two dismantlers have each offered $2500.  Hence the net cost of keeping/
fixing is $5600 + 2500 = $8100.  This seems like too much for a badly
scarred but servicible 944 of this vintage.  Additional variables of
possible relevence: automatic (yic!), one powere seat, all leather,
only 67k miles.

Question- Is this car totaled? If not, why not?

Wisdom (spare the wit) eagerly and urgently solicited.

Thanks
Phil Coffino
86' 928S

Date: Sat, 08 Oct 94 09:03:57 EDT
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 CIS musings

>They can also help you set the fuel system pressure (via shims) and >help in
diagnosing other problems, too.

On the subject of adjusting system pressure via shims.....  I recently took
my car in to a shop to fix some CIS problems (hindsight being 20/20, I should
have bought the pressure gauges and done this myself) - anyway, we (I ended
up helping quite a bit with the repairs) had to add more shims than should
have been necessary to get the system pressure up to specs.  The fuel pump is
OK - system pressure coming out of the filter was >90psi.  The woman at the
shop (these folks are a husband/wife team - she does the CIS stuff, among
other things) felt that I should consider replacing the fuel distributor - I
didn't share her opinion.  The piston portion of my pressure regulator showed
some slight wear/scoring - I'm going to placate myself with assumption that
fuel is leaking past the piston into the return line, hence the need to add
additional shims.  Does this make any sense, or do ya'll think my
distributor is to blame??

Just wondering..

Mike


------------------------------

Date: 09 Oct 94 00:02:02 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: tightening axle nut

I just went by the local VW store to get some 356 carburetor jets (OK, I
admit it, I shop at the VW places.) While waiting, I was looking at some
aftermarket lightweight disc brakes. I don't think these are suitable for
the street, the disc is very thin, maybe nice for the lowriders and drag
racers. But the label on the bag was interesting: it says you have to
tighten the axle nut to some godawful number, 350 or 400 ft.-lbs, or else
you will damage the halfshaft splines. So there's the reason, apparently.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 08 Oct 1994 19:50:10 -0800
From: EMN@smtp.weiss.com
Subject:  Solex jets

Pete and Stan:

I missed the first posting on this subject.  Apparently Stan asked about
obtaining Solex jets.  

A surprisingly little-known secret:  The Main and Air Correction jets for
Mikuni carbs interchange quite nicely with Solexes.  Mikunis are stock on lots
of rice-burners, both two-wheel and four-wheel.

I learned this at Rockwell Motorsports in San Jose, CA, when I was using thier
chassis dyno to tune my 912.  In preparation for putting my car on the dyno, I
had collected a range of Solex jet sizes from the many PCA swap meets we enjoy
here in the Bay Area.  As Murphy would dictate, the car ended up needing a jet
size that I didn't have.  The owner (forget his first name, last name Rockwell,
and a very nice guy) said "no problemo" and went over to his extensive
selection of Mikuni parts, and picked the necessary size.  Exactly the same
threads and dimensions as Solex.  They just don't have "Solex" stamped on them.

Also, I've got lots of real Solex jets, and might part with some.  Whacha need?

Eric Nichols
emn@weiss.com
'67 912 Light Ivory
'93 Civic SI
'88 Robin, jet black tom, very good kitty
'90 Damien, small but fearful black and white huntress

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 06:42:42 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 S2 vs Turbo S

Having owned a 944S and driven a S2 I can tell you that they are worlds
apart. The 944S was one of the bigger dissapointments in my life. Yes it did
have slightly more power than a standard 944 but only after 4000RPM. It
certainly wasn't worth the price. Also it turned out to be a pain in the butt
maintenance wise. Marginally faster than early (83/84) two valve cars. 
The S2 pulls like a tractor which isn't hard to figure, considering it is a 3
liter. For all around driving it is probably the one to go for. 
I am partial to Turbos but the S2 is certainly more tractable in traffic.
I would avoid the 944S like the plague

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 94 16:41:39 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>

Subjects: Nitrogen and rear wheel nuts

Somehow the nitrogen in tires thread seems to have gotten off track.
It is clear that there is little difference (as a gas) between
nitrogen and air (even with a little water vapor in the air).  On the
other hand compressing air often condenses liquid water out while
bottled nitrogen is dry.  Liquid water will affect the pressure in
the tire at high temperatures beyond what is expected from the gas law.
At 212 F, it will add 15 psi to the pressure.  Thus, there might be
a difference for really hot racing tires that us common street drivers
would never see.  Water will also accelerate corrosion on steel rims.

My rear wheel nut tool is a 3/4 inch drive socket on a bar extended
by a pipe from a 1959 Berkeley bumper.  With someone standing on
the brakes, I can easily loosen and tighten the nuts by jumping on
the pipe.  It is certainly true that you do not want the nut loose
enough to allow play under load.  The damage to the splines can be
incredible.  Think of the splines as being primarily to line things
up and the tight nut as what carries the load.  This isn't exactly
how it works, but it is a good approximation.

I learned about splines and wheel nuts on a 59 Berkeley that the
previous owner had not tightened the wheels properly on.  I ended
up having to shim the spline fitting with wires to take up the
play.  I guess that those of you without access to Berkeley parts
will have to find some other way to extend your breaker bar ;-).

Rick Dill
1962 356 B coupe for sunny days
1959 Berkeley 492 cc  .. which needs some work to make it run
  (air cooled, engine over the drive wheels, and only 725 pounds)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 19:56:21 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Nitrogen in Tires

Well, I was chuckling with my lovely wife this afternoon about the N2 in
tires debate, which, I must admit, I was the culprit to instigate this
little excursion.

I had originally intended the aside as a sarcastic remark intended to show
how some drivers will spend large dollars for small improvements in
performance.  My mistake was that I did not include a smiley in my original
comment.

My last word on the subject has to do with observation, not with conjecture
or speculation.

For a few years running, my lovely wife and I were fortunate to work with
the Dyson Racing Team, as they campaigned their Porsche 962 in the IMSA GTP
series.  My recollection of the Daytona pit area included the Goodyear
Racing support truck, which was mounting and balancing tires at a prodigious
rate for the entire period of practice, qualifying and the 24 hour race.

At no time did I see any evidence of Nitrogen bottles there or anywhere else
in the pits during that time.  Goodyear was using nothing but good ol'
compressed Daytona air for inflating (now pay attention to this!) tires that
were going to be traveling at 200 mph for long periods of time!

Now, in my way of thinking (flawed though it may be by years of abuse and
chemicals), if there was any advantage to be gained by using nitrogen in
tires, I would have seen it then and there.

QED, if it was not used there, I doubt that its use on any of the cars that
we drive is going to provide a competitive advantage.  (Of course, if it
helps to keep rubber from oxidizing, there may be a valid reason for using
it, after all...)

I'll go back to sleep now...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 16:50:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Frank William \"Bill\" Addis" <addis@beta.tricity.wsu.edu>
Subject: 951 Transmission Filling

Once when I had a Porsche Dealer shop check on an apparent transmission 
leak around the seals I was told that there was no seal problem, and that 
the leaking was the result of filling the transmission too full. Now I 
think my 951 transmission may need some lubricant added. How is the 
proper fluid level determined? Thanks for any suggestions.

Bill Addis
