Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 17:19:18 -0700
From: retro@ix.netcom.com (Norris Klesman)
Subject: Draining fuel from 924

Would anyone know the best way to drain fuel from the tank of a 924?
I'd like to do it with the minimum mess and spilled fuel.  The vehicle has
had the fuel since December (about 1/2 tank) and will not start (bad fuel is
the probable cause).  I'd like to drain it, hopefully without being drown in
gas.

Has anyone tried to drain by using the fuel pump to drain the tank?

Thanks

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 94 20:06 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Transmission Filling

Frank,

Fill to a level 6 to 8 mm. below the filler bore, that is, the bottom-
most point of the hole.  Most people stick their pinky in to check --
not terribly calibrated, but not terribly critical.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 17:14:17 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Subjects: Nitrogen and rear wheel nuts

>Somehow the nitrogen in tires thread seems to have gotten off track.
>It is clear that there is little difference (as a gas) between
>nitrogen and air (even with a little water vapor in the air).  On the
>other hand compressing air often condenses liquid water out while
>bottled nitrogen is dry.  Liquid water will affect the pressure in
>the tire at high temperatures beyond what is expected from the gas law.
>At 212 F, it will add 15 psi to the pressure.  Thus, there might be
>a difference for really hot racing tires that us common street drivers
>would never see.  Water will also accelerate corrosion on steel rims.

Rick,

First of all, water does not boil at 212 F when subjected to the
pressures a tire is inflated to. I don't know how much higher the
boiling point of water is at 20 or 25 psi, but it is significant.
Also, how can you state that the water, when it turns to a gas, will
add 15 psi? Don't you need to know how much water is in the tire and the
volume of air in the tire to figure this out? The answer is yes. Don't
forget that moisture is not a friend to air compressors, so they tend to
be kept as "dry" as possible.

Again, the bottom line is that nitrogen offers no significant advantage
over air as a gas for tires.

Scott
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Date:          Mon, 10 Oct 1994 17:55:19 +1200
From: "Wayne Fowke" <wfowke@hrr1.hort.cri.nz>
Subject:       928 Ventilation

Having just joined this group I find the topics interesting & 
informative but note the lack of discussion on the 928.
Living in New Zealand with relatively few Porsches seems a different 
world from USA or GB presumably where the majority of "porschephiles" 
mail sources from.

With summer just starting I felt it was time to address the problem I 
have of the fan (interior) and probably the air conditioning not 
working.However I have had the 928 at the auto electrician today only 
to be told that he cant find any obvious cause.

Symptoms- Having just come thru winter I cannot be sure exactly when 
the fan/air stopped but first noticed about a month ago.I checked the 
fuses and unfortunately it wasnt that simple. The fan does work when 
you slide the controll to demist but not when you turn the dial.I 
only presume the air doesnt work ?.About a week ago it suddenly 
started working (& the air) but just as suddenly stopped.
The small fan that runs all the time still works.

It also doesnt help that the bookshop has had the workshop manual on 
order for two months & I therefore dont have a wiring diagram.

Has anyone else had a similar problem?.

Any suggestions would be gratefully recieved. 

Wayne Fowke 
928 S2 1985

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 23:53:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: gschoepp@netcom.com (Gene Schoepp)
Subject: 928 Miscellany

T-plus three weeks as a Porsche owner, and I'm still smiling every time I 
reach for the ignition...

A couple of minor items. First, here's the detail of my 45,000 mile 
service and miscellaneous items. Did I do ok or should I locate a source 
of Vaseline?

	45k svc, oil change, air filter, plugs...$268
	Check all brakes, replace rear pads......$100
	Update camshaft seals (all) to "Vitron"..$150
	Replace all accessory belts..............$135

Had the work done at Classic Imports here in Dallas. Dave Perry at that 
location seems very forthright and reliable. Standard "no relation" 
disclaimer applies.

Ok, here's one I didn't ask Dave (forgot). My steering wheel makes an 
annoying rubbing/scratching sound when turned >1/4 turn or so. Sounds 
like plastic on plastic, but I can't be sure. Any thoughts?

That's about it... Muchas gracias for any help anyone can offer. See ya' 
on the freeway!

Gene Schoepp
'86 928S Marine Blue Metallic

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 03:06:06 EDT
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Broken Generator Hub


Some time ago, there was a discussion concerning how to remove a  36mm
generator nut to R&R the fan from a 356/912. It was suggested  that using an
impact wrench  on the nut as opposed to holding the Generator Hub in a vice
(or with vice grips) might be a Better Idea, as shearing off the key or
ruining the keyway might not be a good idea.
   Last week a Customer  sent me the remains of just such an attempt- holding
the hub in a vice, he attempted to remove the 36mm nut on the fan.
   Result: one BROKEN generator hub, AND one sheared-off key, AND one
elongated keyway in the generator shaft which meant: a ruined generator
shaft! Which meant a ruined generator!
   The rather impressively abused parts are now on display in the collection
of broken Porsche parts  Section in the Maestro's Museum. (Call (408)
727-1864 for an appointment.)
    Sometimes the Porsche gods send you exa
End of Porschephiles

The only difference I've noticed between Zimmerman rotors which come in
the PAG box and those which appear in the wholesale aftermarket, is that
the PAG rotors get their hats painted and don't rust.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 13:42:45 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Of mice and Mufflers


I see a few p-filers have found out what Spyder really means. Be careful
when bug-busting useing toxic agents. tends to stay in the vent system.

Mufflers, well, my Dad told this one. The story has been confirmed by
many of his Air Corps buddies after a few beers.

Seems after WWII ended, my father and his buddies were stationed 
somewhere in the Stuttgart area. They made a deal with some locals for
a bunch of ex-Wehrmacht Zundapp motorcycles. They sounded pretty good 
with the mufflers removed, so I'm told. They liked a Gasthaus out in the sticks, heading out on Saturday afternoons for a beer-tasting. There was a Sunday morning roll-call they had to make, leaving the Gasthaus at 5am
they could make the formation. 

It seems these Sunday motorcycle runs took them through a few small towns
with quaint houses on narrow streets. The locals were not amused at theirsleep being disturbed. 

One clear Sunday morning the troop was returning through a village when 
suddenly, yellow rain decended on them. Seems the locals had a way of
getting the point across.

The following week, mufflers were on all the bikes.

I like quiet cars. It was always rewarding to autocross with a quiet 
muffler and win. A little head advantage.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 11:07:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: carbon deposits and water


Pete -

>If water steam cleans off the oil film, what would gasoline vapor do?

Slightly academic point, but really excess fuel can in fact wash lubrication
from the cylinder walls.  Which sucks.

In everything, moderation.  (I forget the original Latin!)

Kevin

Porschephiles #897                         Mon Oct 10 02:03:11 CDT 1994
Date: Sat, 08 Oct 1994 19:50:10 -0800
From: EMN@smtp.weiss.com
Subject:  Solex jets

Pete and Stan:

I missed the first posting on this subject.  Apparently Stan asked about
obtaining Solex jets.  

A surprisingly little-known secret:  The Main and Air Correction jets for
Mikuni carbs interchange quite nicely with Solexes.  Mikunis are stock on lots
of rice-burners, both two-wheel and four-wheel.

I learned this at Rockwell Motorsports in San Jose, CA, when I was using thier
chassis dyno to tune my 912.  In preparation for putting my car on the dyno, I
had collected a range of Solex jet sizes from the many PCA swap meets we enjoy
here in the Bay Area.  As Murphy would dictate, the car ended up needing a jet
size that I didn't have.  The owner (forget his first name, last name Rockwell,
and a very nice guy) said "no problemo" and went over to his extensive
selection of Mikuni parts, and picked the necessary size.  Exactly the same
threads and dimensions as Solex.  They just don't have "Solex" stamped on them.

Also, I've got lots of real Solex jets, and might part with some.  Whacha need?

Eric Nichols
emn@weiss.com
'67 912 Light Ivory
'93 Civic SI
'88 Robin, jet black tom, very good kitty
'90 Damien, small but fearful black and white huntress

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 06:42:42 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 S2 vs Turbo S

Having owned a 944S and driven a S2 I can tell you that they are worlds
apart. The 944S was one of the bigger dissapointments in my life. Yes it did
have slightly more power than a standard 944 but only after 4000RPM. It
certainly wasn't worth the price. Also it turned out to be a pain in the butt
maintenance wise. Marginally faster than early (83/84) two valve cars. 
The S2 pulls like a tractor which isn't hard to figure, considering it is a 3
liter. For all around driving it is probably the one to go for. 
I am partial to Turbos but the S2 is certainly more tractable in traffic.
I would avoid the 944S like the plague

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 94 16:41:39 EDT
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>

Subjects: Nitrogen and rear wheel nuts

Somehow the nitrogen in tires thread seems to have gotten off track.
It is clear that there is little difference (as a gas) between
nitrogen and air (even with a little water vapor in the air).  On the
other hand compressing air often condenses liquid water out while
bottled nitrogen is dry.  Liquid water will affect the pressure in
the tire at high temperatures beyond what is expected from the gas law.
At 212 F, it will add 15 psi to the pressure.  Thus, there might be
a difference for really hot racing tires that us common street drivers
would never see.  Water will also accelerate corrosion on steel rims.

My rear wheel nut tool is a 3/4 inch drive socket on a bar extended
by a pipe from a 1959 Berkeley bumper.  With someone standing on
the brakes, I can easily loosen and tighten the nuts by jumping on
the pipe.  It is certainly true that you do not want the nut loose
enough to allow play under load.  The damage to the splines can be
incredible.  Think of the splines as being primarily to line things
up and the tight nut as what carries the load.  This isn't exactly
how it works, but it is a good approximation.

I learned about splines and wheel nuts on a 59 Berkeley that the
previous owner had not tightened the wheels properly on.  I ended
up having to shim the spline fitting with wires to take up the
play.  I guess that those of you without access to Berkeley parts
will have to find some other way to extend your breaker bar ;-).

Rick Dill
1962 356 B coupe for sunny days
1959 Berkeley 492 cc  .. which needs some work to make it run
  (air cooled, engine over the drive wheels, and only 725 pounds)

------------------------------

for that reason a little tentative.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 19:56:21 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Nitrogen in Tires

Well, I was chuckling with my lovely wife this afternoon about the N2 in
tires debate, which, I must admit, I was the culprit to instigate this
little excursion.

I had originally intended the aside as a sarcastic remark intended to show
how some drivers will spend large dollars for small improvements in
performance.  My mistake was that I did not include a smiley in my original
comment.

My last word on the subject has to do with observation, not with conjecture
or speculation.

For a few years running, my lovely wife and I were fortunate to work with
the Dyson Racing Team, as they campaigned their Porsche 962 in the IMSA GTP
series.  My recollection of the Daytona pit area included the Goodyear
Racing support truck, which was mounting and balancing tires at a prodigious
rate for the entire period of practice, qualifying and the 24 hour race.

At no time did I see any evidence of Nitrogen bottles there or anywhere else
in the pits during that time.  Goodyear was using nothing but good ol'
compressed Daytona air for inflating (now pay attention to this!) tires that
were going to be traveling at 200 mph for long periods of time!

Now, in my way of thinking (flawed though it may be by years of abuse and
chemicals), if there was any advantage to be gained by using nitrogen in
tires, I would have seen it then and there.

QED, if it was not used there, I doubt that its use on any of the cars that
we drive is going to provide a competitive advantage.  (Of course, if it
helps to keep rubber from oxidizing, there may be a valid reason for using
it, after all...)

I'll go back to sleep now...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 16:50:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Frank William \"Bill\" Addis" <addis@beta.tricity.wsu.edu>
Subject: 951 Transmission Filling

Once when I had a Porsche Dealer shop check on an apparent transmission 
leak around the seals I was told that there was no seal problem, and that 
the leaking was the result of filling the transmission too full. Now I 
think my 951 transmission may need some lubricant added. How is the 
proper fluid level determined? Thanks for any suggestions.

Bill Addis

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 17:19:18 -0700
From: retro@ix.netcom.com (Norris Klesman)
Subject: Draining fuel from 924

Would anyone know the best way to drain fuel from the tank of a 924?
I'd like to do it with the minimum mess and spilled fuel.  The vehicle has
had the fuel since December (about 1/2 tank) and will not start (bad fuel is
the probable cause).  I'd like to drain it, hopefully without being drown in
gas.

Has anyone tried to drain by using the fuel pump to drain the tank?

Thanks

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 94 20:06 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Transmission Filling

Frank,

Fill to a level 6 to 8 mm. below the filler bore, that is, the bottom-
most point of the hole.  Most people stick their pinky in to check --
not terribly calibrated, but not terribly critical.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 17:14:17 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Subjects: Nitrogen and rear wheel nuts

>Somehow the nitrogen in tires thread seems to have gotten off track.
>It is clear that there is little difference (as a gas) between
>nitrogen and air (even with a little water vapor in the air).  On the
>other hand compressing air often condenses liquid water out while
>bottled nitrogen is dry.  Liquid water will affect the pressure in
>the tire at high temperatures beyond what is expected from the gas law.
>At 212 F, it will add 15 psi to the pressure.  Thus, there might be
>a difference for really hot racing tires that us common street drivers
>would never see.  Water will also accelerate corrosion on steel rims.

Rick,

First of all, water does not boil at 212 F when subjected to the
pressures a tire is inflated to. I don't know how much higher the
boiling point of water is at 20 or 25 psi, but it is significant.
Also, how can you state that the water, when it turns to a gas, will
add 15 psi? Don't you need to know how much water is in the tire and the
volume of air in the tire to figure this out? The answer is yes. Don't
forget that moisture is not a friend to air compressors, so they tend to
be kept as "dry" as possible.

Again, the bottom line is that nitrogen offers no significant advantage
over air as a gas for tires.

Scott
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 12:24:53 PDT
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>

and chemicals to raw leather and carpeting.

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 13:42:45 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Of mice and Mufflers


I see a few p-filers have found out what Spyder really means. Be careful
when bug-busting useing toxic agents. tends to stay in the vent system.

Mufflers, well, my Dad told this one. The story has been confirmed by
many of his Air Corps buddies after a few beers.

Seems after WWII ended, my father and his buddies were stationed 
somewhere in the Stuttgart area. They made a deal with some locals for
a bunch of ex-Wehrmacht Zundapp motorcycles. They sounded pretty good 
with the mufflers removed, so I'm told. They liked a Gasthaus out in the sticks, heading out on Saturday afternoons for a beer-tasting. There was a Sunday morning roll-call they had to make, leaving the Gasthaus at 5am
they could make the formation. 

It seems these Sunday motorcycle runs took them through a few small towns
with quaint houses on narrow streets. The locals were not amused at theirsleep being disturbed. 

One clear Sunday morning the troop was returning through a village when 
suddenly, yellow rain decended on them. Seems the locals had a way of
getting the point across.

The following week, mufflers were on all the bikes.

I like quiet cars. It was always rewarding to autocross with a quiet 
muffler and win. A little head advantage.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 11:09:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Wheels for a Race Car


Scott,

>I need to get a set of 9x16 and 11x17 racing wheels for the car I am
>building.  The plan is to put 245/45R16 and 315/35R17 BFG R1 (230 com-
>pound) tires on them.

have used HRE three-piece rims and are happy with them.  We've repaired
one after a driver error, no problem.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 11:07:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: carbon deposits and water


Pete -

>If water steam cleans off the oil film, what would gasoline vapor do?

Slightly academic point, but really excess fuel can in fact wash lubrication
from the cylinder walls.  Which sucks.

In everything, moderation.  (I forget the original Latin!)

Kevin

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 11:15:32 PDT
From: gary@porsche.mce.com (Gary Cook, Dir. Tech Services, MCE, Inc.)
Subject: $931 (924 turbo) / 924 Parts..



Primarily directed to those around the San Francisco Bay Area.  Many of
these parts are too difficult or expensive to ship.

It's time to scrap the Pcar...  Can't afford to "properly maintain" the
beast anymore.  Got a bad turbo, bad wastegate, bad block, slightly
cracked exhaust manifold..  Typical $931 failures.  Cost to repair >
cost of another car.  It's going to be towed to the wrecking yard any
day.

Prices?  Make me an offer I can't refuse.  This stuff needs to disappear
in the next 2 weeks.  I'd hate to add to our land fill problem in 
California.  :^)

I removed most of the good stuff this weekend.  The entire care is
available.  It's fairly worn.  150K+ miles.  The suspension and brakes
were rebuilt about a year before I parked it and have about 10K miles on
them.  There may be other parts that are good that I didn't list.

Good stuff includes:

o  A complete 4 wheel disc, 5 lug wheel 15" wheels (including the
   spare) setup.  A great update for any 924 or turbo without this
   option.  The wheels have 4 205/60 VR15 Comp T/A's in fair condition.  
   Rotors and pads are in great condition, except for a little surface rust.  
   Front A-Arms have new ball joints.  Front bearings are new.  Tie rod ends
   are new.  All four calipers were rebuilt and new pads installed.
   Front rotors are new.  Rear's were resurfaced.
o  Front springs..  2 sets.  220Lb from Performance Parts..  Lowers
   the front about an 1" to 1 1/2".  Anothers set from Automotion that
   are 200Lb.  Lowers the car about the same amount.  This set has dead
   coils that can be cut to further lower the front.
o  New 25mm rear torsion bars, still in the box.  Also from
   Performance parts.
o  Stock front (21/23mm?) and rear (14mm) sway bars including the sway bar 
   mounting kit for 924's that don't have the factory rear sway bar.
o  4 non-sport Koni adjustable shocks with about 10K miles on them.
o  Glass - doors, quarters, and rear hatch with spoiler (with sun
   damage, but looks when cleaned and treated).  Windshield is cracked.
o  Turbo hood.
o  Various motors (doors, wiper, headlights).
o  Cylinder Head "looks" ok.
o  Various relays, including the 931 specific fuel pump relay.
o  Tan interior.  Front seats were recovered.  Not a 100% match, but
   look better than rips and holes.  Front carpet is worn.  Dash is good
   for nothing except scrap.
o  Fan Switch (comes on earlier)
o  Head Gasket Kit (new, in box)
o  Timing Belt (new, in box)
o  Turbo Rebuild Kit (new, in box)
o  "PORSCHE" decal for rear (new, in box)
o  New gaskets for door handles and mirrors. (new, in box)
o  Tranny parts from Performance Parts.  016/9 type like the 944. (new, in box)
	SYC15		1st gear syncro
	SYC16		2nd, 3rd, & 4th gear syncros
	SYC17		5th gear syncro
	477.300.912B	Trans Gasket Set
	016.311.427	Bearing, mainshaft
	016.311.445	Bearing, mainshaft
o  Hella Headlights. (almost new)
o  Battery - Die Hard (almost new)
o  Washer pump, nozzles, & antisiphon valves. (almost new)
o  Switches - Power window, fog, rear Wiper, mirror select (almost new)
o  150MPH (or is it 140?) speedometer (almost new)
o  Brown shift boot (almost new)
o  Shift lever (helps fix sloppy shifting) (almost new)
o  Brown ash tray - improved type (almost new)
o  Cam belt idler..  Improved version. (almost new)
o  Brown Porsche mats, front and rear. (almost new)
o  Washer pump, nozzles, & antisiphon valves. (almost new)
o  Momo steering wheel mount kit with Porsche crest horn button. (almost new)
o  Fuel gauge tank sender (almost new)
o  Battery -  Die Hard (almost new)
o  Lights - Tail, turn, side marker.
o  Cooling fans
o  Oil cooler, hoses, filter adapter.
o  Fuel pumps (high & low pressure)
o  Fuel injection, including injectors, valves, cold start valve,
   flow sensor, frequency valve, injectors, warm-up regulator, etc.
   There a are several (4?) new fuel lines (all those not going to the
   injectors.  The intake manifold has a piece cracked off one of the
   mounts.
o  Power Mirrors - mirrors and motors ok.  Lots of rock chips and
   rubber is sun damaged.
o  Brown luggage cover
o  Brown sunroof cover
o  924 Owners Manual
o  Alternator

Stuff still on the car..  I don't want to remove it.  If you are
inclined to crawl in or under the car, it's yours.  

o  Turbo exhaust system.
o  Entire A/C system.
o  Radiator - probably ok.  Don't remember any leaks.
o  Heater blower / core.
o  Bumpers

The following are known bad:

o  Steering wheel.
o  Console
o  Dash
o  Front Carpet - rear is good, hatch area good, but faded.
o  Wastegate - broken diaphragm
o  Turbo - Probably rebuildable - I have the kit from Performance
o  Parts if there is any interest.
o  Engine.  One cylinder probably was damaged by a cracked ring.
   Probably caused by massive pinging when the wastgate got stuck
   closed.  Full throttle and unlimited boost.  It was fun while it
   lasted.  :^0
o  Exhaust manifold.  It's showing signs of cracking typical of
   $931's.  Right now, the crack is about 2" long of the block side near
   the turbo.  Repairable?
o  Front rack and pinion.  Seems slightly loose.
o  No rear wiper
o  DITC, distributor, heater valve, and starter have already  been
   claimed by other $931 sufferers.
o  The doors are there, but have bondo.  Front fenders are fair.
   Don't know how much bondo might be there.  Too hard to take off.  Be
   my guest if you want to give it a try.
o  Shell, it's sitting in the driveway, free to a good home.  It
   still has the block and 5 speed installed.  The suspension has been
   removed.  The 5 speed tranny, in ok condition.  Typical weak
   synchro's.  I have a box of parts to rebuild it (5 synchros,
   bearings, gaskets).

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 11:05:10 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 / 912E intake manifold question

It took me a while to find this out...

> In 1976, Porsche produced  the 912E, which used 2.0L engines combined with 
> the AFC FI from
> the 1.8L model.  What bolt pattern was used on the 912E intake manifold?

It's a three-bolt, standard Porsche 2.0. Just the top end of the FI has
changed.

> I have been thinking about upgrading the 1.8L engine on my 914 to a 2.0L 
> model.  I would like
> to keep it fuel injected, possibly the AFC unit currently on my 1.8L.  If 
> I do that, it sounds like
> a set of 912E intake manifolds might be an answer to the bolt pattern problem.
> 
> Anyone done this before?  Thanks,

Nope, but it shouldn't be too hard. 

Stan

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 18:28:58 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Windshield Wiper Streaking

I have no idea whether this stuff is any good, but I have before me a flier
for "303 Wiper Treatment", from the folks who brought you 303 Protectant
(which received good rewiews from this group a while back). It is claimed
to stop annoying chattering, skipping, and streaking. You can get six
applicator packets from them for $3.95 plus $1.00 S & H, good for 2-3
wiper blades per packet. It comes from the unfortunately-named "The
World's Best Products", PO Box 966, Palo Cedro CA 96073-0966, and is
non-toxic, biodegradable, environmentally safe, and 100% guaranteed,
according to the flier. 

I Wouldn't take it seriously, except that the 303 Protectant is good, so
maybe this is too. In New England, our windshield wipers fail from
plain wearing out, rather than from ozone or sunlight or things like that.
Maybe if you filled your windshield washers with liquid nitrogen, and
gave them an occasional squirt during the dry season, you Californians
and Arizonans could make your wipers last better?

 -John White-

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 09:36:44 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 928 engine in 914


Okay fantasy engine swappers. Dennis Kravig (think I spelled it right)
did it in 1990. Took him a few years to do it, here's why: There ain't
enough room in the car. Dennis, as i recall, lengthened the chassis 
almost 6 inches to make eveything fit. The 928 engine is VERY long.
I believe the color was aubergine, it has 914/6 GT fender flares. 


Dennis called me two days prior to the 1990 Parade Concours asking if he 
could show it. As the chairman, I couldn't resist, I'd heard of the
project and wanted to see it. We made room in the exhibition class.
There was a BIG crowd around the car. The Porsche entourage stopped for
a considerable time. My german was rusty, but I heard the remark "We
could have killed the Lancia rally team with that." What I learned was 
Dennis had barely completed the car before driving up from Los Angeles.
He drove it straight to the concours site!

Yes one exists. It's fast and makes a great sound.

Jim Pasha

reach for the ignition...

service and miscellaneous items. Did I do ok or should I locate a source 
of Vaseline?

	45k svc, oil change, air filter, plugs...$268
	Check all brakes, replace rear pads......$100
	Update camshaft seals (all) to "Vitron"..$150
	Replace all accessory belts..............$135

Had the work done at Classic Imports here in Dallas. Dave Perry at that 
location seems very forthright and reliable. Standard "no relation" 
disclaimer applies.

Ok, here's one I didn't ask Dave (forgot). My steering wheel makes an 
annoying rubbing/scratching sound when turned >1/4 turn or so. Sounds 
like plastic on plastic, but I can't be sure. Any thoughts?

That's about it... Muchas gracias for any help anyone can offer. See ya' 
on the freeway!

Gene Schoepp

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 03:06:06 EDT
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Broken Generator Hub


Some time ago, there was a discussion concerning how to remove a  36mm
generator nut to R&R the fan from a 356/912. It was suggested  that using an
impact wrench  on the nut as opposed to holding the Generator Hub in a vice
(or with vice grips) might be a Better Idea, as shearing off the key or
ruining the keyway might not be a good idea.
   Last week a Customer  sent me the remains of just such an attempt- holding
the hub in a vice, he attempted to remove the 36mm nut on the fan.
   Result: one BROKEN generator hub, AND one sheared-off key, AND one
elongated keyway in the generator shaft which meant: a ruined generator
shaft! Which meant a ruined generator!
   The rather impressively abused parts are now on display in the collection
of broken Porsche parts  Section in the Maestro's Museum. (Call (408)
727-1864 for an appointment.)
    Sometimes the Porsche gods send you examples of how not to do things, so
that you may learn from the mistakes and Kindness of Strangers. 

KEEP THE  356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 22:50:28 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Joining PCA and VIN numbers question

> 	Wait a min. Do I understand this right, someone has to own a Porsche
> 	and provide it's VIN number before being allowed to join PCA? 
> 	A Porsche enthusiast who can't afford to buy one can't join?!

Yes, you must own or co-own a Porsche. "Own" is pretty loosely defined
so that leases, etc. also count. So it's common to assume that "co-own"
is also similarly loosely defined... I have a friend that wanted to join 
PCA, mainly to have access to Pano to help him with the search for a
late factory Turbo Look cab. No VIN number, no joinee. So he made a deal
with another friend of mine to buy oh say the ashtray in his 930 for $5. 
Makes him a co-owner, right? Uses VIN number of said co-owned car, joins 
PCA. Buys the car of his dreams about 9 months later after some serious
hard looking....

Stan

Date: Sun, 9 Oct 1994 20:23:19 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Nitrogen in Tires

>Well, I was chuckling with my lovely wife this afternoon about the N2 in
>tires debate, which, I must admit, I was the culprit to instigate this
>little excursion.
>
>I had originally intended the aside as a sarcastic remark intended to show
>how some drivers will spend large dollars for small improvements in
>performance.  My mistake was that I did not include a smiley in my original
>comment.
>
>My last word on the subject has to do with observation, not with conjecture
>or speculation.
>
>For a few years running, my lovely wife and I were fortunate to work with
>the Dyson Racing Team, as they campaigned their Porsche 962 in the IMSA GTP
>series.  My recollection of the Daytona pit area included the Goodyear
>Racing support truck, which was mounting and balancing tires at a prodigious
>rate for the entire period of practice, qualifying and the 24 hour race.
>
>At no time did I see any evidence of Nitrogen bottles there or anywhere else
>in the pits during that time.  Goodyear was using nothing but good ol'
>compressed Daytona air for inflating (now pay attention to this!) tires that
>were going to be traveling at 200 mph for long periods of time!
>
>Now, in my way of thinking (flawed though it may be by years of abuse and
>chemicals), if there was any advantage to be gained by using nitrogen in
>tires, I would have seen it then and there.
>
>QED, if it was not used there, I doubt that its use on any of the cars that
>we drive is going to provide a competitive advantage.  (Of course, if it
>helps to keep rubber from oxidizing, there may be a valid reason for using
>it, after all...)
>
>I'll go back to sleep now...

Thank you for the real life sanity check. If Goodyear is not using nitogen,
then there is no advantage!!  As far as the rubber oxidizing is concerned,
there is no way to keep air away from the outside of the tire, so who cares
about the inside!!

Scott
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 12:12:22 BST
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: K&N Filter & Fiche Manuals

Recently I asked about K&N fileter for my 930 - general opinion was go for it 
but dont expect anything fantastic. Well went for it and fitted the new filter
 - on my 930 with air-con this only involves the removal of the inter-cooler, 
moving the air-con compressor and then taking off the airbox an easy 45 mins.
Well nothing startling - 930 already very fast - BUT my wife thinks its quieter (me too) and its a little smoother at the bottom - less hesitent before boost
really  comes on - maybe that was caused by the oiled old filter? So I am
pleased with the results (whether its real or imaginary) and thanks for the 
advice.


On a the fiche manuals. Got a scraped viewer from the company - rebuilt it and
its fine. Manuals from Stoddard in the US - $35 form 911 , $10 for 930 extras.
Look good to me except they are for the US cars as expected but since most bits
are the same should be no problems BUT why didnt I get the parts fiche at the 
same time? Thanks again for all the help.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 07:21:59 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Draining fuel from 924

> Would anyone know the best way to drain fuel from the tank of a 924?
> I'd like to do it with the minimum mess and spilled fuel.  The vehicle has
> had the fuel since December (about 1/2 tank) and will not start (bad fuel is
> the probable cause).  I'd like to drain it, hopefully without being drown in
> gas.
> 
> Has anyone tried to drain by using the fuel pump to drain the tank?
> 
> Thanks

Perhaps the easiest way to get a large amount of gas from your 924 tank is
to remove the fuel gauge sender and siphon it out the top.

The fuel gauge sender is located in the luggage compartment, under the
carpet and a glass fiber protector.  It is held in place by 5 or 6 allen
bolts. After removing the bolts, lift the sender slowly, while the gas
drains from it.  A half-inch (ID) hose will drain about half a gallon per
minute.

I would stay away from using the fuel pump to drain the tank, if only
because it works at 75 psi...

p.s. make sure you have ample cans for the gas before you start the process.
Also, make sure that you do this in a well ventilated area, free from
sparks, etc.  (Liability disclaimers apply...)

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 13:48:58 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 944 alignment questions

JCWhitney has a spring-loaded extensible measuring stick that makes it easier
to get the "within a few millimeters" accuracy you need to set your own toe-in.
You set it between the two inside sidewalls, at axle height in front, and it
can stay right there while you roll forward one half rotation.  There are
scribed lines on the stick, so you are comparing distances of just a few centi-
meters rather than several feet across the track of the car.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 10:16:15 -0700
From: Brooks Esser <esserb@hpcc01.corp.hp.com>
Subject: unsubscribe



Please remove my name from the digest mailing list.

Thanks,

Brooks Esser


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 17:53:27 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: 911 Trailer Hitch

Looking at the wiring diagram for the 84 928S, I was amazed to find that
the instrument cluster has a light labelled "Trailer Turn Signal". The
wires seem to go nowhere past the connector, but clearly someone had plans
for that big V-8 to move something more than the sylphlike 3300 pounds
of the car itself. Match that, you puny air-coolers!

 -John White-

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 13:25:12 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: wna  anted..3.3 tutbo   rbo fuel distrib.             injection parts

> hi im looking for a good used fuel distributor/intake box for an 84
> 3.3 liter turbo, also a warmup regulator..any one have any parts ??

I hate to keep sayin this *BUT*: there's no such thing as a good
used CIS injection part. You can only use them if they came directly
off a running car and go directly on YOUR car, no shelf time in between,
or if they've been through a Bosch rebuild program. 

I can certainly understand wanting to save a buck or three on this stuff,
but you'll pay more in the long run because you'll *STILL* have to replace
the part with a new one. 

Stan

------------------------------

Cleaning your house while your kids are still growing is like

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 13:29:05 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 911sc exhaust

Terry Williams inquires about a heat exchanger on one side, headers on the 
other.  Can there really be someone cheaper than me?  I would guess no problem
if the headers in the heat exchanger are designed identically to the naked
headers.  Have to make sure the air ducting to the no-exchanger side is sealed
off real well.  Lots of swap-meet headers are the guts of heater exchangers
whose shells have rusted away, so you probably could find a "matching" set
of header vestida and header desnuda.  Did you have something in mind besides
saving money?  If not, I'd look for a used pair.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 18:02:11 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Ventilation

My '84 doesn't have a small fan that runs all the time - are you sure yours
does? THE fan just doesn't turn off even at the lowest setting. The most
likely problem is in the switch itself, I think. Someone who knows just a
little about electric things should be able to check it out with an
ohmmeter, if you can figure out how to get access to it. I'll take a look
at the diagrams on my semi-legible fiches and see if anything else is an
obvious candidate.
 -John White-

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 10:00:10 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: More 356 Rear Axle Nuts 


     
     FYI, my '64 VW Double Cab transporter started leaking oil at the right 
     rear drum.  The reason?  The axle nut came loose and was loose for a 
     whole weeks worth of driving.  I was saved by the cotter pin.  From 
     now on I will always tighten the axle nut to 350-400 ft lbs and always 
     install a new cotter pin in case the old one rusts or breaks and comes 
     loose.  (Same goes for my 356 too!)
     
     Derek Au
______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
But the label on the bag was interesting: it says you have to tighten the 
axle nut to some godawful number, 350 or 400 ft.-lbs, or else you will 
damage the halfshaft splines. So there's the reason, apparently.
     
Pete
     
     

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 23:37:49 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Using electrical Heat gun for paint removal.

Hi,

I used an electrical heat gun (max 600 deg. C) to remove paint from my '58 
model 356. It was *very* easy compare to the traditional method. In 3-4 
hours I managed to get half the car down to the original paint, I think it 
had 4 layers of paint over that one. 

Now it is half red, half white and I can recommend this method.

Anyone else have experience with Electrical Heat guns for this task?

cheers,
trond

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 16:35:01 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: Re: 930 Performance questions

Keith,

Do you store your 930 in the winter months? (Sorry, I don't know where you
live).  Bruce Anderson hints that sooner or later all 930 turbos will have
to be replaced.  He gives the turbos a life of 10,000 to 30,000 miles.  Have
you had trouble with your turbo and what is the going rate for turbo
replacement?  I would like to learn storing techniques from 930 owners and
how they avoid the "smoking turbo" upon start up in the spring which
Anderson describes.  Bruce says that these cars should be driven regularly,
but I live in the northeast where the winter (snow and salt) dictates car
storage.

I have just traded my trusty '81 SC for an '87 930.
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 21:53:31 +0300
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
Subject: Re: Hakkapeliitta etc.

It is _Hakkapeliitta_ not Hakkapolitta etc. The fearless finnish  
cavalrymen in the army of king Gustav Adolf II. In particular snow or  
bad weather was no obstacle to these fellows. In later days known as  
a snowtire with akin properties. Get them for your _other_ car. Not  
that they wouldn't work with your P-car - indeed they are probably  
the best snowtires for that as well. But a sportscar in snow? I mean  
most of us prefer traction, right? (Perhaps finally all?) You could  
have a couple of times fun on the ice track but other than that, no. 

Wrap your car up for the winter and instead think of the day you get  
to unwrap it. That day is like other days you get to unwrap  
something. Only much better...

Cheers,

Kari

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 12:20:37 -0500
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Gauges reading high/low, thanks, bandwidth

Thanks to all who suggested other reasons that will make gauges read
correctly (ie when they should) higher readings than normal. All these are
different problems from the one I was pointing out. My original message
stated that the gauges WILL SOMETIMES READ HIGH, WHEN THEY SHOULDN'T, and
at other times LOW, WHEN THEY SHOULDN'T, and asked for an explanation of
these ELECTRICAL phenomena from the experts.

What I was looking for was an explanation, based on wiring, of how this 
will happen. In order to save bandwidth, I didn't respond to any of the
various messages explaining how high readings may be correct (some of them
were instructive anyway). I decided to wait and see who had understood the
original intent of the message. Thank you, John Wright, for some of the
possible ELECTRICAL explanations of how gauges may read high/low  when
they shouldn't.
 
(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis           ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
'87 911 Carrera targa, summer yellow on black full leather  
Washington University in St. Louis (The above are my words/actions, not theirs) 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 10:35:56 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: The Farts (was: Re: Wiper Shudder)

| From: Darren Evans-Young  <DARREN@ua1vm.ua.edu>
|
| On Thu, 6 Oct 1994 14:56:06 -0500 Steve Sarsfield said:
| >On another subject:
| >My 1983 944 makes what I can describe as nothing else but a short,
| >flatulent sound after driving about 20-25 minutes.
|
| My 944S makes a flatulent groaning sound whenever I shut off
| the ignition. I have yet to track it down. It comes from the
| passenger side either in the engine compartment or under the
| dash.

Egads, my '84 944 has just started doing this!  Very embarrassing! ;-)

My first thought was pressure build up in the cooling system, but
I have not noticed any water puddles under the car.

It just occured to me that it could be a vacuum leak. There is a
vacuum tank near the vent fan under the hood.  The ventilation
system uses this vacuum source for operating the dampers
via diaphram actuators. I wonder if one of these devices
could be leaking.  I only notice it after the car has been shut
off after a several mile freeway jaunt.

Anyone have any ideas?

     Eric

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 19:29:13 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Swaybar

I have an 89 turboS that has the stock 28mm front and 18mm rear. the car is
used mainly for track events and the PCA race series. The car is, in fact,
bone stock and is competitive. However I was given some photo's of the car/me
in action and noticed that I was really leaning in some of the faster
sweeping turns. 
I have purchased the 30mm front bar (factory race item) and also a
Weltmeister rear bar (22mm). I have installed the front bar but not the rear.
Since the car was oversteering a bit I want to try just the stiffer front bar
first. 
This Friday going to Summit for the acid test. Give me a holler and I'll let
you know how I made out.
Yes the stock bars might be available. (they are much more rigid than normal
951 bars)

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 21:45:15 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Joining PCA. . .



The mysterious MQL writes: "It is this "exclusive" attitude that keeps me
from joining PCA even after I bought a Porsche. Besides, the few "car"
events I attended, some people there were expressing the same "exclusivity"
attitude. So, until those "owners" get their noses unstuck from whatever
keeping their noses so high, I will withold my 35 bucks."

Too, bad - like most things in life, you get out of the club whatever you're
willing to put into it. PCA regions merely offer the potential - the rest is
up to you. You don't join - you miss out on meeting really great people.

Do some PCAers have a nose-problem? Possibly, like any organization. Do most
PCAers have a nose-problem? Not in my experience, but I've been a member
only since 1961.

As for owning a Porsche to join the Porsche club equals "exclusive
attitude?" Give me a break.

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 16:31:54 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 alignment questions

| From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648"  <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
|
| JCWhitney has a spring-loaded extensible measuring stick that makes it easier
| to get the "within a few millimeters" accuracy you need to set your 
own toe-in.
| You set it between the two inside sidewalls, at axle height in front, and it
| can stay right there while you roll forward one half rotation.  There are
| scribed lines on the stick, so you are comparing distances of just a 
few centi-
| meters rather than several feet across the track of the car.

Is this device "U" shaped?  If not, then it would not be possible to have
it be placed anywhere near axle height in either the front or the rear of
the front tires.  My tires are roughly 23 inches in diameter or 11.5 inches
in radius.  The car has perhaps 5 inches of ground clearance, so a
straight stick would only be able to go (roughly) up to within 6.5 inches
of axle height, which would increase the inaccuracy of the measurement.

Pete's system (using tacks and a plumb bob) would not have this
limitation.

     Eric

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 23:16:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Joining PCA and VIN numbers question

> That's right Steve.It is this "exclusive" attitude that keeps me from joining 
> PCA even after I bought a Porsche. Besides, the few "car" events I attended, 
> some people there were expressing the same "exclusivity" attitude. 

Well, it all depends on the region. Some are just plain fun and full of 
damned nice people; some are kinda fun with some damned nice people and a
few jerks, and some are mostly jerks. Sorry your experience has been with
a mostly jerks region.

But it's kind of like this list: for every Kevin Gross or three, there's also
a T*d (can't say the T-word or my mailer won't let the message go out...).
At issue is whether they show up in sufficient numbers to spoil the fun.

> Join the BMWCCA! Their Roundel magazine is even better than Panorama and they 
> got Satch Carlson writing for them too. Besides you don't need a VIN. I still 
> belong to the BMWCCA after I sold my M3. The people are great too.

Not to disparage Roundel, which is *NOT* as nice as Pano or The Star, BTW, 
but did Satch ever beat those sexual misconduct with a minor charges or
is he just speculating about BMWs from inside the Big House?

In a more personal vein, I'll do things with the local BMW clubs (2 and 4
wheel) and the SCCA (*NOT* autox though), but not with the local PCA region.
The BMW guys are a blast, and they're sooooo slow on the autox courses 8{)
The LSR guys are, well, let's put it like this: I was an officer in LSR for 
two years, at first opportunity I transferred my membership to NNJR (another 
great region!!) and now that I'm back in TX, will transfer to Coastal Bend. 
Sure, it's a bit of a drive to Corpus Christi from Houston, but better than 
the alternative... Further, as they say, deponent sayeth not.

Stan

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 19:29:13 EDT
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Swaybar

I have an 89 turboS that has the stock 28mm front and 18mm rear. the car is
used mainly for track events and the PCA race series. The car is, in fact,
bone stock and is competitive. However I was given some photo's of the car/me
in action and noticed that I was really leaning in some of the faster
sweeping turns. 
I have purchased the 30mm front bar (factory race item) and also a
Weltmeister rear bar (22mm). I have installed the front bar but not the rear.
Since the car was oversteering a bit I want to try just the stiffer front bar
first. 
This Friday going to Summit for the acid test. Give me a holler and I'll let
you know how I made out.
Yes the stock bars might be available. (they are much more rigid than normal
951 bars)

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 21:45:15 -0700
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Joining PCA. . .



The mysterious MQL writes: "It is this "exclusive" attitude that keeps me
from joining PCA even after I bought a Porsche. Besides, the few "car"
events I attended, some people there were expressing the same "exclusivity"
attitude. So, until those "owners" get their noses unstuck from whatever
keeping their noses so high, I will withold my 35 bucks."

Too, bad - like most things in life, you get out of the club whatever you're
willing to put into it. PCA regions merely offer the potential - the rest is
up to you. You don't join - you miss out on meeting really great people.

Do some PCAers have a nose-problem? Possibly, like any organization. Do most
PCAers have a nose-problem? Not in my experience, but I've been a member
only since 1961.

As for owning a Porsche to join the Porsche club equals "exclusive
attitude?" Give me a break.

Date: Sun, 09 Oct 94 21:29:29 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Using electrical Heat gun for paint removal.


     
Yep, they also work great for removing undercoating, seam sealer, tar 
soundproofing and then for reinstalling tar soundproofing.  Thanks for the tip 
for using it on paint.  I really *hate* the (body shop) sand it (and some metal)
off with a DA sander" method.

You're not going to use lead filler *all* over the car again are you?

Derek Au

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
     
Hi,
     
I used an electrical heat gun (max 600 deg. C) to remove paint from my '58 
model 356. It was *very* easy compare to the traditional method. In 3-4 
hours I managed to get half the car down to the original paint, I think it 
had 4 layers of paint over that one. 
     
Now it is half red, half white and I can recommend this method.
     
Anyone else have experience with Electrical Heat guns for this task?
     
cheers,
trond

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 16:31:54 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 alignment questions

| From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648"  <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
|
| JCWhitney has a spring-loaded extensible measuring stick that makes it easier
| to get the "within a few millimeters" accuracy you need to set your 
own toe-in.
| You set it between the two inside sidewalls, at axle height in front, and it
| can stay right there while you roll forward one half rotation.  There are
| scribed lines on the stick, so you are comparing distances of just a 
few centi-
| meters rather than several feet across the track of the car.

Is this device "U" shaped?  If not, then it would not be possible to have
it be placed anywhere near axle height in either the front or the rear of
the front tires.  My tires are roughly 23 inches in diameter or 11.5 inches
in radius.  The car has perhaps 5 inches of ground clearance, so a
straight stick would only be able to go (roughly) up to within 6.5 inches
of axle height, which would increase the inaccuracy of the measurement.

Pete's system (using tacks and a plumb bob) would not have this
limitation.

     Eric

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 23:16:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Joining PCA and VIN numbers question

> PCA even after I bought a Porsche. Besides, the few "car" events I attended,

Well, it all depends on the region. Some are just plain fun and full of 
damned nice people; some are kinda fun with some damned nice people and a
few jerks, and some are mostly jerks. Sorry your experience has been with
a mostly jerks region.

But it's kind of like this list: for every Kevin Gross or three, there's also
a T*d (can't say the T-word or my mailer won't let the message go out...).
At issue is whether they show up in sufficient numbers to spoil the fun.

> Join the BMWCCA! Their Roundel magazine is even better than Panorama and they 
> got Satch Carlson writing for them too. Besides you don't need a VIN. I still 
> belong to the BMWCCA after I sold my M3. The people are great too.

Not to disparage Roundel, which is *NOT* as nice as Pano or The Star, BTW, 
but did Satch ever beat those sexual misconduct with a minor charges or
is he just speculating about BMWs from inside the Big House?

In a more personal vein, I'll do things with the local BMW clubs (2 and 4
wheel) and the SCCA (*NOT* autox though), but not with the local PCA region.
The BMW guys are a blast, and they're sooooo slow on the autox courses 8{)
The LSR guys are, well, let's put it like this: I was an officer in LSR for 
two years, at first opportunity I transferred my membership to NNJR (another 
great region!!) and now that I'm back in TX, will transfer to Coastal Bend. 
Sure, it's a bit of a drive to Corpus Christi from Houston, but better than 
the alternative... Further, as they say, deponent sayeth not.

Stan

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 23:12:34 EDT
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Weber carb. questions

Hi,

This past week I received the Fall/ winter catalogue from Performance
Products. I was browsing through it and saw a section on Weber carbs which
got me thinking about tuning them myself.
Now I have a couple of questions.

1 Perf. Products sells two books on Weber carbs, one from Haynes and another
from HPBooks.  Which is the better book? Or is their another one  that
someone would recommend? 

2. Besides a synchrometer and a float level are there any other tools that I
should buy? 

3.  I am sure that the books will explain it, but how do I use a synchrometer
when I have tubes (they look like torque boosters as seen in the Automotion
cat.) sticking out of the velocity stacks. Can they be pulled out and do they
really help?

4. What size jets should I use. I have a 73 911S and currently have 40 idle
jets and 140 main jets. I feel that the car is running a little rich as their
is a slight smell of gas in the exhaust. Is there a formula for selecting the
idle and main jets? If so, what would be appropriate for my car in weather
conditions such as Miami, FL (Temp 85F, Humidity 75%) and where should I buy
them if they need to be changed?

5. Lastly, how difficult is it to rebuild webers. I have seen kits advertised
in Pano and was wondering if it was a job for pros or any mechanically
inclined person.

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 16:44:32 EDT
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Driver's ed event

Hey,

Just returned from the Alabama Region's PCA driver's ed event (Sunday).  Good
turn-out, considering the *large* amount of rain we drove in all day.  Fellow
pfile Darren Evans-Young was also there in his 944S.

Quite a few off-track excursions (agricultural racing) due to the wet
conditions.  Luckily, I stayed on the pavement.  One of the highlights of the
day was one of the club member's 935 doing a few laps.  Incredible
car.  Quite a few nice cars in attendance, actually.  There was an early
911 race car - could have been an RS but it was raining too hard to go get a
closer look.

Watching a lot of racing on TV, I've heard that "when someone in front of you
spins, aim right for them, because when you get there, they will be gone".
 Well this is true.  A 928 spun right in front of me and the idea of aiming
right for it crossed my mind.  I decided not try anything fancy and just
slowed down.  Sure enough, here he comes back across the track!!  Luckily I
was going slow enough at this point to simply drive around him on the
outside.  

To reiterate some recent posts, join the PCA and get involved in
auto-x/driver's schools/etc!!!

Mike Dayton
76 Euro 911
MLBDayton@aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 23:12:26 EDT
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject:  Alignment adventures and Turbo tie-rods (long)

After asking several questions, I finally have a story/experience to relate
with my fellow Porschephiles. I would have asked everyone for advice on
changing tie rods but time constraints and mail problems limited me to local
knowledge and a poorly written magazine article. Well here goes. Sorry it's
so long.

About two weeks ago I went to get my car ('73 911S)  aligned at my  LOCAL
Goodyear store (let me emphasize local because I'm sure other Goodyear stores
are more competent). After 45 minutes the mechanic told me that my car was
ready. I got ready to pay when I asked for the printout of the alignment
specs. They went to get it and upon receipt I noticed that they had done
nothing to the rear suspension and had not adjusted the camber of the front
suspension.  The manager then put the car back on the lift and talked it over
with his mechanics. After about 20 minutes of looking at the car and
comparing the car with the Hunter display, they decided not to risk messing
up the car any further and said that I should go elsewhere.  No charge.

Then I went to NTW and found a somebody who use to do all the alignment work
for the local Porsche dealership. Well, he put the car on the lift and
checked it out. After 10 minutes he called me out back and showed me how my
tie rod ends were slightly loose and that he couldn't guarantee that he could
align the toe within spec. So I decided to buy Turbo tie rods at Vertex for
 $120 w/tax. Especially since I was going to drivers' Ed at Sebring two days
later.

A nightmare ensued.  The change seemed fairly straight forward. Unscrew
everything and install new piece. The hard part was removing the passenger
side tie rod end from the spindle. It took me about two hours  using a
hammer, crowbar, WD-40.... everything but a tie rod end puller or a pickle
fork. Then magically it popped off. Then unscrewing the tie rod from the
steering rack was also a pain in my ***. The rest of the passenger side went
pretty quickly, relatively speaking. On the driver's side I expected an
equally hard time with the tie rod end and was wondering if I was ever going
to get it off. Fortunately I was wrong. It came off after 3 minutes.  I then
decided to take the end apart and noticed that the ball joint was completely
rusted and didn't have a trace of grease in it. I had more trouble getting
the rod off the steering rack but after several hours the novice home
mechanic had everything back together. Total time: no comment.

I went back to a different NTW  (the original mechanic who pointed out my
problem had the day off so he recommended somebody else. I would have waited
for him but I was off to Sebring the next day and couldn't wait.) and had my
car aligned as closely as possible to spec.  I think the rear toe wasn't in
spec, but the mechanic said that the total toe was well in spec.  Everything
was now completely finished. 

When I first got the car I was a little disappointed that it handled so
poorly compared to my mother's 1987 turbo-look targa, but I just attributed
it to a huge difference between a 8 year old turbo-bodied 911 with a 22 year
old  911 with only 205/60 15 all-around. The car now handles like a dream, it
no longer wanders all over the highway and there is less body roll when
turning (probably because the tires are both pointing in the same directions
at all times). All that for $120. A cheap fix for a Porsche. I was sure that
I needed new shocks and bigger sway bars. For the time being I am so pleased
with the improvement that I think the rest can wait a little longer. 

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 22:06:11 EDT
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Winders Nitrogen tires (Sorry)

Scott Winders came back hard when Rick Dill tried to correct him
about Nitrogen having advantages.

Calm Down Scott! He wasn't talking about your mother (unless you are a son
 -of -an -inert -gas)

He is actually CORRECT. Air compressors do spew out lots of water, due
to it getting compressed out of the air. That is why we use AIR DRYERS
when compressed air needs to be used to paint cars or operate machinery.
They are almost never used at garages. And this liquid H2O WILL at least
partly turn to water vapor when the tires heat up, which WILL
raise the pressure in the tires more (did you ever see a pressure cooker?
Did you ever see water vapor rise from the ground outside although the
air is less than 212 degrees?) And the rusting principle can not be
argued with. Your Ivy-league experts were not asked the questions
correctly, so they didn't answer correctly.

Regards,  Mike Piera  '72 911S

expensive, but I have seen them used at swap meets. One could probably
find enough BBS parts used to assemble the sizes and offsets you need.

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 18:08:11 -0500
From: dkelly@nebula.tbe.com (david kelly)
Subject: Re:  928 Ventilation

John White says,
> My '84 doesn't have a small fan that runs all the time

My '83 didn't either until I took it apart and cleaned it. The dash mounted
temperature sensor has a duct running a couple of inches to a canister
containing a small 12 Vdc fan, about an inch in diameter. This fan keeps
cabin air moving across the thermister, else it bake in the sun.

A relay in the ventilation controls used to buzzing, intermitantly. Traced 
the problem to a bad ground. Couldn't believe Porsche grounded half of
the ventilation controls thru the cigarette lighter's ground.

Now if I can figure out why the upshift indicator is equally random.
Maybe the car is just high spirited and wants to GO! when I'm stopped
in traffic? Yet it is hard to upshift from 5th.

David Kelly, N4HHE
dkelly@nebula.tbe.com

'83 928S
'93 Infiniti G20
(6) Cats.

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 16:20:31 PDT
From: Ehab Aljandali <ehab@cisco.com>
Subject: RE: 911sc exhaust

>
	Just a thought, would'nt the header side run cooler than the normal side
... and if so any preformance decrease??




 
> Terry Williams inquires about a heat exchanger on one side, headers on the 
> other.  Can there really be someone cheaper than me?  I would guess no problem
> if the headers in the heat exchanger are designed identically to the naked
> headers.  Have to make sure the air ducting to the no-exchanger side is sealed
> off real well.  Lots of swap-meet headers are the guts of heater exchangers
> whose shells have rusted away, so you probably could find a "matching" set
> of header vestida and header desnuda.  Did you have something in mind besides
> saving money?  If not, I'd look for a used pair.
> B.
>

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 11:37:26 PDT
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: re:Re: H&R vs. Eibach springs

Drew,

Does the RS America have different mounting than the C2/C4?  I notice in the 
Perfomance Products catalog that they have different H&R springs for the RS 
America than the C2/C4.  I thought the difference for the 2 cars were that the 
spring diameter from factory was slightly thicker for the RS America.  That 
shouldn't justify different H&R springs for the RS vs. the C2/C4.  

BTW, I heard from Performance Products that the main difference was that the 
Eibach's were fixed rate spring vs. the progressive rate springs for the H&R. 
 Maybe that's true for all Eibach springs.

Quincy Dong
QLD1@pge.com

Porschephiles #901                         Wed Oct 12 21:38:30 CDT 1994
Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:29:16 -0700
From: mba@intrepid.th.gov.bc.ca (Murray Baines)
Subject: 944 Vibration

I have had an engine vibration problem for the last 3 years with my 83 944.
My vibration seems to be most prevalent while accelerating from about 2800 to
3600.  I am unsure as to whether it is driveline induced or strictly an engine
thing.  I did re-alighn my balance shafts once and obtained some reduction.[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[D[Dreset my balance shafts once and saw some improvement.  This 
suggests to me that balance shaft error would manifest itself in such a manner.
However to throw a wrench into the works, when driving over smooth pavement the
phenomena does not seem to occur.  Who knows?  Other possible things to think
about, driveshaft and clutch assembly both move at engine speed and both are
subject to load changes during acceleration.  My 944 is tres low, so I know I
have excessive rear negitive camber and possibly toe in.  Does this situation
sound familiar to anyone?  Any comments?

Murray 83 944, 72 Elan +2 and 71 Alfa GT

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 16:21:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@eac00eac1.ea.com>
Subject: Re: Stripping paint

Re: Using heat guns to remove paint:

>Thanks for the tip for using it on paint.  I really *hate* the (body shop) 
>sand it (and some metal) off with a DA sander" method.
     
I have a heat gun but I haven't tried it on paint.....yet.  I'll give it a 
shot.

For those of you who don't have a heat gun or know somebody with one, perhaps 
you have (or can borrow) a small 4" grinder with a wire cup.  This'll strip 
layers of paint and bondo *WITHOUT* scratching up the surface like a sanding 
disc or putty knife.  It leaves the metal nice and smooth.

I stripped both sides of my 914 using this method.  The only problem areas 
are the nooks and crannies around the inner rockers, etc where the wire cup 
won't reach.  Perhaps this is where the heat gun would work well....

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 16:17:00 CDT
From: "Weeks Jr, James P (Jim)" <jpweeks@hsv26.pcmail.ingr.com>
Subject: RE: 928 Ventilation


Wayne,
  From your message it was not clear to me if the fan was running or was it 
not blowing air..
The way the dial works: when you wheel it around to the blue section..it 
trips a vacuum soleniod and opens the upper duct work, the rubber hoses that 
are used in the vacuum lines will dry rot over time and loss of vacuum will 
occur..You can check this by removing the Glove Box and locating the vacuum 
lines and a lever/arm that
opens the upper ducts..rotate that arm open and seal of the opening to the 
soleniod.
A small piece of rubber hose with a larger nail in it works fine..Fresh Cool 
Air should
breeze through the vents..
 If the Fan doens't work at all, disregard all of the above...and check the 
A/C relay
the Chiltons Manual for the 928 has some pretty easy to follow wiring 
diagrams..

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 09:46 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Hakkapeliitta etc.

> Wrap your car up for the winter and instead think of the day you get  
> to unwrap it. That day is like other days you get to unwrap  
> something. Only much better...

I'm with Stan on this one.  My basic tenet is that I'm gonna be dead
in 40 years or so, and have absolutely no plans to spend half that
time driving second-tier cars.  The funeral home doesn't give discounts
to people with concours-condition cars.

I drove my car *every* day in last year's winter, which was pretty
snowy here in New England.  It was the first year on Pirelli 190's,
which were very good and would have been even better had they not been
225 and 205 sizes.  (They came off a car which was bought and then sold
to someone who didn't want 'em.  The price was right.)  I dream of a
nice set of Hakka's -- hoo hee!

This stuff about "Porsches (sports cars) don't handle in the snow" is
absolute horseshit.  You put the right tires on, and you take the
camber down to a reasonable number (like factory numbers), and you
are then all set.

Like the old beer commercial said, you only go around once, so grab
all the gusto you can!

Kevin Gross

buy a new one, I want to ask the collective wisdom of the list if it is
normal for a waterpumper's coolant cap to wear out and not hold
its pressure as it is intended?

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 16:53:16 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re:       928 Ventilation

Howdy Wayne,

Wayne writes:

>Symptoms- Having just come thru winter I cannot be sure exactly when 
>the fan/air stopped but first noticed about a month ago.I checked the 
>fuses and unfortunately it wasnt that simple. The fan does work when 
>you slide the controll to demist but not when you turn the dial.I 
>only presume the air doesnt work ?.About a week ago it suddenly 
>started working (& the air) but just as suddenly stopped.
>The small fan that runs all the time still works.

I had this problem on my '79 928 but the problem was with the fuse; not that
it was blown, it was fine.  The contacts, however, were corroded.  A little
WD-40 and all is well.  And it affected my AC too.  Can't remember which fuse it
was but it's in the owner's manual.

>Having just joined this group I find the topics interesting & 
>informative but note the lack of discussion on the 928.

Well, it's obvious to me that the lack of discussion means that "OUR" cars
are MUCH better designed than those pesky little air-cooled things.  Not
only that, but we can haul Benz's with our cars too!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Date: Tue, Oct 11, 1994 11:02 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4

In message <941007025739_76416.167_FHA23-4@CompuServe.COM> Peter Albrecht 
writes:
> Hi, Mike.
>  
> Well, you asked for comments.
>  
> The nominal torque split of the 993 C4 is 31/69, unless the center
> differential diffs. I don't know what its limits are, but I don't think it
> can go as far as 0/100 or 100/0.
>  
> I think Audi also used an electronically modulated hydraulic clutch system
> like the older C4 for their high-end AWD cars, but I'm not sure. Anybody out
> there ever pull Audi duty under their cars?
>  
> Pete
>  
Pete,

Wasn't Audi duty that rich texan who ran for president in the last election,
until a gang of murderous cubans driving yugos with helium filled tires on
explosive forged aluminum wheels threatened to kidnap his daughter (or at
least ruin her wedding), thus forcing him to retire?

Whatever.  High-end late model Quattros use Torsen (TORque SENsing) center
differentials while earlier models use (lockable) mechanical differentials. 
My Syncro is the Audi 4000 series quattro system (and I believe, the same
as the Ur-Quattro and all other pre-torsen models).  The center and rear
differentials can be manually locked by the driver, on the fly.  No
clutches are used in either system, to the best of my (limited) knowledge.

Ok, I'm going, I'm going... Stop pushing!

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 11:35:37 -0600
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@novell.com>
Subject: Re: H&R vs. Eibach springs



Begin forwarded message:

> Does anybody have any preference between the H&R springs vs. the Eibach 

> springs?  I did read about the H&R springs in a magazine a couple of months 

> ago and thought that the H&R sounded superior to the Eibach springs.  Later,  
I 

> think someone from the p-philes or a rebuttal to the article had also stated 

> that the Eibach also had the same kind of Quality Control or approval as the 

> H&R springs (i.e. TUV approval).
> 

> Drew, how about your opinion on the H&R?
> 

> Thanks for any input that will help me decide which springs to put in my car.
> 

> Quincy Dong
> QLD1@pge.com
> 


I like the H&R's myself, but have not had any experiences with Eibach.  From
feedback that I've had from people to use Eibach, I've not had anyone say 

they don't like them.  Some people have opinions regarding progressive rate
vs. fixed rate springs, but it appears to be a matter of personal preference.
I don't think you can go wrong with either H&R or Eibach, as both appear to 

have good reputations for producing quality products.  The only caveat I've
heard regarding Eibach was the early springs for the 964's required some 

modification of the spring perches on the factory struts due to their 

different diameter.  Andial also sells a spring set for the 964 that is
apparently built by Eibach that the RS America drivers around here seem
to universally hate due to the spring rates, though they're probably 

setup to be installed as a set with Andial's Cup suspension struts.  


Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 08:48:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw3.az05.bull.com>
Subject: RE: 944 latch motor


The motor has nothing to do with raising the hatchback. It is raised by the 
rear hatch shocks, which probably need replacing. Th shocks should push the 
hatch up quite quicky on release, If yours don't do that one or both are 
probably kaput. The good news is they are easy to replace.  If they seem 
O.K. it could just be that one or both latches is out of alignment and the 
locating pins are catching on the latch. They too are easy to adjust (two 
nuts) I did mine by inserting the key in the lock with a vice grip attached 
to the key fob (so it stayed over in the release position)  then I loosened 
the offending latch and moved it until the hatch sprang up and   - Voila!

A careful retightening of the nuts while holding the latch in position and 
no problems since.

Will Hartje
 ----------
From: porschephiles-request
To: porschephiles

Date: Monday, October 10, 1994 6:50PM

hatchback).  I have forgotten what various people have said the problem is,
so if someone could tell me again, I'd appreciate it.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 10:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Re[2]: Joining PCA and VIN numbers question

>That's right Steve.It is this "exclusive" attitude that keeps me from
>joining PCA even after I bought a Porsche. Besides, the few "car"
>events I attended, some people there were expressing the same
>"exclusivity" attitude. 

You know, I hear this sort of thing every once in a long while, and
it's really too bad.  I think that usually somebody just rubbed somebody
else the wrong way, quite by accident.

Couple of suggestions.  There are over 30,000 PCA'ers, they're not all
jerks, and most of them are pretty darn nice.  I think Bill Buff once
made a comment about people who spend too much time sitting in cars
being not all there -- probably explains some of our aberrances!

Most regions seem to have a core of folks who, year after year, do an
awful lot for their members.  The downside to this is that sometimes
it gets a little cliquey, or the region's overt style reflects the
interests of that core.  For example, some regions get tagged "a track
region" because their officers and other core folks favour that
activity.

I don't think there is any volunteer organization which doesn't have
this problem.  Rest assured that there are a ton of people in PCA
with the same car as you and probably the same interests and expect-
ations.

I don't know who the original poster was, but if s/he's in Zone 1,
drop me a line and I will put you in touch with guaranteed non-jerk
PCA people.  Who spend too much time sitting in their cars.

WRT requiring a VIN, this is a subject which has been debated at
the National level in the past.  I think the dominant sentiment has
been that this is a Porsche club, for people who have Porsches,
because that's the kind of club most members want to have.  I happen
to agree.  Owning a Porsche isn't prohibitively expensive, they are
not rare cars.  My feeling is that any club has the right to define
the terms and conditions of membership -- to define itself.

If you disagree, that's cool.  Go start your own Porsche club or join
another one that exists without the ownership requirement.  Or join
SCCA.  Or subscribe to Excellence, Automobile, and SCI, which give
better coverage to Porsches than Pano does anyway.

(I think Pano has become little more than a US version of Christophorus
in many respects, and with all due respect to Betty Jo, Leonard, Bill O,
and the rest of the crew.  It pisses me off that Bruce gets fewer an
fewer column inches every year, that the new model coverage cannot
find anything less than perfect about each car, etc., etc.  Why aren't
Jim Pasha's wonderful articles in Pano?)

Kevin
