Date:    Tue, 11 Oct 94 21:06 EDT
From: MARSHAL@clemson.edu
Subject: smoke, 993, and trafic school

Hello all,
  Well to say the least me and my 914 Kelli had a rather interesting RWe
weekend down in FL. I had to go down to Jacksonville from Charleston
SC to attend traffic school. FL has a cool deal that if you got to
traffic school they forget about the ticket. Considering I belong
to an elite group that get to swim in that high risk pool I didn't
need another ticket on my record. On the rather lame drive down I
get to pass by a rather nice 993. Of course I saw the guy laugh as
I drove by in my rather beat-up, but well loved, 914 which shows
the battle scars of a high risk owner. On the way home some rather
scarry/lucky things happened. When Kelli travels for over an hour at
higher speeds, like 80 or so, she really starts to smoke like a big
dog when A) the gas is bliped but not at a steady position. B) when
slowing down and the engine is under compression. I can hear what
sounds to me like a heavy valve click when the car is under load.
About an hour outside of JAX some little pontiac (the F car) passed
me and of couse I had to follow the faster car. Well he kept going
faster and faster the next thing I know is that he is leaveing me.
I looked down and I was stuck at 100. (yes I know I am crazy) I
know that Kelli can go faster than that. Then with my foot still on
the floor, she started to slow down. 95...90...85...80 at this point
I was waiting to feel a fly wheel hit me in the back. All I could
think was "she's going to blow captain". Well I slowed her down to 60
and half gassed her back up. She was ok after that. A little later
two cars passed at about 90 and I inclined to jump in the line. After
a mile or so I thought I better just take it easy on the way home
just to make sure I made it home. About two more miles up the road
ol' mister blue lights pulled onto the road on pulled those two other
guys off the road. After a little word of thanks for keeping
me out of that little mess I moved on to the rest I-95 north.
me out of that little mess I moved on to the rest of I-95 north
Todd Marshall
74' 914 1.8 (Kelli)
Marshal@Clemson.Clemson.Edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, Oct 11, 1994 10:44 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Center Differentials

Eliot Lim  writes:
 
> this is pretty interesting.  the latest carrera 4 now has AWD that is
> barely more sophisticated than those found on the vanagon syncro,
> various ford and chevy minivans, the lamborghini diablo VT..
 
> in short, it is a part time, automatically engaging 4wd system.  the press
> has almost been silent in pointing this out.  porsche, during the days of
> the 959 and original carrera 4 have been strongly opposed to using any
> form of viscous coupling (as is audi till this day) because "they cannot
> be controlled" and they hamper ABS operation. 
 
> i have always considered the use of a viscous coupling to be a less
> elegant implementation 
[snip]
> there are also a few understeer inducing doo-dads thrown in when the
> accelerometers detect a situation where the tail is about to swing..
> this is the only thing it has over the generic VC auto engaging 4wd
> implementation.

Hi Eliot,

I think you miss the point.  Porsche had an elaborate, computer-controlled,
all mechanical AWD on the original C-4, in which it was all but impossible
in induce oversteer. Porsche replaced it with the new system for two
reasons. The new system is half the weight of the old one, and the new
system allows more driver controll (it allows the driver to induce
oversteer).

Many folks who *don't* own 911s find the prospect of its propensity to
"hang the tail" out in the breeze, something to be feared.

911 pilots, OTOH, generally *love* oversteer, and consider the
significantly higher level of driver's expertise required to master the
challange of taming the 911, a significant part of its charm.  BMW may
claims it produces "the Ultimate drivING machine,"  911 owners know who
produces the ultimate *DriveR's* machine.  And, FWIW, who would argue that,
in a pure sports car like the 911, a much lighter and simpler system is
*Less* elegant...?

OK, I'll go quietly now...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 21:10:06 EDT
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Brittle Plastic 914 fuel lines?

No, these lines do not become brittle with age......mine are 22 years old
and, though I've kept after them, are as good as new.  They mat yellow a tad,
but that's from the heat in the engine compartment (probably).  Don't worry
about them, because the fuel pressure isn't enough to blow them.  However,
I've made it a habit (honestly!) to replace all of the rubber fuel lines in
my car every 4 years.  These really do rot (German rubber sucks) and have led
to the early demise of many 914's due to fire over the years.  Yes to plastic
 - no to rubber more than 3 years old.
Pat Garvey

> up to you. You don't join - you miss out on meeting really great people.

I belong to PCA and agree with the sentiments you expressed above, but the
mysterious MQL makes a valid observation.

Years ago (1963-65) when I was an Army swine living in the hallowed Air
Farce Headquarters city of Wiesbaden, there was a large contingent of
Porsche clubbers (and I'm *pretty* sure it was a branch of PCA) in my BOQ,
the American (OPEN) Arms Hotel.  They were, to a man (and woman), a bunch
of insufferably obnoxious boors, manifesting exactly the attitude expressed
by the mysterious MQL.

There's nothing wrong with "clubiness" in the closed environs of a club.
However, the same "Clubiness" manifested in the genreal public, among folks
not privy to the club, is usually translated by the outsiders as
snobbishness.

I've been delighted find the Porschephiles refreshingly free from this
crap, but I have found the attitude wide-spread; with the unfortunate
result that all Porsche owners get tarred with that brush.  It's no joke,
and all of us need to be aware of the fact that the perception is both
widespread and, to an unfortunate degree, well deserved.





Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 22:16:30 -0400
From: ulrich@canberra.whoi.edu (Nathan Ulrich)
Subject: Re: Turbo Charging a 944 S2 

Building a 3.0 liter, 16-valve, turbocharged engine based on the 944S2 or  
968 engine is theoretically possible.  However,the 16-valve heads are  
marginal in 325 hp normally-aspirated race engines, and would almost  
certainly quickly fail under the extreme combustion pressures of a  
turbocharged engine.

Nathan
ulrich@canberra.whoi.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 18:50:00 +0800
From: tilden@maunakea9.Data-IO.com (John Tilden)
Subject: Re: Brittle Plastic 914 fuel lines?

Pat Garvey Writes:

>No, these lines do not become brittle with age......mine are 22 years old
> and, though I've kept after them, are as good as new.  They mat yellow a tad,
> but that's from the heat in the engine compartment (probably).  Don't worry
> about them, because the fuel pressure isn't enough to blow them.  However,
> I've made it a habit (honestly!) to replace all of the rubber fuel lines in
> my car every 4 years.  These really do rot (German rubber sucks) and have led
> to the early demise of many 914's due to fire over the years.  Yes to plastic
> - no to rubber more than 3 years old.
> Pat Garvey

	If you are speaking of the plastic fuel lines in the engine 
	compartment, supply and return, I found them to get brittle,
	and replaced mine, just a few years after new!
	I had replaced an injector, 'cause the attached rubber line
	ruptured just as I turned off engine upon returning from a
	long weekend trip, (no fire!) in messing around I decided to
	investigate the other lines, and upon tightening a hose clamp
	shattered the plastic supply line!
	I promptly replaced both the supply and return with copper tubing.
	There were lots of engine fires in the early days, after they're
	burnt it's hard to decide which was the culprit that failed!

John Tilden
Data I/O Corp.

 

------------------------------

Date: 11 Oct 94 22:29:39 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: 928 Ventilation

Wayne Fowke writes about his '85 928 whose ventilator fan runs only when the
lower slider is set to defrost, or when set to low. (As John White points out,
at least on the American cars, the fan is never off unless the slider is all the
way to the left.  The rotary switch selects one of four non-zero fan speeds.)  I
also agree with John's diagnosis: given the description it almost *has* to be
the rotary switch or wiring/plug thereto.

I haven't had this particular problem with my '86 928, but I have removed,
disassembled and tested the control switch.  It's suprisingly easy (by 928
standards), and is thoroughly covered in the manual (removal Vol IV p. 87-44).
Basically, you pry/pull the central vent straight out, remove an "H" shaped
plastic bezel from around the switch with gentle prying starting at the top, and
remove the switch by removing a four philips-head screws at all four corners.
The switch plugs into two harnesses, one for the blower and one for the "flaps".

The shop manual provides a step-by-step procedure for diagnosing the whole
switch/slider assembly (p. 87-105:87-114).  In addition, the switch assembly
itself can be disassembled by careful unscrewing and prying, but that's not
covered in the manual.

It really helps to have a shop manual.  Wayne: have you considered ordering one
direct from a Porsche parts supplier in the US?  They're readily available for
about US$270-300.

If you can't solve the problem that way, e-mail me your address and I'll send
you some copies of the relevant pages.

Alan Watkins ('86 928S)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 11:09:58 -0500
From: porschephiles-request@tta.com


------------------------------

Date: 12 Oct 1994 01:52:20 GMT
From: pjb@cco.caltech.edu (Paul J. Brewer)
Subject: Metal Shavings = Dying Autotranny BS | !BS ??

Took the 924S ('87, 28000 miles) to Black Forest Independent Porsche
service here in Atlanta for some minor stuff, and also asked thenm 
to look at the rear end.

The rear end has been leaking diff. fluid (black, thick oil). RUSNAK 
Porsche in CA had told me to (i) check the level every few months
and (ii) that to reseal it was $500 in labor, but wasn't really 
necessary.

Anyway, Black Forest claimed the following:

(i) There are metal shavings in the fluid (at? i think).
    There are also signs of beginning intermix btwn diff and at.
(ii) its going to need a new transmission soon
(iii) they cost $3K installed. for a new one from Porsche installed by them.
(iv) this won't really fix it because the audi transmission is not
up to the power the engine puts out. The new one might not last 30K either.

[ theyalso looked at the sunroof. they told me it needed gears and 
would cost $200 to fix, but thought I might not want them too given 
the rear end. they were right. ]  

Now, if its true then I should sell the car before it gets too bad to sell.

If its not true I should take my service business elsewhere.

A friend told me of a sting he saw on TV. A tow truck would tell motor home
tourists that they were smoking and pull them over. An inspection would reveal
metal shavings in the transmission , which were actually planted there. The
local garage could fix it for about $1500-2000, for which they changed the fluid
and cleaned the unit so that it looked brand new (the unit was not replaced).
In addition this friend seemed to believe that metal shavings were normal
in a auto. transmission and thats why you changed the fluid and strainer.

First, I need to ascertain the seriousness of the situation. Since the car
seems to drive ok, I am not that concerned. Since I don't  drive it to 
work, its not such a big deal. The problem is that I am incessantly 
curious about what is going on.

Paul Brewer
pjb@cco.caltech.edu


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 20:20:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: BMW Shop Problems (Conclusion?)

Hi,

	Well, we had the meeting today with the shop owners about the problem
with the crappy repair work on her 530i.

	The first thing we did was take the car to Neillo BMW here in Sacramento
and have them do an eval of the car.  They said the car definitely 
does _not_ have head problems, but was mal-adjusted.  The timing was way off,
and it was way too lean.  The only thing set right was the dwell, and guess
who did that? :)

	So, we all sat down in the shop's back room, and first off let me say it
was a little distracting, with 911 engines all over the place in varying
states of dismemberment and all kinds 911 parts scattered everywhere!
	
	So we're sitting there staring at each other, so I start with a 
description of the problem and what we wanted done about it, Amy adds her
dissatisfaction with being left out of the loop even though its her car,
and she was paying for the repairs.  They apologized profusely for this!

	We played good cop/bad cop.  I got to be the bad cop!  My position was
that we didn't want to pay anything!  She was willing to work with them.
Their first tactic was to make me look like an idiot my throwing a heap
of technical-speak my way, which I completely and effectively deflected
with firm, well informed responses and a couple of diagrams on some 
scrap paper.

	The mechanic tried to work the customer service angle, with "I'm 
willing to do whatever it takes to get your car running the way you want"  
to which I countered "you already had three tries!"  He then tried the
philsophical angle that "well, thats purely hindsight"  "Well, so is this
entire discussion..." counters I.

	The shop manager tried the humanistic 'you're being a butt-hole' angle
by saying "You know, I've known you for several years, and I've never seen
this side of you.  You've never acted like this - this isn't the Thom I
know"  To which I replied "Jim, we could be the greatest buddies, but 
when it comes down to the fine print, I'm a _consumer_"  I owe somebody
on the Porsche list for that line!

	So we argued.  Amy gave a very clear dissertation on what she thought
the problem was and how she was mad about being left on the loop _and_
being told 3 times the car ran great when it didn't.                

	Amy was actually the deal maker here.  She told them that she was willing 
to pay for the parts, but none of the labor.  I played bad cop and argued 
that we shouldn't even pay for the parts, since they were replacing
stuff in a clueless grasp at fixing the car!   

	She agreed that: she will pay for the parts at cost.  They will pay for
any repairs that the dealer says need to be made.  She will pay for none of
the labor incurred during the previous work (close to 20 hours @ $55).  To
sweeten the deal, they _gave_ her a new battery for the car!  Done deal!

	Amy would like to extend a big thanks to all who helped during this
ordeal.  We would probably not fared as well without your help!

Thom & Amy
- -- 
>> I used to have a handle on life, then it broke.

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 01:47:09 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Re: H&R vs. Eibach springs

> BTW, I heard from Performance Products that the main difference was that the 
> Eibach's were fixed rate spring vs. the progressive rate springs for the H&R. 
>  Maybe that's true for all Eibach springs.

Most of us that have raced on progressive springs think they're evil. The
change in transfer depending on how loaded the suspension is at *that*
point in time is a killer. 

*HOWEVER*, it is good for street use -- in fact, I regularly recommend
the Troutman 165 lb progressive springs for street/light autox use on 
stock 914s. Just don't try to get cute with them on the track or you'll
(maybe) live to regret it.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 11:54:10 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: 914 Recalls

This talk about brittle fuel lines and Pat's comment about 914 battery tray
recalls reminds me of something I found out about in 1990, when I bought my
first 914.

There *WAS* a recall on 914 fuel lines. These are the lines inside the
engine compartment, and it is (was in '90) *STILL IN EFFECT* No kidding.
When I took my car in, they found that my lines had already been corrected,
so I never went all the way through the recall, but the dealer said is was
still in effect, even after fifteen years.

Regarding the Battery Tray: I don't think Porsche ever fixed the actual
tray. What they would do is install a rubber cover over the top of the
battery so that water could not wash over it and down onto the tray and
suspension console. I don't know if that recall is still active.

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 94 12:12:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>

     o   The brake pad wear indicator comes on erratically.

You probably need to replace one or more of the ear indicators.

     o   Yesterday I noticed a whining sound from the back of the car
         just after starting the engine.

Fuel pump.  Why it seems noisy intermittently is a good question.  Make sure
it's secured properly.

     o   The radio (Blaupunkt tuskan) reception is not very good. The
         sound fades and there is some static even with the antenna
         out.

Remember, in Jeopardy all answers must be phrased in the form of a
question.

Kevin Gross

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 07:52:33 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Weber carb. questions

On rebuilding Webbers:

If you have leaky carbs, or the accel pump is not working, or the float
bowl valve are not operating, rebulding webbers is not difficult.  Much
easire than an american-type carb.

If you have loose throttle shafts, leaky plates, it's a whole differnet
matter.  The PMO kit is complete but compes with almost no
instruction.  You'll neet to learn how to set up the idle adjusters.

On jetting Webbers: good luck!  If you have a jet box handy, you can
find a nice place to do accelleration runs and dial them in.  That's
what I did.  As for getting anyone to tell you certain jets are good
for a certain car, hopefully someone will be able to assist.


Regarding the "torque boosters" the UniSyn which PMO sells fits in the velocity stack over this without fussing.

Here's a question for anyone on the net:

	What's the difference between a 40 and a 46MM webber?
	(Be specific - where EXACTLY does the differnce lie?)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 12:13:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Weber carb. questions



On Mon, 10 Oct 1994 NeilK356@aol.com wrote:

> 1 Perf. Products sells two books on Weber carbs, one from Haynes and another
> from HPBooks.  Which is the better book? Or is their another one  that
> someone would recommend? 
The Haynes book is pretty good. Don't know about the other.

> > 2. Besides a synchrometer and a float level are there any other tools that I
> should buy? 
No.


> 3.  I am sure that the books will explain it, but how do I use a synchrometer
> when I have tubes (they look like torque boosters as seen in the Automotion
> cat.) sticking out of the velocity stacks. Can they be pulled out and do they
> really help?
Not sure. I assume you have the so-called boost venturis (a misnomer). 
The Haynes illustrations show those only on the 46IDA's. You sure can't 
take them out! That's where all but the idle fuel comes from.

> 
> 4. What size jets should I use. I have a 73 911S and currently have..
I suggest you call PMO (phone number in Pano). They are knowledgable and 
helpful (a little boastful too, but what the heck)

> 
> 5. Lastly, how difficult is it to rebuild webers. I have seen kits advertised
> in Pano and was wondering if it was a job for pros or any mechanically
> inclined person.
Go for it, it's not as hard as it might seem.
Dave.

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 09:50:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 911 option code question

> 
> Mike,
> 
> Do you know what C02, P65, 018 stand for?  These are listed as options on my
> car.  I also have the 220 and have no idea how different this is from 221.
> The car also has an alarm system, but not listed as option.
> Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu
> 
> 
> 

Thak -

The P65 stands for "with sunroof" on the 911 Turbo's and the 018 stands 
for "steering wheel with raised hub" on all models.  Haven't been able to 
fund out what the "C02" stand for though.  I think it has something to do 
with the general configuration of the car for different areas(?), but 
don't hold me to it.  My 944 has a "C03" and I think I was told it had to 
do with the California type car.  I will check further.

Mike

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 12:05:16 +0000

Hi Porschephiles,

Sorry to hit the list with a mainly out-of-band message,
there is some Porsche content however, all replies in 
EMAIL please!!!

My gf works for a large US management consultancy. They have
a big operation in Cleveland, Ohio. Right now she is based in 
the UK, but now has the possibility of working on a project
out of Cleveland for a prolonged period, probably more than
one year. The upside of this is that she will be able to
pick up a 911 at incredible $US bargain basement prices for
the time she is out there. What we want to know is, what is the
downside?

Please feel free to mail me your impressions on Living in Cleveland,
Ohio, if indeed such a thing is possible. I have this feeling
that Cleveland, Ohio, is one of the less desirable places
to live in the USA, and is the butt of jokes similar to
the ones about Essex and it's inhabitants in the UK. Please
can someone break out the fact from the fiction for me?

Sorry for the mostly out-of-band nature of this post.

Regards

Ben "Geographically Challenged" Evans

Date: 11 Oct 1994 10:36:04 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- hard starting 2.7

                       Subject:                               Time:10:24 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: hard starting 2.7                  Date:10/11/94
mark and greg write:


>>1976 911-S  2.7L  with K-jetronic FI
>>My car is very very hard to start - 15-20 seconds of cranking -

snip

>Greg,
>
>Sounds like the warm up regulator. These units act like a choke. They
>enrich the fuel mixture (by altering the fuel system pressure) over the
>first ~2 minutes of operation. Their primary failure mode is to get stuck
>in one position and stop making any adjustment. I used a fuel injection
>pressure tester to check for this	type of failure; bought one a number of
>years ago from	a Saab dealer (there must be much better sources now) and
>have found it indespensible.	They can also help you set the fuel system
>pressure (via shims)	and help in diagnosing other problems, too.

Yeah, the fuel pressure gauge is great!

>The cold start valve only operates for a few seconds in very cold weather,
>so it is not likely to be the cause. Also, an air leak major enough to
>prevent starting the car will also keep it from idling when it is warm; so
>this is also not likely.

However, these symptoms can also occur with a working WUR and a bad cold 
start valve.  By the way, the cold start valve is operational if the temp
goes 
below 60 deg F, not exactly "very cold weather." 

If the cold start valve injector is worn, it will dribble fuel instead of 
spraying it and will make the car hard to start.

You have to remove it to check; the spray pattern should be like any other 
fuel injector.

The bad news is that (if a '76 is like an '80) the cold start valve is
*really*
a pain to get to: it's behind (forward of in car coords) the throttle body.



- --Soren

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 94 06:56:28 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Power Enhancments

> I have a lowly 83 944 that has seen much abuse and soldiered on without too 
> much difficulty.  What I was wondering, has any body out there installed an
> aftermarket Motronic CPU/Chip in an normally aspirated-humble 8 valve 944?
> Any experience with re-profiled cams or headers?
> 
Hi, Murray...

Well, don't feel too bad.  My 83 944 is what got me started in all of this
(PCA, track events, business...) a few years back.  Your 83 is a couple of
hundred pounds lighter than a lot of 944s, including turbos.

This makes it a better handling car and easier on the brakes and suspension,
etc.

I do currently have an Autothority Chip installed in my 83 944.  I do feel a
noticeable difference in low end torque (I find myself spinning the tires on
hard acceleration in low grip situations more that previously).  The overall 
power increase might be as much as 5 bhp.

That may not sound like much, but every little bit helps.

The best part of the chip is the ability to rev the engine a bit higher.  At
Lime Rock Park, this means that I can take a couple of corners in 3rd gear
with a bit more power available, instead of 4th, because I can complete the
corner without hitting the redline.

So, bottom line, I think that the chip is worth probably $200 in additional 
performance.  I don't think I would spend $495 for that much improvement, but
$200, yeah, OK...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 08:29:36 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Ventilation

Yeah, I suspected that that little fan in my car was dead, just haven't
gotten around to burrowing in there to get at it. Guess I had better do
it. Do you have any wisdom about cleaning it up once I have it out (since
I usually do something wrong the first time around, any gotcha's that
you found)?  

I don't have buzzing relays, but I do have a fan that from time to time
turns itself to high for no more than five seconds, then returns to the
speed the knob is set at - as if the defroster were turned on briefly.

My upshift indicator, when it works at all, seems to do what it's
supposed to - comes on around 1800-2000 rpm at light throttle load,
goes off when you get off the throttle entirely (microswitch) or when
you get on it harder (load). Sometimes it just stays out, though, which
makes me a little nervous since it is driven by a function of the same
variables which control the fuel injection. In fact, it is driven by an
output from the same brain, so it is conceivable that a malfunctioning
light is a symptom of a malfunctioning injection control system. Overall,
though, it serves much more as an irritant than as an aid - maybe a bit
of black tape would solve the problem.

Gee, maybe there is some truth to the warnings people have given that
928's are subject to electrical gremlins.

 -John White-
>

>>My '83 didn't either until I took it apart and cleaned it. The dash mounted
>>temperature sensor has a duct running a couple of inches to a canister
>>containing a small 12 Vdc fan, about an inch in diameter. This fan keeps
>>cabin air moving across the thermister, else it bake in the sun.
>>
>>A relay in the ventilation controls used to buzzing, intermitantly. Traced 
>>the problem to a bad ground. Couldn't believe Porsche grounded half of
>>the ventilation controls thru the cigarette lighter's ground.
>>
>>Now if I can figure out why the upshift indicator is equally random.
>>Maybe the car is just high spirited and wants to GO! when I'm stopped
>>in traffic? Yet it is hard to upshift from 5th.
>>
>>David Kelly, N4HHE
>>

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 01:43:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Futzing with CIS

> Where's the best place to get started? I already have the factory manuals,
> but are there any Bosch CIS specific books applicable to my car? Any old
> articles in Pano or Excellence I should find? What kind of investment
> in tools and gauges am I looking at? Should I even try?

Get the Probst book -- "Bosch Fuel Injectino & Engine Mangement" published
by Robert Bently Books. There's also a moderately decent (notice at no point 
did I say "good") book available from Automotion called "Troubleshooting CIS 
Systems" or some such. The Probst book is The Bible on this stuff, next to 
the factory manuals. The other book is not bad as a mid-tech overview with 
some diagnostic proceedures. Given my background when I waded into CIS, 
and my CIS background when I started fooling with the 911 version, it
was mostly a waste.

You'll need the special adjustment tools, readily available in the
aftermarket. And you'll need a special set of pressure gauge/hoses/fittings/
valve to do most of the tests. Again, Automotion has them,but you can
get the "real" set from Baum Tool for about the same money. Total in
tools here is under $200.

Now, to *REALLY* do things right, you also need access to a chassis
dyno, a engine analyzer, and an exhaust gas and temp analyzer. But
you're probably a ways off from that yet...

As to "should you try", I dunno -- for normal CIS service, the main
issue is figuring out what croaked and replacing it. That's easy to
do without the special tools for the most part. CIS is a nightmare to
performance tune without a huge amount of experience and most of the
things in the "really do things right" paragraph. IF that's your intent,
then no, find someone that knows their stuff and use them. If you're just
looking to better understand things and maybe do a little light repair,
then get the Probst book and consider the gauges and tools later.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 20:55:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Brittle Plastic 914 fuel lines?

> No, these lines do not become brittle with age......mine are 22 years old
> and, though I've kept after them, are as good as new.  They mat yellow a tad,
> but that's from the heat in the engine compartment (probably).  Don't worry
> about them, because the fuel pressure isn't enough to blow them.  However,
> I've made it a habit (honestly!) to replace all of the rubber fuel lines in
> my car every 4 years.  These really do rot (German rubber sucks) and have led
> to the early demise of many 914's due to fire over the years.  Yes to plastic
> - no to rubber more than 3 years old.

Beg to differ. I got to sit out a weekend of time trials and other assorted
fun at Cabaniss Field (ever notice the tendency to want to make that
be "Cannabis Field"? Just wondered...) due to an exploded plastic line in
my 914 2.0 ITA  racer. Since the optional gasoline bath is not an
approved safety item, I decided to fix it right as long as I was at it.
Not to worry, nothing that you can't fix with $200 worth of Aeroquip...

Mind that rear firewall when you go to install bulkhead fittings, though --
it's a 3" thick double wall. Gotta cut a big hole on the inboard side
to let you mount the fittings on the rear wall.  Behind the passenger
seat is the indicated location.

The setup is now Wurth-7-and-9mm-rubber lines to a 3/8" to -06 fitting
for the 9mm and a -04 to -06 fitting for the 7mm line, with -06 female
bulkhead unions fore and aft, and a pile of -06 AQP running through the
passenger compartment. Nice an tidy, all tied down with FAA approved
techniques to prevent hose chafing and everything.. Should never need
to undo the interior piece, and the engine and tank side use regular 
press-on fittings with good German hose clamps...

I *DO* second the motion that you should replace the rubber lines frequently.
Every couple of years or so, less if the car lives outside.

Stan

Porschephiles #903                         Fri Oct 14 02:00:04 CDT 1994
Date: 12 Oct 94 15:48:43 EDT
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Stupid question

When I drive any manual tranny car, including my 951, and I step on the gas 
when the car is in a higher gear (5th?) and turning low revs (1000rpm?) the 
car shudders and shakes until the revs get higher. I believe that this is 
called lugging, and is particularly noticeable in my other non P-car with a 
lightweight flywheel. Why does this happen and why is it bad? What is the 
solution? aside from downshifting. I believe that my commuting habits of 
holding coffee with one hand, and using the other hand to steer/shift don't 
help. Unfortunately commuting from where I live to where I work entails a 
massive amount of shifting.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 94 23:17:42 EDT
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Winders' nitrogen, sorry again

Scott Winders winders@porsche.support.apple.com fired back :

- -------------------------------------------------------------------------
You obviously did not read any of the information I posted. Water boils
at 212F at sea level. The "steam" you mention is not water turning into
a gas; it is another phenomina that I will not get into here. Under
pressure, waters vapor point is even higher than 212F. Water does not
gardually turn into vapor as it is heated as you sumize. ******

Sure, water does get into compressors. The point was that any minute
amount of water that gets into your tire via a compressed air tank is
not going to be a concern.

The point is that nitrogen does not buy you a thing!!!
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- ----

Well, I'm a scientist/engineer and I checked my old chemistry textbook. Old
Dr. Wunderlich at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute must have been pretty good
because I remember exactly what he taught us (he had a GREAT German accent,
and looked like he should be wearing a white jacket in the Porsche lab
hunched over a smoking 356 4-cam engine).

Le Chatelier's principle about equalibrium says that if heat is added to a
system (the tire), the temperature would rise (duh). This would cause a
change in equalibrium which in turn ... would cause more liquid to evaporate,
causing the vapor pressure to increase. 
I quote the textbook : "after the addition of heat the new state of
equilibrium corresponds to increased vapor pressure and temperature. This
prediction (based on Le Ch.) is consistent with the OBSERVED FACT that the
vapor pressure of a liquid increases as the temperature increases". QED.

You hung yourself when you said water does not gradually turn to vapor as it
is heated - this is exactly what happens. Sorry to bore everyone about this
trivia, as it probably doesn't make more than a PSI or two difference, but
being a scientist it kills me to see these errors undisputed. I don't plan on
using nitrogen unless it is commonly available, in which case I surely would
use it.

Non-Dr. Mike Piera  '72 911S, '83 RPI graduate (and president of Rensselaer
Sports Car Association for most of my years there).


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 94 22:05:59 EDT
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Gas octane for 72 911 S


Jeff Shorey, js@ee.duke.edu, asked :

__________________________________________________
Do you have problems running the 87 octane?  That's what I run in mine with
no
pinging.  If you convert the specified 91 RON into our gas (R/M?) you get
something less than 87.  See Bruce Anderson's book.
__________________________________________________

I re-read Bruce's book. Yes, the 87 octane gas (R+M)/2 meets the European
91 RON octane rating. But I wouldn't use it in any 6 cylinder Porsche engine
if I had the chance to buy Premium unleaded. It's false economy. Our older
engines have deposits which raise the octane requirements. Also our fuel 
systems are difficult to keep exactly correct, they can run lean. You may
think your car is not pinging (knocking) but 911 engines knock at high RPM,
and it is very hard to hear it due to the other noises occuring at those
speeds. The higher octane gas has no disadvantages, and is cheap compared
to anything else you need for a 911.

I always use 93 or 94 octane gas (readily available in the northeast), and
try to mix in some leaded racing gas whenever I can. The lead is nice to the
valve seats, but not really needed. Last month I ran at Lime Rock and
couldn't
get any racing gas before my first run group. I was running on Texaco 93 
octane. The car ran bad at high RPM, I had better power by short-shifting (in
an S!). I put in 50% CAM2 leaded (105 octane?) for the second run group and 
it ran much better. Maybe I had a bad tank of Texaco? I usually run Mobil 93
octane and it usually works fine.

I try to use Texaco regular in my street cars because it has detergents
(other brands of gasoline seem to require premium before they give you
the good additives?). I also like to add Chevron Techron to my gas tank
before an oil change, to remove deposits.

Also, NEVER use gas that has any alcohol as an additive. The govt is trying
to push it down our filler caps but WE MUST RESIST! It really SUCKS
basically.

Any other comments are appreciated, these are just my real-life observations
with a real Porsche.

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa spewing lead into the environment whenever possible



------------------------------

Date: 12 Oct 94 16:33:10 EDT
From: Richard Grayson <76226.3526@compuserve.com>
Subject: PCA membership

Yep, the thinking behind the mandatory Porsche ownership escapes me.
If you're thinking about owning, you should read as much as you can about
the marque before you purchase. Pano has a lot of good info, and
the classified ads can help you find out what you can afford.

Now of course I've NEVER done this, but if you just need a VIN number
pick up a copy of Excellence magazine. (Another indispensable mag.)
Flick to the back. Notice all the ads, many with VIN numbers. Change the
last digit of a posted VIN number. Voila! Welcome to the club.

When you really buy your Porsche, just send a letter to PCA with the new
info.

I can't see any harm to this, since PCA will not exclude you if you have a
duplicate VIN. Of course if someone feels otherwise, I'll hear soon....

Richard Grayson
76226.3526@compuserve.com



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 14:37:55 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Suspension Console Rot

> On this subject, I've heard that there is a recall still in effect
> for the 914 battery tray replacement.  It's apparently because
> the batteries fall on the engine and start fires.
> 
> Any word on this?  Should we all be running all our old 914s by
> the dealer for a check?

While you *CAN* take youre car by a dealer and request a VIN check
to see if it ever had the recall fix, please be aware that the "fix"
is a huge ugly "hat" for the battery, which keeps water from hitting
the battery, mixing with acid, and running onto the fuel lines.

That, by the way, was the recall issue. Battery acid running onto
the fuel lines (directly under the battery, natch) and eroding it
to the point of leakage at which point it sprays onto the engine
causing a fire.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 16:58:57 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: '95 PCA Race Schedule (Tentative)

Someone faxed this to me today.

1995 PCA Club Racing, tentative schedule

JANUARY:        None
FEBRUARY:       Sebring (10-11)
MARCH:          Corpus Christie (TBA)
APRIL:          Road Atlanta (8-9), Las Vegas (15-16)
MAY:            Lime Rock (5-6), Hallet (20-21)
JUNE:           Second Creek (10-11), Summit Point (23-24)
JULY:           Lime Rock (3-4), Brainerd (TBA)
AUGUST:         Portland (5-6 or 12-13), Pocono (19-20)
SEPTEMBER:      Road America (1-3)
OCTOBER:        Heartland Park (7-8)
NOVEMBER:       Phoenix (TBA)
DECEMBER:       None

Note the Portland race.  It will be held in conjunction with the Parade and
hosted by my region (Intermountain).

See ya there?

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera

Date: 12 Oct 94 16:33:05 EDT
From: Richard Grayson <76226.3526@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 rough idle


Oh sages of the net, I need some assistance. My 1985 911 Carrera has lately
acquired a rough idle during startup. It stumbles at about 600 rpm for about
15 seconds, and over the next 15 seconds ramps up to 1000 rpm before
leveling off at a proper 800 rpm.

It seems to "need" this thirty second "no throttle" warmup. If I give it
a little throttle to stop the stumble, it will still go through its warmup
"stumble cycle" when I let it idle.

It has a new fuel filter and air filter. Plugs have only 5K miles. I checked
the idle air regulator as prescribed in the manual, and it seems ok.
(Test was to put +12V on center terminal, ground outside left and then right
terminal. Valve toggled quickly from one side to the other when I did this.)

Is this possibly a fuel pressure problem? The engine fires right up; just
runs rough initially. Only happens when it is cold. Perhaps it isn't holding
pressure? If so, why does it still fire up right away?

Thanks in advance!

P.S. Stan - Is anyone else getting "clipped" digests? This morning, I only got
about a quarter of the articles listed in the table of contents.

Richard Grayson
76226.3526@compuserve.com

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 94 11:34:52 cdt
From: Kyle Ehler <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.NCR.COM>
Subject: Re: 914 trunk hinge rework. (bolt zerk mod)



To: pz@caltech.edu

 cc:Mail SMTPLINK 2.0 Undeliverable Message

  John, this bounced numerous times so I am posting it to pfiles..

Subject: Re[2]: 914 hinge rework. (bolt zerk mod)


  I was wondering if anyone would pick up on this..
  You know, I have not done this and would like to have them for
my pair of 14's too.  I will check into who has these already made
up (I do not really have time to make my own right now).
  Seem to remember reading about these in Dennis Deeds
914 Owners Association publication, 'Mid-Engine Views'.  I let my
subscription run out over a year ago..maybe should re-start eh?

  Anyway, the mod was pretty simple in principle.  Drill a hole in
the head of the bolt deep enough to reach the center of the bearing
surface of the bolt, and of sufficient diameter to allow a zerk to 
self-thread in.  Then cut a groove about halfway in the bearing area.
The groove does not have to be deep, only enough for grease to migrate.
  Then drill a smaller hole from the groove to intersect with the
center gallery, your choice of going all the way through from one
side to the other, or just enough to intersect.  Not exactly rocket
science..
  A person could do it with a portable drill and a vice.
  To cut the groove, chuck the bolt into the drill and clamp
a half-moon file in the vice and carefully hog the groove using the 
sharp edge of the file.  A drill press would make life simpler.
  
  Granted, a little precision at the eyeball level, but not impossible.

  The bolts themselves are around $5 each..just a guess at
how much the mod'd bolt would be.. $10?
  btw, these bolts are used on the front and rear trunk lids (914).
  Anyone know if these are used on any other porsches?

  Everyone; go out right now and lube your hinges...=:)

  
  Thanks for the inquiry.
  -kyle

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 94 15:24:08 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Gauge Readings in 924,944


Due to the design of the wiring harness and the early-style modular
fuse panel. there can be some significant variences in the indicated
readings when the headlights or air conditioning are used.

The voltage drop is due to the gauge wire used for power distribution, 
the inherent voltage drop from the fuse panel and the resistance in the 
ground return (again form the wire gauge and connector resistance).

Unless you feel the need and are knowledgeable enough to do a rewire
of the instrument circuit, leave it alone. A voltage/current regulator 
would help a little, however, this requires more circuitry to the
gauges.

The reason for the occurance is thus: there are numerous connections
in the modular fuse panel, each connection has some resistance. The
lights and air conditioning relays are supplied by the same switched 
power circuit the gauges and accesssories are. There is only so much
current available to run everything. Each gauge is electric with a long
current path to the sensors. There is voltage drop in this path, then 
the sensors are a resistive units. All depend on current being available 
to operated them in a given range. If another accessory takes some 
current to operate, then the oil pressure gauge (for example) may have
10% less current operating through it to provide a measured value.

A good designer will try to reduce the amount of current required for 
a measurement so as to minimize changes when other accessories are 
operating.

I never worry about it, I know what the indication is with and without 
the power hungry accessories operating. 

A few parties have added extra grounding between the chassis and engine,
this isn't much help. A cleaning of the existing paths is usually enough,
it is *VERY* important to ensure that the battery leads are free if
oxidation and corrosion. Clean them first, ESPECIALLY the ground strap
to the body and any straps from the engine to ground. I use either a
battery post protector or Permatex Dialectric Tune-up Grease to displace
moisture and dirt at the connections. 

Jim Pasha


911s and 914s have the problem also, though it's less noticeable.

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 18:06:13 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Weber carb. questions

Neil writes:

>1 Perf. Products sells two books on Weber carbs, one from Haynes and another
>from HPBooks.  Which is the better book? Or is their another one  that
>someone would recommend? 

I have the Haynes and HPBooks books, plus some others. The HPBooks is a bit
more theoretical, the Haynes is more a cookbook on how to overhaul a couple
of different Weber models.

I found that a different book, an actual Weber publication, was the most
useful in understanding what all the parts do - it has some very nice
illustrations, and not too many errors in the translation.  I believe I got
it from either Alfa Ricambi or AutoParts International (FIAT and Alfa). 
I'm moving, and I can't get to it for some time (months) to check it for
you. The one I have is specific to the DCOE models, I believe.

Andrew



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Oct 1994 23:30:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Weber carb. questions

> 	What's the difference between a 40 and a 46MM webber?
> 	(Be specific - where EXACTLY does the differnce lie?)

Main bore of the throttle body is 6mm bigger, taking larger venturies,
butterflys, and a few other odd bits (mainly gaskets). Otherwise, they
use the same parts.

The 46mm is too big for reasonable low-end response for a street car.
And near as I can tell, there's *NO* excuse for the 50mm "conversions"
that I'm starting to see... gotta be a penis envy that's misplaced or
something....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 11 Oct 1994 19:17:00 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-n2 in tires

                       Subject:                               Time:5:59 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          re:n2 in tires                         Date:10/11/94
Rick writes:

>>Somehow the nitrogen in tires thread seems to have gotten off track.
>>It is clear that there is little difference (as a gas) between
>>nitrogen and air (even with a little water vapor in the air).  On the
>>other hand compressing air often condenses liquid water out while
>>bottled nitrogen is dry.  Liquid water will affect the pressure in

Actually water vapor will affect the pressure, liquid water will 
affect the ballance  ;-)

>>the tire at high temperatures beyond what is expected from the gas law.
>>At 212 F, it will add 15 psi to the pressure.  Thus, there might be
>>a difference for really hot racing tires that us common street drivers
>>would never see.  Water will also accelerate corrosion on steel rims.

Hot damn!  Must be another M.E. out there!  -sl


Scott writes:

>
>Rick,
>
>First of all, water does not boil at 212 F when subjected to the
>pressures a tire is inflated to. I don't know how much higher the
>boiling point of water is at 20 or 25 psi, but it is significant.

Scott, this is true but irrelevent; the point here is not what the 
boiling point is at 35 psi (about 260 deg. F), but what the vapor 
pressure of water is at 212 deg. F.

>Also, how can you state that the water, when it turns to a gas, will
>add 15 psi?

Rick stated that it would add 15 psi when it turned to a gas at 212 
deg.F, not just when it turned to a gas.  The difference is critical!

Boiling is *defined* as the point where the vapor pressure equals the 
ambient pressure.

Since we know water boils at 212 deg. F, we also know that at that
temp, it has a vapor pressure of 14.7 psi.  [14.696 from the tables]


Properties of saturated water:

Temp (F)      Vapor pressure (psi)

80                .51 
160            4.7
180            7.5 
200          11.5
212          14.7  (14.696)
220          17.2 
240          25.0


>Don't you need to know how much water is in the tire and the
>volume of air in the tire to figure this out? The answer is yes. 

Actually, the answer is sort of.

There has to be sufficent water to saturate (100% humidity) the air.  
Beyond saturation, more water won't generate further pressure increase.
Below saturation, the effect will decrease down to zero at 0% water.

>Don't
>forget that moisture is not a friend to air compressors, so they tend to
>be kept as "dry" as possible.

True.  However I've seen water spewing out of several gas station air 
hoses [in fact I always spray the hose to check for water before 
inflating my tires].  

Generally, compressors are *drained* to remove water.  In addition, most
air lines have water traps in them; I think you can assume that you are 
*not* going to get dry air from a compressor.

>
>Again, the bottom line is that nitrogen offers no significant advantage
>over air as a gas for tires.
>

So says the guys on sci.chem.

However...

The clip you posted discussed a lot of stuff: compressability (not an 
issue), real vs. ideal gas (not an issue at these temps and pressures), 
difference between air and N2 (not an issue).  

It did not discuss the vapor (partial) pressure of water, which is what 
I believe to be the issue.

I mentioned in a previous post that when I first heard that filling 
tires with N2 reduced the pressure rise my reaction was: "nope, wrong,
fairy story; no difference between air and N2 at those temps and pressures."

However, the person relating the story commented that these were 
*measured* results.  Since I believe *the highest truth* is experimental 
evidence, either I discount the information or I have to be able to 
explain it.  Or it'll bug me.

The guys making the measurements were pretty serious motorcycle 
racers; they keep log books, record the changes they make, log comments
about the results of the changes, etc.

In other words I wasn't ready to ignore their data just because it doesn't 
fit my ideas.

So I started thinking what else is there that could explain the results. 
What
I come up with is water vapor.  (this was several years ago.)

My "engineering estimate"  [what they say at work when they want us to 
guess] is that one *could* get twice the pressure rise with wet air that one
would get with dry air.

This assumes a cold temp of 80 F.,  a hot temp of 180 F.,  dry air with no
water,
wet air 100% saturated, uses the above table extraction, and assumes that
T1/T2 = P1/P2.


- --Soren

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 94 06:57:17 EDT
From: klm@othello.macom.com (Kyle L. Martin)
Subject: Re: 944 Power Enhancments



> I have a lowly 83 944 that has seen much abuse and soldiered on without too 
> much difficulty.  What I was wondering, has any body out there installed an
> aftermarket Motronic CPU/Chip in an normally aspirated-humble 8 valve 944?
> Any experience with re-profiled cams or headers?
> 

That may not sound like much, but every little bit helps.

The best part of the chip is the ability to rev the engine a bit higher.  At
Lime Rock Park, this means that I can take a couple of corners in 3rd gear
with a bit more power available, instead of 4th, because I can complete the
corner without hitting the redline.

So, bottom line, I think that the chip is worth probably $200 in additional 
performance.  I don't think I would spend $495 for that much improvement, but
$200, yeah, OK...

So where does one find such a CPU/Chip upgrade for $200.00? I'm stuck with the 
non-socketed '83 944 CPU also!

Kyle M.

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 09:09:40 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Stupid question


Triet Le writes an apparently stupid question, that is more complex
than it might seem!

| When I drive any manual tranny car, including my 951, and I step on the gas 
| when the car is in a higher gear (5th?) and turning low revs (1000rpm?) the 
| car shudders and shakes until the revs get higher. I believe that this is 
| called lugging, and is particularly noticeable in my other non P-car with a 
| lightweight flywheel. Why does this happen and why is it bad?

The answer to your question is that at very low levels of
power and particularly torque, ie engine running at less than 1000
rpm, you must use the transmission in order to reduce the load on the engine!
I think that the car is telling you that it wants you to change gear :-)

I don't consider this a stupid question, in fact it is quite interesting,
I know that it is a characteristic of the reciprocating internal combustion
engine that it produces no power or torque at zero revolutions
(intuitive huh?), and very little power or torque at idle or low revolutions.
Therefore, if you adopt a gear ratio high enough that the force
required to turn the road wheels exceeds the torque the engine is producing, 
it will just stop. I suppose that in the twilight region
where the force required and the torque produced are very close,
then the system gets upset because the engine management is not capable
of regulating the system under load at such low power levels.

It is interesting to contrast the internal combustion engine with an electric
motor, which is quite capable of producing maximum torque at zero RPM and
has a completly flat torque curve. I am sure that
there is someone out there (Hi Theo!) who will be better able to explain
the mechanical principles involved and contrast the power and torque
curves of different types of engine, and correct any defects in my reply.

Regards

Ben

PS: Very disappointing level of response to my questions about
Cleveland, and the desirability of living there. Surely there
must be more people on the list apart from just Stan who have
an opinion! Email me and I will be eternally grateful. 800
USAeans on the list, only one has an opinion on Cleveland,
I am amazed!

################################################################

------------------------------

Date: 13 Oct 94 10:55:32 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Arc welding helmets

Hi, Al.
 
I don't like the electronic helmets. I've used a borrowed one, very briefly,
and several times it undarkened on me while I was making a weld. No thanks.
 
If you have trouble seeing where you're going to start the bead, try working
out in sunlight, maybe with your head in the shadow of something to avoid
extra light inside the helmet from the rear. And don't try to weld right
away, let your eyes dark adapt for 5 to 10 seconds, you'd be amazed at what
you can see through that dark glass.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 08:35:59 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Arc Welding Helmets

I asked a professional welder friend about the electronic-visor arc welding
helmet. His opinion is that it's a good idea, but not quite ready for
prime time. It runs on small batteries, which run down after maybe a
hundred strikes, or after sitting around unused for a month or two; it
is a little fragile for something that is not likely to be handled with
care; and the spatter and crud generated by stick welding will foul the
sensor. He says it's great the first few times you use it, though.

 -John White-

------------------------------

Date:     Thu, 13 Oct 94 12:32:19 EDT
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@pica.army.mil>
Subject:  Dry air in tires (was N2 in tires)

Soren writes:
>
>  [ Steam Tables!  Haven't seen them in YEARS :-) ]
>
>...  However I've seen water spewing out of several gas station air
>hoses...
>
>Generally, compressors are *drained* to remove water.  In addition, most
>air lines have water traps in them; I think you can assume that you are
>*not* going to get dry air from a compressor.    

Unless you know that the water traps are 100%.  

For guarenteed DRY air, any SCUBA diving shop has it.

For us divers, the tire inflator adaptor hooks up to your LP hose; <$20.

For you non-divers, innovation is needed - Scuba is a self-regulated
industry and they're not supposed to sell life support equipment to
untrained individuals.  

You should be able to talk them into putting air into some system thats
obviously not for life support use.  With "el-cheapo" conventional scuba
products, you're talking ~$200 to set up a new system.


 -hugh    

'82 NAUI
'83 ASME
'85 911 Coupe/Iris Blue
'85 Feline/Triple Black
'86 Feline/Orange & White

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 11:17:51 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: 911 OEL- Light

Fellow Porschephiles,

First, I'm happy to say my '74 Carrera is back on the road after putting in a
new clutch. Many thanks to philers Don Munn and Jeff Shorey for making it
possible.

There is a strange problem which has appeared after putting the engine back
in: the OEL- light flashes intermittently after the oil has warmed a bit.
There is plenty of oil and oil pressure is good, so I don't think I really
have an oiling problem. The right cam tower line was replaced when the
engine was out, and the OEL- light sender was removed at that time. But it
was reinstalled and I have double-checked the wiring to the sender. Does
anybody know why this may be happening?

Also, in trying to replace the O-ring for the oil thermostat, I couldn't pull
the thermostat out. It lifts up about half an inch but then won't come out
any further. I've pulled pretty hard and even pried on it a little, but to no
avail. It should just pull right up and out, right? Has anybody had trouble
with this before?

Thanks in advance for any replies,

Dustin Boyette
ldg@mercury.interpath.net
1974 911 Carrera, Signal Green (with a new clutch!)
1978 930, Grand Prix White

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 08:59:26 -0600
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Battery "hat" (Was 914 Suspension Console Rot)

Stan writes about the 914 Battery Tray Recall:
>While you *CAN* take your car by a dealer and request a VIN check
>to see if it ever had the recall fix, please be aware that the "fix"
>is a huge ugly "hat" for the battery, which keeps water from hitting
>the battery, mixing with acid, and running onto the fuel lines.

I've seen advertised, recently, sealed gel-type (?) batteries for automotive
applications that are supposed to eliminate acid leaks such as those common
to 914s.  The gel batteries appear to be about 30-40% more expensive than
conventional batteries.  Are there other disadvantages that make them evil
to use in a p-car?  Anyone have experience with these.  On the surface,
these sound like a better technology for solving the acid problem than the
Porsche's battery hat.

Stph
'73 914 2.0L

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 22:52:15 -35900
From: David Roman <romanda@Shamino.quincy.edu>
Subject: Re: German rubber

> German Rubber Sucks

	Well, as far as the chemistry goes, all "rubber" is not rubber. It 
depends on many factors, one of the most important being the atmosphere 
in which it is synthesized. I guess they just use different vulcanization 
methods in good ole' Germany.

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 09:57:55 -0700
From: William Oldham <oldham@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: 356 ZF Steering box saga


Here is a status report on the 356 ZF steering box repair.  In response to
my request in finding a source for the cam follower (the "peg") I received
several suggestions, but the only actual source apparently is Tanner, 
suggested by Trond.  Trond also supplied the ZF fax number, but they did
not reply to my FAX (and it was in German).  I also got an offer of an
apparently good used box from a PF member at the reasonable price of $125.
Since I have at least one other worn box in my other cars, I did buy this.
But after I obtained the right puller and really got the defective cam
follower out of the box and the bearings off it, I decided to attempt 
resurfacing it.  The nature of the damage was pitting... must have been
some kind of stress corrosion.  There appeared to be no damage to the
worm either.  Luckily I have a "Minimat" which I can  mount on
the cross ways of my lathe.  By chucking a grinding wheel in the Minimat
and the cam follower in the main lathe chuck, I can achieve a pretty
good grinding tool with completely adjustable taper capability.  
Using a dial indicator I could set up exactly parallel to the existing 
taper on the cam follower.  I had to take off a lot of material to get
completely through the pits, I estimate about 0.4 mm off the radius.  This
reduction in diameter necessitated grinding about a mm off the end of the
peg and a similar amount off the shoulder.  The reworked peg looks of
course identical to the original, except the shoulder is 1 mm thinner and
the overall length is about a mm less.  Not knowing the hardening/annealing
history of the material, I decided the safe thing to do is not to attempt to
harden... my reworking the surface would not affect the strength or toughness,
but might have exposed a softer surface, because I may have penetrated whatever
surface treatment was used originally.  I reassembled the box with new bottom
seal and put it back in the car yesterday.  The car (356B coupe) with new
kingpins/linkpins, restored steering box, and (for the first time) correctly
set up toe-in drives like a dream.  Now I want to see if the pin wears
excessively ... keep you posted. 

Bill Oldham

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 10:21:32 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 "pulses"

>>> <WAHRHAFT@sonoma.edu> 09/30/94 12:05am >>>
>I hope someone can help me with a problem that has avoided every attempt at solution.
>    I have a 1976 914 2 liter with about 18,000 on a carefully rebuilt motor. I have had the same problem
>withboth the old motor and with this rebuilt one.
>     The problem is a slight bucking or pulsating or hesitation in the engine.
>It is not a regular rhythm but is repetative.
>It NEVER happens when the accellerator is more than half depressed.
>It only happens when I have a light foot on the gas.
>It tends to happen when accellerating gently in 3 and/or 4th gears.
>It is more pronounced when the motor is cold and in the first couple of miles of the morning the motor
>may also kind of burp a couple of times.  It also happens at constant speeds when I have a light foot on
>the gas.  On level ground at about 50-55 mph in 5th gear, for instance, or when pulling a hill in 4th.
>     We have checked the temp. and pressure sensors, the relays,  the fuel pressure setting, installed a
>new throttle switch,  tried putting another computer on it. Also the alternator and  distributor are new.
>    I'd appreciate any hints aabout what this might be.

Well, I could be way off base on this, but your problem sound very similar to one I just had on my
Toyota Celica.  At constant highway speeds (about 2400 RPM), the engine would buck or stumble
occasionally and increasing the engine load would make it worse.  Depressing the pedal far enough
to cause a downshift (automatic trans) would cause the engine to speed up (>3000 RPM) and it 
would pull great.
Eventually, the problem got worse and the car ran terrible at idle and bucked steadily at speed.
The higher the RPMs, the smoother it was however.
Turns out the problem was a bad fuel injector.  I suspect it was spraying too much fuel as the engine
was running way too rich.  At higher RPMs, the engine could use the extra fuel it was getting and it
smoothed out.  At idle, it was running on three cylinders.

Hope this helps,

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L, 
'87 Celica GT-S, 
(2) '90 rodent hunters



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 07:54:50 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Weber carb. questions


AAAH!  the main bore is not larger, except below the venturi - the same
venturis actually fit though the taper is wrong.  And the gasket sets
are the same!

We discovered (this much to our ammusment) when putting some 38mm
venturis in my 46mms.  Just for jollys we slid in a pair of 32mms from
a set of 40s we ha in hand.

I was relatively amazed to find that a) the venturis fit and b)
velocity stacks are the same on both (which is handy because someone
had put the short - A/C stacks on my 46s)


Other than the size of the bore at the throttle plate, we couldn;t see
any differences externally, though I must admit it was a cursory
examination.

RE the 46s too big - dunno, I think my 3.4 would have a litle trouble
in the above 5000 RPM department running 40s - since it's stronger
everywhere (even 3-4K) with 38mm vs 36mm venturis.  Idle is fine the
car stil has gobbs of turque even below 2K.   I suppose if you were
just goint to use the car to do some shopping ;)  Then again Stan, my
offer's still good - if you can find someone to tune CIS for me I'll be
happy to give it a try!

Steve

- ----- Begin Included Message -----
Cc: NeilK356@aol.com, porschephiles@tta.com

> 	What's the difference between a 40 and a 46MM webber?
> 	(Be specific - where EXACTLY does the differnce lie?)

Main bore of the throttle body is 6mm bigger, taking larger venturies,
butterflys, and a few other odd bits (mainly gaskets). Otherwise, they
use the same parts.

The 46mm is too big for reasonable low-end response for a street car.
And near as I can tell, there's *NO* excuse for the 50mm "conversions"
that I'm starting to see... gotta be a penis envy that's misplaced or
something....

Stan


- ----- End Included Message -----


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 08:59:28 +0500
From: "Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com" <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Winter 911 storage/restoration

Hello,

Well, it is nearly the end of my 911 Targa season in Boston, with frost
beginning to form on the grass when I wake up each day.  No, I will
not drive mine in the winter, I do not have porsches, I have a porsche.
and a winter $100 chevette, and that is life, and I want my porsche to 
be around for a while, galvanized or not, it has never seen snow/salt.

Anyways, I am the guy that earlier this summer, wrecked my valves and
probably other stuff in my 3.0 911 when racing that mustang.  Remember 
that one?  And against the advice of many, I have been drvigin it ever
since, without any problems, aside from a rough idle.  So now, in a few
weeks, I will be putting it to rest in my garage, and contemplating the
best way to go about repairing any damage I caused in the spring.

So I think I will be the first person this year to ask, what is the proper
way to store my '81 911 for the winter?   Last year, Dicks Auto Body 
stored it for the entire winter for free for me while they settled a 
nice $17K repair job on it on some guys insurance.  (He ran me off the 
road, and then tried to get away.  Insurance companies will pay EVERYTING
when their client tries a hit+run.  I got a 930 RUF conversion, new C4 rims, 
and entire paint job from his njegligence.)

Back to my questions about storage now.  Is there a list of things to do;
like defalte tires?  Any treatment for leather seats?  Any special things
I should do to engine until I get around to repairing it in early spring?
Why did someone last year say change the oil, and then change it again in
the spring - since it wont be used oil?  What about the comment I recall
about pressing in the clutch now and then?  Fill gas tank?  Dissconnect
battery?  Should I start it weekly?  I am concerned about corrosion of
the disc brakes.  My chevettte has sat in the driveway all summer, and
now needs brake work due to the grinding I hear when pressing on them 
when rolling.  Should the 911 discs be sprayed with something like wd-40?
What about a good wash, drive, and then wax before putting on the car 
cover?  What can I treat the tires with so the rubber wont crack?  Do I 
have to treat the whole tire, or just the sidewalls?  Should I put it
up on blocks, to relieve weight on suspension and prevent flat tire spots?
Crack open windows to let out moisture?  I may rebuild the Targa top.  
Would it be bad to leave this indoors (off) with the car covered?

My garage is not heated, has no garage door (open all the time), and has 
a concret floor, which gets wet throughout the summer.  Is a plastic vapor 
barrier under the car recommended?  Should I hang a tarp over the garage
opening to prevent snow from getting in, or will this matter since the
car will be covered?  Will the Giants win the Superbowl?  Thanks.

Oh yeah, while I'm in here:  I went to Chambers Porsche in Boston yesterday
and they told me my 911 color was called "SCHWARZ".  It is a dark mettalic
grey/green, almost black.  This is a Euro-911SC car.  What does Schwarz
mean in germany?  Does anyone else have a schwarz colored porsche?  At
the place, I checked out a black 964.  It said on the sticker it was a
turbo, and was a widebody, and had Turbo-3.6 on the back.  When did the
930 become the 964?  Are all 964's Turbos?  Why is this car $124,867.00?  
Who buys these things?  Why do I feel so poor?  help me.

 -Barry Chapin		chapin@draper.com
1981 911SC Targa
Engineer		Draper Laboratory, Cambridge, MA
Patent Law Student	Evenings, Suffolk University, Boston, MA

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 10:32:08 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Winders' nitrogen, sorry again

Mike Piera wrote:

>Well, I'm a scientist/engineer and I checked my old chemistry textbook. Old
>Dr. Wunderlich at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute must have been pretty good
>because I remember exactly what he taught us (he had a GREAT German accent,
>and looked like he should be wearing a white jacket in the Porsche lab
>hunched over a smoking 356 4-cam engine).
>
>Le Chatelier's principle about equalibrium says that if heat is added to a
>system (the tire), the temperature would rise (duh). This would cause a
>change in equalibrium which in turn ... would cause more liquid to evaporate,
>causing the vapor pressure to increase.
>I quote the textbook : "after the addition of heat the new state of
>equilibrium corresponds to increased vapor pressure and temperature. This
>prediction (based on Le Ch.) is consistent with the OBSERVED FACT that the
>vapor pressure of a liquid increases as the temperature increases". QED.
>
>You hung yourself when you said water does not gradually turn to vapor as it
>is heated - this is exactly what happens. Sorry to bore everyone about this
>trivia, as it probably doesn't make more than a PSI or two difference, but
>being a scientist it kills me to see these errors undisputed. I don't plan on
>using nitrogen unless it is commonly available, in which case I surely would
>use it.

Mike,

Here is some more information on this subject from John Porter:

========================================
Here are some useful equations and some numbers I have been playing
around with.

The ideal gas equation is, of course, PV = nRT.
All particles are "generic" in this model, so composition is irrelevant.
Depending on units used for P, V and T, the numerical value of R will
vary.  I will use P(atm), V(L) and T(K) where T(K) = T(C) + 273.15.  In
that case R = 0.08206 L atm/(mol K).

The next level of refinement is the van der Waals equation of state for
gases.  The equation works well for most gases at T >= Tb where Tb is the
boiling point of the gas at the given pressure. (I will get back to this
point later, as it refers to water).

The vdW equation introduces two new "substance-specific" parameters, a
and b.  The equation is:

        (P + (a n^2/ V^2)) (V - nb) = n R T

The first term effectively says the pressure is a bit too low because of
attractive interactions between gas molecules, and the second term
corrects for the fact that the gas molecules actually occupy a finite
volume like little hard spheres, so some volume is excluded.  There are
other equations but, as you'll see, this one does an excellent job at
describing your system.

Now, for the composition of "air" and the parameters for the different
components.  Here is the composition of "dry, carbon-dioxide-free" air at
the surface of the earth (the composition doesn't change significantly
with altitude at values where you wouldn't need an air supply to breathe):

Gas     vol%            a       b
N2      78.110          1.390   0.03913
O2      20.953          1.360   0.03183
Ar      0.934           1.345   0.03219
rest    0.003           (use mean of values above)
H2O     -----           5.464   0.03049
CO2     -----           3.592   0.04267

Real air at sea level and typical temperate climate temperatures has
between 0 - 7% water by volume and 0.01 - 0.1% CO2 by volume.  I used
3.5% and 0.05%, respectively, in my calculations and kept the ratios of
the other components the same as given above.  So, interesting - there is
actually more argon in the air than CO2.

Looking at the numbers for the a and b parameters, you can see some
interesting trends.  The "b" value is roughly the volume of a molecule,
so you can see that water is a relatively small molecule compared to the
other components (it is also light) while CO2 is relatively large (and
heavy).  The "a" values for water and CO2 are very large compared to the
others, because there are strong attractive interactions between water
molecules and between CO2 molecules.  So, a _pure_ sample of either one
of those two gases will differ from the ideal gas law to a greater extent
than the other gases, because the "corrections" are larger.

But just how large are the corrections under the conditions you are
interested in?  And, should the "a" and "b" numbers be different if the gas
is a mixture?  To answer the second question first, "yes".  Probably a
better model of the mixture would be to use a weighted average of the a
and b values, because most interactions will be between unlike molecules
in a pair-at-a-time way.  I didn't do this in my calculations, so I will
be _overestimating_ the deviations from the ideal gas case.

OK, let's calculate some values.  First, I assumed that you initially
filled the tire at room temperature, 25 C, with air containing water and
CO2 as I described above.  My calculations are in terms of absolute
internal pressure of the tire.  The measurement you actually make with
the tire gauge is the _differential_ pressure (Pinternal - Pexternal), of
course, with 1 atm approx. = 15 psi.  I assumed that the tire does not
expand, i.e. it has a constant volume of 22.4 L, as it is pressurized.  I
made calculations for total internal pressures that varied between 1 atm
(deflated) and 10 atm.  I don't know what your pressures are, but I would
expect between 30 and 60 psi (3 atm to 5 atm absolute internal pressure).

I made the calculations by: a) start with a total n, b) partition n
between the components by volume fraction, c) calculate the partial
pressures of the components from the vdW equation, d) sum the partial
pressures to get the total absolute pressure.  Here are a few typical
values (I did this on a spreadsheet):

ntot(moles)     T(C)    Ptot(atm)       P/Pideal
3.000           25.00   3.276           0.9997
4.000           25.00   4.365           0.9992
5.000           25.00   5.454           0.9987
10.000          25.00   10.882          0.9963
3.000           100.00  4.104           1.0006
4.000           100.00  5.470           1.0004
5.000           100.00  6.837           1.0003
10.000          100.00  13.662          0.9994

So what can the numbers tell us?

First, at 25 C when the tire is first filled, the total pressures are
within 1.3% of the ideal gas equation at the upper end of the practical
range, and well within 1% at the lower end.  The situation only gets
better as the tire is warmed; at 100 C pressures are all within a half
percent or so of the ideal gas equation.  So, as I said before, the ideal
gas equation is a damn good first approximation when dealing with air,
even moist air.

Hence, replacing the air with pure nitrogen will have virtually no effect
on these numbers -- if anything, they will get even closer to the ideal
gas limit (compare the a and b values for N2 vs. their ideal values of zero).

Why doesn't the water screw things up?  Well, because it is actually such
a minor component and it is in a pressure regime where the ideal equation
or, better yet, the vdW equation, is an excellent approximation.  If you
filled your tire in water-saturated air at ambient temperatures above 70
C, then it would begin to have a measureable effect.  Of course, you'd be
dead, but that's a minor point.

Also, as I mentioned in my previous note, the most important thing is the
temperature of the system, in terms of parameters that affect the
internal tire pressure.  Look at the huge change in absolute internal
pressure as the tire is warmed from 25 C to 100 C.  This blows away the
tiny "non-ideal-gas" effects.

And, as you probably know if you are a performance car enthusiast, the
_atmospheric pressure_ has a large effect, too.  The rigidity of the tire
is a function of the differential pressure (which is why the gauge
measures this).  So, if the atmospheric pressure changes during a race
day, then this can swamp out these tiny "non-ideal" effects, too.
Atmospheric pressure also has a huge effect on carburetion, and the ideal
gas law can be used there, too.

So, all in all, I would recommend using the ideal gas law as an excellent
first measure.  Control the temperature of the tires, and make
adjustments as the atmospheric pressure changes.  These things will be
far more important that the composition of the gas in the tires.

And, don't listen to "scientists" or "experts" (including me, of course)
without a healthy dose of scepticism.  That's why I like to argue with
numbers, because they are universal.  Models can be crude or
sophisticated, so there is room for argument there, but cranking out some
actual values is usually a very good idea.

This was instructive and fun.  Hope it helps.

J.P.
========================================

As you can see, water will have very little impact on tire pressures.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox weapon)
