Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 07:04:23 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: racing...

> What events would you all recommend a novice driver enter with his/her 
> daily driver?  I like the idea of having a nice car to drive around town 
> and don't really want to thrash it out racing, BUT, I'm interested in 
> driving the car to its limits under "relatively" safe conditions.
> 
> Bert
> 

First of all, "driving the car to its limits under "relatively" safe
conditions." is not called racing, it is called driver education or track
events.

With your daily driver, you can do the occasional track event without too
much noticeable damage.  You will increase the maintenance schedule for your
vehicle, if only to more frequently flush the brake fluid, check your
wheel bearings and brake pads, buy more tires and wheels, change your oil
and tranny fluid, etc.

You may also increase the enjoyment factor of your car, since you will
undoubtedly become a better driver.

If you go to the track (even just to observe) you will see a good
cross-section of nice cars and not-so-nice cars.

(My car is a daily driver, 90K miles, 20K track miles, still going strong!)

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

it returns to clear.

Date: 13 Oct 94 21:34:55 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: CD-1

Bert Garcia asks:

>Does anybody have the name of a company(s) that rebuild or sell rebuilt 
CD-1 or CD-2 units.

I have spoken to both PCNA and Alpine about this.  PCNA will exchange a CD-2 for
a rebuilt one for about $400, if I remember correctly.  I don't know about the
CD-1.  Alpine, who manufactured the CD-2, refuses to provide any information or
to deal with the owner directly, referring the owner to his local Porsche
dealer.  I suggest calling PCNA and asking.

At that price I don't think it's worth it (especially given that I paid about
$200 for the CD-2).  The tuner in my CD-2 is really quite poor (by direct
comparison with a Blaupunkt cassette unit and a Pioneer CD unit).  The only good
things I have to say about the CD-2 are that a) it says "Porsche" on it, and b)
it tracks over rough surfaces better than the Pioneer. 

Alan Watkins ('86 928S)

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 94 21:41:38 PDT
From: dorr@hyperion.llnl.gov (Milo Dorr)
Subject: Cleveland

Ben "Geographically Challenged" Evans writes:
>Please feel free to mail me your impressions on Living in Cleveland,
>Ohio, if indeed such a thing is possible. I have this feeling
>that Cleveland, Ohio, is one of the less desirable places
>to live in the USA, and is the butt of jokes similar to
>the ones about Essex and it's inhabitants in the UK. Please
>can someone break out the fact from the fiction for me?

Ben,

I never lived in Cleveland, but I spent 22 years of my life in western
Pennsylvania, which was close enough.  The weather is lousy (I'm in
California now), but compared to England it might be considered an
improvement.  However, rather than jumping on the Cleveland-bashing
bandwagon, I'll give you a positive for Cleveland Porschephiles.
Stoddard Imported Cars, one of the premier Porsche parts suppliers in
the US (especially for the older models I'm told), makes its home in
Willoughby, OH, which is only a few miles to the east of Cleveland.

 -Milo

Date: 14 Oct 94 08:27:11 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: alcohol in fuel

Hi, Mike.
 
>NEVER use gas that has alcohol as an additive. The government is trying to
>ram it down our filler caps...
 
Too late. They've already succeeded. If I remember the facts correctly, the
ethanol lobby, led by Archer-Daniels-Midland of Peoria, IL (Jack Daniels
etc.) has managed to force the EPA to mandate a certain percentage of
biomass alcohol in the fuel. That means alcohol distilled from corn. And
guess who makes that? The oil companies have pointed out (wrong, right,
don't know, they're self-serving too) that their own MTBE is just as
effective and cheaper, but that didn't cut any ice with those in Washington
who have presumably lined their pockets with lobbyist money. This is a fait
accompli in California and I think is spreading to the rest of the country.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 08:39:06 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: CDs in porsches


Regarding rebuldability of CD1:  Completely unsolicited
advice/question:

I had a 1986 951 converted to somewhere between a TS and a cup car
(Some parts form each suspension wise).  I put an ALpine 6CD changer in
it in the rear left stowage compartment.  It only skipped on SEVERE
bumps.

I'm not sure of the integrity of the sony units, but the local sony
outlet (sells on remanufactured and is actuaslly owned by SONY) has CD
changers AND decent head units -w- cassette, programmanble CD operator
for about $400.
  There's something to be said for having 10 hours of uninterupted un
  repeated CD listening.  Carrying 2 spare magazines will get you most
  of the way acreoss the country.

If your CD1 is toast, you may concider the change over.  Wiring is
realtively simple and sound quality should be comparable.  Just make
sure to hook up the antenna amp!

If you just make adapter plugs for everything you can retro the CD1
when (if) the car is ever sold.

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 20:17:56 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: Re: Stupid question and Cleveland


Ben -

Appreciated your answer to the torque/power/lugging question.
Many would have blown it off, but you resisted the urge to 
grind your teeth, roll your eyes and make those low gurgling
noises in your throat. I didn't - but I applaud your patience
and knowledge.

Cleveland, however, is a different matter.  You are asking
red-blooded Americans to comment on something that is about
as interesting as used toothpicks.  It's a mid-sized city
with crime, poverty, dirt, traffic, kids, schools, churches,
hospitals, police, nice people, nasty people, rich areas
and poor areas. It's located half-way between everywhere
on the south side of a very large shallow lake which helps
to produce lake-effect snow in the cold, wet and windy winters.
The opposite of which is the hot, steamy summers. The surrounding
countyside reminds one a discarded pooltable that allows farmers
to get rich growing lots of things as it goes on and on and on....
Most of the people in Cleveland wish they were somewhere else
but not in one of the dozen or so cities just like it in the
great Mid-West (which spawned me, by the way). While the scenery
make many places great to look at (Bay Area, Seattle, Boston,
Denver, Anchorage), a place is what you make of it and there are
opportunities everywhere. The most important resource, though, is
making new friends - better than gold and nontaxable. 

Lastly, did you say something about getting a Porsche at bargin price?
Well, I guess every thing is relative. 'Course most of my relatives
back in Indiana never even heard of a Porsche so I can probably claim
I'm a victim of Porsche-deficiency-anemia.

In any case, good luck.


Herb Myers

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 09:36:46 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: electronic welding helmets



About 15 years ago, I designed an electro-mechanical welding
helmet for my own use because I was doing some very fine-detail
mig welding that required both hands for control. I used an air
solenoid that pulled a standard darkened welding glass down and it 
returned by spring power. I had a switch on the MIG trigger and a 
fail-safe so that the welder couldn't start until the glass was
fully down. At the time I rejected liquid crystal because it would 
take many layers $$ to get adequate density, and I rejected a Kerr
cell because of weight.

I was pretty proud of my "super helmet" but couldn't get any welders
excited about it. They just didn't have the same problem I did 
starting a weld in precisely the right spot (or didn't care). They
also didn't like the noise (which could have been better controlled)
I used the helmet for a year or so and gave up on the idea. 

Mine was a pretty low-tech solution to the problem. Total cost as 
I recall was about $75 in misc. parts (not including the helmet)
The only machine work was making a custom "frame" to hold the sliding
window and a bracket for the solenoid. It would be well with the
capabilities of most Porsche DYI'rs

 - Reid

#######################################################################

Reid Zeigler                             "I have the simplest tastes.
Sr. Mgr. Visual Communications            I am always satisfied with
Merck Research Laboratories               the best."
zeigler@merck.com                                      - Oscar Wilde
908.594.6770
#######################################################################

Date: 14 Oct 94  8:59:17 CS
From: Henry Hwong <Henry_Hwong@notes.bsginc.com>
Subject: Re: Back-firing 911 SC

My 1980 911SC does the same thing when I lift off the throttle at
high speeds on the freeway (going straight, of course :-)). My
mechanic, too, says there's probably a hole inside the 
muffler itself. Replacing the muffler (and cat, if necessary) is
on my list, behind the fuel injection stuff.

My mechanic says there may be problems with new
Bosch warmup regulators for CIS cars -- something to do
with its fuel/air curve attenuating at then end, causing the
cars to run lean when warmed up. When he tried to compensate
by making the car run a little more rich, the car started surging after
ignition, presumably because it was too rich. Has anyone else
heard of this rumor? Could emissions be a factor in the changes,
if the rumors are true? If so, are European 911SCs using the same
exact part?

 -Henry


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Oct 1994 23:45:35 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: Stupid question (shifting)

>When I drive any manual tranny car, including my 951, and I step on the gas 
>when the car is in a higher gear (5th?) and turning low revs (1000rpm?) the 
>car shudders and shakes until the revs get higher.

Keep the revs above 2000 rpm (at least on a 944) pretty much all of the
time. Lugging the engine is hard on a number of engine/drivetrain
components, so you really want to avoid it. I may get some heat from the
others on the list for this, but I feel that the 944/951 engine is quite a
robust unit. I have just over 75k on my '84 944, and I usually like to
cruise with the motor turning between 2800-4000rpm. I never let the revs
fall below 2000, but sometimes I will cruise at 2200rpm when feeling "laid
back". I really only use 5th above 55mph.

The only time your engine should be turning 1000 rpms (or there about) is
when the car is at idle.

In his excellent series of articles on the 924/944/968 in Excellence
magasine (Oct. 1994), Jim Pasha explains that lugging the engine is hard on
the engine main and rod bearings and other driveline bearings. He also
notes that keeping the trans at higher revs promotes better circulation of
oil in the trans. I think that what Jim says is correct (he knows a lot
more about cars than I do - since he's the one writing the articles and I'm
the one reading them :-)

I hope this helps ...


- ---------------------------------------------------
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer
(A Music Industry Professional -- Ha !!!)

'84 Porsche 944 (Red)
'93 Feline unit ("Corvette")
'94 Child Unit (one month old !!!)

Please note: My old address is: trevs944@aol.com
                 My new address is: trevs944@mixcom.com

Hello Fellow Ethusiasts,

VW-philes.  If so, please EFrom dave.paulin Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:44:47 -0400 remote from sbaonline.gov
Received: by sbaonline.gov
     id A9785wk Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:44:47 -0400

Message-Id: <9410141044.A9785wk@sbaonline.gov>
Organization: Small Business Administration

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:44:47 -0400
Subject: VW & CLEVE.
To: porschephiles@tta.com


Hello Fellow Ethusiasts,
On advice from Stan I put this question to the whole net--Does anyone know of a
VW-philes.  If so, please E-mail me the address at dave.paulin@sbaonline.gov. 
Next, Ben, come to Cleveland it's a great place 8).  Both my parents were born
and raised in Cleveland and all my relatives live there, so I have spent quite
a few ENJOYABLE hours in Cleveland.  A Quick Tour for those who have never
been.  The Gateway complex, containing a new baseball stadium and basketball
arena, was just completed for the beginning of this years shortened baseball
season.  Now, within EASY walking distance of downtown, one  can enjoy sports
YEAR round in Cleveland (how many other cities can say that??).  Then there is
the Flats, which is divided into two banks one on easy side of the Cuyahauga
(something like that) River.  This is the entertainment spot in Cleveland. 
Numerous restuarants, clubs, and bars are located within a 2-3 square mile
radious. Also located in the Flats is the Nautica Complex which is a 10-12
thousand seat out-door concert hall.  I have been to a couple shows there,
seeing top rated bands like Soundgaren and Nine Inch Nails (a Cleve. BAnd).
But, the biggest attraction for Ben would be to see Stoddard in person (done
it)!!!!

Renard Paulin

difference).  When I bought my 914 it came with a bunch of keys (2 of

1 black - opens driver's door and fits ignition
1 red   - opens passenger's door and rear trunk lock

I don't remember which one opens the front hood (bonnet) lock, but I
think it was the red one.

I know the car had been broken into at least once (glass under seats),
but I don't know if any locks were replaced or if that is what the setup
is supposed to be.  Does anyone know for sure?  The setup almost makes
sense (1 key for the driver, and another for everything else).

Any comments...       

Tim Murphy (tmurphy@bnr.ca) 1974 914 1.8L

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 08:44:07 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Distributor Problem/Question


Help, please..

The Problem:

I'm having trouble with the distributor for the '72 911E 
I'm rebuilding.  The  return springs in the mechanical 
(centrifugal) advance do not bring the weights back 
together, i.e., back to the 'zero point'.  Instead, the 
slightest spin, even by hand, brings the weights to an 
almost fully extended position, where they remain.  They 
never go back to the 'zero point'.  Thus, they are in the 
position of maximum advance to begin with, and as a 
consequence there is no advance as engine speed 
increases.  In this condition, it doesn't matter how you set 
the timing, things never work right.  The timing is all 
screwed up and performance is poor.

I've got the distributor apart -- not such an easy task with 
a Bosch unit, although it's a snap with any 
American/Japanese unit I've worked on - and it looks to 
me like both springs are fine.  They're not stretched, or 
otherwise worn.  The mechanism itself is well lubricated 
and free.

>From what I can see, the distributor is designed with two 
advance curves.  There are two different springs.  One 
appears to be designed to control advance at low rpm, 
and the other at higher rpm.  I believe my problem is with 
the low rpm spring.  There is a lot of slop where it 
attaches (slips over is a better term) to the stud on the 
mechanism.  The diameter of the loop on the spring is 
large compared to the stud diameter, so there's lots of 
slack.  Hence at low rpm the weights move out 
unimpeded by the low rpm spring, they merely take up 
the slack in the spring loop/stud arrangement.  When 
they're nearly fully extended the high rpm spring, which 
has a deliberately long (oval) loop and therefore 
deliberate slack,  takes over. It controls the last few 
degrees of advance, probably the last 10 or so. My guess 
is that there was once a teeny tiny bushing on the stud of 
the low rpm spring that must have worn away over the 
last 23 years, and said bushing took up the slack in the 
attachment loop.

The Question:

Is there anyone out there who has looked into a similar 
Bosch distributor who can tell me if I'm right?  It seems to 
me that I ought to be able to fabricate a small bushing, or 
even bend the stud to take up the slack.  I'm planning to 
try the former first, the latter as a last resort.  It turns out a 
new distributor is between $400-$500, and a rebuilt is 
over $300.  Seems nuts when all that might be missing is a 
2 cent part.  By the way, Bosch doesn't sell distributor 
parts, only the whole thing. 

Thanks in advance...better than thanks in retard...sorry, couldn't
resist it...

Bob Spindel

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:43:14 CDT
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: Thanks...

Hey Everybody:

Thanks for responding to my questions about the 88-951s vs 89-951.  I 
think the general consensus is:  Start by asking for the part using 
88-951s.  If their computer doesn't show that model, use 89-951 and be 
"reasonably" assured that the parts will be the same.  It also seems that 
consumable parts (filters, belts, etc..) are the same.

As for the CD-1: Ask the dealership for a rebuilt unit - If too expensive, 
forget it.  There are better units on the aftermarket.

I appreciate the advice.  I'll let you know how it turns out.

Bert

'88 951 S (black)

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 12:00:35 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: How many keys for 914?

> How many distinct keys should there be for a 914 (1974 if it makes a
> difference).  When I bought my 914 it came with a bunch of keys (2 of
> which actually worked on the locks).  The keys which worked were:
> 
> 1 black - opens driver's door and fits ignition
> 1 red   - opens passenger's door and rear trunk lock
> 
> I don't remember which one opens the front hood (bonnet) lock, but I
> think it was the red one.

Well, there are supposed to be two keys, one red and one black, but
odds are that the car's had a  partially lock replacement because it's
*supposed* to have one that opens EVERYTHING and one that only opens 
the doors (both of them) and the ignition. And I get confused about
which is which color.

There's a factory part number for "complete lock set with keys" that
can let you put it all back, or you can have the ignition and
driver's door re-keyed to match the other keys, then find a valet
key blank somewhere...

Stan

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:27:38 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Vibrators and Lugging


Hi all,

A few notes on driveline vibrations from 2700 RPM to 3800 RPM (plus or
minus a few, depending on the mass).

The usual cause is disintegration of the clutch center. This can occur 
on ANY Porsche with a rubber dampened clutch disc. Oil, heat, dirt and
humidity conspire to cause the rubber to delaminate and make the 
vulcanized bond (not Spock as 007) go away. In some cases chunks of 
rubber larger than the usual small pebbles leaves the disc. This causes 
the disc to make noise as the clutch is engaged and disengaged and,
if the mass is large enough, cause a vibration due to a massive 
imbalance. 

How much of an imbalance? It doesn't take a lot. In addition, large 
pieces have been known to lodge in the pressure plate, causing 
engagement and disengagement problems. If caught early enough, just the 
disc requires replacement. Most have required disc, pressure plate, 
throw-out bearing. Always have the flywheel surfaced, have the flywheel and clutch components balanced together and always replace the pilot
bearing. Not-so-cheap insurance.

Lugging a Porsche engine. Well, they'll take it. They buck and shudder 
and gradually get back up to operating range. Consider this, keep all 
but the 928 above 2000 RPM and they will live a long time. The 928 has 
more cylinders and has a design more condusive to "urban" (or is that
urbane?) driving. 

Three things of major consideration occur: 1) Oil flow volume may not be sufficient to "float" the bearings at low crankshaft speeds, scuffing 
can occur. 2) the transmission bearings take a tremendous hit as there 
isn't much lubrication flowing. 3) the clutch takes a beating as the 
power impulses can cause slip. Besides, cooling isn't good because the 
water pump or fan isn't flowing enough coolant over the engine.

Some of the 4-cam owners know that low RPM can destroy an expensive
Hirth rollercrank. Same principles at work.

Turbos will pull well if driven in the 2000 and above range. Lower Rpms
do not spool the turbo enough to produce any useable boost.

One of the things that wipes a Porsche with a driveshaft is lugging. The
shaft bearings are designed to work under load in an optimal range. 
Lugging causes the shaft to flex and whip a little under the pulses.
Just smoothly drive the car, selecting gears as the RPM range and 
driving conditions dictate.

JIm Pasha

Date: 13 Oct 1994 16:02:44 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 914 Rot Report

914 Rot Report
    Hi, again.
    The good news is that the worst rot seems to be confined to
the (non-structural) sheet of metal that the fuel pump was bolt-
ed to.  The bad news is that that piece has rotted *through*,
and that there's a fair amount of surface stuff on the other me-
tal near it.  Some of which is structural.
    So it gets some panic-mode treatment ASAP, including tie-
wraps or duct tape or *something* to keep the fuel pump from
flopping around.  Suggestions?  How about "rust converters?"
Probably have to chop that one section of metal out.  Then do
it right at a later time, when I can take the time to do it right.

- --DD

Subject: stalling 911SC

Hello Philes,

I have a 79 911SC which stalls from a cold start. It starts up just fine but
will stall immediately. If you restart it a couple of times it will stay lit
and runs fine from there on. The colder the outside temerature the worst the
problem is. I figure since the car runs fine otherwise, it's probably not a
tune up or air leak problem. My guess is the warm up regulator. Problem is
the dealer I brought the car from says they installed a new regulator. I
bought the car in the summer so I didn't know the problem was still there.
Can't go back to the dealer since I've lived with the problem for 3 years
(lazy me). I'm concerned that a new WAR might not solve the problem. I
recall some years ago reading that some SCs needed the Euro WAR to solve
this problem. Any ideas?

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 13:20:08 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: racing...

Bert. Are you a PCA member? If not join. I'm not trying to stuff PCA
membership down anyone's craw but it is *THE BEST* source of Porsche car
driving events.  Every PCA Region has some kind of "low speed" novice
event(s), which is the most likely place to begin your driver training.

Autocross (in California it's called a Slalom) is the easiest, cheapest,
least hard on your car activity.  It involves driving your car around a
course laid out with (usually) orange traffic cones. You are running
against a clock and your time through the course is compared to that of the
other drivers in your assigned class.  About the only risk of damage will
be from hitting cones which can sometimes leave a smudge on the car. The
smudge can easily be rubbed off using car wax.  You will put some extra
wear and tear on your tires and you will be up/down shifting several times
during a run.

Driver Education is usually the next step up from Autocross. Most Regions
will *NOT* let you attend a Driver Ed. event without having some autocross
experience under your belt. Driver Ed is almost always held on a race
course and the opportunity to do some real damage to your exists. No, they
do not just turn you loose to see how fast you can go. There are rules, and
for the first one or two events, you will likely have an instructor on
board. These events are not usually timed, but most drivers have someone
time them or use an on-board timer to keep track of how well they are
improving. A variation on driver ed. is called a Time Trial which does
involve a formal timed run, usually on the afternoon of the last day.
Driver Ed./Time Trial events *WILL* put a serious strain on your brakes,
tires, and other mechanicals, but not to the point of breaking. Simple,
regular maintenance will keep your car on the track indefinitely. In
addition, most Regions require a five-point harness, which
may involve drilling a couple of holes.

Somewhere between autocrossing and driver education, your idea of a "daily
driver" will begin to change.  A suspension tweek here and an alignment
change there and...oh what the hell, it's what they were built for. Right?

Have fun!!!

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 14:22:39 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Lugging

Hi Jim, you left one out:

> Three things of major consideration occur: 1) Oil flow volume may not be sufficient to "float" the bearings at low crankshaft speeds, scuffing 
> can occur. 2) the transmission bearings take a tremendous hit as there 
> isn't much lubrication flowing. 3) the clutch takes a beating as the 
> power impulses can cause slip. Besides, cooling isn't good because the 
> water pump or fan isn't flowing enough coolant over the engine.

4) Wrist-pin and big-end bearings take a much bigger impulse during ignition.
The piston is decelerating during the last part of the compression stroke,
which is where the charge is lit off. The thump from the "explosion" is
opposed by the force that causes that deceleration. At low rpm, that opposing
force is much less, which means that more of the thump gets transmitted to
the wristpin, rod, big end, and even the crank mains. Speedster 1500 engines
have a reputation for flat-spotting the roller bearings when you do that...


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: 	Fri, 14 Oct 1994 11:28:21 PDT
From: "William M. York" <york@parc.xerox.com>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4

   From:	"Barton P. Chambers" <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
   Date:	Tue, 11 Oct 1994 04:02:00 -0700

   High-end late model Quattros use Torsen (TORque SENsing) center
   differentials while earlier models use (lockable) mechanical differentials. 
   My Syncro is the Audi 4000 series quattro system (and I believe, the same
   as the Ur-Quattro and all other pre-torsen models).  The center and rear
   differentials can be manually locked by the driver, on the fly.  No
   clutches are used in either system, to the best of my (limited) knowledge.

This was the same scheme used in the Jeep Wagoneer "Quadra-Track"
system in the early/mid 70's, right down to the diff locking.  I think
that this was the first full-time (i.e. dry pavement) 4WD system.

Seriously, the italian-cars list does indeed mostly concentrate
on Alfa Romeo automobiles (note the spelling...) in part
because that's the car of choice of the list manager, Richard Welty.
I believe the subscription address is italian-cars-request@balltown.cma.com
and if that doesn't work, send mail to Richard at welty@balltown.cma.com
Hairy Pennuci! uh, Arrivederci!

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 14:08:58 CDT
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: CD-1 madness...

Well....

I took the advice of a couple of P-philers and called my local Pcar 
dealership, Don Magill in Houston.  The parts guy has 4 !NEW! CD-2 units 
for $350(US) with a kit to get it into older CD-1 applications.  They 
indicated that they only had 4 more left; after that, they're gone for 
good.  He also has CR-1 (tape/radio) units that are pulls from new 
vehicles who's owners wanted a CD player.  He has plenty of these and will 
sell them for $300(US).  

I think the local stereo outlets have a much better deal, though.  After 
reading a posting on the horrible tuners in Porsche's C?-X units and 
realizing that my tuner sounded like hell before it died, I've decided on 
a Blau Lexington tape/radio player; $197(US) from Best Buy.  

All the Blau units sound virtually the same anyway (I'm standing by for 
incoming flames on this one). I can correct for any weirdness using the 
Blau EQ already in the car.  Since I have an extensive vinyl and tape 
collection but only 20 or so CDs (I'm a Porschephile not an Audiophile) 
this seems the best route.  

Now everything on the radio console will say Blaupunk....  yea!  :|

Bert

'88 951S (black)
'64 Wonderful Beautiful Sig. Oth.
'94 Baby Rug Rat (sleeping soundly now)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 15:58:18 CDT
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: Winter 911 storage/restoration

Beacuse I live in the "tundra" and as of Wednesday am a proud owner
of a '87 911 Targa, I am also interested in storage tips.  I've been
meaning to preruse the archives for tidbits, but I'm too busy enjoying
our limited good weather...

Anyway, I paraphrased the following from an article by Paul Brand in
the Minneapolis Star Tribune Oct 9, 1994).  All editorial comments and
spelling errors are mine.

 - Choose the last nice day you want to drive the vehicle.  Take it on
  a nice cruise for at least 30 minutes.  Enjoy yourself.  On the way
  home, fill the gas tank.

 - Once home, perform routine maintenance including oil and filter
  changes, chassis lube, cooling system flush ( ;-) - mjt),  transmission
  fluid and filter change, change brake fluid, etc.  Add fuel stabilizer
  and allow the car to run for a bit to let the stabilizer permeate the
  fuel system.

 - Check the air in the tires - remember that pressure falls with lower
  ambient temperatures.  There is no need to put the car on jack stands...

 - Thoroughly wash, dry, and wax the car.  Clean the interior as well, using
  vinyl and leather protectants where appropriate.

 - Disconnect and remove the battery.  Fully charge it now and once a month
  or so to keep it ready for the spring.

 - Open the side windows a crack to allow air circulation, but not so far
  as to allow small critters inside.  Plug the exhaust to prevent
  unauthorized entry by small critters.  Cover the car with a lightweight
  cover.


DON'Ts

 - Don't store the battery on a concrete floor.  Put it on a couple of
  blocks of wood.  Some people think that the concrete "reacts" with the
  battery, thus rendering it useless.  More likely the concrete slab
  is a good heat sink and that's really what does the poor thing in.
  (Anyone got the real story here, or is this just an urban legend? - mjt)

 - Don't put the car on jack stands.  Most modern tires won't "flat-spot"
  very badly over the winter.  If you must put the car in the air, lower
  the tire pressure to 15 psi.  Remember to reinflate the tires in the
  spring.

 - Don't start the car periodically.  Cold starts after weeks of inactivity
  in extreme cold are not helpful to the oil-feed components.  Short periods
  of idling without significant load are not enough to fully warm the oil
  and evaporate the raw fuel and moisture that condense inside the engine
  on a cold start.

  If you must: make sure the car gets *driven* to fully warm it up.  If
  applicable, run the AC to circulate the refrigerant/lubricant to keep
  the seals fresh.  But, remember that freon condenses into a pure liquid
  at -22F (January in Minnesota - mjt) so starting the car to run the AC
  at this temperature is useless anyway.


Does anyone have comments, changes, suggestions, etc?

thanks,
mjt

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 17:43:52 -0400
From: Dustin Boyette - Logical Design Group <ldg@mercury.interpath.net>
Subject: "The Big Chill" 911T

Fellow Porschephiles,

The verdict is in! Jeff Shorey and I did the frame-by-frame thing on scenes
from "The Big Chill" which feature the 911T Targa which Nick (William Hurt)
drove. It's not a '73, '72, '71, or even a '70. It's a 1969. The giveaway?
The push-button door handles which were replaced by the "trigger" type on
1970 and later models. And it's a U.S.-spec car, too.

It's good to have this crutial piece of Porsche movie trivia cleared up. ;->

Dustin Boyette
1974 911 Carrera, Signal Green (911SC-Powered)
1978 930, Grand Prix White

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 15:07:26 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Ferry tale

During a time near the dawn of civilized thought, a group of Persians
lived in a fertile valley. Although they lacked in worldly possesions,
the bounty of many fruit trees kept them free from hunger and they were,
for the most part, quite content. One day, however, one Persian 
lamented that the fruit, while delicious and satisfying, was difficult
to eat and left a sticky residue all over his hands. Determined to 
rectify this situation, he thought long and hard, and finally came up 
with the idea of lashing a flinty piece of rock to a stick. Using this
so-called 'rock-point' tool, he was able to cut the fruit up easily,
eliminating much of the work and mess. As good as this was, though, 
they still had to use their hands to eat the sticky fruit. So, another
enterprising Persian took this idea further by lashing three long 
thorns off of a tre to a stick. With this 'tree-point' tool, he 
could now eat his fruit and stay clean. There was a complication,
however, since the thorns came off of their ruler, Khar's, ornamental
trees. Since they were a penniless people, the trees were his only 
extravagance. Upon seeing his trees desecrated in such a way, Khar 
seized the 'tree-point' tools and in a frenzied rage, devoured them.
This point in history was then the culmination of events leading to
the development of the 'tree-point' tool eater poor Shah Khar era.....

Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 17:02:08 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: NO SUBJECT

> Can someone help me to unsubscribe to this list?

Here's how it works:

First off, RTFR. You get a set of Rules when you join, and
once again MONTHLY. Send a note to 'porschephiles-request@tta.com'
to get on or of the list , or get your addres changed.

All add/move/deletes are done *MANUALLY*, and while I usually get
around to it at least once a day, it's not instantaneous.

Anytime someone unsubscribes, they *STILL* get anything that's 
queued up with their name on it. I just absolutely refuse to conduct
queue pruning everytime I drop someone from the list. 

Stan Hanks
ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 17:11:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: owner and repair manuals

>      I have a 75 914 2.0L, and I wanted to know if it possible to find the 
>      original owners' manuals, or a copy of them.

Yes. Most of the aftermarket places have them, and the dealers still have
them.

>      Also which is the best "do-it-yourself" guide to the 914, Chilton, 
>      Haynes, or other?

Depends. If you're going to *REALLY* work on the car, there's no substitute
for the factory workshop manuals. If you just want to know more how it 
works, and will do "light" stuff from time to time, get the Haynes. Chilton
is a waste of good trees.

>      Another question, are there any mail order catalogs that would carry 
>      parts and accessories for my P-car

All of them. Performance Products. Automotion. Stoddard. Tweeks.

How do you find these guys? Best way is to join PCA, and once a month
you'll get this GREAT magazine that also has ads in it for these guys,
and more.

Stan

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 15:25:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw3.az05.bull.com>
Subject: Sunroof revisited


My sunroof on my 84 944 has never been able to release for complete removal. 


I am aware of all the advice in the past about ignition key positions etc 
but I would like to try one more crack at identifying where my problem is, 
so please bear with me.

The possible candidates for failure appear to be  :    The sunroof motor
                              The sunroof motor relays (431 951 253 D)  (2)
                              The radio relay (944 615 103 00)
                              The sunroof switch
                              The ignition switch

I would eliminate the ignition switch because it appears to turn on 
everything it should when it should (except the sunroof release)

I would elimate the sunroof motor and it's 2 attached relays as the sunroof 
goes up and down just fine

I would eliminate the sunroof switch becase it has been replaced and the 
problem preceeds replacement.

That leaves the sunroof/radio relay. The radio works fine, but I am not sure 
what role this relay plays in sunroof operation. on inspecting the relay it 
seems to be a complex  beast with chips and transistors in it. Can somebody 
tell me if it is possible to test these things to ensure that they are 
working correctly?

Any advice would be appreciated


Will Hartje

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 18:04:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Rot Report

>     The good news is that the worst rot seems to be confined to
> the (non-structural) sheet of metal that the fuel pump was bolt-
> ed to.  The bad news is that that piece has rotted *through*,
> and that there's a fair amount of surface stuff on the other me-
> tal near it.  Some of which is structural.

Better get on that before it turns into a real problem...

>     So it gets some panic-mode treatment ASAP, including tie-
> wraps or duct tape or *something* to keep the fuel pump from
> flopping around.  Suggestions?  How about "rust converters?"
> Probably have to chop that one section of metal out.  Then do
> it right at a later time, when I can take the time to do it right.

I wouldn't go into a blind panic, but I'd fix this before getting
say new tires..

Like I've suggested before, find a good body shop that has a competent
fabricator, have him excise the bad metal and weld in a new plate.
Needs to be the same gauge steel, needs to be butt-welded, and you
gotta treat any other visible rust...

Shouldn't be very expensive, assuming that anyone in CA still does
work like this...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 16:20:00 PDT
From: Martin Cox <mcox@mswisard.kla.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Sunroof revisited


Will,
>snip snip
>I would elimate the sunroof motor and it's 2 attached relays as the sunroof 

>goes up and down just fine

You may have already done this but check the position.alignment of the two 
microswitches on the motor plate.

>That leaves the sunroof/radio relay.......is possible to test these things 
to ensure that they are
working correctly?
>Will Hartje

This one isn't easy. I think you will need at least a 12 Volt power supply, 
bunch of jumper wires and quality multimeter to check this. The problem is 
that the "relay" senses the voltage level of several inputs to determine if 
it is safe to open the roof. I think that one of them includes wheel motion 
to allow opening. You may need to simulate the inputs. If you don't have a 
full specification for the device you need to work this out from the 
schematic.

I am not sure of the internal circuitry but it may need a output load to 
function correctly. It is basically an electronic switch with additional 
logic. Polarity of the measurements is important as is polarity of the 
supply. If you get the connections wrong you will probably blow the device.

There is a procedure in the factory manual to diagnose the roof. If I get a 
chance I'll dig it out.

I would get a replacement "used" from PartsHeaven or other and try that. If 
anyone has already been through the process and worked out the connections 
please let us know.

Hope this helps.

Martin Cox   mcox@kla.com
'87 944

------------------------------

Date: 14 Oct 1994 16:46:19 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: 911's for sale- 88 & 89

                      Subject:                              Time:  4:12 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         911's for sale: 88 & 89               Date:  10/14/94
I couldn't take it any longer.  Following a fit a temporary insanity,
brought on by a spirited 30 minute test drive in a 993, I broke down and
ordered one a few weeks ago.  I now must do what I never figured I would:
sell our two 911's to pay for the new one.  This is very difficult.

I have owned 7 911's over 25 years and loved every one of them (as well
as a 66 912 and 59 356).  My all time favorite is the 88 turbo-look
below.  But the 89 coupe is hardly used and will make its new owner very
happy.  These were very good years for Porsche and the cars have proven
to be very durable.  If you know anyone interested please pass along the
word.  I will start to sell them seriously in December (ie, advertise them)
but until then it's word of mouth.  Both cars are very well cared for;
spared no expense in maintaining them.  Neither needs any work.

$28k: 88 factory turbo look targa.  Sticker shows $63k new (t-look $13.4k
option).  Incredible handling.  Unbelievable brakes (917).  Optional
diamond blue (silver/lavender metallic) paint.  Nearly perfect condition,
inside and out.  Full leather, full polished Fuchs (7 & 9's), painted crests,
HRS locks, upgrade Blaupunkt, 12 disk CD player, 4 channel Kenwood amp,
phone, never damaged in any way, new top, records, 3k oil changes. 115k
miles.  Looks and drives like new.

$29k: 89 coupe.  Sticker shows $58k new.   Silver anniv special (black
metallic, painted wheels to match, special leather console w/ gauges,
piping trim on seats, matching steering wheel, plush trunk carpet).
Factory short shifter, Autothority performance chip.  New RE71's on 7's
and 8's.  Parking lot fender-bender repaired by Porsche specialists
(BodyStyle, 10/93, *excellent work*). 3k oil changes.  36k miles.

I'm a digest subscriber and slow to read batched mail.  But I do get to
direct mail timely.

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 17:13:06 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: skinny tires

OK tire and wheel experts, I have a series of questions:

I've got a '79 928 with stock ( i guess) wheels in a 7x16 size, phone-dial
type.  When I bought the car (I didn't do it!!) it came with a matched set of
T**-type tires, different sizes and manufacturers on front and rear.  What I
want to know is why someone would put on a smaller tire up front if the thing
understeers like a pig.  I guess I only notice the understeering when I'm
driving "with spirit" in autocrosses.  If I were a betting man, wouldn't I try
and get a bigger (more contact patch) type of tire to help alleviate the nasty
habit of understeer on the front?  The tire sizes are as follows:

front	7x16	205/55-16
back	7x16	255/50-16

I am planning on putting a bigger tire up front (255/50-16) but have no plans
to increase the rear tire size.  What is the widest tire that can be run safely
up front with no mods to the bodywork?

And is 7x16 a stock '79 928 front wheel size?

By the way, this car was purchased at a FBI Drug Seizure Auction about 1.5 years
ago.  That's why I don't know if this pig is stock or not.

later,
bill
billv@retix.com
'79 928 ("No Officer.  I've never seen that stash before")

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 03:16:00 +0100 (MET)
From: joker@diku.dk
Subject: Major DME problems! HELP needed!

Heeeeeeellllppp!

My shop has just transplanted a 3.2l into my old 2.7l targa, but
there is a SERIOUS problem: The engine is burning the DME control unit!

Not every time you turn the key, but about 1 out of 8 or something
like that. It has now shortcircuited 3 DME's and we're afraid to
install any more (it's pretty expensive little suckers - anybody
know how to repair these???)

Apparently car burns the DME when turning the key - NOT when driving. The 
car haven't even been driven hard before stopping the last time. When the 
DME is dead, it'll just open all fuel injectors all the time, flooding 
the engine completely with gas.

We've checked all ground connections to the engine. Furthermore we've 
changed the fuel injectors, the ingnition coil and the distributor just
to make sure.

The engine comes from another (former) 2.7l where there were no problems
at all.

Any ideas how to find out what the problem is?

We think that perhaps the starter doesn't have enough ground and somehow
pulls it through the DME hence burning it, but we've installed an extra
ground cable on the engine with no luck.

HEEELLLPPP!

Christian

911 Targa 3.2 (Anti-computer vehicle)
911 Coupe Turbo-look Carrera (with 9"+11" x 17" - sorry, Ted!)

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 22:34:24 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Winders' Nitrogen tires... V5.1

Dear Scott, winders@porsche.support.apple.com

Soren LaForce said what I have already said twice and you keep ignoring :
your experts' explanations "did not discuss the vapor (partial) pressure of
water, which is what I believe to be the issue."

Your latest expert's calculations are great, but they AGAIN fail to consider
the main point : if there is "liquid" water in the tire. All his calculations
were only considering gases, and I agree that in this case the water content
does not make a difference. If there is liquid water in the tire more of it
will turn to gas at higher temperatures, and increase the tire pressure.

This time I will take the easy way out and ask the experts myself. Here
is the question :

Scott Winders asked you about using nitrogen in tires for racing in order
to have less pressure-buildup with heat. Your answers were good but
unfortunately Mr. Winders has never asked the question correctly. Liquid 
water is commonly spewed out of air compressors and builds up in racing tires
because they are filled and bled many times during their lives. I agree
that the percentage of WATER VAPOR in the tire makes no difference. But
if there is LIQUID WATER in the tire, then more of it will turn to its
gaseous state as the tire warms. This prediction (based on Le Chatelier's
principle which I explained to Mr. Winders) is consistent with the OBSERVED
FACT that the vapor pressure of a liquid increases as the temperature
increases.

Please let Mr. Winders (winders@porsche.support.apple.com) know if you
agree with me or not. Thank you for your time.

I am sending this to :

Bill C Hutton (wchutt@alex.monsanto.com) from Monsanto Company, Corporate
John Douglas Porter (porterj@uclink.berkeley.edu) from U.C. Berkeley
Alex Krooglik (krooglik@minerva.cis.yale.edu), a Yale Graduate Student

Regards,  Mike Piera  '72 911S Targa


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 19:56:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 engine removal, comments sought...

Hello all,

        Well I have finally undertaken the task of dropping the engine
/transmission assembly out of my new project '74 914. My primary
reason for this was to replace the transmission with a freshly rebuilt
one from parts heaven.
        I had a number of reasons to do all this. One, the tranny was
making a loud whiring sound in 3rd, 4th and 5th gears. I figured at
least one or two bad bearings, and I knew there were at least two bad
synchros. I also knew my clutch was bad. And I planned to try and
troubleshoot my overheating problems.
        With some help from fellow 914'er Dave Darling, we proceded to
find out exactly what was needed (and not needed) to drop the assembly
. I won't go into too many details to conserve bandwidth. But to sum
it up, the removal process took slightly over 5 hours for two people
who've never attempted it before. There were a few things that I'll
remark on however, If anybody has comments I'm open to hear 'em.
        One, don't bother with disconnecting the whole wiring harness and
all that, just unbolt the computer and let it come out with the engine
. Two, get the car as high off the ground as you can. I used ramps (
big ones) and with the throttle body and oil filler removed, It -JUST-
cleared the rear valence when I rolled it out on the floor jack with
one 2x4 under the engine. Three, and this is a good one, use two floor
jacks if you can. One on the engine and one on the tranny. And watch
those fuel lines when lowering the engine =8-o.

        Things I found when all was said and done:

On the tranny: lot's of grime ('nuff said). A huge amount of metal on
the drain plug magnet with only 700 or so miles since cleaned. A
totally fried flywheel. It was probably about 6 months away from
wearing all the way thru. All the linkage bushings were either worn or
cracked. The transmission mounts were also on their way out.

On the engine: lot's of grime... A leaking flywheel seal, NINE missing
blades on the fan! That would explain my overheating. Missing plugs
over the engine cowl (more overheating problems). A missing thermostat
, no big deal. 

        So, I plan on replacing the tranny mounts with the urathane
ones from Automotion, does anyone have comments about these. Should I
bother with them or stick with stock? Also, is there something that I
can do to the fuel lines to give them better clearance from the sheet
metal? 
        Any comments or suggestions on what I can do to make
instalation easier?

Thanks all,

Joshua Hadler                           '74 914 2.0L CS(AS?)->CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 1994 23:59:44 -0400
From: NotWise@aol.com
Subject: DME Flash Fires

Joker wrote:
<<My shop has just transplanted a 3.2l into my old 2.7l targa, but there is a
SERIOUS problem: The engine is burning the DME control unit!>>

Check the amperage on the +12v line coming into the DME box.  My bet is that
the car is frying your DME's with too many amps.  Probably doesn't blow the
fuse, but still fries.  

It really can't be anything else.  Electronics burn up because of incorrect
voltage or amperage.

NotWise@AOL.com

84 Blk/Blk/Tail 911 Carrera

Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 23:53:27 MDT

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 94 08:13 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Fwd: Motronic Warning

M. Christian Holmgreen -

This was posted to Porschephiles last May.  Perhaps it is your problem.
I would just go through the wiring diagram for the 3.2, and identify
the signals it expects at each of its pins.

Kevin Gross

 - - -

forwarded message from ken house:

This note is a caution to those people who are retrofitting a 3.2l  Carrera 
engine into an earlier model 911.  i just finished repairing two more DME 
(Motronic) control units that were damaged by incorrect wiring.  The cause 
of this particular failure mode has occurred so frequently that a word of 
warning is warranted.

Scenario: An early model 911 owner/racer buys a 3.2 motor with wiring 
harness and DME control unit, but usually does not buy the tachometer.  
Installation is straight-forward until the wires to the tachometer are 
encountered.  The Motronic tachs are microprocessor-based electronic units 
with two wires coming from the DME unit.  For some reason the wire to pin 
11 of the DME gets connected to a +12 volt line under the dash.  The 
installation gets completed, and the key is turned to start the car --zap-- 
it won't start.  After much time and trouble someone narrows the problem 
down to the DME unit, after a few phone calls they find out that i fix 
DME's and send it to me.

Cause/effect:  Incorrectly putting B+ voltage on pin 11 will BLOW the
proprietary Bosch injection controller chip on the analog board inside the 
DME and render it useless.  The car will turn over with the starter, the 
plugs will spark, the fuel pump will pressurize, but there will be no fuel 
injection.

Reason:   Pin 11 of the DME is an output not an input, it outputs  the fuel
injection pulse width as a 12 volt signal  TO the tach.  The special Bosch 
chip is an analog driver for both the injector stages and the tach.

Repairs:  The repair is easy--replace the chip.  The hard part is to obtain 
replacement chips.  If anyone has a connection to BOSCH to get chips i 
would be interested, or if you have DME problems give me a call.  
- ---------------------------
- --ken house--(800)-752-9574--plans to get an internet line and join pfiles
- ---------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 09:41:56 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: stalling 911SC

Sounds like a classic case of bad warm-up regulator.  You say it is only 3
years old?  My '76 is on its third.  I've heard that these things are capable
of crapping out in amazingly short periods of time.  Before ordering, though,
run a control pressure test on the thing.  If you don't have the gauges, a
shop should be able to do it for you for about $20.  This test will tell for
sure whether it's the regulator or not.

Have fun,

Mike 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 10:14:54 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: 944 rear hatch

To continue a thread--
There are a couple of important points to be considered when dealing with the
rear hatch on the 944 series.
1. The electrical release or the use of the key ONLY is supposed to release
the hatch. It should NOT raise itself when this is activated.
2. The hood shocks provide two services. The prevent the hatch from raising
abruptly and once raised they prevent the hatch from coming back down without
your intervention.
3. If the hatch flies up on it's own accord, in an abrupt manner,  you are
going to end up with some expensive repairs. For instance the hinges and the
mounting for the hinges can break or become distorted. One poor sole told me
his hatch glass fractured when it hit the stops.
4. The point is the hatch should stay in place or rise up very gently when
the release is activated. Any other behavior is not acceptable.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 10:22:30 -0400

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 10:22:35 -0400
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: DME Flash Fires

>Check the amperage on the +12v line coming into the DME box.  My bet is that
>the car is frying your DME's with too many amps.  Probably doesn't blow the
>fuse, but still fries.  

>It really can't be anything else.  Electronics burn up because of incorrect
>voltage or amperage.

>NotWise@AOL.com

>84 Blk/Blk/Tail 911 Carrera


This is not meant as a "flame" (pun intended) NotWise, but you can't "push"
amps into a load. If the DME boxes were defective (i.e. shorted internally),
then they could be drawing more amperage than desireable, but this is
unlikely with 3 different units. Also, it is difficult in a car to find more
than nominally +12 volts.

I suspect our friend's problem is simply a miswired harness for the
particular model DME he is using. I recall a posting here a few months ago
about DMEs from 3.6s and 3.2s, or some such combination. An input to one
model is an output on another. Very "friable" situation!

Regards,
  Lou Krieg
  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
  LouKrieg@aol.com

P.S. As this is a "friendly" list, a personal name is always welcome, in
addition to a mail address.

Thanks for the info.  I didn't know that the PCA Club Racing editor
was out there in the e-world.

Yes, I think an upload of the newsletter would be cool.  However, I
don't have FTP access to the Internet and so would have to rely,
personally, on someone's forwarding it to me.

Related request:  I am not a racer, but I wrench on a number of racers'
cars.  F'rinstance, look in the new issue of Pano at the lead photo
in Ken F.'s story about the Bridgehampton race.  See the blue '69 911T
on the right?  Jerry and I rebuilt his engine that AM in the paddock,
after he missed a shift the previous day.  (He won.)

But do *we* ever see the newsletter?  Nooooo.  So, if there were any
way you could make its distribution available to us, way cool.  We'd
also probably be thrilled at the chance to pick up litte chachkis like
the decal and so forth.  We usually *do* manage to get t-shirts,
because Driver A (or B or C) standing around sorta bored and feeling
guilty that, once again, we are pulling his ashes from the fire,
buys them for us.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: 15 Oct 94 21:46:34 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: CD-1 madness

 
>All the Blau units sound virtually the same anyway. (I'm standing by for
>incoming flames on this one.)
 
No flames here. I am firmly convinced that while the Germans can build
incredible cars, they cannot do diddley with car radios. That goes for
Blaupunkt and Becker. Beckers are even worse, IMHO, with all their
multi-function buttons and menus and stuff. Sure, after you've driven
around for a while with the radio manual open on your lap, you know how all
this works. But I think radio knobs should work intuitively.
 
The problem I've always had with Blaupunkt is the price/performance
tradeoff. The Japanese do it better, cheaper. But in a 911, I figure no
matter what you do, you're competing with a basically noisy engine
configuration anyway, big volumes for speakers are hard to find, and there's
no point in trying to get concert hall sound in a small sports car. So on
that basis I can tolerate Blaupunkt sound, if not the price.
 
Pete
 
2x 1965 356 C/SC with original Blaupunkts that work and get shortwave
(tune in at night to get orders from surfaced German submarine)
 
and a stack of 1964 Blaupunkt Frankfurt cores, just in case.
 


------------------------------

Date: 15 Oct 94 21:46:38 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Auto book prices

I just bought an interesting book, "High Performance: The Culture and
Technology of Drag Racing" by Robert C. Post. It's a well done, scholarly
work by the curator of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American
History. Publisher is Johns Hopkins University Press, it's one in the Johns
Hopkins Studies in the History of Technology series. How's that for going
mainstream? How about a doctoral thesis on the psychography of PCA members?
Or the flame wars on Internet?
 
Anyway, the point of all this is that the latest Motorbooks flyer is on
the current toilet reading stack, and I just saw it in there for $35.95. Add
to that shipping and tax (yes, I have to pay tax although I'm in CA and
they're in WI; their masters are in CA) and we're talking $40 plus. I just
got mine from the local Barnes & Noble; it took one day to order, and the
discounted price is $28.76. With tax, $30.99.
 
That's a 20% saving, closer to 25% if you count shipping. I used to order
a lot from Motorbooks, but they stopped giving volume discounts so now I
buy from Autobooks in Burbank (same price, no shipping) or the local
bookstores. I still get my books, I get them cheaper, and more of the
money stays in the local economy.
 
Support your local full-service bookstore!
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 20:31:31 -0800
From: branick@netcom.com (Robert L. Branick)
Subject: Referee!

Has anyone out there in P-phile land gone through the (California) referee
process with regards to getting your baby smogged?

A little background:  This is a 1977 911S that I bought in 1988.  It was
already on its second engine when it came into my possession, and,
naturally, the thermal reactors and air pump were conveniently left off.
The previous owners provided me with a smog certificate, and, yes, told me
that the emissions stuff was missing.

A little more background:  I've successfully smogged the car twice before.
Obviously the establishments didn't quite know what to look for in the
visual, but the sniffer part was honestly passed.  Says a lot for the value
of those thermal afterburners, doesn't it?

OK, it didn't work this last time.  I tried to play dumb, but no cigar.  I
think I'd rather just do the Referee thing and get it over with.  Or do I?
What can I expect, given my circumstances?  Will the head linesman throw a
flag, blow his whistle and say, "Sorry, you have to rebuild your engine and
make it smog legal."?  Yeah, YOU tell my wife!

Thanks for any insight anyone can offer.

Bob



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 20:55:36 -0700 (PDT)
From: pft@netcom.com (Patrick Ford Trumbull)
Subject: a few questions


	I have started using my 914 as a daily driver, which is a
	hundred or so miles a day, and I have a couple questions.
	I put a 2.4 cis motor in it, and the oil tank is of unknown
	origin, and the oil cooler is 911, not 914-6.  The tank does
	not have a drain plug, which makes oil changes VERY time
	consuming.  My first question is can I cut one of the rubber
	oil lines and put some sort of a t in it that I can use to 
	drain it?  If so, which hose?  The 2nd question is about the
	ignition.  It has a relay plate with the CDS box on it, but at
	some time the motor has been switched to points and coil ig-
	nition.  I think I can probably pass smog (California) as is
	but I wonder what I am missing.  I have not had any real plug
	fouling problems, but it does load up a bit after warm starts,
	and takes a bit of running to clear out. (Reminds me of my
	2-strokes)

        Patrick
        pft@netcom.com     
        bunch of cars
        bunch of motorcycles
        bunch of pets, etc

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 1994 00:03:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: Clocks

On Fri, 14 Oct 1994, Hartje, Will wrote:

> I need to replace the quartz clock in my 84 944. The replacement part is 944 
> 641 115 00. The price quoted by my friendlt Porsche dealer is $135 list but 
> I can have it for $110.
> 
Speaking of clocks, I notice the digital LCD clock in my '86 944 has no
backlight. Is it supposed to light up at night when the parking lights are
switched on? If so, is it possible to replace the bulb? It's hard to
believe Porsche would put in an unlighted clock. 

Chris
'86 944

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 0:00:49 CDT
From: husain@zeus1.issc.com (Afsar Husain (N3564))
Subject: Re: Sunroof revisited

> 
> 
> That leaves the sunroof/radio relay. The radio works fine, but I am not sure 
> what role this relay plays in sunroof operation. on inspecting the relay it 
> seems to be a complex  beast with chips and transistors in it. Can somebody 
> tell me if it is possible to test these things to ensure that they are 
> working correctly?
> 
> Any advice would be appreciated
> 
> 
> Will Hartje
>                          

   I finally got my sunroof operating perfectly (knock on wood).
The problem was the sunroof relay. New relay is expensive but
I picked up a used relay from a fellow list member George of 
944 Ecology. I must remind you that another fellow list member
Jim Pasha had an article in Excellence magazine on the subject of
buying used Porsche parts and he adviced against buying used
electrical parts.

I tend to agree with Jim but if you can pick one up relatively cheap
(i.e $10-$20) then I must say you should go for it. An ideal situation
would be to find a used part dealer locally, where you can check the
relay in your car and ensuring a proper sunroof operation. This will save
you shipping charges along with the satisfaction that you paid for
something that resolved the problem.

If luck is NOT on your side and you end up burning the used relay than
think of the money spent, as cost of trouble shooting and isolating the 
problem. Then replaced the relay with a new one. 

 I did opened my old relay, it has two circuit boards and a few,
what looks like a micro-processor. One of the resistor and the attach
point on the PC board looks burned ( dark area on the PC board ) but
thats about the extent of my trouble shooting. I think that without the
schematic it is going to be tough job but I am planning to tackle it
in future.

PS> With all the 944 owner having this problem I am wondering if Porsche,
	North America is aware of this problem and has there ever been a reall
	of this relay by Porsche?


Regards,
Husain.

- -- 
e-mail: husain@zeus1.issc.com

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 06:19:42 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Clocks

                                              
> Speaking of clocks, I notice the digital LCD clock in my '86 944 has no
> backlight. Is it supposed to light up at night when the parking lights are
> switched on? If so, is it possible to replace the bulb? It's hard to
> believe Porsche would put in an unlighted clock. 
> 

Hi, Chris,

Yes the digital lcd clock in the series II 944s are backlit.  Bulb
replacement is not a trivial task, but can be done.

Steve Ross of Northeast Region PCA wrote an article for their newsletter a
couple of years ago about a procedure to replace the bulb, but I don't have
a copy.

Plan on $3 for the bulb and 100 for the labor, unless you do it yourself.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: 16 Oct 94 10:52:46 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Carrera Cup roll cage

 
Hi, Phil.
 
Here's what happened, to the best of my recollection.
 
1) Porsche built what, 20 cars for Carrera Cup. Cars were brought in as
street legal machines.
2) Andial gutted the cars, installed roll cages to make them racers.
3) Series never happened.
4) Roll cages were cut out of cars to return them to street status.
5) Cars were eventually sold off. Many customers wanted the roll cages back
in them, so in they went again.
 
I would suggest that your reader contact Andial directly. If they don't have
any cages left over, I'm sure they still have the drawings and would be
happy to make a fresh copy for him and install it. Andial is sort of the
factory U.S. west coast skunk works. They have a very close relationship to
the factory racing department. I've stopped by there and found Porsche
executives "just looking around. We're on vacation." Uh-huh.
 
Andial Road & Racing
3207 S. Shannon
Santa Ana, CA
714-937-3900
 
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 11:37:28 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: PCA thing


Hi, Bart - 

Had to get back to you about the 'clubbiness' of the porschers
at Wiesbaden, back then. It wasn't too long after your tenure
there in '63-'65 that Gen. David Jones, CINC USAFE, (can you
spell as***le) decreed that the entire headquarters unit be
moved to Ramstein AB. You know as well as I do that that is
like moving from New York City to Peoria. So they got their
comeuppance. Seems that when I was at Ramstein, '75-'79, one
of my NCOs was (gasp!) a member of the local club and was
having a great time in his 356. It was still going strong
when Pete said he atteneded some events down at Zweibruken 
in the early '80's. So justice does seem to have been served.
(Except that Davy Jones became Chairman, Joint Chiefs of Staff
after the USAFE tour which solidly proves the adage of the
more incompetent, the higher the rise).

Herb

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 1994 10:41:14 +0500
From: myers@land.vf.ge.com (Herbert D Myers - MMC)
Subject: Blaupunktisms


Dear Sir,

I've been exposed to different Blaupunkts over the past
2 decades or so and I cannot, to this day tell if they are
any good. Every car, 3 Rabbits, 1 GTI, 1 Campmobile,
2 Vanagons and 944 porch, has drowned out everything
except Jimmy Page doing his great riff in "Black Dog".
The one exception was the brand new '88 Volvo 244:
not bad for $623 option! And it worked fine until a 
daughter rammed her 'New Boys on the Block' tape into
it and jammed it permanently. It was still under 
warranty so the dealer reluctently replaced it. The
very next day, my soon-to-be-ex- totaled the whole
car! My last adventure with said brand was after getting
the 944, I immediately replaced the orginal Bpkt with
the Chicago (?) that played CDs. Misss-take. The CD skipped
so bad I thought I was back at a sock-hop and the damn
tuner buttons were hard to see there on the bottom of
the stack. Well after about 8 months of it sitting a
couple inches away from the exhaust, the CD mechinism
was toasted and wouldn't work anyway. Then some dumbs**t
stole it (it was a pop-out) and I got the insurance
money for it!
But I think the thing I won't forget is turning that 
brand new Blaupunkt over when I got it and seeing that
it was made in Taiwan! 
Sorry to go on but I'm glad to see that the 'mystique'
of the German radio being as good as the car is not true. 

Herb

(ahhh...Pete, ole buddy, I don't think the Kommandant will
  be very happy when he finds out you told every one about
  the sub! I sure wouldn't want to be in you shoes....)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 20:58:01 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 1986 944 Turbo Wheels

> What size wheels were standard on a 1986 944 Turbo? What size wheels were
> available as options? Were these wheels Fuchs? Phone dials? I need this
> information for a friend who is contemplating the purchase of a 1986 944T.
> Thanks for any information. 

Hi, Tom,

For the 86 944 Turbo, two wheel arrangements were available\:

7x16 Front, 8x16 Rear Fuchs Forged Wheels
7x16 Front, 8x16 Rear Cast Phone Dial Wheels.

Those wheels were equipped with a 23.3 mm offset (that number can be found
on the inside of the wheel center - e.g. ET 23.3).  Wheels for 1987 and
later cars used a 52.3 mm or 65 mm offset and should not be used on the 86 or
earlier cars.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 21:00 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 911 OEL- Light

Dustin,

The sender on the cam oil line boss is for oil pressure, not the oil
light.  They are separate.  The oil light switch is at the other end
of the engine.

I don't know why you are having a problem getting your thermostat out.
I think, like you, that it ought to come out pretty directly.  But
what do I know...

Kevin

Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 21:08 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Torsen, Quaife, ...?

My sum knowledge of differentials comes from reading "The Racing
Differential," written by Carroll Smith as a supplement to a recent
issue of Racecar Engineering.  He describes both Torsen and Quaiffe,
and mentions that they are "fundamentally very different."

Rather than my paraphrasing a lot of text I barely graps, I would
recommend that any interested pick up a copy, available from EWA.

Kevin

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 00:55:47 -0500 (CDT)
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Re: Apparent problem with mail to saic.com

In case any of this makes it through the relevant subscribers, or in case 
any of you happen to have other correspondence with any listmembers at SAIC, 
I thought might share this tidbit with you.

It is common for all-of-a-sudden mail to stop working to everyone at
a particular company or institution. It usually has as a root cause
someone having reconfigured something, and can be quickly fixed once
the necessary people know about it. So, when I started having significant
trouble with mail to the half-dozen SAIC employees  on the list it didn't
bother me too much. When it didn't let up in a day or so, I decided to
send the usual polite note to the postmaster *and* root at SAIC since
that way at least someone would get the message. Started off "Gentlemen"
since it was going to two people, etc.

In response, I get this:

> First of all, the postmaster here is not a gentleman, I am a woman.
> Secondly, since this is not a business related issue for SAIC I will not
> devote any time to look into this problem.  Delete these users or send them
> mail to unsubcribe to this list.

So, in the event that I have to drop the people at SAIC, that's what 
happened. This is the *FIRST* time I've been dealt with in such a manner.
Just an FYI.

Stan Hanks,
ListMeister

------------------------------

or even Good for that matter, but *Drinkable.  Dortmunder Union, maybe one
or two others.

otherwise rational folks have a taste for it, so who am I to judge, the same
rule applies.  (If you need proof, consider what they serve in Ol' Blimey...

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 9:39:11 EDT
From: Brian Abernathy <cba@atl.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 914 keys.

When I bought my 914 (NEW!), it came with two sets of keys:  One black,
which would open EVERYTHING, and one red one, which was the valet key.
It would unlock the doors, and start the car.  It would not unlock the
trunks, or the glovebox.

Upon examination, the keys were IDENTICAL, except the red one had an
extra notch in the top of the key, apparently made into the key blank,
so it would be possible to take the black key to a dealer, and get
another valet key cut, or vice versa.

(Lost my valet key years ago!)

- --

Date: 17 Oct 94 09:24:34 EDT
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: 944/951 Clock bulb Replacement 

I found this in the archives for those who are interested in changing
the clock bulb in the 85/1/2 944 series and newer. Thanks to milo Dorr!

I will be doing this soon also. Mine jus went.

****************************************************************************

Subject: Replacing 944/951 clock bulbs        (Friday  Dec.4  1992)


I got a number of requests for my offered procedure for replacing the
clock bulb in 944/951s.  Since this seems to be a fairly common
problem, I would like to post it here, at least for the sake of our
archives.

 -Milo

____________________________________________________________________________

My approach to replacing the clock bulb in an 85.5+ 944 (inc. Turbo)
involves removing (at least partially) the part of the dash that
contains the hazard flasher switch, clock module and cigarette
lighter.  This is a long plastic strip that is attached to the dash at
four points.  To remove it:

1.  Remove the plastic plate that covers the heating/AC control unit
in the dash.  To do this, you must first pull off the knobs on the two
slider switches that control the vents that send air to your feet and the
windshield.  These are just pressed on and will come off with
a gentle tug.  The control unit face plate is also just pressed on,
and can be removed by gently prying it out with a screwdriver or putty
knife at several points.  Take your time with this, since the plate is
not very thick at some points and is easy to crack if bent too much.
After you have the plate off, unscrew the four Philips head screws
that mount the heating/AC control unit to the dash.  Slide the control
unit out about 1" to get it out of the way a bit (it is not necessary
to disconnect or remove it).

2.  Locate the passenger compartment temperature sensor, which is
under the round, 5-slotted grate immediately to the right of the
cigarette lighter.  Remove the grate by inserting a coin and rotating
the grate counterclockwise until it pops out.  Remove the small
Philips head screw underneath the sensor hole.

3.  Continuing to the right along the dash, locate the (approx .5" x
1.5") rectangular cover plate to the left of the side vent.  Gently
pry this plate off using the slot at the bottom.  Underneath, you will
see two Philips head screws that you will also remove.

4.  Finally, open the passenger side door and observe that the end of
the dash is covered by a plastic plate attached by a Philips head
screw at its center.  Remove the screw and the plate.  This will allow
you to then remove the last Philips head screw attaching the end of
plastic strip we are wanting to remove.

At this point, the only things holding the strip (other than a snug
fit) are the electrical connections to the hazard flasher switch,
clock, cigarette lighter (and its light bulb).  It is probably best to
go ahead and disconnect all of these so that you can completely remove
the strip and have easy access to the back of the clock (which comes
out with the strip).  You might be able to sneak a new bulb into the
clock with some of these connections still attached, depending on your
dexterity.

The clock bulb has a "squarish" base that protrudes from the back of
the clock module.  Simply rotate it 90 degrees, remove and replace it.
I'm not sure how common these bulbs are.  I got mine from an
independent repair shop, but dealers should definitely have it.

As they say "installation is the reverse of removal" :-).



- ------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 10:06:53 -0400
From: Andre Rotchel <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
Subject: 944 steering vibrations


Hi,

last time I had my steering vibrating on 
the highway, my mechanic told me that my front
suspensions needed to be changed. So it was 
diagnosed and so it was repaired. The vibrations 
were gone for 2 years and a half... 

Now the vibrations are back. I've been told that 
Montreal "roads" (i.e. pothole sequences) are 
capable of destroying suspensions within 2 years.

Could this be the case or is there other ailments 
associated with this symptom?

Regards,
Andre Rotchel.
944 '86, 80000 miles.

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 09:03:03 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Cd-1 madness (or do they always break?)

Subject: CD-1 madness
 
>>All the Blau units sound virtually the same anyway. (I'm standing by for
>>incoming flames on this one.)
   Pete Albrecht replies;
>No flames here. I am firmly convinced that while the Germans can build
>incredible cars, they cannot do diddley with car radios. That goes for
>Blaupunkt and Becker....The problem I've always had with Blaupunkt is the
>price/performance tradeoff. The Japanese do it better, cheaper. But in a 
911, I
>figure no matter what you do, you're competing with a basically noisy engine
>configuration anyway, big volumes for speakers are hard to find, and there's
>so point in trying to get concert hall sound in a small sports car. So on
>that basis I can tolerate Blaupunkt sound, if not the price.
 
    Several years ago, I was at Delco's radio/test engineering facility
  in Kokomo, and ran across the guy who tested OEM cassette transports
  (of course, Delco buys these). Who made the best transport ? "Clarion".
  Who made the worst ? "Blaupunkt".
    Nearly every Porsche I've ever bought had a Blaupunkt in it, and they
  were -all- broken. In the mid-70's at least, Blaupunkt only guaranteed
  their tape decks with 60-minute cassettes, when 90 minutes was already
  the standard. with such experience I'll never get close to their CD unit.
    I agree also with Pete's assessment of ambient noise; an audiophile
  and a Porschephile cannot simultaneously exist. It is downright
  silly to talk about CD-quality signal-to-noise ratio and 96DB dynamic
  range in a 911 (there is some hope in a 928 or maybe a 944). I tried
  before with extra amps,eq, speakers in all corners, but as soon as you turn
  the key its all wasted effort.

           - Lee A. gave up and use $120 radios
