Date: 17 Oct 1994 09:36:58 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 / 912E intake mani

Re>> 914 / 912E intake manifold question
>> I have been thinking about upgrading the 1.8L engine on my 914 to a 2.0L 
>> model.  I would like
>> to keep it fuel injected, possibly the AFC unit currently on my 1.8L.  If 
>> I do that, it sounds like
>> a set of 912E intake manifolds might be an answer to the bolt pattern
problem.
>> 
>> Anyone done this before?  Thanks,
>
>Nope, but it shouldn't be too hard. 

    I learned this talking to Stan about (almost) the same subject quite a
while
ago:  Stan's definition of "not too hard" is *not* the same as others' (mine,
for
instance).
    It shouldn't be too bad (maybe) if you *start* with 2.0L heads and
exhaust.
But those are the priciest bits, so you might as well go with the full 2.0L
FI,
right?  Putting 2.0L P&C's on the 1.8L case/heads/etc is non-trivial. 
Something
about deck height requires machining the case or the cylinders...  I don't
re-
member the details, sorry.  Not at all hard for Stan, but not something I
wanted
to pay someone else to tackle for me.  (I don't build 914 racers regularly
for
fun...)
    If I remember correctly, Stan told me that the AFC FI from the 1.8L would
work fine with 2.0L displacement, even with higher ("Euro") compression.  So
if
you can do/have the machining done, it may then turn into a "bolt-on"
operation.

- --DD

Hi Steve,

Those of us lucky to have been Cold-warriors, and even more fortunate to
have been stationed in Dear old Deutschland got quite a rude awakening when
we learned that every male German citizen, upon graduation from middle
school, is issued a brief-case; pre-stocked with a loaf of (great) bread, a
kilo of fantastic Wurst (of his choice, depending on the state he resides
in), and (at least) two half-liter flip-top bottles of Local Bier.

I'm fairly certain that this is *Guaranteed* by the German Constitution,
that also mandates regular breaks during the work day, during which the
contents of said brief-case, representing that which is good and wholesome
in life, are to be savored in the appropriatly reverential and grateful
spirit.  Then, again, I could be as full of sh*t as a Christmas turkey,
who's to say...???


Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 12:50:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Re: 930 Spark Plugs

On Mon, 17 Oct 1994, Kevin Hughes wrote:

> For the uninitiated what are Split Fire Plugs????? what advantage are they
> intended to give? and whats the cost differential?????

Kevin:

This is snake oil sold in the USA. The plug has the tip of the electrode
split into a "Y". No other differences. It's heavily marketed on TV. THe
price is about 5X what a normal brand name plug list. They also sell their
own brand of plug wire -- with, you guessed it, two parallel wires going
from distributor to plug. Pure marketing hype -- think of it as the Zymol
of spark plugs; the Duralube of spark plug; or the Slick-50 of spark plugs.

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 10:15:00 PDT
From: "Hartje, Will" <whartje@smtpgw3.az05.bull.com>
Subject: Phoenix Time Trial


What a fun weekend we just had at the PCA Time Trial/Drivers Ed on the IMSA 
track at PIR in Phoenix.
Saturday morning greeted the 99 cars entered with uncharacteristic rain 
which kept the slick-equipped racers in the garage for the first two 
practice sessions. While us low life street legal types waltzed all over the 
track.

The field consist of a broad cross section of  Porsches from old tired daily 
drivers with numbers slapped on the doors to race prepped  914 s and 911 s 
to  Tom Congleton s exotic collection , a 906., a 907 and a 917K

By midday the track was dry and out came the likes of Martin Snow (lapping 
at 1.03) and Tom Congleton s exotics  As the weather improved the times 
quickened and at the end of the day POC ran a club race in their series. The 
incident du jour was when Martin Snow got inside the 917K at turn 2 and 
nudged  the $1,000,000 plus vintage race car into a spin. Fortunately, the 
contact was only with the tire of the 917k but the nose of Snow s 911 was 
well knocked about forcing him out of a race that he was leading by nearly a 
lap conceding  the race to a yellow and black  race prepared  914-6 ( sorry 
I don t have the entry list so I can t give you his name) .

Sunday was cold, - yes cold!, but dry. The rain threatened but never 
materialized. There were two more practice session s before the timed runs 
were started. The time trials were completed by early afternoon and POC 
again put on club racing. Snow gave another driving exhibition clocking at 
least one lap in the 1.02 s but the star of the race was the vintage 907 
that started near the back of the field and came storming through the pack 
to take second place on the penultimate lap of the race, Snow was way to far 
ahead to be caught.

It was a great weekend from both a participation and viewing perspective, 
Both the PCA and POC crowd are friendly and helpful. There is much you can 
learn from just wandering round the pits and talking to people, not to 
mention what you can learn out on the track.

To those of you that have been ,asking about drivers ed and racing, I 
thoroughly recommend you get out to one of these events soon.  -It s a blast 
and a great education. For those of you within driving distance of Phoenix, 
we will be out there again in February

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 10:58:30 PDT
From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM" <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>
Subject: 944 oily wheels


Hi, 
 
              I has spend the weekend driving around skyline and 
              Mt. Hamilton (bay area, CA) and had the oppurtunity 
              to do some spirited driving on the fast twisty roads 
              The suspension and brakes were under some load (tires 
              squealing etc...). After the drive, I noticed a thin 
              black oily film on both the front wheels (the car 
              was washed just before the drive). I had noticed the 
              oil on the wheels before but was very little and over 
              a long period of time/driving. There is no significant 
              drop in any oil levels but I am not sure. What could be 
              the reason? Any help would be appreciated. 
 
              PS: I flashed at a couple of 911's on the twisties but 
              they didn't even blink their eyes back ;-) 
 
thanks 
Sreelal 
84 944 
metallic burgundy

Date: 17 Oct 1994 11:09:28 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  How many keys for 914?

RE> How many keys for 914?
>How many distinct keys should there be for a 914 (1974 if it makes a
>difference).

    One.  Well, okay, I guess the "valet key" might be the second one,
but there should be one key that does all the locks.  My 74 914s came
with two keys for the 1.8L, four (!!!) for the 2.0L.  The 1.8 is down
to 1 key, the 2.0 down to 2.  And that'll go to one key whenever I
get 'round to taking the trunk pull out.  (yech!)
    If the car's been broken into, the drivers and ignition may very
well be replacements.  But the doors and rear trunk locks are nearly
trivial to remove.  E-mail me for details.  I got quotes of $10-15
per lock to re-key them to a specific key (my ignition key).

- --DD
Dave Darling, graphics_group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 14:35:43 EDT
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: 911 option codes -- where listed on car?

Hi

Where are the option codes listed on my '83 911? I bought it used and
I'd like to know what suspension option it came with, because it's got
Bilstein (green) shocks installed.

I'm wondering if the car came from the factory with Bilstein shocks and
the appropriate torsion bars and anti-roll bars, or if the Bilsteins were
added later without upgrading the suspension.

So I guess my other question is, can I tell by looking at the struts,
torsion bars, and/or anti-roll bars, what type they are and whether they're
matched to the Bilsteins?

Actually, even if I *do* have the big torsion bars, can I put softer shocks
on the front and back and get a slightly softer ride, or must I change to
the softer torsion bars and/or anti-roll bars?

Thanks in advance!
Stefan

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 15:09:49 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: "Oily" 944 wheels

Sreelal,

I suspect, especially since the "oil" appears on both front wheels, that what
you see is a combination of pad dust from your dirty factory pads combined
with road grim,oil/tar.  You might want to dry some non-factory type pads,
like Repco DeLuxe and Metalmaster pads to reduce the wheel grime.

 -Allen Henderson-

------------------------------

Date: Mon, Oct 17, 1994 3:20 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: PCA thing (long, what else?) (fwd)

Hi Herb, Jim, Phello Philes,

Good to hear from you, thanks for jogging my (alleged) memory!

> Had to get back to you about the 'clubbiness' of the porschers
> at Wiesbaden, back then. 

You know, I got to thinking about this business and remembered something I
had long forgotten.  One of the most obnoxious guys in Wiesbaden turned out
to be a pretty nice guy when I ran into him 3 or so years in Saigon. I had
just arrived in Tan Son Nhut in May of '68, just a few weeks after the
shooting had stopped (more or less) from Tet and ran into him at the USAF
O'club.  He spoke to me first, as I hadn't recognized him at first.  We had
a couple of drinks at the bar, and he asked me where I was staying.  I told
him I had just arrived about 30 min prior to meeting him, and planned to
stay in the VOQ.  He offered me a place in the house he was sharing with 4
other AF Officers, as soon as the current "short-timer" rotated, which was
a week away.  I took him up on the offer, and lived there for about 6
months.

It was a pretty good base to get to know Saigon from.  The house shared
side walls with the houses on both sides (a town-house) and was 4 stories
high, with the fourth floor having a single large bedroom and attached
bathroom. The rest of the floor was Penthouse terrace, covered with terrazo
pavers and included a T-shapped Khoi pond, about two feet deep and a meter
wide. The shaft and top of the T were about 13 meters each, and the pool
complete with a good number of *large* Khoi, 12 to 24 inchers (!).

The AF had obviously occupied that house for several years, there was an
elaborate, thached-roofed bar with stools, refridgerator and three-burner
electric stove; and a large steel column out in the middle of the terrace
piercing a circular hand-made aluminum table top about 10 feed in diameter,
and supporting a large parasol roof, about 15 feet in diameter, to shelter
us from the monsoon.  Each evening, we'd gather around the table as we
dutifuly took our daily anti-malarial quinnine (suitably fortified with gin
or vodka) and watched the war go on around us.  Darkness would fall, Hueys
would start flying the perimeter of Saigon, probing the night with their
searchlights, and streams of orange tracers would rise from the ground
seeking them out like a bunch of glowing streams of water.  These, in turn,
would be answered by similar earth-bound streams from the Cobra gun-ships.
We had front-row seats, far enough from the action to be able to enjoy it,
and high enough and close-enough to appreciate it!  A civilized way to do a
war, to be sure.

[snip]

> It wasn't too long after your tenure
> there in '63-'65 that Gen. David Jones, CINC USAFE, (can you
> spell as***le) decreed that the entire headquarters unit be
> moved to Ramstein AB.[snip] So justice does seem to have been served.
> (Except that Davy Jones became Chairman, Joint Chiefs of Staff
> after the USAFE tour which solidly proves the adage of the
> more incompetent, the higher the rise).

Hmmm, wasn't he *busted* (relieved of command) due to "Foot-in-mouth" 
disease during Desert Storm?  (or was that some *other* AF general...)?

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Guards Red
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)


------------------------------

Date: 17 Oct 94 13:02:00 -0500
From: /DDV=SATCOM1/DDT=CCMAILPO/I=Ann/G=Miller/S=Dr._P25430/OU2=SATCG/OU=AZBH/P=MOT/A=MOT/C=US/@email.mot.com
Subject: Club Racing 

There have been several e-mail notes recently about PCA racing -- as a note from 
a novice whose initiation was this past weekend (rainy Saturday, dry Sunday) at 
Phoenix International Raceway -- GO FOR IT!  

You get 2 hours of raceway driving on day 1, an hour on day 2 plus the thrill of 
the timed laps.  There's lots of good Porsche-speak and Porsche-friends, too.

Special thanks to Phil Ryan (a e-porschephiler, too) and all who organized the 
PIR time trials.  In addition, there were POC cup races as well.  Both days, 
drivers and spectators managed to see lots of beautiful Porsches, including a 
906, a 907, and a 917  (no typos, you read it right).  In fact, the event T-
shirt featured the nose of the 917 in a rear-view mirror with the slogan "Toto, 
I don't think we're in Kansas anymore".

So, if you've been thinking about it, try it out. Also, some of the other clubs 
may invite your local PCA to join to halp in cost-sharing.  So you have several 
avenues, so to speak. 

And to all porschephiles in or around or just motoring through Zone 8, the next 
scheduled event will be in February and there will be a porschephiles posting.

AM 

======================================================================  

Ann Miller
'93 911 RS America (daily driver as well)
3 Scottish Deerhounds
1 Borzoi
1 hound hauler (aka non-Porsche)
E-mail:  miller@sat.mot.com     or    Ann_Miller-P25430@email.mot.com
======================================================================

>Date: Sat, 15 Oct 94 08:13 EST
>From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
>Subject: Fwd: Motronic Warning
>
>M. Christian Holmgreen -
>
>This was posted to Porschephiles last May.  Perhaps it is your problem.
>I would just go through the wiring diagram for the 3.2, and identify
>the signals it expects at each of its pins.
>
>Kevin Gross
>
> - - -
>
>forwarded message from ken house:
>
>This note is a caution to those people who are retrofitting a 3.2l  Carrera 
>engine into an earlier model 911.  i just finished repairing two more DME 
>(Motronic) control units that were damaged by incorrect wiring.  The cause 
>of this particular failure mode has occurred so frequently that a word of 
>warning is warranted.
>
>Scenario: An early model 911 owner/racer buys a 3.2 motor with wiring 
>harness and DME control unit, but usually does not buy the tachometer.  
>Installation is straight-forward until the wires to the tachometer are 
>encountered.  The Motronic tachs are microprocessor-based electronic units 
>with two wires coming from the DME unit.  For some reason the wire to pin 
>11 of the DME gets connected to a +12 volt line under the dash.  The 
>installation gets completed, and the key is turned to start the car --zap-- 
>it won't start.  After much time and trouble someone narrows the problem 
>down to the DME unit, after a few phone calls they find out that i fix 
>DME's and send it to me.
>
>Cause/effect:  Incorrectly putting B+ voltage on pin 11 will BLOW the
>proprietary Bosch injection controller chip on the analog board inside the 
>DME and render it useless.  The car will turn over with the starter, the 
>plugs will spark, the fuel pump will pressurize, but there will be no fuel 
>injection.
>
>Reason:   Pin 11 of the DME is an output not an input, it outputs  the fuel
>injection pulse width as a 12 volt signal  TO the tach.  The special Bosch 
>chip is an analog driver for both the injector stages and the tach.
>
>Repairs:  The repair is easy--replace the chip.  The hard part is to obtain 
>replacement chips.  If anyone has a connection to BOSCH to get chips i 
>would be interested, or if you have DME problems give me a call.  
>- ---------------------------
>- --ken house--(800)-752-9574--plans to get an internet line and join pfiles
>- ---------------------------
>
>
>------------------------------

>Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 09:41:56 -0400
>From: MLBDayton@aol.com
>Subject: Re: stalling 911SC
>
>Sounds like a classic case of bad warm-up regulator.  You say it is only 3
>years old?  My '76 is on its third.  I've heard that these things are capable
>of crapping out in amazingly short periods of time.  Before ordering, though,
>run a control pressure test on the thing.  If you don't have the gauges, a
>shop should be able to do it for you for about $20.  This test will tell for
>sure whether it's the regulator or not.
>
>Have fun,
>
>Mike 
>
>------------------------------
>
>Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 10:14:54 -0400
>From: Jerry944T@aol.com
>Subject: 944 rear hatch
>
>To continue a thread--
>There are a couple of important points to be considered when dealing with the
>rear hatch on the 944 series.
>1. The electrical release or the use of the key ONLY is supposed to release
>the hatch. It should NOT raise itself when this is activated.
>2. The hood shocks provide two services. The prevent the hatch from raising
>abruptly and once raised they prevent the hatch from coming back down without
>your intervention.
>3. If the hatch flies up on it's own accord, in an abrupt manner,  you are
>going to end up with some expensive repairs. For instance the hinges and the
>mounting for the hinges can break or become distorted. One poor sole told me
>his hatch glass fractured when it hit the stops.
>4. The point is the hatch should stay in place or rise up very gently when
>the release is activated. Any other behavior is not acceptable.
>
>Regards,
>Jerry
>89 944turbo S black (track Car)
>89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
>
>

>Date: Sat, 15 Oct 1994 10:22:35 -0400
>From: LouKrieg@aol.com
>Subject: Re: DME Flash Fires
>
>>Check the amperage on the +12v line coming into the DME box.  My bet is that
>>the car is frying your DME's with too many amps.  Probably doesn't blow the
>>fuse, but still fries.  
>
>>It really can't be anything else.  Electronics burn up because of incorrect
>>voltage or amperage.
>
>>NotWise@AOL.com
>
>>84 Blk/Blk/Tail 911 Carrera
>
>
>This is not meant as a "flame" (pun intended) NotWise, but you can't "push"
>amps into a load. If the DME boxes were defective (i.e. shorted internally),
>then they could be drawing more amperage than desireable, but this is
>unlikely with 3 different units. Also, it is difficult in a car to find more
>than nominally +12 volts.
>
>I suspect our friend's problem is simply a miswired harness for the
>particular model DME he is using. I recall a posting here a few months ago
>about DMEs from 3.6s and 3.2s, or some such combination. An input to one
>model is an output on another. Very "friable" situation!
>
>Regards,
>  Lou Krieg
>  '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
>  LouKrieg@aol.com
>
>P.S. As this is a "friendly" list, a personal name is always welcome, in
>addition to a mail address.
>

>Date: 15 Oct 94 21:46:34 EDT
>From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
>Subject: CD-1 madness
>
> 
>>All the Blau units sound virtually the same anyway. (I'm standing by for
>>incoming flames on this one.)
> 
>No flames here. I am firmly convinced that while the Germans can build
>incredible cars, they cannot do diddley with car radios. That goes for
>Blaupunkt and Becker. Beckers are even worse, IMHO, with all their
>multi-function buttons and menus and stuff. Sure, after you've driven
>around for a while with the radio manual open on your lap, you know how all
>this works. But I think radio knobs should work intuitively.
> 
>The problem I've always had with Blaupunkt is the price/performance
>tradeoff. The Japanese do it better, cheaper. But in a 911, I figure no
>matter what you do, you're competing with a basically noisy engine
>configuration anyway, big volumes for speakers are hard to find, and there's
>no point in trying to get concert hall sound in a small sports car. So on
>that basis I can tolerate Blaupunkt sound, if not the price.
> 
>Pete
> 
>2x 1965 356 C/SC with original Blaupunkts that work and get shortwave
>(tune in at night to get orders from surfaced German submarine)
> 
>and a stack of 1964 Blaupunkt Frankfurt cores, just in case.
> 
>
>
>------------------------------
>
>Date: 15 Oct 94 21:46:38 EDT
>From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
>Subject: Auto book prices
>
>I just bought an interesting book, "High Performance: The Culture and
>Technology of Drag Racing" by Robert C. Post. It's a well done, scholarly
>work by the curator of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American
>History. Publisher is Johns Hopkins University Press, it's one in the Johns
>Hopkins Studies in the History of Technology series. How's that for going
>mainstream? How about a doctoral thesis on the psychography of PCA members?
>Or the flame wars on Internet?
> 
>Anyway, the point of all this is that the latest Motorbooks flyer is on
>the current toilet reading stack, and I just saw it in there for $35.95. Add
>to that shipping and tax (yes, I have to pay tax although I'm in CA and
>they're in WI; their masters are in CA) and we're talking $40 plus. I just
>got mine from the local Barnes & Noble; it took one day to order, and the
>discounted price is $28.76. With tax, $30.99.
> 
>That's a 20% saving, closer to 25% if you count shipping. I used to order
>a lot from Motorbooks, but they stopped giving volume discounts so now I
>buy from Autobooks in Burbank (same price, no shipping) or the local
>bookstores. I still get my books, I get them cheaper, and more of the
>money stays in the local economy.
> 
>Support your local full-service bookstore!

>Pete

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 13:24:22 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Distributor Mechanical Advance - Update


I discovered something this weekend that might be useful 
to those of you with early 911's.  This is an interim report.

In my previous posting about slop in the mechanical 
advance mechanism I speculated that there must be a 
nylon bushing on the spring retainr studs that had worn 
away.  I contemplated making one if someone could 
confirm its existence on a good distributor, or bending the 
stud to take up the slop.  Well...no one confirmed its 
existence.  Actually, no one unconfirmed it either...

But, if you go to the trouble of pressing out the gear pin 
and removing the gear so you can slide the entire 
mechanism out of the distributor case, you will have 
access to the bottom of the advance mechanism, and 
surprise, surprise, there are two screws there that allow 
you to move the spring studs to take up any slack in the 
springs.  Which I did.

The reason this is an interim report is that I don't yet have 
it back on the car, so I am not 100% sure everything's OK.  
But it's looking very good.  Stay tuned.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E  almost finished

------------------------------

Date: 17 Oct 1994 14:06:27 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group.SIMLAB#u#1#u#N243@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: RWR AutoX

RWR AutoX
    Yup, you guessed it, another event up at the Sonoma County
Airport this past weekend.
    This one was a long course--TTOD was in the low 51's.  Hank
Watts, as usual.  He keeps bringing out his 69 E ("the Elf")
racer--I think he didn't want to lose to Scott Winders again ;-)
It was a tight battle, which wasn't decided until Hank's last
run of the day.  Unfortunately, I forget who he was battling
against...  Third place, and TTOD for much of the morning, was 
our own Eric Nichols, in his white 912--feels good to see a four-
banger placing so highly.  Bill Newton, another fast 912 pilot,
commented that Eric "is so smooth, it took him three years to wear
out his first set of tires!"
    Unfortunately, I slept through my alarm (long night...) and
missed the morning session.  Sigh...  My times were less than stel-
lar, with a 59.3 being my best official run.  My one fun run wound
up with a 58.1, and I know that there was a lot left out there.
One person (who I'm told had only been to a couple of autoXes) com-
plimented me on my smooth driving.  Smooth?  I don't know.  But I
do know that I wasn't *nearly* agressive enough, and I was *way*
off my apexes--almost five feet in one or two places...  Sigh.  I
was still trying to figure out where the course was, I guess.
    More good news, Ray Scruggs was back with his silver 914/6.
You may recall that he bent it at the last Sonoma event.  Well, it
turned out to be not nearly as serious as it looked.  It did take
a number of hours on the frame machine, but according to Ray, it's
straighter now than it was before this whole adventure.
    He went down to the shop to pay the bill, and was told that,
"Someone came down earlier with a check.  It's covered."  It seems
that Certain Parties (who shall remain nameless) got together a col-
lection to help Ray with the bill--and to everyone's surprise, the
collection pretty much covered the whole thing.  The joy on Ray's
face as he related this was really nice to see.
    Damn, what a good group of people we belong to!  [Dave sprains
his arm trying to pat himself on the back...]
    Next Redwood event is November 5, again at the Sonoma County
Airport.  E-mail me for directions.  Unfortunately, I won't be there,
as I have a wedding in Illinois to attend on that date.  Too bad.

- --DD

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 17:10:41 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 Idle

Hi,

I picked up your message about 914 idle speed.

1400 RPM is too high. 850-900 is right. 

If this just happened to you, after it idled correctly for some time, then
I would suspect either a loose air hose or the Aux Air Regulator (AAR). But
first check your idle speed setting by turning the screw on the throttle
body (after you take off your air filter housing). Make sure that the car
is warmed up, then adjust. If you cannot lower, then check that all air 
hoses are connected.  

Also check your throttle spring; if it is old and corroded, and the idle 
does eventually get back to 900, but verrry slowly get a new one at a 
Porsche dealer!

If the hoses are connected,spring is good, and the idle adjust doesn't
help, then check the Aux Air Regulator. (1400 sounds just like mine when
the AAR failed...) It is kind of tucked behind the dipstick and looks like
a teacup with two hose attachments of top: One of these goes into the air
filter unit. With the air filter unit off, the hose from the Aux Air Reg will
be open at that end. A correctly working AAR will be closed (no air
drawing through this hose) once the engine is warm. 

If open, then note: The AAR's evidently fail a lot after 20 years...I had
a heck of a time finding one used, and they are not made any more. If you
live in a warm place, put a plug in the hose: The AAR will then never act
open, and the car will idle right once warmed up (a little harse until
then). If you live in a cold place, then first check out the electrical
connection to the AAR; one red wire, should get 12V with engine running.
If if does, then take out the AAR, spray some HD40 into the top, put it in
a can with 1 inch of HD40 (or similar) overnight, and the next day, tap it
gently on top. It may unfreeze. (Mine did not!) You can test it by putting
it on 12V and then you can see the inside piston close in a circular
way... 

If you really need one (cold climate, HD40 no help), call Rich at High
Perf.  Products in Redwood city, he has tested units: $75. OR Jay of
PartsWerks in Chicago; first one he sent me wasn;t tested, next one was
and worked too: $45. but more hassles. These were *$150* new.

Mark

PS Stan, hope I didn't miss anything...I should know about this...and by
the way, Performance Products had the best price I could find in the USA
for new Bosche 914 2.0L 73/74 Injectors -- $59. And in stock too! Car 
should be running again on Weds. Thanks for the help.

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 14:21:41 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Vibration and Lugging


Mr. Lupien is correct, the top wnd of the rod and the wrist pin take
a big hit when the engine is lugged. Also, just FYI, the pistons
slap the cylinder walls head enough to consider it family violence.
Seriously, this is what causes piston skirt wear and cylinder wall 
scuffing.

Mr. Myers, 
I am sorry that all this talk about vibration go to you. I know a 
lady with a '59 Borgward that says it vibrates erotically. She loves 
to offer rides to anyone willing to help her with the problem. Frankly, 
I could never see anything erotic about a Borgward except the name
Isabella. That was on a night in Barcelona many years ago.....

I hate any vibration in my Porsches. It takes away from the 
pure experience of driving by suggesting mere sex. These days I can 
drive much longer (*sigh*).

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 14:38:03 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 oily wheels

| From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM"  <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>
|
|               I has spend the weekend driving around skyline and
|               Mt. Hamilton (bay area, CA) and had the oppurtunity
|               to do some spirited driving on the fast twisty roads
|               The suspension and brakes were under some load (tires
|               squealing etc...). After the drive, I noticed a thin
|               black oily film on both the front wheels (the car
|               was washed just before the drive). I had noticed the
|               oil on the wheels before but was very little and over
|               a long period of time/driving. There is no significant
|               drop in any oil levels but I am not sure. What could be
|               the reason? Any help would be appreciated.

If it was a dust coating, then it would be brake pad dust and nothing
to worry about.

If it is indeed an oily fluid, how thick is it? A thin fluid would indicate
leaking caliper seals. In this case, an immediate caliper rebuild
is indicated.

If it is thick, it could be bearing grease. If the wheel bearing seals
were bad and the bearings/hub had heated up, then it would be possible
to throw grease. If the bearings run out of grease, they fail and then
your wheels fall off. Car control degrades once the wheels fall off. <insert
obligatory smiley>

If it were either bearing grease or brake fluid, it would be a bit of a
coincidence for both sides to fail simultaneously. But stranger
things have happened.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red (which is probably the same thing as 
metallic burgundy)

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 16:11:42 PDT
From: Carl DeSousa <desousa@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: 930 Spark Plug: Split Fire Plugs


>From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>

>This is snake oil sold in the USA. The plug has the tip of the electrode
>split into a "Y". No other differences. It's heavily marketed on TV. THe
>price is about 5X what a normal brand name plug list. They also sell their
>own brand of plug wire -- with, you guessed it, two parallel wires going
>from distributor to plug. Pure marketing hype -- think of it as the Zymol
>of spark plugs; the Duralube of spark plug; or the Slick-50 of spark plugs.

This may be true for the Split Fire Plugs but the Bosch Tri-electrode
plugs work *very well* on my 84 911.  Audi uses them as OEM on thier
turbos and I hear they're standard on new VWs as well.  I understand
they were designed to eliminate extinguishing spark in high boost
applications.  This is all "here-say" mind you, but others on the Audi
Quattro net swear by them.  I use them in in both of our Audis as
well.  I've tried the platinums plugs but the Tri-electrodes are definetly
better.  Sorry, I have no imperical data to back this with, the cars
just seem to run better, smoother idling, better cold starts etc... 
For those of you with turbos, I would highly recommend trying them.  
Anyone else try them yet?

Carl DeSousa

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 16:45:12 PST
From: Christopher Holl <holl@priacc.com>
Subject: Porsche 914-6 for sale, San Diego CA


Text item: Text_1

     Dear Porsche folks,
     
     I hope this is the right place to do this.  If not, apologies, and I'd 
     appreciate knowing the proper place.
     
     I've decided to part with my '71 914-6.  It has just over 50k miles on 
     the odo.
     
     It is a conversion with a '69 911 carburetted (Webers with Watershield 
     covers) motor.  About 8k miles ago the pistons and cylinders were 
     replaced with new 2.2 liter, 911E parts and the heads were rebuilt.  A 
     couple of months ago I added the hydraulic tensioner upgrade.  The 
     motor is very strong (~150 hp) and smooth, making the car very quick 
     and a pleasure to drive.  It has heavier-than-stock springs and Koni 
     shocks (I'm not sure about the sway bar), braided steel brake and oil 
     lines, an MSD/CD system (not the musical kind), and a new Bursch 
     exhaust.  The exhaust has heat exchangers, so the heater works.  It 
     has a short-shifter kit, and naturally, the tach was rebuilt for the 
     6-cylinder motor.  California smog legal with current certificate and 
     registration.
     
     It has an upgraded interior with the adjustable passenger seat, new 
     black carpet and seats, and gray door panels.  The center console 
     holds oil pressure and oil temperature gauges, a clock, an 
     am/fm/cassette stereo, an equalizer, and Clifford AND Alpine alarm 
     systems.  There are two tops (one with a tinted Plexiglas panel in 
     it), and both types of parking brake handles.  (The original, 
     retractable type is installed.  The other is in a box.)
     
     It has beautiful red paint, excellent chrome bumpers, Porsche nose 
     badge, 15" Rivera wheels with almost-new low-profile tires, and the 
     plastic thing that says "PORSCHE" between the tail lights.  I replaced 
     the plastic, crushable trunk rollers with bronze ones.
     
     The price is $9k firm.  There is another 914-6 conversion in the local 
     Auto Trader for $10,500 and there is an original 914-6 in AutoWeek for 
     $17k, so I think $9k is quite reasonable.  There's more to the car 
     than I can list here, and there's no way this car could be built for 
     $9k.  (I've probably gone on long enough, but I really love the car.)  
     This is a rare opportunity to buy a car someone ELSE has sunk tons of 
     time and money into.  :-)
     
     Please send any inquires directly to me at holl@priacc.com.
     
     Thanks,
     
     Chris

cleared this arrangment with her manager.  Hopefully someday other dealerships
will catch on and lower thier prices too.  But don't hold your breath.

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 17:35:30 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: '83 928 heater always on

I'm posting this for a friend that owns a "hot" '83 928S.

He's already looked through the factory manual microfiche for help.

If anyone has any advice, either post it to the list or e-mail directly
to me.  

Thanks,

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

****************************************************************

Can anyone help me solve a heater ventilation problem on an '83
Porsche 928S?

Normally, the automatic climate control (ACC) system on the 928S
would provide fresh air ventilation in the ECON mode. Recently
however, the ACC would always blow hot air through the passenger
vents in the ECON mode (heat setting was set to COLD). Turning
the ACC to AUTO (A/C) mode did not help since the A/C could not
offset the hot air coming from the heater unit.

I discovered that the heater control valve for the heater was not closing
 -- thereby always letting hot water flow to the heater core and producing
hot air in the passenger compartment. I verified that the heater
control valve was faulty by manually applying 18 psi vacuum to
the heater control valve. An 18 psi vacuum would close the valve
and eliminate the hot air. I tested the vacuum from the ACC
central diaphram and measured only 15 psi -- apparently not enough
to close the heater control valve.

At this point, I suspect three causes:

   A) Could the vacuum system be not generating normal vacuum?
   B) Could the interior and/or exterior temperature sensor in the 
      ACC be reading wrong and causing this problem? 
   C) Is it possible that the heater control valve has gotten "sticky" 
      and now needs more vacuum to operate?  


Thanks.

------------------------------

Date:    Mon, 17 Oct 94 20:44 EDT
From: MARSHAL@CLEMSON.EDU

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 17:58:32
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re:  914 / 912E intake mani

 
>Re>> 914 / 912E intake manifold question
>>> I have been thinking about upgrading the 1.8L engine on my 914 to a 2.0L 
>>> model.  I would like

>problem.

>>
>>Nope, but it shouldn't be too hard. 
>
>    I learned this talking to Stan about (almost) the same subject quite a
>while
>ago:  Stan's definition of "not too hard" is *not* the same as others' (mine,
>for
>instance).
>    It shouldn't be too bad (maybe) if you *start* with 2.0L heads and
>exhaust.
>But those are the priciest bits, so you might as well go with the full 2.0L
>FI,
>right?  Putting 2.0L P&C's on the 1.8L case/heads/etc is non-trivial. 
>Something
        2.0 heads will not fit on 1.7 or 1.8 eng cases as the head
studs are not spaced the same. 
>about deck height requires machining the case or the cylinders...  I don't
>re-
>member the details, sorry.  Not at all hard for Stan, but not something I
>wanted
>to pay someone else to tackle for me.  (I don't build 914 racers regularly
>for
>fun...)
>    If I remember correctly, Stan told me that the AFC FI from the 1.8L would
>work fine with 2.0L displacement, even with higher ("Euro") compression.  So
>if
>you can do/have the machining done, it may then turn into a "bolt-on"
>operation.
>
>--DD

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 18:01:42
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re: 914 idle

 
>     At what optimum rpm should my 75 914 2.0 L P-car idle at?  According 
>     to by instruments, I'm at 1,400 rpm, but it does not sound like its 
>     that high.
>     
>     Marc  Robson
>     DirecTv
>
        My 73 2.0 idle at 900-1100 --  1400 is to high sometimes on
these engines it is not possible due to the age of all the hose
etc to get them to idle down. One this I had to do was take a sheet
metal screw and put it in the hole in the trottle body. This will
allow you adjust the idle lower.

                        mike

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 20:53 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: EWA?

Hi Ed,

"EWA" is Eric Waiter Associates, I believe.  Their latest catalog just
lists the name as "EWA & Miniature Cars USA Inc."  In any event, they
sell a ton of, you guessed it, minature cars, as well as a number of
British autosports magazines and a few unusual books and videos.

Racecar Engineering is indeed a good read, esp. for the Formula 1 fans
among us who figure ourselves a little more technically inclined.  EWA
also distributes "911 and Porsche World," which is a fine independant
magazines from the UK.

Give 'em a ring at 908 665 7811.  Or you can find them on CompuServe.

Nope, no shop in central CA.  I am in eastern Mass.  Take care,

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 21:05:26 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 930 Spark Plugs



On Mon, 17 Oct 1994, Kevin Hughes wrote:

> 
> For the uninitiated what are Split Fire Plugs????? what advantage are they
> intended to give? and whats the cost differential?????
> 
> 
> Kevin 1980 930
> 
Supposedly, they are the latest miracle gain in both HP and efficiency. 
They have a split tip that you are led to believe fires two sparks 
simultaneously. I'd be willing to bet if you slowed the tape of them 
firing, you would see that only one side fires at a time. That being the 
case, the off center configuration might actually be detremental. When 
will the masses realize you can't get a free lunch.

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 22:51:18 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Loelle S Poneleit" <poneleit@student.msu.edu>
Subject: timing belts

Here is some information that may be helpful to porsche owners in the future.
As i understand it 944s have a lot of problems with timing belts. Currently
these timing belts are made by Pirelli(sp?) (PTI) and supplied O.E. to porsche.
About a year ago the division of pirelli that makes belts and hoses was
purchased by Dayco Products Inc. Dayco is the largest O.E. suppliers of
belts and hose as well as one of the largest aftermarket suppliers. As part of
this purchase the pirelli name could only be use for one year. The one year is
almost over and the pirelli name will no longer be used(as far as i know). As
part of Daycos new 94 part numbers for the aftermarket are timing belts for
porsche 944,968 and 928.(these were previously unavalible from dayco)
I was unable to find out if these belts are made by in the pirelli plant or
somewhere else( they also purchased another itilian timing belt manufactuer
at about the same time). The belts made by pirelli have a "dimple" at the
bottom of each tooth. I also could not find out if these belts are made to the
exact spec. as O.E.. The timing belts for these cars in the aftermarket are
quite a bit less expensive ($40 compared to $200). I will try and get more info
but its difficult because the plant is overseas. These may be a less expensive
belt that mactches O.E. quality. In the future the timing belts should not
have the pirelli name(as of some time this spring).

 John Haley
 Lansing, MI

 78 911SC targa

P.S.

I work for Dayco in aftermarket sales. Maybe someone on the list(in europe) can
get more information than I could(I dont know much about 944 ) All i could find
out is that Dayco tries to make all there parts meet or excede O.E. spec and
that they could be made in the pirelli plant( i have not looked at one of these
belts yet)

 Kevin,

 Split fire plugs have a double electrode and hence a double spark.
 Claims have been made about more HP and better gas mileage.
 From the responses I've been getting on behalf of my PML  subscriber, I'd
say the consensus is they don't work.

 PhilVB, PMLetter, 66/67/80 911

Date: 18 Oct 94 01:05:33 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Beer of choice for Porschephiles

Hi, Bart.
 
(Flame suit on...single layer OK this time)
 
Guinness is actually pretty good WHEN DONE PROPERLY. That means on tap. The
bottle stuff tastes completely different. Some friends and I used to hang out
at the Krone, just about the only decent place to go in Weissach in the
evening (the other, and much less desirable, being the pizzeria across from
the end of the single-car railway line that ends at Weissach -- the orange
white and blue car can be seen in the current Porsche TV ad). Anyway, Herbie
the bartender started the Guiness thing, all the Brits from the styling
studio would hang out there, and when the place changed hands they kept the
Guinness. It was either Guinness or Pils for most of us. (Pils takes 5-10
minutes to tap a glass, to keep the foam down).
 
Small World Syndrome -- when I started work at Road & Track in early 87, I
rented an apartment in Huntington Beach. One night at the pool, a bunch of
folk with British accents came by. One looked a little familiar. We compared
notes, it turns out his previous job was clay modelling at Porsche. He used
to hang out at the Krone too, in the other corner. Mind you the Krone was
small, I think 20 customers would fill it. I think it had 5 barstools.
Anyway, his job in California was at the local branch office of IAD,
International Automotive Design, in HB.
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 18 Oct 94 01:05:36 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 oily wheels

 
If you're not misinterpreting a thin black layer of brake dust as oil, and
if the hub cap (the actual 2" or so cap over the central nut, not any sort
of decorative thing) isn't losing bearing grease, then you may be losing
brake fluid. THIS IS DANGEROUS. See if the inside of the wheel is wet. Look
for wet spots on the ground. Most of all look for dropping brake fluid
levels in the reservoir. You MAY be able to drive this way if the leak isn't
too extreme and you keep the reservoir topped up, but it needs to be taken
care of as soon as possible. If it is indeed brake fluid, you probably just
need new seals, about $10 plus lotsa labor.
 
Pete

From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 'Project 914' series in European Car magazine?

tube-framed racer being built for SCCA racing, a street 914 and 'project 356 
racer' which they just finished welding the holes in the body. 

This month's issue features 2 articles on 914s.  Last month featured many 
articles on tuning the 911 for more power.  Some articles are step-by-step 
how-to-do-it and some detail how a particular car was set up and amount to 
plugs for the various manufacturers/tuners.

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 12:59:28 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Racing!!!!!

>Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:59:48 CDT
>From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
>Subject: Racing!!!!!

>Ok I'm SOLD!!!!!

>I'm joining PCA (should have done this earlier anyway) and getting 
>involved in the driver's ed program(s).  According to the loyal following 
>out there, it's a real RUSH!

>If anything else, it will help me keep my Pcar from becoming embraced by 
>another less experienced Houston WHACKO driver.

Great!  Get out there and learn how to really drive your 951 quickly and 
safely.  Yes, it is a real adrenalin rush.  However,  PCA Driver Ed events is 
**NOT** wheel-to-wheel racing.  Passing is only allowed on certain sections of
track and only with the go-ahead of the car to be passed.  In NNJR, the 'R' 
word is verbotten at a PCA Driver's Ed. event.  Other than restraining the 
impulse to 'race' in an environment where other folks are trying to learn and 
bringing your car home without new 'racing' stripes from the Armco, another 
good reason to make the distinction has to due with your insurance.  Some 
insurance carriers will cover driver's ed but not racing (check your policy). 
 So track events may be covered but not autocrosses.  Of course, there is PCA 
Club Racing and the SCCA if and when you really want to go all-out racing.   
Sorry if I sound preachy, but this is a sore topic with me with everyone I 
know who disapproves of high-speed driving telling me about 'racing' my car.

OK, I'll get off my soap-box now.

____________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	               '87 951 Pearl Black 
AT&T Business Communication Services   '87 Audi 5000CST 
Bridgewater, NJ 
sjagernauth@attmail.com

------------------------------

Date: 18 Oct 94 12:12:12 GMT
From: mvmas@mvusa.att.com
Subject: Re: 930 plugs (Kevin)

> Kevin,

> Split fire plugs have a double electrode and hence a double spark.
> Claims have been made about more HP and better gas mileage.
> From the responses I've been getting on behalf of my PML  subscriber, I'd
>say the consensus is they don't work.
>
> PhilVB, PMLetter, 66/67/80 911

Whoa, Nellie!  For now leaving aside the question of whether splitfire's
"work", unless the laws of physics changed since I got out of school,
there will only be one spark here just like a normal plug.  A spark
ionizes the air in its path, and the lower resistance guarantees that
the rest of the charge will take that path.  Therefore, only one spark
per compression stroke.  Of course, what they show in the commercial,
is the spark coming from all over the place, but they are just getting
one spark per 'firing'.  The spark can come from a lot of places if you
have a plug where a large area is about equally distant from the center
electrode.

Mark Skala                            "If you're not part of the solution,
mvmas@mvusa.att.com                    you're part of the precipitate"

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 08:08:45 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ryan A Erickson <eric0019@gold.tc.umn.edu>
Subject: 914 restoration


	I just bought a very cheap 1973 914 2.0 and it is time to make it 
look not so cheap.  This is my first porsche so I don't know as much as I 
should. I've restored plenty of older american cars and I feel 
comfortable with my car abilities.  I would like to hear from other 914 
owners about the best sources for information (written and spoken), the 
best/cheapest part supplies, etc.  I've read the 914 FAQ and I bought a 
Haynes, but I'm sure there is more and better.  I paid $500 for the car 
which was built in 9/72 (is September the first month for '73?).  It's a 
2.0 liter with the fuel injection still in place.  The body is in 
excellent shape (the doors close solid and easily with approx. 450 lbs in 
the car and the roof off).  The car is missing all exterior trim, 
however.  It is missing both bumpers, tail lights, side markers, front 
parking lights, and headlight surrounds.  The floor boards are extremely 
solid and interior is in far shape.  There are couple cuts in the driver 
seat and dash pad.  It has a 150 mph speedo which I believe is incorrect 
for 4-cyl. 914's.  The car was last driven in 1983 so I plan on 
rebuilding the engine before even attempting to drive it.  Also, the 
front, right torsion bar adjuster is broken so the sits unlevel. 
	So anyway, there is the car.  It's obviously not in perfect shape 
but in good overall shape and well worth the price in my opinion.  Any 
help from seasoned veterans or young porsche pups like myself will be 
greatly appreciated.
						Thanks in advance
						Ryan

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 10:20:58 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: RE: Vibration and Lugging

> Mr. Lupien is correct, the top wnd of the rod and the wrist pin take
> a big hit when the engine is lugged. Also, just FYI, the pistons
> slap the cylinder walls head enough to consider it family violence.
> Seriously, this is what causes piston skirt wear and cylinder wall 
> scuffing.

And if your bearings at either end of the rod are at all loose,
the resulting slap gets even more sever, while normal higher-rpm
operation might still be quite benign.

By the way, you can call me "John" - this "Mr." stuff makes me feel
old.

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 09:54:14 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Sparklers


Been reading a little on the thread about spark plugs. Interesting.
Here's a few cents for you guys that want a little more from your plugs.

Try indexing your plugs (I know you'll try it, read on). This involves 
using some spacers and marking your plug for the direction of the 
electrode. Indexing is used by ALL the major engine builders. The idea
is to ensure that the electrode "points" toward the piston face. The
spark-ignited fuel  is at the face of the piston as the gases are 
compressed, having an unshrouded spark igniting the mixture assures a
more complete burn.

I have used this method while testing spark plug combinations and for
my own cars. I can tell the difference. I have a device that I can 
screw the spark plug into to see how the electrodes are aligned. They
usually are not. In a given set you may find half that will point in 
the right direction when torqued in the head. The others point in 
directions you do not want. This is where the spacers come in. They 
come in thicknesses that allow for 60 degree adjustments. Some plugs 
are so far out that I just keep them for an oddly threaded cylinder. 
Generally, I can get plugs aligned within a 30 degree spread. 

I mark the plug base so I can observe the location when torqued. For
911s and engines with shrouded plugs, I have a set of extensions and 
spark plug sockets that are marked. I put the plug in with the marks 
aligned. 

My opinion of the plugs available. I have tried all of the popular 
configurations. Split-fires work, but not according to their 
instructions. They have crappy sealing rings and cost too F****** much
for what they deliver. My preference in Porsches, turbo or otherwise, 
are Bosch Silvers. They last and rarely foul. My opinion of Platinums
isn't very high unless we are talking about the old style and are 
running all day on the Autobahn. Follow the Factory recommendations 
on plug gap unless you are a mechanic of the Vasek or Andial calibre.

Most of the indexing components, calibration fixture, spacers, etc are
available from speed shops or certain engine builders. It is worth the 
trouble to do if you are going to track events with your vehicle.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 13:53:41 -0600
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: Sponsor stickers on car.



Begin forwarded message:

> > >The stickers will need to stay in place for a week of "spirited"
> > >track & road driving. 

> > 

> > I did this just for fun once.  I put the sticker on a piece of magnetic
> > vinyl (?) cut it to fit around the sticker, and slapped it on...
> 

> Ummm. This is fine for autox and "around town" cafe racer stuff, but 

> won't work if you're at speed on a track.
> 

> Common wisdom is to wax the car heavily, apply the sticker as late as  
possible,
> and take it off as son as possible. Good luck.
> 

> Stan
> 


FWIW: If it's a one-off, I'd do as Stan suggests. If you plan on
using the stickers continuously over time, see below...

Actually, the mags will work on the track.  Through experience, I've
found that the larger the sheet of mag material, the better it sticks. Duh.
I also use a small amount of tape along the leading edge of the magnetic
material to seal the leading edge to prevent lift.  If you can keep the
magnetic material in a rectangular or curcular shape, this works pretty well.

The best tape I've found is used by the people in the medical
profession.  It's clear and has an effective, but not overly tenacious
adhesive.  I've also used duct/racer's tape in this application as well.
It doesn't take much tape to seal the leading edge so it's not unsightly.
If your're predisposed to travel at high speed in either direction (as I
have been known to do, on occasion) you may want to tape the trailing 

edge as well, but we all hope that this doesn't happen with your new
baby.

Oh, I almost forgot.  If you do use magnetics, I would still recommend
waxing prior to application and be sure to get the car-side of the 

magnetic sheet clean of dust/dirt/iron filings, etc.

Good luck,
Drew

Drew Spencer
'93 RS America

------------------------------

Date: 18 Oct 1994 10:28:43 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 idle

>One this I had to do was take a sheet
>metal screw and put it in the hole in the trottle body.

    Ummm....  "Hole in the throttle body?"  No *wonder* you
had a high idle!  Any holes in the sides of the throttle body
should have fittings on them, and vaccuum hoses attatched to
those fittings.  One for vaccuum advance, one for vaccuum
retard.  '74 and later (?) should only have one, unless they've
been retrofitted, like mine.
    Any other holes are bad news.

- --DD

Subject: 928's forever!

So, to answer my question; the '79 928 came stock with 7x16 inch wheels front
and back, and with 225/50-16 tires front and back.  The automatic had 15 inch
wheels.

Peak torque is at 3600 rpm.  Peak horsepower is at 5250 rpm.  Max horsepower is
SAE net 219, with Max tourque of 245 ft/lbs.  Curb wieght is 3351 lbs.
My power-to-weight-ratio is 15.3 lbs per horsepower.  

So why am I in IS along with some 911SC's that are modified?  No wonder I only
beat 2 people at the last Auto-X in S.D.!

bill

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 17:10:40 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.GSFC.NASA.GOV
Subject: 951s and Turbocharging


Hello Phello Philes;

I have been following with interest the recent thread on engine lugging and 
suggested RPM ranges for best drivability of our Porsches.  I have had my '89 
951 for about 3 months/3000 miles now and I am still learning the power 
characteristics of the 2.5L Turbocharged engine.

Looking at the Torque/Horsepower curves for the engine shows what the seat of my 
pants already knows, below about 3000 RPM there just isn't much power available.  
>From 3000 RPM up to  6000 RPM the power builds rapidy.  Many refer to this as 
'the boost coming on'.

I don't quite understand this phrase.  Say I am running at 2000 RPM and floor 
the gas pedal.  A look at the boost guage shows 1.2 bar, i.e. full boost.  Yet 
the power is not felt until that 'magic spot' between 3000-4000 RPM when the car 
takes off like a rocket.  On the other hand, if I am running at 4000 RPM and 
floor the gas, the reaction is almost immediate at the same 1.2 bar boost.  Is 
this what is meant by Turbo Lag?

I think I understand the basic principles of Turbocharging:  using exhaust gas 
to spin a turbine which pumps more air into the cyclinder allowing more fuel to 
be burned generating more power.  Is there some RPM in the 951 at which the 
Turbocharger starts working its magic?  Below that RPM the 951 is no better than 
a normally aspirated 944?

My quest for this knowledge is based somewhat on relatively poor performance at 
the 3 or so Autocrosses I have participated in since purchasing my car.  I am 
finding it very difficult to keep the power up on tight, twisty courses even 
with downshifting to 1st gear.  I know I still have much to learn about driving 
my car, but maybe someone can pass on some of their secrets of success using 
Turbocharged cars for autocross.  Those pesky 911s and 914s are eating my lunch.  
My first track experience with the 951 will be November 13. 911s beware!  I will 
keep you posted.  Any enlightenment passed on would be much appreciated.  Thanks 
in advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

------------------------------

Date: 18 Oct 1994 10:11:11 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 Idle

>Hi,
>
>I picked up your message about 914 idle speed.
>
>1400 RPM is too high. 850-900 is right. 

[very good advice about Aux Air Regulators deleted]

    Must'a missed the original post...  [**&#$#&* flakey
QuickMail...]
    Typical source for high idle in D-jet 914s (1.7, 2.0)
is/are vaccuum leaks.  One internal (a biggie, too!) is the
AAR, previously mentioned.  Any or all of the rest of the
hoses could be disconnected or bad as well.  Check 'em all,
or as many as you can keep track of!

- --DD

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 14:16:33 TZ

for using VISA. YMMV...

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 17:36:00 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: TurboS Brakes

Careful inspection of the brakes on my 89 951 showed that the rubber dust
boots around the brake pistons on the front brakes were disintegrating. This
is probably the result of my Oh Sh.t braking technique at the Glen.
Anyway it seems that they should be replaced so off I went to my friendly
Porsche dealer to purchase new rubber boots. Slight problem, they are
available only in the rebuild kit which contains the piston, etc. These kits
are about $45 each and eight are required, not to mention the unappetizing
prospect of pulling the calipers off and removing the probably perfectly fine
pistons. 
Having rebuilt 911 calipers that have only two pistons to deal with I
certainly don't feel like dealing with four piston calipers unless absolutely
necessary.
The question is;
1. Is it necessary to rebuild the whole caliper and replace the pistons when
just the dust ruffles are shot. (no signs of leaking anywhere)
2. These are Brembo calipers and the dust boots have Brembo stamped on them.
Is there a source of these parts other than Porsche?
3. Is there a Brembo dealer out there.
Thank you to anyone who responds.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

still doesn't pass, you may get an exemption of it costs more than $xx

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 15:16:10 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: 951s and Turbocharging

Tracy writes:

>My quest for this knowledge is based somewhat on relatively poor performance at 
the 3 or so Autocrosses I have participated in since purchasing my car.  I am 
finding it very difficult to keep the power up on tight, twisty courses even 
with downshifting to 1st gear

A trick I used with success on my other car (Dodge Daytona Turbo Z) was to use
the brakes hard in tight corners, but also keep the throttle open, thus keeping
the flow through the turbine side of the turbocharger.  It's real tricky, but
I can't think of a better way to keep the turbine/compressor spinning at peak
rpm's.  And when you complete the corner the revs of the turbo should be high
enough to get you to the peak torque of your engine (what you feel at 3000-4000
rpm) much faster.  The trick is to get your engine to peak torque quicker 
than the next guy, but with turbos, it's kinda difficult.  

The old Audi Quattro racers (Michelle Mouton...what a babe!  And she can DRIVE!)
used a technique at Pike's Peak where they had a bottle of compressed air that 
would contantly spin the turbocharger at max rpms.  Whenever they needed the
power, the turbo was ready.

later,
bill


------------------------------

>altering the electrode position in the vertical direction (ie 944) just
>as easily negatively/positively impact ignition?

Isn't there some kind of racers tweek about "indexing" the spark plugs so 
that the spark faces the inlet valve? This should allow more complete 
combustion, more power etc etc. I seem to remember that Tweeks or 
Performance Products advertises adjustment washers so you can align the 
plugs (and presumably move the vertical postion).

So my question to all you racers (especially Stan) is does this work? Is 
there anything to be gained on a street/autox car?

Martin Cox
mcox@kla.com

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 16:41:23 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 928's forever!

Bill,

     I guess you are allowed the same 6 modification points as us
SC's,  but  your  point  is  well taken.  I  have  NEVER  seen  a
competitive 928 at one of our autoXs.  They just can't get around
all  those  corners fast enough.  They do great on  the  straight
sections though.

     Seriously,  it's  no fun to be totally  uncompetitive.   Why
don't  we bring it up to the autoX comittee.  Arbitrary rules can
always  be changed.  Maybe we would get more 928s out if they had
a competitive class to run in.

Bob

PS.   Maybe  you should try Holtville next month.   I  understand
they have a 1 mile straight!

Date: Mon, 17 Oct 94 16:39:31 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: More 356 Rear Axle Nuts 


     
     FYI, my '64 VW Double Cab transporter started leaking oil at the right 
     rear drum.  The reason?  The axle nut came loose and was loose for a 
     whole weeks worth of driving.  I was saved by the cotter pin.  From 
     now on I will always tighten the axle nut to 350-400 ft lbs and always 
     install a new cotter pin in case the old one rusts or breaks and comes 
     loose.  (Same goes for my 356 too!)
     
     Derek Au
______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
But the label on the bag was interesting: it says you have to tighten the 
axle nut to some godawful number, 350 or 400 ft.-lbs, or else you will 
damage the halfshaft splines. So there's the reason, apparently.
     
Pete

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 17:21:54
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re:  914 idle

Hole is in the butterfly sorry for the mistake

                                mike 
>>One this I had to do was take a sheet
>>metal screw and put it in the hole in the trottle body.
>
>    Ummm....  "Hole in the throttle body?"  No *wonder* you
>had a high idle!  Any holes in the sides of the throttle body
>should have fittings on them, and vaccuum hoses attatched to
>those fittings.  One for vaccuum advance, one for vaccuum
>retard.  '74 and later (?) should only have one, unless they've
>been retrofitted, like mine.
>    Any other holes are bad news.
>
>--DD

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 17:54:29 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: Stalling 911 SC

I have a '78 911 SC that has started stalling when coming to a stop 
after the car is warmed up, particularly when I come to a stop quickly, 
so the engine speed goes from fast to idle quickly when the clutch is 
depressed.  Sometimes it doesn't stall, but the RPMs dip to ~200 and 
then back up to 1000.  It's almost as if it's trying to stall every 
time, but most of the time something kicks in as the engine is idling 
down (i.e. clutch goes in when the RPMs are around 3K) to prevent the stall.

At one point (beginning of the summer), I reconnected the vacuum lines 
to an engine component on the top left of the engine (just behind the 
accelerator linkage).  Prior to that, the line was plugged below the 
'T' where it would normally connect to said engine component.

Any ideas?

Marc
marco@microsoft.com

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 20:54:58 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Horsepower

> I'm restoring a '76 914 2.0L and would like to increase the power as much 
> as possible and remain streetable and reliable. 

And you only want it to cost $12.53 and you want it to get 45 MPG. Just
like everyone else.

Look, I've had a lot of experience. And the trophies to prove it. You 
*CAN* get 100K miles out of a 914 engine, really. You just can't do
it and make 125+ HP. Plus, you have a '76. If you live in a smog controled
area, you're gonna have to have all the relevant smog gear plus meet
spec on emissions or you're not going to be able to register the car
starting in '96.

> Does anyone have any experience with the 103mm P&L's, big valves, stroked 
> cranks, etc. What kind of increases can I expect? Is it worth the $'s or 
> should I convert to a six? 

*ANYTHING* that involves a change from stock necessarily involves 
re-engineering. There's no such thing as "bolt-on" performance. WHen
you change any one component, there are three or four others that get
affected.

The 103mm pistons are horrible on the street. Lots of piston slap, and
it takes the rings a long time to seat if they ever do. Plus, that
would bias the engine towards higher RPM operation, but (1) those pistons
aren't light enough, and (2) then you gotta do all the things to keep
the rest of the engine together above 6000 RPM.

Stroked cranks are also bad, since now you gotta have custom rods and you
may have to have custom pistons to get the wrist pin geometry correct.
Not to mention the extra pounding the bottom end is gonna take.

Big valves are *ONLY* useful if you've increased the displacement, and
even then you don't need valves as big as the "performance shops" are
selling. Remember, they're in business to take your money, *NOT* to
solve your problem...

As to the 4 or 6 question, you can build a very good streetable 914 engine
that makes 125-130 HP on stock EFI and will last for 50-60k miles for only 
about $7,500 to $9,000. Depending on what you have to start with.

You can buy an early 911 engine (it's gotta be from the "with carbs"
era or you run afoul of the emissions stuff again), build it out to 
2.4 liters and make 140-190 HP for close to 100K miles for only about
$8,000 to $11,000 again depending on how lucky you are. Oh, then you
gotta pony up another $3-4k to modify the 914 to accept the 6 -- oil tank
and plumbing, different fueling, different motor mounts, etc. You could also
buy a good used 3.2 and plug it in but there is a TON of work to make
that  go together right. And more money spent solving unexpected problems.

The prices I'm citing are retail and assume that you have someone that
knwos what the hell they're doing actually do the work.

So, you tell me: what do you want to do?

Stan

------------------------------


End of Porschephiles

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 21:27:15 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: timing belts

>As i understand it 944s have a lot of problems with timing belts.

No they don't, the timing belt is simply a maintenance item, just as it
would be in any other car with a rubber timing belt (and hey I know, while
I was being paranoid about my 944 timing belt, my '90 Mitsi Eclipse broke
it's timing belt - fortunately it was under warranty).

>Currently these timing belts are made by Pirelli(sp?)

Well, I do believe that the 944S belt is a Pirelli (I'm not sure though,
because I've never owned a 944s), but the 944 belt is a Gates belt (at
least the ones I get at my dealer are - and this is one of the few parts I
go to the dealer for, 'cause it isn't one you want to cheap out on).

I don't know, I think that I would want to keep getting my belts from
Porsche, just for piece of mind sake, even if it does cost more. I know
that the 944s belts are quite expensive (he, he... yet another advantage to
having an 8 valver), but hey, there's 16 very expensive valves in there
(and lifters, etc.), and a lot of labour getting there to replace them. So
hey, I think it would be best to stick with the factory part in this case
...

Just my $.02 worth !!!


P.S. - A while ago I was coming home from Milwaukee and my balance shaft
belt broke. Even though I had never experienced a 944 with a broken balance
belt, I knew exactly what it was. Of course, I was due for belt replacement
about 10,000 miles ago - but I kept putting it off. So I drove the car home
(yes, the balance belt <did not> take the timing belt with it, and I'm
thanking the Porsche Gods for that to this day), and changed the belts the
next day. The timing belts Gods warned me, and I am thankful that they had
mercy on my 944's soul !!! Now I know to adhere very closely to the golden
rule: replace at 30,000, retension at 2,000, and then again evey 10,000.


- ---------------------------------------------------
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer
(A Music Industry Professional -- Ha !!!)

'84 Porsche 944 (Red)
'93 Feline unit ("Corvette")
'94 Child Unit (almost two months old !!!)

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 23:02:13 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: more horsepower from a 914



I agree with Stan about HP/Reliability/Streetability/Cost
issues in hotrodding a 914. After all, if you had megabucks,
you would have started with a 930, right?

IMHO, I'd go for (1) upgrading suspension and tires, (2) reducing
as much weight as possible and (3) improving driver skills
 - Your order may vary based on current skill level.

PCA events are handicapped so that you can have an absolute
blast competing against cars with similar characteristics and
capabilities (except maybe 928's) without spending gobs of 
money.

There are some awesome (in the non-California sense of the word)
purpose-built 914's with tube frames and big liter engines, but
the cost and engineering effort involved puts them out of the
range of most mere mortals. You can go and drool over them at one
of the PCA Racing Series events. It's always fun to dream - and
much more affordable.

 - Reid

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 1994 21:49:36
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re: 914 restoration

It will cost some good dollars to bring car back to orig shape I
suggest you get some parts catelogs and price all what you will
need before you start this project. I good engine rebuild will
cost a min of $3500.This will be for a better than factory eng you
can get by cheaper. Do not use the Japanize pistons and barrels
they do not work real well. Rings do not seat!!!!

If you have to replace rubber seals on car will cost apporx 1500
for this alone.

Crome bumpers will run apporx 250-300each for rechrome once you
find the bumpers. The 914 bumpers are so thin that they can only
be rechromed if they need any dent repair work.

I recently did a 73  914 and with paint all parts interior etc had
an easy 3000-3500 without any engine or trans work.

Let me know if I can help 

                                mike sacto cal

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 02:16:50 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 70-73 Values (Dave)

Dave,

I'm assuming you mean 911 values here. If I'm wrong, let me know.
Our 911 issue, which came out in July/94,  actually showed an
increase in average asking price for 70 - 71 cars (about 5%) and a
decrease in average asking price for 72-73 cars (about 15%). These
are 'asking prices'  based on PML ads between 8/93 - 7/94. I think
that the excitement generated by a new, and relatively affordable,
Porsche like the 993 and the availability of used C2/C4 cars will
naturally dimish interest in earlier cars(other than special cases
like 67S, 72-73S, etc). For this reason, it seems to me that now 
is a good time to look for any 911, 3.2L Carrera and back, and 
expect to find some good prices.  I just spent the last few weeks
getting my current issue out and haven't checked Pano closely yet.
You are the 2nd person to write this month commenting on what
seem to be reasonable prices on 911's in Pano. I've always found
prices to be relatively high in Pano(also the quality of cars is high),
so perhaps we should all be watching our favorite models closely
as 993's, Boxter's?, etc come out and get all the press!

PhilVB, PMLetter

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 01:49:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 injectors

>         I have a question about the injectors on my project 914. Is there
> any way to determine if the injectors are bad by visual inspection? 

No.

But, if you didn't replace them, odds are that they're the original
injectors. If you really love your car, you'll get new ones. Should be
about $60 each. You'll be amazed at the difference it makes.

On the "little hoses" -- they're a one-time compression fitting. You 
*CAN* break the compression band and then pull the hose off, replacing
it with new 7mm Wurth braided high-pressure fuel injection line and
a good Wurth hose clamp (you can even use the BMW clamp that breaks the
screw head off when you hit the right torque if you like...). HOWEVER,
if you need new hose, you gotta figure that it's because the old hose
started deteriorating, which probably means little pieces of rubber
got into the injector. You can hope they all went through, but if they
didn't they may be clogging the injector or disrupting the spray 
pattern. In any case, time to change them.

Stan

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 11:38:26 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Referee!


- --Boundary-4480122-0-0

Just went thru this referee process with my 68 912.  It's a pain in the butt.  
Here are the basics.   
 
1. make an appointment with the referee. (Took 3 weeks before I could get an 
appointment). 
2. Show up at the appointed hour.  he will inspect to see if you have the 
factory installed smog stuff on the car.  If you don't he will give you a list 
of the parts you're missing. He will also give you a phone number to call for 
the "parts locater". 
3. Go home, call number.  Tell them what car you have and what parts you're 
missing and they'll give you the numbers of at least 3 parts places that may 
have the pump, reactors, etc.  Call them and tell them what you need.  If the 
parts are available, you have to buy them and put them on.  If they are not 
available, you have to call the locater back and tell him that the parts 
aren't available.  then he gives you a number and a phone number to call to 
make another appointment.  (three more weeks).   
4.  Go back to the referee.  If your parts are no longer available, he will 
smog your car and pass it.  If the parts are available, you have to put them 
on.  If you do this,then just go to a smog station and get it  smogged. 
 
There is a solution to this.  I won't put it out over the newsgroup, but if 
you  forward your email or phone I'll pass it on. 
 
Ted Smith 
ehsmith@us.oracle.com 
415 506 6553


- --Boundary-4480122-0-0
X-Orcl-Content-Type: message/rfc822

Received: 15 Oct 1994 20:35:12                    Sent: 15 Oct 1994 20:35:11
From:"Robert L. Branick" <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Referee!
Reply-to: porschephiles-request@tta.com
X-Orcl-Application: Mime-Version:  1.0
X-Orcl-Application: Content-Type:  text/plain; charset="us-ascii"


Has anyone out there in P-phile land gone through the (California) referee
process with regards to getting your baby smogged?

A little background:  This is a 1977 911S that I bought in 1988.  It was
already on its second engine when it came into my possession, and,
naturally, the thermal reactors and air pump were conveniently left off.
The previous owners provided me with a smog certificate, and, yes, told me
that the emissions stuff was missing.

A little more background:  I've successfully smogged the car twice before.
Obviously the establishments didn't quite know what to look for in the
visual, but the sniffer part was honestly passed.  Says a lot for the value
of those thermal afterburners, doesn't it?

OK, it didn't work this last time.  I tried to play dumb, but no cigar.  I
think I'd rather just do the Referee thing and get it over with.  Or do I?
What can I expect, given my circumstances?  Will the head linesman throw a
flag, blow his whistle and say, "Sorry, you have to rebuild your engine and
make it smog legal."?  Yeah, YOU tell my wife!

Thanks for any insight anyone can offer.

Bob




- --Boundary-4480122-0-0--


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 20:30 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: TurboS Brakes

Jerry,

I went through the same "invoice shock" recently when I ordered these kits
to rebuild a set of 951 callipers.  I ended up sending them back.

>1. Is it necessary to rebuild the whole caliper and replace the
pistons when just the dust ruffles are shot. (no signs of leaking anywhere)

Yes and no.  If the pistons are pitted or otherwise damaged, you should
replace them.  They may not be visibly leaking today, but...  If you
are replacing the seals, you are effectively rebuilding the whole
calliper, since you have it as apart as it comes.  Do take everything
apart (except for the through-bolts, Lance!), clean it and dry it.  I
replace any hardware that even hints at looking questionable.  I also
popped, a couple of years ago, for a jar of the Unisilicon assembly paste,
lifetime supply.

>2. These are Brembo calipers and the dust boots have Brembo stamped
>on them. Is there a source of these parts other than Porsche?
>3. Is there a Brembo dealer out there.

Porsche does not sell a repair kit with just the seals.  They used to,
but no more.  I don't know of a US Brembo source.  Brembo UK can be
reached at (0280) 700664.  Jon Milledge would probably be a good
person to ask about a US source.

Kevin
