Date: Wed, Oct 19, 1994 8:09 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: 951s and Turbocharging

Hi Tracy,

Pretty interesting post.  I'll be following the thread closely.

Until you commented that you are getting the same 1.2 bar pressure reading
at 3000 rpm, I had always believed that the problem was "turbo-lag"; i.e., 
that the turbo was not spinning fast enough in the low end of the rpm band,
and was therefore not producing significant overpressure.  Your message would
seem to contradict that, and now , too,I wonder what's los.

One answer could lie with the cam characteristics (profile, lift, overlap and 
timing).  Back in '66, when I was playing with different cams for my Corvette,
the first one I tried was from the '65 Fuelie.  It made a fantastic change,
it would run strong to 7500 rpm, but it had *0* power below 3000, and to
get off the line without bogging, the clutch had to be dropped at 6000!
Truly unsatsifactory for the application, and not too surprisingly, a HD
racing clutch was only good for about 10 runs.



Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indishrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 8:38:58 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: 914 2.0 injectors


  >        I have a question about the injectors on my project 914. Is there
  >any way to determine if the injectors are bad by visual inspection? Three

Find a local mechanic with an injector cleaner.  This is basically
a pump handle with a pressure gauge and a reservoir for cleaning
fluid, with a fitting comming off it which connects to your injector
like the fuel line in the car does.  Using this setup you can tell at
what pressure the injector opens, wether it leaks at pressures it's
not supposed to and what the spray pattern looks like when it is
open.  Oh yes, you can also clean injectors with it too.
================================================================================
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: 19 Oct 94 10:44:59 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Sponsor stickers on car

 
>I know [magnetic material] is commonly available, I just don't know where.
 
Most of the sign places you find in the Yellow Pages carry it. You can
buy a yard of it for a few bucks. This is how I put my slalom numbers on; we
have two drivers and can quickly change the two big "bullseyes" carrying our
numbers. Both surfaces should be clean to avoid scratching paint.
 
I painted the white magnetic material with yellow Krylon before applying
black numbers cut from Pantone adhesive paper, available in sheets at art
supply stores. I don't like the contact paper from the local variety stores
(intended for shelf liners). Art supply stores also have rub-down letters
from Pantone and other suppliers for smaller print like your driver names
and such.
 
Pete

Date: 19 Oct 94 10:44:56 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 914 restoraton

 
Hi, Ryan.
 
The best sources for info are the official factory parts and service manuals
Mass market manuals like Haynes or Chilton's or Clymers leave a lot out, and
use a lot of generic info reprinted as boilerplate in every book they do.
 
To find out what was supposed to be on your car, you might also try Dr.
Brett Johnson's "914 and 914/6 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity". $19.95.
Motorbooks has it.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 19 Oct 94 10:45:10 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 951s and turbocharging

 
Hi, Tracy.
 
Even if you are getting 1.2 bar of boost at 2000 rpm, that doesn't mean you
will feel strong acceleration there. It all depends on the cam and how well
the engine breathes at that speed.
 
Consider that a non-turbo has one atmosphere (more or less) of absolute intake
manifold pressure when the throttle is wide open. Your turbo, if the gauge
is to be believed, has 2.2 atmospheres absolute pressure at 2000 rpm (1
atmosphere ambient, + 1.2 bar boost, = 2.2; a bar is one atmosphere is 14.7
lbs/sq. in. more or less). OK, so a non-turbo has 1 atmosphere or bar
absolute to work with at 2000 or 4000 or whatever rpm. Your turbo has 2.2 at
2000 or 4000 or whatever absolute pressure to work with. Just as you
would not expect the non-turbo to pull strongly at 2000, the turbo won't
either, unless it was designed to do so at low rpm (like a truck
or tractor or piston aircraft engine).
 
As you have correctly surmised from watching the boost gauge, you do have
boost at low rpm, just nothing happens. People who say the car comes onto
the turbo at 3000 or 4000 or whatever are wrong; it has boost well before
that, and the electronically controlled wastegate keeps it steady at 1.2 bar
across a wide band. The reason you don't feel a kick until 3000 or whatever
is that that is the engine's torque curve, which is really a reflection of
the breathing efficiency (engineers call it volumetric efficiency) of the
engine. Non-turbos exhibit the exact same effect. This is just the way the
cam and valves and all that apparatus flows air as a function of rpm. The
newer 968 with resonance induction and variable valve timing (VarioCam) has
a broader torque band; it's like having two different cams in the engine,
and switching between them. By the way, the electronic
boost gauge (I don't know if your car is digital readout or analog dial) are
placebo gauges. On the 911 Turbo, they reach a predetermined value and stop.
That's to keep Joe Goldchain from going in to the dealer and saying Tom
Toupee's Turbo goes to 0.72 bar while his only goes to 0.71 and fix the damn
thing, will ya? (It doesn't matter, but Goldchain doesn't know that).
 
One trick to keep boost up on turbos is to shift very quickly. Drag racers
are able to shift without taking their foot off the throttle, but I
would not recommend this with any car you plan to own for any length of
time. I do it when testing cars for magazines, but then I get to give them
back a week later. (Except for a Lotus, which was doomed to fail anyway, I
have never broken any engine bits in 6 years of this "power shifting" or
"speed shifting").
 
Another trick to get going from a standstill with a turbo is to make sure
you have boost before engaging the clutch. You can sit there at a red light
and rev the thing to 6000 rpm all day, and it will not make much boost. The
engine has to be under load; you have to have the throttle wide open to make
boost, and you can't get the throttle wide open by holding revs constant
with the clutch out. The trick is to nail the throttle wide open from idle
with the clutch pedal down, and then when the revs pass the point where the
engine is making maximum torque, more or less (adjust rpm up or down to
compensate for tire grip) you engage the clutch. Not violently, not by
sidestepping it and letting the pedal snap back (some magazines test by
revving to 6000 and sidestepping the clutch. They break lots of cars but
because they are BIG magazines the manufacturers keep sending them more).
The idea of flooring the throttle from idle is to build up some boost by
making the engine work against its own rotational inertia. It can't do that
if held at constant rpm; it's only working against internal friction then. If
you do this right, upon engaging the clutch smoothly but quickly,
your engine will "hang" at some intermediate RPM (remember
you have engaged the clutch well before the engine could reach redline) while
the tires fight for grip. Once they have grip, the revs will climb toward
redline and you now drive as you normally would. Now, if the tires break loose
and the tach heads for the redline with spinning tires, it means you let the
revs go too high before engaging the clutch. On your next try, let the clutch
in maybe 500 rpm lower. If the engine rpms suddenly sag, you launched at too
low an rpm. Try 500 rpm higher. As you fine tune this, you may try 200 rpm
increments. What you want to look for is a brief second or two where the
tach "hangs" at one rpm, or drops no more than 50-100 rpm, before going up
normally to redline.
 
The quickest accelerating turbo I've ever tested, not counting the Brumos
IMSA Porsche Turbo a couple of years ago, was the 3.3 liter Turbo of I think
1991 or so, before they went to 3.6 liters. I tested that on a 40 degree F.
day on a deserted road in France. Turbos like cold air, and I would never be
able to get such performance here in California, at the Pomona drag strip
(70-80-100 deg. F). Using the technique described above, and power shifting
(leaving right foot down) I saw 0-60 mph in 4.25 seconds, repeatably. I
just looked up my test gear printout, the launch rpm was something like
3500 rpm. 1/4 mile in 12.74 at 108.9 mph.
 
Power shifting -- if you rev to redline, leave right foot down and then VERY
QUICKLY hit the clutch, yank the shift lever and get off the clutch, you
will not overrev. The engine can't overcome its internal rotating inertia
that quickly at peak rpm. Like I said, don't do it with something you plan
to keep.
 
For comparison, the Brumos car got 0-60 in 4.52, but that was not at full
throttle; this was the scariest ride I've ever seen at full throttle in
first gear and I couldn't use the technique described above, as the back end
would break loose and the car would slew back and forth violently. But it
did the quarter mile at 119.3 mph, and it takes a lot of power to make up
for time lost in first gear and reach such a high speed (1/4 mile time was
12.61, not that much better than stock 12.74). I figure the Brumos car had
450 - 500 hp.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 19 Oct 94 10:45:23 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: TurboS Brakes

Hi, Jerry.
 
Brembo's rep in the U.S. is, by all accounts, impossible to deal with. But
you should call Todd Gartshore at Baer Racing in Phoenix, he may be able to
help. Baer imports Brembo stuff independently. 1-602-233-1411
 
It doesn't make sense to replace perfectly good pistons. I know that for the
356 you can buy a seal kit consisting of the rubber dust bootie, the steel
spring ring that holds it, two clips for the brake pad retaining pins
and the piston rubber seal for I think about $10
a wheel. The pistons are $45 each, $90 a wheel. Unless the Brembos are built
differently, I would think the seal installs the same way and the piston
need not (and probably should not) come out.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 09:21:32 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: Smog check questions


      There's obviously a lot of experience on the net with "smog check,"   
    now we (Harris County aka Houston Tx) are going to have this instituted. 
    I have 2 cars that I'm worried about; a '70 with nary a smog device 
    designed into it and a '79 with its Catalytic Converters removed.
    My question to anybody who knows is;
 
      1. Are older cars exempt from testing ?  How old does the car have to
         be before nobody cares (even the '70 is a daily driver) ?

      2. Do the sniff test limits vary with the year of the car ? i.e., does
         my '70 w/o even a smog pump have to test as clean as a '94 Honda ?

      3. Assuming that the '79 car passes "visual" check, is there any hope
         it will pass the sniff test ? (the cats are there, just 
         hollowed out).

      4. Are there any good ways to cheat ? I'm wondering if there is any
         high-alcohol fuel mixture possible that appears clean enough
         to pass test.... 

        After reading the August issue of National Geographic relating the 
      environmental damage in the USSR, I'm starting to get past the very
      non-chalant attitude about just how much CO and NOx I'm spewing, and
      can respect what I once thought was environmental extremism. But
      I'm also interested in DRIVING....

       5. As a last question, about Lambda sensors; I'm considering putting
          one in my exhaust to monitor mixture. The Bosch unit appears to 
          act as a switch, i.e. above 14.9:1 a/f it puts out 0.2v,below
          14.5:1 a/f it puts out 0.9v. Is there another kind of oxygen sensor
          that is more linear over a 12:1 to 15:1 air/fuel range ?

     
       Thanks--Lee A. (on Greenpeace's hit list)

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 10:53:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Vertex


I've had good dealings with Vertex.  Just beware the advertised prices 
varies between magazines (Euro Car, Excellence, Pano).  Pano usually seems 
to have the best price, but not always.  Perhaps due to different publisher 
deadlines?  If you order parts from them, make sure you get them to verify 
the prices and double check the bill on receipt.

For example, I recently ordered rear rotors for my 928 advertised in Pano @ 
$60 each, advertised @ $70 in other magazines.  When I received them (ATE 
rotors), the invoice listed them at $70.  I called and they promptly gave me 
a $20 refund and an apology for the mix up.  No bitching required.

Anyone can mess up, how it's handled afterwards tells you allot about the 
company.  They handled it very well.  Their shipping charges are fair, 
unlike some other part houses that see it as a profit center.  I have 
ordered from them twice now and would order from them again.

PAP in GA is also very good.  Their unadvertised prices are sometimes better 
than those at Vertex.  I get my filters and other parts from them.  Vertex 
claims to beat any price, if you want to haggle.  I never bothered on the 
small orders I have placed.  With all the parts you are looking to get, it 
may be worth a few calls.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 10:34:23 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 Brakes update

Here is a progress report on my 914 brakes.  (I have had a mushy/springy feeling brake
pedal and less than effective braking force.)

After much fiddling with the stock 914 proportioning valve and many test drives, I could not
get a satisfactory pedal feel and I could not get the rear brakes to lock up.  I decided to replace
the stock valve with an aftermarket unit.  I located a Wilwood proportioning valve at a local
racing supply shop and spent about a week hunting down the correct adapters to convert
from the metric brake lines to the 1/8 NPT threads in the Wilwood valve.  I ended up bending
and installing new brake lines to connect up to the proportioning valve, saving the original lines
in case I ever needed to go back to the stock valve.  The Wilwood valve output pressure is
adjustable from 57% to 100% of the input pressure.

The pedal feels very solid now.  The harder I push, the harder it pushes back - no more springy
region as the pedal gets half way to the floor.  Unfortunately, even with full rear bias, I still can not
lock up the rear wheels.  Either the stock 914 rear calipers are not strong enough to do this or
there is still something wrong somewhere.

I am considering a few options:
1.  Replace my unknown brand of brake pads with pads known to have a good grip.
      (Ferodo street pads?)
2.  Rebuild my rear calipers.  I should do this anyway as I have noticed that (at least) one of the
      piston dust boots is cracked.  Maybe I have a seized piston?
3.  Temporarily cap off the brake lines going to the front calipers and test the effectiveness
      of the rear brakes by themselves.  I stress that this would be a temporary, controlled test
      done just to determine how well the rear brakes are working.  I think they are doing something
      because the rear rotors do get hot, although not as hot as the front rotors.  I would expect this.

Overall, I like the new proportioning valve.  Even though it didn't fix my rear brake problem, installing
it was worth it for the improved pedal feel alone.  Anyone else considering a swap might want to
take the effort to find a valve with metric fittings as it was a lot of work to find the correct adapters.

Pete Klager



------------------------------

|          high-alcohol fuel mixture possible that appears clean enough
|          to pass test....
'cheating 'usually involves setting the car up as lean as possible, getting it
past the check, and then richening the mixture back up. as far as actual
cheating goes, i've not heard about it. if your car is in good shape, 
you shouldn't
have any problems.

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 11:06:50 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Smog check questions

>       There's obviously a lot of experience on the net with "smog check,"   
>     now we (Harris County aka Houston Tx) are going to have this instituted. 
>     I have 2 cars that I'm worried about; a '70 with nary a smog device 
>     designed into it and a '79 with its Catalytic Converters removed.
>     My question to anybody who knows is;

I started looking at this a few years ago... Having just about identical 
concerns.

>       1. Are older cars exempt from testing ?  How old does the car have to
>          be before nobody cares (even the '70 is a daily driver) ?

"older" is pre-68. Your '70 will be subject to the same scruitiny as a '89.
Different specific standards, yes, but the intent is the same. All the
emissions stuff must be there. All the levels at the pipe must be as spec'd.

>       2. Do the sniff test limits vary with the year of the car ? i.e., does
>          my '70 w/o even a smog pump have to test as clean as a '94 Honda ?

The spec you have to meet is the as-published spec for your car for your 
year. There's no "must be this clean to drive" spec. Fortunately.

>       3. Assuming that the '79 car passes "visual" check, is there any hope
>          it will pass the sniff test ? (the cats are there, just 
>          hollowed out).

Maybe. Then again, maybe not. And see below....

>       4. Are there any good ways to cheat ? I'm wondering if there is any
>          high-alcohol fuel mixture possible that appears clean enough
>          to pass test.... 

Well, in TX the DPS will be running the emissions stations initially,
then handing them over to approved contractors. It's not like a state
inspection or for that matter like emissions checks in CA. There have
been rumors of chassis dyno checks for dynamic measurements. If they
do that, it's gonna be tough to cheat... And if Trooper Bob is actually
running the station, don't even think about bribery....

A good friend of mine was the DPS captain responsible for implementing this
in the metro Houston area. Unfortunately, he had to take early retirement
and move to Little Rock to deal with a major family crisis. I'm trying to
get him to connect me with someone on the inside that can keep me informed
and might be willing to hearing an enthusiast view...

Stan

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 11:11:54 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Brakes update

> I still can not
> lock up the rear wheels.  Either the stock 914 rear calipers are not strong 
> enough to do this or
> there is still something wrong somewhere.

Something's wrong. Really wrong.

> I am considering a few options:
> 1.  Replace my unknown brand of brake pads with pads known to have a good grip.
>       (Ferodo street pads?)

CoolCarbon orange compound. Frodo pads are for hobbit cars. They just don't
work as well as the latest technology. Sort of like Pirelli tires.

> 2.  Rebuild my rear calipers.  I should do this anyway as I have noticed that (at least) one of the
>       piston dust boots is cracked.  Maybe I have a seized piston?

Most likely the problem. I discovered in doing a brake job on my 356SC that
of four rear pistons, only *ONE* was actually moving. No wonder the
brakes felt so bad...

> 3.  Temporarily cap off the brake lines 

Don't do this. It's not necessary. If the rear is working right, they
*will* lock up, even with stock Textar pads.

Stan

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 09:32:16 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 Spark Plugs


Andy,

The correct plugs are W7DC. WR7DP or WR7DS may be substituted. Gap
at .028". Always check the gap prior to installation no matter what 
the manufacturer tells you.

1976-1979 924    W7DC
1980-1984 924    WR7DS
1980      924 Turbo WR7DS
1981-1984 924 Turbo WR6DS

R= resistor type plug
D= the reach or type insulator
C= Copper electrode
S= Silver electrode
P= Platinum electrode

Jim Pasha

Dave,

     If  your  ignition switch problem is electrical,  you  don't
have   to   remove   the  cover  plate.   The   electrical   (non
lock/tumbler) portion of the switch comes off from the under-dash
side, although a double-jointed elf would help.

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 13:15:00 
From: "Sanford, Frank" <FES@scires.com>
Subject: 914 D-Jetronic F.I.


I own a 71' 914 with the 1.7L and F.I.. While chasing wires and testing
components for a fuel problem (which turned out to be a pressure sensor which
was filled with corrosion and rust) I found my F.I. wiring harness, "brain", and
throttle switch were all for a 73' model. I didn't mind this in the least since
1. they're newer  and 2. the later model "brain" allows me to adjust the fuel
mixture. This leads to my 2 questions:

    1. Should I be adjusting my CO% for the 71' or the lower (in CO%) 73' specs.


    2. As far as I can tell, the only other difference between the 71' and 73'
F.I. systems is a deceleration valve on the 73' models. From what I've read and
understand, the 71' model F.I. had a different throttle switch with extra
contacts so that the "brain" would know to shut off the fuel during
deceleration, while the 73' model instead used the decel' valve to inject extra
air to take care of the extra fuel during deceleration. My question is: since at
this time I don't have either system in place, should I hook one (most likely
the decel' valve- its cheap,easy, and goes along with the reast of my
components) up? Is there any performance benefit (ie; fuel economy, etc.) or
does it help engine longevity, or is it "only" for smog prevention? It doesn't 
have to pass any emmisions tests but I'm willing to make it as mechanically and
enviromentally correct as needed, as long as the price isn't outrageous (which
this doesn't seem to be).

Any thoughts, insights, or comments would be appreciated.

Frank Sanford
fsanford@scires.com
Atlanta, GA

71' 914 1.7L

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 10:21:28 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: How Do I Take It Off?


     Do you mean the black round cover plate that goes around
     the keyhole and is on the dash?  If so, thats an easy one.
     Look around the edge of the circumference of the plate.
     You'll see about four tiny holes about 3mm dia around the
     circumference.  Insert two pins which will fit *snug* into
     two holes which are opposite each other.  Hold the pins
     and turn the cover plate anti-clockwise to unscrew it from
     the ignition keyhole.  If it is too difficult to turn, just
     insert one pin and hold it in place while tapping *lightly*
     on the pin with a small and light plastic faced hammer/mallet.
     
     Be careful not to scratch your dash!!!  Mask the dash area
     with masking tape before you attempt this.
     
     Derek Au
     
     
     
     P.S.  Welding rod or stiff coat hangar wire may work well.  Or
     best of all, a bent pin punch.
     
     
_____________________________________________________________
     
 Well, the responses to this ought to be interesting...
     
 After much moaning and gnashing of teeth, I'm going 
to have to replace the ignition switch in my 911.  So I got 
out my Haynes manual, and it sez, with marvelous brevity, to 
remove the switch cover plate.
     
 No kidding.  But how?  shotgun?  chainsaw?  blowtorch?
If anybody has done this without ruining the plate and/or 
scratching the dash, please enlighten me.  Other than the 
shear bolts, what else should I replace whilst I'm in there?
     
Dave ('84 Carrera Targa, platinum metallic) 
wife, assorted kids, mortgage, etc

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 14:05:34 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Vertex, low price leaders

I've purchased parts from Vertex on a couple of occassions and been
completely satisfied.  The parts were first class and the service OK.  I had
forgotten about the adder surcharge for credit card but I even with the 2%
their prices are excellent.

Recently I faxed a list of 911 engine rebuild parts to several advertisers in
Pano and Excellence.  Europroducts and Vertex were consistantly the lowest.
 EBS, in Colo. also had good prices.  One must factor in Sales Tax. For
example, in CA it is over 8% so one can save by ordering out of state.

 -Allen Henderson, Los Gatos CA-
'72 911S, silver coupe

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 11:06:54 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: 928's forever!

>From Bob:
>>      I guess you are allowed the same 6 modification points as us
>> SC's,  but  your  point  is  well taken.  I  have  NEVER  seen  a
>> competitive 928 at one of our autoXs.  They just can't get around
>> all  those  corners fast enough.  They do great on  the  straight
>> sections though.
>> 
>>      Seriously,  it's  no fun to be totally  uncompetitive.   Why
>> don't  we bring it up to the autoX comittee.  Arbitrary rules can
>> always  be changed.  Maybe we would get more 928s out if they had
>> a competitive class to run in.
>> 
>> Bob
>> 
>> PS.   Maybe  you should try Holtville next month.   I  understand
>> they have a 1 mile straight!
Yeah, I hear the speeds get pretty high.  Just make sure you've got
someone to pull you out of the bush!  8-)

>> 
>> 
>> 
>From Bill:
>> Yo Bob!!!
>> 
>> Thanks for the response; but what six modifications can I do legally?  How
>> many do bigger tires count?  Or a bolt-in roll-cage?  How about
>> aftermarket shocks?  A smoother driver?  A less-smokey engine?  Headers?
>> 
>> But what is really important here is that I beat the woman in my class (smiley
>> face here)!  Wait, let me get my nomex on...
>> 
>> 

Bill,

San Diego Region uses the Zone 8 rules.  The way it works, as Bob
has pointed out above, is that you get so many points to play with for
each progressively higher catagory (from "stock" to "prepared" to
"improved" to "modified").  The points are assigned for each of the
mods (not one per mod) as the Zone 8 rules commitee has determined to
assign the points.  

This system is often villafied, but it allows for personal choice as
to the mods that a person can make to a car.  Also, this helps keep
cars within a class competitive.  Way back when, there were several
drivers that ran 928's at both time trials and autocrosses and I've
seen some of the trophies taken by these cars, so they can be
competitive.  

  So, here's a quick rundown on your listed mods:
	bigger tires		2pts and up (depends on how big you
				             go)
	bolt in cage		0pts (as long as you don't go through
				      a firewall or to a suspension point)
	shocks			0pts (as long as they are the same
        			      style as stock - brands and valving 
				      are all free!)
	smoother driver		0pts 
	less_smokey engine	0pts (and then we won't think it's a
				      914)
	headers			0pts (for exhaust mods - just keep it
				       under 92dB.)

So, you're looking at 2-4 pts for tire size (unless you're going
_really_ big) so there's still points to play with.  Such a deal!

I suggest you get a copy of the Zone 8 rules, study up, and if you
want a change, now is the time to suggest it.  The Zone 8 presidents
meeting will be in San Diego at the Zone 8 Time Trial on Nov. 19.
This would be a great place to suggest any changes, or send them to
the rules guys beforehand.

What you guys really have to worry about is that I'm looking for a new
class to run my 914 in next year... humm, 928s and SCs, sounds pretty
easy to me.... 8-) 8-)

...time for my nomex...

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com
(still here...)
'72 914 (the Black Widow)

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 11:34:55 PDT
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: Re: 914 D-Jetronic F.I.

; Frank Sanford said...
; Subject: 914 D-Jetronic F.I.
; 
; I own a 71' 914 with the 1.7L and F.I.. 


	Isn't a '71 914/1.7 an L-jet injected motor ? 

; 
;     1. Should I be adjusting my CO% for the 71' or the lower (in CO%) 73' specs.


	Depends on what year cam you have. Typically mid 70's cars will open the exhaust valve
earlier to reduce combustion temperature, and thus reduce NOx emissions. I don't know the
specifics of cam timing fro different 914 years/displacements these...


;     2. As far as I can tell, the only other difference between the 71' and 73'
; F.I. systems is a deceleration valve on the 73' models. 

	The decel valve was to richen the mixture on trailing throttle in order
to reduce combustion temperature; thus lowering Nitrogen oxide emissions (NOx).
Ca. smog tests don't currently test NOx on older cars. 

; understand, the 71' model F.I. had a different throttle switch with extra
; contacts so that the "brain" would know to shut off the fuel during
; deceleration, while the 73' model instead used the decel' valve to inject extra
; air to take care of the extra fuel during deceleration.

	D-jet meters fuel primarly by mainfold pressure. Injecting air resulted
in injection of more fuel and a richer mixture. This was to reduce NOx at the expense of 
Hydrocarbons.

Throttle switch in D-jet is to richen the mixture on opening the throttle. If you
turn on the ignition and open the throttle, you can hear the injection firing (clickclickclick)



; My question is: since at
; this time I don't have either system in place, should I hook one (most likely
; the decel' valve- its cheap,easy, and goes along with the reast of my
; components) up? Is there any performance benefit (ie; fuel economy, etc.) or
; does it help engine longevity, or is it "only" for smog prevention? It doesn't 
; have to pass any emmisions tests but I'm willing to make it as mechanically and
; enviromentally correct as needed, as long as the price isn't outrageous (which
; this doesn't seem to be).

	 Removing the decel valve will improve compression braking with the only 
ill effects being higher NOx emissions and maybe slightly shorter exhaust valve life. 
...ff course disabling the decel valve is illegal in Ca. for street cars.


; 
; Frank Sanford
; fsanford@scires.com
; Atlanta, GA
; 
; 71' 914 1.7L
; 

							-jd
						"I don't know nothing about no L-jet"

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 15:05:54 -0400
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 944 windshield washer bottle story

This is a rather unimportant, but interesting 944 story.

Recently I noticed that I was using up the supply of windshield washer fluid
in my 944S2 too quickly. When I spotted the puddle on the floor after I
filled it up, I concluded that there was a leak in the bottle, so I removed
it last night.

There was no leak:  Rather a 'straw' from the electric pump is simply
press-fit into a hole in the bottle. Over the miles the pump assembly had
jiggled around (I guess) and exposed the hole, so the fluid all leaked out.
Solution: push the pump straw back into the hole.

I don't think that Gerhard und Fritz did their best engineering work the day
they designed this method.

Fred Pack

PS: I think the waterbottle is a VW part, so maybe Gerhard und Fritz work
for VW.

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 14:40:54 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Brakes update

>   > work as well as the latest technology. Sort of like Pirelli tires.
> 
> Sorry if I missed something, but what's wrong with Pirelli tires?

Only a  few things....

1) they don't stick as well as any of the Yoko, BFG, or Goodyear
   rubber

2) oh yeah -- the P-Zero *DOES* stick pretty well but not nearly enough
   to justify it's pricing 50-75% over the other tires that perform
   just as well.

3) they go out of round at around 20k miles

4) they largely suck in the wet (except the P-600 which makes up for
   it by largely sucking the rest of the time)

Gone are the days when the CN-36 was *THE* tire to have and the P-7
was spoken of in reverential terms. Pirelli just sat on past glories
these days, as far as performance tires go, is just about irrelevant.

Stan

Hi all, 
 
      Regarding the oil on my 944's front wheels, after the advice from  
      you all, I took a close look and found the following: 
           -    Ball, shaft seal is leaking. 
           -    Cam housing is leaking (very slight). 
 
      Both these above leaks are very small and there is no dripping on 
      my garage floor. I don't have the know-how to fix this, and even 
      if I was prepared to do it from the workshop manual, I don't have 
      the required tools. So I am badly in need of a Porsche workshop. 
      Please let me know of any good P-shop in the Bay area. I live in 
      Sunnyvale CA, and wouldn't mind driving to a place a bit far off. 
 
      I am switching to synthetic engine oil (mobil 1) today. The car 
      was previously on organic oil. Any advantages/disadvantages for 
      synthetic oil in 944's? Also, what is the oil change frequency 
      for synthetic's? 
 
      thanks, 
      sreelal 
      '84 944

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 16:47:35 EDT
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: October Porshing Column


My personal mailing list for my monthly newsletter column has gotten
large enough that I decided to just start sending my column to the
whole Porschephiles list.  It is, and shall be, merely for entertainment.
If you don't like it, don't read it.  Feel free to use it in another
publication as long as my name and region are preserved.

Porsching - by Chris Welty, Hudson-Champlain Region

Perhaps I hadn't been paying attention.  Perhaps I was unaware that
the sun had been trying all day to break through the protective layer
of clouds.  I barely noticed the patches of blue sky in front of me,
but other than this, there was no warning.

Fire.  Bright blasts of searing heat detonated in waves of color,
blistering the paint on my blood-orange 911.  Poking through holes in
the scattered cloud cover, sunlight exploded on the trees in blinding
bursts of light - summer's verdant flame had been replaced by the
intense inferno of fall.

The air hissed loudly in protest, but like a fiery arrow I flew down
the blazing highway, creating brief swirling maelstorms of red,
yellow, and orange in my wake.  There was no stopping in this
firestorm, the ardent forest blasted my eyes until I could barely see
the road, and my ears were continuously assaulted by the deafening roar.

The heat was unbearable, surely neither I nor my car could withstand
it much longer.  The entire forest was ablaze, the flames blowing over
the road with the currents of rapidly rising air.  It was too late to
turn back, my only choice lay ahead in the hope that a break in the
inferno, a brief respite from the ceaseless burning, might offer
relief.

The turbulence of my passage evoked incindiary retaliation from the
forest, behind me now was a sheer wall of flame, which would soon
overtake and envelop my vehicle.  Survival now became a question of
speed, and my surroundings blurred into a swirling mass of blinding
color.  Car control was a matter of instinct, as temperature became
my all consuming concern.  The paint, coaxed on by the intense heat
around it, began to erupt in small flashes as it bubbled off the
surface, revealing the bare metal beneath.  My own skin was not far
behind, I felt as if I would ignite at any moment.   My breathing got
shorter, unable to compete for oxygen with the all-consuming fire.

I burst forth from the forest in a shower of flames.  I cranked the
wheel hard and slammed on the brakes, bringing the car around to face
from whence I had come.  After a moment for my vision to return, I
noticed that the clouds had once again succeeded in cutting the supply
of sunlight, and without this to fuel it, the forest had returned
to a cooler, more timid display of color.

"Oh," said my wife, just waking up. "The leaves are changing."

I shook my head.  She had no idea...


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 13:52:12 PDT

Whats up with this?

Tom

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 15:11:32 CDT
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)

> Speaking of F1 (and again having nothing to do with Porsches) last night
> on the local Telemundo affiliate, I would swear that the announcer said
> Paul Tracy is going to Benneton next year. Reality check: is this true,
> or do I need to send those Spanish-recognizing neurons in for a checkup??

Tracy tested with Benetton several weeks ago.  Rumors exist that he
signed a deal to drive for Benetton *IF* he goes to F1 in the next
3 years.  However, he will be in IndyCars next year as he has signed
with Newman-Haas to partner Michael Andretti.

One far-fetched rumor is that Penske is buying McLaren who will
drop Peugeot for Mercedes.  Since Schumacher's Benetton contract
is only through '95, he will return to Mercedes (at McLaren) for
'96 and be partnered by Tracy.

Obligatory Porsche content:  Has Porsche found someone to bankroll
their F1 V-10 for next year?

mjt

Tom,

I don't get the relationship between Tracy and Ham.......

Ham was not spending time in Europe driving the car and testing. Because of
this, and his lack of familiarity with the circuits in Europe, led to poor
performances on the track. Because of this, he was fired and someone new
was hired (I forgot his name).

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 16:19:16 CDT

If I recall correctly from Octobers Pano, this wouldn't have come as 
a surprise.  In the article Nick Ham seemed to say that he was on the
hook to produce at Hockenheim.  He didn't seem to mind this as he
said that he normally did well at Hockenheim.  However, on race day
he didn't run well and made some crucial mistakes ending up with a
finish well down the pack.

I guess this was the last straw for the team manager and from your mail
it looks like the team has asked Nick to move on.

Richard Hocking

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 16:13:42 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: Smog check questions

>> >       2. Do the sniff test limits vary with the year of the car ? i.e., does
>> >          my '70 w/o even a smog pump have to test as clean as a '94 Honda ?
>> 
>> The spec you have to meet is the as-published spec for your car for your 
>> year. There's no "must be this clean to drive" spec. Fortunately.


Well, look out.  There's a lot of talk that this is the next step here
in CA.  If your car is so clean (factory specs, at the motor, not
after the cat.) you drive so many miles.  If you go over, extra taxes
and extra smog checks and possible fines.  Nothing is really clear
yet, but a lot of talk.  Still, this is the way all of the other
checks started.

Now, where to put that odometer cut-off switch in the 944...

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 17:16:10 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: Smog check questions

>> ....  God forbid they actually
>> try to charge according to road wear and tear, gas consumption,
>> and overall environmental impact.  

Actually, the latest word is that it's not gas consumption that is 
the problem, but emissions - straight out of the engine, that is to
be taken into account.  So, if your new 55mpg Honda isn't clean at the
engine (no, after the cat doesn't count) you won't get to go as far as
a "clean" car.

>> Hehe, that's the great thing about the 914...  The odo only works
>> intermittently.

Yeah, I wonder if that was a "feature" that the factory designed in in
anticipation of laws like this.  8-) 8-)

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914 (with a working odometer/speedometer!!!)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 20:21:20 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 various messages

I noticed a few 914 messages worth commenting on:

1. On fast idle: I forgot in my note about fast idle and AAR's to mention 
something learned at the side of the master (Stan). To find out if a 
vacuum hose is leaking, spray carb cleaner at the hoses (especially the 
ends) while the car is running. A bad hose will suck in the air and idle 
will be even faster for a few seconds. Replace that hose. (We replaced 
ALL our hose even though the old tested ok; very little work or expense.)

2. On injectors and testing whether one is bad: Our 914 73 2.0L has gotten
pretty bad gas mileage. I noticed the other day that there was a gas
smell, and have since replaced one bad injector (gas was dripping out
underneath) and seals. (thanks Stan) Two others appear to have gas
covering the bottoms (finger under the injector comes up with a film of
gas)...all will be replaced by Sat at 11 AM. If you suspect the injectors 
are bad, you might try this finger under injector test...even slight 
fuel leaks are bad news. 

3. On parts from Auto Atlanta: If I could not find the part anywhere 
else, and I was desparate, I *might* call them. I do call Performance 
Products, Tweeks, High-Performance House and the dealer too. Although 
I've been told that High Performance House is high priced, he is much 
less than AA (1/2 in many cases) for used parts, and HPH's used parts 
are tested and work (at least for me). Parts Heaven is good too.

Enjoy

Mark

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 17:52:40
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Motor racing-Michael Andretti, Tracy replace Mario, Mansell (fwd)

Hi there all you interested in indy cars here is mess from
newsgroup 

                                mike

                FORWARDED MAIL ------- From:
C-reuters@clarinet.com (Reuters) Date: 18 Oct 94 Originally Posted
On: clari.sports.motor 

         LINCOLNSHIRE, Ill. (Reuter) - Canadian Paul Tracy and
American Michael Andretti were named Tuesday as the new drivers
for the Newman/Haas IndyCar motor racing team, replacing
Britain's Nigel Mansell and Andretti's father Mario.
         Financial terms of the deals were not announced, but owner
Carl Haas said Andretti had signed for three years.
         Regarding Tracy, Haas said in a teleconference, ``We both
understand that we're looking forward to a longterm relationship
and I think that will happen, without going into a lot of
details of the situation.''
         Tracy, 25, comes over from this year's dominant Penske team,
for whom he finished third in series points and tied Mansell
with a season-high five victories. Mansell, a former Formula One
and IndyCar season champion, is back on the Formula One circuit
after two IndyCar campaigns.
         Tracy in the last two seasons had eight IndyCar wins, second
only to Al Unser Jr.
         A British racing magazine reported last month that Benetton
was believed to have offered Tracy a three-year deal worth some
$8.5 million to race in Formula One.
         Said Tracy of his European experience: ``The way things had
unfolded I was asked to come over, no strings attached. When I
got there, the situation changed. I wasn't about to sign
anything just to do a test on a car.
         ``I had my plans set for what I definitely wanted to do for
1995, that was to drive for Carl. I gave him my word on that,
and my word is good. We shook hands on the deal weeks and weeks
before anything of Formula One testing came up.''
         Tracy added: ``A contract was offered but it's something
right now I'm not interested in. I'd like to win a championship
in IndyCars first.''
         Tracy also said, ``At the end of '95 we'll make a decision
where we're going to be.''
         Tracy got some advice from his new teammate and from Mansell
about dealing with the Formula One scene.
         ``I might have told him, just don't trust them over there,''
said Andretti.
         ``I talked to Mansell and a lot of guys from Formula One,
and they said, don't trust anybody,'' said Tracy. ``You almost
have to wear a sheet of armor on your back when you walk around
there.''
         Andretti, 32, replaces his father Mario, who retired after
spending the last 12 years of his 31-year IndyCar career with
Newman/Haas. The younger Andretti is rejoining a team for whom
he raced from 1989-1992.
         During that time, he won the title in 1991, was the series
runner-up in 1990 and 1992 and ranked third in 1989. He won 20
races and 21 pole positions in 64 starts with the team, more
than any other driver in the four-year period.
         ``It feels like I'm going home with this Newman/Haas team,''
said Andretti, who upon his father's retirement became the
winningest active IndyCar driver with 29 victories.
         The big challenge for the Newman/Haas team is to catch up
with the Penske operation, where Tracy's teammates were
Brazilian Emerson Fittipaldi and Unser.
         ``We're having new cars designed, new Lolas, and we're
continuing to use the newest version of the Cosworth engine,''
said Haas.
         ``Michael and I bring a lot to the table this year, Michael
being the factory Reynard driver and myself being at Penske the
last 3 1/2 years,'' said Tracy.
         ``We know pretty much what is going on with their new cars
for the future, which I think gives us pretty much of an upper
hand for 1995 in terms of developing the new Lola.''
         Said Andretti: ``Everybody on the team is working very hard
to attack the Penskes, obviously, because they seem to be the
team to beat. Knowing what they're doing, what's happening
within the team, I think we are going to be competitive with
them.''
         Haas said of the inside information his drivers were
briging, ``It's not an automatic magic, so to say, but it's good
input and there might be some things we can pick up.''
         Tracy said there had been difficulties with Penske's
three-car operation.
         ``With three cars at Penske it was a tremendous strain on
the team and the crew guys,'' said Tracy. ``Sometimes it looked
great from the outside but from within, it was quite a struggle.
For me, going back to a two-car team with a more concentrated
effort, I think it's the best situation for me.''
         He added of Roger Penske's chances of enticing him back,
''If everything goes right it's going to be pretty tough for him
to get me back. I'm pretty comfortable here right now.''

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 18:03:07 PDT
From: Mike Conte <mikecon@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Euro F1 results, Tracy

Tracy tested a Benneton and impressed them, getting into the 120's, but 
he said afterward that he would stay in Indycars for at least 3 years. 
Then it was announced that he had signed on with Newman - Haas to be 
Michael Andretti's team mate (below).

RESULTS             GRAND PRIX OF EUROPE
                    World Championship of Drivers, round 14;
                    Jerez, Spain , October 16th, 1994.
                    69 laps, 305,532 kms.

 1,Michael Schumacher,Benetton-Ford Zetec R B194,1h 40m 26,689 secs,182,507kph;
 2,Damon Hill, Williams-Renault FW16B, 1h 40m 51,378 secs;
 3,Mika Hakkinen, Marlboro McLaren-Peugeot MP4/9, 1h 41m 36,337 secs;
 4,Gerhard Berger, Ferrari 412 T1-B, 68 laps;
 5,Gerhard Berger, Ferrari 412 T1-B, 68 laps;
 6,Heinz-Harald Frentzen, Sauber-Mercedes C13, 68 laps;
 7,Ukyo Katayama, Tyrrell-Yamaha 022, 68 laps;
 8,Johnny Herbert, Ligier-Renault JS35B, 68 laps;
 9,Olivier Panis, Ligier-Renault JS35B, 68 laps;
 10,Jean Alesi, Ferrari 412 T1-B, 68 laps;
 11,Gianni Morbidelli, Footwork-Ford HB F15, 68 laps;
 12,Rubens Barrichello, Jordan-Hart 194, 68 laps;
 13,Mark Blundell, Tyrrell-Yamaha 022, 68 laps;
 14,Michele Alboreto, Minardi-Ford HB M194, 67 laps;
 15,Pierluigi Martini, Minardi-Ford HB M194, 67 laps;
 16,Alessandro Zanardi, Lotus-Honda-Mugen 109, 67 laps;
 17,Christian Fittipaldi, Footwork-Ford HB FA15, 66 laps;
 18,Eric Bernard, Lotus-Mugen-Honda 109, 66 laps;
 19,Domenico Schiattarella, Lotus-Mugen Honda 109, 64 laps.

Schumacher.

 Lap 42,David Brabham, Simtek-Ford HB S941, engine;
 Lap 47,Nigel Mansell, Williams-Renault FW16B, spun off.


GRAND PRIX WINNERS' PRESS CONFERENCE
                    GP of Europe, Jerez, October 16, 1994
                    (Courtesy Marlboro Sports Data System)

1. Michael Schumacher (Benetton-Ford); 2. Damon Hill 
(Williams-Renault), 24.7s behind; 3. Mika Hakkinen (McLaren-Peugeot), 
44.9s behind

Q. Congratulations, Michael.  How did you feel about today's win?

MS: Just great!  It's the best thing that could have happened, starting 
with the football match that my team won.  Everything went perfectly 
today, especially with pole position yesterday after the little problem 
that we had on Friday.  Then we won the race today not just by a little 
margin but by a big one.  That's exactly what you want to do.  I just 
want to say that it has been a hard time for everybody on our team.  
Everybody has been even more motivated, to push even harder.  And we 
are a team -- this is a great team -- working as a team.  It is a nice 
feeling.  Today we proved it again. This has been a big success for me 
and for the team.

Q. Your race seems to have gone perfectly.  Did anything go wrong today?

MS: It was a 99 per cent: the one per cent was being held up by 
somebody. Apart from the first set of tyres, the race went perfectly.  
This is just the way you like to come back to F1: this is where I left 
it.  I am really pleased about the way things happened.  It has been 
very difficult in the last two races, for the whole team and for me.  
It could have been that the situation in the team had changed.  There 
was the pressure, and things going on that might have put down the 
level of motivation, or things like that. But as soon as I came back 
and started to test at Estoril, everything went back to normal.  It has 
been an amazing effort: the guys have done a fantastic job.  We proved 
that our strategy was the quickest way, but first you have to make all 
the stops exactly right.  They worked out perfectly. Plus I had to work 
things out on the circuit, and this worked out as well. I am just very, 
very pleased.

Q. At the start it looked as though you moved, then stopped ...

MS: Yes, it was like that.  Normally the red light stays on for a 
shorter time.  This time it was on for ... quite a long time.  I was 
also very close to the bite point of the clutch, and the clutch heated 
up and suddenly started to drag.  I had to come off the clutch again, 
and when the green light came on I was not prepared.  Then I bogged 
down and picked up too much wheelspin.  It was a mess ...

Q. Damon, did you keep to your original pitstop strategy?

DH: We always planned to stop two times, but the second stop came a 
little earlier than I expected.  It mean that I had quite a long second 
stint, which, with hindsight, may not have been the right way to go.


Q. You seem to avoid doing the three stop strategy, which always seems 
to work for Michael ...

MS: I would agree, up to a point.  But you have to remember that I was 
ahead of Michael, on a two-stop strategy, when he came in to the pits. 
That meant that I should have been looking very good.  But the race 
seemed to go his way at mid-distance and we seemed to lose out during 
that period, when you would have expected it to be the other way 
around.  I am obviously pretty disappointed.  I have to say that I had 
got my hopes up about doing well here.  The margin of victory was 
greater than I would have liked, also. Nevertheless, by finishing 2nd 
here to Michael, my chances of winning the championship are still open. 
 And with Suzuka coming up I can look forward to a circuit where our 
horsepower advantage will be worth having. I think we put up a close 
fight here.  If, from the three [end-of-season] circuit, you had to 
chose the one where the Benetton could be expected to be at its best, 
it would probably be Jerez.  Second place here is not, er, great, but 
it has kept everything alive, and it is still a good result in a GP.

Q. Where were you missing out to Michael today?

MS: He just seemed to pull away in the middle part of the race much 
more than I expected.  It's difficult to say, really ... I have to 
analyse things after, because it's not always easy to do it when you've 
been in a race. After my second stop I could see Michael ahead of me, 
but I just wasn't able to push in order to stay with him.  He was 
getting away at too much of a rate.  I was not able to keep up the same 
pace without starting to make mistakes or working the tyres too hard.

Q. No problems with the car, then?

DH: None at all.  It was great.  But you can't drive it beyond a 
certain point before you start to get into handling difficulties.  Like 
anything, it has a finite limit.  Anyway, Michael drove a great race 
and it was exciting there, for a while.

Q. Did you feel you had bad luck with the backmarkers?

DH: No, not really.  Part of the problem was that we had too much fuel 
on in the middle part of the race -- and it is more difficult to pass 
with more fuel in the car.

Q. Mika, your fourth 3rd place running!  Having started 9th, then got 
involved in that lively group at the beginning, was it a good race?

MH: It was really exciting today.  I was more or less watching what was 
going on, but I didn't want to join in so badly because it didn't look 
like much fun to me.  So I was waiting to see what happened.  Also, my 
car wasn't handling too well on the first set of tyres and I didn't 
want to take any risks.  Our tactic was to do two stops in the race.  I 
think it was right for us, and it felt good.  When I put on the second 
set of tyres at the first stop, the car felt much better.  That gave me 
an opportunity to drive harder -- and it ended up really well.  I am 
really pleased about finishing 3rd.  Of course I would like to be the 
winner, but it wasn't going to happen today.

         NEWMAN/HAAS 1995: ANDRETTI, TRACY,  Kmart, BUDWEISER, TEXACO


     LINCOLNSHIRE, Ill. -- Michael  Andretti and Paul Tracy will drive 
for the Paul Newman-Carl Haas team in the 1995 PPG Indy Car World 
Series with primary sponsorship from Kmart Corp., Budweiser and 
Texaco/Havoline, it was announced today.

     Haas said during a news conference  that Andretti will return to 
Newman/Haas Racing to drive the Kmart/Texaco/ Havoline Lola, while 
Tracy will pilot the Kmart/Budweiser Lola. Both cars will use 
Ford-Cosworth engines, Goodyear Eagle tires and Havoline oil.

     Andretti, 32, of Nazareth, Pa.,  will replace his father, Mario, 
who has retired from Indy Car competition. Michael Andretti raced for 
Newman/Haas from 1989 through 1992, capturing the PPG Cup title in 
1991. He was the series runner-up in 1990 and 1992 and the third 
 -ranked driver in 1989. He won 20 races (31 percent) and 21 pole 
positions (32 percent) in 64 starts with the team, more than any driver 
during that four- year period.

     The Andrettis formed the sport's  only father-son team during 
Michael's previous stint with Newman/Haas. Mario has spent the last 12 
years of his 31 - year Indy Car career with Newman/Haas, his longest 
tenure with any one team. Michael had two wins this past season driving 
for Ganassi Racing and was fourth in PPG Cup points.

     Tracy, 25, of West Hill, Ontario,  Canada, is widely regarded as 
one of Indy Car racing's brightest young stars. Last year, in his first 
full season of competition, he tied Nigel Mansell with a series-high 
five victories and placed third in PPG Cup points. His peers voted him 
"Most Improved Driver."

     Tracy was the 1990 American Racing  Series (now called Indy 
Lights) champion with a record nine wins in 14 starts. He made his Indy 
Car debut the next year and joined Penske Racing mid-season as a test 
driver. He had three victories this past season, including the last two 
in-a -row, and again was third in the point standings.

     "Paul Newman and I are very pleased and excited that Michael and 
Paul will be driving for us," said Haas. "We enjoyed a lot of success 
with Michael in the past and, hopefully, that will again be the case.

     "Paul Tracy has proven that he is a fast and aggressive driver. 
Those are the qualities we want. We are delighted to have him."

     Michael Andretti said: "Going back  to Newman/Haas is kind of like 
going home. Paul and Carl provided a great home for Dad for many years, 
and also for me. I think the record proves the team and I worked very 
well together, and I'm really looking forward to re- establishing those 
relationships as we get ready for the 1995 season."

     Tracy said: "It's great to be with  the Newman/Haas team. There 
are only a few teams I'd want to drive for, and this is definitely one 
of them. I want to thank Paul and Carl for this opportunity and their 
confidence in me."


     Haas noted that Kmart, one of  America's largest retailers, will 
continue with Newman/Haas as a lead sponsor for the eighth consecutive 
year. The Budweiser brand of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., was the team's 
sponsor in 1983 and 1984, with Mario Andretti winning eight races and 
the 1984 PPG Cup championship under the colors of the "King of Beers." 
Texaco/Havoline has been a co-primary sponsor of Newman/Haas Racing since 1989.

     Joseph E. Antonini, chairman,  president and chief executive 
officer of Kmart Corp., said: "Kmart is proud of our partnership with 
the Newman/Haas Racing team and its professional approach to 
championship racing. We are especially pleased to welcome Michael 
Andretti back to the Kmart family and are excited that Paul Tracy is 
joining our team. The 1995 season promises to be one of excitement as 
Kmart also welcomes Budweiser as a primary sponsor. The 
Kmart/Texaco/Havoline and Kmart/Bud cars will proudly represent our 
commitment to excellence just as we strive to deliver that same 
commitment to customers of our Kmart Automotive Service Centers nationwide."


     Tony Ponturo, vice president,  Corporate Media and Sports 
Marketing for Anheuser-Busch, Inc., commented: "Everyone at Budweiser 
remembers fondly our role as the first primary sponsor of Newman/Haas 
Racing -- and driver Mario Andretti -- in 1983. The following year, 
Mario, Carl and Paul promptly rewarded Budweiser with a then-record six 
victories and the PPG Indy Car World Series championship, and stirred a 
passion for Indy Car racing at Budweiser that endures today. We are 
again proud to be a primary sponsor of the Newman/ Haas team -- and 
also of the brightest young driving star in Indy Car racing, Paul Tracy."

     Thomas M. Matthews, president of  Texaco Refining and Marketing 
Inc., said: "Newman/Haas Racing's reputation for achieving excellence 
is well known among Indy Car competition and its knowledgeable fans. We 
are proud to be associated with this outstanding team, our fellow 
co-sponsors Kmart and Budweiser, and the extremely talented Michael 
Andretti and Paul Tracy. This winning combination embodies the same 
spirit of excellence and top performance which we build into every 
Texaco product. We are looking forward to an exciting and successful 
1995 season."

     Haas added that associate sponsors  on both cars include 
Energizer, Gillette, Maxell, Uniden, Exide, RC Cola, Anderson 
Consulting, Braun, Bosch, Alexander Julian, Navistar trucks, Segerdahl 
Corp. and Yamazaen Inc..

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 21:32:30 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: porschephiles vs. AOL

All,

Has anyone besides me been having problems lately with AOL and porschephiles?
 Specifically, using Flashmail and getting garbage headers in the list of
mail you get?  Stan says I'm the only one to complain to him so far, but the
coincidence with the change in the way he sends out porschephiles and the
start of my problem is too large to ignore. If no one else has a problem,
I'll crawl back in my hole and ignore it...

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 20:44:33 PDT
From: George Durden <durden@bga.com>
Subject: Parts Suppliers

I thought I would share some experiences with you all regarding
some Porsche parts suppliers I've been dealing with. First, I've 
got very high marks for PartsHeaven. They have spent a non-
trivial amount of time on the phone discussing technical issues
regarding my 911 and 914, in one instance I ordered a parts kit,
received an incomplete kit, and they fedexed a complete new kit
to me (at no charge)  and told me to keep the first for future use...

Another supplier I've had good luck with is German Parts and 
Restoration. I've found them to have the absolute best prices
on Bosch FI parts and things like Oxygen Sensors. Usually about 
half price of places like Performance Products and/or Tweeks. The
other week, I ordered new CIS injectors for my 911, new injector seals,
and a set of washers for the banjo fittings at the fuel distributor. I ordered
everything on tuesday with 2nd day delivery so I'd have everything for the
weekend, on friday I found two packages on my doorstep, a box shipped
2nd day air with the injectors and seals, and a Fedex letter shipped overnight
with the washers! It turns out that they were out of stock on the washers when
they shipped my other stuff on wednesday, but washers came in late wednesday
so they packed up a set and overnighted them to me! (at their expense). Thats
what I call great customer service! Sooo... in the what it's worth department, I
highly recommend both PartsHeaven and German Parts and Restoration for
both good prices and high quality customer service....

George
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                                             George A. Durden
Home:                                  1980 911sc Targa         Office:
durden@bga.com              1976 914 2.0                  gad@odt.com

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 22:16:10 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  '83 928 heater always on

>>control valve was faulty by manually applying 18 psi vacuum to
>>the heater control valve. An 18 psi vacuum would close the valve
>>and eliminate the hot air. I tested the vacuum from the ACC
>>central diaphram and measured only 15 psi -- apparently not enough
>>to close the heater control valve.
>>
Something here does not compute. Atmospheric pressure is only 15 psi,
so that's the highest vacuum you can get. Probably just a gauge that's
mis-calibrated, but 18 psi vacuum implies negative 3 psi absolute.

My guess is that the valves are not very sensitive to exctly how much
vacuum is applied, since they have to deal with reduced vacuum during 
accelaration, for example. It is a little hard to tell, since your
measurements are impossible, but if just one valve is malfunctioning
it seems to be a likely culprit. How about comparing its operation
with the others?

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 20:47 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: TurboS Brakes

Hi Jerry,

>I am curious; you said you returned the rebuild kits after the sticker
>shock, yet you also said that you rebuilt the calipers?!?

Correct.  The few times that I have rebuilt callipers, I have popped for
the seal kits, which are cheap ($10 or so).  Regardless of the seal
condition, I have replaced them.  At $10 a calliper, it's cheap and
its the safe thing to do.

This time, because of the cost (like $150 or so per calliper) and
because the existing seals inspected OK, I simply stripped, cleaned,
inspected, and reassembled.  The callipers were take-off's being
brought out of retirement.

The only things needing any attention inside the calliper were the
pistons.  Brake dust builds up and solidifies on them.  I take it
down with a mild scrubbing pad, like a green Scotch Brite but much
milder.  We snarf them from the body shop next door.

I would like to find the seal kits minus the pistons, for future
reference.  They are not available in the wholesale aftermarket.  If
no one on the list is successful in finding a source, perhaps I could
give Brembo UK a call, or whatever.

Let me know what you find.  Take care,

Kevin Gross

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 20:32:56 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: 951 turbo failure/problems


question (maybe sanity check): took a very well running (and "tweeked") 951
to the shop today for minor stuff (brake bleeder screw, transaxle oil change)
and the mechanic calls in a panic---> said while on a test drive the car
strangely stopped making any boost. Car was fine-- stopped to pick up a part-
restarted the car and no boost.

then the scenario went: could spin turbo by hand ok, wastegate not stuck,
installed new knock sensors, no apparent oil leaks (or turbo seal leaks).
Restarted car, more tests, cool down car -> now turbo will not spin by hand.

diagnosis: seized turbo  (ie "probably coke on bearings)

The car has ONLY had Mobil 1 (since new), turbo is allowed 5-10 minutes 
idle cool down after hard runs (ie each track session), left to cool with engine
er hood, up. Oil is changed every other track event -> ie after each 12-14
hours of use.

Somehow I find this hard to swallow. Will turbos suddenly "seize" with no
warning (binary operation?)? Could something else be at fault? With the
careful effort to *prevent* heat buildup & cooking the oil in the turbo is it
still vunerable to heat related failures like this? Is there a better solution
to avoiding this in the future? (turbos are not cheap).

Thanks in advance.

 -jim
 87 944turbo (getting turbo transplant-- glad to have a spare motor for just
              such an diaster)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 23:48:36 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Brakes update

> Gee, do I dare ask your opinion of Dunlop D60M2's?  I have D60A2's
> on my Celica and they have been a good all season street tire for me.

They're a good tire for Celicas. They're also OK on 944s, oddly 
enough. Not a *GREAT* tire, but a good tire.

> So I was planning on replacing the old Sears roadhandlers on my 914
> with the Dunlop D60M2 series since the 914 won't see snow.
> (195/65 if I can get 'em to fit).  I expect these tires to be for street
> use only.

You'd be happier with Yoko A-509s or AVS Intermediates, and 195/65 should
be fine on a 5.5" wheel. I race on 195/50s, FYI.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 17:47:48 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: REFEREE!!


OK! OK!  I got covered with responses from people wanting to know the 
"solution" to the California smog "referee" process that I decided to put it 
out to pfiles and let the flames begin. 
 
First, a couple of things.... 
	1.  My car is legally smogged now.  While jumping thru the hoops the 
state puts you thru to get a 24 year old car smogged, I vented my frustration 
by focusing on figuring out how to be legally registered without having to go 
thru this insanity. The smog parts I needed are no longer available, they 
haven't been available for years, but the state keeps making us go thru this 
process every two years.  It took almost two months and to get the car 
smogged.  Technically, I couldn't drive it during this period but the state 
got registration (use) fees while I wasn't on the road.  I had no choice there. 
	2.  The environment is important to me.  I support clean air.  My car 
passed easily, it has a fresh rebuild, is in constant good tune and is not 
modified. All of my other vehicles are also smog legal and clean.  This car is 
rarely driven. The process that the state has set up to get older cars smogged 
if parts aren't available feels purely like harassment.     
	3.  A friend has another old Pcar with the same problem.  He drives 
his every day and couldn't park it while waiting for the wheels of bureaucracy 
to roll on so I gave him my solution.  It worked for him. Here you go: 
 
In Calif., there are two agencies you deal with to get smogged.  The DMV and 
the BAR.  They only connect with each other over your smog situation when you 
bring paper from one to the other. So, the right hand doesn't know what the 
left hand is doing. 
 
First, go to the DMV, pay your fees, get your registration.  You are now 
legally registered!!!!  You have paid your use tax!!!  You have a valid 
registration certificate!!!  They will not give you the yearly sticker until 
you come back with a smog certificate.  you have everything you need but the 
sticker. 
 
Next, go to your local "motorcyle dismantler" and buy a $50.00 wreck to 
"restore" .  honda 305's or 160's are good for this along with mashed Vespas.  
Take the title and pink slip to the DMV.  Spend five bucks, register it.  They 
give you a "sticker".  Same size, current year.  Take the honda to a landfill. 
 Keep the registration for next year.  you figure out where to put the sticker. 
 
You may notice that the sticker has numbers on it.  Do you think that the CHP 
can tie those numbers to license plate they're on?  Guess again.  Those 
numbers are for DMV internal tracking purposes.  Ask a CHP guy. 
 
Does the DMV follow up on the smog.  I don't think so. The car has to be 
registered whether you drive it or not.  BAR knows nothing about you until you 
show up at a Smog station or the referee. 
 
Well, this is what good citizens do when government runs amok, I guess. 
  
If you can get smog gear for your car you should.  If not, this works.  Good 
luck. 
 
I'll put on my Nomex suit now and wrap the terminal with asbestos.  Hell, we 
probably haven't has this much fun since the other Ted left.  
 
Ted Smith

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 09:49:23 +0200 (EET)
From: hy03545@uwasa.fi (Jan Widjeskog)
Subject: Re: '69 912: a better car?

 pallis@aol.com wrote

> I have heard generally that the '69 912 is superior to the '67 and '68 model,
> but I don't know specifically why that's so.  Can someone help me out ?
> Also, any thoughts about the '76 912E ?
>
	
	I don't have any driving experience of any of these cars so i can't
	tell you anything about reality, but i happen to know some technical
	and theoretical stuff that supports the superiority theory.
	From model year '69 the 911 and also the 912 got their wheelbase in-
	creased with 57mm (that's about 2,2 inches) by moving the rear wheels
	backwards.That made the 911/912's weight-distribution change for the
	better,it became more balanced.Before this operation Porsche had even
	used lead weights in the front of the car to prevent the front end to
	'jump' in sharp bumps.This gave the car better handling off course.
	Otherwise the '69 912 should be similar to the '67 and '68 models.
	The '76 912E is different than the '69 912 on one major point,the 
	engine. While the '69er has the old 1600cm3 engine from the 356 model,
	and thus is a 'real' Porsche,the '76er has the 1600cm3 Volkswagen type
	IV engine with fuel injection.Technically these engines are very simi-
	lar apart from the fact that the VW engine is equipped with fuel injec-
	tion (a mechanic one, not to be confused with modern electronic fuel
	injections).Both engines should produce 90bhp so performance should 
	also be very similar in both cases.The only difference is that (if I'm
	correctly informed) the VW engine is easier and cheaper to 'hot up'.
	That is because of the availability of parts for the VW engine, and I
	know that it's possible to enlarge the VW engine up to 2900cm3.One guy
	in Sweden built such an engine to 2500cm3 and it pumped out about 
	200bhp so that should give Porsche-like performance...
	If anyone has other info you may correct me.

				Yours,
			   Jan Widjeskog
			   University of Helsinki,
		           Dept. of Law
			   FINLAND

------------------------------

------------------------------

From: owner-porschephiles@tta.com

	id m0qxxK0-0000dXC; Thu, 20 Oct 94 09:14 EDT
Message-Id: <m0qxxK0-0000dXC@inasec.ca>
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: 944 engine work & clutch (long-winded questions about)
To: porschephiles@tta.com
Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 09:14:20 -0400 (EDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3686      

(Actually, I have a 924s, but the engine is the same as a 944.  :)

Hello there, my name is Craig Seko, and I'm a recent addition to the
mailing-list here, and its *much* nicer since...  oh yeah, that's
off-topic now...  <cough>

Anyways, at our (Rennsport Region's) last track event at Mont-
Tremblant in September, the power steering at idle was jerky,
which suggested either a worn power steering pump or a failing
steering rack. I continued to run, however when I started the car for
the last run of the the day, the P-car made that "Number 2 rod-bearing
has spun" noise. I have experienced this noise before - and, as such,
I was surprised because at the end of the previous run I had listened
to the motor at idle and nothing seemed wrong. I had also checked the
oil pressure constantly, and the oil level after each run. A
well-respected ex-dealer mechanic listened to the car and pronounced:
"bottom end" <sigh>. A new-to-Porsches by-stander also thought he saw
the crank wobbling. Needless to say, I trailered the car home, my sole
track time on Sunday being in my student's 993 <grin>.

Once home, I dropped the oil pan (NOT fun), and looked at the rod 
bearings. ALL of them were fine, which, it seems, implies the problem 
was a crank bearing (oh my gawd), so I pulled the motor (REALLY not 
fun in a gravel driveway with no garage), which leads me to my first 
question:

1. Can I use a "regular" four-finger engine stand to hold a 944 motor?
I have one, but I know there are special stands for 911's, and I don't
want to see the threads pulled out of the aluminum block because they
can't take the weight of the motor by themselves (the engine is
sitting on my front porch now, much to the chagrin of my neighbours).

Once I get the engine inside and on (hopefully) the stand, I'll be 
able to have a look at the crank bearings. One thing I have noticed
is that the power-steering pulley on the crank spins freely, which
explains the steering problem and wobbly appearance of the pulley (the
crank bolt is still on quite tight). I was wondering, though,

2. Would such a loose pulley (broken crank key, I'm assuming) cause or
be caused by a main bearing failure/bent crank? Would such a loose
pulley perfectly imitate a knock deep down in the engine?

I guess I'll find out the answer to this sooner or later, but I 
wondered if anyone had experienced a similar problem... and I'll be 
pretty damn upset at myself for pulling a motor for no reason. The 
engine was re-built at 40,000 miles (25 track hours), thanks to my
then-ignorance of the proper oil level, and I've only put another
25,000 miles (another 20 track hours) on since then.

3. If the crank is bent, though, I may have a line on an '89 944S2
motor w/Motronic for $CND3k ($2200US) - has anyone done this swap,
and/or am I asking for an electronics nightmare? (not to mention
needing better brakes).

On the other hand, now that the motor's out, I might as well replace 
the clutch, which leads me to two final questions:

4. What is the size of the internally-splined bolts that hold the
flywheel onto the crank? The socket I'll need is special order
(i.e., non-returnable) from the local tool places, so I need the right
size the first time.

5. I've heard awful things about rubber-centered clutch disks. The
only spring-centered ones I've been able to locate are the Sachs 
competition ones, which cost about double the already bloody expensive
OEM rubber clutch disk. Any opinions, sources?

Thanks for reading this, and I look forward to any and all replies.


Craig Seko, Team OS/2, cseko@inasec.ca, (613) 951-6960 days.
'87 924s
'81 Suzuki LJ80 (800c.c.'s, and no, it isn't a bike, its a 4WD truck!)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 09:20:26 EDT
From: javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com (Javier Rodriguez - ATT ASCC)
Subject: 944: rear seat removal

Hello PorschePhiles,

Could somebody please tell me how to remove the rear seats on a '88 944?

Thanks in advance,

Javier - '88 944
javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 10:03:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: ICAC@delphi.com
Subject: Sponsor stickers - thanks.

Thanks for all the advice & recommendations on how to apply
stickers to a car & then be able to remove them without damaging
the paint. I received a ton or replies. I guess a few of you have
done this before!
 
There were really two basic option: use magnetic patches cut to
the size of the decal or apply wax &, prior to buffing the wax
clear, attach the decal over the cloudy wax (then buff the
surrounding wax clean).
 
For both options I was advised to apply a couple of fresh coats
of wax to the car before the stickers saw the light of day!
 
I use the magnet option for my car numbers when I take the car to
the track but I think for the stickers I'll try the other method.
I also like the idea of "linting".
 
I have a few months to decide before the event so I have plenty
of time to think about it.
 
Anyway, thanks for all of your help,
 
John Mulligan.
ICAC@delphi.com
