Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 10:13:21 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: New Subscriber/911 Owner


Text item: Text_1

Hi to all subscribers,
I am a new subscriber and new (first time)P car owner having recently, that is 
less than 500 miles ago, acquired an '86 911 Turbo. After having changed 
underwear from the results of the first straight line acceleration I flung it 
into my favorite corner, a 180 deg. compound curve jobbie, and was mortified by 
the amount of understeer. I never thought it possible to build that much in to a
car with  so much rear weight bias and power! However a visit to our local 
suspension wizards here in Cincinnati, Performance Alignment, has cured all of 
that and the car now drives really sweet for road use at least.
Real purpose of writing was to seek some help. My early reaction to the car was 
amazement that the people at P would arrange the go fast and go slow pedals in 
such a stupid juxtaposition. How am I supposed to 'heel and toe'? (or should one
say center and side foot). Does any one know of a simple kit such as longer 
adjustable linkage and stops for the aforementioned go fast pedal which would 
make an elegant solution to the problem or do I have to duct tape a block of 
wood to the pedal?
Second question relates to seats. I have the standard electric up and down only 
seats. Some previous person hauled on the fore/aft release lever to such an 
extent that the torque tube connected to the lever has badly distorted and will 
not release the catch on the opposite side seat rail. I have jury rigged it by 
bending the tie rod and supporting the tie bar with a nylon tie wrap. Where can 
I get a new torque tube assembly, tie link and nylon clips/bushings for the tie 
link? also how do you separate the hard nylon bushing/clips to get the old tie 
link out?
As an expatriate Limy of 14 yrs. I have to advise Ben Evans that his gf should 
take the Cleveland experience, after all it was only for a year, just remember 
everything on this continent is more extreme, weather highs and lows (be careful
of quoted averages the standard deviations are extremely big), egos and fishing 
achievements included!!!!!!!! Beer of choice has to be real ale or porter pulled
by hand from the wood at cellar temperature, that's 57 deg. NOT warm, 
notwithstanding all of the Lucas ULs. I drink a half of Guinness once every five
years to remind me how horrible it is.
Sorry this has rambled on a bit, promise it wont happen again, thanks in advance
for anticipated help re pedals and seat.

Neil Walker '86 911 turbo
The driving power behind Martins 911 Targa Engine o'haul! 
walker_neil_nw@ae.ge.com    

Text item: Text_2

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 07:31:16 PDT
From: Scott.Gemmett@Eng.Sun.COM (Scott Gemmett)
Subject: Re: REFEREE!!


>First, go to the DMV, pay your fees, get your registration.  You are now 
>legally registered!!!!  You have paid your use tax!!!  You have a valid 
>registration certificate!!!  They will not give you the yearly sticker until 
>you come back with a smog certificate.  you have everything you need but the 
>sticker. 
  

Hmmmm - I have done this 2xs recently when I bought cars
that were not presently running so I could not get them smogged. Both times
I got a non-valid registration card (one that clearly states this
on it) This only documented the fact that you had started the transfer 
and paid your use tax within the required 10 days of obtaining the vehicle.
If you do not return with a smog certificate later you will receive a
letter from Sacramento stating that you have an incomplete registration
in process. (I believe it says get a smog cert or sign on the dotted line 
that you are not using the car anymore)

Well anyway, unless different DMV branches operate differently, I don't
think that you could get a car registred in CA without getting 
a smog cert. 
But of course there are many ways of getting that cert ;)

Scott

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 07:23:14 -0800 (PDT)
From: sag@atreides.ca.boeing.com (Stuart Galt)
Subject: Re: Smog check questions (dyno check .vs. 4WD)

Dave Lawson writes
>I have heard that here in Colorado, we will also be going to dyno emissions 
>testing some time in '95. Has anyone heard how the states will be handling 
>the AWD cars like the C4, various AWD vans, Audi quattros, etc. Will they 
>really put in variable wheelbase 4WD or AWD dynos?

In Seattle we have dyno checks.  For two wheel drive they put you drive wheels
on the rollers and make you get out of the car.  The attendent then gets in 
your car and does the "driving".  For 4x4 or AWD type vehicle they just do
a regular tail pipe sniff at two or three rpm settings (and you get to see
how close your tach and theirs agree :-).  With 4WD vehicles they are worried
that the wheels not on the dyno may suddenly drive the vehicle off the dyno and 
cause damage to various things (people, buildings, cars, etc).

Thats how they do it here.

stuart galt   <sag@atreides.ca.boeing.com>  | #include <standard/disclaim.h>
boeing computer services seattle washington | I don't know what they say,
(206) 544-0991   or home (206) 361-0190     | they don't know what I say...


------------------------------

Date: 20 Oct 1994 07:45:41 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: 69 912

        Reply to:   69 912
In 1969 Porsche increased the wheelbase of the 911 chassis 2.5
inches (the rear wheels were moved aft).  The engine remained in its
same place, but the rear drive shafts were angled back and the the
trailing arms were extended.  This change, carried forward on all
later cars, improved ride quality and had better weight distribution.
Porsche also flared the rear wheel wells some, allowing slightly
wider tires, and used twin batteries mounted in the front corners to
improve weight distribution.  (Remember the dopey iron weights
used in the very early cars' bumpers?)

I could be mistaken, but the 69 912 should have had these same
chassis improvements (maybe not the batteries?).  The 68 911
had horrible air-injection emission controls which caused plug
fouling, and overheating.  The 912 may not have, due to its
different engine.

The early 912 engine was the same as the 356SC (it is said it
was "detuned").  So this was a true Porsche engine.  The 76 912E
was not.  It was an Audi, I believe (or could it have been the old
VW 412?).

Hope that helps.
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@synoptics.com (Santa Clara)
88 factory turbo look targa (sold yesterday...<sigh>)
89 silver anniv coupe
95 993 (coming soon...<yeah!>)

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 10:30:00 DST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 engine work & clutch (long-winded questions about)


Hi Craig,

Sorry I missed a fellow p-filer at the event.  I was there too, had a very 
enjoyable
week-end.  It was my first time to Tremblant, and as you and I know, it's a 
gorgeous circuit, technical and long like Bridgehampton, but green and with 
good run-offs like Lime Rock.  Highly recommended.  RSR runs a very nice 
event.  The Saturday evening dinner at the top of Mt. Tremblant was 
wonderful.

(I couldn't get my car to stick all week-end, one reason/excuse for being 
rather slow.  Found out later that my fancy-pants digital tire gauge's 
batteries had gone off.  While it read 30 PSI, I had more like 38 to 40 PSI 
in the tires!  Argh.)

>1. Can I use a "regular" four-finger engine stand to hold a 944 motor?
>I have one, but I know there are special stands for 911's...

Dunno 100%.  You won't pull the threads, they're adequate to the job.  I do 
know from experience that you do *not* need the bespoke 911 stands.  The 
shop uses generic, adjustable stands for 911 engines, not even Snap On, and 
they are fine.

>2. Would such a loose pulley (broken crank key, I'm assuming) cause or
>be caused by a main bearing failure/bent crank? Would such a loose
>pulley perfectly imitate a knock deep down in the engine?

a) Probably not, b) quite probably.  If I were you, I would give some 
thought to fixing the PS pulley and putting the engine back in your car. 
 I'll bet your bearings are fine.

>3. If the crank is bent, though, I may have a line on an '89 944S2
>motor w/Motronic for $CND3k ($2200US) - has anyone done this swap,
>and/or am I asking for an electronics nightmare? (not to mention
>needing better brakes).

If you get *everything* under the hood, you're probably OK.  But a lot of 
stuff is different on the S and S2, all over the place.  Think about the 
transmission in particular.

>4. What is the size of the internally-splined bolts that hold the
>flywheel onto the crank? The socket I'll need is special order
>(i.e., non-returnable) from the local tool places, so I need the right
>size the first time.

I think the tool is a 12 mm internal spline, er, could be 10 mm.  You can 
get Stahlwille sockets from Performance Products, I think, not too much 
money.

>5. I've heard awful things about rubber-centered clutch disks. The
>only spring-centered ones I've been able to locate are the Sachs
>competition ones, which cost about double the already bloody expensive
>OEM rubber clutch disk. Any opinions, sources?

The rubber-centred clutch pack is fine.  Like I've said before, the 
spring-centred clutches fail too, generally because the spings break or, 
with the pre-S 951's, the friction material comes free of its disk.  When 
the rubber centre fails, the rubber bits usually fly out and lodge in the 
perimeter of the pressure plate case.  You can drive the car home, gently, 
on the travel stops.  (I've done it.)  When a spring breaks, it as often as 
not lodges and inhibits clutch/declutch.  Or it gouges the flywheel face. 
 Moreover, the spring-centred clutches transmit much more shock to the 
transmission, which is why 951's chew transmissions and R&P's.  Figure it 
this way: Porsche decided that the rubber centre was OK for the 200+ hp 
944S2.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 07:55:08 PST
From: morobson@CCGATE.HAC.COM
Subject: 914 Idle Update

     I decided that since the car was new to me I would take it into a 
     mechanic and let them do a tune-up and look over the car for anything 
     out of the ordinary.  I also specifically told the them that the tube 
     to the vacuum advance was disconnected and plugged...
     
     I got it back a few hours later, the vacuum advance was reconnected 
     and the car was idling at about 900-950, a vast improvement. I drove 
     home no problem.  On my way to work I noticed , especially in lower 
     gears, that after accelerating up to 3000 rpm or so and changing gear 
     the rpm would drop down to 500 and the car would "sputter" for a 
     second or two , by which time I gave it some gas and that brought it 
     back up.
     
     I have worked on old cars before but none of them Porsches and none of 
     the fuel injected.  Apart from checking for leaks in the vacuum hoses, 
     using the suggested carb cleaner, what else may I want to check?
     
     Also, is that mechanic to blame for missing something that would have 
     caused it, he claimed to be a VW (Porsche 914) specialist.
     
     Thanks in advance for any advice
     
     Marc Robson
     75 914 2.0 L - Signal Orange
     94 RCA 18" DSS

>> So I was planning on replacing the old Sears roadhandlers on my 914

it almost impossible to get these to squeel on the on ramps and off ramps
with the race suspension.  They are also REALLY impressive in the wet.
Never tried them in the snow as the race car doesn't work well then :-).
We have 20K+ of spirited sriving on these tires and they are hardly worn
(but are being used on light cars).  YMMV.

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 09:32:02 PDT
From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
Subject: RE: '69 912 a better car

The '69 912 is considered a better car than a pre-'69 for a few
reasons I know of.

1.  Fenders are flared a little more so you can do
wider more modern profile tires
2.  Battery tray moved to prevent acid rotting apart
the suspension mounting points (This is a $1000-$2000 repair
needed on almost every pre - '69 models)
3.  Turn signal lenses instead of single-piece body
turn signals -- much cheaper to replace

Dan
'68 912

------------------------------

Date: 20 Oct 1994 09:50:36 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  Injector prices

>Wow, really $60 ea.  AJR is quoting me about $26 ea 
>for the CIS injectors for my 82 911SC.  Is there really
>that big a price difference ?

    Well, the injectors in 914s are solenoid-controlled 
valves.  Lotsa stuff in there, not that cheap to make.  
>From what I know, the CIS injectors spray all the time, 
so no solenoid.  Just a valve to keep them closed until 
sufficient pressure builds up "behind" them.

- --DD



------------------------------

Date: 20 Oct 1994 10:04:27 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  Smog Tests

Please note:  my experience is all with the California smog laws.  The ones
that they pass for your area may be different in specifics--but they should
be similar.

>      1. Are older cars exempt from testing ?  How old does the car have to
>         be before nobody cares (even the '70 is a daily driver) ?

    Yes.  In CA, I think, the "exempt" years start at (I think) 1965.  Later
has to pass a sniff test, even on pre-emissions equipped cars.  Just no visual
check (except possibly for "original"-type induction and/or exhaust).

>      2. Do the sniff test limits vary with the year of the car ? i.e., does
>         my '70 w/o even a smog pump have to test as clean as a '94 Honda ?

    Yes.  No.  I mean, different standards exist for different years.  The
Honda has to be *very* clean, the '70 dosen't.

>      3. Assuming that the '79 car passes "visual" check, is there any hope
>         it will pass the sniff test ? (the cats are there, just 
>         hollowed out).

    Yes.  I know of a number of people (including at least one SC) that have
passed the sniff test with a "test pipe" or other substitute for the cat.  I
don't know if they had to tweak the heck out of the mixture, but they passed.

>      4. Are there any good ways to cheat ? I'm wondering if there is any
>         high-alcohol fuel mixture possible that appears clean enough
>         to pass test.... 

    It's easier to pass visual when you get a smog tech that dosen't even
know which end of the car the engine is in.  One guy smogged my stock 914
1.8L as a VW 1600, checked off the "carbs OK" box, and checked "FI n/a",
when all of the FI was right there, staring him in the face!  I could have
brought a really radical racer in, as long as I could tweak it to meet the
sniff test, and had it passed.  Oh, well.

- --DD


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: 20 Oct 1994 10:17:15 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  914 decel valve, or no?

>My question is: since at
>this time I don't have either system in place, should I hook one (most likely
>the decel' valve- its cheap,easy, and goes along with the reast of my
>components) up? Is there any performance benefit (ie; fuel economy, etc.) or
>does it help engine longevity, or is it "only" for smog prevention?

    The decel valve should give you some control over how quickly the
engine spools down from higher RPM.  But basically it seems to just be
there for emissions.  It seems to be a throttle bypass, kinda like the
idle air passage and the aux air regulator.  Gets air from one side of
the throttle to the other.
    The reason that they changed from a fuel cutoff to a throttle bypass
is (according to Probst's _Bosch_FI_and_Engine_Management_ book) because
air-cooled engines frequently put out more emissions when going from
normal running to decelerating with no fuel.  I think he said that it's
due to "uneven cooling"...  Whatever that really means.

- --DD

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 11:29:54 -0600
From: dhagood@page.mmc.com (Dave Hagood)

Subject:  Re: European F1 Results
- --------
John Lupien sez:
> Not at all likely. Tracy tested a Benneton, but failed to really drive the
> wheels off of it. Same general problems as Mike A. - not used to the short
> braking distances, and not as confident entering the high-speed turns. Wound
> up about 2 seconds down on Schu. Tracy has reportedly just signed with
> Newman-Haas, so he probably won't be in F1 next year.

In a word, no.  While I don't have the numbers in front of me, Tracy did a
lap that would have qualified him 5th on the grid for the previous weekend's
race at Estoril.  He went faster in Verstappen's car than Verstappen did, 
despite never having driven an F1 car before (and Verstappen, heavily hyped
pre-season, has driven it all year).

Schumacher was testing new spec Goodyear tire; Tracy was running with those
tires *after* Schumacher had run them off.  All reports that I have read,
from a variety of sources, say that everyone was extremely impressed with
young Mr. Tracy.  Tracy is _seriously_ fast, but not yet predictable.

I'd would call his performance at Estoril "driving the wheels off it".

Dave (F1 driver hell, I wanted to be a fighter pilot like my dad!)

------------------------------

Date: 20 Oct 1994 10:51:58 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  '69 912- a better car?

>I have heard generally that the '69 912 is superior to the '67 and '68 model,
>but I don't know specifically why that's so.  Can someone help me out ?
> Thanks.

    At least part of this is due to the longer wheelbase.  It supposedly
made the 911 more tractable, and gives a better ride.  There were probably
other refinements.

>Also, any thoughts about the '76 912E ?

    Heavier than the earlier 912s.  2.0L 914 engine with thermal reactors,
catalytic converter on it, also the AFC (L-jet) FI more or less from the
1.8L 914.  Still only 90 HP, but probably a wider torque band, due to the
larger displacement.
    The AFC FI is regarded by some as problematical.  It *hates* vaccuum
leaks (don't ask how I know), the flapper box is expensive and thought by
many to be too fragile, and it dosen't work as well as the D-jet up above
4K RPM.  Fine for around-town driving, not so great for racing, etc.
    It also suffers quite a bit in comparison to similar-year 911s.  The
earliest 912s were only down 20 or so HP from the base-level ('T') 911s.
In 1976, most 911s seemed to be 'S' models, with 150+ HP (?)--a big dif-
ference.
    My personal opinion:  bleah.  914 more fun, 911 more power.  914/6 
both.  And with the prices people want for the 912E's, you can get a
very good 914, or most of a 911 or 914/6.

- --DD

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 11:09:56 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: 914 Brakes update

Pete,

>> Gee, do I dare ask your opinion of Dunlop D60M2's?  I have D60A2's
>> on my Celica and they have been a good all season street tire for me.
>> So I was planning on replacing the old Sears roadhandlers on my 914
>> with the Dunlop D60M2 series since the 914 won't see snow.
>> (195/65 if I can get 'em to fit).  I expect these tires to be for street
>> use only.

Well, I've actually used these on my 914 as street/track tires.  Very
reasonably priced and they stick pretty well, too.  Infact, I was only
just over .5 second off the 2.0l 914s in my class running A008Rs's.  I
kept then as long as I could and would consider them again.

Pat

> 944S2.

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 13:39:46 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 Tires (and wheel offset calculations/questions)

>>> Graphics Group <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov> 10/20/94 01:30pm >>>
>    They should fit.  I got the 915/60's to fit fine--seemed to have some room left.
>
>--DD

Wow, Dave, thats some serious rubber!!!  I calculate those tires to be just over 3 feet wide. :) :) :)
I know, I know, it was just a typo...

The reason I'm worried about 195's fitting is that my aftermarket wheels are closer to the outer fender
than my stock steel spare wheel.  I measure 3 7/8 inches from the mounting flange to the inside of the
rim.   With stock 165 width tires, I have just about 1/2 inch of clearance between the tire and the outer
fender.  My stock steel spare rim measures 4 7/8 inches and the tire actually rides closer to the inside
of the wheel well than the outside. 

If I know the right way to calculate offset, zero offset would mean that the mounting flange would be
located at the half-way point of the rim width.  (2.75 inches for my 5.5 inch rims).  Anyone/everyone
feel free to correct me on this.  That would mean that the stock steel rim has an offset of
2.75 - 4.875 = -2.125 inches and the aftermarket wheels have an offset of 2.75 - 3.875 = -1.125 inches.

How does this compare to offset of the rims that you are using?

Pete Klager

Date: 20 Oct 94 15:04:04 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Pirelli tires has-beens

Hi, Stan.
 
Agree 100 percent on your assessment of Pirelli. Yes, in the early and mid
70s, the CN36 was THE tire. Then the P7 was developed specifically for the
911 Turbo, and for nearly a decade it was the ultimate high performance
tire. Then everybody else passed it by. The P Zero is not a financially
viable option for anybody but Italian exotic car makers, and it has no
significant advantage over Japanese and other Euro performance tires.
 
I've owned cars with CN36, and have gone through I don't know how many sets
of P7s on various 911s, but these days I stick with Bridgestone and
Yokohama. The C4 parked outside (temporarily, unfortunately) has Michelins
on it and those are pretty damn sticky too.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 12:21:05 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?

Greg writes:
 
> What I'm looking to know:  How much maintenance does the valve train need?
>How long does the timing belt last?  Anyone changed one?  How are 928s in
>adverse weather conditions?  In general what sort of problems have you
>experienced?

The valve gear uses hydrolic (I JUST forgot how to spell that word!) lifters
so the valve train is nothing to worry about.

I don't know how long the cam belt will last and have not changed mine yet.
It's new to me (the car) and has 109,000 miles on it.  The dealer charges
$62.00 for the belt.

In rain, even with junk tires, it feels stable.  The wipers (front and back)
work great and the ventilation system is very powerful.  Lights are also very
bright and interior is comfortable w/ lots of glass. Brakes are powerful and
easy to modulate in bad conditions; i.e. drunks, tires in roads, cars in road,
cops in road, etc.

problems:
- --------
parts				cost	where
- ------------------------------------------------------
Pilot Shaft Bearing             18.80   Taub Porsche
Oil filter                       9.00   Taub Porsche
gas filter                      27.99   Kragen
Ignition switch (electrical)    42.19   EASY
battery (85-month)              74.89   Chief
Ignition switch cam              3.74   Steve Taub Porsche
Oil Pressure guage sender       20.34   EASY

And I did all the work myself so I saved a bundle.  As for dislikes, I can't
think of any.

bill
billv@retix.com
'79 '28 (except for the color; I wish it was red.  Come to think of it, I've 
never seen a red 928)

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 12:53:08 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 911 brake pedal adjustment

     If  your brake pedal linkeage is the same as an SC, you  can
easily  adjust  the  pedal height.  Remove the carpets,  and  the
*PLYWOOD*  floorboard (is that why they call them  floorBOARDS?),
and the adjustment will be obvious to you.  You can set the brake
pedal as close to the floorBOARD as you like.

- --   Bob

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 14:44:25 CDT
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: Let's stir it UP!

Hey Y'all

Let me preface this with an "I do not want to be the next T** statement" 
but things are getting pretty dry around here.  All this techie talk 
leaves me wanting for a little Porsche philosophical cud to chew on. So 
here goes:

Who came first: Chevy or Porsche.  In 196X when both companies had air 
cooled, six cylinder sport coupes and convertibles on the road, who's was 
the faster car.  Which company had the REAL sports car and which company 
was the poser.

Blow torches to high.

Bert
'88 951S (black)
'64 Very Loving Wife
'94 Baby Porschephile (had her first ride last weekend)

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 16:10:30 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 914 Brakes update

> You'd be happier with Yoko A-509s or AVS Intermediates, and 195/65 should
> be fine on a 5.5" wheel. I race on 195/50s, FYI.
> Stan

I have the A-509's on my Corolla, and they are awesome in the wet, quite
nice in the dry. They really shine when it's damp - the start of the
rain lifts the oils and other slick stuff up out of the crevices in the
road surface, and the heavier rain hasn't washed it away yet. With the 509's,
I can just ignore it and crank right along, with lots of margin, while people
going 10-15 mph slower than me are losing it. Mike K. (you still there?)
says to watch out when the tread depth gets shallow, though.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

width A008 RS'es and I'm on 195 width A509s...  And also
since he was beating me thoroughly at every race for a
while.  Not to mention the fact that he got six runs, with
three practice laps, while I got three and none.  (Four,
counting the fun run that I beat him on...)

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 16:44:47 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: Porsche vs. Corvair

I liked my Corvair a lot - 64 coupe, 110hp - but I would not put it in the
same class as either a 356 or a 911, and I don't think Chevy would either.
They thought they were building the Nissan Sentras of their day, and yes, the
hot models were nice little SE-R analogs, but never a sports car.  That 
doesn't make the driver of either one a poser.  Certainly Chevy was the one
appropriating ideas, not the reverse, unless you believe that F. Porsche only
learned in 1964 how to count to six.  Chevy was also the one more ready to
compromise the idea, first by building 80 (SAE) hp 2speed automatic four-doors
and then by running away and hiding from Ralph Nader.

Given Chevrolet's loyalty to a design concept, if there were still a Corvair,
the way there is STILL a 911, it would probably be the size of a Caprice, with
a pickup bed in front, driven by both passenger-side wheels.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 17:08:00 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 engine work & clutch (long-winded questions about)

Hi, Craig,

About your questions:

1) Can I use a "regular" four-finger engine stand to hold a 944 motor?

Yes, you can. I do it all the time and have no problem at all.  Make sure
that the bolts do not go too far into the block or they will break the 
mounting points for the bell housing.

2) Would such a loose pulley (broken crank key, I'm assuming) cause or
be caused by a main bearing failure/bent crank? Would such a loose
pulley perfectly imitate a knock deep down in the engine?

What might have happened is that the large crankshaft bolt (the one that
also holds on the PS pulley, might have backed out enough to allow the 
driving hub of the oil pump to stop turning the gear inside the oil pump,
thus causing a lack of oil pressure.  That, in itself, can cause a spun 
bearing anywhere, including the main or rod bearings... Probably not a bent 
crank, YMMV.

3) Swapping 944S2 Motor - Never done it, my usual advice to those who wish
to do 944/turbo/16 valve swaps - sell your car and buy the original.  ALWAYS
cheaper to do it that way.

4) Size of the 12 point socket - 12 MM.  Get the best one you can find.

5) Rubber center clutches - I use a rubber center clutch in my 83 944, best
price these days is from PAR in Yonkers, @ 449 for the rubbercenter clutch,
throwout bearing and pressure plate.  Spend another $20 for the pilot
bearing and you're in fat city.  When I replaced my original clutch after 65K
miles, the rubber center was perfectly intact.  Those that have failed have 
tended to be on machines that had "rev the engine to 6000, sidestep the
clutch pedal" starts on them.

We had a guy in our PCA Region who said, "the car acts funny when I do this"
and showed me his Big Daddy Garlits launch.  So I said, "stop doing it."  He
didn't and did grenade his clutch soon thereafter.

For most Porsche 944 drivers, who acknowledge that the car is not a
dragster, this is not a large problem.

Once again, YMMV.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 17:25:14 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944: rear seat removal

Hi, Javier,

Removing the rear seats on a 1988 944...

If you have a single seat back (two persons wide), the upper part is removed 
by unbolting the pivots (one shouldered 10 mm bolt on each side).  A 1/4
inch drive should let you in there.

If you have two seat backs (each one person wide), each upper part should
have the same kind of shouldered 10 mm bolt on the outer pivot.  The fiche
is not too clear at this point, but the inner pivot should just pop out of
its mount.

The seat bottom is glued in place.  After removing the seat belt anchor
bolts, start at the lower front edge of the seat (near the floor carper) and
gently begin to pull it up with your fingers.  It will eventually begin to
release from the chassis.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 17:59:18 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Winders' nitrogen conclusion

I have not heard from Scott after his expert answered my last question.
I won't waste bandwidth by including all this garbage, but here
is the conclusion :

porterj@uclink.berkeley.edu (John Douglas Porter) gave Scott a new set of
notes that goes over the effects of having liquid water present in the tires
at the time they are filled. He said :

"You (Mike) are correct in saying that the pressure will increase faster with
increasing T than predicted by the ideal gas (or other) equation if there 
is liquid water present."

The conclusion is that any dry gas (like bottled nitrogen or air from an air
compressor with a dryer) will work fine. Nitrogen DOES have a benefit if you
are using a compressor that spits out water (like the little one that I use
that plugs into my cigarette lighter).

Hail Ferry, Hail Ferry ... Hail Ferry (Actually I didn't start it, I ended it
(hopefully!)) Please no more on this subject, ITS DEAD!!!!

Mike Piera,  '72 911S Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 17:59:05 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: Let's stir it UP!

>...Who came first: Chevy or Porsche...Which company had the REAL sports
car and which company was the poser...<

True story here: Back in 1962 or 1963, my across the street best friend had
an uncle who owned a Porsche. Co-incidentally, a co-worker of mine had a
Corvair Monza. As luck would have it, the Monza owner showed up at my house
at the same time as the Porsche owning uncle was across the street
visiting.  A discussion ensued over exactly the topic suggested above.

A quick drive to a deserted (relatively) road and a drag race was on.

The P-car was quicker off the line, but only off the line. As soon as the
turbo on the chevy spooled up, he was gone, gone, gone.

"Ah yes" said the uncle. "But you should try me up a canyon".

Another quick drive to the mouth of a nearby canyon.

I was riding in the Monza, my across the street friend was riding with the
uncle. With a wave of the hand the race was on. The P-car again got the
jump but was soon passed by a couple of smug individuals who had no clue as
to what was about to transpire.

The entrance into the canyon began with a tight left-hand sweeper and onto
a short straight and then into some twisties.  At the exit from the sweeper
I looked out the back window. The Porsche was twenty car length behind. At
the end of the straight he was thirty lengths back. We entered the twisties
at at least two times the speed limit. The Corvair was beginning to use up
a lot of road. I was no longer looking out the back window, I was holding
on for dear life. I had driven this canyon dozens of times but *NEVER* at
this speed.

By now we were using both lanes of the road. Not on purpose either. The
exit from the twisties was an up-hill right hander across a narrow bridge.
I was yelling at my co-worker to slow down, but to no avail.

To make a long story short, it was at this moment that the Chevy gave up
all desire to be a Sports Car, and instantly reverted back to its original
design as a tail heavy, softly sprung, four passenger piece of Detroit
Iron. You know, the kind of car that always knew that real cars have their
engines in front. As The car looped backwards, we found our selves staring
into the front hood of the Porsche. He had been right on our collective
ass. The Porsche blasted past on the inside as the guardrail made a hell of
a mess of the passenger side if the Monza.

Ralph Nader was right!!!

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 15:21:41 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Winders' nitrogen conclusion

>I have not heard from Scott after his expert answered my last question.

>increasing T than predicted by the ideal gas (or other) equation if there
>is liquid water present."

>The conclusion is that any dry gas (like bottled nitrogen or air from an air
>compressor with a dryer) will work fine. Nitrogen DOES have a benefit if you
>are using a compressor that spits out water (like the little one that I use
>that plugs into my cigarette lighter).
>
>Hail Ferry, Hail Ferry ... Hail Ferry (Actually I didn't start it, I ended it
>(hopefully!)) Please no more on this subject, ITS DEAD!!!!


Mike,

Here is what John Douglas Porter sent me:

Scott, (this is long)

OK, we're closing in on a solution to the tire inflation problem.

I had assumed that air compressors used for your application were a cut
above run-of-the-mill service station types.  The compressors we use to
provide air in our labs include condensors and filters to remove water
and oil mist, for example, although they don't provide CO2-free,
water-free air.  Hence, in my previous notes, I had assumed that the
tires were filled with "equilibrium air" of the same composition as the
external environment, i.e. air equivalent to "divers' air".

Enough of a preamble.  If there is liquid water present in the tire, then
the situation is different from the conditions of my previous note.

In the previous note, the total number of moles of gas in the tire was
assumed to be constant.  If there is liquid water in the tire, this will
not be a valid assumption.  The reason is that the number of moles of
water vapor will change with temperature, even though all the other
components will be constant.

First, consider the (ridiculous) extreme where there is a large amount of
liquid water present in the tire when the tire is filled at 25 C.  Assume
that the volume of water is Vw (L).  Then everything from my last note is
valid at 25 C (i.e. the gas in the tire can be approximated well by the
ideal gas equation, including the water vapor component), but the volume
of the gas is now Vtire - Vw.

Now, if the temperature of the tire is changed, water will evaporate from
the liquid if T increases and water vapor will condense into the liquid if
T decreases.  Eventually, the system will come to equilibrium.  The
partial pressure of water vapor (the component of the pressure due to the
water) will be equal to the equilibrium value provided there is always
liquid water in the tire.  Here is a short table (there are more complete
ones in the CRC Handbook, for example):

T(C)    T(K)    Pw(atm)
0       273.15  0.006025
10      283.15  0.01212
20      293.15  0.02308
25      298.15  0.03126
30      303.15  0.04187
60      333.15  0.1966
80      353.15  0.4672
100     373.15  1.000

This is a pretty steep curve.  It can be approximated quite well by an
equation of the form:

        log(Pw) = (a/T) + b

where a and b are constants and T must be in kelvin.  You can use a
spreadsheet to estimate a and b if you like, or you can plot log(Pw) vs.
1/T(K), which should be a straight line, to get a calibration curve.  The
curve will only be good between 0 C and 100 C.  The value of Pw is
completely independent of the volume of the gas because there is a
reservoir of liquid water to act as a source or sink of water vapor.

So, as the tire temperature is raised the total pressure in the tire will
increase faster than in the previous calculations (although the ideal gas
equation can still be used for each component of the gas, as before).
Just substitute for Pw from the curve and Vtire - Vw for the volume.

This is obviously a worse situation than before.  So, filling the tire
with any gas in the presence of liquid water in the tire is worse than
filling the dry tire with any gas.  In other words, using nitrogen in the
presence of liquid water will be just as bad as using compressed air with
liquid water.  You want to get rid of liquid water in the tire.

OK, what about a more realistic situation, where there is a small amount
of liquid water in the tire?  For example, let's say you have
overinflated the tire (off the car), then rotated it to get the water
over the valve and released the pressure to expel most of the water.

In this case, there could be too little water for the system to remain
saturated with water vapor at all temperatures.  In other words, as the
temperature of the tire is increased, there may come a point where all the
liquid water evaporates.  The approach described above should be applied
for temperatures where there is still liquid water in the tire.  When
there is no liquid water, then the situation is analogous to my previous
note once again, except that the total number of moles of water vapor is
larger than assumed before.

So, this gives another way to empty the tire of water.  Deflate when the
tire is hot enough for the water all to be in the gas, then refill with
dry air.  Repeating once or twice will give you a bone-dry tire.  Which
brings you back to the "gas is gas" condition where nitrogen is no
different from any other (non-condensible) gas.

Let's do an example calculation.  Assume there is 50 mL of liquid water
remaining in the tire when it is inflated at 25 C (rather a large amount,
I think -- you would hear it sloshing).  This is 0.050 L x 55 mol/L = 2.75
mol water.  Assume that the tire is 22.4 L again.  If all the water was in
the form of vapor, then the partial pressure of the water would be
approximately Pw = (2.75 x 0.08206 x 300) / 22.4 = 3.0 atm.  This is
un-physically high (compare the values of Pw in the table above).  Hence,
50 mL water constitutes an "infinite volume" of water according to the
distinction given above.  If there was this much water in the tire, then
basically it wouldn't all evaporate until the temperature of the tire was
greater than 100 C.  Hence, you could look up the partial pressure of
water from the graph or table.  So, if your tires reached 80 C during a
run, the partial pressure of water would be 0.4672 atm, independent of the
volume of the tire or the pressures of the other components.  The original
partial pressure at 25 C is almost insignificant compared to this, so you
would take the "ideal gas" solution described in my last note and add
approximately 0.43 atm to it.

How little water do you need to make sure it is all evaporated at, say, 60
C?  Look at the value of Pw in the table: Pw = 0.1966 atm.  Put this into
the ideal gas equation to solve for n:  n = (0.1966 x 22.4)/(0.08206 x
333) = 0.16 moles.  This corresponds to 3 mL of liquid water, which isn't
much.


So, what are the general conclusions regarding tire inflation?

First, the ideal gas equation provides a good description of the
non-condensing gases in the tire.  The van der Waals equation is better,
but only by a percent or so at lower temperatures and by an even smaller
margin at higher temperatures.  The main message of these models is that
temperature is really the key parameter that needs to be measured and
controlled, if possible.

In order to use these models to predict the cold pressure needed to
achieve the desired race pressure, it is necessary to know: A) the
atmospheric pressure outside the tire, B) the differential (tire gauge)
cold pressure, C) the (cold) temperature, D) the (cold) tire volume and
E) the final (hot) tire temperature.  A better estimate would be obtained
if the hot tire volume were known (we assumed it didn't change in the
last note.  As you pointed out, it will increase with pressure, but not
by much once the tires are at their correct working pressure.  This could
be calibrated by immersing the tire and rim in water and measuring the
displaced water, correcting for the volume of the rim.)

Alternatively, the tires could be warmed to their race temperature and
the pressure adjusted to the desired value.  This could be done by
immersing them in hot water at the correct temperature, for example.

As far as inflating your tires is concerned, any non-condensing gas will
do, since they all behave similarly over the P-T range of interest.
Hence, pure nitrogen will be indistinguishable from air.

The presence of a condensing gas in the tire below the "dew point" of the
gas is bad.  The example given here is water.  The presence of liquid
water in the tire will cause the variation of P with T to be more extreme
than predicted by the ideal gas (or vdW) equation.  Even though the
situation is less ideal, it can still be taken into account and modeled if
necessary, using the equations given in this note.  Better to avoid this
complication, however.

It doesn't take much liquid to have an adverse effect.  A few mLs in the
hypothetical example tire was enough to have a big effect on the pressure
as the tire was warmed.

Hence, the use of _dry_ gas to fill your tires is very desirable.  The
use of _dry_ nitrogen is a good thing, then, if it avoids the
introduction of liquid water into the tire.  Alternatively, you could use
_dry_ air and get the same performance.  (Not all nitrogen tanks contain
dry nitrogen.  I have heard water sloshing in some.)  Dry compressed
(tank) air will give the same behaviour as dry compressed (tank)
nitrogen.

If you have your own compressor, and you suspect that water mist is
getting into your tires, I would suggest fitting a drying cartridge to
the output line.  There are commercial ones that contain a water adsorber
(like DriRite) and the adsorber can be reconditioned by baking in a
microwave.


Executive summary:

        dry air = dry nitrogen

        liquid water in tires = bad ... get rid of it if possible

Hope this helps.

J.P.

letter from Sacramento stating that you have an incomplete registration
in process. (I believe it says get a smog cert or sign on the dotted line 
that you are not using the car anymore)

Well anyway, unless different DMV branches operate differently, I don't
think that you could get a car registred in CA without getting 
a smog cert. 
But of course there are many ways of getting that cert ;)

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 1994 21:40:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: 944 belt idlers and tensioners


Much has been written about the changing and inspection of 944 timing
belts but no one has mentioned how you are supposed to check whether the
belt idlers and tensioner rollers are any good. I have heard of cases
where they've been known to take the belt with them on failure but is this
common? How long can I expect the originals to last usually?
 
In Peter Morgan's book, 'The Porsche 924/944 Book', pg. 95, regarding the 
timing belt, he states:

'The 1985 recommendation was that the tension must be adjusted again 
after 750-1500 miles (at the initial service),once the belt has completed 
its initial stretching. This has now been relaxed to 2000 miles.....After
this, routine checking is advised every 12,000 miles. The belt is claimed 
to last the life of the engine.'

Is the last sentence true? This seems to go against everthing I've read or 
heard. 
 
Chris
'86 944

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 06:08:13 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: '69 912: a better car?

Dear Pallis:

     Yes, you're right- the '69 912 is , IHMO, the best of the 912's. It has
a longer wheelbase, and is the last of the Real 912's, but more importantly
it has NO SMOG PUMP unlike the '68 912. The '69's use Teflon coated intake
manifolds to eliminate the dreaded air pump that most all '68's had removed
long ago (although with smog inspections being  all the rage these days, the
lack of a smog pump is coming back to haunt the '68's. In spades.)
      Thanks to the lack of cold air being injected into a hot head, '69
912's crack the heads less frequently than '68's do. (The expectation now is
that three of the four chambers on a '68 912 will be cracked!)

     '69 912's also have a modified Rear Mount with 6 rubber cubes. (Previous
years from 67-68 had 4 rubber cubes; 1965 and early '66's use a solid rear
mount.) The 6 rubber cube rear mount does a better job of keeping engine
vibration from bad Solex carbs from being transmitted to the driver and his
passenger(s), and is a Better Idea.
     All in all, the '69 912 is my favorite 912.  '76 912E's are orphans,
made for only one year and have a modified VW 411 engine, NOT a "real"
Porsche engine. And good luck trying to find parts for a '76 912E- most
everything on the engine is special and since they only made 'em for 1 year
things are kinda rare.

   Just my $.02.
   KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
   The Maestro


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 07:47:28 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 belt idlers and tensioners

Hi, Chris,

To check the idlers on a 944 one may remove them from the timing belt
housing and spin them by hand, listening for problems.  That's the cheap
way... The expensive way is to replace them at regular intervals.
Since the bearings are sealed, there is no way to predict when the failures
will occur, but they do occur.

As far as the belts lasting the life of the engine, when they break, the
engine is DEAD!  I guess that Mr. Morgan must have had his tongue in his
cheek when he was writing the article.

I change the timing belt at 15K intervals, since they are cheap at $9 or 10,
and if you have the right tools and the right attitude, it can take as
little as an hour.  After all, it is a maintenance item, like oil filters and
fuel filters.

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 8:12:41 EDT
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: Hmmmm, maybe I will hire a stereo installer

> I have a new deck and CD changer taht I was foing to put into my 944, but I 
> seem to have run across the most bizzare (to me at least) problem.  I can't 
> figure out how to remove the old deck.  There is currently a pretty nonfunctional Blaupunkt deck in there, and I haven't the slightest clue how to get at it.

If it's like the Blaupunkt that was in my car, it has a hole at each corner
of the front panel through which you can stick a nail, which you want
to do because it releases the spring clip that's holding the front of the 
radio to the dashboard.

If you jam a nail into each of the 4 holes, releasing the clips, you can
pull the radio forward and out of the hole.

Good luck.

Stefan

Date: Fri, Oct 21, 1994 9:28 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Porsche vs. Corvair

Bill Kennedy, NJIT  writes: 

> I liked my Corvair a lot - 64 coupe, 110hp - but I would not put it in the 
> same class as either a 356 or a 911, and I don't think Chevy would either. 

Hi Bill,

Good to see another old Corvair veteran.  I loved/hated my Black '65 Turbo
Corsa coupe (white Naugahyde interior, white beltline pinstripe, full IRS
and 180 hp).

I loved the car, but hated its piss-poor assembly, and the Lawton, OK
dealer I bought it from and had to deal with. It had a terrible surging
condition at 30 mph, that I never got eliminated, but I *loved* the way it
would *smoke* full sized, power-pack Chevys.

'65 was the year the Corvair went from swing-axle to full-IRS, and I do
believe that it would corner at least as well as any stock Pcar of that
year (Gasp! Oh! the heresy...).  On the handling score, there was no
comparison between the IRS and swing-axle models, which were *evil*
incarnate!  I discovered this fact while in the mountains just out
Saltillo, Mexico. Corner hard, ooops, inside rear lifts, tucks, rolls tire
off rim, swap ends, flip, <crash>.  Get our, look around <turn green when
discovering good fortune in crashing into side of mountain, not over
1000'(+) drop on outside of curve).  (another long story omitted,involving
curious Mexican laws) Discoverd charms of driving 1200 miles, from Saltillo
to Dallas, sans benefit of windshield.  Not recommended, if you can avoid
it, by the way

I wasn't real charmed, though, by the fact that although it would run
happily all day at 95 mph, about 10 secs or less after hitting 100, the
overheat alarm would go off, and the cyl head temp would hit 525 F! < I
never did find out how fast it would go because of that. > If you would
stop and sit patiently on the side of the road to let things cool down, no
harm; but equally, no fun!  Fail to stop *right* now, no engine.  Alas.

Well, it was such a lemon that despite its considerable charms, I couldn't
take more that 8 months of dealing with the problems (or the *#@&% dealer)
and traded it on my '66 Corvette, a car that was assembeled as
exceptionally *well*, as the Corsa had been *Poorly*.  Who says there's no
justice...


Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 09:15:25 -0400 (EDT)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: RE: Bo Diddly was right.

Barney Bettilyon wrote:

<snip -- anecdotal story of badly driven Monza vs 356 deleted>

> Ralph Nader was right!!!

For those with RCI.

The Corvair and the 356 have their roots in a common design, the 
"people's car." They suffer from the same design weaknesses in the
rear suspension and location of the engine behind the rear axle.
Corvair corrected this with the later cars -- 66-68. This was never
corrected in the 356.

The significant difference was the 356 was an expensive (for the time)
low volume sports car. The Corvair was the General's small economy car.
For a sports car to outhandle an inexpensive sedan is to be expected.

356s, especially the disk braked cars, very especially the Carrera
versions, were great little cars. Even the base 356 sold for 2 or 3
times the Corvair. The Corvair's were also great little cars --
especially the 66-68. They were sedans, not sports cars. The potential
of the design was illustrated by such things as the Yenko Stinger and
the Fitch.

BTW, the original design for the 911 used the same single cam with
pushrods that the Corvair featured. 

Comparing the Corvair and the 356 is just not appropriate. Different
design objectives. Like comparing apples and koala bears.

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 09:43:54
From: pjoyce@hoh.MBL.EDU (Paul Joyce)
Subject: removing a Blaupunkt deck

Matthew,

The Blau head units are a piece of cake to remove. I'm using my '86 944 as a 
reference. There should be four small holes in the corners of the head unit. 
There are U-shaped tools that fis into these holes, that look like the 
handle mounts of rack mounted home stereos. You could probably buy the tools
from an installer, but I made a pair from a wire coat hanger. I have seen 
recent Ford radios use an identical setup. The tools fit in and release
catches on the sides of the deck that hold it into a thin metal sleeve around 
the unit. So, just make up two U-tools out of a coat hanger, so that one 
goes into top and bottom holes on the left, the other into top and bottom on 
the right, and gently pull the deck out of the car, using the tools as 
handles. If you want to remove the sleeve, too, it is held in place in the 
dash by tabs bent out to secure it. When installing the new radio (if you've 
got a windshield antenna) be sure to hook the power antenna booster wire back 
up.

Incidently, current Blau head units are made by Sony, with the exception of a 
couple of the lower line models which are made by Toshiba.

Good luck

Paul Joyce
pjoyce@mbl.edu

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 09:12:15 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: Re: '69 912 A Better Car?


>I have heard generally that the '69 912 is superior to the '67 and '68 model,
>but I don't know specifically why that's so.  Can someone help me out ?
> Thanks.
>

My experience as a '66 912 owner is that the '69s are a better
car simply based on the price of pre '69 parts!  Brakes, suspension,
body parts (long wheel base!), almost everything I've been looking
for has been cheaper on '69 and later models.  Plus, lots of parts are made
by non-Porsche manufacturers - so at least you have lots of choices.
If the car needs any work at all and you dont enjoy the "hunt", my advice
is to at least consider '69 and later vintages of p-cars.

Ron
rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 11:25:37 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 sunroof water woes

> Help, pls: In bad rain the sunroof in my 944S2 leaks at the rear. I find
> water in the back seat. Does this mean that a seal is imperfect, or is there
> an adjustment?
> 
> What do I do?
> 
> Fred Pack					fh                                                       

Hi, Fred,

Most likely it means that one of the four drain tubes is blocked in some way
(leaf crud, kinked hose, etc.)  You might try removing the sunroof completely
and trying to pour a bit of water down each tube to identify the culprit.

As I recall, the tubes go down the a-pillars and b-pillars.

(I would not suggest compressed air to clean out the culprit, because you
might blow the tube completely off the drain attachment point..)

Later,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:23 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Let's stir it UP!

Hi, Barney.
 
And don't forget, the turbo on those things didn't work worth a damn anyway.
At least not for long. Typical GM solution: hurry up, install it, let the
customer do your development testing for you.
 
Back then, they had no idea how to manage the turbo output,
and just sized the things to choke at high flow rates and so be
self-limiting. Nobody had a wastegate on cars until Porsche brought it out
in the early 1970s. And they had no clue how to cure the bearing coking
problem.
 
Pete

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:18 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Pirelli tires has-beens

 
Yesterday I reported that the C4 outside has Michelins. Wrong, I had
Michelins on European press cars, but this one has Continental Sport
Contact. They work fine. I took the C4 up to Mount Palomar yesterday.
Handling is the most incredible thing I've ever experienced, it has just
the slightest understeer when pushed too hard, is dead nuts neutral
the rest of the time and NOTHING seems to make it oversteer, not even
flooring the throttle in first while going around a wet street corner.
 
Pete

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:13 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: lowering an 81 SC

 
Hi, Stephen.
 
The factory's position on lowering sounds like it was taken from a handbook
on sex for the AIDS generation. "Don't, but if you do, do this..."
 
                    Standard (Euro) height               Lowered
Front axle          108 +/- 5 mm                     128 +/- 5 mm
                    (center of torsion bar BELOW     (center of torsion bar
                    center of wheel)                 BELOW center of wheel
 
Rear axle           12 +/- 5 mm                      9 +/- 5 mm
                    center of cross tube ABOVE       center of cross tube
                    center of wheel                  BELOW center of wheel
 
Note that this lowers the car another 20 mm.
 
Front camber: 0 to -1 deg.
Front caster: standard (5 deg 50' to 6 deg 20')
Front toe:    0 (preloaded with 15 kilo force)
 
Rear camber: -0 deg 30' to -1 deg 40'
Rear toe:    0 to 20' toe-in
 
These were taken from a 1981 factory document, applicable to your model year.
 
Pete

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:20 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Let's stir it UP!

 
Hi, Bert.
 
I don't know which was faster (no fair using a Yenko) but I tried a mind
experiment while working at Porsche. In one of my textbooks,"The Internal
Combustion Engine in Theory and Practice," C F Taylor, MIT Press, Vol. 2 p.
442, is a cutaway of a Corvair engine. I held my hand over the caption and
showed it to a Porsche engine guy. "Oh, yeah, that's an early 901 engine
prototype. We decided to go with a vertical fan arrangement." Then I moved
my hand away, revealing the type and date, well before the 901/911 came out.
"Ach SO...."
 
The Corvair is another fine example of GM taking a great idea and tossing it
on the trash heap of history. Others: Wankel engine in general and
three-rotor Corvette in particular, the Fiero... I forgot a lot of examples
too.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:06 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: New Subscriber/911 owner

Hi, Neil.
 
If your Turbo had understeer going into a turn, it was because you were off
the throttle. (This is forgivable on your first turn -- or your first 100,
or first 1000 -- in this car). <g>
 
Easy way to fix the pedals: move the throttle pedal higher. Easy way to move
the throttle pedal higher:
1) Go to Porsche parts counter
2) Buy new plastic throttle pedal
3) Remove existing pedal to make work easier. There is a ball joint about
midway up, pops right out of the plastic socket, and two bolts on the floor.
Hinge is just plastic.
4) Taking new pedal, cut the stop off the back with a hand saw. Cut hinge
off bottom with scissors or whatever.
5) Look at waffling on back of pedal, decide where you are going to put 3
holes for screws. Drill new pedal with clear holes for something like an M5
(metric) or #12 (SAE) countersunk machine screw. Countersink holes in face
of new pedal.
6) Drill holes in old pedal small enough to take thread from screws. Not
necessary to tap; plastic will conform.
7) Bolt this thicker pedal assembly back in.
 
Yes, you sort of tap the throttle with the side of your foot, but it's a lot
better with the thicker pedal.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 21 Oct 94 11:26:53 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Finally, a bad Japanese radio

After bashing Blaupunkt and Becker radios, and saying that the Japanese
offer better price/performance tradeoffs, I have to take that back, at least
in part. The Carrera 4 I have now has an Alpine stereo/CD deck in it, and it
is absolutely the pits. It's one of the removable face jobbies (reminds me
of the hockey game in the leper colony -- they had a face off in the
corner). Anyway, the pushbuttons feel cheap, the whole face moves when you
push something, the controls are not user transparent (have to get out the
manual), functions do not work conventionally (to store a station in memory,
you have to hold the preset button, and then when the display blinks, PRESS
IT AGAIN.) Worst of all, either the radio or the speakers are responsible
for absolutely dismal bass, with unbearable distortion. I'm not even talking
about Brian Adams, cranked full blast here (the Becker in the Mercedes 600
SEC at least did that well, it sounded so good I got sick). We're talking
Enya, "Shepherd Moons." Not your typical hard rock with lots of bass.
 
Past experience has shown that humans can get used to anything (including
Democrats in the white house), and I'm sure Carrera owners will get used to
this stereo deck, but with all the good Japanese decks out there, why did
Alpine copy the worst features of Blaupunkt and Becker, combined?
 
Pete (I say, bring back vacuum tubes!)
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 10:45:00 PDT
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: Stumbling 944


Am new to group so hope I don't break any of meister Stan's rules
and get roasted.

Thank you in advance to anyone who actually wades thru this mess with me.

Riddle that beats the "experts".....

Have '88 944 (136,000 mi) "stumbling idle" problem.  Also stumbles
under acceleration, especially at lower revs (2500 or so). Bought
U.S. spec 944 new, Tourist delivery Stuttgart Sep '87.  Have had
problem for 2-3 yrs.   Problem has stumped dealer AND two
independent local shops [who claim specialization in
German / Bosch / Porsche].  Taking matters into own hands.
Tired of throwing $$$ to incompetents only to hear how everything
checks out fine.  Collecting data re areas to check.  Don't own
Bosch injection manual but considering one.  Only have Haynes.
Wish I could get better schematics without spending $200+ for
factory manuals.





Detailed problem description.....

Only happens in COLD ambient air conditions - around 40-50F
and below - summer is fine.  Problem same with cold OR hot engine.
On idle stumble tach visibly dips to 50 or so (engine nearly stalls
out totally) then, ALWAYS, something steps in and revs back to
1000 or so and holds OK - for a moment or so.  Never dies
completely - just acts like it will.  Believe same problem manifesting
itself as momentary [often violent] stumble under acceleration.
Never misses under steady cruise.  Car has some history of
electrical gremlins.  Suspecting electrical rather than fuel.





Some electrical gremlins.....

Random, intermittent LOUD thumps in audio sys - usually
shortly after start of engine - then no more.

Fog lights stuck on - could not turn them off - was finally able
to cycle full headlight actuation in various combinations with
fog switch and get them to go off.  Other times, had to pull fog fuse.
Guessing sticky relay.

Recently blew cig lighter, dome light, etc. fuse - replaced fuse -
fine now for a few months.

Electrical gremlins seem to like rainy, damp weather - no big surprise.





Failed solution attempts (by Dealer, other shops).....

O2 sensor OK.
Fuel pump OK - good pressure.
Distributor checked / cleaned up - OK.
Various electrical grounds verified OK.
Some kind of throttle control plate thingy in intake air path - OK.
I ran a bottle of Techron thru - desperate, I know.






My thoughts.....

Peeked under hood on very dark night - cool light show going
on with original plug wires arcing to engine.  Replaced plug
wire set and plugs - no effect on problem.

Ignorantly went 94,000 mi on factory fuel filter - technician
commented "never seen sludge like that pour out of a fuel
filter" - oops.  Have since changed fuel filter again myself -
no visible sludge at 2nd change.  But maybe figures into things.
Filter located such that engine warming up wouldn't warm it - but
suppose exhaust would (ambient air temp correlation?).  Naaaa.

Original cat clogging? 136,000mi [largely interstate cruising].  Naaaa.

DME unit dying?  Damned expensive item to trial / error
investigate.  Ambient air temp?  Naaaa.

Tried disconnecting after market alarm sys, self-installed
stereo sys - no effect.

ODD SEQUENCE OF EVENTS - maybe bigtime clues here.
Last [non-dealer] tech identified bad air box.  Air box, incidentally,
also has [I think] intake air temp sensor in it.  Ambient air temp
correlation?  Hmmmm.  So.......installed new (rebuilt) air box
(not cheap) from Python Injection via Imparts.  Car barely ran
at all - useless.  Bad air box I said.  So did my technician.  Fine.
Shipped back air box.  Got exchange (noted s/n to be certain
they didn't just ship back same).  Installed 2nd new (rebuilt) air box.
Exact same behavior.  Car barely drivable.  OK, maybe Python
injection just sucks as a parts rebuilder.  But....tech then tried his
own air box from his own '87 944.  Exact same barely drivable
behavior yet again.  Hmmmm....new theory suddenly.
Remembered dealer comment that when adjusted CO mixture
setting [as part of problem pursuit] had to use up FULL RANGE
of some adjustment somewhere.  And even then couldn't get it
quite right - but close enough - they said - much to my chagrin.
Things that make you go hmmmm.  Could it be I really did have
a bad original air box and the incompetent dealer techs just
wanged the hell out of some other adjustment(s) to compensate -
poorly.  This last [non-dealer] tech conclusion - sell car in
summer - it's possessed.  I refuse to let this technical problem
beat me.  I do still love the car.  Considering installing yet
another new air box (non-Python just to feel statistically confident),
then limp to dealer again one last time.  But dealers suck.

Need more complete understanding of exactly what inputs
DME unit needs to do its job.

Any clues anyone may have - even long shots - would be
humongously appreciated.  Long shots may be best hope
since "experts" [hofentlich] checked standard causes.

Kirk Shafer
sick '88 944

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 11:38:37 EDT
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: '73 911 passenger side horn

I recently purchased a pair of OEM horns for my '73 coupe.  The existing
driver's side horn made a pathetic tone and was missing its bugle and the
passenger's side horn was nonexistent.  A few questions came up that maybe the
collective wisdom of porschephiles can solve:

  1) Did my car even come with a passenger's side horn?  The wiring was
     present, but it is debatable whether it had ever been used or not.
     Another '72 owner (Bob Spindel) was also missing that side's horn.
  2) Where do I properly attach the horn?  It came with an approx. 3" long
     bracket with a 6mm hole in one end and an 8mm hole in the other.  I ended
     up connecting the large-holed end to the base of the headlight bucket
     where a bolt comes down and connects to a bracket on the battery box.  The
     other end went to the top of the horn - it is positioned pointing
     downward next to the battery box in front of the tire.  In this
     orientation its flared end is barely inside the lip of the S spoiler.
  3) There was an extra set of horn connections on the driver's side, wired in
     parallel with the ones used.  Did they put both horns on one side if the
     car had a fender-mounter oil cooler (which mine does not)?

BTW I purchased these horns at Zims for ~$25 each.  They are original with the
exception that the bugle-like portions are black instead of red.  The horn now
sounds "like a 911 should sound (tm)".

 - Jeff Shorey
  '73 911S Coupe

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 11:43:22 CST
From: "Mike Selner Jr" <mike@MR.Net>
Subject: What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?

Engineers:

A trivia (trivial?) question - I was wondering:

What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?
i.e. in definition and in popular usage.

I thought the definition might be that a motor converts electric energy 
into  mechanical energy and an engine converts some other form of energy
into mechanical energy, but this does not fit popular usage.
You never ride an "Enginecycle"!

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 11:12:21 -0700
From: Clyde Gamboa <gamboa@proton.llumc.edu>
Subject: tracy-thred

>off r.a.s

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 17:06:26 GMT
Lines: 33



Just a few observations after listening in on the Newman-Haas
news conference yesterday (the 18th):

Obviously, no-one would say much about Tracy's contract, but
there was plenty of talk about "long-term relationships".
The subject of Penske's option on Tracy for 1996 came up, and 
Tracy made it pretty clear he was not interested in returning
to Penske, and suggested things on three-car team were not nearly
as wonderful as they may have looked from the outside.

Clearly, Tracy was not about to say he'd love to go back to
Penske at a Newman-Haas news conference, but the tone of his
response suggested he'd be quite pissed off if Penske even
made an attempt to exercise his option.

On other topics, the Newman-Haas people indicated neither Michael
nor Paul would be designated as a "number one" or "number two"
driver, and said they were prepared to live with the risks of
having two very aggressive drivers going wheel-to-wheel from
time-to-time.

For those warming up their car-spotter skills for '95, 
Andretti will drive the Texaco-Havoline-Kmart colours; Tracy
will be in the Budweiser car.


Craig Steenburgh,
Great White North

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>.
Hope this helps all those who were interested in this.

Clyde

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 09:27:53 PDT
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: ca smog checks


	Last time I checked California Biannual smog checks were only required on
domestic cars '65 and newer and imported cars '70 and newer. They still send
out the regestration that says "smog certificate required" but on the back side
you can check off your exemption. For '64 and prior domestic and '69 and prior
imported cars, a smog certificate is required on change of registration, but
a biannual smog check is not required.


								-jd

				...wishing there was such a thing as a '69 914/6

'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 14:48:05 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Passing emmisions in an olde car

Hi all,

In Connecticut we've had the emmisions "sniffer" for several years. There are
two basic things to do to get your car to pass. I have not seen any replies
about how to make a car pass, so here is what I have done successfully on
older cars :

1. Add a few cans of dry gas to your tank (without much gas in it). Don't use
the old alcohol style, (methanol?) but the new one recommended for fuel
injected cars. On later cars with oxygen sensors this probably won't help,
but it should lean out older cars a bit.
After testing, fill up the tank with good gas to dilute it.

2. If possible, lean out your mixture, but not so much that you get a lean
misfire. If you read excessive HC after trying this, you probably went too
far and have a lean misfire.

3. Retard your timing. 5 degrees or so should be no problem. I retarded my
'72 S more
than that and it ran VERY HOT so be careful. You may want to adjust it a
block away from the testing center, and set it back to stock after it passes.

4. If possible, adjust your idle speed higher, or slowly depress the gas
pedal when the car is being checked at idle. You will run cleaner at about
1000 RPM's than at low idle.

Hope this helps someone to BEAT THE SYSTEM.

Mike Piera, AnalogMike@aol.com  '72 911S ('70 240Z, '74 Mazda RX-4, '84 Colt
Turbo, and other cars passed with these adjustments.)

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 12:16:55 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?

>Engineers:
>
>A trivia (trivial?) question - I was wondering:
>
>What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?
>i.e. in definition and in popular usage.
>
>I thought the definition might be that a motor converts electric energy
>into  mechanical energy and an engine converts some other form of energy
>into mechanical energy, but this does not fit popular usage.
>You never ride an "Enginecycle"!

According to Webster's:

A machine that converts any of various forms of energy into mechanical
force and motion is an engine.

A power unit that develops energy or imparts motion is a motor. Examples
given:
        A: A small compact engine
        B: An internal combustion engine
        C: A rotating machine that transforms electrical energy
           into mechanical energy.

Based on this information, an engine is a motor but a motor is not
necessarily an engine. These definitions even hold up in the real world!

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 12:08:15 -0500 (CDT)
From: THOXNER@ualr.edu
Subject: 944 Belts Lasting the Life of the Engine

Chris was surprised to hear that the 944 timing belt is claimed to last the
life of the engine. This is true, because when the life of the belt ends, so
does the life of the engine. So the belt lasts as long as the engine, however,
this may be only 30-40,000 miles. :-).
Tom Oxner

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 15:26:15 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Stumbling 944

Hi, Shafer,

If you can catch this problem when it's happening, check the air-flow sensor
plug to make sure that the contacts are all good. (Try wiggling the plug.)
I have a similar problem on my 83 944 that I found when it was doing it, by
accident.

Also, time to check for vacuum leaks. If you haven't yet, spend another $20
and replace the injector seals.  Those things drive you nuts when they get
hard...

Keep us posted on your (lack of) progress...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 12:35:19 PDT
From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM" <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>
Subject: SOS (944's and mine)


Hi, 
 
           Took my 944 (88K miles)to the shop yesterday to check the cam 
           housing leak. They have recomended the following: 
 
           -  Change lower radiator hose & all 
              coolant hoses  (no leaks but the   ----  $300 
              radiator hose is oil stained)                 
            
           -  Front of engine re-seal            ----  $650 
 
           -  Flush brake fluid system           ----  $70 
 
           -  Change head gasket and cam 
              housing gasket (no visible leaks   ----  $900 
              from the cylinder head) 
 
           -  Change power steering hose and 
              fix pump leak.                     ----  $115 
 
           -  Front wheel bearing repack (has 
              thin grease now which  runs down   ----  $140 
              wheels when hot) 
 
           -  Oil cooler reseal                  ----  $260 
 
              There is absolutely NO oil drippings on my garage floor 
           though there is a slight drop in the power steering fluid. I am 
           flat broke right now after buying the car and I cannot afford 
           to do all the above jobs now. Please let me know which of the 
           above list should be done immediately and if any of the esti- 
           mates are high. Is there any thing that I can fix myself (I  
           have the workshop manual)? I'm sorry to keep on asking  
           questions but I new to the country, the car, the workshops etc 
           and dont know any better than to ask people who know better! 
 
           thanks in advance, 
           Sreelal (SOS) Ramachandran 
           '84 944

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 12:48:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Belts Lasting the Life of the Engine



On Fri, 21 Oct 1994 THOXNER@ualr.edu wrote:

> Chris was surprised to hear that the 944 timing belt is claimed to last the
> life of the engine. This is true, because when the life of the belt ends, so
> does the life of the engine. So the belt lasts as long as the engine, however,
> this may be only 30-40,000 miles. :-).
> Tom Oxner
> 
Ha-ha.. No, actually I was skeptical about Morgan's claim but doubt he 
made it in jest in his 'serious' book. Don't get me wrong, I would never 
leave the belts in forever. I know Peter Morgan has written other Porsche 
books on 911's etc. but his statement about the 944 cam belt causes me to 
question his technical competence.

Chris
'86 944

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 14:54:45 CDT
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: Re: SOS (944's and mine)

>           Took my 944 (88K miles)to the shop yesterday to check the cam 
>           housing leak. They have recomended the following: 
...

>           -  Change power steering hose and 
>              fix pump leak.                     ----  $115 

...

phew - thats a lot of stuff! It sure sounds a bit suspicious to me. Have
you tried calling the BBB about this shop?

About the power steering - mine was leaking slightly, and I found that it
was just seeping from where the hose attaches to the underside of the
reservior. There is a hose clamp there, but apparently the hose can
harden. I just bought another clamp from Home Depot and put it on above
the old one, so there are now two clamps on. That fixed my leak. That may
be worth a try, especially if the hose appears to have fluid on it.

Jeff

***	Jeff Holt  Advanced Graphics Systems Design  (205) 730-6098     ***
***	jjholt@ingr.com                               FAX  730-6011     ***

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 19:46:34 -0400
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: 914 Idle

Hi,
I had a high idle on my 914. just happend one day. Solution I knocked a
vaccum hose off of the distributor. The small one I think. Hooked it back
up and idle went to 850 rpms. Good luck
Nick
