Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 17:33:19 -0400
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: no longer mute!!and 914 stuff

Hi everyone,
Now I think the admins here and at tta.com have figured out how to get us
talking again I will!!
First off The P-car and the Girlfriend had a wonderful trip to western
Maryland. Twisty montain roads. I had a blast with the car. Leaves changing
corners changing speeds change in short change is good. On this trip the
speedo cable broke. Anyone got one for sale. I also need a rain tray. I
think Mike Willis is going to sell me the heater control valve I need. Now
some old messages that bounced back.


Hi everyone,
Now that it is getting cold I have noticed or rather my passengers have
noticed that there is no heat on the right side of the 914 (if it above 40
degrees and dry the top is off). So far I have checked the heater contol
valves and both open and close when I move the switch between the seats.
When the fan is on and the car is off on the left side of the car air is
being blown out in the car but the right side gets nothing. The fresh air
fan works on both sides. under the car it feels like air is coming out of
the heat exchangers near where the engine cool fan is (this is still with
engine off heater fan on). there is no air flow anywhere else on the left
side of the car. Nothing at the heater valve their at all. In addition for
some reason the dealer unplugged the heater fan and now if it is plugged in
it runs all the time. I have three wires. two go into the plug and the
third is dangling from the ground on the left side of the car. If I touch
the ground to the wires in the plug the fan turns on and off. Were is the
ground wire suppose to go so the switch in the car does this?


Exhaust noise. I love it!!!! I know this is an old thread but I have to get
my two cents in. The 914 with monza exaust sounds great to me. The day this
thread broke out I started the car up in front of a crackfinder oops I mean
pathfinder and its alarm went off! In parking garges cars with alarms will
anounce my arival by sounding their alarms. I love the way people turn to
look at my noisy little beast. There are  a few frowns, but most people
smile and give me a big thumbs up. I  went the vintage car races in philly
and the cars were loud and that was half the fun. In fact the M3 that went
around the track at high speeds were boring. No sound except for tire
squeel. A PORSHE is a a sensory joy. The more sensory feed back the better!
Loud exaust steering wheel that talks to your hands about what the road is
doing in relation to the tires and pedals that give feedback on what they
are opening or closing. The joy of a porsche is it includes all the senses
in driving. A loud exaust is just helping a sense join in the fun.
Nick

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 15:43:54 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Bauman's Great Adventure



Hi there folks .....

I just returned from a short vacation in the U.K., and
had a really cool experience, that while not *exactly*
Porsche related, is close enough!  

The airfield my dad flew from during WWII is now a
race track (Castle Combe). So, I pulled in to the
pit area which is adjacent to a small sideroad.
The gate was open, and there was some activity
on the track.  The activity, as it turned out, was
the boys from McClaren with two of their million dollar
road cars -- the 220 mph F1.  I had a nice talk with
them, drooled a lot, took a few pix, admired the 400 kph
speedo and the 600 HP + engine, and watched as the
McClaren helicopter came in and landed next to my rental
car.  I was slightly in awe of the whole scene!

Then, in London, I attemted to visit Ben Evans
at his fortress office next to Victoria Station
in London. Ben was on holiday!! Thanks Ben!!! I suppose
next time I should tell you I'm coming your way!! (-B

Jim Bauman
Back in the US, back in the US, back in the US
with my '86 Cab thank god!! 

PS: I saw an ad in one of the London papers for the 993
tiptronic...they were noting the fact that the transmission
is controlled with push buttons on the steering wheel
(like the F1 cars).... THAT would take some getting used
to. It was bad enough having to shift with my left hand,
negotiate roundabouts the wrong way, drive on the wrong
side of the road, watch for pedestrians on humped zebra
crossings, keep my headlights dipped, and wonder what the heck
a stretch of motorway without cats eyes was! But, the Guiness
was great!
.

Date: 21 Oct 1994 11:10:58 -0800
From: "Tom Biesiada" <Tom.Biesiada.TEST#u#B131@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re: Hmmmm, maybe I will hire

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               Re>Hmmmm, maybe I will hire a stereo
installer


If your Blaupunkt is like mine, there should be two holes on both the left
and right side of the front of the deck.  If this is the case, then I've seen
the deck removed by inserting the ends of a horseshoe shaped tool (1 for each
side of the deck) into the holes.  This apparently releases a detent and
allows you to pull the deck out.  I've heard of people accomplishing the same
thing with 4 nails.  A word of caution however, you can apparently damage the
mounting fixture if you are not careful.  If you bought your new equipment
from a store that does installations, they would probably pull your old deck
using the proper tools (and experience) at no charge.  That's how I witnessed
the process.

Best of luck,
Tom
'87 944

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 16:07:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: Government interference/emission testing


Many people on this list keep complaining about the stupidity of the various 
governments and its intrusion, not to mention all the pork and crooked 
members of congress.  I keep hearing I'd join an organization if I 
thought it'd do any good.  That's the problem!  The National Motorists 
Assn only has about 15,000 members because everyone sits on their ass and 
complains that it is ineffective, then doesn't do anything about it.  

How many of you have written to your congressman recently about a car 
related issue?  How many have ever written?  I write about speed limits, 
HOV lanes, emissions inspections, etc. about every 6 months to some 
elected official.  If only 10% of you did the same they would be hearing 
a much different message than they hear from all the car haters who are 
constantly lobbying them.

The NMA dues are only about $25 a year.  That's less than PCA, and is the 
only source we have at the moment.  They're not perfect, and only 
partially effective, but without a larger membership base what can one 
expect?  

(Flame off mode:)

In the soviet of Washington cars 67 and earlier are exempt from 
emissions.  Cars 68-79 are not inspected to see if emission equipment has 
been removed, unless they don't pass.  

Ted Rodgers

57 Speedster
67 911S
67 BMW 1600
(No emisssions inspections on any of the above)
Life member NMA




------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 12:00:41 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: '69 912: a better car?


- --Boundary-4560386-0-0

Pallis, Pallis....., the thread here seems to be in favor of the 69 912's as 
the better 912.  Not so!! Sayeth I.... The earlier cars IMHO are the better to 
own because they are simply....MUCH MORE FUN TO DRIVE!!!!!! 
 
...and here's the scoop: 
 
First, the difference between the 912 and the 356 (note that I have a 68 912 
targa softback and a 64 356 C cpe, both painfully restored to STOCK FORM). 
Also note that I've done some research and am giving  you stats and driving 
impressions from "professionals" who wrote articles for major auto pubs, not 
just my opinions.  Though I have to concur with them. 
 
Excellence, Feb, 1988;  "912, the Proxy  Porsche", by David Coleman 
"assuredly, a Porsche engine thru and thru, the 912 motor underwent subtle 
changes from 356SC form to lower its output from 95hp/DIN to 90hp/DIN.  While 
sharing the 356SC;s undersquare bore and stoke ratio of 74mm x 82,5mm, the 912 
version reduced compression ratio to 9.3:1, altered valve gear specs, valve 
timing and camshaft design to reduce peak torque output from 4200rpm to 3500 
rpm.  Peak power in both available at 5800rpm.  The tuning changes produced a 
tractable, torquey,engine which could be revved dependably to 6000rpm without 
fear of damage." 
 
You shift at a lower rpm in the 912 because of this and plug in the 5 speed 
not avalilable in the 356 and voila!  faster!!  and it handles, oh how it 
handles. 
 
same article  "a happy byproduct of placing the 4 cylinder in the 911 bay was 
the alteration of the tailhwavy weight distribution of the 911. 41front/59 
rear to 44front/56 rear in the 912.Unlike the twitchy early 911, the 912 
proved virtually impossible to provoke into oversteer.  ...The 912 never 
threatened to swap ends like it's more powerful sibling.  ROAD AND TRACK 
adjudged it's handling to be vastly imporved over that of its predecessor the 
356-'Oversteer is a thing of the past and one no longer need be an expert of 
any kind to keep from losing it even in the wet....  Both ends grip 
tenaciously and about the only way to break the back loose is the same 
technique applied to front heavy cars: brake in the middle of a tight turn."  
If I drive the C over the same roads and at the same speeds as the 912,  I'm 
sideways in the C but just zipping along in the 912. 
 
Now, in 1969, the wheelbase got longer and wider to accomodate the 6 cylinder 
911. These early 911's(pre 69) were also a blast to drive but you had to get a 
little track experience before you got any good at keeping the car facing the 
direction you wanted to go. IMHO, the pre 69 912 was about as well balanced a 
car as one could find,  no need to change it.  The 69 912 lacks quick steering 
and is a heavier car.  It feels better in 911 form then 912. I drove several 
before I got the 68 and was really disappointed. 
 
Now, any of the early cars (65-68) are fine.  The 68 had a smog pump and yes 
it did cause some problems but it's no longer availble and is exempt from smog 
regs even here in Calif.  No pump-no problem! 
 
Parts cheaper in the later models?  Don't know about that but the later car is 
a WHOLE DIFFERENT CAR.   The difference in parts availabilty may be a factor 
but I've had no problem finding parts, new and used.  Also, you can buy a real 
nice, unrusty car in good shape here in Calif. for around 5K. 
 
76 912E?  Don't bother.  From all I've seen of them they don't do anything 
well.  Driving characteristics?  From "Porsche Sport, 1976/77, Joe Rusz blamed 
the 912E's poor handling on overly soft suspension settings and inadequate 
front roll bar size commenting "...there is a noncommittal feel which is 
perfectly acceptable for the non enthusiast driver.  Perhaps that what Porshce 
had in mind when it designed such an indistinct performer".....From previously 
quoted Excellence article "  The car that Porsche had originally devised as an 
amalgamation of the 356 and the 911 had grown flaccid in its 1976 incarnation." 
 
 I focus on driving characteristics in my response because to me, that's what 
Pcars are all about.  There you go....... 
 
Ted Smith

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 12:48:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Belts Lasting the Life of the Engine



On Fri, 21 Oct 1994 THOXNER@ualr.edu wrote:

> Chris was surprised to hear that the 944 timing belt is claimed to last the
> life of the engine. This is true, because when the life of the belt ends, so
> does the life of the engine. So the belt lasts as long as the engine, however,
> this may be only 30-40,000 miles. :-).
> Tom Oxner
> 
Ha-ha.. No, actually I was skeptical about Morgan's claim but doubt he 
made it in jest in his 'serious' book. Don't get me wrong, I would never 
leave the belts in forever. I know Peter Morgan has written other Porsche 
books on 911's etc. but his statement about the 944 cam belt causes me to 
question his technical competence.

Chris
'86 944

- ------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 94 14:54:45 CDT
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: Re: SOS (944's and mine)

>           Took my 944 (88K miles)to the shop yesterday to check the cam 
>           housing leak. They have recomended the following: 
...

>           -  Change power steering hose and 
>              fix pump leak.                     ----  $115 

...

phew - thats a lot of stuff! It sure sounds a bit suspicious to me. Have
you tried calling the BBB about this shop?

About the power steering - mine was leaking slightly, and I found that it
was just seeping from where the hose attaches to the underside of the
reservior. There is a hose clamp there, but apparently the hose can
harden. I just bought another clamp from Home Depot and put it on above
the old one, so there are now two clamps on. That fixed my leak. That may
be worth a try, especially if the hose appears to have fluid on it.

Jeff

***	Jeff Holt  Advanced Graphics Systems Design  (205) 730-6098     ***
***	jjholt@ingr.com                               FAX  730-6011     ***

Date: Wed, 19 Oct 1994 19:46:34 -0400

Subject: 914 Idle

Hi,
I had a high idle on my 914. just happend one day. Solution I knocked a
vaccum hose off of the distributor. The small one I think. Hooked it back
up and idle went to 850 rpms. Good luck
Nick

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 17:33:19 -0400
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: no longer mute!!and 914 stuff

Hi everyone,
Now I think the admins here and at tta.com have figured out how to get us
talking again I will!!
First off The P-car and the Girlfriend had a wonderful trip to western
Maryland. Twisty montain roads. I had a blast with the car. Leaves changing
corners changing speeds change in short change is good. On this trip the
speedo cable broke. Anyone got one for sale. I also need a rain tray. I
think Mike Willis is going to sell me the heater control valve I need. Now
some old messages that bounced back.


Hi everyone,
Now that it is getting cold I have noticed or rather my passengers have
noticed that there is no heat on the right side of the 914 (if it above 40
degrees and dry the top is off). So far I have checked the heater contol
valves and both open and close when I move the switch between the seats.
When the fan is on and the car is off on the left side of the car air is
being blown out in the car but the right side gets nothing. The fresh air
fan works on both sides. under the car it feels like air is coming out of
the heat exchangers near where the engine cool fan is (this is still with
engine off heater fan on). there is no air flow anywhere else on the left
side of the car. Nothing at the heater valve their at all. In addition for
some reason the dealer unplugged the heater fan and now if it is plugged in
it runs all the time. I have three wires. two go into the plug and the
third is dangling from the ground on the left side of the car. If I touch
the ground to the wires in the plug the fan turns on and off. Were is the
ground wire suppose to go so the switch in the car does this?


Exhaust noise. I love it!!!! I know this is an old thread but I have to get
my two cents in. The 914 with monza exaust sounds great to me. The day this
thread broke out I started the car up in front of a crackfinder oops I mean
pathfinder and its alarm went off! In parking garges cars with alarms will
anounce my arival by sounding their alarms. I love the way people turn to
look at my noisy little beast. There are  a few frowns, but most people
smile and give me a big thumbs up. I  went the vintage car races in philly
and the cars were loud and that was half the fun. In fact the M3 that went
around the track at high speeds were boring. No sound except for tire
squeel. A PORSHE is a a sensory joy. The more sensory feed back the better!
Loud exaust steering wheel that talks to your hands about what the road is
doing in relation to the tires and pedals that give feedback on what they
are opening or closing. The joy of a porsche is it includes all the senses
in driving. A loud exaust is just helping a sense join in the fun.
Nick

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 15:43:54 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Bauman's Great Adventure



Hi there folks .....

I just returned from a short vacation in the U.K., and
had a really cool experience, that while not *exactly*
Porsche related, is close enough!  

The airfield my dad flew from during WWII is now a
race track (Castle Combe). So, I pulled in to the
pit area which is adjacent to a small sideroad.
The gate was open, and there was some activity
on the track.  The activity, as it turned out, was
the boys from McClaren with two of their million dollar
road cars -- the 220 mph F1.  I had a nice talk with
them, drooled a lot, took a few pix, admired the 400 kph
speedo and the 600 HP + engine, and watched as the
McClaren helicopter came in and landed next to my rental
car.  I was slightly in awe of the whole scene!

Then, in London, I attemted to visit Ben Evans
at his fortress office next to Victoria Station
in London. Ben was on holiday!! Thanks Ben!!! I suppose
next time I should tell you I'm coming your way!! (-B

Jim Bauman
Back in the US, back in the US, back in the US
with my '86 Cab thank god!! 

PS: I saw an ad in one of the London papers for the 993
tiptronic...they were noting the fact that the transmission
is controlled with push buttons on the steering wheel
(like the F1 cars).... THAT would take some getting used
to. It was bad enough having to shift with my left hand,
negotiate roundabouts the wrong way, drive on the wrong
side of the road, watch for pedestrians on humped zebra
crossings, keep my headlights dipped, and wonder what the heck
a stretch of motorway without cats eyes was! But, the Guiness
was great!

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 01:32:24 -0700
From: "Timothy E. Wilson" <wilsont@python.CS.ORST.EDU>
Subject: 944 cooling system woes.


(my mail from rahul.net bounces, soooo...)

Okay, something wierd is going on with my 85 944.

a few weeks ago:

my temp gauge would stay pegged in the center (as it should) but at stop lights 
and such, the temp gauge would rise to the caution zone. My big fan wouldn't
come on though.
(rec.autos and this list told me to change the sensor)

last week:
Well, I was broke, and I wanted to fix my other problem, I had some gunk in the
system, so I got some coolant system cleaner and followed the directions.

Lo and behold, my gauges and fans all came on fine and everything worked great.

This week: my coolant leaks like crazy if I stop my car after driving it.
i have to keep putting water in every time I start my car. :(
Also, my fans stay on almost constantly, anyone got tips on wehre to start?

I know I should look for the leak (duh), but I think its at the top of the
radiator on one of the hoses, unfourtunately, this is also the hardest spot 
to look at.

Also, i want to replace my coolant resevoir, any prices for those?

Thanks alot!

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 10:08:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 914 Tires

206/60-15's are standard here. There isn't much clearance in the rear on 
either side, and the fronts will just barely rub the inner side if you 
turn as far as the steering will allow.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 10:18:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Motor vs. Engine?

As an electrical engineer and a bit of a purest prude, I've always tried 
to make the "proper" differentiation. A motor converts electrical energy 
to kinetic energy (mechanical rotation), while an engine is generally 
considered to be non-electrical (there are many types!)

However, I've given up since just about everyone uses the term "motor" 
to refer to an automobile engine. Might (and mass) make right. So call an 
engine a motor, everybody else does.  

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 11:57:12 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?

>>
>>  Well I've been thinking of buying a 928S ('84-'87) for a while now and
>>I think I may finally have convinced myself to do it.  So...
>>
>>  What sort of problems/maintenance issues have people seen with th 928?  I
>> (BTW, I'm thinking of going with an automatic).
>>
I've had an '84 928S for about 18 months - parked it during Jan - March,
since the roads around here are pure salt, and not every bit on the car
is aluminum or galvanized (though most are).

Let's see - timing belts at 45 or 50K miles. I had mine start to make an
audible slapping noise at around 52K - tensioner was at the end of its
travel - drove it slowly and cautiously to the mechanic who replaced all
the belts for about $600. Certainly could be done yourself for the cost
of the belts.

Replaced the clutch master and slave cylinders - about $70 each from Zims.
Master cylinder is buried, so it takes a few hours. Slave cylinder is
easy.

I've had a few electrical gremlins, which seems to be a common complaint.
Mine have been in the antenna, the heating control panel, the inside
temperature sensor, one door's alarm keyswitch,...  Nothing disabling,
just annoying.

The only other complaint at the moment is very weak to non-existent
synchronizers on 1st and 2nd, and a bit of a growl from the trans-
axle which I am pretending not to hear.

I am still terrifically pleased with the car. No way on earth could
I have found a new car for twice the price which would have pleased
me as much. I think that the automatic is reasonable, especially if
you are going to be in traffic a lot - apparently the majority of
US cars were automatic, and it's only a bit slower, according to the
figures in the owner's manual.

Handling in bad weather is really a tire question - the car has 50/50
front/rear weight distribution, so it is different from cars which
have the majority of their weight at one end or the other. Mine has
Pirelli P7's - frowned upon by the list - which for my purposes are
OK in the dry and wet, but pretty hopeless in snow. Porsche
recommends skinnier tires and wheels for winter driving.

Looking forward to see what other responses you get...

 -John White-


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 12:21:37 -0400

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 16:04:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Loelle S Poneleit" <poneleit@student.msu.edu>
Subject: 911 engine upgrades

I will be moving to Denver CO. in a month. I am looking forward to moving but I
think it will cause some problems with my 911. I have a 78SC and I will
have to pass smog inspection to get new plates in CO. My problem is that i
currently do not have any of the original injection or exhaust. I replaced the
heat exchangers with SSI and replaced the CIS injection with Carrera electronic
manifolds and injectors, all run with a L-jetronic injection computer from a
Nissan(i had planed to go with programable cumputer in future but smog
inspection has changed plans).
I have a couple options 1) buy all the injection and smog parts to pass
inspection 2) sell the engine and buy a 3.2l 3) trade my engine and trans with
a friend who has a 79 3.3l turbo engine and trans.( with engine apart). I
would like to go with the turbo engine as it is the most bang for the
buck(friend has theft recovery turbo, likes looks but doesnt care much about
speed and looking at high cost of putting engine together). I think the
3.2l would not have any more power at 6000ft than i have now(at close to sea
level). I will do all the work myself and have a good idea of what it will cost
to but 3.3l back together(rebuilt my 3.0l this winter). What problems will I
find in putting 3.3l turbo in SC or 3.0l in turbo? What other options might i
have (would like more power, must pass smog dyno testing in95)? any ideas
appreciated.


John C. Haley

78 SC turbolook slantnose (maybe turbo power in future!)

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 94 17:31:23 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Servicing

Hi, Nathan,                                                                  
  
> I have heard alot about Porsche owners buying parts through discount houses.
>  Who installs these parts?   Can I as an owner simply take the appropriate
> parts to a mechanic and have him install them, thus avoiding the high mark-up
> at a dealership?  It seems like improper etiquette.

Yes, definitely improper etiquette.  Better approach is to buy the parts
cheaply and install them yourself.  Also a cheaper approach.

Keep in mind that the Porsche mechanic, whether he be a dealer or an
independent, is in business to MAKE MONEY!

He not only makes money on labor, but on parts markups...
He takes your money and does what he thinks is an adequate job on your car.

With a little bit of knowledge of basic mechanics, a few special tools, and
mostly non-special tools, some time, and a willingness to get your hands
dirty and learn something, anybody can fix a Porsche.

Also, if you haven't heard my rantings before, join the Porsche Club...for
36 bucks (roughly what mechanics around here get for one half hour's labor)
you get access to experts and porschephiles around the country and around
your own neighborhood.

Keep your money. Strike a blow for frugality. DO IT YOURSELF!

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Sat, 22 Oct 1994 19:41:19 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: 10" wheels for 951/Brembo parts

Has anyone tried to fit 10" x 17" wheels on the rear of an 89 944T. Since I
race in the stock class I am allowed to go one size up, wheel wise. I would
like to use 315mm tires on these wheels and also I would like to do this
without altering the bodywork in any way, which is a definite no no in the
stock classes. 
If anyone has done this and knows a reasonable source of wheels please let me
know.
Also I am still searching for a source for brake piston dust covers for this
car. They are Brembos and apparently are made of unobtanium since no one will
sell me the proper parts. They only come in a complete caliper rebuild kit
which includes the piston, the seals, and the dust cover. The price of the
kit is about $50 and you need 4 kits per caliper. Even my simple math tells
me this is ridiculous. Any help or suggestions will, of course, be
appreciated and thank you to the people who are already trying to help.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 00:20:35 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 Servicing

>Also, is there anyone out there in the Milwaukee metro area with advice
>regarding a good Porsche mechanic/dealer.  I've owned a Porsche before and
>I'm sure I will have a frequent relationship with some mechanic, so I'm
>trying to prepare before a crisis.

Hi Nathan,

        I live in the Milwaukee area (actually Burlington WI. - aka "Hick
Town") and have used Capitol Import autos up on Brown Deere Rd. from time
to time. Although I don't have a personal relationship with any of the
mechanics there (I do most of my own work - so I rarely need to go to the
dealer) they have always done good work.

        A better alternative is a Porsche mechanic by the name of Frank
Collins who works at Motor Werks in Barrington, Illinois. Although this
would be a little bit of a drive for you, Frank does excellent work, and
you can bring your discount parts to him and he will install them at his
house (he does a lot of work out of his house, but I don't know how common
knowledge that is around Motor Werks, so if you call him there, I wouldn't
mention his home deal until you speak with him directly - in private). He
is a very busy guy, so if you're in a crunch situation, this may not be the
best, 'cause he usually can't do what you want right away. But if you can
wait until he can do it, you can save substantial money. I don't know if
he'd want me to publish his home number on the net, but if you are
interested in contacting him I could e-mail his number to you after asking
him if it's okay.

        You could also just have the work done at Motor Werks, and request
that you want Frank to do the work. Motor Werks is a very reputable outfit,
and of course, an Auth. Porsche dealer. They are expensive (as is any
dealer), but they are quite a bit cheaper than say, Lynch Porsche in
Chicago.

        Finally, I do agree with George that the best way to do the work is
yourself. The 944 isn't really that hard to work on, and you don't really
need to buy many special tools to do most things. I got my "Baptism of
Fire" a few years ago with my first p-car, a '79 924 euro. What a great car
!!! It was so easy to work on, it was great. The 944 is a little more
complex, but hey, start slowly, build your knowledge with things like this
list (and Jim Pasha's very cool articles in Excellence), and you will get a
feel for working on the car.

        Remember, no mechanic, no matter how good, will do as good a job on
your car as you. I don't mean that the mecanics don't do a good job, most
of them do (at least the ones working in Porsche shops). But hey, let's
face it, when you're working on something that's your own (as opposed to
someone else's), then you're going to do a better job.

        I hope this helps you out. Let me know if you have any questions
about your car, I will try to help as much as possible. It's nice to a
fellow Cheese-head on P-files !!!


regards,
trev.

- ---------------------------------------------------
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer
(A Music Industry Professional -- Ha !!!)

'84 Porsche 944 (Red)
'93 Feline unit ("Corvette")
'94 Child Unit (almost two months old !!!)

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 94 10:53:52 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re:  Bauman's Great Adventure


Hi Jim and Philes...

| The airfield my dad flew from during WWII is now a
| race track (Castle Combe). So, I pulled in to the
| pit area which is adjacent to a small sideroad.
| The gate was open, and there was some activity
| on the track.  The activity, as it turned out, was
| the boys from McClaren with two of their million dollar
| road cars -- the 220 mph F1. 

For reasons that remain mysterious, the UK is a large centre
for the development of race car technology of various forms,
almost all the F1 teams are based in the South of England,
ditto engine development, chassis development, chassis and
engines for Indy etc etc. There is often testing going on 
at the tracks, but usually you can't get in.

| Then, in London, I attemted to visit Ben Evans
| at his fortress office next to Victoria Station
| in London. Ben was on holiday!!

| Jim Bauman

Ahh... Stalag Luft IV, yes I'm out on parole at the moment,
but if I am not back by Monday they will be after me with
the company attack dog team, in order to round me back up
and nail me to my comouter for another year..... Oh yea..
come and get me copper, you'll never take me alive!!!!, 
On top of the world Ma... 
etc..etc


Regards


Ben

I personally like the look of the SWB cars ('66-'68). Sure, some of the parts
are more expensive, but they've got a look about them...maybe it's an
acquired taste. If you want to add flares or do the '73 RS thing you should
definitely buy a '69 (with a SWB you could make it look like the unbelievably
cool 911R). If you want a car that just screams '60's buy a SWB. 

 Rich Lambert

Date: 23 Oct 94 14:44:30 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?

A  few thoughts after 2 years of '86 928 ownership (in So Cal.):

The years mentioned (84-87) cover what is arguably the most important transition
in the 928's life: the change with the '85 model to the 4-cam engine.  This is
an important issue because with the 4-cam engine (on the plus side) you get a
whole bunch more power (like well over 50 hp), while on the minus side, due to
piston/valve clearance issues, a broken timing belt's could cost you $4,000+.
This makes timing belt maintenance a Very Big Deal.  As I understand it, the
2-cam US models will simply quit running and your out one belt.  I believe that
Euro 2-cam models will eat valves under these circumstances as well, but at
least there are half as many to replace.

The '87 model ("S4") is in a way the "culturally" more important transition,
since it has a (I think undeserved) reputation for being the year of most
significant improvements in the car.  It is the first year of the only
significant restyling the car got, along with an improved induction system
(which by the way makes the engine *much* easier to work on), electric rather
than belt-drive fan (another work reducer), improved aerodynamics (who cares?),
a better clutch, but not much else that I recall.  I think a good '87 can be had
for very low twenties, where an '85 or '86 should go for about $15-17K.  If I
had it to do over again, I would hold out for an '87, mostly because of the
engine-maintenance issue and the clutch.  I'm lucky enough to have a 5-speed
which I would recommend just because it's more fun, but they are hard to find
representing 20% or less of the US population.

Bruce Anderson's series on purchasing used Porsches in "Excellence" magazine are
must reading here.

My main caution to the prospective owner is go in with your eyes open regarding
parts cost and maintenance requirements. There are many, many 4-digit priced
parts in the car, and they are all packed into the car very tightly, making what
on other cars would be simple operations very time-consuming (John's reference
to the clutch master cylinder being an example).  So, thorough pre-purchase
inspection is absolutely critical here, and availability of a complete
maintenance record is even more desirable than usual.

On the other hand, when it's running right, it's the epitome of effortless and
composed high-speed travel over any paved terrain.  And there's no sensation
quite like the muted bellow the 4-cam V-8 makes in a head-long rush for the
horizon.

Alan Watkins ('86 928)


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 11:43:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Servicing


On Sat, 22 Oct 1994, George Beuselinck wrote: > Yes, definitely improper
etiquette.  Better approach is to buy the parts > cheaply and install them
yourself.  Also a cheaper approach. > Keep in mind that the Porsche
mechanic, whether he be a dealer or an > independent, is in business to
MAKE MONEY! > I've tried to do as much as I can on my 944 such as removing
the rad to have it checked, but if you're in Canada and you don't put a
lot of mileage on the car, it just isn't cost-effective to buy the
necessary Porsche tools sometimes. For example, on the advice given on
this list, I ordered a Pirelli cam belt from Automotion for $17 US. My
total cost is (parts+shipping)*1.3=$29 cdn + duty $1 + tax $2 + Customs
handling fee $5 = $37 cdn. The dealer charges $74 cdn for this and its not
even Pirelli. Dealer price for balance belt: $192 (Ack!). 
 
Now the belt tensioning tool..The cheapest I've seen is $360 US = $490 
cdn + $18 duty +  $36 tax + $5 customs = $550 cdn not inclu. shipping!
 
The dealer charges $80/hr and quoted a 2 hr job for the belts which works 
out to about 3 to 4 belt changes to break even or 21 yrs given what I 
drive in a year.

I checked and my dealer has no problem with me supplying my own parts. 
The only caveat is they would not warranty the belt (big deal). At least 
the job will be done correctly (I hope). In the past, I've successfully 
replaced the head on my BMW, but on my 944 for certain jobs, I'd just as 
well have the dealer do it, if not for peace of mind.
 
Chris
'86 944 

ps. For us Canadian readers, it would be nice to see km or mi whenever 
quoting mileage in future posts.

Date: 23 Oct 94 14:44:34 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: 928 Alarm keyswitch problem


In John White's response to "Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?" he mentions
having a problem with one door's alarm keyswitch.  I was just wondering if your
problem resembled my problem.  Namely, every once in a while (like once a
month), under a very specific usage pattern, the alarm will go off when I unlock
and open the driver's door.  The particular usage pattern is that I start the
car from cold in the morning, drive it somewhere for lunch, leave it parked
*uncovered* (it's black, BTW) in the sun (normally it's under a car cover when
parked out doors) for about an hour, and then unlock it.  All I can surmise from
this is that either the alarm "brain" is nuts, or the driver-side alarm switch
closure that is supposed to disarm the alarm brain never arrives, but only under
this particular temparature-over-time profile.

I'd appreciate any hints anyone might have.  My next move will probably be to
swap the alarm brain ($125 new), but I really hate black-magic debugging like
that.  Especially when I have to wait an unkowable amount of time to determine
if I fixed it!

I guess I could attack the "intermittent alarm switch" theory by wiring up a
buzzer or light to go if it is ever the case that the "unlock door" signal is
present when the "disarm alarm" signal is not.  At least then I'd know if it's
the brain's fault.

Thanks,

Alan Watkins.

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 16:36:15 -0400
From: FASTRON@aol.com
Subject: Fwd: Re: 951 turbo failure/pr...


- ---------------------
Forwarded message:
Subj:    Re: 951 turbo failure/problems
Date:    94-10-21 20:29:28 EDT
From:    FASTRON

To:      jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com(jimgregory)

The extended turbo life in a 951 is aided by the water cooled bearing
housing.  The housing is fed by a small pump which have been known to leak
and have intermittent failures.  Make sure your pump is OK or you'll need
another turbo
FASTRON@AOL.COOM
2 1986 Turbos one track the other a spare

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 15:22:16 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: passing emissions - a couple more ideas



In addition to Mike's list, here are a couple of other
things I found to help:

    Clean or preferably replace the spark plugs the
    night before you test.

    Pick a warm day, and make sure your car is FULLY
    warmed up when you test (at least 180 degrees)

    On MFI cars, the hose from the left heat exchanger
    to the warm-up regulator must be connected and in
    good condition.

    Pick a time of day when you don't have to wait in
    line if possible.

    Be curteous and polite, so that if you're borderline
    they'll give you a break. - Remember, they will start
    out assuming you're a jerk unless you prove them wrong.
    (also applies to police)

Using the above guidelines and some of Mike's before I 
rebuilt my engine, I sailed through emissions checks 4
years in a row. (the first year I went in with stone guards
over my non-compliant H4's, track-type near slicks and an
attitude) I reeducated myself after getting tired of 
retesting that first year.


 - Reid



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 14:53:33 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: motor vs engine

Mike asks-

>What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?
>i.e. in definition and in popular usage.

Generally, an engine always has pistons but a motor
can be electric, gas or whatever.

I've always seen the distinction as regional / cultural.

But, drivers that race in circles always have *motors* - 
wherever they race.

         ********************************

Seen on the toolbox of a pickup the other day (with a motor)

   "Anything with tits or wheels is trouble"


 - Reid

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 22:26:35 -0400
From: NotWise@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Prejudice



I was pulled over yesterday at 1:00 am for driving through a red turn signal
light (I know.. I shouldn't  have)

A cop pulls me over, very upset and tells me that just because I own a
Porsche doesn't mean I own the !@#&^*%$ road.  Now where did he come off
saying that?   I seriously think that our cars have an extremely unfavorable
bias with the police.

I was driving on the 80-90 toll road in Ohio today and the buddy who was with
me remarked at how many people were speeding.  I asked him who the cop would
pull over if everyone were breaking the law.  He stated, quite bluntly, that
I would surely be pulled over first, because a car like mine would obviously
be speeding.   That's pathetic...

"Automotively Challenged"  NotWise

'84 Blk/Blk 911 Carrera

Hi, Clark.
 
PA:
>Drag racers are able to shift without taking their foot off the throttle

Just as not all sports cars have semi-automatics like Formula One cars,
not all drag racers have automatic transmissions. Top fuelers and funny cars
aren't the only classes in drag racing.
 
Pete

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 23:42:51 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: 944 Pwr Steering Groans When Cold...

A small question re. the power steering on my '84 944:


When the weather starts to get colder out (like below 50, the way it is
here in Wisconsin), the power steering groans when the car is cold. It only
groans when I turn the wheels and the car is moving slowly or is at rest.
As soon as the car gets even *slightly* warmed up, the groans go away.
There is the proper amount of fluid in the pwr steering reservoir (as a
matter of fact, the system has lost almost no fluid in the last year ...)

So hey, any new wisdom on this would be welcomed. The car has been like
this for some time (it did it last winter - yes I do drive my 944 in the
snow, 'cause it's the *only* car I own), but this only happens during the
colder months. Is there a problem here, or is this normal for the power
steering to groan when it's cold out and the car is still cold ...

Thanks in advance ...

trev.

Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 14:57:08 +0300
From: Kari Eloranta <eloranta@lammio.hut.fi>
Subject: Re:  Porsches and doing science

I second the motion by Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com> and  
john@pelican.HAC.COM that observatories must be existing because of  
Porsches. While in the States I visited a few of them and in  
particular the road to Mt. Hamilton turned to a bad addiction. Very  
few campers or bicyclists around so I didn't feel like risking  
others. Motorcyclists were sometimes a problem, but cannot really  
complain since even if they would slow down one couldn't catch them  
on four wheels. Actually I wonder how many of them are in the gorges  
there (or in the Pacific off Hwy-1)...

The astronomers probably don't like rides to their citadel too much.  
The noise breaking a good days sleep and the dust messing up the  
night ;)

Cheers,

Kari

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 08:35:42 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Alarm keyswitch problem

My alarm problem is pretty simple - the driver's side door lock neither
arms nor disarms the alarm, and the passenger's side and hatch locks
do. Took me a week or two to figure out what was going on, though.
Every once in a while I would unlock the car, same as any other time,
and the alarm would go off - it finally dawned on me that it only
happened when I had locked it on the passenger's side. I just assume
that the problem is in the switch, since it isn't aggravating enough
to start pulling the door apart - yet.

One question about your problem - how do you turn the alarm off, once
it is triggered? Just twist the key in the driver's side door again,
or in a different lock, or ...? You could try always unlocking the
car on the passenger's side whenever the appropriate circumstances
arise - if it never fails it would tend to implicate the door switch
and its associated wiring. All it would take is an intermittent
connection in the wiring, which is the kind of thing your temperature
cycling would bring out.

Maybe you could just put an LED on the "disarm alarm" signal, and mount
it someplace visible from outside the car. I don't even know whether
it gets grounded or +12v to signal activation, but that should be
(somewhat) apparent from the schematic. My guess is that the black
box is a fairly unlikely culprit - my other guess is that your guess
is the same, but it's the easiest thing to try, so why not?

Keep us posted on your progress, since it is probably only a matter of
time before the rest of the 928 owners have the same problem.

 -John White-
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 09:03:47 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Beer of choice for Porschephiles

My beer of choice is brewed right here in newark...at 373 W chestnut,
in my kitchen!

People always complain making beer is too expensive/time
consuming/etc.

Here's the deal:

1 hours effort -> 4 cases of pints, any kind you want, $8-10 per case.
Startup cost - $40 includes ingredients for first brew, frementing
bins, lids, bubblers, siphon, capper, etc.

Details below:




Here's the entire process

1) Heat up can of goo in saucepan (so it thins) with lid on
2) Dump out water in saucepan and put in 1 quart
3) Dump goo into saucepan.
4) Heat to boil
5) Fill "Fermenter" (pickle bucket) 3/4 full with cold water
6) Pour saucepan contents into fermenter (bucket "A")
7) Add enough water to fermenter to make 48 pints (5 gallons).   If
you're smart, you'll take 5 mikjugs of water and fill it up first, make
a permanent mark, then you never have to measure again!
8) Sprinkle yeast over mixture.
9) Cover for 1 week until "bubbler" stops
10) Siphon into bucket "B" taking care nbot to siphon ueast at bottom
11) Mix 1 cup "priming sugar" with fermented mixture
12) Bottle using capper and supplied caps, along with any returnable
 bottles from beer distributor.
13) Wait specified time (I always wait 6 weeks)

Yeild: 48 pints.  It's timewise efficient toi double batch it, i.e.
make 2 buckets full, which means you'll have to invest $9 in a second
bucket, lid, and bubbler top.

BUT - it's better than ANYTHING

Kunstharzlack

1411-L

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 10:15:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 944 Servicing

> I have heard alot about Porsche owners buying parts through discount houses.
>  Who installs these parts?   Can I as an owner simply take the appropriate
> parts to a mechanic and have him install them, thus avoiding the high mark-up
> at a dealership?  It seems like improper etiquette.

Minor Dissertation on How Shops Work, Part 1:

When you take your car to the shop, your bill comes in four
parts: labor, parts, shop materials, and tax.

Labor: for "routine" jobs, you're typically charged the shop hourly
rate times the "flat rate manual" hours for that job. Sometimes you
win, if you have a particularly difficult car (i.e. parts rusted
frozen, etc.), sometimes the shop wins if the tech can do the work 
faster than the manual says. For "wierd stuff" and debugging type
things (like chasing wiring problems in a  356 for instance), you're
charged by the hour of real time.

Parts: you're typically charged the "suggested retail" from the *supplier*
that the shop uses. The shop typically gets 10-25% off as a shop, with the
expectation that they'll make some money on selling the parts to you. In
reality, the 10-25% *just about* covers the costs of keeping  and
managing inventory, shipping costs, and the costs of ordering (either
paying for a parts person or taking time off of "other jobs" in a one
man shop). This is not a profit center in most shops!

Shop materials: in the Old Days, this never ever showed up on a bill -- this
was part of the overhead of the shop. It's still part of the overhead,
but in an effort to hold shop hourly rates down, some shops started charging
directly for "materials" -- hand cleaner, parts washer solvent, etc -- 
on a small-percentage-of-net-cost basis.

Tax: you know all about this...

Anyway, the shop is paying the tech something per hour or per job but less
than the shop hourly rate for sure, is paying less for the parts that it's 
selling them for, and may be recovering some money from materials charges.
So, in theory, for every job they bring in more money than it costs them
in "direct costs". AH hah!!! Yoy say... Profit!!!!

Not so fast.... out of this "profit", they have to cover the rent, utitlies, 
the admin overhead (accounting, taxes, front office costs), buy new tools,
pay up front for inventory they may resell later (maybe a *LOT* later),
and "eat" mistakes and other rework. They also have to pay for advertising,
for other cost-of-sales items like those little promotional keychains and
stuff. They must cover their portion of payroll taxes, and pay the hidden
taxes like state and federal unemployment tax, workmans's comp, insurance,
and other things. On top of this all, they have to pay environmental
fees and use taxes, they typically pay tax on the total value of the 
business (the tools, inventory, etc) as well as income taxes on the
business income.

Then they *MAY* have a profit. Most likely they have a  huge pile of paper
and the owner is left sitting with his head in his hands going "Plumber....
I should have been a plumber...."

To add to their grief and agony, they have "good customers" coming by
asking for discounts off the shop rate, "deals" on parts, or to really
add insult to injury, customers that want to supply their own parts.
That's a bigger problem  than it sounds like, because in addition to the
fact that the shop is now losing money on this job, there's a VERY good
chance that the parts will either be wrong (because they were misordered
or mis-shipped) or that there will be additional parts needed that will
either piss off the customer ("well, I could have gotten them for you")
or cause delays, taking up space in the shop with a car that's unnecessarily
waiting on parts.

The exception to this is if the shop either asks you to provide the
part, or says "well, I'll install it if you bring it in." By the way,
that latter phrase is a *CLEAR* clue that maybe you're asking them to
do something stupid.... Just an FYI, you know?

Bottom line: "good customers" don't bring their own parts. They don't
ask for discounts. If they like the service, they send other people to the
shop. If they're smart, they make sure the shop owner knows about it. 
If *HE'S* smart, he then "takes care of you" by doing small things at
not charge or passing on discounts that he can or doing other things to
retain your trust and keep you coming back and sending more customers to
him. In return for this, you can expect to get the work done on your car
the way you want it done, to have it done right and in a timely manner,
and to get answers for any questions you may have. 

If you don't get what you're expecting, you will probably find another
shop. If you don't behave like the shop owner needs you to, he probably
won't ask you to go elsewhere. Just another inequality to think about.

Stan

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 08:35:00 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: Re: ca smog checks

     This  past spring the Cal. smog test cutoff was '65/'66  for
everything.    Think  of  it  this  way.   356's  don't   require
inspection  of any kind (a pleasant surprise when registering the
new  '65  SC),  911's  do.   These  cutoff  dates  have   changed
occasionally.  I once was required to have a '63 Falcon inspected
for an aftermarket PCV device.  That would no longer be required.

     I've  also  found  the  inspectors  getting  stickier  about
operation  of  the various devices.  I've a '78 Jeep,  which  has
always passed the sniffer test (had it for 10 years).  This year,
I  was  forced to replace a non-functional EGR.  This EGR  hasn't
worked  for  10  years.  In the past, they  mentioned  it  was'nt
working,  but gave me the certificate because the emissions  were
OK.   This  year  I  went to three places, all of  who  spent  20
minutes  or  so  checking things, verifying  the  emissions  were
within  spec.,  then  refused  the certificate  (and  my  $12.95)
because  the EGR wasn't working.  Finally, I bought another,  got
the  certificate,  and  re- installed the old  one  (because  the
driveability with the new one was terrrible).

     The  moral  here  is that things continue to  change.   Smog
compliance is a moving target.

- --   Bob



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 8:38:46 PDT
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Fuel Pressure Sender

> 
> Does anyone have a good source for a reasonably priced fuel injection
> pressure gauge with fittings? I need to test the fuel pressure on my '85 911.
> It's checked via a test fitting on the fuel rail.
> 

Consider using a standard oil pressure sender, and wiring it into your
oil pressure gauge.  Then you can check fuel pressure on the road, watch
the warmup regulator operate... oops, you're Motronic.  Not sure how
useful this will be to you; is system pressure as informative as it is
with CIS?

On my '83 I got a duplicate oil pressure sender (it's a generic VDO
part) and a brass adapter tee and mounted the sender in the fuel line at
the warmup pressure regulator.  Then I ran the wire up to the dash (the
only messy part of the job... run several wires while you're at it),
and ran it and the original oil pressure wire thru a selector switch and
thence to the oil pressure gauge.  For CIS troubleshooting this is handy
as you can check things out on the road without hassle, and anytime
anything "funny" happens.  Warmup, leakdown, full throttle... all show
up in fuel pressure readings.

Let me know if you're interested, I can look up the part numbers and
other details.

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 94 10:53:52 GMT

Subject: Re:  Bauman's Great Adventure


Hi Jim and Philes...

| The airfield my dad flew from during WWII is now a
| race track (Castle Combe). So, I pulled in to the
| pit area which is adjacent to a small sideroad.
| The gate was open, and there was some activity
| on the track.  The activity, as it turned out, was
| the boys from McClaren with two of their million dollar
| road cars -- the 220 mph F1. 

For reasons that remain mysterious, the UK is a large centre
for the development of race car technology of various forms,
almost all the F1 teams are based in the South of England,
ditto engine development, chassis development, chassis and
engines for Indy etc etc. There is often testing going on 
at the tracks, but usually you can't get in.

| Then, in London, I attemted to visit Ben Evans
| at his fortress office next to Victoria Station
| in London. Ben was on holiday!!

| Jim Bauman

but if I am not back by Monday they will be after me with
the company attack dog team, in order to round me back up

come and get me copper, you'll never take me alive!!!!,

Date: 23 Oct 94 14:44:30 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?

A  few thoughts after 2 years of '86 928 ownership (in So Cal.):

The years mentioned (84-87) cover what is arguably the most important transition
in the 928's life: the change with the '85 model to the 4-cam engine.  This is
an important issue because with the 4-cam engine (on the plus side) you get a
whole bunch more power (like well over 50 hp), while on the minus side, due to
piston/valve clearance issues, a broken timing belt's could cost you $4,000+.
This makes timing belt maintenance a Very Big Deal.  As I understand it, the
2-cam US models will simply quit running and your out one belt.  I believe that
Euro 2-cam models will eat valves under these circumstances as well, but at
least there are half as many to replace.

The '87 model ("S4") is in a way the "culturally" more important transition,
since it has a (I think undeserved) reputation for being the year of most
significant improvements in the car.  It is the first year of the only
significant restyling the car got, along with an improved induction system
(which by the way makes the engine *much* easier to work on), electric rather
than belt-drive fan (another work reducer), improved aerodynamics (who cares?),
a better clutch, but not much else that I recall.  I think a good '87 can be had
for very low twenties, where an '85 or '86 should go for about $15-17K.  If I
had it to do over again, I would hold out for an '87, mostly because of the
engine-maintenance issue and the clutch.  I'm lucky enough to have a 5-speed
which I would recommend just because it's more fun, but they are hard to find
representing 20% or less of the US population.

Bruce Anderson's series on purchasing used Porsches in "Excellence" magazine are
must reading here.

My main caution to the prospective owner is go in with your eyes open regarding
parts cost and maintenance requirements. There are many, many 4-digit priced
parts in the car, and they are all packed into the car very tightly, making what
on other cars would be simple operations very time-consuming (John's reference
to the clutch master cylinder being an example).  So, thorough pre-purchase
inspection is absolutely critical here, and availability of a complete
maintenance record is even more desirable than usual.

On the other hand, when it's running right, it's the epitome of effortless and
composed high-speed travel over any paved terrain.  And there's no sensation
quite like the muted bellow the 4-cam V-8 makes in a head-long rush for the
horizon.

Alan Watkins ('86 928)


- ------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 11:43:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Servicing


On Sat, 22 Oct 1994, George Beuselinck wrote: > Yes, definitely improper
etiquette.  Better approach is to buy the parts > cheaply and install them
yourself.  Also a cheaper approach. > Keep in mind that the Porsche
mechanic, whether he be a dealer or an > independent, is in business to
MAKE MONEY! > I've tried to do as much as I can on my 944 such as removing
the rad to have it checked, but if you're in Canada and you don't put a
lot of mileage on the car, it just isn't cost-effective to buy the
necessary Porsche tools sometimes. For example, on the advice given on
this list, I ordered a Pirelli cam belt from Automotion for $17 US. My
total cost is (parts+shipping)*1.3=$29 cdn + duty $1 + tax $2 + Customs
handling fee $5 = $37 cdn. The dealer charges $74 cdn for this and its not
even Pirelli. Dealer price for balance belt: $192 (Ack!). 
 
Now the belt tensioning tool..The cheapest I've seen is $360 US = $490 
cdn + $18 duty +  $36 tax + $5 customs = $550 cdn not inclu. shipping!
 
The dealer charges $80/hr and quoted a 2 hr job for the belts which works 
out to about 3 to 4 belt changes to break even or 21 yrs given what I 
drive in a year.

I checked and my dealer has no problem with me supplying my own parts. 
The only caveat is they would not warranty the belt (big deal). At least 
the job will be done correctly (I hope). In the past, I've successfully 
replaced the head on my BMW, but on my 944 for certain jobs, I'd just as 
well have the dealer do it, if not for peace of mind.
 
Chris
'86 944 

ps. For us Canadian readers, it would be nice to see km or mi whenever 
quoting mileage in future posts.

- ------------------------------

Date: 23 Oct 94 14:44:34 EDT
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: 928 Alarm keyswitch problem


In John White's response to "Purchasing a 928, what to watch for?" he mentions
having a problem with one door's alarm keyswitch.  I was just wondering if your
problem resembled my problem.  Namely, every once in a while (like once a
month), under a very specific usage pattern, the alarm will go off when I unlock
and open the driver's door.  The particular usage pattern is that I start the
car from cold in the morning, drive it somewhere for lunch, leave it parked
*uncovered* (it's black, BTW) in the sun (normally it's under a car cover when
parked out doors) for about an hour, and then unlock it.  All I can surmise from
this is that either the alarm "brain" is nuts, or the driver-side alarm switch
closure that is supposed to disarm the alarm brain never arrives, but only under
this particular temparature-over-time profile.

I'd appreciate any hints anyone might have.  My next move will probably be to
swap the alarm brain ($125 new), but I really hate black-magic debugging like
that.  Especially when I have to wait an unkowable amount of time to determine
if I fixed it!

I guess I could attack the "intermittent alarm switch" theory by wiring up a
buzzer or light to go if it is ever the case that the "unlock door" signal is
present when the "disarm alarm" signal is not.  At least then I'd know if it's
the brain's fault.

Thanks,

Alan Watkins.

Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 16:36:15 -0400
From: FASTRON@aol.com
Subject: Fwd: Re: 951 turbo failure/pr...


 - ---------------------
Forwarded message:
Subj:    Re: 951 turbo failure/problems
Date:    94-10-21 20:29:28 EDT
From:    FASTRON

To:      jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com(jimgregory)

The extended turbo life in a 951 is aided by the water cooled bearing
housing.  The housing is fed by a small pump which have been known to leak
and have intermittent failures.  Make sure your pump is OK or you'll need
another turbo
FASTRON@AOL.COOM
2 1986 Turbos one track the other a spare

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 15:22:16 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: passing emissions - a couple more ideas



In addition to Mike's list, here are a couple of other
things I found to help:

    Clean or preferably replace the spark plugs the
    night before you test.

    Pick a warm day, and make sure your car is FULLY
    warmed up when you test (at least 180 degrees)

    On MFI cars, the hose from the left heat exchanger
    to the warm-up regulator must be connected and in
    good condition.

    Pick a time of day when you don't have to wait in
    line if possible.

    Be curteous and polite, so that if you're borderline
    they'll give you a break. - Remember, they will start
    out assuming you're a jerk unless you prove them wrong.
    (also applies to police)

Using the above guidelines and some of Mike's before I 
rebuilt my engine, I sailed through emissions checks 4
years in a row. (the first year I went in with stone guards
over my non-compliant H4's, track-type near slicks and an
attitude) I reeducated myself after getting tired of 
retesting that first year.


 - Reid



- ------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 14:53:33 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: motor vs engine

Mike asks-

>What is the difference between a Motor and an Engine?
>i.e. in definition and in popular usage.

Generally, an engine always has pistons but a motor
can be electric, gas or whatever.

I've always seen the distinction as regional / cultural.

But, drivers that race in circles always have *motors* - 
wherever they race.

         ********************************

Seen on the toolbox of a pickup the other day (with a motor)

   "Anything with tits or wheels is trouble"


 - Reid

I was pulled over yesterday at 1:00 am for driving through a red turn signal
light (I know.. I shouldn't  have)

Porsche doesn't mean I own the !@#&^*%$ road.  Now where did he come off
saying that?   I seriously think that our cars have an extremely unfavorable
bias with the police.

I was driving on the 80-90 toll road in Ohio today and the buddy who was with
me remarked at how many people were speeding.  I asked him who the cop would
pull over if everyone were breaking the law.  He stated, quite bluntly, that
I would surely be pulled over first, because a car like mine would obviously
be speeding.   That's pathetic...

"Automotively Challenged"  NotWise

Subject: 944 Pwr Steering Groans When Cold...

A small question re. the power steering on my '84 944:


When the weather starts to get colder out (like below 50, the way it is
here in Wisconsin), the power steering groans when the car is cold. It only
groans when I turn the wheels and the car is moving slowly or is at rest.
As soon as the car gets even *slightly* warmed up, the groans go away.
There is the proper amount of fluid in the pwr steering reservoir (as a
matter of fact, the system has lost almost no fluid in the last year ...)

So hey, any new wisdom on this would be welcomed. The car has been like
this for some time (it did it last winter - yes I do drive my 944 in the
snow, 'cause it's the *only* car I own), but this only happens during the
colder months. Is there a problem here, or is this normal for the power
steering to groan when it's cold out and the car is still cold ...

Thanks in advance ...

trev.

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 15:48:38 GMT
From: Richard Cole <colers@prl.philips.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Early 911 Chassis Plate:

Bill,

The plate you describe is the paint colour code.  The chassis plate is next
to the front lid locking mechanism.  The chassis number is also stamped into
the boot (trunk) floor on the left behind the fuel tank (looking from the
front of the car).

Richard

'72 911E

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 09:16:32 -0700
From: "Richard Vercillo" <rick@parsec.radiology.arizona.edu>
Subject: Re: Motor vs. Engine?

	Well, perhaps the mass has come full circle.  We sometimes
refer to the measurement of computational power of computers as
Horsepower and just as often we refer to the CPU and associated
firmware/software as a computational Engine.  Next we have a fan motor
sitting on top of the CPU to cool the device.  I just wonder if a 50/50
mix of anit-freeze and H2O will cool the Pentium better.

 >As an electrical engineer and a bit of a purest prude, I've always tried 
 >to make the "proper" differentiation. A motor converts electrical energy 
 >to kinetic energy (mechanical rotation), while an engine is generally 
 >considered to be non-electrical (there are many types!)
 >
 >However, I've given up since just about everyone uses the term "motor" 
 >to refer to an automobile engine. Might (and mass) make right. So call an 
 >engine a motor, everybody else does.  

Just Grins,
Rick Vercillo

dry).

have to remove the A-arms to lube the rubber bushings.  Am I correct?

Once I get in there, what grease should I use?

Thanks all,

Pete Gregory

A week or so back Stan wrote:

>In a more personal vein, I'll do things with the local BMW clubs (2 and 4
>wheel) and the SCCA (*NOT* autox though), but not with the local PCA
region.
>The BMW guys are a blast, and they're sooooo slow on the autox courses 8{)

>two years, at first opportunity I transferred my membership to NNJR
(another
>great region!!) and now that I'm back in TX, will transfer to Coastal Bend.
>Sure, it's a bit of a drive to Corpus Christi from Houston, but better than
>the alternative... Further, as they say, deponent sayeth not.

events of late, what with a move to/from New Jersey and all.  However I do
have to comment 'cause I think there are some folks that are working hard on
the LSR AX's as well as the High Speed Driver's Ed events (self included)
that this does a disservice to.  The crowd at both these LSR series has
changed in the last year and I think both groups are trying to steer clear
of the politics that were going on at the top (of the region).  I too moved
my membership back to my former region (Golden Gate) during the height of
the crap that was flying around in LSR.  I think that most of that has
stopped now and we decided to dual-member with LSR earlier this year.

I think the current LSR events are better than Stan remembers them from a
couple of years ago.  Both series are focused more on driver education and
the Autocross group is planning several AX schools next year.  I'd encourage
any Porsche owner in the Houston area to come out to our events -- we have
fun and we're fortunate to have some nationally top-rated solo drivers as
instructors at our AX events.

As far as the Beemer drivers being "soooo slow", we've got a few drivers
from the local BMWCCA that show up regularly, Stan, that are pretty good.
 Too bad you sold your "autocross weapon" or you could come out and show us
what you learned in New Jersey (big smile here)....

 -Scott Jessen

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:20:03 -0500
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Why engines lugg in low gear, other gear/engine limits

Hi all,

Back from a few days away from Porsche mail. Skimming through it I saw
Ben Evans' request for an explanation of why the engine "luggs" in low gear.
Hmmmmmm. Here is a simplified explanation. Any flamers, I am turning off your
pilot flames. I said, SIMPLIFIED. I can't draw figures very effectively using
ASCII only, and I don't want to write a textbook here. (I will also not be
drawn to a discussion like the one on N2 and H20 in tires...). The following
should suffice for the purposes of this list.

  Power
  required to move car  
    |                      _-  
    |                     _-
    |                    _-
    |                   _-   
    |                 _-   
    |               _-            (starts from 0.0 speed, 0.0 power)
    |             _-     
    |           _-   
    |        _-  
    |   _-  
    |==________________________
      Car speed (mph or km/hr)
  



              limits of       
              bearings       turbo match limits 
               /             \
              /               \
             /                 \ -----
  Engine    /        ____ bmep-/\
  Power    /    ---/     limits  \
    |     /----/              _-<------3rd gear  (up to about 80 mph)
    |    /                  _-     \
    |   /                 _-        \
    |                   _-   .<-------- 2nd gear  (up to about 60 mph)
    |                 _-    . 
    |               _-     .
    |             _-     .
    |           _-    .       _
    |        _-   .         -. <--------1st gear (up to about 40 mph)
    |     _-  .     ____.--- 
    |     ____.----
    |____|_____________________|  
       idle                red line
              ENGINE RPM

On flat road every CAR has a speed-power curve that **LOOKS LIKE** the top
figure (one line only, the ordinate is Car Power, the abscissae is car speed). 
The higher the car speed the higher the power needed.  The car speed is
proportional to wheel speed (neglecting tire-diameter increase due to
centrifugal forces). Between wheel speed and engine speed a 911  has 5 gears
and a 993 has 6 gears. At all times:

(Engine Power) = (Engine Torque) * (Engine rpm) * (a constant, 2*pi/60.)
(Car Power)    = (Engine Power) - (Friction in gears, differential etc)

and neglecting friction (Car=engine power)
(Car Power)    = (Engine Torque) * (Engine rpm) * (C,a gear-dependent constant)

The second figure is also on flat road, and the curves would move upwards (more
power needed) to climb hills. In 1st gear one moves on the lowest line above,
and in top gear on the highest (only three gears on flat road are shown in the
figure). Of course in all shifts except from neutral to 1st  one doesn't go all
the way down in rpm, one jumps to  the higher line somewhere half way its
length. Let's go through 2 shifts:

1st gear, idle to 6,000 rpm: from low to moderate power, 
                             lowest value of the constant C, highest torque 
                             (to get you moving).
2nd gear, 3,000 to 6,000 rpm: from moderate to middle power, 
                              with a bit higher value of C than in 1st,
                              a bit lower torque.
3rd gear, 3,000 to 6,000 rpm: from middle power to higher power,
                              a bit higher value of C than in 2nd,
                              a bit lower torque.

The engine figure (2nd figure) shown above has superimposed islands of constant
efficiency  (or it's inverse, fuel consumption). It is critical to observe the
three (main) limiting lines shown in the second curve: (a) the bearing load
limit (the shafts need to MOVE to support loads at the bearings); the turbo
matching limit (that's to match engine air flow with air flow through the
turbine to power the compressor of the turbo); and the maximum bmep limit
explained below.  The location of lines in the above figure is APPROXIMATE. It
is critical to accept that at each rpm  the engine curve above has upper and
lower limits within which the engine will operate happily. At
low-power/high-speed  combinations marine engines tend to form sludge (I don't
know what 911 or 951 engines do, I don't normally rev the engine to max rpm in
neutral!).  Let's go up the 3,000 rpm line. Low power, but some power ok. Up a
hill, higher power, still ok. Steeper hill, max power at 3,000 rpm, engine
wants to stall, approaches bmep (Break mean effective pressure) limit. Break
means dynamometer brake, but it also means highest pressures in combustion
chambers etc. You increase engine power, you increase bmep, and eventually you
need "race" gaskets. Anyway, you eventually stall the engine as you are
straining to blow the gaskets, which are designed for max bmep.

This max bmep limit runs along the top of the second figure, slightly curving
upwards with increasing rpm. 

Now it is time to study the engine power and  gear-shift curves shown at
the back of the owner's manual. Note that at the back of the owner's manual you
get one line of engine power  versus engine speed, presumably from a dyno test,
near max bmep (Peter Albrecht,  can you confirm what's published in the
manual?)

When you insist in staying at a high gear in low rpm you operate the engine
near the bearing load limit, and as Jim Pasha has already said, you will need
to rebuild the bearings soon. It damages the engine unnecessarily, so please
don't do it. 

(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis           ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
'87 911 Carrera targa, summer yellow on black full leather  
Washington University in St. Louis (The above are my words/actions, not theirs) 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 13:15:04 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 10" wheels for 951/Brembo parts

I'm running 10x17, 275/40 BFGs on my 86. they rub on the INSIDE. I spent a
weekend at the glen using washers to space the wheels further out, until
they hit the fender lip too. the 86 doesn't have rolled fenders, later cars
do, but that won't buy enough room. I have the andial cup sway bars, but
factory sport suspension otherwise. the torsion bars may be smaller on the
86, but I saw no evidence of bottoming. there was another guy at the track
with 11s(!) on a later turboS, but he rubbed too. I have HRE wheels (BBS
lookalikes). I needed custom offsets as the fronts now have floating
calipers on aluminum hats and the red calipers.
the work was done by a local shop, here in NJ, and its going back whenever
I get the chance. nothing more money won't fix.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (944 turbo)(NEW Clutch!)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 13:43:37 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: motors vs engines



>We sometimes refer to the measurement of computational power 
>of computers as Horsepower and just as often we refer to the 
>CPU and associated firmware/software as a computational Engine.

Come to think of it, Pascal referred to his invention of the first 
mechanical computer as a "computational engine"  Also there 
were "dividing engines" for cutting gear teeth before the time of 
Christ.

I guess in the definition above an engine is a mechanical thing
that does a precise repetitive task.

 - Reid

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 14:58:29 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: '73 911 Brake warning light

Hi, 

I have a small problem with my brake warning light. My brakes work fine, but
the light never comes on. So one day I decided to take out the guage holding
the warning light and noticed that the light bulb was missing. So I
temporarily put the generator bulb in the brake light warning socket and then
turned on the ignition. With the ignition on, the light blinked on and off at
the same rate as the turn signal and made the same clicking sound. It did
this continuously. Is this how it functions when there is a brake failure or
is it somehow improperly connected to the turn signal?

Any input would be greatly appreciated. Thanks,

Neil Kumpers

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 14:58:21 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Re:'73 911 passenger side horn

Hi Jeff,

I thought that I would try to help you out with your horn questions.

>  1) Did my car even come with a passenger's side horn?  The wiring was
>     present, but it is debatable whether it had ever been used or not.
>     Another '72 owner (Bob Spindel) was also missing that side's horn.

My car doesn't have it either. This may sound stupid, but was their a
regulation
stating that horns had to be placed on the driver's side of the car? That way
if somebody brought the car to a country where they drive on the otherside of
the  road there would be no problem in changing the horn from the left to the
right side. But that is probably (certainly) wrong.

> 2) Where do I properly attach the horn?  It came with an approx. 3" long
>     bracket with a 6mm hole in one end and an 8mm hole in the other.  I
ended
>     up connecting the large-holed end to the base of the headlight bucket
 >   where a bolt comes down and connects to a bracket on the battery box.
 The
>     other end went to the top of the horn - it is positioned pointing
>     downward next to the battery box in front of the tire.  In this
>     orientation its flared end is barely inside the lip of the S spoiler.
>  3) There was an extra set of horn connections on the driver's side, wired
in
>     parallel with the ones used.  Did they put both horns on one side if
the
 >    car had a fender-mounter oil cooler (which mine does not)?

Did you install 1 or 2 horns? I have two horns and they are both attached to
the battery box. One is facing forward and just fits behind the S spoiler and
the other one is facing down and is about 6 inches from the front tire. If
you only installed one horn that would explain the set of extra connectors.
If you have any other questions just E-mail me and I'll take a closer look.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa
