Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 11:55:10 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: "Miracle Paint"


Lee-

Haven't tried Miracle Paint, but there is a product I like very
much called Hammerite.  It's available in lots of hardware stores.

The stuff dries hard in less than an hour, and seems impervious to
everything, including gasoline and lacquer thinner.  I've used it
to paint the engine compartments of two Z cars, the floor of a TR3
(because driving a TR3 in the rain is almost like driving with an
open top - the floor fills up like a bathtub), and have just used
it for the battery boxes on the 911 I'm restoring.

 -Bob

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 12:00:20 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Ignition Advance

Anyone out there had any experience "tuning" the ignition advance
on early 911's?  Mine's a '72.  The factory advance curve seems to
be rather slow, which I think was characteristic of the early
'70s cars when emission control laws first appeared.  The slow
advance helped, but it didn't do much for performance.
I haven't seen anything on P-philes on the subject, and have
looked through some of the archives to no avail.

Putting in softer mechanical advance springs (or removing the 'stiff'
one in distributors that have two kinds) is pretty straightforward.

Any comments?

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

'72 911E under restoration

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 15:17:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Don Munn <dmunn@Cybernetics.NET>
Subject: Re: '73 911 Brake warning light



On Mon, 24 Oct 1994 NeilK356@aol.com wrote:

> Hi, 
> 
> I have a small problem with my brake warning light. My brakes work fine, but
> the light never comes on. So one day I decided to take out the guage holding
> the warning light and noticed that the light bulb was missing. So I
> temporarily put the generator bulb in the brake light warning socket and then
> turned on the ignition. With the ignition on, the light blinked on and off at
> the same rate as the turn signal and made the same clicking sound. It did
> this continuously. Is this how it functions when there is a brake failure or
> is it somehow improperly connected to the turn signal?
> 
> Any input would be greatly appreciated. Thanks,
> 
> Neil Kumpers
> '73 911S targa
> 

Neil, I have this same problem/feature in my '75 914.  I believe it is 
due to the turn signal relay.  Does your turn signal indicator on the 
dash glow all the time????  I looked at a schematic and the wireing of 
the circuit is less than intuitive, so I opened up the relay, and there 
is a circuit card with multiple active devices!!!!  I could not determine 
the purpose of the complex electronics for a turn signal.  I made the 
assumption "that which I cannot understand or figure out must be the 
problem."  Since this is a low budget car, I pulled the warning light 
back out and put the dash back together, and I watch the turn signal 
indicator glow.
This may sound dangerous to not have a brake warning light, but according 
to the schematic for the '75, the "warning light" only tells you if the 
parking brake is on.  Besides, when you drive a 914 you always drive 
without brakes :-)!!!

If there are any difinitive answers to this, I would be interested in 
knowing.

Don

  I had this problem on my 74' and the cause was a bad brake pressure switch
the one on the master cylinder.  I took it out and cleaned it and the problem
went away.. (It was full of junk).  So disconnect that switch and see if the
blinking stops..

  Damon
   74' 914 - Brown and rusty

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:17:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: '73 911 Brake warning light

>I have a small problem with my brake warning light. My brakes work fine, but
>the light never comes on. So one day I decided to take out the guage holding
>the warning light and noticed that the light bulb was missing. So I
>temporarily put the generator bulb in the brake light warning socket and then
>turned on the ignition. With the ignition on, the light blinked on and off at
>the same rate as the turn signal and made the same clicking sound. It did
>this continuously. Is this how it functions when there is a brake failure or
>is it somehow improperly connected to the turn signal?

This could also be caused by the wires being improperly connected to the
master cylinder.  If they are on backwards, then it will blink ALL the time,
I wonder if it goes out when the brakes fail???  Hmmm...

Anyway, I found out by experience.   Try reversing the wires and see what 
happens.

Thom
'71 911T Targa

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 94 13:38:21 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 944/968/928 Timing Belt Idlers


There has been a thread going on for sometime about the other components of 
the 944/968/928 engine families. 

This is about the idlers bearings. The idlers are primarially set in locations 
to provide support and change direction of the belts. The main timing belt has 
two for the 944/968 family. The first is the main belt adjuster, the second is 
the small backside idler which has a static position. Both can have bearing 
wear, this is the priciple mode of failure. Lubricant can get old, dirt get 
in, metal fatigues; there are many reasons for failure. When you have the 
belt out for renewal, most of the idlers will need to be removed. Any 
impending failure due to the sealed bearing going away can be found now by a 
simple test.

Take the idler and slowly rotate the pulley. If you feel any clicking or 
roughness or hear any grinding, toss it and replace. Simple as that. Or spend
about $200 and replace as a matter of course. Most of the cars that I see that have have 200,000 + miles (300,000km) still have the originals. I think the 
thing is inspection each time the belts are  serviced.  

One thing, there are some toothed gears on both belts, if these develop pits
on the driven surfaces, replace them. This indicates some foreign matter got
in and over time eroded material from the gear. In the event a balance shaft 
or front crankshaft seal sprays the belt housing and components, a thorough
checkout of all components, especially the 1987 and later self-adjustment
systems is required. The 968 has an oil actuated adjuster that has the 
potential of leaking, so check that part out also.

I don't have a real solution to the tensioner tool. It measures the stress 
on the belt fibers. This is more accurate, but it requires a special device
to measure the tension. If a 1987 or later tensioner is operating correctly, 
there should be very little to check, other than the balance shaft belt.

The main accessory drive belt also requires a tension gauge for its adjustment.

Porsche recommends the belt change at 45,000 miles (72,000km), earlier at the
mechanic's discretion. Much of the folklore is reflected by the willingness
of mechanics to "guide" their customers into things that line their pockets.
To any mechanics that read this, sorry, but I have been on both sides. I know
quite a few shops in the Bay Area that like to "advise" customers to get rid 
of a car because the mecahnic can no longer keep the car in good running 
order in the low maintenace mode. They have to really work at tuning up a car.
Performing service on a newer than 7 year old Porsche is really no more time
consuming than any American car, 911 valve adjustemnt included. Many easy, but
profitable service items are pushed, the 944 belt being one. My observation,
over ten + years, is that many of these shops didn't like the 944 family 
because the usual "gravy" wasn't there. Even the water pump "problem" was 
less in labor than a late 930 valve adjustment. In fact, if you add up the 
total labor to do the water pump, adjust the belts, change the motor mounts 
and do the clutch, it is less than 14 hours. At the local $72/hr rate, 
that's $1,008 for labor, probably another $1,100 in parts at the prevailing
best price. So the shop sees a potential of about $2,500 in a car for the 
first 125,000 miles. This is not going to keep them in business. The average 
911 owner will spend twice to three times that amount in the same period, I'll
except the 1986 and later Carreras as they are very good on service.

I will repeat a fact that few mechanics can refute, more damage to Porsche 
engines (and drivetrains) has occured because of mechanics that know little 
about what they are doing. Many of these jerks work at dealerships and are 
protected by their Union. Quite a few competent independant shops have to
tell a customer that another mechanic did something improperly and it finally 
caused a failure. What PCNA and Porsche AG fail to comprehend is that people
become irate and sell the cars after learning and seeing what the dealer did.
Many never consider another Porsche. The result is that the mechanic, in this 
case, does a repair as necessary and the car is sold. The new owner gets 
pissed when the poor repair fails and bitches on P-files (just an example).
And so on. 

Anyway, check or have checked all the belt pulleys at the inspection (or
replacement) interval.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 17:35:46 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Taking parts to the shop...

>Normally I wouldn't bother to save a few bucks but the
>difference between a mail-order clutch [<$350] and the 
>"shop" price [$600] I'd rather blow the $250 difference
>on stuff like food and my mortgage. :-)
>Basically, I want to know if my normal shop is likely
>to take umbrage at the suggestion.

I think the best thing to do in this situation is to talk to the 
shop in question and tell them what you want to do.  It sounds
like you're not in a habit of doing this, and they should sympathize
with the difference in parts costs.  It seems like the shop would
try to work with you to an extent - after all, I think I would rather
make a little bit of money than no money at all.  Especially if it 
meant keeping you as a customer...

Mike Dayton
 - who just paid a shop $220 for a CIS warm-up regulator...

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 18:10:48 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: taking parts to a shop



If you develop a good relationship with _one_ shop (see Stan's
earlier posting) usually they will work with you to save money.

Any reputable mechanic would be wary of installing parts of 
unknown origin because it's _his_ butt and reputation on the
line. Even in the best of circumstances parts can fail - then
where do you place the blame? If a part like a clutch fails, it
means a day of non-profit labor to fix it when it may not even
be his fault.

My favorite mechanic - Gene Kirchner at Autohaus - (shameless
plug here) will tell me to find my best price on a part, and he'll
either match it or install what I found if it's of acceptable
quality. That's nice, and he has my continued loyalty as my thanks.

 - Reid



------------------------------

Date: 24 Oct 1994 16:56:05 -0500
From: "Mohr Bob" <mohr_bob@po.gis.prc.com>
Subject:  944 Pwr Steering Groans When Cold...

Trev,
Have the same problem with 87 924S (96K miles).  Problem is a seal that
shrinks in cold weather allowing air into the fluid causing cavitation and
groan---so I've been told. When fluid warms seal expands, etc. Could also be
that clamp at base of reservoir is not working correctly as is often the
case.  I think it is Kevin Gross who perodically says to replace clamp with a
regular hose clamp. If it's the seal causing problems you used to be able to
get one in a power steering rebuild kit, tho that no longer seems to be the
case.  Ivan, the rooftop mechanic claims, that he replaced seal with a Mazda
seal.I guess one could learn to live with it, but in very cold weather it
seems to last interminably, and I can't believe it's not damaging something
or other.
Hope this helps.
Bob

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 17:20:40 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 Brakes:  60 - 0 stopping distances

At the suggestion of p-philer Mark Skala, I ran some 60 - 0 MPH stopping distance tests with my 914 this
weekend.  Test conditions were cloudy, 45 degrees, dry asphalt pavement (if it matters).

(Test run not measured)
Run #1 - 135 feet  (some tire lockup)
Run #2 - 137 feet  (some tire lockup)
Run #3 - 122 feet  (no lockup)
Run #4 - 121 feet  (no lockup)
Run #5 - 123 feet  (very light lockup)

These results are actually better than I thought they would be.  Perhaps the high pedal effort leads me to
believe that the brakes aren't as effective as they are.  If my memory isn't too fuzzy, isn't the 60 - 0
stopping distance for an average sedan around 120 feet?  Does anyone have information on the stopping
distances for various Porsche models?  I recall watching a mid-80's Motorweek show in which a Corvette
had a stopping distance of 98 feet.  Not that I expect a stock 914 to match a Corvette...

Thanks,
Pete Klager

Date: 25 Oct 94 13:00:23 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 914 brake tests

 
Hi, Pete.
 
How did you measure the starting and stopping points? Human reflexes aren't
good enough to judge exactly where to hit the pedal. Your 12 ft. difference
in distances amounts to only 0.14 sec. difference at 60 mph (88 ft/sec.)
That's about the order of magnitude of human reaction times for an expected
braking operation. Human eye-hand-foot coordination will give you more
scatter in the data than that already inherent in your braking system.
 
Distance will depend strongly on road surface. I test on a drag strip, and
pavement differences are enough to make a stop take forever if I hit the
wrong spot. The rubber laid down by dragsters is greasy under braking. I
have a certain "sweet spot" I use, about 300 ft. long. And it's been getting
smaller as they repave the strip over the years. But I think the record from
60 with my equipment is held by a 911 Turbo at about 113 ft. Anything below
120 ft. is phenomenal, and requires really high quality tires and brake
system engineering.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 25 Oct 94 13:00:19 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Speed shifting and drag racing

 
Hi, Clark.
 
I just happened across a Top Alcohol car sponsored by the Fluke (test
equipment) people at the local Fry's Electronics. I put the team to The
Question (manual or automatic) and what they call an automatic is different
from what you and I would call an automatic. No torque converter, a
conventional clutch is still used on the initial launch, but from then on
the driver has to manually punch up each gear shift (but does not have to
work a clutch). They use a planetary gearbox with three gearsets. (Actually,
it may be closer to a Sportomatic...)
 
Other interesting stuff -- the engines are even more like Porsches than
Porsches themselves; they have NO COOLING SYSTEM. No water jacket passages.
Not even a fan. It's not a drag race, it's a race against meltdown. Of
course, the alhohol fuel itself is the coolant.
 
Now this one I find hard to believe, and I'm too lazy to get my textbooks
out, but I'm told that nitromethane (the fuel for Top Fuel) apparently
contains so much of its own oxygen that it will burn just fine without
outside air. Basically, one of those rocket fuels that doesn't require a
separate oxidizer (that type of fuel has a name, I forgot it). I find that
hard to believe, as Top Fuel cars still suck in lots of air judging by the
inlet hardware that's visible on top of the things. But maybe some of the
chemists on the list can comment to this off the top of their heads.
 
(Later) Yup, sure enough, I looked it up and PURE nitromethane (dragsters blend
it though, don't run it pure) is a monopropellant (there, that's the word),
and a darn good one too. Specific impulse 210, compared to only 175 for
hydrazine or hydrogen peroxide, traditional rocket fuels. Density impulse is
not so great though, you would need a bulkier rocket to do the same job as
other fuels.
 
(This begs the question, why bother running nitromethane through something as
inherently inefficient as a piston engine, when you could be using it as
reaction mass for a rocket car? Answer: advertising. Detroit isn't selling
road rockets yet, and the fans might find the rocket cars and other forms of
weenie roasters interesting but not part of real racing.)
 
If this is true though, it means racing on the moon will be possible. This
will require (Yuppie Buzzword Alert!!!) a pardigm shift, because there will
be no need for aerodynamic devices, for one thing. You can make a Lunar Top
Fuel car as ugly as you want, it won't matter. You won't have Urropeen
tippy-toe drivers in the Formula Luna series bitching about the other guys'
cheater ground effects.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 13:42:33 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Speed shifting and drag racing

>> 
>>If this is true though, it means racing on the moon will be possible. This
>>will require (Yuppie Buzzword Alert!!!) a pardigm shift, because there will
>>be no need for aerodynamic devices, for one thing. You can make a Lunar Top
>>Fuel car as ugly as you want, it won't matter. You won't have Urropeen
>>tippy-toe drivers in the Formula Luna series bitching about the other guys'
>>cheater ground effects.
>>
To get enough speed to make Formula Luna interesting, it will have to be run on a
very high-banked oval, so you can generate some downforce. Then, since the
excape velocity is pretty low, going off the track could result in the car
going into lunar orbit!  

 -John White-

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 12:45:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: THOXNER@ualr.edu
Subject: Power Shifting

Gee Peter, you knew very little about drag racing. It is not a buch of low
tech good ol' boys running the quarter mile. The level of technology is
pretty high and the performances have to be seen to be believed. If you
think that Porsche is the paragon of technology, you have a great deal to
learn. As an ex drag racer and the owner of three Porsches, I don't really
think Porsche is the only source of innovation. The drag racers do a great
deal of testing and innovation on budgets that would not cover the pit crew
for a F1 team.

Well, it had been about 5 years since I used a MIG and it took about 5 
minutes to figure out that I had forgotten alot.  I have been doing heavy 
stick welding on trailers and such, but that's like a sledge hammer compared 
to MIG/sheet metal.  I did do one thing right, I decided to weld a cart for 
the welder instead of starting on the car!!!!!  ( My wife teases me that 
I put the cart before the Porsche!!!)  I need a good 
reference/training/idiot book for body and frame welding, any 
recommendations????.  Any ideas as always are welcome.

Second, both rear tires have a significant amount of camber.  At first I 
thought my car was falling apart, but yesterday I saw a car that WAS 
falling apart, and the camber was not that bad.  That unmentionable car 
parts "store" in Atlanta said it could just be missing shims.  Are there 
any other reasonable explanations?  Maybe bushings???  The trailing arm 
console is in good shape.  The frame member in front of the console is OK 
but needs some help.  (The car I saw the other day was missing the 
jack point, so I looked in the hole on the rocker panel, I saw leather, 
leather???? Oh, its my shoe!!!  I mean BIG holes in the frame.  More 
motivation to stop the cancer before it is terminal.)  Thanks again.

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 14:18:09 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: RE: RE '73 brake warning light

I'd like to thank everybody who responded to my post concerning an improperly
functioning brake warning light. As it turns out Thom had the answer to my
problem. The connectors to the switch at the master cylinder were reversed
thus causing a constant blinking. Now the light works as it should and I
adjusted the switch at the parking brake as Reid suggested. If only I had
fixed last night. I found myself driving with the parking brake, fortunately
I caught after a 1/2 mile. Now it won't happen again. 

Thanks again,
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 94 11:31:48 PDT
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: Re: Welding MIG style,    914 rear camber.


Don Munn <dmunn@Cybernetics.NET> asks:

;				 I need a good 
; reference/training/idiot book for body and frame welding, any 
; recommendations????.  Any ideas as always are welcome.

	Lincon Electric make a couple of good and cheap books on 
arc welding. Can't remember the name right now- gonna have to look
when I get home.

; 
; Second, both rear tires have a significant amount of camber.  At first I 
; thought my car was falling apart, but yesterday I saw a car that WAS 
; falling apart, and the camber was not that bad.  That unmentionable car 
; parts "store" in Atlanta said it could just be missing shims.  Are there 
; any other reasonable explanations?  Maybe bushings???  The trailing arm 
; console is in good shape.  The frame member in front of the console is OK 
; but needs some help.  (The car I saw the other day was missing the 
; jack point, so I looked in the hole on the rocker panel, I saw leather, 
; leather???? Oh, its my shoe!!!  I mean BIG holes in the frame.  More 
; motivation to stop the cancer before it is terminal.)  Thanks again.  

	Rear camber is set with shims under the outside mount of the swing
arm. Large negative camber is difficult. I had to modify the inner mount
to get -2.5 deg ! If you have large negative camber, something must be
wrong with either the rear console or with the swing arm/bushing.  Factory
bushings seem to be availiable only with the purcha$e of the swing arm. The only
replacement bushings I know of for the 914 swing arm are from Weltmeister
and are plastic so they will have to be dissassembled about once a year to
be re-lubed (If you use the right lube) or the sound will drive you crazy.
If you use the wrong lube, they will allways be noisy no matter how often you
lube them.

							-jd

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 13:39:59 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  Welding MIG style,    914 rear camber.

>>> Don Munn <dmunn@cybernetics.net> 10/25/94 01:03pm >>>
>Second, both rear tires have a significant amount of camber.
Don,
Could be sagging rear springs.  I just replaced mine this summer for the same reason.
The 914 rear suspension geometry is set up such that as the wheel moves upward, it also tips inward.
So as the springs sag, the camber increases.

Hope this helps,
Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 94 12:18:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


The dealer could not solve this problem the first time around, hopefully 
someone on the net can share some wisdom or recall a similar experience to 
mine.

Two weeks ago my '84 928S (93,000 miles) stalled while driving down the 
interstate (at highway speed) , but only for a minute.  It restarted before 
I coasted to a stop and I made it to work, another 40 miles, without further 
incident.

On the way home it died after approx.. 10 miles.  After trying to start it 
every 5-10 minutes for an hour, it started right up like normal and went 
another 10 miles before stalling out again.  I had it towed to Ray Catena 
Porsche in Edison, NJ where they diagnosed low fuel pressure as the problem. 
 They installed a new fuel pump, fuel filter and fuel pump relay for $688.

I picked it up this morning and drove about 10 miles before it died again, 
same symptoms as before.  Seems the $688 fuel pump was not the answer to my 
problem.  As the tow truck approached 40 minutes after it died, I tried to 
start it and it kicked right over.  But I had it towed in anyway.  Stalling 
on a busy interstate is not the rush I was looking for when I bought this 
car!

Each time it bucks a bit before dying, similar to running out of gas.  When 
trying to restart, it runs rough for 5-10 seconds before dying.  I seem to 
have spark, compression and some gas.  Since it will run strong, for 10 
miles anyway, I think my compression is OK.

Could it be some electronic black box or sensor somewhere?  I want to make 
sure the dealer has checked all possibilities this time around.

Should I pay for the previous repair which now seems needless?  I used a 
Master Card to pay and can fight it that way if need be.

History:
======
Timing belt (installed at dealer) has under 1,000 miles on it.
Old fuel filter had only gone 6,000 miles when they replaced it.
Plugs, cap, rotor, air and air pump filter replaced 6,000 miles ago with 
fuel filter.
No previous problems, always ran strong and started right up.

TIA for all suggestions!
 -Bill Smyth

smYthB@DBIS.COM





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 12:00:45 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: Speed shifting and drag racing

Pete writes:

>I just happened across a Top Alcohol car sponsored by the Fluke (test
>equipment) people at the local Fry's Electronics. I put the team to The
>Question (manual or automatic) and what they call an automatic is different
>from what you and I would call an automatic. No torque converter, a

The top fuel and funny car people have been racing WIITHOUT gearboxes since 
about '88-'89 ish.  Those cars have a direct drive (through a clutch) but no
gears.  This was made possible by making a different size and MUCH stronger
ring and pinion set for the diff.  You never hear these guys talk about gear
boxes exploding or losing gears anymore; you always hear them talking about
dialing in the clutch.  This non-gearbox stuff was made initially by Gene Snow,
a Top Fuel guy and it was his secret to success for 2 seasons.  evenmtually,
the word got out and he told them of this special diff set-up.  They even
showed it in the pits on TNN one time (yes, TNN does have some great color guys
and good racing occasionally).  This guy is putting the engine in the dragster
and the other guy grabs the transmission, holds it up to the camera and turns it
around so you can see through the gearbox.  No gears, selecctors, bands.
Nothing.  Gene went on to the finals, but I can't remember how he did.  I
believe this also has to do with the et's dropping and the speeds increasing.

later,

Wild bill

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 15:21:44 -0400
From: Andre Rotchel <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
Subject: Re: Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles


Hi Bill,

I've had a similar problem with my 944.
Fortunately, the dealer was honest enough to 
admit he did not know the source of the problem.

I realized that it was an electronic problem
(as opposed to mechanical) given the nature of the 
symptoms. The bottom line is that the source of the 
problem is a relay that controls fuel injection 
called the "DME". 

Regards,
Andre Rotchel.

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 94 14:40:55 -0500

> Each time it bucks a bit before dying, similar to running out of gas.  When

   Had a friend with the same problem turn out to be a bad gas line, It had 
a kink that would close after about 10 miles.  He finally put a pressure 
guage on the line and you could watch it drop to 0 when the car would die
and after a few minutes it would return to normal.  So a extensive trace of
all the fuel lines let to the kink.. Replaced it and all was well. But this
car was not FI.

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 15:03:35 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 brake tests

>>> Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com> 10/25/94 12:00pm >>>
>  Hi, Pete.
>  How did you measure the starting and stopping points? Human reflexes
>aren't good enough to judge exactly where to hit the pedal. Your 12 ft. difference
>in distances amounts to only 0.14 sec. difference at 60 mph (88 ft/sec.)
>That's about the order of magnitude of human reaction times for an expected
>braking operation. Human eye-hand-foot coordination will give you more scatter
>in the data than that already inherent in your braking system.

Well...
There was a skid mark laid down perpendicular to the traffic lane which I
used as a starting point.  I went down the road aways and headed towards the start
at 60 mph.  About a second before reaching the starting point, I pushed in the clutch
and moved my right foot to the brake pedal.  I tried to anticipate when my front wheels
crossed over the starting mark and hit the brakes just as they did so.  Hopefully, this
eliminated (or at least reduced the effects of) my reaction time from the test.
After the car came to a stop, I got out and marked a line in the gravel shoulder parallel
to the front axle.  I did this five times.  Then I measured the distance from the start
point to each end point.  I ran the test five times for several reasons:
  - to search out the point of maximum braking without skidding.
  - to average out the differences between the starting point and where I actually hit the brakes
    assuming sometimes I was early and sometimes I was late hitting the brakes.
  - to average out the effects of the brakes heating up and gripping better -or- heating up and fading.

Certainly, there will be inaccuracies in the test due to reaction times and speedometer error.
I ran these tests to determine if my car's brakes were operating as well as they should be, rather
than relying on a "seat of the pants" feeling.  If I had gotten distances in the range of, say, 160 - 170
feet, I would have had good evidence that my brakes are as bad as the pedal makes them feel.
Now I know that even though I really have to stand on the pedal, I do get a reasonable stopping distance.

Pete Klager


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 15:03:16 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Welding MIG style,    914 rear camber.

> The 914 rear suspension geometry is set up such that as the wheel moves upward, it also tips inward.
> So as the springs sag, the camber increases.

For those of us racing 914s, this adds another factor: rear bump steer.
If you have springs that are too soft, then under compression (usually
acceleration exiting a corner) you get a huge camber change, which also
brings with it a caster and toe change. Ooooops. Come see my "Mr. Conehead"
award I got at one SCCA event for hitting most cones, tires, and other
barriers before I figured this out and went to 260 pound (yes, that's
260 as in DOUBLE what the "conventional wisdom" says is good) springs....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 15:06:16 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 924 injectors

> I have a '79 924 with over a 100,000 miles.  I was wondering
> if anyone had an idea how long the fuel injectors last from that
> era.  I just purchased the car last spring, and am wondering 
> approx. how long the injectors will last, and if there are any
> warning signs as to when they are going bad.

Almost any fuel injected car will run a LOT beter with new injectors
if the current injectors are more than a few years old. "A few" varies
some by type and application, but anything over 3 years old will just
about certainly give a performance boost if replaced.

Note that this does not answer the "when will it die" question. With
a Porsche, my view is that the "when does performance degrade" question
is much more important...

And don't go to carbs. Just don't. It's a bad idea for lots of reasons...

Stan

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 16:50:06 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: SCCA Runoffs : Porsche wins

Here's some good news for Porsche race fans :

At the recent Mid-Ohio SCCA road racing national championships, Porsches did
quite well. Vic Skirmants won GP in his trusty 356, and David Finch won GT-2
in his awesome 944. Third place in GT-2 was taken by our local driver Jim
Goughary in his 944S. Jim's car, like most SCCA GT cars, is a "funny car"
with only the engine block and roof made by Porsche. It is the only Porsche
that I have seen with a SOLID REAR END (no transaxle). It allows him to run
at a lower weight.

Mike Piera, '72 911S Targa (like Jim, sponsored by Danbury Porsche)

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 94 17:05:00 PDT
From: "GASKILL, GREGORY" <GASKILL@rerw.wpafb.af.mil>
Subject: RE: Help! Car needs to rest...


I had a similar problem on my 924 but it was solved with the fuel pump 
relay.

I also had the injectors replaced on my Vanagon, under a factory recall, 
because they apparently were not sealed properly, leading to bad electrical 
connections.  This exhibited itself with the stall or near stall at speed 
which you mentioned.  Starting wasn't generally a problem though.

------------------------------

Date: 25 Oct 1994 14:13:38 U
From: "Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re:  '73 911 Brake warning l

>I have a small problem with my brake warning light.

[mucho stuff deleted]

(  Assuming that the 73 911 is like the 74 914:  )
    The brake warning light blinks at you (it's supposed to
blink) under two circumstances:  1) your parking brake is
on,  2) half of your "dual master cylinder" (master brake
cyl) has failed.
    There are two switches to check: one under the handbrake
handle, and one on the brake master cylinder.

    If your turn signal bulb continually stays on, yes the
relay is bad.  EASY in Emeryville, CA will sell you a used
one for $5-10 or so.  BT, DT.

- --DD

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 16:14:00 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914-4 and 914-6

> I'd like to hear some first hand accounts on the driving "feeling" of 914-6
> vs 914-4. I further have the following questions:

A good six is a thing of beauty, but it provides one of the toughest
choices in Porschedom: do you keep it stock and live with any number of
inadequacies, or do you make it "right" and destroy the value of the car.
I tend to follow the "keep it stock" view, except when building a six
out of a stock 914-4. *THEN* you make it "right"... and then some!

Bone stock, a six has a ton more top-end than even a 2.0. However, the
torque is lower at the low RPM range, and it's not as good an autox
car. With some reasonable and inobtrusive modifications (like 2.4E
pistons/cylinders and a '68 S cam slightly advanced), it's a whole 'nuther
story....

> 1. What's a fair price for a 914-4 (2.0) and 914-6 in "good" condition, e.a.
> fairly well preserved interior with some rust on the usual spots.

Good 2.0s go from about $3500 to about $6000, depending on how lucky you get 
and how good the car is. Good 914-6s start at $9k and go up from there.
Usually, $14-15k will get a Very Good car, and $20k will get a 97 point
concour car. We're talking Real Prices here, not asking prices.

Any car with rust is too expensive. You'll need to take it apart to fix
the rust,and once you do that, you'll want to "do" everything -- which
is VERY expensive.

Ghost Racing does stock and modified 914-6 restorations for customers, 
since the principals own a total of 6 914-6s and have ample sources of
comparison for originality. The last one done for a customer was a
"street restoration" -- i.e. probably a high-80s concour car, but it was
just *GREAT* for the street. I think it cost the guy about $18k plus
his car, but it included an engine rebuild, full strip, fix rust, all
new original color paint, interior repairs, etc. Looked great, but not
a concours job by any means... To pick up those last 10 points or so,
you can roughly TRIPLE that cost...

> 2. What's the purpose of a side shifter modification ?

The original 'tail shifter' is about as precise as stirring a bucket of 
mud with a thin stick. The side shifter "cures" that. Sort of like
smoking cures lung cancer, in my opinion. It *DOES* help, but a shifter
spring upgrade kit and fresh hand-fitted shift bushings, plus new
motor and trans mounts, and some tranny work, will do about as good while
preserving the original setup.

> 3. Anyone with a 914-4/914-6 for sale ??

Yes. Two. Prices start at $15k. These are great street/track cars, 
have fresh engine rebuilds and mechanicals. If you're *SERIOUS*,
shoot me a note. If you want a great deal on a great car, this is
a good opportunity. If you want something cheaper, go bother someone 
else...

BTW, there are usually at least a few in the Porsche Market Letter.

Stan

I'm in the process of buying a 914 and am interested in getting into a porsche
mailing list.  Who do I talk to and what do I need to do to do this?

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 17:44:54 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: intermittent stalling



Although the problem sounds like a bad DME connection or relay
here's one from a "stump the mechanic" piece that I read a couple
of years ago:

The symptoms were exactly the same. The car would run for a while
then shut down without warning. After sitting for a minute the car
would run for while and repeat the problem. After several trips to
the shop, replaced DME chip, relays etc. they pulled the gas tank
off and found the problem. A disgruntled assembly line worker had
put a baggie in the gas tank. It would get sucked around the in-tank
filter while the car was running, then float away when the car 
stalled. Strange huh?

 - Reid




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 15:48:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: intermittent stalling

>Although the problem sounds like a bad DME connection or relay
>here's one from a "stump the mechanic" piece that I read a couple
>of years ago:
>
>The symptoms were exactly the same. The car would run for a while
>then shut down without warning. After sitting for a minute the car
>would run for while and repeat the problem. After several trips to
>the shop, replaced DME chip, relays etc. they pulled the gas tank
>off and found the problem. A disgruntled assembly line worker had
>put a baggie in the gas tank. It would get sucked around the in-tank
>filter while the car was running, then float away when the car 
>stalled. Strange huh?

I had a similar experience years ago with a VW bug.  The little hole
that lets air back into the gas tank got plugged, so when the suction
in the tank went just above what the fuel pump could suck, the car died!

Thom

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 19:28:20 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Help!  Car needs to rest 45 minutes after every 10 miles

This sounds pretty dumb, but one possibility might be that you're
developing a vacuum in the gas tank, due to a plugged vent. (I think
this was a Car Talk puzzler). Next time it happens, take off the gas
filler cap and see if you get a big whoosh from air rushing in. If so,
problem solved; if not, the shop that did the work certainly owes you
a loaner fuel injection control unit, to see if that cures the problem.
You could also figure out how to connect a pressure gauge to the
fuel rail test fitting; I thought the idea of using an oil pressure
sender, with an adapter for the fittings, connected via a two-position
switch to the oil pressure gauge was pretty cute, but maybe more
complex than you want for one-time troubleshooting. Your shop could
maybe connect a gauge so that the next time it happens you could leap
out, pop the hood, and check the pressure. The fuel pump doesn't run
if the engine isn't running, but the residual pressure should be 
pretty close to the roughly 2 bar expected during idle; that's
something you can check when the car is working, to compare with
when it's not. As always, let the list know the right answer, when
it's found.

 -John White-
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 17:43:15 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: 944 Oil filters


A while back I bought 10 oil filters from Automotion during one of their 
sales. What I received was a mix of Mahle OC142 (short) and OC75 (tall) 
filters. Seeing as the box for OC75 said it was for a 911 Turbo I thought 
they had sent the wrong filter. Automotion assured me that the tall 
filter was indeed correct and the short one was being phased out. In fact 
they said some customers were specifically asking for the tall ones.
 
What's the true story behind this filter swap? Did Porsche really change 
the size of the filters used for 944's?
 
Logic would dictate that a bigger filter would be better for increased 
filtration. On the minus side is that it might increase the restriction 
on oil flow but this might be negligible given the pressures involved.
 
Which filter should I be using?

Chris
'86 944

------------------------------

Date: 25 Oct 94 20:55:53 EDT
From: Richard Grayson <76226.3526@compuserve.com>
Subject: Fuel Pressure Sender


I wrote
  
> Does anyone have a good source for a reasonably priced fuel injection
> pressure gauge with fittings? I need to test the fuel pressure on my '85 911.
> It's checked via a test fitting on the fuel rail.
 
Ed Mellinger replied

> Consider using a standard oil pressure sender, and wiring it into your
> oil pressure gauge.  Then you can check fuel pressure on the road, watch
> the warmup regulator operate... oops, you're Motronic.  Not sure how
> useful this will be to you; is system pressure as informative as it is
> with CIS?
> 
> On my '83 I got a duplicate oil pressure sender (it's a generic VDO
> part) and a brass adapter tee and mounted the sender in the fuel line at
> the warmup pressure regulator.  Then I ran the wire up to the dash (the
> only messy part of the job... run several wires while you're at it),
> and ran it and the original oil pressure wire thru a selector switch and
> thence to the oil pressure gauge.  For CIS troubleshooting this is handy
> as you can check things out on the road without hassle, and anytime
> anything "funny" happens.  Warmup, leakdown, full throttle... all show
> up in fuel pressure readings.
> 
> Let me know if you're interested, I can look up the part numbers and
> other details.

Thanks for the offer Ed, but as you mentioned, the Motronic FI system in my
Carrera does not vary fuel pressure in the way that a CIS system would. 
I really just need to check a couple of data points- pressure with the
engine running and pressure "bleed down" with the engine off. Your set up 
sounds like a great way to monitor a CIS system though.
 
Tom Oxner gave me a great (and now obvious tip) about fabricating a 
connection to the test connection on the fuel rail. Just take an old fuel
hose with fitting (like the one that connects to the fuel filter), cut it in
half and use some low tech hose clamps and non-metric fittings to mate it
to an inexpensive hardware variety pressure gauge.

Richard Grayson  76226.3526@compuserve.com
1985 911 coupe

The 75-77 911 are years to stay away from has they ran to hot and
overcooked the the lower valve train.

also the 2.7 will need major work if it has not had it. you need
to update all the head studs to delvair and change the 7 blade fan
to 11 blade, change,but keep, the thermal reactors. All this stuff
may have been by now. 

$19,000 should bring you a low mile excell shape 70's early 80's
vintage 911

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 00:58:04 -0400 (EDT)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: intermittent stalling due to tank vacuum


	One quick way to see if the gas tank is developing a large 
	amount of vacuum is to remove the gas cap when the car stalls
	and see if there is a big "whoosh". If the car then starts ok,
	look at the tank venting/vapor recirculation system.
- --

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 22:04:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Why I won't use K&N Filters

*** WARNING , the follow is quite long....  

Why I Won't Use K&N Filters 

Before purchasing a K&N filter,I decided to take a careful and
common-sense approach to checking out K&N's claims. I was able to acquire
a K&N fact sheet and product literature on their filters. The more I read,
the more I had reservations about using their filter on my car.  

First, let me say that I believe that they WILL increase performance by
increasing air flow. The question is at what cost? The viewpoint I took in
my analysis was that I was to be using my car for street driving only and
not racing, auto-crossing, or off road driving (duh). Also, I was not
going to sacrifice engine longevity for a minimal increase in performance.
I disregarded the cost issue (i.e. as compared with paper filters) as I
seriously doubt people buy K&N filters to save money.  Anyways, here are
my concerns with K&N's claims. Let me know if I'm way off base in my
reasoning: 

K&N: "When K&N air filter is clean, the air flow and filtering
capabilities are very high, and remain so for an extraordinary period of
time. As the filter begins to collect debris on the outside, from the
atmosphere, an additional form of filtering action takes place. Because
there are no small holes to clog the filter itself, the large and small
particles adhering to the outside of the element, held by the oil, begin
to form a fitlering barrier."

 - This is my biggest concern and one which I'm surprised K&N is admitting
to. Basically, K&N is saying that when the filter is clean, you get lots
of air (and presumably dirt). As the dirt builds up, it serves to block
the dirt which was passing though when the filter was clean. Given their
claim that the air flow remains high for an 'extraordinary period of
time', imagine how much dirt makes it into the engine before the dirt
accumulates enough to become a filtering medium. On the other hand, paper
filters are designed to block out ALL dirt from the beginning. 

 - Also, no where in the literature does it state the minimum dirt particle
size which can pass through the filter. The emphasis of the text is
clearly on air-flow rather than engine protection. As such, there is no
quantitative measure of filtration throughout the documentation. 

K&N on the aluminum mesh in the filter: "The combination of square holes
in the screen and fabric create a grid-like effect which actually
straightens the air as it passes through. The air moving in a straight
direction moves faster than tumbling air creating an increase in air flow.
The principle of straightening air through a grid system is used by the
Aircraft industry in wind tunnel testing of aerodynamic shapes" 

 - Bogus. First, the filter is pleated so the air isn't going to hit the
mesh straight on. Second, the fact the the air usually has to travel
through a series of curves through the air-box, past the throttle plate
and into the intake manifold is going to cancel out any effect of
'straight air' from the filter. In terms of aerodynamics, scale makes all
the difference. This is why car manufacturers always like to perform
aerodynamic testing on life-size models. When using scaled down models,
other effects come into play which can influence test results. I'd be
hesitant to directly translate the results of aircraft testing to the
performance of an air filter. 

K&N: "...a filter that is cleaned too often might become damaged as well. 
A K&N Filtercharger can safely be washed up to 20-25 times. After this,
the filter should be replaced with a new one. Excessive washings of the
filter will tend to deplete the tiny cotton-hairs that criss-cross the
openings and grab the really small dust particles. If these tiny hairs are
damaged, the filter will gradually lose its ability to trap fine dust." 

 - You can bet the cotton starts to deteriorate after the first several
washings. And how can you really be sure when these 'tiny cotton-hairs'
are depleted? Ever notice how cotton towels are rough and their fibers
'stringy' after being washed. If you look closely, the cotton-hairs bunch
up and the towel never really feels as soft as it did when new. Why
wouldn't the same effect happen to a K&N? You could spray all the oil on
it you want and the fine hairs wouldn't 'stand up' again. 

K&N - Performance Hints: "Let the dirt "build-up" work for you; it will
not hurt the performance and actually helps filter the air. CAUTION: 
Extreme fine dust - agriculture or offroad use - will pull the oil from
the element. Frequent re-oiling of the element's clean side might be
required....For extra protection, use K&N sealing grease on rubber ends of
the element."  K&N: "Many K&N PANEL filters require a special touch to
install. Due to the firmness of the urethane we use, most filters should
be installed into lid first." 

 - Again, K&N admits it relies on dirt to filter dirt. Fine dust is
encountered in city driving too. You can guess where the dirt contaminated
oil gets pulled into. And what a mess this would make in the intake
manifold over time. Since when did a paper filter require sealing grease?
Good filters have a soft and rubbery sealing edge. K&N's are hard
urethane. 

 - "a special touch to install" - translation: our filters aren't
manufactured too precisely or too closely to spec so it may be kind of a
hassle to install and you may need our special grease just to seal out the
leaks. I doubt many owners use this grease and if they did, cleaning the
filter would be all the more messy. I've heard of owners having to
cut/grind/modify their factory air-box just to get the K&N filter to fit. 
What does this say about the quality of these filters? 

K&N: "A walk through the pits at an off-road race will show the numerous
K&N filters installed on competitive and class-winning machines. A look at
these filters after the race will show a considerable amount of dirt on
the outside of the filter, yet the inside will be as clean as a new
filter.." 

 - All used filters look clean on the inside! Perhaps the K&N is so clean
on the inside is because the dirt simply passed right though into the
engine. Also, what a lot of auto-products companies like to do is to use
racing as an example of why a regular driver should use their products. 
This is a false conclusion. Race car engines are constantly taken apart
and serviced so engine longevity isn't really a concern as it is for the
regular car owner. 

From Automotion Catalog on K&N filters: "Engine protection is so good that
over 90% of the NASCAR drivers use K&N filters....Maybe the best news is
K&N's written warranty,for the life of your engine." 

 - I seriously doubt NASCAR drivers care much about air filter protection. 
It's the air flow they're after. Their main concern is that the engine
will last the length of the race. 

 - As for the warranty for the life of the engine, wouldn't it be to K&N's
advantage if your engine DIDN'T last that long? They'd have fewer filters
to give away. Just like the timing belt joke...sure, the belt will last
the life of the engine; when the belt snaps, your engine's dead. If you
think about it, it is virtually impossible to prove damage from their
filter.  K&N claims a performance increase of 5 to 10% horsepower IF you
use their filter AND replace the factory air filter case.  This implies
changing the filter alone isn't going to buy you a whole lot, especially
when this may lead to pre-mature engine wear in the long run. Your engine
probably isn't going to take much advantage of the increased ability of
the air to flow if you don't reduce the restriction at the other end; the
exhaust system. 

  I've heard of many cases where 911 engines having easliy reached 200K mi
without major engine work and 944 engines opened up at moderately high
mileages and showing practically no measurable cylinder wear. Of these
cases, I wonder how many had K&N filters installed from the beginning? 

  I'd be interested to hear your comments on this filter or on my
ramblings. Actually, I hope I am wrong in my assumptions as I'm itching 
to put one in my car but given the reasons above, cannot do so in good 
conscience. Easy on the flame-throwers... 

Chris 
'86 944 (with MAHLE luft filter)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 22:18:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: K&N air filters

>hope I'm not wasting my time again. My question is:How much does a stock
>Porsche air filter cost compared to a K&N filter. Also, who can install it?
>Will my very user unfriendly dealer tell me to go away? Should I try a

I can't speak for 944 stuff, but I was paying about $15 for stock air
filters, and I paid $30 for my K&N.  I have a '72 911, so YMMV

I change my oil about every other month or so (I know I don't need to,
but I'm anal that way) and I do the air cleaner every other time.  I
just hose it off, let it dry, and re-spray it.  A single can of oil has 
lasted me about 4 years!

Thom

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 07:49:41 GMT
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: Unleaded petrol

Well there has been a big fuss over here about unleaded petrol for non-cat
cars. Scientific evidence? suggests that benzene in unleaded petrol is worse
than the lead for the environemnt. Government could end up with egg on its
face as they have been pushing unleaded for that last 5+ years - and most cars
have not cats. 

  This has prompted me to ask what Porsche cars run on in the states - my 930
only runs on 4 star (98 octane) but PCGB says that 3 fills of Super unleaded
(98 octane, no lead) to 1 4 star is OK (My mechanics say 4 star ALLWAYS). I
have been wondering how long leaded petrol is going to last and what I will be
able to feed the thirsty beast in a few years time. Any comments most welcome.


Kevin 1980 930

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 12:42:19 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Power Shifting

>Gee Peter, you knew very little about drag racing. It is not a buch of low
>tech good ol' boys running the quarter mile. The level of technology is
>pretty high and the performances have to be seen to be believed. If you
>think that Porsche is the paragon of technology, you have a great deal to
>learn. As an ex drag racer and the owner of three Porsches, I don't really
>think Porsche is the only source of innovation. The drag racers do a great
>deal of testing and innovation on budgets that would not cover the pit crew
>for a F1 team.
>Tom Oxner
>61 356B  72 911T  85 Carrera

For the first it's stupid to compare to F1!
Formula One is a testbed for the future,....lotsa ideas are transferred to 
standard cars and the money spent can (almost) be justified.

 Whereas a dragster is only motor and aerodynamics, and various combinations 
of the latter. How many breakthrough technology ideas evolved from Drag 
Racing?  

If you think pushrod Hemis are High-Tech, great for you. 584 cubic inches of 
Keith Black or Donovan *SHOULD* move a piece of tubing in a glassfibre shell 
fast.....*very* fast. If you think high speed/horsepower and high technology 
are synonyms, go buy yourself a dictionary....

The technology involved is old, too old in my opinion. It is just a matter 
of who's got the most Horsepower/Money.

Last time I went to see drag racing I fell asleep after the first hour, and 
that on the PRESS tribune, 25 metres from the Christmas tree.....only wake 
up for a few minutes to catch the Hydroperoxid jet dragster blow dowm the 
quarter in 4 seconds.

Trond

PS: Nothing wrong with Drag Racing,....*I* just don't like it.

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 09:55:47 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sanjay Nasta <sanjay@bga.com>
Subject: Help:  944S making High Pitched Noise

 Thanks to the detailed directions found in the Porschephiles archive I
 managed to replace the clutch on my 1987 944S.  However, when I start it up
 it makes a high pitched, loud, whining noise.  I think it sounds like a
 turbine my brother thinks it sounds like a vaccuum cleaner.  The noise is
 constant and does not vary significantly if the car is in neutral or in
 gear, if the clutch is pressed in or released.  The noise doesn't vary with
 the rpm or car speed either.  I've already tightened the bolts on the exhaust system. 
 Have checked to see if I knocked a hose loose (didn't find one buy
 perhaps)...The clutch seems to work just perfectly.  Any clues?


Sanjay@bga.com

>> I think the current LSR events are better than Stan remembers them from a
>> couple of years ago.  Both series are focused more on driver education
and
>> the Autocross group is planning several AX schools next year.  I'd
encourage
>> any Porsche owner in the Houston area to come out to our events -- we
have
>> fun and we're fortunate to have some nationally top-rated solo drivers as
>> instructors at our AX events.

>My main beef is still first and foremost *SAFETY*. As long as the safety
>steward can be overruled by the event chairman, it's a joke. As long as
>Jay Pineau is going around telling people in 944s with *SERIOUS* you-can-
>hear-it-pouring-on-the-ground gas leaks that it's OK to run because
otherwise
>we might lose their $15, it's a MAJOR joke.

Hmmm.  Only gas leak related problem I'm aware of with a 944 is one where we
yanked a person out of grid AND HE DIDN'T RUN AGAIN.  Perhaps you are
thinking of the time that the one of the safety team, Elmer Fooey, wanted to
bounce
an SCCA legal CP Mustang for his exhaust not terminating behind or to the
side of
the car.  Elmer's point was that the exhaust pointed at the rear axle and
was about 2'
from the gas tank.  In this instance, the other two members of the safety
TEAM met
with Elmer and it came to a 2 to 1 vote. It WASN'T the event chairman, and
it DID really
piss-off Mr. Fooey; but I also looked at the configuration and it met all
SCCA reqmt's
as well as having had been run that way for 2 years without problems. It
looked very
safe -- especially for an AX, If I was tech'ing the car for any kind of
high-speed event,
it would NOT have passed, however.

The current group is extremely concerned about safety at our AXes and I'd
have to
say that things have changed if that's what you were used to at LSR AX
events.  Again,
I think you ought to come out to one once you get settled.

>I don't even want to talk about
>TWS where you have guys driving cars with video cameras sticking out of
>the sunroof (totaled the car later that day) or where you have the
>instructors totalling their own cars by driving it into the wall at a
>fairly low speed at that....

I have to concur with you on the safety aspects, as well as the "fun
quotient"
of past high speed events at TWS.  I ran a bunch of Time Trials with Golden
Gate Region prior to moving to Texas, and I was literally scared to run with
the
LSR folks.  However, there is new blood running that series as well.  Once
Sally and my's national schedule calmed down this year I went to a TWS
event.
I was amazed at how much better they are run and how much safer they are
run.
The LSR TWS events are not near a level of safety (or competitiveness) that
the
GGR TimeTrials are run (things like full SCCA communications and SCCA
qualified corner workers is nice), but they are a lot better than they were.
 Again,
I'd say you ought to try one and see what you think, I know you'll see a
difference.
Besides, you won't have to think too hard on which car to take]  ;-)
  (Hmmm, do I
take the EP race car and get some valuable practice towards that license, or
do I take one of the 356s -- decisions, decisions....).

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 15:15:36 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: 88 Carrera problem


I have a rather strange problem with my 88 Carrera.

If I rev the engine while the clutch is depressed,
the RPM falls at about half the speed one gets if
I rev the car with the clutch up. The car is obviously
in neutral to do this. This is an irritating problem
because when shifting up the revs do not drop as fast
as one can make the change.

For some reason pressure on the clutch pedal is interfering
with the release speed that the mechanism that the
accelerator pedal operates, is the theory that I have.

Is this a common problem? Does anyone know what might
be causing it, I am not familiar with the mechanics
of the pedal box, and would like some advice on diagnosing
this problem from one of you gurus please.

Regards

> > the rpm either.  I've already tightened the bolts on the exhaust system. 
> > Have checked to see if I knocked a hose loose (didn't find one but

> > --XAA16875.783146077/zoom.bga.com--

> 

Hi, Sanjay,

Sound like you might have damaged the pilot bearing when replacing the
clutch. 

Or, it could be that you received a defective throwout bearing.

Or, that you assembled the throwout bearing improperly on the pressure plate.

I wouldn't touch it for the time being...maybe it will fix itself...

Good luck, 

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 11:35:15 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: 914-4 and 914-6

Bart says:

>...I'd like to hear some first hand accounts on the driving "feeling" of
914-6 vs 914-4. I further have the following questions: 1. What's a fair
price for a 914-4 (2.0) and 914-6 in "good" condition, e.a. fairly well
preserved interior with some rust on the usual spots. 2. What's the purpose
of a side shifter modification ?...<

Yo, Bart. Been there, done that.

I autocrossed, time trialed, and raced my 2.0l for three years and then
last year, traded up to a "six". Here is what I found:

The 2.0 has slightly more low end grunt, is marginally quicker off the line
and handles about the same as the six. In fact, the simple addition of
carburetors makes the 2.0 quicker everywhere except at the very top end.

The six on the other hand, winds to an extra 1000 rpm, has better gearing,
slightly better brakes and makes a much nicer sound. On a track, the six is
significantly faster than an injected 2.0, and slightly faster than a
carbureted one. On an autocross course, they are all very close with the
edge going to the carbureted four bangers.

I really haven't noticed a big difference in handling except that, on the
track, the six is generally going faster so cornering is more of an exact science.

The side shift modification is a must for the track and serious
autocrossing, but not needed for average use.

There were over 115,000 914-4s manufactured, but only around 3360 sixes.
Expect to pay $3500 to $7000 for a four, and $10000 to $15000 for a six. A
first class, "concoursable" six can go as high as $20000 or $25000.  DO NOT
accept any visible rust! Rust is a sign of poor maintainance. And watch out
for "converted sixes", someone had to ruin two cars to make one.

Any issue of PANORAMA or EXCELLENCE, will have four or five sixes and twice
that many fours for sale.

Good luck

Barney Bettilyon        cmxk95a@prodigy.com     '70 914-6   '89 Carrera


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 17:13:51 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: The heat is off...

Howdy,

After months *without* crawling around in my garage, I finally got around to 
remove the last traces of old paint on my '58 A model the last few days. 
Well almost, the original primer is still on at most places. It is *much* 
harder to remove. 

The 2000W 600 deg. C BOSCH heater gun I bought easily handled the task. I 
removed a total of 10-12 kilo of bondo, old paint (4 layers!!) and yucky 
mutations from the shell. Thats what one gets when people go crazy with 
sprayfiller!

To my big surprise I found all the uncovered outer panels to be 100% rust 
free. All the bondo/filler was there to 'hide' dents. 
Crazy, instead of knocking out the dents they used filler. The American 
way,....eh? ( just kiddin')

The next weekend I'll take out my BOSCH PEX 125 which is an excenter 
'grinding' machine with rotating speed at 22000RPM. I suspect 1-2 hours in 
the garage with this machine will leave me with a 'bare metal' A coupe.

Then I'll lead load around the Simonsen fender repair panels I used, and 
finish off with Corrorless. The heater gun could be fine for lead loading 
too, the lead comes off after some heating and I guess the gun will be great 
for this task. Anyone tried this?

I hope I'll have more to report from the project soon.....(as do the Car  :-)

cheers,
trond




Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no
Institute for Energy Technology
OECD Halden Reactor Project
P.O Box 173; N-1751 HALDEN Norway
Work; tel   +47 69 183100   fax +47 69 187109
Home; tel +47 69186769

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 11:07:03 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: 914 engine rebuild


Now that the weather is taking a turn for the worse and the body of my
'70 914-4 is ready for its trip to rustoration-land, its time to start 
the engine rebuild.

The goal is to have a very good-looking, streetable 914-4 I can enjoy for 
many years to come.  Once my baby is on the street, then I'll address 
performance issues if there's anything I don't like about the way it drives.

The engine has already been disassembled, cleaned and polished.  The stock
pistons/cylinders didn't, however, come close to specification when they were
measured.  Knowing as little as I did at the time, I opted to purchase a
"big bore" kit(it was cheaper than replacing the stock equipment), and have 
since been wrestling with the issues involved in increasing the displacement
of the stock engine.

I'm aware that it is impossible to slap on extra displacement and improve
performance.  I need to be fully aware of all the issues involved before I
start the rebuild(since I don't want to do it twice).  

In short, what are the required and optional addition modification the engine 
will require to support the 96mm pistons?  Would I be better off in returning 
to stock pistons and cylinders?

I've read that the D-Jetronic is very adaptive without modification.  To
address the additional displacement would 2.0l injectors do the job?  (If I
recall the bore kit uses pistons slightly larger than the stock 2.0)  

The specifications for the camshaft and timing are the same for the 1.7 and
the 2.0 914s, but the value sizes are different.  Are the larger valves crucial
to proper aspiration?

Heater boxes/muffler.  I definitely want an after market muffler, but am not 
sure if modifications to the exhaust system will be required.  What is 
necessary in this area?

You can see from the questions that it would probably be much easier in the
long run if I stuck to a stock engine.  However, I want to know *all* of the
issues involved before I sent the big bore kit back to the supplier.

Thanks in advance,
Jerry

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 09:31:37 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: 928 Stalling


I've seen the thread on the 928 that goes ten miles and stops. As a 
few other people have mentioned, the fuel pump or DME relay could be 
acting up. They are in line with each other on the circuit. They are
also fused. Check all locations. 
If the relays prove to be good, open the hood, and inspect the firewall
electrical connector (take it apart) for corrosion. this has proven to
be a source of similar troubles. This was covered in a recent Panorama
by the PCA 928 Technical man.

Also have the fuel pressure checked to see if the pressure regulator and 
damper are working correctly.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 12:08:33 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine rebuild

Hi Jerry,

Glad to see you're doing it right. Most people forget the critical
"clean and measure everything" step before getting into making decisions
about what they're going to do.

> In short, what are the required and optional addition modification the engine 
> will require to support the 96mm pistons?  Would I be better off in returning 
> to stock pistons and cylinders?

Hard to say. You have a 1.7, right? With the stock 1.7 EFI too, right? So
your big bore kit will take you to just over 1.9 liters. For the engines we
do at Ghost Racing with the NPR big bores, we usually also add a few things:

* balance everything -- crank, rods, flywheel, clutch presure plate, etc.
  You don't have to balance the pistons out of the box, but if you have 
  to deck-cut them, you'll need to do them too.
* high-capacity oil pump
* if it's going to be used "hard" or in very hot climate (like TX, AZ, etc),
  an external oil cooler with fan
* if it's either going to be a long-life or high performance engine, a
  Canton/MECA oil filter setup
* for competition, an Accusump
* for better performance, a FAT Performance "fuel injection cam"
  with new lifters (ALWAYS use new lifters with a new cam!) and new
  timing gear.

None of these things are "required" -- they just make you like the big bore
better. The oil mods allow you to maximize the life of your engine. The cam
gives you 10-15% more power and works very well with the big bore.

> I've read that the D-Jetronic is very adaptive without modification.  To
> address the additional displacement would 2.0l injectors do the job?  (If I
> recall the bore kit uses pistons slightly larger than the stock 2.0)  

Yes. We use stock 2.0 injectors on 1.7 big bore kits. You also *MAY* need
to modify your manifold pressure sensor to be adjustable. With a first-
increment cam, it's usually not required; with the next step up it's almost
a certainty. 

> The specifications for the camshaft and timing are the same for the 1.7 and
> the 2.0 914s, but the value sizes are different.  Are the larger valves crucial
> to proper aspiration?

Depends. On the 2.0, there's absolutely no way that you need any head work
at all. On the 1.7/1.8 heads, it depends. For "normal" street use, you're
probably fine. I would recommend a venturi valve job (different from the 
"racing 3-cut valve job" that some places sell, or the stock two-cut.
For anything where you need to *sustain* over 5400 RPM, you have to do the
math and put your heads on a flow bench. Sometimes it's just a little porting,
sometimes it's new bigger valves. For full-race E Production engines, it's
cut the head in four pieces, weld up and re-cut the whole intake and exhaust
paths, weld the head back together, etc. About $2k a head for state-of-the-art
but that's a 10,000 RPM applications....

Big valves will slow the airflow speed at low RPM causing poor performance 
until you get to the point where they make a diffference. Since that's a
high-RPM application, it's seldom justified on the street.

> Heater boxes/muffler.  I definitely want an after market muffler, but am not 
> sure if modifications to the exhaust system will be required.  What is 
> necessary in this area?

Nothing.  Use a Bursch extractor muffler and stock heat exchangers. The
next step up is a full Kerry Hunter header system, and that's not only
expensive, but you lose the heaters. Not indicated for cars that are not
*MAINLY* competition vehicles.

> You can see from the questions that it would probably be much easier in the
> long run if I stuck to a stock engine.  However, I want to know *all* of the
> issues involved before I sent the big bore kit back to the supplier.

I think I've pretty much covered it. You'll need to check your deck height
and have the high pistons deck-cut to make that the same on all cylinders.
You can run a deck height of 0mm, BTW. You will also need to re-compute
the compression that you get with the cc volume of your heads, the deck
height and your new bore size. You can run up to 9.5:1 on super unleaded,
but extra oil coolin gis *HIGHLY* encouraged at that point. Stock is 7.6:1
and you *SHOULD* have about 8.5:1 or so with the kit as it comes. If you
need more deck height to reduce compression, you can either shim the
barrels or deck cut the pistons, I usually vote for shimming the barrels
but *ALWAYS* shim them all the same. Use Locktite 574 as a case sealer,
not Permatex 3H or *ANY* RTV/silicon/etc product. And good luck!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 13:25:22 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: Help:  944s making high pitched noise

>>
>>> > it makes a high pitched, loud, whining noise.  I think it sounds like a
>>> > turbine my brother thinks it sounds like a vaccuum cleaner.  The noise is
>>> > constant and does not vary significantly if the car is in neutral or in
>>> > gear, if the clutch is pressed in or released.  The noise doesn't vary with
>>
>>> > the rpm either.  I've already tightened the bolts on the exhaust system. 
>>

>>clutch. 
>>
>>Or, it could be that you received a defective throwout bearing.
>>
>>Or, that you assembled the throwout bearing improperly on the pressure plate.
>>
>>
Wait a minute - "the noise doesn't vary with the rpm" - does that mean
that the amplitude doesn't vary, or the frequency, or both? If the
latter, then the answer couldn't be any of the above, but maybe I just
misunderstood what was meant.

 -John White-

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 11:04:17 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Help:  944S making High Pitched Noise

| From: Sanjay Nasta  <sanjay@bga.com>
|
|  Thanks to the detailed directions found in the Porschephiles archive I
|  managed to replace the clutch on my 1987 944S.  However, when I start it up
|  it makes a high pitched, loud, whining noise.  I think it sounds like a
|  turbine my brother thinks it sounds like a vaccuum cleaner.  The noise is
|  constant and does not vary significantly if the car is in neutral or in
|  gear, if the clutch is pressed in or released.  The noise doesn't vary with
|  the rpm or car speed either.  I've already tightened the bolts on 
the exhaust system.
|  Have checked to see if I knocked a hose loose (didn't find one buy
|  perhaps)...The clutch seems to work just perfectly.  Any clues?

GeorgeB mentions the possibility of defective throwout or pilot bearings.
However, the above description makes me think of the radiator fan. This
is a two speed fan which is nearly inaudible at low speed but quite loud
at full speed. Perhaps its (actually, their, there are two fans) controlling
circuit (relay and temp sensor switch) has been defective and up to
now only running the fan at low speed. Now, the nature of the defect
has changed so that the fan is running constantly at high speed.

Just a thought...

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 14:16:36 -0400
From: Jim01j21m@aol.com
Subject: Re: CD-1 tuners remanufactured

From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com

Bert asked...
Does anybody remanufacture the CD-1 or resell restored units?  Do any of 
you do this kind of work or am I better off buying another different unit 
from the local stereo store?  (tuner's shot..I'm ready to buy!!)

I have the CD-2 out of my 89 928GT sitting on my lap as I write this.  The
unit is manufactured by IWAKI ONKYO in Japan and you should be able to get an
authorized agency to repair it.  Mine was replaced by the previous owner
because he felt the tuner quality sucked.  He replaced it with an Alpine
which I am very happy with.  Just have to upgrade the speakers...

Hope this helps!

Jim Mayzurk
89 928GT

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 13:01:54 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; nitromethane and my Moped

 Pete A writes;
 (Later) Yup, sure enough, I looked it up and PURE nitromethane (dragsters 
blend
>it though, don't run it pure) is a monopropellant (there, that's the word),
>and a darn good one too. Specific impulse 210, compared to only 175 for
>>hydrazine or hydrogen peroxide, traditional rocket fuels...

>The top fuel and funny car people have been racing WIITHOUT gearboxes since
>about '88-'89 ish.  Those cars have a direct drive (through a clutch) but no
>gears.  This was made possible by making a different size and MUCH stronger
>ring and pinion set for the diff.  You never hear these guys talk about gear
>boxes exploding or losing gears anymore...

     One of the most exhilirating things I did during college (since I went
 to a school with lots more engineers than women...)  was a "drag race start"
 on my KZ1000; in first gear, feet down, rev the motor the 8krpm--to launch,
 start to slip the clutch and increase throttle to stay near 9krpm. Then
 you perform a balancing act of slipping the clutch out while increasing
 throttle, so after 1 second when the clutch is all the way out you are
 already at redline, and at peak HP the whole time.  This works great (time
 and again) on a motorcycles' multi-plate clutch, I was able to do it -once-
 in my 911 ! Smoke, smell, slip, Visa....

     Dragsters use open-loop "traction control," where a multi-finger clutch
 keeps engaging as the car travels down the quarter; the motor stays at
 6500 rpm, the drivetrain itself finally locks up the last 200 feet.
 Closed-loop traction control was banned after it won 2 years (I think 
 87/88), nowadays actuation of the clutch is probably the key to winning the 
 race; a computer is used only to train on the course (they can still monitor
 tire slippage, they just can't use that information til the next run) to
  setup the clutch.

     Pete, thanks for educating that Nitromethane is a "monopropellant." If
 Air/Fuel mass ratio is 14:1 (for gasoline), and the -volume- of air-fuel is
 11,500:1, imagine how much energy you can pack into a supercharged cylinder 
 if you don't have to worry about so much air !  Supposedly a dragster uses
 like 7 Gallons of fuel during its 5 second run (yes, 28gpm). You'd have a
 hard time dumping over 7 buckets during only 5 seconds.....but actually 
 combusting it is incredible.

    So tech question, what is the correct Air/fuel ratio for nitromethane  
blend  ??  Or, imagine a 600 cubic inch motor (er, engine) runs at 6500 rpm  
 for 5seconds  and uses 7 gallons of fuel...

           Lee A. (enquiring minds want to know...)

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 15:58:37 EDT
From: cohen@ATB.teradyne.com (steve cohen)
Subject: Re: CIS mixture adjustment tool

6mm for a '77 911

I have observed this being done to my '77 911.  This seems to be quite
a touchy adjustment.  My local mechanic charges between $10 and $15 to
do this with an exhaust analyzer.  Seems like a good deal.

A friend of mine tried this adjustment himself on his 911 with a crappy
analyzer.  He ended up with fouled plugs and a tow job.

Good Luck,

 -Steve
