Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 16:11:37 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Porshcephiles and AOL

All, 

First my apologies to some of you that I may have incorrectly advised that
you could use AOL Flashsessions with Windows to download your porschephiles
mail and read it offline. While this is true for almost all Macintosh
versions of AOL that have been released, the Windows versions don't have it
yet.  It alledgedly will be out when version 2.0 comes out.  I never DREAMED
that AOL would leave something so vital out of the Windows versions that had
been in the Mac version for so long. The closest you can come at the moment
is to ask Stan for the digest version rather than individual mail, open your
mail and save it to a file, then read it offline.

Second, if you have version 2.5.1 of the Mac version of AOL (I don't know
about earlier versions), you can now FTP files from the internet, including
porschephiles.  Use Keyword "FTP" , and when you go thru a couple of other
dialog boxes that allow you to enter your own ftp address, simply enter
"tta.com".  You'll see file folders once it connects, and you can find the
Porsche files in the "publications" folder as I recall.  I have NO idea if
any of this works with the Windows versions. This is new to AOL and they
admit it still has some bugs. And given my experiences with the internet, you
won't ALWAYS connect the first time.  My limited experience with this on AOL
is that it is reasonably fast for a modem connection at 9600 baud, actually
better than my convoluted internet connection at work! REMEMBER Stan's rules
about the times to access the files.  If in doubt, read the RULES that he
uploads once a month.

Good luck.

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Just noticed this thread and thought I'd insert this info.  Someone oughta buy 
this car I've seen for sale around these parts for the last 2 years.  It's a 
1971 911T with low low (less than 5K) miles on it.  It's a silver car.  The 
story I remember is that someone bought it new, had a minor fender bender, 
took it to a body shop.  The body shop fixed the car (pretty good job) and the 
owner never showed, died, moved, went to jail, whatever.  The body shop owner 
finally got the title, put the car in storage and there she sat until 
recently.  I first saw the car in a repair shop (does good work) where they 
were getting it out of storage and running.  The owner was asking 25K.  I saw 
it recently and it was still for sale but now for 16K.  The phone is 510 452 
2700.  I have no monetary interest.etc., etc.. Would be nice to see someone 
buy it and do a concours number on it.  So, gentlemen, start your index 
fingers......and dial away.

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 94 11:57:02 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: 356 tires

Hello PBoys (and PGirls). Need some net wisdom on tire and rim choices for the 
C cpe. Thanks in advance for the input. 
 
Currently have 4 1/2 chromes with Michelin 165x15's.  Tires are starting to 
get small cracks in the sidewalls.  Have had this happen with other tires this 
size on the 356's and  912's I've had.  Seems like the cars are so light that 
you can't hardly wear out tires before they die from old age.  I associate 
this condition with a lack of adhesion.  They seem to get hard and lack bite.  
Anyway, these tires are not too sticky.  I push it a bit on local two lanes 
and get perpendicular to the white line a little too easy.  Doesn't bother me 
as much as it rattles oncoming traffic but I would like some sneakers that 
stick a lot better. 
 
Soooo, how large a tire and what brand?  I'd like to keep the car as stock as 
possible for street concours events. What am I limited to with the 4 1/2 rim?  
I can get steel 5 1/2 rims pretty easily.  Chrome one's are another story.  If 
I go for the 5 1/2's, what will fit.  Looked at a 356 cab, 63 with 5 1/2's and 
165s.  There didn't seem to be much air between the fender and tire.    Any of 
you 356 faithful have any ideas and recommendations for brands, tires, 
concepts, ect. Also, do tires lose their adhesion with age and is there any 
preventative steps one can take. I  had a set of Continentals go away in 3 
years/ 6000miles.  Sidewalls cracked and they seemed to "loose their grip".  
Is that my imagination or does it really happen. 
 Thanks again, Ted Smith



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 19:32:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 tires

> Need some net wisdom on tire and rim choices for the 
> C cpe. Thanks in advance for the input. 

Ah. A popular topic.... Gotta be at least, what 2? 3? people with
opinions here.... How's that go again? Skinny is better because... 8{)

> Currently have 4 1/2 chromes with Michelin 165x15's.

Not a bad choice. But there are better.

> Soooo, how large a tire and what brand?  I'd like to keep the car as stock as 
> possible for street concours events. What am I limited to with the 4 1/2 rim? 

I'm running 195/65x15 Pirelli P6s. The last set was P600s, but they got
totaled in an unfortunate incident involving a 50 pound box of roofing
nails. 

Unlike the 9xx cars, the 356 has a special problem: it's a swing axle rear
suspension. That means you get a serious camber change with body roll,
fore-aft weight transfer, and changing phase of the moon. To maximize the
amount of rear tire you keep on the ground with a fairly stock car, you 
need a fairly tall sidewall and a rounded shoulder on the tire. That's
where the problems come in.... that's *NOT* how modern performance tires
are typically built.

You can get Michelin XZX in 165x15, but that's a pretty crummy tire. There
are more options in 185/70x15, but most of them have square shoulders.
There are *SOME* tires in 195/65x15, still having the square shoulder problem,
and you really can't go bigger than that without modifications.

Despite all the really nasty things I say about Pirelli, I use them for
this ONE application. P6, P600, and yes, you can even get CN-36s (which
are just the CN-36 tread carved on a P6 carcass). If you need the CN-36s,
which are a pretty nifty thing for the concours events, they're only 
available from Eurotire in Fairfield NJ or Stamford CT to my knowledge. 
It's supposedly part of some special deal they have that involves the tire
support for the Ferrari Challenge.

Anyway, I'd also consider the Yoko A-382s, since they're slightly rounded.
I use them on my wife's car, but decided to go back with Pirelli for the
356 again.

For serious competition use, you'll have stiffer rear torsion bars, do the
decamber thing, maybe put on a camber snubber or a Z-bar. *THEN* you can
use the modern tires in 185/70 or 195/65! A008s tend to rip your suspension
off. I'd hate to think about using a Goodyear GS-CS or BFG T/A R1. Still,
that's between you and your wallet...

> Also, do tires lose their adhesion with age and is there any 
> preventative steps one can take. 

Absolutely! The rubber hardens and as a result has less adhesion. The best
preventative I've found is to just drive the bejesus out of the car, and
try to wear the tires out first! It's usually worked for me.... (except
this one set of Flintstone umm, errr, Firestone slicks that just wouldn't
wear out....)

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 19:45:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: CIS mixture adjustment tool

Assuming it's the same as the 911, it's a long 3 mm allen wrench. As I 
recall, clockwise richens the mixture.

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 18:09:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: CIS mixture adjustment tool

Hi Andy -

If I remeber right from my 924 days (I had two of them; '77 & '78) it 
takes a long 3mm allen type wrench.  As you adjust the set screw down 
inside the injection body, clockwise raises the sensor plate thus making 
the mixtures richer.  It doesn't take much to adjust this.  A quarter 
turn is too much.  Make a mental note of where allen wrench aligns with 
something to start and adjust maybe only 1/12 of a turn per time.  Then 
drive that car a bit and check your progress.  And also don't put to much 
downward pressure on the wrench as it is adjusted.

Hope this helps.  If this is wrong, maybe Jim Pasha should correct?

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-GGR

> 
> Hi All,
> My '79 924 has some injection problems and I was curious as to what
> size allen wrench the CIS mixture screw would be to see if I have one
> the right size, thus avoiding having to buy another tool I already had!
> Thanks in advance!
> Andy
> Lt40_481055@emuvax.emich.edu
> 
> P.S. Oh yeah, which way does one turn it when viewed from above to richen/
> weakne the mixture, I've heard conflicting reports and wanted the "expert"
> opinion. =)
>

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 22:14:06 -0400

Subject: 914 engine life

Hi all,
My conversations with Josh have brought back a nagging question at the back
of my mind. This is it: 914 140,000 miles, no rebuilds burns oil at the
rate of 1 quart every 900 miles. Smokes only under heavey acceleration or
backing off at high RPM. Corrvette auto X guy named me old smokey. It
smokes alot in these situation. Driving moderately the smoke is not
visiable. Can any body ball park how long the motors last. By the way I
drive a lot of hiway miles. I'm going Lancaster PA to New York city this
weekend. Is this motor ready to die.
Question two: When the motor reaches this point in life I'm I risking
massive engine failure and masive damage to the engine part I would hope to
reuse in a rebuild like the crank after some machine work engine case and .
. . or is it just going to loose compression over time until it one day
won't start?
Finally I have been chasing the FI hesitation slight miss and backfire
through exhaust mostly but sometimes through air filter I was reading in
Hanyes that these syptoms could be burned valves. Does this sound right for
this kind of mileages?
Thanks for the info
Nick

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 22:15:10 -0400

>  Stan mentioned a Porsche Market Letter in a recent posting. I > haven't

> of this before. Any comments or other information?

Brian,

PML is a Porsche only newsletter now in it's 13th year. It collects and
presents Porsche FOR SALE ads nationwide, normally 1000+ ads per monthly
issue. Each issue has an article featuring a Porsche model along with
historical 'asking price' tables from our database.
October was the 912 issue, November is the 914-4/914-6 issue. Subscribers can
advertise free(see another posting today for info on Porschephiles members
advertising FREE). The $55/year subscription includes a copy of Dean
Batchelor's "Illustrated Porsche Buyer's Guide".  A free sample issue is
available for upon request.  Future plans include expanded technical and
informational articles as well as 'online' access. Order line is
(619)727-4856, VISA and MC accepted.

Thanks for your inquiry!

PhilVB, PMLetter@aol.com

My brake upgrade situation as of now is as follows. 911 master cylinder 73

installed this as is fronts locked up first. They locked up way before the

valve with T-junction helped I think maybe it was in my head because it

going to wish I had the valve back to balance things out or can I get a

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 19:53:48
From: mswillis@chilli.win.net (Michael S. Willis)
Subject: Re: 914 engine life


Lots of miles for a 2.0 what can happen you can suck a valve and
really case internal problems.  To rebuild a 2.0 will run 3500 for
a better than factory engine.  You can gain a lot by using euro
spec pistons and barrels which you will need to replace anyway
with those milesl.  do not use the NPR big bore kits they do not
work very well as the rings do not seat.

I would do much to the fuel injection until you get the engine
done and running then ck out the fuel injection as some of the
problems could go away with a good engine.

My guess is that most of your smoke is bad lose valve guides and
rings are gone by now.  

If eng never been rebuilt and you do not have rod knock you should
be in good shape to rebuild your engine with minimal machine work.

                                        mike sacto cal

Date: 26 Oct 94 23:34:04 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: K&N air filters, 356 oil filters

 
Hi, Chris.
 
Good posting. Makes sense to me. I especially like the claim about "flow
straighteners." We should start marketing stick-on "speedlines" to improve
the aerodynamics of our cars -- little tape or wire dealies that extend back
from the edge of the roof, etc. to make the car look like it's zooming
right along.
 
I don't have anything to add to your assessment of K&N (I now have even less
intention to buy them than before I read your post) but your line about
using Knecht filters reminds me.
 
Before this weekend's slalom at Las Vegas, I decided to change the oil and
filter of my 356. For the first time in about four years, I replaced the
rubber gasket in the oil filter canister lid. The old one was fine, but hey,
an Italian filter I bought had a fresh rubber ring in it. Being a little
skeptical of this odd brand Italian filter, I used a Mann
filter but the Italian gasket. Just to be safe, I put the old gasket in my
on-board tool kit. Torqued the filter can lid down tight like it needs to
be, started up, checked for leaks, everything fine. Drove around for two
days, no problems. On the way to Vegas, checked the engine at a fuel stop in
Barstow, everything OK. My co-driver parked the car while I went for
munchies. Coming back, there was a trail of oil leading back from the car,
and a big puddle under it. I followed the trail back, it started 20 ft. past
the fuel pump. Total oil loss under 1 liter, and quick reinstallation of
the old gasket fixed it, but if it had happened underway, it is possible I
would not have noticed oil smoke in my mirrors it until way too late and the
green oil pressure light came on.
 
So I'm returning the remaining stock of my Italian oil filters and sticking
with the German filters and old rubber seal. (I don't use the new German
cardboard seals).
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 22:38:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 brakes and upgrades

> When I
> installed this as is fronts locked up first. They locked up way before the
> rears. Corrective action #1 proportioning valve to the rear all the way.
> Helped but not much valve leaked (It was 20 years old). Next step replace
> valve with T-junction helped I think maybe it was in my head because it
> helped  a little. 

Nope. A T junction should send even more pressure to the back -- a prop.
valve is just not 100% "clear" when adjusted all the way off. So that's
believable.

> Heres the question. How about higher friction pads at the
> rear? Or is this a bad idea. If I do try higher friction pads in back I'm I
> going to wish I had the valve back to balance things out or can I get a
> subtle change in pads? 

This is a bad idea. For starters, it's just about impossible to find
pads with differing coefficients of friction that also have the thermal
properties. So there will be an operating range in which things could
be OK (or more realisticly, could be adjusted to be OK using a prop. valve)
but ove the operating temp range of normal usage, or more particuarly,
SEVERE usage, one end of the other will "go away" first. Probably just
when you need it. Also, there's the future liability issue -- if you've
designed a system that only works with model X pads in front and model Y
pads in rear, and eventually SELL the car to someone that promptly tosses
out your written instructions on how to care for the car, you could have a
really interesting problem on your hand when they have a serious braking
related accident....

> Finally the most expensive fix upgrade rear
> calipiers. I have heard this is harder and more expensive than up front.

You *COULD* do this. For racing, where you don't want/need an ermergency
brake, it's common to use 911 M calipers on the rear. Works really well.
But you won't pass inspection in any state that has a DOT based inspection
program (like TX). Hence, it's not a great idea for street cars.

Best idea: a dual master cylinder with adjustable bias bar. Should be
about $200 or so, some fabrication required to make it work for your
car. Tilton, Neal, JFZ all make good parts. Then you can fine-tune
your braking as you like it.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 23:05:53 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine life

> This is it: 914 140,000 miles, no rebuilds burns oil at the
> rate of 1 quart every 900 miles. Smokes only under heavey acceleration or
> backing off at high RPM. 
> ...
> Can any body ball park how long the motors last.

Sounds like it's time. If not now, soon.

> Question two: When the motor reaches this point in life I'm I risking
> massive engine failure and masive damage to the engine part I would hope to
> reuse in a rebuild like the crank after some machine work engine case and .
> . . or is it just going to loose compression over time until it one day
> won't start?

Here's the deal: 914 cranks rarely break but often bend. The big problem
is that if the main bearings have gone, the case center is likely 
pounded out. Or worse, there may have been fretting at the edges of 
the case or on the center webs. In either of those situations, the case
is worthless and cannot be reused. Good used cases are only about $150,
but still... So, you have to send the crank and rods out to be checked,
and may have to toss the case. Beyond that, I'd bet that the cam is
toast, and if you replace that, you also have to replace the lifters.
Plus, you will likely need to replace the pistons and cylinders, and
may need to have cracked heads repaired if it's a 2.0 or a 1.8 (don't
ask me why the 1.7s don't crack, they just don't). And of course a
valve job, with new guides, seals, and almost certainly, exhaust valves.

> Finally I have been chasing the FI hesitation slight miss and backfire
> through exhaust mostly but sometimes through air filter I was reading in
> Hanyes that these syptoms could be burned valves. Does this sound right for
> this kind of mileages?

Don't even bother chasing this until you have the rest of the engine done.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Oct 1994 21:40:02 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 944 belt sprocket wear

Jim Pasha:
>One thing, there are some toothed gears on both belts, if these develop pits
>on the driven surfaces, replace them.

Jim (and others),

Are pits the only thing to worry about?  For example, have you ever
seen the *edges* of the teeth wear to such an extent that replacement is
advised?

I am about ready to replace both belts on my car, which has now racked
up 106 Kmiles (not on the same two belts, of course :-)).  Part of me
wants to just go ahead and replace the sprockets and idlers as a
"routine" maintenance operation, but since I didn't see any obvious
signs of wear the last time I tensioned the belts, the other side of
me say is saying "if it ain't broke ..."

 -Milo
MiloDorr@netcom.com
'86 guards red 951

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 10:17:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: "N. Jay Ellis" <ellisn@iia.org>
Subject: 951 suspension upgrade options

In my quest to turn a stock non-S 951 into the ultimate track car, 
I've discovered two different methods (so far) of upgrading the 
suspension.  An article in Up Fixin Der Porsche vol. 7 describes
the installation of stiffer springs, a larger sway bar, and larger 
torsion bars to match.  This is confirmed by what I see at the track
as well as what I read from other p-philers.  

As an alternative, a mechanic I've been using lately has suggested a 
different approach:

1) Install larger (30mm) sway bar in front
2) Install coil-over shocks with adjustable ride height (400lb springs 
   front, 250lb or 350lb springs in back)
3) Leave torsion bars alone
4) Test car at track, and adjust ride height and/or change springs 
   in rear until car performs as desired
    
I think his theory is that the springs in back will take the place of
the stiffer torsion bars, and will be less costly to swap in and out
if additional changes are desired. 

I'd appreciate any comments on this approach, especially from those 
who have 951 track cars.  Thanks.

Jay Ellis
ellisn@iia.org
'87 951 Guards Red
'89 Feline Tigger
'92 Feline Grisabella


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 10:24:34 -0400
From: TommyWmson@aol.com
Subject: Vintage Racing & Auto. Atlanta

Just got back from Atlanta, where I spent 2 fun filled days
drooling over cars that are worth more than I'll make in my
lifetime.  The Sportscar Vintage Racing Assoc. held an event 
at Road Atlanta and about 200 vintage racers showed up. Lots of
356's, a few 911's and a 906 were there.

Wow, what a weekend. Of course, now I have the "racing bug".

While I was in Atlanta, I dropped by the famous shop of "Dr 914",
Automobile Atlanta.  Nice collection of 914's, 914-6's, 914-6GT's 
and a 916. A little disappointed that they were all behind glass, but
I can understand that he didn't want my drool and paw prints all over
them.  While I was there I picked up a few low dollar items even 
though I may have been able to get them cheaper somewhere else.
One of the parts I needed was the ignition switch for my 914. I told
George the symptom's and he said that the plastic switch usually
cracks and that it was easy to replace. I asked how big a job it was
and he said if I had the car with me, it would only take him about 15
minutes. Since the car was 400 miles away, George brought out a
complete steering column and switch assembly and showed me how
to do it! This probably saved me several hours of frustration because
I would not have thought that I needed to put the key in the switch 
and release the steering lock in order to get the switch assembly out.
I guess it sometimes pays to buy parts from a guy who knows about
your car.


Tommy
73 914 2.0L

tommywmson@aol.com

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 11:07:52 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: 951 suspension upgrade options

Torsion bars are not that bad if you are mathmatically minded.

I uprated mine from 24 mm to 26mm (38% increase) by measuring angular
sweep of the 24mm bar, then calculating (by multiplying by 62%) the
angular sweep req'd by the new torsion bars, adjusting the inital
rotation of the trailing arem accoringly, and setting the 26mm to that
position.

Alone, without a lift it took about 8hrs and was very close the first
try.  Contraty to popular beleif, the eccentric on the trailing arm
gives .75" of rear height adjustment eah way from center, so you don't
really have to be that close on the torsion bar adjustment.

The problem with the spring-seat rear shocks is that the springs rare
lightly preloaded at normal ride height (unless you pull the torsion
bars and back them off), so they "clank" as the car comes off the rear,
such as under decelleration.

Secondly, the shocks/springs  are VERY expensive.

If yo ucan decide what spring rate you want in the rear, you can
calculate the diameter of the torsion bars, install them, and be pretty
close.  I think something like 30MM woul dbe pretty radical for a track
car (244% as stiff as stock 86, 191% as stiff as TurboS ) it's not a
bad setup.  At @$ 200 per pair it's pretty cost effective even if you
guess wrong once.

------------------------------

Date: 27 Oct 94 11:18:36 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Nitromethane and my moped

 
Hi, Lee.
 
I just found a reference to nitromethane in the excellent new book "High
Performance" this morning. It seems drag racers run 2:1 or even 1:1 air/fuel
ratios while dumping straight nitromethane into the cylinders. I guess
rocket engines, open at one end, can go from liquid state to combustion
by-products with no problem, but I guess it's impractical fill the entire
combustion chamber with liquid and then light it off...
 
Stoichiometric air/fuel ratio; lessee if I get this right, chemists please
help/feel free to correct.
 
Nitromethane is CH3NO2 (3 and 2 subscripts, of course, can't do it here).
 
4 CH3NO2  + 3 02  --> 4 CO2 + 6 H2O + 2 N2
 
(not considering the CO2 or N2 in air; simplified version, it goes through
unchanged)
 
So yeah, for complete combustion you add oxygen. (How do rockets do it? Why
is this then a monopropellant, no oxidizer required for rocket use?
Anybody?)
 
Specific weight of nitromethane is 61.04 grams/mole. Oxygen in air has a
mole fraction of .2095, so you need 28.967/.2095  = 138.3 grams of air to
get a mole of oxygen.
 
So air/fuel ratio for stoichiometric combustion of nitromethane is
 
[138.3 x 3] / [61.04 x 4] = 1.699.  By comparison, the stoichiometric
air/fuel ratio for 2,2,4 trimethylpentane (close enough to gasoline),
C8H18, is as follows:
 
2 C8H18 + 25 O2 --> 16 CO2 + 18 H2O plus all the inert stuff,
 
AFR = (25 x 138.3) / (2 x 114.223) = 15.13, there's that magic
15:1 air/fuel ratio we always hear about.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 94 08:30:43 -0700
From: jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com (jim gregory)
Subject: re: 951 suspension upgrade options



Jay-

As an alternative, a mechanic I've been using lately has suggested a 
different approach:

1) Install larger (30mm) sway bar in front
2) Install coil-over shocks with adjustable ride height (400lb springs 
   front, 250lb or 350lb springs in back)
3) Leave torsion bars alone
4) Test car at track, and adjust ride height and/or change springs 
   in rear until car performs as desired
    

*this is what my mechanic is advocating also. anyone tried this yet?

 -jim g

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 94 09:24:31 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 944 Pulleys; Addendum


Milo, 

One thing I forgot to mention when inspecting all toothed gears and pulleys,
if the pulley teeth have tooth wear from the belt and/or pits, replace them.

Tooth wear is when there is a perceptable ridge or shoulder from the belt
passing over the tooth. This erosion is the same as metal-to-metal wear,
eventually there will be a problem. If you can feel a shoulder by pulling
your fingernail across the DRIVEN face, replace it. It will wear a new belt
too.

This is one good reason to ALWAYS have the timing belt covers on while the
vehicle is in service. The dirt and crud present when driving will 
destroy a belt and the gears in a short period of time.

If everything is in good order, then okay. If you, the owner, has a doubt,
replace the component.

Jim Pasha

Subject: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)

Hello Porschephiles,

I'm new to the list, I've been lurking for a while to see if you are a
friendly bunch. It looks as if you are, so I'll post a question or
two.

I've just recently become very interested in owning a Porsche. Either
356 or 911. Don't get me wrong, the others are nice cars, but the shape
and the idiosyncratic arrangement for these cars makes them very
special.

What I'd really like to do is to restore one of these models, but I've
never restored a car before. However I hate to see a beautiful thing
grow old. I do some simple maintenence on my wife's MG Midget ('72)
but this is her daily driver and doesn't really need too much work at
the moment. I'm attending a course in car restoration where I'm
learning bodywork/coachbuilding type skills. I should be learning some
mechanical restoration skills next year.

>From what I read here a number of you maintain and restore your own
Porsches. Do you find them difficult to work on? I'm inclined to think
that restoring a Porsche as a first project is probably more than I
could/should handle. Would I be better to start with a simpler car?
I've considered starting with a VW Beetle as these seem to be fairly
easy to work on, not too expensive, and might present me with some of
the problems I might encounter on a Porsche. Is this a good idea? Have
any of you restored both? How do they compare (as a project)?

I'd be interested to hear your opinions,

Chris Willis

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 16:35:07 +0500
From: "Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com" <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Re: Speed Shifting and drag racing

Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com> wrote
>(This begs the question, why bother running nitromethane through something as
>inherently inefficient as a piston engine, when you could be using it as
>reaction mass for a rocket car? Answer: advertising. Detroit isn't selling
>road rockets yet, and the fans might find the rocket cars and other forms of
>weenie roasters interesting but not part of real racing.)

Another answer which may or may not be more likely:  
In Arizona, or New Mexico, there is this sled test, which is a car on railroad 
tracks.  When the company I work for was making the inertial guidance systems 
for the Apollo missions, and other spacecraft and missles, they made these
accelerometers which they bolted to the sled and sent down the track to test.
Similar to a drag race, but no other sled next to it.  The G forces
measured on this sled were far beyond what a human could withstand without
coming out of a drivers seat in the form of a pancake (eyes in back of head,
most internal organs flattened against rear of the rib cage, etc.  You get
the idea, its Halloween right?).  They would put outdated or surplus missle 
engines on the back of this sled.  I know NASA put animals, and astronauts
on this type of sled, to see the effects and what rates lateral G forces can be
sustained by humans.  The sleds can pull 200+ G's and reach Mach 6.  The 
limiting factor of speed at sea level is aerodynamics and heat.  Humans who 
pilot fighter planes blackout at around 6 to 10 G's, and a guy who worked 
for NASA won a congressional medal of honor to sit on that sled and see what 
the limitations of the human body were.  They found out that the limiting 
factor of acceleration or deceleration on a human was the point where your 
eyeballs pop out of your head.  This happens at about 25 G's, and the guy 
nearly lost his eyesight.  A rocket car could be made that would make you 
a winner of the race for sure, but never be able to see the prize money.

 -Barry Chapin		Draper Laboratory, Cambridge, MA
1981 911SC Turbo-body Targa
These are my opinions, not anyone elses.

Date: 27 Oct 94 11:18:40 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 tires

 
Hi, Ted Smith.
 
My personal recommendation is to get those 5 1/2 inch wheels or have your
present wheels widened if/when you rechrome them (not that expensive, in fact
it should be free if you decide to have the wheels
rechromed, as part of the rechroming process is to cut off the
old rims and weld fresh ones on; it's not worth trying to get a smooth
surface on old pitted rims). I like Bridgestone RE71 tires, size
195/60 x 15. If you get these, you won't be sorry. They stick and last a long
time in regular driving. Yes, they are a bit smaller in diameter than stock,
but I have zero problems with clearance.
 
On 4 1/2 inch rims, it is going to be hard to find modern performance
rubber.
 
I don't concours, but I understand that 5 1/2 wheels are accepted now,
without penalty points (anybody differ?)
 
You might consider an extra set of 5 1/2 and keep the 4 1/2 (and you
should keep them, unchanged, if they are the original rims from the car,
with correct date stamps; note that not all wheels on a car need to have
exactly the same date stamp). For concours, Stan's CN36 suggestion sounds
good, and you can also get Continental Contact tires, new, in 165 SR 15.
Continental and Dunlop were OE suppliers to Porsche; I don't think Pirelli
supplied tires for 356s.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 17:47:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Loelle S Poneleit" <poneleit@student.msu.edu>
Subject: Re: K&N filters


>
> - This is my biggest concern and one which I'm surprised K&N is admitting
> to. Basically, K&N is saying that when the filter is clean, you get lots
> of air (and presumably dirt). As the dirt builds up, it serves to block
> the dirt which was passing though when the filter was clean. Given their
> claim that the air flow remains high for an 'extraordinary period of
> time', imagine how much dirt makes it into the engine before the dirt
> accumulates enough to become a filtering medium. On the other hand, paper
> filters are designed to block out ALL dirt from the beginning.

I remember reading that during desert storm that K&N filters were instaled in
hummers because the paper filters were not up to the job.

better than later I have a dilema. The 914 is my only car for at least a
year. So how much would it be to buy a core 2.0l motor that has a good case
and a good chance of having a usable crank and good heads. What about the
possibility of buying one with an induction system, preferably FI. Is 3500
dollars a resonable budget to get a 2.0l core motor and build it with a cam
and euro pistons. Is there a big bore kit that works better than the
slapping NPR kit that is cost effective. The extra oil cooling suggested
earlier for a similar project was external oil cooler and hi volume oil
pump. My goal is a reliable 130-140hp are these resonable modifications to
get there in this kind of budget. I plan on doing all the work that doesn't
require machining myself. The ideal would be to get the motor working
outside of the car, so the only down time would be instalation. One weekend
I hope.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 18:03:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Changing shocks on '86 911

> 1) Anything special involved in changing the struts and
> shocks on my '86 Carrera ?  Basically, is is simple enough to
> do without the factory manuals and do I need any special
> tools ?  I need the ride height adjusted anyway so I figured I do
> the shocks then drive to my mechanic and have the height
> adjusted.

It's no big deal, but it's SOOOOO much easier to do with air tools
that it's not even funny...  Find out what your mechanic want for
the labor first. You an spend a couple of hours doing this with
hand tools, but do all four in half an hour with air tools and
a little experience. This is one of those deals where the Flat Rate Manual
works very heavily in the mechanic's favor...

> 2) It has been suggested that I have the car lowered when
> I have the height adjusted.  I plan to track the car a 2-3
> times a year and do auto-X's with it.  It's also my daily driver
> during the summer.  Is lowering really a Good Thing or
> a Bad Compromise ?

Lowering the car much more than to Rest of World specs is not a
great idea unless you bump up the spring rates and shock dampning
rates. I used to run my Euro 911 at RoW height and found that I
only had parts drag on the ground coming out of or goin into very
steep driveways.

> 3) I have a dragging front (?) caliper that makes a moaning
> sound.  What's the fix for this ?

Have the caliper rebuilt. As your mechanic about this.

> 4) My helmet hits the roof unless I open the sunroof.  
> Would and aftermarket racing seat sit lower enough
> to get around this problem ?  (I don't have sport seat
> so I'm interested in getting another seat to put in for
> "play" days.)

Maybe. You can have the brackets altered more easily on many of the
aftermarket seats than the stock seats. Best value is an aluminum
stock car seat for about $150 (see ads in Circle Track and Stock Car
Racing). Best seat is a Recaro, priced from $500 to as much as you
want to spend. Sparco also has a good fiberglass seat, nicely
padded with Nomex, for not too much.

Stan

     N.O.S. stuff, can I ask that you mention the need for the following?
     
     - slider control on dash
     - 6v elec. fuel pump
     - glass fuel filter and lines
     - solid fuel line
     - mounting brackets
     - exhaust duct
     - relay
     
     Thanks, buddy.
     
     By the way,  I'm still holding parts for you.  If you successfully 
     help me locate the stuff above, I'll send you the parts you wanted for 
     free!  Is there any 356 stuff you want me to enquire about here in the 
     U.S.?
     
     Derek Au


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
     
Howdy,
     
After months *without* crawling around in my garage, I finally got around to 
remove the last traces of old paint on my '58 A model the last few days. 
Well almost, the original primer is still on at most places. It is *much* 
harder to remove. 
     
The 2000W 600 deg. C BOSCH heater gun I bought easily handled the task. I 
removed a total of 10-12 kilo of bondo, old paint (4 layers!!) and yucky 
mutations from the shell. Thats what one gets when people go crazy with 
sprayfiller!
     
To my big surprise I found all the uncovered outer panels to be 100% rust 
free. All the bondo/filler was there to 'hide' dents. 
Crazy, instead of knocking out the dents they used filler. The American 
way,....eh? ( just kiddin')
     
The next weekend I'll take out my BOSCH PEX 125 which is an excenter 
'grinding' machine with rotating speed at 22000RPM. I suspect 1-2 hours in 
the garage with this machine will leave me with a 'bare metal' A coupe.
     
Then I'll lead load around the Simonsen fender repair panels I used, and 
finish off with Corrorless. The heater gun could be fine for lead loading 
too, the lead comes off after some heating and I guess the gun will be great 
for this task. Anyone tried this?
     
I hope I'll have more to report from the project soon.....(as do the Car  :-)
     
cheers,
trond
     
     
     
     
Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no
Institute for Energy Technology
OECD Halden Reactor Project
P.O Box 173; N-1751 HALDEN Norway
Work; tel   +47 69 183100   fax +47 69 187109 
Home; tel +47 69186769

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 18:24:42 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engines

> So how much would it be to buy a core 2.0l motor that has a good case
> and a good chance of having a usable crank and good heads. What about the
> possibility of buying one with an induction system, preferably FI. 

I just did this exercise for another list member in a similar situation.
Core's *ARE* available, sometims with EFI, sometimes not. Odds are 50-50 
on any piece of the core being usable. Rods are *USUALLY* not a problem 
unless you're building some kind of competition motor where you just don't
want to even think about using reconditioned rods. The crank, case, and
heads all automaticly need to be cleaned and checked carefully. If you
can't use the case, good used is about $150. If you can't use the heads,
they can be fixed, or you can go looking for more. 2.0 heads in good
shape are *VERY* hard to find, BTW. If it has the EFI still intact, you
can use everything but the injectors and probably the injection points.

> Is 3500
> dollars a resonable budget to get a 2.0l core motor and build it with a cam
> and euro pistons. 

*NO*. Euro pistons alone are $800 as of two days ago. We figured that we
could get a core engine, do all the work, and have it ready to ship for
about $6500. There was only $1100 of labor in that price.

> Is there a big bore kit that works better than the
> slapping NPR kit that is cost effective. 

No.  There are no good 914 big bores. Next question.

> The extra oil cooling suggested
> earlier for a similar project was external oil cooler and hi volume oil
> pump. 

Yes. And you still  need that if you change the HP output on the engine.
Unless, of course, you live north of the artic circle...

> My goal is a reliable 130-140hp are these resonable modifications to
> get there in this kind of budget. I plan on doing all the work that doesn't
> require machining myself. 

Dream on. You *CAN* get 120HP out of a streetable engine. You *CAN NOT* get
a long life from that engine. Maybe 45-50k miles tops. And while I have
no doubt that most of the people on the list *COULD* build an engine in
their driveway using a $99 set of Craftsman sockets and get it to sort of
run, trying to build a performance engine with no experience, none of the
special tools, none of the industry contacts, and have it be your FIRST
engine is sort of like OJ Simpson suddenly deciding to defend himself....

For your application and budget, the best thing you can do is call up 
FAT, RIMCO, or GEX and get a 914 long block sent out to you for about $1200.
It'll take all weekend to swap the sheet metal, EFI, etc. but it's 
cheap and quick. Make sure if you currently have a 2.0 that you get a
*914* 2.0 with the three-stud heads instead of a Type II 2.0...

If you had more money, I'd suggest you call Ghost Racing and get a real
engine...

Stan

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 19:57:56 -0400

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 19:30:23 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)

> What I'd really like to do is to restore one of these models, but I've
> never restored a car before.

Don't start with a Porsche. You'll kill yourself before you're done.
You need to understand the process so you'll know what *MUST* be done,
and what it's going to take to do it.

> From what I read here a number of you maintain and restore your own
> Porsches. Do you find them difficult to work on? I'm inclined to think
> that restoring a Porsche as a first project is probably more than I
> could/should handle. Would I be better to start with a simpler car?
> I've considered starting with a VW Beetle as these seem to be fairly
> easy to work on, not too expensive, and might present me with some of
> the problems I might encounter on a Porsche. Is this a good idea? Have
> any of you restored both? How do they compare (as a project)?

I'd recommend that you start with a '63 VW Beetle. It's easier, cheaper,
the parts are more available, and when you're done, it's still a nice
car with decent market value.

I've done early Jags, pre-1950 VWs, many different Porsches, tube-frame
race cars from the dim past, and Mustangs. They *ALL* take the same
amount of work. They all have the same sorts of things wrong with them.
The difference is in what you have when you're done, and how much the
parts cost.

Good luck.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 94 17:40:44 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Parking Brake, parts fiche

| From: Carl Brian Klinetob  <vp@strauss.udel.edu>
|
| 	I need a little help with adjusting my parking brake.  There was a
| discussion about this before in which someone said there are two
| adjustments: one at the handle and on at the rear wheels.  The haynes
| manual I have also says this but only show illustrations for rear drum
| brakes.  Mine has disk and I was unable to find any way to adjust the
| cable there.  Can anyone help me?  Thanks.

Haynes shows drums because the parking brakes *are* drums.
These are miniature drum brakes in the hub of the rear disk rotors.
The parking brake adjusts just like you would expect of a drum
setup: turn the star adjuster to spread the drums apart or vice
versa. You need to jack the car and remove the rear wheels
because the access hole for the star nut is between a pair of
wheel lugs.

The only real problem you might encounter would be if
the parking brakes had been neglected long enough
for the star wheel to be "frozen" on its threads. Disassembling
the hub is not fun because of the stub axle nut: it's torqued
to 400 ft/lbs. And, if the car has been driven a lot with the
parking brake engaged, then the shoes may be worn
out. This would be an extreme case though.

At any rate, adjust the shoes to the point that they rub when the
hub is spun and then back off until they just no longer rub. If, at
this point, the parking brake lever still comes up too high, then
you will need to adjust the cable nut underneath the lever.

* The Parts Fiche

I had forgotten exactly how the parking brake went together,
so I looked at my parts fiche.

The official parts fiche for your year and model car is a
great source of information. Not only do they give the part
numbers so you can order replacement parts, but they are
composed of exploded diagrams of every assembly in the
car. Viewing the fiche, you can tell what parts disassemble,
what they look like, and more or less how they fit together.

If you don't have a parts fiche, go to the dealer and get one.
The local dealer gave me an old one free of charge. Most
libraries have fiche readers and some have readers with
built in photocopiers so you can get hard copy diagrams.
I consult the parts fiche more often than the factory service
manual, although the manual is a valuable source of info
if you intend to do serious repairs.

BTW, the dealer (Barrier Motors)gave me a great PCA discount
on the service manual: $165. Most mail order places get nearly
a hundered bucks more.

Eric
'84 944, Ruby Red, daily driver & auto-x source of embarrassment
'93 Mercury Villager, Forest Green, family transporter
'56 Sheryl, loving spouse
'78 Larisa, '89 Zoe, '92 Sasha, smart, beautiful daughters

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 20:47:22 -0400
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: 914 engine choices

Hi all,
Now I know what a four banger is going to cost to get 120hp it is not
really an option in my mind. Now The body of the 914 isn't perfect, but all
structural rust was removed last winter so all that is left are some
bubbles in the sail panel and front fenders. These are very small. And of
course there is the rusty rear trunk floor. I can live without fixing this
for a while longer.
Now with the motor. The way I look at it is I have two serious options. One
3.0SC motor with modified body or FI to fit under the rear trunk, or a 2.0
six built out to 2.4 and carborated. Now I am inclined to the 3.0 with FI
because of reliability and CIS. But what about emissions with this motor.
For it to pass will I have to come up with a fancy custom exhaust that has
catalytic converters
Engine choice two: a built 2.0 six. Going this route do I avoid all
emission regs. Finally the 914 is mainly a blast because of low wieght in
my mind. How big a weight penalty for the 3.0 over 2.4.
I would probably right now go with the cheapest lightest solution. And I
already did the brakes so maybe now that the car stops fast I should make
it go fast.
Nick

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 16:55:04 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 Tires

Thanks to all who responded with tire suggestions for my 914.
I ended up getting a set of Yokohama AVS Intermediates as they
were only slightly more expensive than the Dunlop D60M2's that I had
been considering.  Ordered them from The Tire Rack on Monday around
2PM central time.  The guy says they should arrive in 2 - 4 days.
I'm thinking "Yeah, right.  A couple of days to process the order, a few
more days bouncing around on a UPS truck -- they'll arrive sometime
next week."  Well, they were waiting for me when I got home yesterday
(Wednesday).  Now that's FAST service!!

I noticed that each tire has a small red mark on the sidewall.  I had heard
that tires come marked to indicate which point is lightest (heaviest?), but
never really believed it.  I mean, it's got to be balanced on the rim anyway,
right?  Maybe the story is true after all?

BTW, I chickened out on trying to fit the 195's and ended up getting 185/65R15's.
The 185's look much wider and has much squarer shoulders than my old
Roadhandlers.  I'm sure I will be very pleased with them.  Thanks again.

Pete Klager

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 94 18:27:17 PDT
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: 911 prices


- --Boundary-4694116-0-0

I recently bought a 78 SC in #1 condition, all options with 56K miles for 
13.5K.  It needed shocks and tires, about $1000.00. Real prices, selling not 
asking, seem to be from 10K to 15K depending on miles, condition, etc.  Tell 
your friend that it's a lot cheaper to buy a real nice one that needs little  
or nothing than it is to buy a 150K miler that needs paint, interior or any 
other repairs.  They don't break easily but they ain't cheap to fix. Good 
Luck,   
Ted Smith


- --Boundary-4694116-0-0

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 21:21:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: Jeff Francis <jeff@prufrock.bga.com>
Subject: Motors Make Music

	Earlier this evening I stopped by my favorite local bookstore
to see what was new.  This month's issue of the British magazine "Car"
has an article on the new C4.  Buried deep within the article is a
sentence that caught my undivided attention.  It states that somebody
has recorded 45 minutes of the sound of a 911 motor on CD.  The author
says it's selling like hotcakes in Japan.  All right, call me wierd,
strange, and perhaps obsessed, but I WANT ONE!  Unfortunately, there
are no other details.  I stopped by several CD stores on the way home,
and got some rather interesting looks when I described what I was
hunting.  None of them had the slightest luck in locating it.  Has
anybody else heard of this?  Anybody know where to order it?  Or who
publishes it?

	Of course, once I find it, I'll have to memorize the rev
patterns, then drive around town in my truck with the windows down and
the stereo up high...

- --Jeff Francis--
'91 Ford Pickup (well, at least it has *six* cylinders...)

for LOW mileage cars(40 - 70k?) and pay a bit more for a fun car you can
drive for many miles!
Good luck!

	didn't mention pre-'78 911s
	'78-'83 were the SCs.  3.0 liter
	'84-'88 were the Carreras.  3.2 liter
	'89-current were the Carrera 2's and 4's (this was before the 993)

I was informed that the '89 was still a Carrera and had a 3.2 liter engine
while the C4 had the 3.6 liter engine.  However, I never asked about the
body style.  Does the '89 Carerra (3.2 liter) have the body of the previous
Carrera's or does it share the body style of the 964?  The reason I am asking
is the in an advertisement in Automobile magazine (December 1994) on page
157, Prestige Imports shows an '89 Porsche 911 Cabriolet.  It has the 964
style body, though.  Is this a mistake or do the '89s all have 964 body
styles?

Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 23:50:59 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine choices

> Now with the motor. The way I look at it is I have two serious options. One
> 3.0SC motor with modified body or FI to fit under the rear trunk, or a 2.0
> six built out to 2.4 and carborated. Now I am inclined to the 3.0 with FI
> because of reliability and CIS. But what about emissions with this motor.
> For it to pass will I have to come up with a fancy custom exhaust that has
> catalytic converters

Yup. That's essentially correct.

> Engine choice two: a built 2.0 six. Going this route do I avoid all
> emission regs. Finally the 914 is mainly a blast because of low wieght in
> my mind. How big a weight penalty for the 3.0 over 2.4.

You can get a lot of power out of a 2.4, in fact, you can get as much
out of a 2.4 as the bone stock US spec 3.0. Go look up the HP for the
various 911s sometime -- the '72-3 911S made more power than any non-turbo
911 until the '81 Euro 911SC.

> I would probably right now go with the cheapest lightest solution. And I
> already did the brakes so maybe now that the car stops fast I should make
> it go fast.

I'd vote for the 2.4E-on-a-2.0 case plan. If you pick a '68 or earlier
case number, it's technically a '68 engine and free as far as emissions
go.

Stan

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 02:15:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)

> 	Stan has had his hands on British iron! What models Stan? Those 
> 	of us porschephiles who are also on the Jaguar mailing list want
> 	to know. :-) 

Series II XKE. V-12. Roadster. Of course. 8{) But what I really
want is an XK-140 in decent shape... One of these days....

>	If you are saying that the amount of work is the same
> 	it would almost seem like it would make sense to put the work into 
> 	a car that will be worth more in the end. 

Yes and no. That only applies if you get it right. I did a ground-up
body-off-pan resto on my wife's '73 Beetle that she bought new in '73
after it suffered some serious heavy collision damage. It was worse than
some of the rusted out 356s I've worked on. Was it worth it? I think
so. Still, what I have is a perfect $7000 car with $22000 in it. On the
other hand, when I helped a friend do his 300 SL gullwing, the labor
was the same (we did spend a *BIT* more time getting the plating right)
but the parts cost was probably at least an 15 times higher. Is his car
"worth it"?? I *really* don't know -- the collector market flattened
out so the cash value is low relative to the net investment, but he has
a DAMN nice car...

And, you might get it wrong... A not-quite-up-to-speed resto on a fairly 
common car ('63 VW for instance) won't hurt the value of the car; on the 
other hand, butchering (the offical Dead Car Society term for not quite 
getting it right) say a Carrera GS or an 550RSK or an XK-SS even could have 
quite a different turn: not only will you not learn anything from the 
experience, but you'll have spent a lot of money to reduce the value of 
the car you love...

Turning out a less than spectacular S-90 Cab isn't *QUITE* in that league,
but it's close. I certainly feel that if you've never done a resto, that
you should start with something easy. If you've done *ANY*, then you probably
know enough to do the research on what to do for an early Porsche.

I *ONLY* do restos these days either for paying customers, or on cars
I personally want to keep for a long, long time.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 10:13:15 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Sleeping at the 'Drag Show'.(Too long...)

Hiall,

>   As someone who has fallen asleep at a John Cougar Mellonhead concert, I
>can understand Trond

>youth or whatever, off we went.  He got into a set that I didn't care for
>and managed to fall asleep, much to the surprise to everyone around.
> 
>Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
> 81 SC Pacific Blue - Der Luft-Klub fur Manner
> 

Deaf? Who? Me? Naah,...I can hear a squirrel fahrt from across the Valley! 
(Remember Norway *IS* a little land... ;^)

The real reason I feel asleep was the saturday night party, I was signed up 
as an assistant to our local newspaper sport journalist, a friend of mine, 
and this just to get in for free, lookaround in the pits and generally have 
all them PRESS benefits.
A *HUGE* outdoor party with zillions bottle of Beer, Vodka and 'Moonshine'. 

The only *real* nice happening that weekend was something that occured when 
tracelling to the dragraces Friday evening. We picked up some girls with a 
broken up car along the road, and got invited to a party. They served us 
real nice, food a beer and...... (NO, not *That*!) but a couple of hours rest.

The funny part was when my pal, we were actually 3 that went down there, 
started hitting on some of the girls(YES,...*some* of them!). He being a 
rather serious 'Don Juan' we soon started to think that we might not reach 
the Motel at Mantorp Park (yes guys, that is in Sweden) in time.

Sometimes a man has to do things he are not proud over, but the life of a 
man is intricate. The other guy and I, merged with the people at the party 
and , secretely to our friend, informed them to be careful around him. We 
actually told all the girls that he was a rapist out on parole and that they 
shouldn't be alone in a room with him, and all the boys that he was a 
homosexual.
(Please note: I am not single minded, and try to accept people as they are!!)
After that statement I go on with the story; What seem to be a long night in 
Karlstad,(between Halden, Norway and Mantorp in Sweden) reached an 
anticlimax for our friend, and 20 minutes later he suggested we should get 
in the car and head for the Motel. 

cheers,
Trond

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 11:11:20 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)

Stan et al.

>Series II XKE. V-12. Roadster. Of course. 8{) But what I really
>want is an XK-140 in decent shape... One of these days....
Nice car, but personally I prefer the XK120. I think the 140 & 150 series 
are inbetweens,...but thats *my* opinion. I take it for granted you want a 
roadster, the FHC's look to strange.

>Turning out a less than spectacular S-90 Cab isn't *QUITE* in that league,
>but it's close.
I agree with Stan, open cars are woth almost double to coupe's and they need 
to be 100% to justify top prices.

But don't let your own skills stop you from putting that 'non-restorable' 
old car back on the road! Even if your first restoration might only be 
'good', your next will be better and so on. 
The importance of pre restoration research is tremendous, reading a few 
books and familiarizing with the car one have/want to restore and having 
faith in oneselfs abilities will do 'half the job'.(The other half is the 
tools.... ;-)
 
Trond

Date: 28 Oct 94 09:39:21 EDT
From: Richard Grayson <76226.3526@compuserve.com>
Subject: First Restoration Car

> 
Stan replied...
> I'd recommend that you start with a '63 VW Beetle. It's easier, cheaper,
> the parts are more available, and when you're done, it's still a nice
> car with decent market value.
> 
> I've done early Jags, pre-1950 VWs, many different Porsches, tube-frame
> race cars from the dim past, and Mustangs. They *ALL* take the same
> amount of work. They all have the same sorts of things wrong with them.
> The difference is in what you have when you're done, and how much the
> parts cost.
> 
Then Steve replied...
>>
>>   Stan has had his hands on British iron! What models Stan? Those
>>   of us porschephiles who are also on the Jaguar mailing list want
>>   to know. :-) If you are saying that the amount of work is the same
>>   it would almost seem like it would make sense to put the work into
>>   a car that will be worth more in the end. However I do think a first
>>   restoration should be some thing simple like a VW or a Model-T or
>>   Model-A Ford. Possibly a nice rust free MGB. When I first got my
>>   S-90 B roadster I had another Porsche enthusiast in the area tell
>>   me I should sell it to someone who could do justice to the car as
>>   restoring a XK Jaguar couldn't be compaired to doing a 356. I was
>>   more than a little insulted to say the least. I guess it takes all
>>   kinds of car folks to make the rest of look good! :-)

AHH, this is interesting as I'm in the same situation, i.e., a restoration
"virgin" trying to decide on my first project car. My '85 Carrera is in
great shape, and rarely needs work. So, I need to get my shopwork "fix"
somewhere else. Guess I should clarify restoration- I'm talking about a
"street" restoration, not a "100 points" car. I would like to rebuild the
engine and mechanicals as a learning experience.

I'd be interested in any other opinions/experiences for first cars. I agree
with Stan that a non-Porsche should be a first car. I'd love to start on
a 356 or early 911, but parts are not cheap and any mistakes I make will
be quite costly.

Here's my admittedly eclectic list of cars I am thinking about. I hope to
do research over the next few months and start early next year. I've got
quite a few British cars in it. (H'mm do I really want to battle the Prince
of Darkness? There is a ton of literature/how-to stuff on them though.)

VW bug (convertible)   Simple, parts available, timeless
Triumph TR6            Nice lines, strong engine
Triumph TR7            Modern convenience, weird sides, sort of the 928
                       of TR's (no offense 928'ers, I like 928's too)
TVR                    Not that common, but parts (Ford) pretty available.
                       I DO like the way they look.
MGB                    An obvious choice, but I just can't get excited about
                       them.
Jaguar                 XK's too pricey for me. Early XJ6's look interesting,
                       prices certainly cheap, how easy are repairs?
BMW 3.0                Again, probably not cheap/simple.
Alfa GTA               Nice engine, interesing lines. Somewhat practical.
Lotus Elan, Europa     Nice lines and handling. $$?
Toyota MR2             Yikes, from the Orient! They do handle well though.
Datsun 240Z            A milestone. Always liked the original.

Yeah, I know this is quite a range of very different cars -- I should figure
out what I REALLY want to do with the car when it is done. I'm still working
on that. This exercise will help me work to that end.

P.S. Anyone going to the Hilton Head Island Classic Concours on Nov 4-6?
I hope to go. Supposed to have about 150 cars there. The Jaguars class will
have a national points competition.

Thanks folks.

Richard Grayson
76226.3526@compuserve.com
1985 911 coupe

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 09:05:45 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: fi_pump_mech

I have a factory supplement to the 911 repair manual for the mechanical 
injection system.  The pump repair however is not covered.  This pump is 
similar to the pumps used on MB's both gas and diesel.  Try a 280se.  
Some diesel pump rebuilders have a test bench that will accommodate a 
Bosch pump.  Locally a nationally known rebuilder has slipped at least 
one 72 911T pump through there.  

Porsche had many sub-versions of this pump.  Too rich?  There are several 
adjustments on the outside of this pump that can be made.  One screw 
however, is accessed through the cooling fan with a long handeled 
recessed allen head wrench.  Look for it!

I have had the pump on my 70E rebuilt by Pacific Fuel Injection.

Good luck
David Duffield
dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us

on my Zeniths.  Can anyone tell me what constitutes disabling that circuit?
I have the solenoid installed but disconnected, both big adjustment screws
turned all the way in, and the rest of the system intact.  Is there anything
else I should do to keep that system from throwing off the tuning of the carbs?
Thanks for your insights.

real sports car (actually I have know this since I was six).

I currently have a 90 Miata - great car - really but no comparison.
So how do I go about finding a 911. Budget 25,000.
What can I expect in terms of maintainance expense, downtime, is there
really 13 quarts of oil in a 911? what years do I avoid? Should I consider 88-90
 - this is what 25000 will buy? What do I look for? what are the weak - problem
areas? should high milage on a well cared for car be a concern? how many
miles before a major engine rebuild? I am not int[C the LUXO - leather  
electric headrest/ windows/ mirrors, prefer simple, lightweight, no-frill
fast car.

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 09:39:14 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: Restoring VW or P-Car?

Chris writes....

>From what I read here a number of you maintain and restore your own
>Porsches. Do you find them difficult to work on? I'm inclined to think
>that restoring a Porsche as a first project is probably more than I
>could/should handle. Would I be better to start with a simpler car?
>I've considered starting with a VW Beetle as these seem to be fairly
>easy to work on, not too expensive, and might present me with some of
>the problems I might encounter on a Porsche. Is this a good idea? Have
>any of you restored both? How do they compare (as a project)?


While I've spent the last three years on my p-car doing the
restoration of the body/suspension...my Brother has been restoring
a '61 VW Beetle.  From JC Whitney's in Chicago, I bought NEW non-OEM
Fenders for $49 ea!!!!!!  Unbelievable, the parts costs are simply
trivial compared to a Porsche.  I'd recommend you start with VWs
and move to a Porsche of you choice later, yes VWs are much easier
to restore.  I worked/restored several beetles and a karman ghia
before starting on my 912 and it was a great set of learning experiences.
It will also get you used to thinking in terms of "air cooled" instead
of water-cooled stuff.


Good Luck!!


Ron
rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 09:31:22 PDT
From: john@pelican.HAC.COM (John  (619) 931-3910)
Subject: Re: 914 engine choices


Nic wrote:

; Now I know what a four banger is going to cost to get 120hp it is not
; really an option in my mind. 


	I think it's time for a reality check. Are you saying you can't
afford a good 4 for your 914 so you are going for a 6 instead ? The cost
build a good 6 is astronomical compared to a 4. Plus you get to put a
lot on work into the conversion. If you are looking at something like
a 3.0SC motor, then your work increases by another big chunk, 'cuz you're
going to have to do a lot of mods to take the extra torque and still
have a somewhat reliable car. 

a *very* rough budget.

a decent flat 6    $7,000-$15000
conversion of your car from 4->6  $3000-$5000 
Mods to take extra power (trans, CV, half shafts, chassis, swing arms, brakes...) $3000-$5000

so a rough minimum to do this right would be about $13K with $25K easily possible.

								-jd

							'74 914/2.0 SE for the street
							'73 914/6 2.7 for the track
							'70 914/6 stashed away for future use

have a vehicle to take surfing and to shows to pick up those expensive
Porsche parts in.

The earlier the bus you restore, the more acclimated to paying $$$ for parts -
like the $200 I spent for taillights for my bus, or the $200 or so I'm going
to pay for the engine lid, and then $100 for the brake light....

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 09:50:15 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Rocket-Propelled Machine


With the current Drag Racing thread, the following comes to mind.

You don't just strap a jet or rocket to your butt and go to the drag 
strip on roller skates. When I was in college 30 years ago, a fellow
named Romeo Palamedes came to me about doing some work to keep his 
jet powered dragster from reaching rotational speed and flying. I had
just built a small wind tunnel, so the request was possible. I asked him 
what the problem was, he said " I had a driver get killed." He wasn't 
smiling. Seems he had a J79 out of an F-104 to play with. He had
been using a low-power J-45 in the wrecked car.

I was able to get him a body which didn't fly, but they had brake problems
after that. Seems they could hit 275 MPH in the 1/4 mile.

There was a fellow named Al Cadrobbi in Van Nuys that raced a Carrera 
4-cam at the drags. Use to be very fast. I don't remember what he used for 
fuel but my eyes watered after he went by. Hydrazine?

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 13:22:47 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: Re: Restoring VW or P-Car?

Thom Fitzpatrick (another with dual membership: Pphiles and Vanagon list) 
recommends a VW bus as a restoration choice.  I don't think medical science
has identified why some people NEED to sit over the front wheels to drive,
but I'm pretty sure that one either has this affliction or doesn't.  Buses
are good driveway projects in that you don't need ramps for a lot of projects.
When you do need ramps, with bus or Vanagon you can put the ramps in FRONT of
the back wheels and drive up.  Try that with a 356.  On the other hand, the
idea of a bus unibody on a rotisserie for a full resto boggles the mind.  And
the impossibility of getting all that metal flat is why there are no black
VW vans.

VWs generally are better training for Porsche work than other cars.  But I
think that if you want to work up to Porsches that need a lot, the place to 
start is a Porsche that doesn't need a lot, rather than a VW that does.
B.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 11:24:02 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: first resto project choice

Subject: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)
  Chris writes;
>I've just recently become very interested in owning a Porsche...
>........I'm inclined to think that restoring a Porsche as a first project is
> probably more than I could/should handle. Would I be better to start with a
> simpler car? I've considered starting with a VW Beetle as these seem to be
> fairly easy to work on, not too expensive.....

   Picking a project car is like picking a wife; you better be really
 sure you love it before you get involved....You'll have it for years
 if not for life, it will demand all your time and and you'll spend every
 dollar you make on it. Whether its a blonde or brunette is insignificant,
 if you make the wrong choice your life will be hell, if you make the right
 choice there is nothing like it.

   Another Porschephiler, Tony Eggers, helped a friend restore a '70 Mustang.
 It was his friend's first project car, originally planned to be a daily
 driver. The guy researched the car to death, apprenticed for a year (for 
 free) at a body shop on weekends to learn paint and body, and did every inch
 of the work (including the rebuild of the Automatic tranny) himself. $30,000
 and years later, the car made the cover of Mustang and Fords magazine and 
 wins Trailered Concours class at the National level.  That car has got to be
 the exception, though; most guys I know with project cars have them
 undriveable after 5-10 years, and have lost money, time and hope...

   Be honest about why you are doing the restoration, spend 6 months
 researching before you buy any car. Buy every book about the car you can
 find and read it first. But above all, be realistic about your abilities,
 your time, your expectations and your checkbook.

   The kind of work that restores a 100-point Impala SS is the exact same work
 that restores a Maserati Mexico. The difference is in resources (parts,
 books, expertise) available. In that regard, a Porsche is a pretty good
 choice and a 911 an excellent choice. You are -going- to lose money on
 whatever you do, just make sure its the kind of entertainment you want !

  - Lee A. (family projects '28 Chevy, undriven in 12 years
                            '49 Chevy PU, undriven in 8 years
                            '70 DeTomaso Mangusta, undriven in 10 years

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 15:40:43 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Changing struts/Air tools

After last weekend's blast at Bridgehampton (Hi Kevin G.), my 951 has some 
front-end wander. What was very slight play before the event has turned into a
thumpethy-thump from the front-end.  I don't think it's the ball-joint since 
they checked it at tech.   When the front wheels are rocked top-to-bottom, 
there is a slight play and I can feel movement in the strut.  I had changed 
and adjusted the outer bearings but not the inners.  Is this a sign of bad 
struts or inner bearings?  I have the original factory Konis.   If nec., I'll 
be changing struts/shocks on both cars (the daily-driver Audi also needs 
struts/shocks with 113k miles) and since I will have the springs out, 
replacing with stiffer springs and lowering the cars.  I'm looking at Koni 
adj./Eibach springs.

I'm also considering investing in air tools.  Of course, I still have to sell 
my loan officer (aka spousal unit) on the idea.  For home use, i.e. changing 
struts/shocks and an occasional clutch or three, what size air compressor is 
sufficient?  Brand names? Will they handle those tough 400 lb. ft. axle hubs? 
 Can you preset torque on an air-ratchet or is that a 'special' tool?

Other than spring compressors and large channel-locs, any other special tools 
needed for struts?

TIA,

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 16:06:02 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 air box

> 
> I want to determine if my air box's intake air temp sensor is behaving.
> 
> Does anybody know the output voltage characteristics for the intake air temp
> sensor on a 944 air box?  I think there are 4 conductors on the
> air box electrical plug - assuming 2 for air flow reading, 2 for air temp.
> 
> Kirk Shafer
> sick '88 944

According to the 944 Service Manual, page 28-28,

"Check temperature sensor I (intake air temperature). Turn off ignition and
pull off plug on air flow sensor. Connect ohmmeter between terminal 6 and 22
on air flow sensor (both outer flat male plugs).

Specification at 15 to 30 degrees Centigrade: 1.45 - 3.3 k-ohms.

Note:
Interruption on tenperature sensor causes richer mixture.
Short on temperature sensor causes leaner mixture."

Good luck..

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 15:15:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: address wanted

> Does any Porschephile know the adress and/or phone number of a company by
> the name of Halltech (sp?).  I believe they make F.I. equipment and 
> instruments. TIA.

Haltech makes an OK unit for competition, but it mostly sucks for combination
street and competition  use. It's also not nearly as programmable as some
of the other units available. Beware the Electromotive unit unless you
have a common intake plenum!

You also still have to provide the various instrumentation, intakes,
and throttle bodies. I know that Gene Berg has that based on Weber IDX
carb bodies if this is for a 914 or 356. There are places that do the
same for Weber sidedraft carbs for the 924/44s. Total to add custom 
programmable EFI to a 4-cylinder is about $3k. Total to add custom 
programmable EFI to a 911 is more like $8500-10k

Just and FYI, from someone that used to make a lot of money setting these
things up for IMSA cars...

Stan

Date: 28 Oct 94 19:11:28 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Restoring a Porsche (maybe)

 
Hi, Chris.
 
Go for it. I took a body and fender class at the local community college
too, because I didn't like what I saw at the professional shops and figured
I could do better. Turns out I can, it just takes waaaaaay longer. The class
lasted 2 years, about 3-4 hours a day, 4 days a week.
 
The 356 and VW Beetle are very similar in many ways, certainly mechanically.
The Beetle body is built differently; the body is removable, as are the
fenders. On the Porsche, all that is welded to the "inner body" so if it's
bad you have to undent it, or cut it out and patch it, or replace entire
sections like the front or rear "caps" (known as "clips" in the trade), etc.
A VW body can be lifted off the frame to do a top-notch restoration; the
Porsche body can be stripped, but you still have a shell that is pretty much
complete.
 
Mechanically, 356s are fairly easy to work on. Most service parts are
reasonably priced, but certainly more expensive than VW (and no, there aren't
many parts that interchange between the two, so forget that right off) but
almost everything seems to be available. When not dealing with service
parts and normal wear items, things can get expensive, so be sure the car
you buy for restoration is at least complete. For example, it's cheaper and
easier to rechrome straight but pitted bumper guards than it is to buy four
reproductions, with questionable fit and high prices.
 
If you do a 356 (or any car) don't fool around with aftermarket manuals, get
the factory manuals and parts catalog. They tell you everything you need to
know. Get the leading parts suppliers catalogs to see what you're getting
into (for 356, that's Stoddard, NLA Ltd., Tweeks to see what's available but
not to buy, a few others).
 
As a first project, I would recommend the 356 over the 911; it's a much
simpler car. Look around for a while (several months is not out of line),
look at and UNDER lots of cars, form an impression of what cars are really
bad and what cars are in pretty good shape, be prepared to let what you
think are good cars go until you have more experience, then when you feel
confident you can recognize a good car when you see it, and the price is
right, go for it. Buy the best basis for restoration you can afford; a
basket case may be cheap but you'll probably never finish it. A good
drivable car with a few cosmetic problems may be best.
 
Good luck.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 20:13:12 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: 911 brake pedal adjustment

> 
> Bob Albrecht writes:
> 
> >Remove the carpets,  and  the
> >*PLYWOOD*  floorboard (is that why they call them  floorBOARDS?)
> 
> 
> Yes. (For historical reasons).
> 
> Regards,
> 
>   Lou Krieg
>   '87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
>   LouKrieg@aol.com
> 
As I understand it, Henry ford specified the exact dimensions and construction
of the wooden crates which were used to ship (some unknown) parts in.  Being
the innovative and wiley entrepreneur he was, he arranged those dimensions
and construction methods to allow easy disassembly, and instant use of the wood
for floor boards with no manufacturing on his end.  Sort of outsourcing before
its time :-)

I have no proof of this, but it is common folklore...

 -chuck
'83 911 cabriolet (guards red)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Oct 94 15:45:28 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Changing struts/Air tools

| From: Stephen I Jagernauth  <sjagernauth@attmail.com>
|
<strut stuff deleted>
|
| I'm also considering investing in air tools.  Of course, I still have 
to sell
| my loan officer (aka spousal unit) on the idea.  For home use, i.e. changing
| struts/shocks and an occasional clutch or three, what size air compressor is
| sufficient?  Brand names? Will they handle those tough 400 lb. ft. 
axle hubs?
|  Can you preset torque on an air-ratchet or is that a 'special' tool?

An air ratchet is not an impact wrench. Two different beasts. An air
ratchet is similar to a standard ratchet except you can use the air
to spin the socket to the point where the nut/bolt is snug. You then
use hand power to rotate the handle of the air ratchet exactly as
you would a hand ratchet and vice versa for loosening. Actually,
I don't use the air ratchet for final tightening; this is where one
employs a torque wrench.

You can use an impact wrench to loosen the really tight nuts/bolts,
like lug nuts and axle nuts. However, the bargain counter impact
wrenches only go up to 250 or so ft/lbs. To get a 400 ft/lb wrench,
you are looking at $150 or thereabouts. They do have adjustments
for torque output, but those are not accurate, although it would
probably be good enough for the axle nut.

That said, I don't have an impact wrench. I just use a breaker
bar and, if necessary, a pipe cheater. To spin the nuts on/off,
I use either the air ratchet or a cordless electric drill with a 3/8
square drive adapter. The bigger of my two torque wrenches
goes up to 100 ft/lbs, so I use that for the final tightening of my
lug nuts. For the axle nut, I use my 3/4 inch breaker bar with my
trusty 3 foot long cheater pipe. I weigh 180 lbs, so if I apply all
of my weight about 2.5 feet out, that's roughly 400 ft/lbs. Voila!

BTW, my compressor uses a 2 HP, 1800 RPM motor running
on 220. I built it myself using a Dayton motor, Sears 2 cylinder
pump, and a 10 gallon roll around tank I bought from an
industrial supply (I forget the brand, I could look it up if needed).
I don't think this is the way to go if you are looking to save
money (its a long story why I did it this way). You can probably
get a good deal on a compressor from one of those warehouse
hardware supply stores (Eagle, Home Base, etc).

If you do get an air compressor, don't forget to get the most
valuable accessory: an air nozzle for blowing things off.

    Eric

------------------------------
