Date: 29 Oct 94 10:23:37 EDT
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Rocket-propelled machine

 
Jim Pasha mentions Romeo Palamides and his rocket cars.
 
Palamides is one of the early big names from drag racing history. The book
"High Performance" mentions his rocket car experiments:
 
"Bob Smith of San Jose, who took over the controls for Palamides after
Liederbrand went to work for Garlits, sustained only cuts and a few broken
bones when Untouchable 2 crashed off the end of a strip at Union Grove,
Wisconsin, but later he suffered extensive injuries when Untouchable 4's
parachutes failed at Milan, Michigan. It was not an edifying story.
Palamides, sure Smith would die, 'grabbed all the appearance money and took
off for California,' then filed for bankruptcy. Smith spend three years
recuperating, but he did survive. Later there were fatalities involving jet
machines built not only by Palamides but also by Fredrick and both the
Arfons brothers as well."
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 29 Oct 1994 10:04:33 -0700
From: tomc@ncd.com (Tom Canning)
Subject: Air Tools

        If you're going to buy a compressor, IMHO don't buy something too small
since over as time you will get used to air tools, you'll buy more and more
and you'll will need more air.

        I had a so -called "fake 5" ie -a 5 hp , 60 gal 220v, @3250 rpm.
Was fine at the beginning but after more and more projects, I began to cook
it.CFM was around 5-6CFM.

        Just bought a Curtis upright - 5hp, 80gal, 220v 850rpm, 2 stage.
CFM is 18-20CFM. If you have the budget - get a 2 stage, something in this
class.

I run for example;
3/8,1/2 impacts,3/8,1/4 rachets ( life savers!),DA's,Airfiles,Killers,
Sandblaster,flangers,cutoffs,HVLP spray guns, you name it. And all I
started with was a blow gun. Air is totally infectious and the greatest
thing for your home shop. Especially cool are the dustless DA's and
sanders..

The whole heart of your system of course will be the compressor. Prices new:
5 hp, single stage, 220v, 3250 rpm ~5cfm ~$350-500.00
5 hp dual stage                    ~7cfm ~$500-800.00
5 Hp, dual                850 rpm ~ 18-20~ 1500.00 - 2500.00

Used - 5 hp single - 250.00 300.00
       Big 5 - 700-900.00 if you can find one..
Remember - next toys are dryers, regulators, reels etc etc $  $ $.
Tom

- -------------------------------------------------------------------
Tom Canning                             E-mail:  tomc@ncd.com
Account Executive                       Voice:   415-691-2829
Network Computing Devices Inc.          Fax:     415-961-6289
350 North Bernardo Avenue
Mountain View, CA 94043
- -------------------------------------------------------------------

seconds time frame).  Could I have made some kind of dumb wiring mistake???
I don't think so but I'm totally lost right now.

Subject: Corvette Club AutoX

Hey,

I had the unique opportunity to spectate at a Corvette club auto-
cross here in Hunstville today.  Pretty interesting.  Here are some
observations:

1.  Corvettes are much quieter than Porsches.
2.  Even though this was a "timed" event, these folks didn't seem
     to be pushing their cars very hard (with a few exceptions).
3.  Alot of mechanical failures/problems with the cars.  The course
     even had to be altered due to the fantastic amount of oil laid down
    when one guy's engine let go.  There was another car parked with a
    *large* pool of coolant under it.  I could go on.
4.  Alot of the guys were overweight.  Sorry - couldn't resist.

Too bad I was in my 4Runner instead of the 911.  I actually think I 
could have held my own;-).

Have a good weekend!!

Mike

they raised the front end by about 1.5 inches and that the front end was 
raised more than the back. Is there a way to get the car back to the 
original ride height? If I replace the springs with Eibach springs, which 
would lower the front, what is the likely effect on handling if I don't 
change the rear torsion bars? More oversteer or more understeer?

Subject: 944 Coolant Leakage


My '88 944 seems to be losing coolant much too quickly (1.5 quarts in 3 
weeks). I haven't noticed any water on the ground, but will be looking at it 
tomorrow. Any ideas on common leakage areas. I noticed a few drops of 
coolant visible near one of the bolts at the top of the water pump near the 
hoses, but it doesn't look like it has been leaking much there. If the water 
pump does need replacement, does it require removing the timing belt, etc?

Thanks for any help
Peter Tracy
ptracy@keps.com

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 06:31:54 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Coolant Leakage

> 
> My '88 944 seems to be losing coolant much too quickly (1.5 quarts in 3 
> weeks). I haven't noticed any water on the ground, but will be looking at it 

> tomorrow. Any ideas on common leakage areas. I noticed a few drops of 
> coolant visible near one of the bolts at the top of the water pump near the 
> hoses, but it doesn't look like it has been leaking much there. If the water 

> pump does need replacement, does it require removing the timing belt, etc?
> 
Hi, Peter,

Yep, much too quickly.  Look more closely at the water pump. Also, if you
can pressurize the cooling system (your mechanic may have a gizmo to do
this) and can leave it pressurized for a while, you may be able to figure
out where the coolant is going.  (Head gasket or oil cooler may be a
possibility...does your oil have a light chocolate brown consistency?)

Your radiator may be leaking, or any of the hoses.

Water pump replacement does require timing belt removal, inasmuch it is
driven by the timing belt.  Since you have a later model car, with the belt
tensioner builtin, you should be able to do it yourself, but make sure that
you have the factory shop manual before you attempt it, otherwise you may
hurt your motor by mistiming.

Good luck, 

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593



- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 08:16:42 -0800 (PST)
From: Chris Kan <chriskan@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Coolant Leakage


> My '88 944 seems to be losing coolant much too quickly (1.5 quarts in 3 
> weeks). Any ideas on common leakage areas.

Mine was leaking until I had it fixed. The leak was at the seam where the 
plastic tank is clamped onto the aluminum core. I brought the rad in and 
the shop fixed it by simply clamping it tighter with pliers. Another 
possible source of leak is at the fitting under the top rad hose where a 
small hose is attached. This fitting simply a plastic nozzle screwed onto 
the rad tank and could be loose. For mine, I wrapped it with Teflon tape 
and made sure it was tight. Both these leaks were difficult to detect, 
the only evidence being one drop of coolant on a bolt holding the lower 
engine cover. Removing the rad is easy; raise the front of the car so you 
can crawl under. Then drop the fan assembly followed by the rad.
 
As for the water pump, I've read you have to remove ALL the belts, 
pulleys. idlers etc. just so you can remove the rear belt cover which 
blocks access to the water pump. Not a trivial task as is with many other 
cars. This is definitely one area where Porsche screwed up. In fact, I'm 
beginning to think this, and the need for P9201 gauge for changing belts 
was designed to discourage owner service (I was quoted $700 cdn for P9201 at 
the dealer!).
 
Chris
'86 944 

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 10:16:39 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 944 Raised by Koni shocks

I don't have a 944, but I can say the shocks should never by themselves 
affect the ride height. Their sole purpose is to damp the bumps by 
working with the springs.

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 11:30:48 -0500
From: ClinTNS@aol.com
Subject: MY ' 86 951 fuel leak

After filling up recently I noticed a strong fuel smell and assummed
that the attendant had "topped it off"(ie; spilled gas all over the car).
When I still noticed the smell the next day I checked under the hood
and found gas dribbling out of the supply line where it goes into the
pressure regulator(is that right?).
   After determining that it was coming out of the hose(possibly crimp
connection) and not just a loose fitting, I ordered part #951.356.919.03 fuel
line.  This is a rubber hose with a heat shield jacket and crimp connections
to a solid tubing with an inline connector that apparently connects to
another solid line somewhere
behind the right front wheel well.  The hitch is that my existing line
goes all the way back to the rear of the car where it connects to the
fuel filter. No inline connector anywhere  Do I need to replace that whole
line from the hose that comes out of the fuel filter and runs forward?  Is
this an update/modification?  Any help would be appreciated.
Clint Pease
'86 951

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 14:01:30 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re:MY ' 86 951 fuel leak

Hi, Clint,

According to the microfiche, the original part number for that hose is 
951.356.919.02, which was superseded to the .03 part.  So, it seems that 
Porsche decided to add a connector to make life easier for them.

Looks like you might have to order a couple more parts:

477.209.169 Connecting Piece
951.356.967.02 Fuel Line

The Fuel Line shows as connecting to the fuel filter.

Good Luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 16:29:30 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: 911/2 Strut Cartridge Replacement

Just a quick question for the strut experienced:

Okay, I'm replacing my strut cartridge inserts in my '66 912.  I
removed the old ones this weekend and a few tablespoons of what
looks like hydrolic oil came dripping out.  I read in the factory
manual that I should expect this - ok.  

BUT, I took out the old Konis and they look like the top isnt
sealed and that oil would go in/out of them?  Now, I bought Boges to
replace them and they look to be 100% sealed.  The factory manual 
says to drain the old oil out, but, doesnt say anything about putting
new oil back in.  The Boge instructions say to put oil in if the
manufacturer says to.

The factory manual doesnt say anything about putting oil in or what
kind or how much.

So..... what to do?  My current thinking is that since the Boges appear
to be completely sealed, I'm not gonna put any oil in there.  I would
appreciate anybody's help on this who's already been through this.

Thanks!

Ron
rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 18:50:21 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  I'm tired of driving the Honda

>>  >The noise does not vary
>>  >in amplitude or frequency whether I have the clutch in or clutch out, reve
>>  >the engine...put it in neutral or a gear...drive it or not.  Any clues???
>>
>>  >One of the things I had to pull out when replacing the clutch was the
>>  >starter.  Well, turns out the starter needed rebuilding....so I put a nice
>>  >rebuilt starter in there.  It starts the car just fine.  However, it is
>>  >heating up rapidly AFTER the car is started and the starter is off (3-4
>>  >seconds time frame).
>>
>>Any chance the starter is not disengaging properly and is being
>>spun by the motor - perhaps that's the source of the whine
>>
>>
Not likely - the frequency would change as the engine was rev'd. But the
fact that the starter is getting hot sure sounds like it is continuing to
run after the engine starts. That would certainly make a constant noise.
Put a voltmeter on the starter leads (assuming they are accessible) and
find out whether there is any voltage there when the engine is running.
Seems obvious, but why else would the starter be getting hot?

 -John White-

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 18:45:51 PST
From: linton@dgs.dgsys.com (Dave Linton)
Subject: 968 Tires

The rear tires (Yokohama ZRs) on my 1992 968 have worn down to the warning 
bands after only 13,000 miles, and the front ones are not far behind.  This, 
on a daily driver with no track time or prolonged high-speed driving (OK--one 
autocross session).

Any suggestions on tire brands/speed ratings that would prove more durable?  
Would a lower speed rating tire provide greater mileage?  I am running 
original equipment Yokohama 205/55 ZR 16s on the front and 225/50 ZR 16s on 
the rear.  Thanks.

Dave Linton
1992 968 Coupe
Washington, D.C.

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 17:48:42 PST
From: albrecht@cod.nosc.mil (Robert Albrecht)
Subject: 356 calipers, etc.

- -------
All,

	The exercise is to replace the rear wheel bearings, rebuild the
calipers, and replace the rotors on the rear of a '65 356.  Well,
the axle nuts came off without great trouble.  They were tight, but
certainly didn't take 400 ft/lbs.  I got down to the wheel bearings
and discovered the need for the special puller.  I'll be looking for one to 
rent or buy tomorrow (suggestions?).  anyway, on the the primary subject.

	I can't get the pistons out of the caliper.  I've tried shop air
(about 100 psi), and rotating them with pliers.  No dice. 
Initially, I pushed them in a little to get the pads out, and remove 
the caliper.  That was OK.  Removed the dust boots, which were essentially
shot, and loose.  There is some surface rust under the boots, including the 
small portion of the bore visible when the piston is compressed.  Anyway,
The air would push the pistons out to a point (roughly the operating point
for worn pads) and I could push them back with pliers.  Getting nowhere, I
tried pushing the pistons all the way in (C-clamp).Now the shop air won't
push them back out at all.  They seemed to move smoothly, so I don't think
they are cocked in the bore.  Is this what is meant by "frozen calipers"?

	Any suggestions on getting the pistons out?  Should I give up and
pay to have them rebuilt?  At this point, I COULD put it back
together and drive it somewhere.  How about hooking it back up to
the hydraulic system and punching them out with the brake pedal?  I
expect I might get one out that way, but not both.  

	Suggestions and experience apprecieated.

Bob	'83SC,	'65SC.
- -------


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 20:12:24 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911/2 Strut Cartridge Replacement

> BUT, I took out the old Konis and they look like the top isnt
> sealed and that oil would go in/out of them?  Now, I bought Boges to
> replace them and they look to be 100% sealed.  The factory manual 
> says to drain the old oil out, but, doesnt say anything about putting
> new oil back in.  The Boge instructions say to put oil in if the
> manufacturer says to.

Well, there was this technological revolution about a decade or two back
resulting in gas pressurized shocks and strut inserts. In the Old Days,
shocks were no only rebuildable, but you could vary the damping by
changing the oil in them to something stiffer or lighter as your tastes
dictated -- sort of like motorcycle forks still are. But these days,
almost everything is sealed. So clean out the strut housings, install
the new inserts, and go play. You don't need to add other oil.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 20:23:21 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 968 Tires

> The rear tires (Yokohama ZRs) on my 1992 968 have worn down to the warning 
> bands after only 13,000 miles, and the front ones are not far behind.  This, 
> on a daily driver with no track time or prolonged high-speed driving (OK--one 
> autocross session).

Are you sure you didn't used to own a NSX?? 8{) Please don't take this as
a personal attack; it's directed at everyone out there that complains about
this and you're just the first person in a while to say anything.

Tires are made of rubber. You have two choices: hard rubber for long
life, and soft sticky rubber for better performance. There is no such
thing as hard rubber that gives good performance. There is no such thing
as sticky rubber that doesn't wear rapidly.

OK: you spent *HOW MUCH* on the car, to get a *HIGH* performance vehicle, 
and now you're concerned about tire life??? The tires are a very important 
part of the overall performance of the car. If you change over to oh, let's 
say Kelly or General or Atlas or Western Auto store brand, sure, you'll can
get a 40,000 or even a 60,000 mile tire, but at the expense of not
*EVER* being able to drive the car it was meant to be driven.

Suck it up, and buy new tires. The right stuff -- Yokos or other sticky
tires. Sure, it's $150 a tire, but that's what percentage of the total
car??? And you got what, nearly 3 years? I went through a set of rear
tires on my 911 every 14 months, like clockwork.

I'm sorry, but this is BIG issue for me.... I got religion about this
when I started bitching about how much motorcycle tires cost, and a
friend said "do the math". He further explained that I should figure out
how big my contact patch was, and think about what my life was worth,
and did I really want the cheapest tires or the BEST tires I could find.

It's a little different putting tires on a P-car, but not much: what do you
value about the car? If the words "handling" or "performance" even *ENTER YOUR
MIND* when you answer that, think about it. Hard. Do you want to do something
to change that for the worse? Or should you just have bought a sedan to begin
with?

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 20:31:20 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 calipers, etc.

> I got down to the wheel bearings
> and discovered the need for the special puller.  I'll be looking for one to 
> rent or buy tomorrow (suggestions?).  

You need the special VW tool. You *MIGHT* be able to rent one from a 
shop that specialized in aircooled VWs. Failing that, it's made by
Baum, or you can get it at the dealer...

> 	I can't get the pistons out of the caliper.  I've tried shop air
> (about 100 psi), and rotating them with pliers.  No dice. 
> ...
> Is this what is meant by "frozen calipers"?

Oooooo. It's deja vu all over again... I *BROKE* two of mine getting them
out. Eventually, after spraying liberally with ZEP-45, I grabbed the little 
lip with ViseGrips, and pulled like a son-of-a-gun, finally getting just enough 
out to grab the main piston body (barely!) in the bench vise, where I was 
then able to put one foot on the bench, pull like hell, twist a lot, and 
eventually get it to pop out. It was toast anyway, so I didn't worry about 
further damage. The bore was fine, and I have NO IDEA why it was stuck.

Of the four rear pistons, only ONE came out OK. I broke two, which meant
replacing them ($37 each at Stoddard) and was able to save the other one.
Worst brake rebuild nightmare I've ever had...

Good luck. Sometime I need to get around to writing up how I went from
just changing pads to only have one metal line from the original brake
system left with all else replaced or rebuilt in only three easy weeks...

Stan

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 23:13:00 EST
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Raised by Koni shocks



 ----------
>> From: David J. Christiano
>> To: Peter Tracy
>> Cc: Porschephiles
>> Subject: Re: 944 Raised by Koni shocks
>> Date: Sunday, October 30, 1994 10:16AM
>>
>> I don't have a 944, but I can say the shocks should never by themselves
>> affect the ride height. Their sole purpose is to damp the bumps by
>> working with the springs.
>>

For normal shocks, you are correct. However, the Konis are gas pressurized 
and thus apply a force which tries to keep the shock shaft fully extended, 
pushing the car up.

Peter

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 23:10:00 EST
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Coolant Leakage



 ----------
>> From: George.Beuselinck
>> To: pgt
>> Cc: porschephiles
>> Subject: Re: 944 Coolant Leakage
>> Date: Sunday, October 30, 1994 6:31AM
>>
>> Yep, much too quickly.  Look more closely at the water pump. Also, if you
>> can pressurize the cooling system (your mechanic may have a gizmo to do
>> this) and can leave it pressurized for a while, you may be able to figure
>> out where the coolant is going.  (Head gasket or oil cooler may be a
>> possibility...does your oil have a light chocolate brown consistency?)

The coolant looks normal, no oil in the water. I ran it for a while today 
and looked all around underneath and on top and saw nothing abnormal. One of 
those pressure testers sounds like a good idea.

I did discover that my power steering fluid is coming out of the hoses at 
the bottom of the reservoir. It looks like the clamps are the wrong size to 
properly hold the hoses. I replaced one with a clamp I had around and will 
get another tomorrow. Everyone should check this out on their car because 
the fluid has spread about and probably will damage the rubber in bushings 
etc.

>>
>> Your radiator may be leaking, or any of the hoses.
>>
>> Water pump replacement does require timing belt removal, inasmuch it is
>> driven by the timing belt.  Since you have a later model car, with the 
belt
>> tensioner builtin, you should be able to do it yourself, but make sure 
that
>> you have the factory shop manual before you attempt it, otherwise you may
>> hurt your motor by mistiming.

Does this mean that the expensive tool is not needed to replace the timing 
and balance shaft belts on my car? I have the factory manual, but it doesn't 
show the tensioner; maybe I need some updated pages??

Thanks,
Peter

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 1994 19:34:46 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: 914 engine rebuilding


I'm a newbie, so don't flame too hard if this has been covered before...

I've got a one-owner, high-mileage 1974 1.8 liter 914 in need of engine
work - it still runs, but with 189,000+ on it, well...

Question of the moment is this:  Does anybody out there have experience
with the hydraulic lifter cam set up sold by Performance Products?
I want the car as a street only machine - no competition.  The idea of
hydraulic lifters appeals to me, since it should lessen the need for 
valve adjustments.  Yeah, I know it's a privilege to crawl under there
every 3,000 miles, and all that; but at my age & with kids, I'm also
a realist, and know it ain't gonna get done...

So, how 'bout it folks?  Anybody running one of these setups?

BTW, thanks for the comments on the big bore kits - I'd been debating 
that, too, but now it looks like stock barrels for me - I want reliability,
not ultimate performance out of this car.

Thanks, 
Henry Bibb
'74 914 1.8

Date: Sun, 30 Oct 94 21:06:59 PST
From: Francis Chiu <chiu@io.nosc.mil>
Subject: Re: Restoring Porsche...

  I agree with Stan's advice on learning how to restore cars with a Bug
instead of a Porsche.  While the two seemed to be similar at first glance,
(Hold the flame throwers, I meant only a *slight* similarity) the cost of 
a screw-up is much easier to live with.  

  On the other hand, even after I have brought 2 different bug back to life 
and drag raced them back to their graves, I must admit that I was still 
unprepared for the BIG different in part prices between the bugs and the 
'74 914 2.0 that I'm currently working on.  Especially in the engine category.  

  $800 worth of valves/valves guides/welding on the 2.0 heads could've
bought a NEW pair of machined/full race/ready to run heads for a TYPE I.
Why does it appeared that no one is offering reasonably priced high 
performance aftermarket parts for Porsches?  For the price of freshening up 
a 2.0 914 engine, I could've bought, out right, a race ready TYPE I.  Now if 
I can shoehorn that TYPE I into the 914... (just kidding).

  Enough whining for now, back to the current project:

  Now that the 914 is almost ready to go again, can anyone suggest a
decent set up for a 914 that is mostly driven on the street?  I was told
to keep the front sway bar, get rd of the rear bar and change the tie rods 
to the 930 type.  Is this a good starting point?  Any recommended alignment
settings?  Please bear with me since the Bugs I used to drive doesn't need 
to turn corners very well. :-) The suspension on the 914 is currently stock
except for the KYBs that I bought the car with. 

  While I'm at it, anyone know of alignment shops in the San Diego area
experienced in aligning 911/914?  Thanks in advance for any help.

Francis Chiu
chiu@nosc.mil

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 01:05:49 -0500 (EST)
From: Don Munn <dmunn@Cybernetics.NET>
Subject: Re: Restoring VW or P-Car?



On Fri, 28 Oct 1994, William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648 wrote:

> Thom Fitzpatrick (another with dual membership: Pphiles and Vanagon list) 
> recommends a VW bus as a restoration choice.  I don't think medical science
> has identified why some people NEED to sit over the front wheels to drive,
> but I'm pretty sure that one either has this affliction or doesn't.  Buses

Actually, in the flat sections of the US, I felt like I usually got about 
and extra mile of vertical sight distance with my van!!! (It's 
unbelieveable what you can see from up there) 

> are good driveway projects in that you don't need ramps for a lot of projects.
> When you do need ramps, with bus or Vanagon you can put the ramps in FRONT of
> the back wheels and drive up.  Try that with a 356.  On the other hand, the
> idea of a bus unibody on a rotisserie for a full resto boggles the mind.  And

My friend and I were just discussing last night such a thing.  My '72 
type II needs a bit of clean up, and he offered his old tobacco barn.  
22" logs hold the roof up at about 13' off the ground.  Our napkin 
calculations indicated this could combined with a few hoists for an 
exciting Saturday.

> 
> VWs generally are better training for Porsche work than other cars.  But I
> think that if you want to work up to Porsches that need a lot, the place to 
> start is a Porsche that doesn't need a lot, rather than a VW that does.
> B.

Actually I have been struggling with this exact question since I got the 
914.  The van is a part of my family history.  When I was a kid, my folks 
bought the thing new and we drove around in the thing across the US and 
Canada a few times.  It was also my mom's station wagon.  It was my 
travelling companion for my own jouney across the states and my sailboard 
hangar.   Now it sits and rusts while I consider what to do with the new 
little toy, mild rust, but nothing like impending doom.  

My conclusion is to try to sell the rusty runt and buy another that is in 
better condition, and spend my time on the van.  I think this would 
reduce the stress while welding and grinding.   The only excuse I can 
come up with is the van actually  actually deservs a bit of restoration, 
while the 914 hasn't earned it's stripes yet!!!!  Yes, a bit twisted.  Oh 
well.

See ya on da road

Don

'6? tolerant spouse
'72 VW Type II Oil distribution device.  (Goumbago)
'75 914 Road Runt
'91 feline OOC  (Object Oriented Cat)
'92 K-9 protection device ( yeah right )

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 00:40:33 -0700
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Mass flow sensors

>     Does anyone have any knowledge about aftermarket mass flow sensors (such
>as the Autothority unit in the Performance catalog)? Is the performance worth
>the expense? Are there negative aspects to this?

Rich,

I have a '78 911SC with an '88 3.2 in it.  I was looking at building a
very fast autocross car (which it turned out to be) so I was looking for
all the horsepower I could find and still be somewhat street legal.  What
I mean by that is changes that I could undo in a day or so are okay, any-
thing else would have to wait for a dedicated car.

Anyway, the options I came up with included equal length headers, less
restrictive mufflers, mass flow sensor systems, and after-market chips.

After talking with a lot of people, especially those with no financial
interests in what I was doing, it became apparent that the mass flow
system from Autothority was not worth the dollars. Jerry Woods felt
that it was a waste of money (maybe a 5 HP gain). My engine guy said
the best thing to do is to go with equal length headers, a less
restrictive muffler system, and use an after market chip.

Autothority claims a 19% gain in power. Do you really believe and engine
can gain 40 HP by changing just the intake side of the equation? I don't!
The way to get a 3.2 to perform better (without spending a fortune or
changing all kinds of hardware) is make it breathe better. The intake side
is fairly adequate, the exhaust is the problem.

I went with 911SC RS style equal length headers with a '74 style dual
inlet, single outlet muffler and a Jerry Woods chip. I figure to have
in the area of 240 HP. This about all you can expect out of a 3.2 with
out changing the fuel injection, cams, pistons, cylinders, etc.

Hope this helps...

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
weapon)



------------------------------

	mass flow sensor vastly different than some of the newer Bosch
	designs? Any other comments on this?

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 09:46:09 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: 356 calipers, etc.

Bob,

Try a 'Grease-Press'(Dunno if thats what you call it...). Make an adapter, 
and connect it to the caliper. Grease presses can make an awfullly high 
pressure.

Another idea is to carefully heat the caliper, then try with air or Grease 
press. 
In a last attempt you could use 'shrink' spray (BRRR,...I'm freezing just on 
the tought..;-) on the pistons while the calipers are heated.

Trond
(PS: As a 356 owner I assume you have a grease press ;-)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 10:07:34 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: 968 Tires,OR; tires for a purpose.

Hiall,

If you're among the the Porsche owners that use their car as it is intended 
too be used, buy Sport tires.(If there is such a thing...)
 
But on the other side I believe there are a lot of Porsche owners that 
doesn't care about what *Porsche* intended the car to be, they are merely 
interested in what *they* have intended for the car.
 
Anyone that need an A to B vehicle and think that a Porsche would be nice, 
doesn't neccessarily have the lust/need to push their car against any limits.
Why should you use Yoko's, Dunlop D40(?) or some other sport tire if you're 
mostly doin' 55 on your way to work?

My advice would be; choose your tires according to your drivestyle.

Trond.

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 10:48:07 +0000
From: Paul Negyesi <paul@ktud.elte.hu>
Subject: This is a car related post.

Hello everybody,

Sorry 'bout the subject, but I can't figure out a better one. Sorry 'bout 
this long post, but I can't compress it :-( (and my sin is bigger, as I 
will distribute to various groups and mailing lists, please flame off :-( ).
Some of You may recognize me, as a guy who is bothering you from time to 
time with his ktud.elte.hu anonymous ftp site :-).
So I need the help of the whole world. As you may know from my e-mail 
address I'm living in Hungary, which is a small Eastern-European country. 
I have a list of current car manufacturers from all over the world. At this 
moment I have the following rules:
 - the manufactured vehicle has more than 2 wheels.
 - the vehicle is either destined for a (small-)series production or at least 
three have been made.
 - the product of the company is either a car or an off-roader or 
an electro or a microcar.
 - the company not only changed the body but they modified the engine as 
well. 
So in other ways the list includes all the assemblers, the kit-,the 
replica-, and the hobbycar makers, the "normal" car companies, some of the 
design studios, the tuning companies etc.
This list can't be complete, but I'm trying to do my best.
I have entries from such countries as Uruguay, Chile (mostly assemblers), 
Taiwan etc. etc.
I'd like to ask people who are living in the following countries and are 
ready to either check a list of manufacturers for me or create me a list 
to get in touch with me:
any non-European country, except: Malta, Australia, New Zealand and the 
United States of America.
So I can't give you money, all I can give you is a credit. All I need is: 
to be fan of cars, be a journalist or such or has any access to car-show 
organizers, magazines etc. E.g. there is a company in Brazil, named 
Aurora which is reportedly making a Ferrari F40 replica, which was shown 
years back in the Sao Paulo show. I have no info either the show or the 
company. Other things: the British Which Kit? magazine, recently featured 
a Taiwanese kit-car maker: Chi & The Gang. I'm afraid there are a lot 
more in that country and other countries as well. If somebody has any 
idea whether how can I get a list of these only-in-that-particular- 
country-available car makers I'd be very grateful.
Thanks in advance and thanks for listening,
Sincerely,
Paul Negyesi
Paul@ktud.elte.hu

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 08:35:14 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Coolant Leakage

> 
> The coolant looks normal, no oil in the water. I ran it for a while today 
> and looked all around underneath and on top and saw nothing abnormal. One of 

> those pressure testers sounds like a good idea.
> 
> I did discover that my power steering fluid is coming out of the hoses at 
> the bottom of the reservoir. It looks like the clamps are the wrong size to 
> properly hold the hoses. I replaced one with a clamp I had around and will 
> get another tomorrow. Everyone should check this out on their car because 
> the fluid has spread about and probably will damage the rubber in bushings 
> etc.
> 
Well, not Everyone. My 83 has manual steering and will NEVER leak!  :-)

> Does this mean that the expensive tool is not needed to replace the timing 
> and balance shaft belts on my car? I have the factory manual, but it doesn't 
> show the tensioner; maybe I need some updated pages??

The tensioner is not needed for the timing belt on your 88 944. In 1987,
Porsche added a spring-loaded tensioner, designed to set the tension
properly at installation, and then be locked in place (keep in mind that it
is not a self-adjuster, but setting the initial tension only).

However, the tension on the balance shaft belt and on the alternator belt
must (read should) be set with the expensive tool, P9201.  

The way I figure it, your car is worth about $10K-$15K.  Buying a tool that
costs $350-400 that saves you a couple of hundred dollars every 15K miles
will pay for itself in a couple of years.  Do the math.

After all, you do own a Porsche!

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 07:49:19 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: 968 Tires,OR; tires for a purpose.

This brings up an interesting point - tires with a warranty.

I recently puchaced a set of Bridgestoine RE92 for my Honda.  I have
never been able to get more than 20K out of a set of tires on this or
any other car due to my cornering technique (scrape the door handles).
These tire came with 3 nice things:

1) The bridgestone Platnum Pacvt -
	30 day no questions asked money back Free hazzard replacement
	NOT prorated for treadwear.  Free flat repair 2) Free
roattion/balancing for the life of the tire 3) 40,000 mile pro-rated
treadwear.

The tires are HR rated and really stick.  At $300/set instralled they
were relatively inexpensive (about $63/tire + mount-bal).

Service is through Firestone.

I'm curious as to the warrantly on the RE940, RE71 and expedia.  I
liked the idea that the Firestome MasterCare Center  had prices within
$4.00 of tire rack (delivered) and I had a persdon to bitch to backed
up by a real dealer network.

FYI,
	STeve

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 08:23:51 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re:  914 Brakes

>>> George Durden <durden@bga.com> 10/26/94 11:12pm >>>
>I've seen some references on this list regarding the use of
>914 front brake calipers on the rears. Does anyone know the
>specifics for this conversion, Does it simply require spacers
>at the mounting points? Also, has anyone replaced the stock
>brake proportioning valve with an adjustable unit? If so, which
>one did you use, how'd it work, and where was the best source
>for it. I'm determined to make my 914 autocrosser actually stop
>on command.

The stock 914 proportioning valve is adjustable.  I replaced mine
with an aftermarket unit from Wilwood because I didn't like the
springy feel that the stock valve gave my brakes.  It was a pain
to find the fittings to convert the 1/8 NPT fittings on the Wilwood
valve to the metric brake fittings on the car.  If you do replace
your valve, it might be worth it to try and find one with metric
fittings.  I got mine from a local racing supply shop.  Apparently,
Kelsey-Hayes units are available from a GM/Ford/Chrysler
dealer, but I didn't check into this.  That might be a source for
one with metric fittings.

With the new valve, my brake pedal is *much* harder.  However,
even with full rear bias, I'm not sure I can lock my rear brakes,
so I think I need to rebuild my rear calipers.

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L


------------------------------

Date: Mon, Oct 31, 1994 9:35 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: First restoration car

In message <941031011548_76226.3526_HHB69-1@CompuServe.COM> Richard Grayson 
writes:
> Pete A. wrote:
> 
> > Hi, Richard Grayson.
> >  
> > How about an early Mustang? Relatively cheap, lots of parts available, lots
> > of support in the form of clubs, books and repro manufacturers. And you can
> > do a Shelby GT 350 replica.
> 
> Pete- H'mm hadn't thought of any Ameerrcan cars. Well, not really true, had
> thought of a '63 split window 'Vette but that's out of my league for now.

Hi Richard,

GT-350 would be cool.  My nephew, not a skilled mechanic (at the start 
anyway) did a teriffic job on a 64.4 Mustang convertible, so creating a 
GT-350 should be very do-able.

I wouldn't rule out a corvette so quickly though (other than the '63 split-
window - real bodies are so rare now) OTOH, the '65-'67s are relatively
cheap and pleantiful, plus they have disk brakes all around (some '65s
did have the disk-break delete option, and have drums, but not many)

A roadster would make a great choice, but any corvette would have the same 
dual advantage/disadvantage:  the 'glass body doesn't dent or rust, so you 
miss the exercise of metal body repairs (a significant component of any metal
bodied restoration)  This would *Significantly* reduce the cost of the 
restoration.  Other benefits include the relatively bullet-proof drive
train and running gear of those years, and the ease of using a late model
and relatively inexpensive "built" chevy V8 for everyday use, while you keep
the original, restored matching-number motor (Yeah, I know... so's yer old 
man) relatively pristine and Lo milage.




working in his back yard

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro)

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 08:39:59 CST
From: dhartger@nas_jsc1.jsc.nasa.gov (Dan Hartgerink)
Subject: Power steering fluid leak 




(snip!)

>........
>I did discover that my power steering fluid is coming out of the hoses at
>the bottom of the reservoir. It looks like the clamps are the wrong size to
>properly hold the hoses. I replaced one with a clamp I had around and will
>get another tomorrow. Everyone should check this out on their car because
>the fluid has spread about and probably will damage the rubber in bushings
>etc.

(snip!)

>Thanks,
>Peter



Yes, the fluid will eat the rubber bushings on the front end.  I was 
changing the H2O pump in my '87 944 this weekend and noticed 
that the right sway bar bushing that holds the straight horizontal 
part of the bar is totally oil soaked and has deteriorated to the point
that it has split apart in the middle and has squeezed out of  the 
clamp that holds it in place. (fortunately no similar damage to the 
other bushings on this side).  The left hand side partner to this 
bushing is free of oil and looks to be in great shape.

My power steering reservoir has been leaking fluid for years now.
About two years ago I went in and cleaned out all the dirt and 
muck and replaced the hose clamps on the reservoir fittings 
figuring that this would cure the problem.  One week later I 
opened the hood and found hydraulic fluid all over the place just 
like before.  

I'm at the point now where I think I'm going to replace both hoses
that go to the reservoir in hopes that this will solve the problem. I
wonder if the hoses have become hard with age and no longer 
conform to the fittings well enough to make a good seal?

Anyway, I'm going to fix this, now,  before any more damage occurs 

Dan Hartgerink   
'87 944  daily driver

Harumphhh, (ahem...) Well, I nearly cried my eyes out when I read that the
factory had burned down, and the fire destroyed all the current XK-SS
production ['57(?)].  I know that at least one survived (maybe more, but
not many).  Tragically, the factory decided not to resume that line.
Imagine my sorrow and chagrin.

I seem to recall that the only XJ13 was (also tragically) destroyed, so
that leaves either an XK120C (aka "C-type), XK140MC (make mine a Drop-Head
Coupe, resplendant in BRG with Tan leather, Thank you very much) or a
D-Type (Ok, Same color scheme, but give me the full-Sail fairing) for those
of us who lust for models from the "Golden Age" of Jaguar.

I know, I know; XK150s were made in the tail of that era, and are pretty
sleek, as is the E-type, but somehow... nah...; they lack the that
muscular, yet voluptous line that characterizes Jaguar's Golden age. (Well,
OK, we'll allow the XK150 after all...)

The E-type though, with it's excellent IRS, doesn't even *handle* like a
Jaguar... Sheesh...

the good people from "Opinions R. Us", whose motto is

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 09:35:06 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@cis.corp.medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: 356 calipers, etc.

I remember reading somewhere about a technique for "exercising" brake calipers.
The idea is that once a year or so, you move the pistons through their full range of
travel to keep them freed up.  This is done by temporarily replacing the brake pads
with the thinnest, most worn set you can find and stepping on the brakes to extend
the pistons.   Then, use a clamp to retract the pistons back into the caliper.  (Watch
that the brake fluid doesn't overflow the master cylinder as you do this step.)  Finally,
put the good brake pads back in and step on the brakes to move the pistons back
to their normal position.

Has anyone heard of or used this method?  Comments?

Pete Klager



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 09:44:59 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: 911\2 frnt shock r&r

Some old tips on this project.
The top cartridge retaining threads on Boge struts differ from Koni 
struts.  One is fine the other is coarse.  Cartridges can be had for either.

Re: Oil surrounding cartridge? Yes its for heat transfer.  Dead air may 
act as an insulator.  Heat in shock cartridge must be transferred to 
outside air.

Text item: Text_1

     Hello files,
     
     I have just installed my 930's engine after removing it to have the turbo 
     rebuilt.  I have also replaced the spark plugs (damn are these expensive).
     
     After everything was together, I turned the key, only to have the engine 
     turn over extremely weakly, as if the battery was lacking oomph.  So I 
     jumped the battery to an operational 911, and got the same effect.  I 
     assumed I had a bad ground, so I polished the ground contact from the 
     transmission to the frame.  I also polished the starter contact.  It did 
     not change the situation.
     
     Anyone out there have any ideas for what could be wrong?
     
     --len

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 08:16:20 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: What car to restore


Richard Grayson lists potential cars for a first restoration and asks for 
suggestions.

I like German cars.  When I made the decision a couple of years ago I
picked a BMW 1600 (for pre emission check reasons), but would recommend a
2002.  Lots of parts are available, they are relatively easy to work on,
and lots of advice can be gotten from enthusiasts.  You can build 
anything from an original daily driver to a serious hot rod.  
Furthermore, since so many were made it isn't like you were desecrating a 
Carrera GS Speedster or something.

My 2 Pfg. worth.

Ted Rodgers

Date: 31 Oct 94 10:58:28 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: Coolant leaks and restos

If you are going to bring a 944 to a shop for a pressure test, if it has 
50K+ miles on the original hoses, if you don't think that your water pump 
is leaking, and if you are not getting lots of vapor in the exhaust, I 
would have all the water hoses replaced first. German rubber sucks. The 
cost of doing a pressure test would probably pay for the bulk of total hose 
replacement. And you have an excellant chance of fixing the problem. And 
you can probably do the hoses yourself, unlike a pressure test.

What major brands of coolant can be used in a Porsche? I know that Prestone 
and Zerex cannot, because of phosphates.

BTW, coolant leaks can damage more than your 944 clutch. Mazda has issues a 
recall on '93 RX-7's to replace the radiator cap. The old ones leaked, the 
coolant dried and became very flammable, and a few cars burnt to crisp.

If I wasn't to restore something, but was still looking, I would leaf 
through Hemmings, and check out parts and parts availability for 
restorations. Based on that, Mercedes and Jaguar have many great choices. 
For instance you can get a ratty but running 450SL for well under $10K, 
maybe even $5K. They are classics, 200hp+ on the early ones, the original 
build quality is there, parts are readily available, you can still drive it 
on nice days during the restore, and the value will hopefully go up by the 
time the restore is done. Beats the H*** out of restoring an MR-2 in every 
way. Of course, I would not do this and just go for something visceral like 
a Lotus Super Seven (in polished, waxed aluminum with a turbo FI RX-7 
powerplant) or a DeTomaso Pantera (street restore 500hp worked 351 and 
Italian styling).

	conversion to 6.0liters.

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 11:24:33 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Mass flow sensors

>      Does anyone have any knowledge about aftermarket mass flow sensors (such
> as the Autothority unit in the Performance catalog)? Is the performance worth
> the expense? Are there negative aspects to this?

They're "cash flow" devices, not "mass flow" devices. Unless, of course,
they're talking about the mass of cash that outflows from you to them...

In short, no real gains, except someone's bottom line. That's *possibly* 
not true if you for some reason built a radical race engine but elected
to use the stock DME instead of say a Comptech or Bosch competition DME.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 11:30:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine rebuilding

> Question of the moment is this:  Does anybody out there have experience
> with the hydraulic lifter cam set up sold by Performance Products?

There are three problems: 1) you run into HUGE difficulties if at any point
you have the car serviced by someone that does not know that there's
a hydraulic cam in the car and adjusts the valve as per normal on a 
mechanical lifter car. Bent valves, etc. kind of "Huge Difficulties"...
2) you have to keep the oil meticulously clean for the hydraulic lifters
not to gunk up. That means more frequent oil changes, or a conversion to
a Canton/MECA or System 1 oil filter, or better, both. 3) if you still
decide to do it, that's the wrong kit and in general the wrong place to
get it. Corollary: your engine builder had better know what he's doing,
too.

> BTW, thanks for the comments on the big bore kits - I'd been debating 
> that, too, but now it looks like stock barrels for me - I want reliability,
> not ultimate performance out of this car.

We use big bores on 1.7 and 1.8 engines all the time, and see the 100K
mile life out of them that we get on factory pistons and cylinders. Anything
bigger than 96mm is bad news, though, since it takes re-engineering the
whole top end. I'm not really sure where the "NPR == evil" word of mouth
got started, but I'd bet it involved engines in which *OTHER* things were done
to increase performance, that led to an untimely engine death.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 12:39:25 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: 6cyl Vanagon Update

A quick update since several on both lists (Porschephiles, Vanagon list) have
aided and abetted:

My 81 Vanagon is back on the road, now with 2.7 liters rather than 2.2 (still
with the 2.2's Zeniths tho', while I get the CIS FI organized).  Half a liter
is a noticeable difference.  In a sense the bigger breakthru is using the 
stock Porsche muffler.  This time I hung the engine about 2.5 inches lower,
at which height the Porsche muffler does fit.  With the six at the VW engine's
height the Porsche muffler would not fit, and no aftermarket solution I found
was at all satisfactory.  Now the engine is low (muffler 9+ in. from the
ground, 1.5 inches lower than it is in a Targa) but no problems in one after-
noon's test drives.

The 2.2 liter engine is excess to my needs now -- I would even listen to offers
on the 2.7 if someone wanted that market-forsaken size instead.  Email me
direct if you have a 914-4 or a bus or Vanagon that is waiting for this step
up.

B.
William R. Kennedy
kennedy@admin.njit.edu

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 09:40:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: 356 calipers


Well, getting old rusted pistons out of calipers is a messy and
potentially dangerous job, if using air, but it's the only way I could do
it.  When I ran into the problem Robert Albrecht described I filled the
caliper with brake fluid, put plenty of ship rags and soft pads between
the pistons, put the whole thing in a soft container with a lid, then
connected the air and let it sit.  Sometimes it took 5 minutes before it
popped loose.  Can't remember if I used WD40 in it overnight, prior to
this or not.  Obviously, a thorough cleaning of the caliper, both inside
and outside before reassembly is a must. 

Be careful when hooking up the air.  Those pistons coming out can damage 
other parts or you.

Ted Rodgers

P.S. Do it away from things you don't want to get brake fluid on.  Also, 
this is a good use for the remainder of the container you opened when you 
changed fluid in the spring.

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 19:16:50 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re:: 356 calipers, etc.

>     I  haven't a clue what a "grease press" is (something like a
>wine press, used to reclaim lard from re-fried beans?)  Actually,
>I assume it's a hydraulic piston activated by a grease gun, but I

Actually it is this 'lever action' 'thing' you put grease patron's into. 
Some just fills up with grease from a bucket too. We have one that generate 
a 400kp/cm2 pressure from that tiny little piston, pops out almost any thing.
(and you don't get the problems that compressed air can give...)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 10:40:00 PST
From: "Pickell, Kevin" <KPickell@ea.com>
Subject: re:914 engine choices


     As a 914-6 conversion owner I thought I'd pass on my
     914s setup and experiences. My 914 was converted by
     the previous owner. He bought his engine from a place
     called Garretsons for about 5k. It consisted of a case from a
     1967 911s, 2.8 pistons, 2.4 heads and 46 Webers, and
     some sort of racing cams. The engine consistently
     fouled plugs and had no-power below 5000 rpm.
     The engine was a race engine, not intended for the
     street.

     He also installed a 915 transmission to handle the
     extra power. As for shift linkage he constructed his own,
     which was (is still) a mess. And also modified VW Bus
     half-shafts.

     When I bought the car it wasn't really street drive-able because
     of the very narrow power-band. My mechanic recommended
     and did the following changes. Have case-squirters installed.
     Change the 2.8 pistons to 2.7 to lower the compression ratio
     (it was supposed to be 13 to 1 with the 2.8's). Change the 46
     Webers to 40 Webers and lastly change the cams to
     a milder cam (from a 911 e, I think?). The engine was much
     more docile and drive-able after this.

     The engine started fouling plugs. I have since given up on that
     mechanic and started getting advice from a local 914-racer.
     He recommended that I add a CD to give me a hotter spark.
     He said that MDS-6 was an ok system and I got one with the car
     (in a box) so I'm going to put it back on. He also said that I had
     the wrong type of plugs and told me the right type of plugs to
     put on it. The distributor that is on the car is a Marelli and he
     recommended removing it and replacing it with a Bosch.
     As for the shift linkage, he has a Vellios 916 side shift kit on his
     915 tranny and recommended that I do the same.

     The car has been in my garage for the last year waiting for
     me to purchase the Vellios transmission kit.

     As for the engine I have the MSD-6, new plugs and the proper
     Bosch Distributor. But not being mechanically inclined, I have
     put off fixing the engine until I get the transmission kit, and do it
     all at once.

     How hard is it to install a MSD? How hard is it to swap the
     Marelli distributor with the Bosch. Should I do these at the same
     time? How hard is it to change the plugs? :-)

     As for conversion costs. I was told that the previous owner spent
     5k for the car. 5k for the engine, and about 10k for the transmission,
     oil tank, sheet metal, 911 suspension (he upgraded to 5 bolt),
     fuch alloys, and everything else, for a total of about 20k.
     He then sold the car to me for 7k.

     Kevin Pickell
     kpickell@ea.com

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 11:26:46 -0800
From: William Oldham <oldham@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: 356C brake calipers


I remember well in rebuilding my 64 cab brakes the difficulty in
removing the pistons.  Eventually I used air and a handpump...
kind of dangerous because when the piston came out (at around
200+psi) it didn't just flop conveniently on the bench.  I chased
the first one across the garage... the unguided missle luckily hit
only wood and cardboard and was undamaged.  Learning from that experience
I contained the others in some rags etc. But they were all perfectly
servicable, and when cleaned up did not bind of course.
Having more stuff , possibly even more smarts,
now I would definitely use hydraulic pressure, not
air.  In particular, a master cylinder with the addition of
only a suitable lever can be made in to a VERY high pressure pump.
That can be connected with steel brake line to the piston.  The other
ports on the mc plugged, and no flex hoses used....   (By the way
a way to plug the other ports is with crimped brake lines).


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 11:38:53 -0800
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Mass flow sensors

>Re: Scott Winder's reply to Rich's question about mass flow sensors
>        Scott: Perhaps the claims of a 19% increase in power apply to
>        changing from a older flapper type of mass flow sensor to a
>        hot wire type (less restriction on air intake)? Or is their
>        mass flow sensor vastly different than some of the newer Bosch
>        designs? Any other comments on this?

Steve,

The Autothority Mass Flow Sensor is a hotwire type. However, this does
not automatically make it produce more power than the stock system.

As I said before, the problem with the 3.2 engine is not the fuel injection
system or how the air is metered. It is the exhaust and muffler system.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 12:08:10 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: RE-Coolant leaks



Triet Le asks: "What major brands of coolant can be used in a Porsche? I
know that Prestone and Zerex cannot, because of phosphates."

Wow, finally. A technical question I can answer!

According to PCNA Technical Bulletin Number 9408, Group 1, dated August 30,
1994: "All full-aluminum water cooled Porsche engines should only use
approved, phosphate free anti-freeze. This anti-freeze may be obtained from
Audi/Volkswagen or Mercedes dealers under the brand names "Autobahn" and
"Mercedes Benz" respectively. Where available, "Zerex Extreme 450" may also
be used."

Larry Wilson

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 15:13:15 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 911: (re) zenith's enrichme

Hi, John.  I'll play back my understanding of the 911T Zenith fuel enrichment
circuit and that will give the real gurus a target to correct.  The purpose
is to richen the mixture during high vacuum medium RPM conditions, like on
decelleration with throttle shut.  Your ignition system (which I lack on my
Vanagon-converted-to-911-six-engine) tells it when to turn on and the big
adjustment screws tell it how much.  Its effect is to lower emissions during
the particular conditions, and I suppose in the long run to extend the life
of your intake valves.  Since the RPM range that turns it on is around 1800,
there shouldn't be any effect on performance.

One response to my question on disabling it said crank the big screws in and
optionally plug the lines into the carbs; also make sure that the diaphragms
are in good shape.  The other just said plug the lines.  I can second the
importance of keeping the diaphragms in good shape (in this as in other parts
of life).  One throat of one of my carbs didn't respond at all to the idle
air correction screw until I had replaced the idle enrichment diaphragm, which
had literally had a hole burned into it.

If I had the electronics, I would run mine.  Let me know what you decide and
why.

B.

Hi George -

You said, "My 83 has manual steering and will NEVER leak!"

Roger, that! I have the same situation. But last year my
steering went from solid as a rock at highway speeds to 
super-light and the steering wheel is now off TDC by about
20 degrees. My mechanic checked it out and did not find any
bushings, tie rods or any thing else wrong - in fact he said
the movement of the steering wheel was transmitted to the 
linkages just fine - no slack at all. He narrowed it down to 
the steering box and called around to try to find one. Most
difficult to come by since almost every other 944 has power
steering and the non-power steering units rarely fail.
Except mine, of course.
Any suggestions?

Herb Myers

worthy of respect.

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 13:16:52 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Tires


Hi all,

Replacement tires for a 968. Well, make sure they are the same speed
rating as the OEM tires. Then make sure they are at least the same 
size AND aspect ratio. 

This means a "v" rating, minimum. Yeah, these can be expensive, especially
if you have the new 17" wheels. They should last longer than 12,000 miles, 
but the REARs on Porsches usually wear first, even on the front-engined
cars. It's all the power the factory gives us.

Seriously, keep inflation correct. The OEM tires can be replaced with
Yoko AVS, Dunlops, Goodyear GS-C, Michelin, etc. Replace ALL four with the 
same make. Differing compounds will cause some handling problems. Toyos 
work good also. Anyway, with AVS tires, I went 34,000 miles, rears wearing 
first.

If you have differing wheel sizes on your Porsche, front and rear (7" front,
8" rear), DO NOT rotate front to rear. This was intended. Just expect the
rears to wear first. If you have the same size (width) front and rear, it is
okay to rotate. This is true for ALL Porsches.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 14:09:27 PST
From: Patrick Buddenbaum <Patrick_Buddenbaum@ccm.fm.intel.com>
Subject: Exhaust and muffler upgrades


Text item: Exhaust and muffler upgrades



  >Steve,
  >The Autothority Mass Flow Sensor is a hotwire type. However, this does
  >not automatically make it produce more power than the stock system.
  >As I said before, the problem with the 3.2 engine is not the fuel
  injection
  >system or how the air is metered. It is the exhaust and muffler system.
  >Scott Winders

  This seems like a good lead-in to a question I've been having regarding
  upgrading the exhaust and muffler system on my '84 911.  Saw and heard a
  new black cabrio at the last two track days in Portland with aftermarket
  headers and muffler.  A wonderful sound, though hard to describe - a bit
  more throaty than stock.  Defintely demanded attention as it rumbled on
  past  :-).  Too bad the guy didn't know what kind they were  :-(    Of
  course, now my interest has peaked and am thus revisiting this upgrade.

  I've seen the ads and done a bit of research regarding new headers/heat
  exchangers and mufflers.  Just wondering what the net has to say
  regarding all the different systems out there?  I'm sure a lot (if not
  everything) depends on how much you're willing to spend, but I'm just
  looking for reasonable suggestions.  Seen the Borlas, Ansa, B&B, etc. -
  any thoughts.  Also, is the recommendation replacing all components at
  once, or piece by piece as the money becomes available?

  I guess other considerations that will need to be addressed include:
  catalytic converter - retain or lose, DME chip - need upgrade for a new
  exhaust?  Any and all thoughts, comments are appreciated...

  Thanks,
  Pat Buddenbaum
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com

  Oil/Filter change with Mobil 1 about 500 miles ago
  New rear tires last week;

Alignment.  The steering wheel is offset about 15 deg. CCW when the car is going 
straight.  This just happened after getting the new rear tires.  Go figure.

adjust them and the effect the adjustments will have.  Lower ride height?  
Stiffer ride?

appreciated.  Please respond directly to me unless you feel your inputs would 
benefit other list members.  Thanks in advance.

Subject:  911 Shocks

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      10/31/94
          SUBJECT:   911 Shocks
 
 
I have only been a member of this list for a few months, so if this topic
has been recently covered then point me to the correct archive.
 
The 1972 911T that I purchased in June will be getting new shocks, and
probably larger torsion bars (21 and 26mm) this winter.  In addition I
will be having the ride height set down, the cars ride height has not been
touched (you could drive a Mini-Cooper under it).
 
I autocross and will be wanting to track the car next year (updated chain
tensionors will be done also).  As far as the torsion bars go, I really do
not know if I want the change in ride, since lowering and replacing the
shocks will stiffen the ride anyway, but since the car will be partly
taken apart to replace the shocks, and I would not like to have to pay for
two ride height adjustments, I may go ahead and install the new torsion
bars.
 
As far as shocks go, I have used Koni on other cars that I have owned.  I
would like an externally adjustable shock, but I am not sure if I really
need it for a 911.  Does Koni make an externally adjustable shock for 1972
911's?   I can get Boge, KYB, Koni, Blistein, I have not seen any sources
for Carrera, does anyone know of a supplier?  My personal order of shock
quality and reputation is:
 
        KYB
        Boge
        Koni
        Blistein
        Carrera
 
What do others think, am I being to name brand conscious.
 
Other questions,
 
Frequently, when I turn on the turn signal, right or left, both turn
signal lights on the Tach flash.  If I turn off the signal, then turn it
back on, it is ok, but sometimes it does flash both lights again, is this
symptoms of a bad relay?
 
What can be done to fix the Tach from bouncing during shifts, I read in
Up-Der-Fixen III, that a capacitor can be added the Tach.  Since the
articles are from the early 70's, I was wondering if there was a more
modern fix.

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 18:53:54 EST5EDT
From: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 Track prep questions

> 
> Hi, Tracy:
> 
> I am preparing to take my stock '89 951 out to Driver's Ed at Summit Point 
> Raceway with the Potomac region of PCA on November 13.  This will be my first
 
> Driver's Ed with the 951.  What preparations should I make on my car before 
> going?  

Looks like you're ready for your first driver's ed.

My advice is to not do anything to change the car before you go to the track
for the first time. Chances are, (if you pay attention to your instructor)
that you will not be reaching the limits of your car in any way.

Your car is already faster than you are capable of driving. So, leave it
alone until you are faster than the car. (BTW, I don't know too many
drivers, even instructors, who are faster than a stock 89 944 Turbo!!!)

As far as the steering wheel being not centered by 15 degrees. That should
be taken care of by wheel alignment. Since your car has an airbag, the
normal solution of removing the steering wheel and repositioning it is not
for the amateur.

Enjoy yourself, but remember, this is an education, not just a chance to
drive fast....

George Beuselinck
Intrepid Driver Ed Instructor
(After 7 years of track events, I'm finally learning how to drive...)
- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ intel.mhv.net
E-Mail: bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 15:15:30 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Starter Wires.


To the fellow with the possible starter problem:

The 944 starter wires are fairly simple:


	            Early (to 1985 1/5)      Late

From Battery                 Red              Black   Large Lug
From Alternator              Black            Black   Large Lug

From Ign. Switch             Red/Black        Red/Black  Small Lug


The starters may have TWO small lugs, inspect to see which you have BEFORE
removal and where the ignition lead goes. If you wire to the relay side, the 
starter will be on as soon as the key is connected. It will stay on, maybe
not engaged, as long as the switch is on in that condition.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 15:18:18 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: First Restoration 


Don't know who first brought this up but...

I've been away, and am just catching up on my e-mail.  So this 
advice might be out of date already.

What you do for your first restoration depends a lot on what 
you already know.  Have you ever taken an engine apart?  Will 
this be the first?  Have you ever done any painting? Bodywork?  
Are you going to do it all yourself, or send pieces out to 
commercial outfits?  Like painting? engine rebuild?  The 
questions go on.

If you've never done any of the above, I'd strongly recommend 
something inexpensive and simple like an older water cooled 
car.  One of the best to start with is an early MG or Triumph, 
say late sixties.  They're simple, basic cars.  No emission 
controls, and the bodies are completely removable from the 
frame.  You can get the entire thing apart, right down to the last 
nut and bolt.  And parts are still available and relatively cheap.  
There are even a half dozen mail-order places that specialize in 
them.

I just redid two 240Z's, a '71 and a '72.  They are also very 
simple, and are available for a lot less than an MG or Triumph.  
You can get one in pretty decent shape for $1000 to maybe 
$1500.  And parts are about as cheap as you can find them, and 
usually available at your local parts shop.  The only slight 
disadvantage is that they are unibody construction (like the 
911) so the body and frame are integral.  Thus, they don't come 
apart quite as easily or as completely as cars with separate 
bodies and frames.  There's a book called "Restoring a Datsun 
240Z" or something close to that, that will be a big help. Also, 
there are a few books about rebuilding 240Z engines.  (If you go 
for the 240Z, let me know and I'll look them up for you.)  Those 
books are one thing that makes the 240Z such an attractive first 
restoration.

The VW is simple too, and air cooled like the Porsche.  
However, I think the VW engine is slightly more complicated 
than a standard water cooled unit for a first time rebuilder.  
Others may disagree, which probably means they're roughly 
the same.

All the advice about reading, reading, reading is very sound.  
Also, as someone said (Bart? Lee?), pick something you like.  
You'll be living with it for quite a while, and you'll want to 
spend that time feeling good about it.  

One more thing.  None of these cars will ever be worth a whole 
lot of money, at least not for a darn long time, but if you redo it 
yourself, it'll be worth millions to you in satisfaction. 

Bob Spindel
(currently restoring a '72 911)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 18:19:07 EST
From: Stefan Reitshamer <sreit@ctp.com>
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades

...
>   This seems like a good lead-in to a question I've been having regarding
>   upgrading the exhaust and muffler system on my '84 911.  Saw and heard a
>   new black cabrio at the last two track days in Portland with aftermarket
>   headers and muffler.  A wonderful sound, though hard to describe - a bit
>   more throaty than stock.  Defintely demanded attention as it rumbled on
>   past  :-).  Too bad the guy didn't know what kind they were  :-(    Of
>   course, now my interest has peaked and am thus revisiting this upgrade.
...

I'm by NO means an expert, and I wouldn't mind having a slightly lower,
"throatier" exhaust sound as well as more power; but I believe that the
factory spent a lot of time tuning the exhaust on my '83 911SC, not just
to meet noise requirements, but also to make the engine's power output smooth
and driveable and match it to the transmission ratios. 

An engine with aftermarket exhaust will have differently shaped pipes which 
I think will affect the power of the engine at different engine speeds, 
making it less than pleasant to drive.

Someone please confirm or shoot down my theory :-).
- --
``````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````
Stefan Reitshamer      sreit@ctp.com       Cambridge Technology Partners, Inc.
                                           304 Vassar St., Cambridge, MA   USA
                                           (617) 374 8371

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 18:22:19 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: re: 951 Track prep questions

Tracy Meyer asks,

| I am preparing to take my stock '89 951 out to Driver's Ed at Summit Point 
| Raceway with the Potomac region of PCA on November 13.  This will be my first 
| Driver's Ed with the 951.  What preparations should I make on my car before 
| going?  The following work has been performed recently:  
....
| Shock adjustment.  The front shocks are adjustable, but I am not sure how to 
| adjust them and the effect the adjustments will have.  Lower ride height?  
| Stiffer ride?

I set mine to full-stiff on the track.  Others like about half-stiff.
Since this is your first event and your speeds will be relatively low
(it won't _feel_ slow!), it probably won't matter much.  They don't
affect ride-height. Set them to however you set them on the street. That
way, the experience you get at speed on the track will transfer to your
street driving. If you get hooked (I mean when :-)) and you start doing
more track events, you can start experimenting with varying shock
stiffness.

I tell all my students to _resist_the_urge_ to modify their cars until
they have enough experience to know what makes sense - for them.  If
you're not judicious, you can spend an infinite amount of money
upgrading your car. What's "essential" for one driver is a luxury for
another.  Remind yourself that a drivers ed. event is educational - not
a race: you can learn a great deal in a stock car. Actually, probably
more than if you're constantly `upgrading' the car: when you come back
to the track and find that you're 2 seconds faster than you were last
time you won't have to wonder whether it's you or the latest gadget you
installed.

My car is basically a stock '87 951. I've put '89 shocks all around, '89
springs and swaybars in front. Lowered it about an 1.5". Cool Carbon
Blue brake pads. Comp/TA R1 tires. Roll bar and 5-point harnesses. 
Autothority 2.5 chip. Note that none of these modifications were done
until after I had half a dozen schools under my belt. I didn't install
the chip until long after I became an instructor.

Re: oil. Common wisdom is to "overfill" your oil by about half a quart
for the 944/951. This supposedly helps prevent starvation of the #2 rod
bearing... 

Enjoy! Driver's Ed events are the very best reason for owning a P-car.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Porsche is a two syllable word.
  '74 914 2L (silver being overtaken by rust) [toy car]
  '87 951    (guards red) [track animal and daily driver]

Steve Tynor		Internet: Steve.Tynor@atlanta.twr.com
Tower Technology	UUCP:     twratl!Steve.Tynor

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 15:48:02 -0800
From: winders@porsche.support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Exhaust and muffler upgrades

>I'm by NO means an expert, and I wouldn't mind having a slightly lower,
>"throatier" exhaust sound as well as more power; but I believe that the
>factory spent a lot of time tuning the exhaust on my '83 911SC, not just
>to meet noise requirements, but also to make the engine's power output smooth
>and driveable and match it to the transmission ratios.
>
>An engine with aftermarket exhaust will have differently shaped pipes which
>I think will affect the power of the engine at different engine speeds,
>making it less than pleasant to drive.
>
>Someone please confirm or shoot down my theory :-).

Stefan,

The factory exhaust system, especially on 911's after model year '74, are not
high performance systems. The factory had to make a lot of compromises to
meet noise and smog requirements.

If your 911SC is a U.S. spec car, you have a single catalytic converter on
the left side of you car. Look at the path the exhaust gases take to get to
the converter. This is horrible for performance. For best power, through out
the RPM range, it is good to have relatively equal length paths for each
exhaust pipe to the accumulator. The factory system does not even come close.

Scott Winders
winders@porsche.support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 19:04:23 -0500
From: Red912@aol.com
Subject: 944 Coolant leak

     My '86 944 was losing coolant fast, it turned out to be the valve that
routes coolant to the heater. It was an easy fix that didn't cost much. It's
located on top of the motor near the firewall.

Rich Lambert
'68 912
'89 Carrera Targa

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 94 16:25:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Track prep questions

>Enjoy yourself, but remember, this is an education, not just a chance to
>drive fast....
>
>George Beuselinck
>Intrepid Driver Ed Instructor
>(After 7 years of track events, I'm finally learning how to drive...)

Very true....

I've been to 3 autox events this year and at the last one, a guy decided to 
slalom down a hill a little too fast for the rainy conditions.  He got loose 
and sloppy and tried to "save" his run by doing everything he could to get 
his car around the cones without hitting them, but ended up nailing a 
concrete post instead.  Personally, I'd rather take a 2 second penalty and 
nail the cone.

Earlier this year I attended a 1-day high performance driving course with the 
local Ferrari club - my boss let me drive his 348!  Before we did any 
"serious" track time, we were supposed to follow the instructor-driven lead 
car single file around the course to see the "line".  A few cars in front of 
me, a guy decided he didn't like the slow 20mph navigation through a set of 
corners and decided to have some fun - he floored it in a corner from his 
slow speed.  Well, his car got sideways, then faced the other way, then it 
launched up a small dirt hill, through a fence, and ended up in a pile of 
dirt, rocks, and wood.

One of the instructors figured he did about $60,000 CDN worth of damage to 
his car - it was actually bent in the middle!!!

So, go out there and have fun LEARNING how to drive, but don't be a goof 
about it.  Be reasonable.  Who would have thought you could total a car going 
single file at 20 mph?  Definitely not the owner of that Ferrari!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
1975 914/6

I called PCNA last year to ask them about Prestone Long-life antifreeze.
It claims to be phosphate-free, and OK for aluminum engines. PCNA said
it was fine, as far as they were concerned. I also asked them about
Sierra, which claims to be "environmentally sound"; they had not tested
it, so were not willing to OK it. Now, this is just a guy on the end of
a phone line (better than a guy on the end of an Internet link, though),
but so far it works for me.
