Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 17:33:23 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Re: 914 engine rebuilding

Stan, thanks for the reply;  of course that generated a few more 
questions...

> > Question of the moment is this:  Does anybody out there have experience
> > with the hydraulic lifter cam set up sold by Performance Products?
> 
> There are three problems: 1) you run into HUGE difficulties if at any point
> you have the car serviced by someone that does not know that there's
> a hydraulic cam in the car and adjusts the valve as per normal on a 
> mechanical lifter car. Bent valves, etc. kind of "Huge Difficulties"...

No problem. Ain't nobody gonna touch it without an education from me..
Actually, I usually end up doing most maintenance on it anyway.

> 2) you have to keep the oil meticulously clean for the hydraulic lifters
> not to gunk up. That means more frequent oil changes, or a conversion to
> a Canton/MECA or System 1 oil filter, or better, both. 3) if you still

Please enlighten me on these oil filters; I've not heard of them.  By 
'more frequent oil changes', you mean more often than 3,000 mi?  How
often would you recommend, for a car that's driven regularly, but not
especially hard?

> decide to do it, that's the wrong kit and in general the wrong place to
> get it. Corollary: your engine builder had better know what he's doing,
> too.
> 
Alas, the engine builder is likely to be me, too.  With some machine 
shop help, of course...  I'd appreciate some more hints...  I'm in 
the process of looking over the archives, but I haven't seen a list of
suppliers yet..

> > BTW, thanks for the comments on the big bore kits - I'd been debating 
> > that, too, but now it looks like stock barrels for me - I want reliability,
> > not ultimate performance out of this car.
> 
> We use big bores on 1.7 and 1.8 engines all the time, and see the 100K
> mile life out of them that we get on factory pistons and cylinders. Anything
> bigger than 96mm is bad news, though, since it takes re-engineering the
> whole top end. I'm not really sure where the "NPR == evil" word of mouth
> got started, but I'd bet it involved engines in which *OTHER* things were done
> to increase performance, that led to an untimely engine death.
> 
Ahh, now we're confusing me again... I had heard the 'NPR == evil' thing,
and took it as gospel - the 'moderate' big bore kits are OK, are they?

> Stan
> 
I appreciate any and all input, fellows:  I've had this thing since Aug '74,
and I've been promising her an overhaul for a while now...  I'm just getting
into the serious investigative stage here.  Unfortunately, I've been out of
the 'scene' for a while, too - wife, kids & all that.  So, I've got a bunch
to learn.

Thanks for the help,
Henry Bibb
'74 914 1.8 looking to rebuild

Date: 31 Oct 94 21:58:17 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 Raised by Koni shocks

David Christiano writes:
>>>I can say the shocks should never by themselves affect the ride height.

The 944 uses MacPherson struts as its front suspension, right?  That means that
the ride height is determined by the location (height) of the lower spring seat
relative to the wheel centerline.  That means that the "shocks" (if by that term
you mean the front struts) *completely control* the ride height.  This holds for
*any* concentric shock/spring situation, not just MacPherson struts.  I know
this from sad experience using Spax shocks on a Lotus Europa.  Spax didn't
bother to put the spring seat as low as they were the factory shocks, so you go
a free but undesired 1" increase in ride height.

If by "shocks" you mean a strut insert, then we're back to Peter Tracy's
gas-pressure theory, or something.  Is the gas pressure really enough to raise
the car by 1-1/2 inches?  If so, that seems like a fairly serious design error
on Koni's part.

Alan Watkins ('86 928)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 23:34:41 -0500 (EST)
From: yml@radixii.com (Yermo M. Lamers)
Subject: Advice sought - '87 911 Carrera Coupe

Porschephiles,

I am new to Porsches and am in the market for a 911. I am currently looking
at a 1987 Carrera Coupe (Black w/ whaletail) at a local dealership.

It is reported to have 80 some thousand miles on it. (The odometer has been 
changed. I have service records up through 89,000.)

I am having a place called Autothority evaluate the car for me. (It's near
Alexandria Virginia.) Can anyone offer any opinions about Autothority? Should
I have the car inspected any place else?

The body and interior of the car seem to be in fine shape (albeit the interior
is an ugly burgundy.) I took it for a test drive and it seems to be okay. The
engine pulls strongly and the suspension seems flawless. It drives practically
the same as later models that I have tried (for twice the price).

There are a few things that concern me about the vehicle:

Reportedly, 5000 miles ago major engine work was performed. I have the repair
receipt but it does not make sense to me. Supposedly the previous owner was on
the retentive side and had the engine completely overhauled at 89,000. The
receipts that I have (more are supposed to be forthcoming) don't add up. How 
many valve guides will $137 buy? How many head gaskets (are there 6?) does
$369 buy? how many rocker arms does $64 buy? There's also a cam shaft listed
for $596? (Is there one shaft for an entire side of the engine? Or is there
one per head? (There are 6 separate heads, no? One per jug?) There's a head
refurbishment listed on the receipt for #6 cylinder head. Is it normal to
just refinish one instead of doing all of them?

Is it "normal" for a Porsche to require major engine work at only 80K miles?
According to the service records there was one case where there were more than
22K miles between 'tune ups'. (I hope that the oil was changed during this time)
There was another where 17K elapsed between maintenance intervals. Could this
have toasted the engine? If the engine were in bad shape how would one determine
this?

The dealership has agreed to fix any items that are found to be wrong with it. 
We shall see  to what degree they actually mean it.
I am having it checked out by (what was told to me to be) a professional outfit 
and I am posting my concerns to this list. Is there anything else that I should
do or check before seriously considering the car? The asking price is $23,900
and from the sound of things they would probably accept 22,500.

I will get more information on the engine work that was performed tomorrow.

Any replies, suggestions or advice would be greatly appreciated. I am 
treading in unfamiliar territory . . .

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
Yermo Lamers                              Radix II, Inc.   
yml@radixii.coml                          Oxon Hill Md, USA
Senior Systems Programmer                 Standard Disclaimers Apply

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 22:50:39 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Brake Caliper Fun

>P.S. Do it away from things you don't want to get brake fluid on.  Also, 
>this is a good use for the remainder of the container you opened when >you
changed fluid in the spring.

This post, for some silly reason, reminded me of a time I agreed to help a
friend of mine repack some front wheel bearings.  While we
had the brake calipers off the vehicle, we decided to replace the brake
pads.  Of course the old pads came out easily, but I was having a heck
of a time getting one of the pistons to retract to get the new pads in.  I
finally became really annoyed and employed a set of *very* large channel
locks in an attempt to push the piston back in (the automotive victim in this
story was a 4WD Toyota - no pcars were injured).  For better or for worse, my
friend and I had consumed a few beers that day and I must say that generally
I have very good bladder control.  Having said that I now had the sensation
that I had just relieved myself right there in his driveway.  Luckily, it was
not my body fluids staining my
shorts, but a high pressure blast of brake fluid that hit me right in the
crotch as the bleed screw suddenly decided to rid itself of some crud.

Needless to say, no one fell for the "brake fluid" story as I walked around
the rest of the afternoon with a *big* stain in my pants.

Does this kinda stuff only happen to me?

Mike

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 23:09:44 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Changing struts/Air tools

Steve,
I'd love to know if those ball joints failed spontaneously. I've had 3 ball
joints go south and all of them let me know with plenty of warning.
Obviously this is a part you don't want failing at speed. If you are lucky
the only thing that will happen will be considerable body damage from the
flopping tire assembly. If unlucky......
Anyway when you check the joints there should be virtually NO play in any
direction. A clunking noise when turning or when hitting a bump is a real
strong signal to pull over and investigate.
It would be interesting if anyone else has had this kind of problem

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
